description:
Pretty good spot for some beers and food. We were a group of three and were seated after a bit of a wait. I think you can make a reservation in advance as it gets packed during the weekend. 

To snack on we got the fries and the brussel sprouts which were really good and had a nice sauce. The fries were also tasty, thing and crispy and a lot of them too. 

Beers we got two Weiss and a more bitter one. The two Weiss were the highlights for sure.
author: Valeria S.

description:
Came here Tuesday 10/09/18 about 7-ish. 

ORDERED:
- Brussel sprouts
- Mussels
- Club Soda
- Water

PROS:
- mussels were delicious with capers. You could pretty much order extra bread to dunk in the delicious caper lemon broth. 
- I liked the club soda brand
- staff is really nice and chill
- menu had some really delicious sounding options available 
- decor/design is cozy inside 
- our server moved us to a bigger table when it came available

CONS: 
- because we were a party of 2 we couldn't sit in a booth and had to sit at this small table that was the size of notebook paper. 
- even though we were moved to a bigger table it was still a nuisance to pick everything up and move across the restaurant. This was why I knocked off 1 star
- wish they had more options for healthy eating. There were only 2 salads and tomato bisque for soup. 
- the Brussels sprouts were way too sugary sweet.
author: Krystal A.

description:
It can be a bit crowded to come here for just for drinks / beer. Beer selection is solid, but the bar area isn't that large so occasionally we'll pop in to see if there is space to sit and we'll head elsewhere if not. 

I have come here for food once and I enjoyed the burger.
author: Sophia L.

description: Beer and Fried Chicken Sandwich. Name a more iconic icon. I can't. I remember a co-worker recommended this place just for the beer selection (and it was a good list of beers from the menu). I finally decided to check it out for lunch. I wanted a Death & Taxes but they didn't have it on tap but the Smoked Black Lager that I ordered upon a recommendation was great. Fried Chicken Sandwich came with with a crispy bun. Loved the big piece of juicy chicken. And what's a sandwich without fries which were crispy and good. I'll be back just to try a few of the beers they have on the menu.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
Came here for dinner. Ordered the Brussels sprout salad, the Mac and cheese, and the lamb burger.
I was super excited for the Mac n cheese cuz it's one of my favorite foods but it was bit underwhelming. Tasted more like pasta with butter than Mac n cheese. But the LAMB BURGER tho. Freakin amazing. I'm not a burger person but this was very juicy and very flavorful! Not usually something I would order but please try this if you're ever at monks kettle!! The Brussels sprout salad was also really good but the most memorable was, did I mention this dish already? the LAMB BURGER
author: Annie L.

description:
Big fan of this place! It has a cozy and inviting atmosphere with really cool and rustic decor and furniture. The service is very friendly and efficient, and the food is on point. I recommend adding yourself the Yelp waitlist to avoid waiting for too long. 
Between my bf and I, we shared a bottle of Cabernet Franc, a pretzel, pickle jar, mussels, and tamales. Perfect amount.

Pickle jar: love the assortment of veggies! There were some beets, bell peppers, cauliflower, asparagus, cucumbers, onions... very vinegary! (5/5)

Pretzel: love! Fluffy, not greasy. Some places put too much butter in their pretzels, but this place doesn't. It comes with whole grain mustard-- delicious! (5/5)

Mussels: Generous portion. Although a few of the mussels had closed shells (don't ever eat them if you didn't know that, haha), it was a great dish overall. It comes with only a little bit of broth, which is extremely salty. It's definitely not a broth you would want to slurp with a spoon. The grilled bread that comes with it is fluffy and delicious, and definitely can be used to mop up a bit of the broth. (4.5/5)

Tamales: my bf really enjoyed this and polished this dish off. It comes with a generous portion of avocado. (5/5)

I'll definitely be back!
author: Christina W.

description:
If you're coming here to eat, then you can get a table.  Otherwise, expect to sit/stand at the bar.  It's a little off-putting, but that's the format here.  But expect that when you come here if you're thinking this is more of a bar.

Anyways, this place has a solid list of beers.  A decent number of on tap beers and a large selection of bottled stuff.  They also have some wines as well.  The Monk's Kettle can get pretty noisy inside, but the table booths are nice.  They serve a good variety of beers too if you're looking for Kolsch, saisons, or darker beers too.  

For the food, I had the lamb burger and the fried oyster.  Both were great.  The lamb burger came with some arugula and cheese.  The cheese wasn't too overpowering over the lamb burger.  It was also a great juicy burger too.  I really enjoyed their fried oyster as well (I usually don't care for these, but the pictures made it look good).  It was fried where the outside was crispy, but the inside was still kind of raw, very tasty.  

Overall, great food and beers.  Definitely one of the better bars in the Mission District if you're looking for a pretty chill bar.
author: Bryson L.

description:
I finally made it to Monk's Kettle!

Awesome beer spot on 16th and Mission, a hop and a skip from BART. It was surprisingly not busy for a Saturday at 6pm. They have a very impressive beer selection, Pliny the Elder on tap y'all! They also have a great selection of HenHouse, Alvarado Street, and other Bay Area breweries. We only ordered the fries and Brussel sprouts but they were good for an app. Peeking over other tables, the Mac and cheese looked so tasty! I'll definitely be back for more beer and some food!
author: Marcie A.

description:
Too expensive

Weird wait staff


Good day at Solano Avenue stroll
author: Foodlover B.

description: They have a really good selection of beers and friendly bartenders. I went there by myself and enjoyed the ambiance. I ordered a burger and fries. The burger was really good but the fries were soggy and bland hence the 4 stars.
author: Shaurav G.

description:
Last Saturday, Gayle and I decided that we needed to get out of the house and have a fun field trip.  She suggested that we pick a BART station and wander off from there.  Rockridge and Glen Park were initially considered and rejected.  I then suggested that Gayle contact her nephew (Ben) to see if he and his Wife (Fathima) wanted to meet in the Mission (where they lived) for Lunch. And before you could say "16th and Mission" it was a 12 Noon date at The Monk's Kettle. 

The 4 of us had a great time.  We sat outside on a rare warm and sunny day and chatted away over a nice selection of craft beers (draft this time),  delicious appetizers of Caramelized brussels sprouts (with honey, balsamic red onion reduction, lemon) and Pretzel knots (with beer cheese fondue and house mustard).  We continued on with 2 Monk's Burgers (with fries to share), 1 Lamb Burger, and a Tuna Nicoise Salad Sandwich.  All were excellent.  Service was friendly, unobtrusive, and knowledgeable concerning food options and beer selection.  It was also fun to interact with the dog at the next table and talk about life in the city and upcoming family activities. 

After our goodbye hugs, Ben and Fatz headed home, while Gayle and I needed to work off a very satisfying and filling lunch. After a stop for ice cream at Bi-Rite Creamery, we walked to Castro Street, turned left, went up and over to 24th Street, strolled through Noe Valley, and returned to the 24th and Mission BART station.  We'll definitely do something like this again, and maybe with a walking tour thrown in.  This time around, the Monk's Kettle was the fuel for our exploratory fire.
author: Eric B.

description: I'd give it zero if I could. Came in on a slow Monday night for some beers with family from out of town. One server was particularly rude. First he wouldn't let us sit at an empty table at an empty restaurant. That should have been a red flag. We spent $70 on beers and tipped accordingly. You'd think an empty establishment would be happy to have some business on a slow Monday night but for whatever reason this particular server kept on being rude to us. The final straw for me was when he bumped into me while I was standing at the bar, which he made us stand at because he wouldn't let us sit at a table, and had the nerve to tell me I was in his his way. He then disappeared downstairs like a coward. I'm never coming back and I'm upset that we even spent money at this place.
author: I D.

description:
This place is pretty small, but worth checking out. Beer lovers will feel right at home. There is a large menu of various beers available. I tried a ginger flavored cider from the menu and thought it was both refreshing and appropriately priced. 

To eat, I ordered a side of their tomato bisque and the fried chicken sandwich. The tomato bisque had a great consistency and flavor. This was one of the better tomato bisque 's I've tried. I would rate the fried chicken sandwich a 8/10. The salty and sweet toppings that came on top of the fried chicken sandwich tasted great. The breading around the chicken tasted a little bland to me, but the toppings helped enhance the overall sandwich.  I only had a bite of my dining partners lamb burger, but I loved the well seasoned meat and toppings.
author: Yvonne I.

description:
So, I had never been to a gastropub and was dying to try one on my last trip to SF. It also happened to be my anniversary, so off we went to The Monk's Kettle! 

Honestly what initially sold me was the amount of beer they had (28 on tap, 150 bottled). I ended up choosing the Allagash White which was really refreshing and tasty. 

The place itself is super small, and the kitchen is even tinier. The food was really good and arrived in a timely manner. I ordered the steak and vegetables ( I can't remember what the name of the dish was on the menu). The steak melted in my mouth, it was so tender.

Seating is limited, and they have a host at the door with an ipad taking down names. Luckily, we didn't have to wait long at all (thanks yelp!) but people after us were on a pretty long wait. It's in a busy part of town as well, so if bar hopping is something you want to do after dinner, you're in the perfect spot to do so.
author: Brittany F.

description:
An astonishing number of beers to on tap and bottled, and good bar food. What's not to love?

Fantastic place to try a few unique beers from all over world if you don't have time to go to a local brewery.
author: Lily H.

description: Pretty good spot for some beers and food. Beer is on the more expensive side at $9 but have a ton of variety. Nicely lit and music is loud enough without being too loud. Definitely recommend!
author: Shimoli S.

description:
The Monk's Kettle is a great spot especially if you are a beer lover. They have an amazing beer selection and the atmosphere is really chill. Based on what style of beer you order they will serve it in the appropriate glassware at the optimal temperature. The selection of draft beers is really nice and they also offer a really great selection of bottled beers as well. 

I didn't eat there but everything I saw on other people's tables looked really good. The staff was very attentive even though we just sat at the bar and came to check on us to make sure we weren't getting parched from lack of beers. The place can get crowded pretty quickly especially on the weekends and it is not huge, so just keep that in mind.
author: Stephanie A.

description:
Been here before but this time I actually tried their food.  One of the better chicken sandwiches I've had in a while, this is saying a lot since I think this sando is so overplayed.  The lamb burger was fine but nothing too memorable.   I wasn't a fan of the cornmeal fried oysters.   The sauces definitely sabed that dish. The service was decent.

Food 4
Service 3.5
Overall 4
author: Patrick C.

description: The two of us walked in on a Saturday evening and were able to grab seats at the bar for dinner.  The beer list was great, and the service was fast and friendly.  For food, I had the pretzel, which was very good, and the chicken sandwich, which was just ok.  We'll definitely be back to try more of the beer selection.
author: Simon L.

description: The monks kettle is a solid spot - consistently good gastropub (fancy bar food) food and excellent beer selection. Beers come in appropriate glasses and are a good mix of known and unknown/ uncommon beers. Not cheap but for sf I woulda call it expensive
author: David G.

description:
As someone who frequents Mission bars, this is one of the best, if not the best... This is the place to be especially if you love Beer and like to grab a booth and chill with friends. They have got a great collection. I haven`t really had a full meal here but only small eats and they are really good. This place is really popular and it could be a drag getting a table especially on a Friday night. So, either make a reservation or keep your fingers crossed :)

Would highly recommend this place if you`re in the Mission !!!
author: Pranav B.

description: Showed up an hour and a half before closing. We asked to sit next to a window that was closed (it was cold) and we wanted a bigger table. We were told "sorry, that's our biggest table ". We were sat at a small table, given a menu with unappealing food, and were so turned off by the service, temperature, and menu items - we just ended up walking out across the street to Pakwan, where we had some amazing late night eats. Pass.
author: Devin M.

description:
Loved this spot! Was looking for a chill bar with food and found the perfect place. The monk kettle is clean, modern, and cozy. Seating is a bit cramped, and you can very clearly hear the groups around you speaking. But it's still a nice vibe and good atmosphere. 

Service was friendly and efficient. They got us seated right away on a Friday night even though it was packed. 

Tons of beers on draft! I tried Moonlight Brewing Co. and loved it. The food came out quickly too and was piping hot. The lamb burger was tasty, but the bun was cold (sort of like it had been refrigerated and reheated) and the fries were hard and not very flavorful. The Mac n cheese was my favorite dish of the night. I added in the lobster for $5 and do not regret it. The cheese sauce was light and creamy, not thick or gooey like other places, so I really enjoyed it and thought it went well with the beer. Got a side of brussel sprouts, and was surprised by how soft and flavorful they were. I definitely choose those over the fries!

Overall, this is a great little spot in the Mission and if you love beer, this is a must try.
author: Sara S.

description:
pro tip: get the brussel sprouts and the mac and cheese and eat them together. HEAVEN.

Solid beer list as well, of course. And very reasonable prices for the quality.
author: Colleen R.

description:
This was my first visit to this well-regarded Mission District craft-beer spot; it won't be my last.  A smallish storefront, with an L-shaped bar, booths, and (presumably only in good weather) outside tables.  Friendly and informative bartender, and one guy who appeared to be the owner or manager.  I didn't try their food service, but it appears fairly ambitious for a place of this sort, including daily off-menu specials and a weekend brunch.  Printed beer list, featuring 29 drafts at $4.50-$11.75; over 100 bottles and cans, sorted by style, at $6.50-$63.00 (not a typo!); and ten or so vintage bottles at $12.00-$56.00.  Also functions as a bottle shop, with bottles and cans to go 25% off the menu price. Brand-specific logo glassware for many but not all drafts.  Menu includes a useful glossary of beer terms. 

I tried three brews:

- Bruery Terreux Frederick H. Berliner Weisse. 4.4% ABV.   6-oz. tulip, $6.50.  Deep clear gold, fast-fading 2-finger head.  Very tart, fairly fizzy; a good example of a style which isn't one of my favorites.  (When it's available, I usually tone down Berliner Weisse tartness with Himbeersaft (raspberry syrup) or Waldmeister (woodruff).  

- Cellarmaker Quadruple Dobis Quadruple IPA.  12.8%, 106 IBU.  $7.50 for an 8-oz. wine glass.  Near-clear orange-gold, halo and patches head.  Noble hop and peach nose.  Taste us a rich sweet malt balanced against assertive hop bitterness; the alcohol rises to a flavor note.

-  Ale Smith Decadence Winter Wheat Wine (2014).  10%.  6-oz., $7.75.  Poured from an already-opened bottle; the bartender tasted it, found it flat, discarded it, and opened a new one.  (Mixed feelings on my part as I watched the remnants of the old bottle go down the drain--"sober children in China," and all that.)  A beautiful clear amber, light head, a bit of sediment.  Sweet malt and pear nose.  Deep sweet malt taste, with candi sugar obvious among the fermentables; wheat presence not apparent.  Moderate hoppiness in the finish.  Delicious and potentially sneaky.

One TV, muted, tuned to sports programming.  Background music.  Clean gender-neutral restroom.

Street parking, theoretically; I believe the last person actually to find an open space in the Mission was Junipero Serra.  A block and a half (disregarding a few minor side streets) from the 16th-Mission BART station.  On the 22-Fillmore bus line, which, for pub crawlers, provides a convenient 5-10 minute connection to Toronado at Haight and Fillmore.
author: Alan F.

description: Since the Owner contacted us, I am giving Monk's at least a four star rating until we get a chance to try here again.  I am excited to try the burger! With a great beer selection, nice staff, and good food you can't miss.
author: Mike G.

description:
They have a long list of craft beers and quite the list of food.

The food is pretty solid but I'm just not impressed. Server seemed rushed and angry but offered to take one of the cheeses off the bill of our charcuterie board.

Highly recommend using Lyft or Uber since Monk's Kettle is located in Mission
author: Mabel Y.

description:
Dinner review. 

Fries (bone marrow aioli) 
Pretzel knot (gouda Havarti fondue) - 4/5 
Beer cheddar bratwurst chowder - 3/5
Mac and cheese (bacon) - 4/5
Monks burger (brisket/chuck + bacon) - 5/5

Beer selection+++ (4 full pages)

Overall, "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description: It was our first visit and went there on a July Sunday afternoon. We sat at the bar and all of the wait staff was super friendly. I had the black bean quinoa burger and husband had the Monk's burger. We both got the caramelized Brussels sprouts and they were amazing! Beer is good too! We would definitely go back!
author: Ann F.

description:
Wonderful beer selection ranging across the spectrum.

Delicious mac n' cheese that was the perfect balance between soupy cheese and al dente pasta with crunchy bread crumbs.

Went with the burger, medium-rare (because this is the only temperature option :P), which came out juicy and full of flavor.
author: Tucker N.

description:
Faced with the classic "Where do you want to eat? You pick. I'll eat wherever you want to eat." dilemma, my boyfriend and I decided to walk down the street to The Monk's Kettle after seeing a picture of their mac and cheese online.

When we first walked in, it looked like it was packed! Luckily they had a few tables open for dinner, and we were seated right away. We got the mac and cheese with lobster and jalapeno, the shishito peppers, and pappardelle pasta. Our eyes were definitely too big for our stomachs, but everything was so delicious we finished anyways! Highly recommend, and would come again!
author: Alice L.

description:
I've been impressed with the Monk's Kettle ever since my first visit years ago, and now that I've gotten reacquainted with it recently, I am still a fan!  There are several places in San Francisco that are of the gastropub style, but I think this restaurant does a great job of providing both an excellent beer selection and solid food items.  

If you like beer, I don't think you will be disappointed with the wide selection of bottled and draft beers available.  You can definitely splurge here if you are in the mood and want to pay top dollar for your suds, but I've enjoyed their more affordable draft options; I've always felt that I was getting quality beer for what I was paying without feeling like my wallet is going through a wallop.

While I think beer is their primary focus, the Monk's Kettle also pays sufficient attention to food.  During a recent visit, I tried their B.L.T. special and thought it was top-notch; the aioli and bacon melded well together and the fries were excellent.  I will definitely be back again!
author: Keith H.

description: Went here for a mini reunion with friends and really enjoyed the vibe. Not too crowded for a given Friday night, great for hangouts,  and !
author: Moorissa T.

description: Yesterday: cool place. Service is good food is ok. Next time I'll try their Mac and cheese. They do have a large selection of beers. Overall 4 star.
author: Christy V.

description:
Unreal beer selection. The variety as well as the quality. There isn't a bad beer on the entire list. 

Food is superb. The chicken w/ chimmichuri. Pappardelle. Charcuterie (Lonza. Smoked branzino pate.). 

A lot of people just moved here don't know this restaurant was a pioneer and trailblazer in the mission. It started a wave years ago that's been building ever since.
author: Matt C.

description: Monk's Kettle is a great spot to take some friends for a fun, casual, drink on a weekend. Service is great, the staff is friendly, and the space is small and bustling with a constant stream of people. Unfortunately, I wouldn't recommend the food. I ordered the steak, which I understand may not be the best choice for a food selection for a bar, but when you're not eating bread or cheese, there weren't many other options on the menu. I asked for the steak to be cooked medium, and it was well done with the meat thoroughly browned all the way through. I'm a little surprised it even came out being that they pre-slice the meat for you, so it would have been instantly obvious that it wasn't cooked properly. Anyway, besides the food, I would definitely go back for a drink. It's a casual fun spot that has a great selection of beers.
author: Sally Y.

description: Really enjoy this dark cozy neighborhood joint. Lots of beer selection and decent food quality. Fills up fast but usually not too long of a wait.
author: TJ S.

description:
Got the duck leg confit for an almost-midnight snack.

Duck leg was very salty (but seems like this is the style these days), meat on it was firm but easy to chew apart and not dry. Skin was slightly crispy without too much fat underneath. Definitely something I would eat again. Bean and sausage stew it came in was also tasty but very salty. Would have liked some more veggies or just something to balance out the saltiness but the brussel sprouts that accompanied it were garnish only. Definitely had to drink something after.

3.5 stars for food, 2.75 stars for quantity. 3 stars for the price-- definitely on the more expensive side of things, even given SF pricing. I was very impressed that the delivery arrived piping hot.

I recognize that this is food is meant to accompany beer though, so perhaps best to take this salad lover's review with a grain of salt (ironic).
author: Nicole H.

description:
Food: pretzel with fondue cheese and fancy mustard 1/$6, 2/$11. It was delicious! I suggest getting 2
Pretzels, they are somewhat small. The pretzels are light and fluffy, which is the only food that comes in premise from a bakery. 

Drinks: the wine selection is minimal and I was kind of disappointed. I did not order anything. Hubs ordered an IPA and said it was delicious. 

Ambience: small, quaint and a local spot. 

Staff: fast and friendly. 

Overall Experience: quick stop since I did not drink
author: Nicole G.

description:
It's okay. Good beer selection. They also have wines.

I didn't find the servers here helpful.  They give off a snobbish vibe if you ask questions regarding their drinks and the food.  They will answer your questions but not enthusiastically, it's more like "ugh, why are you asking me that" kind of attitude. 

Place is expensive and space is tiny.  It's an ok place to me. Not impressed.
author: Sarah L.

description:
If you're looking for a late night dinner spot before a night cap this is the spot. Cozy and dim, but still inviting and friendly at the same time. Beers galore on tap. No liquor.

We came around 11PM hoping they were still serving the full menu, and they were! We got the last open table, ordered the only bottle of champagne on the menu (pretty good) and grubbed.

We tried the pretzel knot, charcuterie w/ goat cheese and beef and the MUSHROOM RISOTTO to share. Yes, it deserves all caps. Rich, creamy and salty, oh so salty but I have zero complaints. Hands down I would come here alone just to eat that in the corner and leave. 

I've said enough. Hope to be back!
author: Heather H.

description: In town from a fly over state, and was lured to Monk's Kettle by the promise of Pliny the Elder on tap. Found it via Untappd, another of my favorite apps. They Yelp reviews were great so I was excited to visit, and as usual, was not disappointed at all! The menu looked so good decided to have a snack. Had a great salad, and also ordered their daily off-menu special and it was delicious. What a great gastropub. Incredible, well-curated beer selection. Both on tap & in the bottle. Good ambiance. If I lived in the neighborhood I would be at this place 3 times a week.
author: Lucas E.

description:
Monk's Kettle is a nice little bar with somewhat vibrant atmosphere but the food isn't as good as reviews say here.

I've been here couple of times, both of them were not as good food-wise as I expected. In fact, the most recent meal was one of the worst I had in a long time.

The meal featured a piece of "close to salmon"  fish, as it was described by the waiter. The fish filet was placed upside down on the bed of uncut bitter lettuce leaves, some if which were as big as my face. 

The filet wasn't cooked properly, the fillet got an overcook split in the middle, so the presentation had to hide this oversight.

The peculiar salad also had half circles of persimmons, cubes of beets, and whole walnuts. Nether I could taste these ingredients together nor it looked nice or cohesive. 

I asked the waiter about the salad and just to cut it a bit better. After that, I was able to eat more than one ingredient, so it got apparent that the bitter taste of greens and the dressing doesn't compliment the fish at all, but overpowers it.

The vegetarian burger with fries was nicely done, my husband had a nice dinner for sure. Again, how hard is it to make a nice burger?

Long story short, basic traditional taste pallet is the strongest at this place, as far a little more complex flavors are out of Monk Kettle's league.
author: Julia G.

description: Such a great little gem in the Mission! HUGE selection of beers and really delicious food (try the french fries, pretzel twists, and pickle jar). Highly recommend the cask beer (check to see if it is still available). They also have a gluten-removed beer on the menu and great wines if you are gluten-free. Great service and great vibe inside. FYI they start carding around 5-6 pm so make sure you have your ID with you.
author: Sarah N.

description: We had delicious beer from extensive selection, Brussel sprouts, fries and pretzels with cheese sauce and mustard for appetizers and juicy burgers (very well flavored) for mains. The wait staff was patient with our non-English speaking guests. I will return!
author: Suzanne S.

description:
Brunch was awesome. Great beer selection. I was impressed that each beer style was served in the appropriate glassware.

Mac n cheese was incredible and the fried chicken sandwich was comforting
author: Austin J.

description:
If you're a beer nerd and a sour beer lover, then Monk's Kettle is unmissable. An unbelievably long list of craft beers by the bottle and on draft make this place one of the better beer bars in San Francisco. What's even cooler is that they cellar certain beers and release them many years later (like wine), and offer them to their patrons. I mean, that's dedication.  

I happen to be a huge sour beer fan and it just so happens that The Monk's Kettle is serving up some summertime session sours. I stopped by last Saturday as I hadn't been in a while and when the sun is out, sour beers taste amazing! It's normally pretty packed on the weekends but, we were able to find a couple spots at the bar after being greeted by a really nice doorman. 

We ordered a couple different sours on draft from Russian River Brewing Company (Santa Rosa, CA). They were both aged in wine barrels, one from a Chardonnay and the other Pinot Noir. Did I mention they were amazing?! One thing I love about sour beers is how they are respected and treated. Monk's Kettle serves all of their beer in wine glasses so you can get the full effect of the beer's quality. Props to that. 

I've always wanted to eat here as the food coming out of the kitchen looks amazing. Guess I'll be back soon for some more sour beer and kitchen fare. :)
author: Benjamin F.

description: Lobster Mac n cheese, garden burger and awesome friendly employees. One of my favorite places to chill out with a beer in the mission.
author: Leah M.

description: Entries are tiny. Ordered steak with potatoes. Literally came out with 4 thin slices of stead and 4 finger potatoes (of which the waitress dropped one) costed almost $30. Went across the street to Picaro to finished dinner.
author: Diane Z.

description: I've been here once very late in the night before closing in a Saturday. It was pretty empty so the waiter was super attentive to us. The beer menu is massive and they go through and recommend what you'd like based on your taste. It's a worthwhile visit if you're a beer lover.
author: Kara J.

description: This place is dang good. The whole team from the door man to the bus crew are awesome, friendly people. And to the kitchen team, thank you! Everything we ordered was a 10! Will be back again soon.
author: Kyle D.

description: This is such a hidden gem or feels like it anyways. We love this bar because they served fresh draft Pliny. Yes, Pliny! I was amazed! We went midday and the ambiance is really chill. Definitely a place to go out for drinks with friends or even a date night.
author: Ann A.

description: Chanced upon this place when we were hanging around Mission. Amazing beer menu, both bottles and draft. Close to a hundred beer from all across the world. I tried a Scottish dark ale that was delicious. And if their burger is anything to go by, all the food will be fantastic. Very cool pub altogether.
author: Rudrajit D.

description: Really great experience here last night. The starters are really good - I would recommend the tomato bisque and the cheese plate. For your main course, get the Monk's burger. The service, ambiance and number of beers on tap are all huge bonuses.
author: James M.

description:
A place for the beer lover. This place has a huge selection of beer that does not disappoint any type of beer drinker. A hot place in the Mission as there is a pretty huge wait for a table inside on a weekday for an early dinner. Clearly they know what they're doing.

We started with some meat and cheese which was honestly a bit of a let down. My expectations may be too high, but was not all that impressed with the meats or cheeses. I did very much like their apricot chutney and their mustard though.

I very much like their burger. Big and tasty. Meat cooked perfectly to rare/medium rare with huge flavor. Delicious caramelized onions to bring the cheese and greens together. Served next to a large bed of fries which were standard.

The flank steak. This was okay. The SAUCE was magical. A mushroom cream sauce with HUGE flavor. Unfortunately, the steak was too chewy. Lots of tendons and what not, a bit difficult to eat. Maybe should've ordered it a little less rare.

In the end, the beer menu here is stellar and the vibe is just what you would expect. A large bar with a ton of beers on draft. Good food, good beer. That's all I ever really need in life.
author: Bryant C.

description: The staff was extremely nice and accommodating to our family (kids age 9-11). I'm from the midwest and was looking for Pliny the Elder. They had it and were very happy to help us. I would go here again and again.
author: John D.

description:
Great beer selection but warning: the prices are completely exorbitant. Maybe these folks enjoy ripping off their clientele, but I cannot justify returning to this establishment. 

$10 for a Temescal Brewing IPA (brewed in OAKLAND several miles away). This beer costs $6 at the brewery. 

Here's the kicker:
$10 for Cellarmaker Brewing beer (brewed a mere 1.4 miles away!!) you could walk over there in 15 minutes and save yourself $3. 

If that's not bad enough they also charge an additional TAX on the beers as well. So two LOCAL beers comes to around $23 plus tip. Sorry, but $10 for a LOCAL beer should include tax. 

This is just pure price inflation with no justification to do so. The ambience is okay but not enough to justify a 30% increase versus other Bay Area beer bars. My advice: your money is better spent elsewhere.
author: Rusty S.

description:
Encyclopedic beer selection - literally - paired expertly with a well-executed menu. Even though the food offerings change from time to time, you can't go wrong with a selection of smaller plates to share - whether fried oysters, croquettes, or poutine - or some larger, more substantive entrees like a savory risotto. 

For beer lovers, the best part is how they take beer - and food pairings - seriously. And if you're in an adventurous mood and want to try different beers on your own, there's a gigantic set of offerings to choose from. Service is knowledgeable and authentic, although this place is so popular, given its small footprint, that waits can be pretty intense. Word to the wise: get there early.
author: Vincent L.

description: Great beer! One of the bartenders even called the brewer to find out If the beer I was interested in contained something I'm allergic to. Talk about customer service!
author: Daniel W.

description:
Wow - seriously, a ton of draft beers! This place is always packed in the evenings but came on a Sunday afternoon and was able to snag a table in the back. 

Food was pretty good:
- Hand cut fries - $8, a bit expensive - but we were hungry
- Mixed greens salad with chicken - not chicken breasts, but liked the balsamic-like dressing and the almonds
- Pretzel knot - tasty home-made pretzel, though more like crunchy oily bread than super pretzel-like. Tasty for being what it is though!

Service was super friendly, food came out quickly.
author: Kristie C.

description:
Slightly nicer, typical SF bar. I had some friend visiting and one of them wanted to try Pliney the Elder. This was closet bar to us that had it on tap. It was not what I expected based on the name, but it had dinning as well as a full bar. There was also a chalkboard that you could draw on that was a nice touch. 

Overall: I good bar with decent prices.
author: Amanda S.

description: Whenever I'm in town visiting my family my mom always wants to go to Monk's Kettle. We solely go for the PENN COVE MUSSELS served with grilled levain, the white wine sauce is bomb. We've tried a few other dishes and they were pretty good as well: MONK'S BURGER -  house ground NY strip, brisket and chuck, onion jam, gruyere, and aioli and the SCHMALTZ FRIED SPICY CHICKEN SANDWICH which is served with a citrus slaw, dill pickles, and chipotle aioli. All the dishes are decent but nothing keeps me coming back like the mussels do. It's also a great spot to grab beers, they have a nice selection of craft brews on draft. This is one of the restaurants I like to keep in my back pocket, our go-to whenever I'm back since the wait for lunch is usually short, service is great, and the food hits the spot!
author: Elaine N.

description:
Food is always good! Even if you take it to go. The fried chicken sandwich is da bomb! (I don't eat chicken and I break my own rule for this one)

It's the mission so parking is a challenge, but it's close to 16th & Mission BART or take Lyft.

It's hard to get a table on busy nights.... because it's delicious.

I'm not a beer person (like everyone else in the joint)... but the wine list is decent. Only challenge is no cocktails.
author: Deedee C.

description:
Gotta say Monk's kettle, the single piece of lobster on the Mac and Cheese that we ordered via Trycaviar delivery doesn't seem like it should add $5.

Other than that the fries with the chicken sandwich were great.
author: Arshad T.

description:
Although the space is a little tight, they have a mind-boggling number of beers on tap (including the relatively rare Pliny the Elder) and in bottles. The food is excellent - we sampled the pretzel with fondue and mustard (which was so good we ordered a second one), some mac and cheese, and a fried chicken sandwich. All of it was very good, and the nicely crispy fries were utterly addictive. After all that food I was full, and as much as I had hoped to try another beer from the extensive menu, there just wasn't space in my stomach.

People complain about the prices but these are just normal San Francisco prices, so get used to it. A place like this is worth the money anyway.
author: Marco C.

description:
My friends and I were looking for a good gastropub and I remembered bookmarking this place for quite some time. We called in advance to check if their kitchen was still available since majority of us were hungry. Their kitchen is open all night until closing. Since The Monk's Kettle is located in the Mission area of Dolores Park, parking is terribly hard to find. After circling around for awhile, we finally found one 5 blocks away. I'd suggest you take Uber here. Anyways upon entering, you get your ID checked at the door. The waitress brought us to our seat in the back and I was surprised but happy that it wasn't one of those overcrowded bars. Our waitress was really nice and came to check on us several times. 

We shared the pretzel knots, Monk's burger with fries, Mac and cheese with bacon, kale salad and a steak dish with potato confit. Everything was delicious and there were no complaints. 

My girlfriend and I both agreed the Mac and cheese was definitely our favorite thing on the table. It's cheesy, creamy and a really nice touch with the added bacon. 

The burger was juicy and the fries were fried to a perfect crisp. 

The infamous pretzel knots were great as well-we ordered these (2 for $11) because a lot of Yelpers advised us to and they were pretty good. It came with two dipping sauces: one with the same cheese as the Mac and cheese and the other was a mustard dip. 

The kale salad with added chicken was a nice variety, however I felt this dish lacked a missing ingredient-not sure what. I didn't try the steak dish but everyone else loved it. 

The Monk's Kettle offers a variety of beer and not so much on cocktails. We tried one of the beers and it wasn't too bad. I would come back.
author: Laura T.

description: Okay just okay. We went there because of great reviews, however compared to what my wife are use to, we could not figure out why this place had such great reviews. The food was okay the service was not so great. It was like an episode from Sinfeld with the soup Nazi. The waitress just was not about service or working.
author: Dan N.

description: Monk's kettle has one of the best beer selection in San Francisco from what I've seen so far. Many beers from Europe that I enjoyed while living abroad you can get here. The place is a bit small so it can be hard to find a seat occasionally. I didn't try their food so I can't comment on that.
author: Clayton B.

description: If you're looking for some great beer in SF, Monk's Kettle has one of the better selections. Although the prices are somewhat steep, they really had some great stuff on tap. The bartender also gave me a little extra bottle pour too, so I would highly recommend visiting this spot to get your beer cravings.
author: Nick D.

description: Managed to get back over here.  Busy, sure but worth it?...oh yah.  Good food, Ah-maze-zing beer selection, super nice staff.
author: Kim S.

description: I stopped in here with friends visiting SF with the intent of wanting Pliny the Elder on tap. There was 6 of us, so finding a table was going to be challenging since reservations aren't accepted for dinner. That being said, the guy at the front door kept an eye out for us and made sure we got seated in one of the booths. My friends and I ordered a number of beers, including Pliny the Elder, and food. I had the burger, and let me tell you about those FRIES. SO GOOD. Service was good, and it was a great night to sit and hang out over some delicious food and beer.
author: Lisa I.

description: Monk's Kettle has a huge selection of beer. They also have beer to go at a discounted rate which is very convenient for those going to Dolores Park afterwards. I went with a group of friends and decided to get some food to nibble on while drinking beer. The mac and cheese is delicious and should definitely be ordered! Service is pretty good but not the best. I think it's because there weren't that many servers when we were there.
author: Nickie D.

description:
The Monk's Kettle pretty much ruined the Mission District bar crawl for me, simply because there's really no other place worth visiting in the Mission District after you've been (and have been promptly seated at) to the Monk's Kettle.

Where to even begin. The food at Monk's Kettle is out of this world; I've never once been disappointed with their Monk's Daily Sandwich, and the charcuterie board is a home run if you're just stopping by for a few casual drinks late in the afternoon. If you end up staying for dinner, like I usually end up doing once I see the lines forming outside, their trout is a delightful combination of juicy and chewy (two adjectives I don't commonly associate together with fish), and I double dog dare anyone to NOT fall in love with their duck confit. It's impossible, I swear.

The beers. By now everyone has that one friend who is absolutely bonkers about craft beer. When I say absolutely bonkers, I mean that this one friend is the one that drives four-five hours to a different state for bottle releases, will look his nose down at you for drinking an IPA out of a nonic pint glass, and publicly shame anyone who thinks Blue Moon is a "craft beer." Monk's Kettle is kind of like that annoying friend, except he has an ulterior motive to be nice to you in that he wants your money. So imagine that the one beard-toting, hop-sniffing, pot-belly-having, brewery t-shirt wearing friend suddenly had some sort of a lightning epiphany and decided he wanted to share all of his prized possessions with you (in exchange for money) and you pretty much have the Monk's Kettle.

For those of you that speak beer, the Monk's Kettle is one of two places that I can count on to carry Russian River Brewing Company's Pliny the Elder on tap at any given day of the year. They also have around 25+ taps of beer, primarily from CA (Cellarmaker and Firestone Walker being the usual suspects) with some other choice curations from around the US and Europe. They also have an extensive, yet somehow rotating bottle list as well which includes a vintage ($$$) sour/stout selection; a very curious selection of hard-to-find (albeit grossly marked up) Belgian beers with the likes of De Dolle Brouwers, Brasserie De la Senne, and Oud Beersel; and for extra brownie points, they also serve the original Leipziger Gose here as well.

If by some chance you're that one absolutely bonkers guy and are still sporting a resting meh face even after reading the above paragraph, Monk's Kettle is also a long-time participant of Pliny the Younger Day (February); on top of that they regularly have themed tap events, like hosting a vertical of all the years and variants of Deschutes' the Abyss, for example. 

My advice for any beer-oriented guy or gal looking for a good time in the Mission District would be to shut up and let Monk's Kettle take your money.
author: Scott S.

description:
4.5 stars. I've been waiting to come here ever since moving to San Francisco almost three years ago. It's about time, and Monk's Kettle was definitely worth the wait. I came here with a friend on a rainy Friday evening around Happy Hour time, which was perfect, because we were seated immediately. Monk's Kettle usually has its indoor and outdoor seating completely packed, and this has previously deterred me from visiting.

We ordered alcoholic beverages off their extensive and impressive drink menu. Note to self... Come here more often for Happy Hour. My friend and I decided to share two dishes, the kale salad and risotto. It was the perfect amount of food with a variety in texture and flavor. 

The kale salad was simple and refreshing, with apples, fennel, red onions, and walnut vinaigrette. The risotto had wild mushrooms, goat cheese, rosemary, and birracotto. Savory and creamy. Would recommend both!

Service was great. The place itself is kinda small, but there's space to huddle around the bar, and they do have outdoor patio seating when the weather is nice. I'd love to come here again, and actually going anywhere in the Mission District reminds me that I should hang out in this neighborhood more often.
author: Stefanie C.

description: Do not order the steak. I ordered it medium rare. It arrived overcooked and covered in some weird, sweet, cold sauce that tasted like it was straight out of a bottle. A shame as the Mac and cheese was pretty good and they have great beers.
author: Sally H.

description:
Summary: I had an excellent brunch experience on a Sunday at 2pm. The service was exceptional and the food was delicious.  I would go back and order the burger at brunch or dinner, and I'd be interested to try other things on their brunch and dinner menu and their beer menu. 

There were a few tables available inside, and I was eventually directed to one by the busy but friendly staff.  

From the first server (woman), I ordered the smoke trout salad ($15) and the burger ($18), medium rare, with two patties (extra $8). I asked the second server (guy) who came to fill my water glass for the second patty after I saw the size of someone else's burger, and he said "Sure!  No one has asked for that before because they're about 7oz, but ok!".  We had a good laugh (and yes, I eventually ate 14oz of delicious burger).  

Both servers were busy but attentive and they refilled my water when it was low.  Despite their bustle, they seemed genuinely concerned about how my meal and experience was, which was nice!

The salad came to the table first.  When the salad came dressed, I pointed out that I asked for it on the side, and the friendly server (guy) was really quick to apologize and make sure I got my correct order.   It was really just a slight mishap that didn't bother me much, and they adjusted quickly and were very considerate and quick to replace the dressed salad a few minutes later.  After an undressed salad arrived and I was enjoying it, the first server (woman) who took my order quickly came over to make sure that everything was okay, and it was!  The smoked trout was tasty, the manchego added nice salt and creaminess, and I didn't need the dressing.  3.5 out of 5.  It wasn't very memorable or a must-have, but it was a nice start to the meal.  

The burger was a solid 4 out of 5.  The flavor and texture of the meat was nice and well, meaty, and both quality patties were a perfect medium rare.  The sweet and soft onion jam, the soft cheese and the flavorful aioli gave it the good flavor and texture.  The bun was a good size match in size for one patty and had decent flavor (so I took one patty off and ate it alone...it was good).   While the bun wasn't toasted on the outside, which might have made it better, it was a good vehicle for the rest of the burger ingredients.  
I had mixed greens on the side with the dressing on the side, and the dressing was popping with flavor.  It was so good I dipped the rich/fatty burger in the tangy dressing, and that turned out to be an unexpectedly good choice.  

No beer for me this time around, but the beer menu is extensive and I'd like to explore it next time. 

(Side note: I'm not a believer in gruyere as a good cheese on most burgers.  It was alright on this one, but per the usual gruyere-on-burger, it didn't elevate the burger with texture, flavor, or mouth-feel.  Maybe it added richness?  I think gruyere tastes its best at room temperature, when it's solid, and some of its salty and funky qualities get lost in most burgers.  If you feel the same way, and if you want the burger at Monk's Kettle, ask the server if they have other cheese options.  The gruyere was good, it just wasn't what I would have chosen for it.  It doesn't hurt to ask, right?)
author: Andrew D.

description: Amazing place. Loved the chill vibe, awesome bartenders/waiters and the food! Beer selection is amazing. We ordered the homemade pickles, pretzels, and Brussel sprouts. Hands down must tries. For entrees we had the brussel sprout salad, burger, fried chicken sandwich, and tamales. Would highly recommend all of the above.
author: Nicole O.

description:
Alright... I've been back to Monk's Kettle several times since my original review, and it's time to give a well deserved five star update.

The beer selection is still great...the food is better than before... and the service has been wonderful each time.

You truly are a fantastic upscale tavern and we look forward to our next visit.
author: Zoran L.

description: Great atmosphere, rather limited brunch menu, but what they offered was delicious. That Mac and cheese with truffle oil will be in my dreams for a while now.
author: Kelly O.

description:
Loved our server mikahla. Also love the awesome outdoor seating.  Chicken sandwich yum.  Burger awesome.   I forgot to take pictures and the food was all gone by the time I remembered.  

Awesome.  Thank you.
author: Sfclint O.

description:
Went here for drinks on a Friday night around 11pm. The bar had maybe 10 people around it, with another 6ish people sitting at tables for a late dinner. Came here with about 6 people and were told that we cannot sit at any of the empty tables unless we were going to order food. We resulted in standing in one corner and blocking people passing through given the limited amount of room between the bar and their tables. We asked again if we could sit at a table and were rudely told NO, even though there were no one sitting at any of the tables at this point. I find this rule really odd, given it was almost midnight and no one is going to order food at this point. I would totally understand if we sat down and people wanted the table for food, we would gladly move, but to say NO upfront and hold the tables AND not have enough standing room?

If you have a party larger than 4 and only want drinks, this is not the place for you. 

Staff is also very rude and unfriendly.
author: Nelson S.

description:
Get a cracker and cheese plate!!! I was amazed at how good this actually tasted. It wasn't anything like buying some cheese from the store and putting it on some crackers off the shelf. It's so much more and you won't get it till you've tried it yourself. 

Definitely the pretzel was worth it. No regrets ordering a $6 pretzel because it was crunchy on the shell and so soft on the inside. It even came with some good... like GOOD cheese fondue.
author: Wendy T.

description: Great atmosphere, excellent food and great beer. And our server Bryce was excellent. Loved the look of the place
author: Ann H.

description: Great selection of beer. Decent wine. Staff was nice and bartenders were friendly. Had the fries which were good. Overall a little pricey, but worth checking out.
author: Lyndon G.

description: Great beer selection but the beer battered fish sandwich was undercooked so it didn't have that nice flaky fish texture. Also the fish probably didn't rest enough after being fried so the sandwich tasted a bit oily overall. Very friendly staff were kind enough to refund me the sandwich. I would go back. Wish the had greener items on snack menu
author: Danbi L.

description: Good beer selection, some are strong. As for the burger, it was actually pretty good. We were seated down rather quickly, but the bar is a pretty chill spot to eat as well.
author: Gage G.

description:
2ishpm on a Monday. Fantastic tap list. Even had Pliny the Elder! Was not very hungry so I just had the deviled eggs that were the perfect temperature and
texture.
author: Seth E.

description: Good beer selection, some are strong. As for the burger, it was actually pretty good. We were seated down rather quickly, but the bar is a pretty chill spot to eat as well.
author: Asa H.

description: Food was good, extensive beer menu, and cute atmosphere, but felt slightly unsatisfied with the price and wait times.
author: Jaden S.

description:
Excellent beer selection, superb fried chicken sandwich and fries.
No lies, I come here primarily for the beer, and I've never left disappointed. The staff is usually well-versed and knowledgeable about the various beers available, and so far has made good recommendations.
I do agree with prior reviews; the prices are a little high, but keep in mind this is San Francisco we're talking about. However, the slightly inflated prices are the only thing that prevents me from being a recognizable "regular" at Monk's Kettle.
author: DAllenRegisteredNurse 5.

description: Seriously?? The mustard that comes on the pretzel appetizer is ridiculous good!!! I am normally a cheese girl all the way, but this mustard made my heart go pitter patter! Real tight in here, but the selection of great beer on draught and the incredible food makes a little squish ok!!!
author: LuLu L.

description:
Went here for dinner around 10:30pm. It was one of the few places that was still open within walking distance.

We shared a poutine. It was pretty good, though not really the typical gravy-ful cheesy goodness you may expect. The best part about the poutine was definitely the pulled pork shoulder. It went well with the (slightly over salted but otherwise bland) fries. There wasn't much cheese curd in this poutine.

I got a Kale salad, it wasn't a good choice. There wasn't enough dressing on it (other than oil) so it was pretty much just a plate full of raw Kale some bits of fruit.

My friends got the fried chicken sandwich, which tasted pretty solid. They come with the previously mentioned blande fries.
author: Lily L.

description:
A real disappointment. We came with a party of 10 for dinner on a Friday night. Understandably, the place was packed and we expected a wait. After an hour or so, they said that they would have to split up our tables, but because one table was already free, the first half of our party would need to take our seats.

Ok, so we parted ways and took our seats. We put in some drink orders while the rest of the party remained outside, waiting for their table to open up which took another 20-30 minutes (and was located in the other corner of the restaurant). We didn't want to order our food until the other half of our party was seated, because we didn't want to finish our entire dinner before they had even started... Thus we continued to sip on our drinks. However, our procrastination only lasted us for so long and we were told that we needed to put our food orders in as soon as possible if we were to stay at our table. We were essentially forced into ordering before the other half of our party was situated.

The food ended up being mediocre and overpriced. The beer selection was good, but nothing noteworthy. The entire experience was a huge letdown, being that we really wanted to experience what was known as one of the city's greatest gastropubs. We just weren't impressed with anything at Monk's.

(Props to the door man, though. He was probably the nicest and most patient person there. He really tried to help us out.)
author: Michelle H.

description: Fantastic gastropub in the mission district. Their menu is like the beer bible, amazing diverse selection of beers from around the planet. They make a mean burger as well. Great place for beer and bar food.. the quintessential pub in the true sense.
author: Sudipto G.

description:
A San Francisco staple for lovers of craft beer.  The selection is like no other and they are meticulous about keeping the list fresh.   Also, the bartenders and servers are very knowledgable and very open to educating patrons on beer.

I love the Daily Roast when it comes to food and it changes daily (or almost).  The Fries are stellar too.  Can you say Bone Marrow Aioli??!! Nom Nom!  The Fried Chicken Sandwich is BOMB too!

The kitchen is very open until 1AM...I repeat 1AM (!!!) which, for some reason, is a rarity in SF.  So if you meet that special beer lover at the bars on Valencia and want to woo them with a damn fine late night bite and a tasty Porter...head to the Kettle my friend!
author: Lee S.

description:
Friday night dinner review with 5 people.

We got lucky: grabbed the last table! 

Drinks: they guys had beers; a ginormous selection!

Eats:
- Monk's poutine fires: ordered the large and great for 5 people to share. Nice mix of cheese and crunchy fries. (5/5)
- mussels: sooooo fresh, soooo huge! Came with some toasted bread. Broth was spicy but didn't take away the delicate mussel flavour. (5/5) 
- charcuterie plate: it was OK; I like the charcuterie at Trou Normand and Doc Ricketts a bit more. Ok to skip. (3/5)
- burger: pretty tasty with added bacon! Nice patty (not dry). A close runner up to the NOPA burger and SuperDuper burger. (4/5)
- Kale and apple salad: a bit tough to chew as they used Dino kale (not baby kale). Apples were nicely thin and tart. Vinaigrette was ok. I would skip this. (2/5)

Pluses: 
Clean bathroom, even on a busy Friday night.
Very close to Bart!

Coming back?:
Yes, would get the mussels, poutine fries and burger for sure.
author: Mary H.

description:
Special Sour Event +1 
Great outdoor area +1 
Wide range of beer choices +1 
Consecration (AMAZING sour) +1 
Friendly Host +1

Pretzel was good and fries were done well but couldn't taste the hop notes 

Overall Thoughts

What a serendipitous event for us to stumble onto Monk's Kettle for their special sour event, will definitely be back to try Monk's other options
author: Eddie W.

description:
With 20 seats at the bar, 20 seats inside, and 20 seats outside, everyone can enjoy good beer or good food at Monk's Kettle. They have 28 beers on tap (whoa!), but the variety of beer will blow your mind. Pages after pages of beer adds up to about two hundred beers! I really dig the glossary (beer terminology) in the back of their menu.

The bar is really nice to look at, and the bartenders are knowledgeable and attentive. It's a perfect date spot even if you're sitting at the bar. :)

I heard the food here is bomb diggity, so I'll definitely be back to try the food (and drink more beer)!
author: Christine S.

description: Great place in the mission area. We dropped in for a quick drink and were positively surprised. We ordered a cider and a stout and both were delish! We didn't try the food so I can't review that. However, people seemed to like the place. Good tap list and vibe.
author: Marilu G.

description:
Came here because my friends wanted to try their beer selection. They loved it.

I, however, only had the French fries. A bit too salty for me, but loved  how it came with mustard.

I'll definitely come back and try the food
author: Angelica C.

description: Really tasty beer and pretzels. Incredible selection. A tad expensive for the food, but nothing crazy as far as SF goes. Seemed like a tech bro hang out so I'm not too into it.
author: Charles W.

description: The beer selection and corresponding glassware was great to see. The staff is knowledgeable and knows their beers really well. To get this beer into the US is not easy. The prices per bottle are through the roof, however. I attribute this to the San Francisco CoL taxation on everything in the City. Also my MW burger was way underdone ordered mw got less than m... too hungry to send it back.
author: Tim M.

description:
This place is insanely crowded so the ambiance is just not there. We literally had to push and shove just to get a sandwich on a Wednesday. However, the chickpea burger was pretty good and the fries are massive steak fries. Nom nom nom.

3.5 stars
author: Ninette C.

description:
Ever since seeing this establishment on the Food Network, I've had this place bookmarked. Upon arrival around 6:45pm on a Thursday, there was already a 45 minute wait for tables inside but no wait for the outside seating. Being hungry and anxious to eat, there was no hesitation to sit outside.

The Monk's Kettle is sort of known for assisting their guest in pairing particular beers with their food. I wanted to order their Hanger Steak and my server recommended the Sour in the Rye from The Bruery. It only comes in a 750ml bottle so my friend and I decided to split it. I thought this sour beer complimented my Hanger Steak very well, helped bring out the flavors in the dish. I really enjoyed how well the steak was cooked and the sides it came with. I had a piece of my friend's Duck Leg Confit which was delicious too. Food and drinks are a bit on the pricier side but well worth in terms of quality.

Their bible of beer is something I hope to tackle more of next time!
author: Kathy L.

description: Cool bar that is really close to the BART station. Very large beer selection. Just a bit too loud for my taste. Didn't love the mac&cheese - should probably have ordered the burger instead (that's what everyone was doing, hopefully for a reason)
author: Clémentine C.

description:
I have reached an age when having a six-pack no longer comes from beer. Despite my fear of growing a potbelly, I succumbed to the extensive beer list and guzzled a glass of the lightest beer I could find. Light means diet-friendly, right?

Thank goodness I ordered such a healthy beverage, because I ate like a fat pig. I started off with some delicious cornmeal-fried oysters, followed by the unbelievable mushroom toast, followed by a trio of perfectly-fried sunchoke arancini, followed by sips of the flavorful onion soup...and this list is getting embarrassing! I'm ashamed to admit I completed my meal with a sinfully juicy burger and perfectly crispy yet fluffy fries for dessert. Although I was stuffed beyond belief, I couldn't stop cramming those crack fries in my mouth until the last crumb was gone. 

I will now forever dream of the pillowy mushroom toast, perky fries and leaky moist burger.
author: Suany W.

description:
Monks kettle monks kettle

It's pretty cool how they have an actual kettle on the store sign :) Like most places in the mission, this place is actually quite small, with a lot of seats that are squished together. It's also frequently packed, so they have a bouncer outside to make sure only a certain number of people get in.

The food is not bad--I got the mussels, which was pretty good, with a large piece of bread to soak up the sauce. The price is decent. The portions are not huge, but enough to get you full. The bar is also pretty nice, always packed with a lot of folks sipping beer, chatting, and generally having a good time

Worth a visit!
author: Henry L.

description: Best apps especially the fried oysters and pretzel but the worst main entree experience I've had in a long time. We got the veggie burger which was hard as a rock and the server tried to justify it (after waiting over 20 mins to get her attention) I'm sorry but I've worked in the food industry and there's no excuse for a burger patty or bun or even fries being so hard u have to pry at it with a fork and it still doesn't break off. We left most of the food on the plate and asked about it and got a lot of excuses on how that's how it should be but we're still charged a hefty price for it. I recommend this place highly for the apps but never for the main food. We got another two entrees that we're $$$ And also not worth it.
author: Dom L.

description: Nice little place with a bustling crowd. Went around 6:30 on a Tuesday and it was packed. Extensive beer menu so if you're a beer drinker definitely a good place to get a drink. Not a ton of seating and most people were at the bar. Nice seating at tables by the windows so you get good lighting. The food was good but honestly nothing spectacular. We had the burger and the spicy fried chicken sandwich both with fries. Fries lacked salt and the chicken was good and crispy but lacked the spice I was seeking. Burger cooked perfectly to medium rare but overall was lack luster. Still would consider it a good place to go to for pub fare.
author: Amanda L.

description: Two thumbs down. Took my out of town buddies down to the Mission District. Walked in and asked if we could sit at one of the two empty tables. We were told the tables were only for customers buying food. Evidently buying "drinks and snacks" at 4pm doesn't count and we weren't seated. I tell all of my friends how friendly people are in SF and this place just made a liar out me. Represent your city you asshats! Shun the Monk's Kettle.
author: Dusty B.

description: Stopped in for late afternoon hamburgers and beer. Great drinks and food, very busy and crowded. The hamburger was pretty delicious despite the crowds.
author: May O.

description:
Great servers/hosts, delicious food, great selection of beers and great customer service - what more could you ask for?

The wait might be long depending on the time you go but it's worth it. We waited about 30 minutes for a table in the patio and the restaurant was accommodating with our drooling dogs.

If you're overwhelmed with the selection of beers they have, I suggest asking your waiter what they recommend based upon your preference (ie: pale ale, IPA, etc). I wanted to try a pear cider and my waiter recommended the Cedar Red from 101 Cider House. It was perfect and what I had in mind!

We ordered appetizers which ended up being pretty filling:
Oysters - definitely get these! They're coated with corn meal and fried to perfection. I forgot what their sauces were but the oysters were delicious with it.

Fries - also perfectly crispy, not soggy. Comes with a pickle mustard dipping sauce and ketchup.

Flatbread - I think there were 6 slices which is a pretty big portion size for an appetizer. The vegetables and cheese complimented each other well. The waiter suggested prosciutto on top of our flatbread, which added a nice salty touch to it and wasn't overpowering.

I can see why people are willing to wait for a place to dine/drink at this restaurant. If you're visiting SF and want a laid back place to be at, this is it!
author: Cathy N.

description:
I came here on a Thursday night and they refused to seat my party! I don't get it... I called ahead to check hours of service, as a party of 6 brown people it seemed more like a race issue than table issue. 

I saw more than enough open space and when I asked to speak to a manager she had no reason for not seating us. She didn't mention reservations or anything. I've never in my life experienced such a thing!
author: desiree c.

description:
This place has been on my list for a few years...but parking in the Mission....forget it. We decided to stay at Beck's,  so The Monk's Kettle was just a short walk. 
They had Pliny on tap. Even though we had dinners plans, I had to order a poutine, yum.

We will be back for more
author: Kris M.

description: Found this on Yelp while in the area. The burger was great but my brother ordered a fish sandwich and it wasn't cooked. They replaced it but the batter was over fried... I guess to make sure the fish was cooked? Disappointed with that. Otherwise, would have been a 4 for the burger.
author: Mack T.

description: Look at what they give me for food?! Two of us spend $70 a bottle of red wine and they giving me bad service, burn food and rush to kick us out of the place because they are closing. Never ever go back again! What a good night for us.
author: Kobee L.

description: Selection of beers is excellent.  The pretzel is awesome -order two.  Staff is great.  Enough said
author: Threemealsaday W.

description: Wife and I strolled in. Beer selection is very good but the food really stood out. The fried oysters were large, very fresh, and were just amazing with a corn meal batter. We enjoyed this small but cozy bar.
author: Keith P.

description:
Super cool place.
Good food (we had the special fish and chips and a flank steak), but the main attraction is the beer. The selections come out in a book. I didn't even need to flip back to the bottles section because they had an Allagash sour on tap. Thank you for that.
Small but enjoyable patio. 
Kids welcome.
The wait can be long: on a Saturday evening it was 2.5 hours for inside, 1 hour for outside. Fortunately, they will call or text when your table's ready and there's plenty to see in the neighborhood.
author: Mindy A.

description: This was a very fun place. Tiny and crowded but great selection of beer and the food was amazing. I had several IPA's but I do recommend the American Strong for any of you whisky drinkers. It's barrel aged and was fantastic. Deviled eggs are worth it, pretzel is perfect to share, plus the have the best mustard ever!! Definitely recommend.
author: Mackenzie V.

description:
I can finally unbookmark Monk's Kettle! The gastropub is decently sized with amble seating. We arrived around 6 on a Friday night and was seated within 5min. 

They have a solid list of bottled beer and beers on tap. The staff was knowledge and helpful. The food was delish, I got the crispy chicken sandwich with salad and my bf got a burger with fries. Standard gastropub fare.
author: Jessica Z.

description:
After reading the reviews on this joint I was pretty excited to try it out. We popped in on a Wednesday right before they closed and grabbed a quick bite. 

The food was delightful and creative. The service was great. This is a great spot for some grub before a night cap. I will definitely be back!
author: Christina G.

description:
I came here on a Friday night around 10:30PM. The place is relatively small and if you want to sit at a table, your whole party HAS to order dinner... Which wasn't what me and my friends wanted to do (but don't worry, you can order appetizers at the bar if you want!), so we had to wait for a place on the booth or stand around awkwardly. Fortunately, when we got in, a group of 3 was leaving and we immediately go to take their place at the bar.

I'm not very knowledgeable of beers, but my friend recommend me to try anything because everything is good! So once I looked through the menu, I noticed sour beer... Whoa. I asked the bartender about that because I personally love sour and he told me that it's getting pretty popular! So I ordered the Rodenbach (sour beer). It was sooo good! i can't really describe it to you, but it leaves a interesting (in a good way) linger in your mouth. My friend ordered the Vanderghinste beer while literally tastes like those hard cola candies but sour - so cool/ good!

I forgot the name of some of the appetizers, but they're pretty fancy and not bad to grub on when you're drinking. 

The bartenders are super chill and nice! I would definitely come back here again to catch up with a friend or two.
author: Nicole C.

description:
We really thought this place was going to be good, but it was pretty dissapointing. It wasn't worth the wait and the food was forgettable. I chose this for a date night and totally regretted it. Check out ABV instead (it's right up the street, and way better).


I will remove this review if this restaurant unlists themselves from Uber Eats.
author: Jessica And Joe W.

description:
I loved this place! We came in on a Tuesday and Wednesday evening and enjoyed it both times. We were carded by Joel, the uber cool doorman, who remembered us the second night and let us right in with our friends. Sounds like the type of place I could be a regular if I lived nearby!
The environment is nice. You can have a nice dinner here or have it as a stop on a night out. It's a very tight fit, especially with a big party, so you'll end up standing around the bar or the back side table, but that's perfectly fine with the staff. Just don't stand on the barstools to reach the upper chalkboards... you will get yelled at, obviously. The drunkies just didn't understand... sigh. 

They have an EXTENSIVE list of beer, domestic and imported, bottled, on draft. But the cost of having all these gems available to you is reflected in the price. It's probably a few dollars more for the glass than your average gastropub, but you can try really interesting brews here.

On top of the great beer selection, they seem very popular for dinner. I am the type to get very hungry while I drink, so I ended up ordering the Monk's poutine, just a monster of a plate. Fries smothered in gravy with a mountain of juicy shredded pork on top. Excellent portion to share! It was so good, everyone stopped creating their chalk masterpieces to have a few bites. 

Service is fast. They check on you very often and deliver drinks quickly. You will probably get drunk quicker than you think. Overall, fun place that can be a chameleon for the type of night you plan on having, be it romantic date or night out with friends.
author: Joanna H.

description:
After 3 weeks in Southeast Asia, where my diet consisted of rice, noodles, tropical fruits, and tapioca starch products, it was fitting that my first meal upon returning to the states on New Years was my fav thang: a burger.

It was unintentional though. The boyfriend and I decided on Monk's Kettle because, well, it was open on New Years. Oh, and he's head-over-heels for their grilled chicken sandwich, which he proclaims is the best he's ever had.

Predictably, the moment I eyed the word "burger" on the menu, my heart and stomach tossed to the wind any notion of a chicken sandwich and committed to bodacious beef.

Before we get to the food, Monk's is also known for their extensive beer selection. He adores the dark, frothy, bitter Obsidian Nitro stout from Deschutes Brewery in Oregon, whereas I chose the lighter Vitus Weizenbock from Germany. We probably should have waited for our food to arrive, but sometimes beer should be its own meal. With repercussions.

He ordered the $26 half chicken under a brick with cranberry beans and pickled peppers (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-monks-kettle-san-francisco?select=ubTrls_1hijhXL8aur7AXQ#ubTrls_1hijhXL8aur7AXQ), and I have to say, they do chicken well. Juicy tender chicken enveloped by a lightly crisped skin, accompanied by a serving of richly seasoned veggies and beans. Spot on.

My $16 fresh ground beef burger with onion jam and aged white cheddar, served with a side of fries or a side salad for $5, was fantastic, excepting the rarity of the burger (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-monks-kettle-san-francisco?select=ubTrls_1hijhXL8aur7AXQ#u3-NduRwxbPdzFwrGz79Ag). I asked for medium-rare, and it came out closer to medium, but the patty was remarkable, generous with fat, juices gushing out with every bite (wow, describing good food is incredibly sensual...). The patty is simply seasoned with salt, so you mainly taste the heartiness of the beef. The melted cheddar is fabulous, and the onion jam is the icing on the cake...I mean, burger. A burger well done.

As a burger fanatic, my criteria has narrowed down to an obsession with thick, juicy, hearty patties (versus my previous holistic evaluation of patty + bun + toppings yadda yadda just cut to the meat). I would still rank Wes Burger #1, largely due to the unique salty char he gives his patties. A very close second, third, and fourth go to Monk's, 900 Grayson in Berkeley, and NOPA. Then come Serpentine and Umami, then Marlowe and Roam. Big Chef Tom will give you your pork belly burger fix, and Chez Maman will break your stereotypes on the identity of a burger. Smashburger and Super Duper deliver slightly larger patties than In-N-Out and Jenny's Burger in Inner Sunset.

Can't get any better than a burger P:
author: Adele F.

description:
It has been way too long since I've been to Monk's Kettle.

It has been way too long since I've seen my friend M.

And like reconnecting with anyone or anything you LOVE, it's like no time has passed.

The Monk's Kettle still has the same digs, ginormous beer selection and awesome bar food (now lunch food because I am old AF).

Unsurprisingly, M is still awesome.

Speaking of awesome, the double Brioche Pretzel thingamajig is my new carb crush ($10). Especially when dunked in the cheesy sauce. (Sorry mustard, but you know, CHEESE).

Speaking of twists, I enjoyed my side salad of kale, pomegranate seeds and fennel MORE than my fried chicken sandwich ($17). ::sound of lightening striking:: The former was flavorful and perfectly dressed and the latter was itty bitty. 

M also had a nice looking salad but wasn't wild about her oysters appetizer as they unexpectedly looked more like hushpuppies than oysters.

So note to self, double down on those brioche pretzels. 

And triple down on the cheesy sauce. 

12/2015
author: Amy C.

description: Oh my gosh!  I came to the Mission District looking for some yummy tacos before my concert. As I strolled down 16th I saw The Monk's Kettle and it was jumping.  Decided to give it a try and WOW I'm glad I did. At their recommendation I ordered the ribeye. What a plate of flavor!  It was amazing!  With a wonderful "Reality Czech" on tap and sitting outside in the beautiful breeze. It was divine!  I'll be bringing my mister back next time!
author: Julie D.

description:
A boisterous, tiny gastropub, with a beer list that dreams are made of.
We were able to walk in early on a Wednesday night and nab the very last booth in the back and get our grub on.
Our server was helpful (offering up a taste of a certain beer in question) and dealing with our excitement over the day's special (tagliatelle with a beef & pork ragu) with aplomb.
We shared the poutine (yum) and the mixed greens salad (the sour cherries and almonds were an amazing touch).  I shared the mushroom risotto with a friend (it was oddly sweet, but good), while my dining companions inhaled the pasta of their dreams (the aforementioned special), and the classic onion soup.  We left full and happy.
Great beers + great food + great company = a great experience.  Thanks Monk's Kettle - you saved the day!
author: Jennifer D.

description: Very good food, very good beer and very good service! The restaurant is small so there's often a line but worth the wait. One of our favorite casual date spots during off hours.
author: Urban S.

description: Holy sh*t ! This place just blew my mind. I always see that this place is super busy and finally decided to try them out since I'm always at the bar (Delirium) right across from The Monk's Kettle.
