Anyway, I ordered the Grilled Caesar salad (grilled lettuce, blackened salmon, grilled lemon). THAT WAS THE BEST CEASAR AND JUST IN GENERAL SALAD I've ever had in my life. I am so satisfied !! I wrote this yelp review right after I ate the salad honestly, that's how amazing it is or was :). The workers, especially the cashier were all nice so that's a plus. Shout out to our friend Tone (one of the cooks) for recommending the amazing food.
author: Roxy O.

description:
Huge selection of beverages. 

Well-organized beer menu with detailed descriptions (even a glossary!) 

Friendly, attentive bartenders. 

Food selection / menu was unique & what was delivered to other tables looked amazing (although we didn't order anything).  

Keeping this spot bookmarked for future ref :)
author: Kai R.

description: Can't speak for the food or beer, they were just too rude to hang around even for a bit. Needs more hospitality.
author: Nishanth A.

description:
I love their beer selections!  It's one of the places to go to when in Mission for bar hopping!

Their menu for entrees, exhibits modern American cuisine.  I ordered up their Hangar steak with cranberry marinade delight with mashed potatoes on the bottom of the savory meat sauce and it was fabulous!

They have many other refined dishes to order up if beef isn't to your preference.

The vibe here is low key, but the ambiance is wonderful with delicious entrees and beer!
author: Tiffany D.

description: Wow!  Split several items with my friends.  Everything was fantastic.  Loved the pretzels!  Soft yet with a little crunch.  Yummy.  And the Monk burger....delicious!
author: Kathy H.

description:
I can't believe it took me this long to finally check this place out. I think I tried to stop by a few times before and it was ridiculously packed each time.

I stopped in with a friend on a cold afternoon and we quickly shared the following:

charcuterie and cheese plate (rillettes and a blue cheese)
poutine
brisket and chuck burger
fried chicken sandwich

The poutine was one of the best I've had and the sandwiches were, although on the small side, well-crafted and tasty.

The main misstep was the charcuterie and cheese plate. When they brought it out I was super surprised to see how small the portions were. They added picked vegetables and other spreads and gave a decent amount of bread but the rillettes was a very small ramekin and it looked like they barely broke off a corner piece of the cheese on the plate. Definitely not worth the $17 so just skip it.

The service was ok and the atmosphere was seemed a bit too enclosed but was fine overall.

This place wouldn't be a destination spot for me, considering the lack of value, but the food was good so if you don't mind spending a bit extra, this place is fine.
author: Art O.

description:
Great beer selection! If you're in the mission and you want great craft beer, this is your place - it does get crowded at nights, so the best time to come is right after six. 

We had their Putin fries, and they were alright. I thought the gravy on top didn't go well with the ricotta, two soggy soft differently tasting textures just didn't go tighter.

They don't have Mac & Cheese, which would have been great with my beer. I talked to the staff and they told me they had it at one point, so maybe they'll bring it back, fingers crossed!
author: Zorayr K.

description:
The Monk's Kettle basically epitomizes everything good SF has to offer to us South Bay residents; it's a cool oasis of hoppy goodness when compared to our desert of fun bars / gastropubs.

The beers on tap are excellent. I've had maybe 15 different beers here in the last few months because they keep rotating taps and there are so many excellent options to chose from. The staff are also very good at recommending beers based on what you like, and what goes well with the food. Just as a note, I had the good fortune of tasting the Perennial Ales Abraxas, and my life is forever changed ... I plan to spend my remaining days in search of this amazing concoction.

While I haven't had much of their food, I can definitely say I'd eat a dozen of their soft pretzels if I had no self control. Same with the bread pudding dessert. See a theme in my food choices? I love bread and things that taste like bread (beer)!

Anyway, go to Monk's Kettle and appreciate some of the fine brews they have on tap. You'll thank me!
author: Akash K.

description:
I've been raving about this place to my husband for at least 6 years. When we finally made it here??? O.m.g.

My general advice is if you have 2 hrs to spare to get here over the bridge, 30 min to wait for a table, 20 min to take your drink order, another 20 min to take your food order, another 20 min to watch the tables around you who ordered after you receive their orders before yours and then another 30 min to get what you ordered then totallllyyyyyy come here.  

I'm here right now on a Saturday, 2;30pm service. "Service." Seriously if they wanted to serve their customers maybe have more than 2 servers for the entire, crowded restaurant. No beer is worth the hours I took to get here, park, order, eat and then leave. There are way too many beer joints around now for this kind of service.
author: Christy L.

description:
*** In Short ***

Extensive beer menu with great food, but terribly long waits to get a table.

*** In Depth ***

Alright, so, extensive is a bit of an understatement. The variety of beers here number well into the hundreds, which normally means that someone like myself who doesn't really drink beer would be screwed. Fortunately, I am blessed with friends that do, and do it a lot. And with hundreds of beers to pick from, it's not entirely surprisingly that they actually found one that I enjoyed: who said choice was necessarily a bad thing (when you have someone else choosing for you, anyway).

Now, enjoyable as the beer was, the food was definitely the highlight. My friend proclaimed their burger to be the best she's had in the city, but, well, I wasn't so easily convinced about the worthiness of a $17 burger, so, instead, I went with their roasted mushroom risotto instead, which was absolutely fantastic: rich, flavorful, creamy, and very filling. My friend, kind soul that she is, offered me a bite of her burger, if not just to prove a point. That point being that, yes, their burger IS indeed incredibly good. Certainly among the best I've had in the city, but, having had Nostra's raviolo burger recently, best is debatable.

My only qualms with the place? It's certainly a little on the pricier side, but worse is the fact that they don't take reservations, which, in our case, meant waiting for two hours before we had the opportunity to eat. But, if you don't mind drinking while you wait, and you show up before you're hungry, Monk's Kettle ain't a bad option.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - While the place is accessible, maneuvering through the restaurant when it's busy (so, basically, all weekend) can prove to be a little challenging with the narrow walkways. The tables and counter seating in the very back don't pose any height difficulties though, that being said.

Bathroom - In the very back, so, assuming you can make it back there, given the aforementioned, the bathroom itself is totally accessible.
author: Johnny W.

description: Love this place!  There's always great food and beer and it's always packed so be prepared to wait or maybe sit outside.  We opted for a table outside instead of waiting and it was right under a heater so it turned out perfect seating.  The first time I was here I had the chicken sandwich and fries and was amazing.  The chicken was super crispy and was close to being the best chicken sandwich I've ever had.  This time opted for the special gumbo and the only complaint was that I wished it came with more than just three pieces of shrimp, but I still really liked it.  The chef here is amazing!
author: Nyla K.

description: With the promising reviews, I thought this place would be good. Maybe just for pricer drinks but not food. Beer was so so, pretty pricey even if other bars aren't selling it. The chicken was salty and it would've been nice to know a half chicken is mainly the breast. Nothing wrong with that but the portion did not justify the pricing. The sides were meh, kinda wanted some mash potato to go with. Oh well. Nothing else stood out on the menu. Sandwiches? Seriously? Can you add bone marrow back or some cool dishes like pork belly, ribs, or some fried appetizers? Good service though
author: Ann L.

description: Easy check in on the app. Showed up and was in on about 15 min. Raining outside and isn't have to wait due to early check in. Great place too.
author: Manny E.

description:
You know those places that are over-hyped? Yup, Monk's Kettle is one of them.

I've heard COUNTLESS amazing reviews about MK whether through Thrillist, SF residents, or Bay Area friends...and I thought DAYUM this place must be super ballin' or something! Welps, to say the least, I was let down not only because of the high prices, but also because I think SF has other great bars and spots that are better priced and more unique than this space. 

I came here with 3 other friends with the intention of ONLY getting their drinks at the bar, and (I hate to sound like a prissy princess, but) were lead to two stools...soooooo I guess that means that we have to draw straws and find out who has to stand? I mean c'mon, the prices (pretty high) should reflect the experience AND the quality, right? Also, the time that we were there was very early in the evening's festivities, and the place wasn't even packed yet!

My SF resident friend said that their sour beers were definitely unique and a must-taste here, and we found out that the cheapest one was around $15! Did someone say #bougielife? I got a draught beer because I'm a cheap beer snob, but the whole experience wasn't just cutting it for me. There was a "bouncer" at the front of the entrance...who was basically a yoga-esque looking lady who was kind and polite, but I have nothing to comment about that. The bartenders were very knowledgeable and helpful--so I have only great words to say to them :) 

I hope I'm not sounding ridiculous right now, but I'm glad I came and had the experience of pondering on what drink to get on their extensiiiiiiive beer list. The place was in tight quarters and smack-dab in the middle of Mission district, giving it a cozy and "local" feel to the vibes. However, the high prices and lackluster overall experience won't be a reason for me to visit a second time.
author: Jodi H.

description:
Great beer selection and tasty eats! The service received was split for me. The bartender was incredibly warm and attentive, whereas another worker was barely friendly and accommodating at all. 

I would absolutely come back to enjoy the great selection of beer while munching on the steak, fries, and kale salad!

Warning though - it is fairly small so if you want to go after work or during other "peak" hours, know you will have a wait to get seating at the bar, in the dining section, or even outside (~ 4 tables set up on the side).
author: Anna M.

description: Comprehensive beer list, fantastic service, and retro, but rich/soulful interior-loved the bar decor. Menu was less comprehensive, but nailed it for pairings with the extensive wine and beer list, as well as  a variety of dietary preferences.
author: Melissa L.

description: Really solid place. We were seated right away. A little bit loud but still fun! Ordered the Mac n Cheese, burger, and chicken!
author: James B.

description:
8/30/14: Came here on an epic beer run over the Labor Day weekend.  And after hitting up many breweries including Lagunitas, Russian River, Rogue, Cellarmaker, and Mikkeller, this was our next stop.  To be honest, since I already had a ton of beer, I might have been a bit tired by this point, but alas despite that, this place was quite decent.

The atmosphere definitely was tailored towards the hipster crowd, and there were several skinny bearded men with tattoos on one arm.  Due to the dim lighting and plenty of aging but beautiful wood, it felt cozy--trendy but homely at the same time.

I didn't sample any food, but had a single beer: "Bourbon Arrogant Bastard."  Being one of Stone's popular brews, I was happy to find this special twist on it the famous Arrogant Bastard.  Unfortunately I didn't have the foresight to do a side-by-side compare between the 2 versions, but this one was definitely delicious and rich.

This is a good place to hang out with your friends and talked since it's not stupid packed and loud.

Beer selection is immense.  Prices are good.  Nice place.

Wish I could comment on the food, but as is 4/5.

#pub #bar #beer
author: Dean C.

description:
Good for beer, but not much else. I've never been a huge beer drinker, but in the past couple of years, I've learned to appreciate it more, so I can see the allure of Monk's Kettle for beer. But for food? I don't think I'll understand why people want to eat here. I came with a group of 4 and we ordered the following:

Drinks:
Draft duvel single ($8)
Prairie bomb ($18)
Draft allagash white ($5.75)

Food:
Daily pickle jar ($5)
Fried oyster ($3 ea)
Bricked chicken ($23)
Burger ($15) +Bacon (+$2)
Daily roast ($25)
Seared boat scallops ($26)

The food was very average for what it was. I don't think you can call it gastropub food. It was more like diner food at gastropub prices! So not worth it! And I don't understand the wait to get in here. I showed up earlier than the rest of the group, so I was able to put our name in to secure a table.

4 stars for the beer, but 2 stars for the food!
author: Elena N.

description: Service is terrible! We were pointed to a table. We sat down. Then told to move. Then no one came to take our order. Managers and owners should be ashamed for not training there staff in basic customer service skills.
author: Lady J.

description:
Stopped in for a bite and a drink after a little shopping down the street. The place is nice and small but still seats a good amount of people including outside. The alcohol menu has PLENTY to choose from so you won't be left hanging.

I wanted to order the house sandwich which was a ribeye but they were out already so I chose the burger. Now I don't want to justify a $17 burger but theirs was so good. You can also add bacon for $3 more. They use high quality beef that I had cooked medium well. The onion jam looked like it would be too much but the ratio ended up perfect for me. It also had aged white cheddar and a house aioli. The house cut fries were hot and fresh along with a home made ketchup which was great. My only knock was that it was slow to get service when we initially sat down.

So I usually come here for my favorite clothing store on 16th, but now I can add an extra stop the next time I shop there.
author: D B.

description:
My husband and a friend and I popped into this place on a whim, without a reservation, on a Saturday night, because we heard they had a great beer list. This place was awesome all around, with the service and the beer both being phenomenal. We were so excited to find a few Russian River beers on tap, and we devoured the Consecration (both at 2013 and a 2017) as well as the Supplication. My husband tried the Anianish wild ale from de Garde Brewing Company, something he'd never heard of before. It was phenomenal. We got more.

But, even before we got to the beer, we were greeted by what appeared to be the manager, who had no problem with us just walking in, and she promptly sorted us out for a table outside with a 5 min wait. While we were waiting, she made sure we had a beer menu so we could get started with our choices -- this extra touch is so very rare and was much appreciated. The waitstaff were attentive, funny, and knowledgeable. It was a tightly run ship and it showed.

Finally, a note on the food. We had a smoked trout salad, mac and cheese, and shishito peppers. Nothing big, nothing crazy, but it was all very good. 

We will definitely be back.
author: Genya D.

description:
Not bad food. 
Great outside seating, it was well tended to for service 
The beer menu is fantastic!!!!!!!
Though there was one server dude with long hair, I work service industry and it was just strange terse service... grabbed everything like RIGHT IN FRONT OF me and, maybe the only friendliness was expressed when dropping off the bill. Idk just seemed awkward for service. I went alone in the mid afternoon and it was slow outside. Maybe it's just me. But the female server was polite. Just awkward oh well
author: Miss J.

description: Haven't had the food here, but people seem to really enjoy it. Been in here several times for beers, and they have a good selection available. If you're looking for a nice beer at a sit-down place, check it out.
author: Matthew M.

description:
Beer selection is really great here, and their staff is very knowledgeable. If you don't know what beer to order, you should definitely ask for suggestions! They have plenty of beers on tap...If you have a craft beer nerd in your group (like my husband), I would definitely recommend taking them here!

The bar itself is pretty small, and seats at the bar are first come first serve. I would steer clear if you have a big group. They have a few tables outside for outdoor seating.

We were here on a Saturday night for beer and fries, and it was a great stop. Most people were drinking and having a few appetizers, though some people were eating dinner. All of the food looked great.

Prices were a little high, but overall a good beer stop. I would come back!
author: Jessi C.

description:
I finally got to come here on a day off.  I'm lucky that I got here early as the stool seating at the bar filled up quick.  After looking at the menu, they had an entire list of entrees that reminded me of higher end restaurants.  I just ended up getting a pretzel and I focused on the beer since the beer selection was why I came here.  Most of the pours were less than a pint of varying strengths.  I ended up trying the Imperial Pumpkin Sleigh'r by Ninkasi and the Le Terroir (Lips of Faith), both very high quality beers.

I'm glad that I got to come here and experience this place before it got extremely crowded.  I would come back again for the beer selection alone but will try more food if possible.
author: Ben H L.

description: Lots and lots of beers here. Excellent place if you love beer. They also have wine. The food is also really good here. We had the poutine fries which were great. The pork was really tender and the gravy was delicious. Also had the burger which was cooked perfectly. Long wait on the weekends but you can put your name down and they'll call you when the table is ready.
author: Lisa D.

description:
This place has glossary in their bible of beers! It helped me when making my decision as this book of beers was overwhelming.

The wait was long so we were lucky and found open seats at the bar. The bartender was knowledgeable, friendly and helpful with making suggestions when pairing beers with meals. Their beer selection is huge and one can get overwhelmed.  Sampling taste allowed prior to order a glass.  

Notes:
-Come early as it's a small venue and can get packed.
-Street parking is difficult take an uber and save yourself the headache.
author: Peter C.

description:
It's small.  So get there early.  But it's nice inside.  Light. Clean. Wood.  They have really cool and beautiful taps.  

I just came in for Beer.  I'd like to return for food sometime.  

There Beer selection is good.  20-30 on tap, MANY, MANY more in bottles.  It did seem to lean towards the European style on the selection... I got an IPA made with Brett from Fieldwork in Berkeley.  Pretty good. Crisp.  On the light/not hoppy side for an IPA.

Not cheap.  I think it was $7.5 for my 13oz pour.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Another long-awaited joint to check out, and another that I'm thoroughly glad that I did.

What we found out is you need to get here very early if you want be seated immediately. Otherwise, they take your cell number, and you can wander the area. They'll call you when your table is ready, which is pretty cool. Luckily, we came early!

AMBIENCE.
Man oh man is it LOUD. Tables are a little close together, and I think it was the "TGIF" vibe that made it impossible to hear one another without shouting. I always get bothered by that, but I guess it's to be expected with the popular places.

DAS BEERS.
Their beer menu is...impressive, to put it lightly. Imagine page upon page of every type of beer you can imagine, with an emphasis on good old Belgian ales. My only gripe was that my Triple Karmeliet came out a little warm, which was a bit of a bummer (and our server apparently has no clue how to pour a beer without getting a massive amount of head). We did try their house recommendations as well, however, and the Kyritzer was fantastic.

CORNMEAL-CRUSTED DEEP FRIED OYSTERS.
Mostly got them because they sounded interesting. While one a person is hardly filling, they were quite good, not rubbery at all, and the cucumber ketchup was an awesome addition.

CORNED BEEF HASH CROQUETTES.
Felt like more potato than corned beef, to be honest, but still quite delicious! The white sauce it came with was the perfect accompaniment, although I wish there was more.

BEEF BURGER WITH ONION JAM, AND AGED WHITE CHEDDAR.
Ohmyyum. One of the best burgers around, seriously. It was positively dripping with juices, and the onion jam was incredible. I mildly regret not getting bacon on top as well (although $3 for bacon seems like a bit much). And don't even get me started on the french fries - some of the BEST that I've had, cooked to perfection, and topped in hop salt. Just wish there was more ketchup, ya stingy guys!


No room for dessert (not surprisingly), but I'm seriously in love with this place. Just wish parking/noise level wasn't so blergh.
author: Claire S.

description: This place has excellent service, delicious food, and a great atmosphere. The waiter was able to make a fantastic recommendation on a beer. The food was served hot, neat, and tasted excellent. The vibe inside is a pleasant medium of casual and mission classy. The only downside is the garbage that floats all over your meal and inside your drink every time there is a gust of wind. The canopies just enforce that the trash remain floating at the outdoor seating area only. DONT SIT OUTSIDE. Unless you want to cover your drink and food every time Mother Nature offers a breeze.
author: Amanda P.

description:
I give it 5 stars for beer, 4 stars for food, 4.25 stars for size and atmosphere. Oh yeah, and 10 stars for dealing with my in-laws who could not comprehend fire code and why we couldn't squeeze three tables together in front of a window.

So, OK, beer. They've got a lot of it on tap, and in bottles, and some of it is stuff you want, others are not, and some of it is sweet, and others malty. Man, it's all here. Seriously, you can get it if you want.

Food is very much small plates oriented, which is actually really great given the size of tables and the fact that they are easily shareable. Don't bring a big crowd here (5), you won't fit. You might be able to commandeer enough space outside, but that's up to you. Do try the poutine with your group, as well as the meat and cheese offerings. I'd also recommend a sandwich, because they have some great ones.
author: Wes T.

description: Beer is their focus - but the bites, particularly the Oyster fritters, old bay remoulade 3 for 9, the Kale salad, shaved fennel & pear, pomelo segments, walnut vinaigrette for 13 and the Roasted sweet potato and leek risotto, aged parmesan, fresh herbs 22 are each excellent in their own right. Service - great attitudes and always done with a smile!
author: Nick S.

description: This review does not reflect the quality of the beer or the service. Why, you ask? Because my husband and I walked out after being inside for less than one minute. We love beer and we were excited to experience this notable spot. Our impression of MK's was tarnished immediately upon reaching the front door. The unpleasant doorman told us that there was standing room only. We then stood there like idiots until I asked if he needed ID. We walked in and saw plenty of seating for diners. A few other couples were standing around uncomfortably, trying to avoid knocking into people. The aesthetic of the place was uninspired hipster chic, a mashup of late 19th c. industrial design and you know what the fuck I'm talking about. I prefer to not have my ass in people's face when they eat. So we left all butthurt and went to a dive bar next door and sat down and stewed. Half way through writing this I realized that this is all probably more my issue than their's. So, the takeaway: 1) you are not the losers we are and always get a seat at the bar and look cool, have friends, and strangers envy you. Good for you. Have fun at this bar. 2) You glimpse a little of yourself in my cantankerousness. It's okay. Just go next door.
author: Sunny R.

description: Everything amazing at this place, excellent service, excellent menu if slightly too salty a bit, but excellent anyway.  Great vibe, great atmosphere overall, great drinks.
author: Penny F.

description:
Basically, Travis is the man. He was our bartender as we sat at the bar, super helpful, super friendly, and ran after me after I forgot my phone after leaving. Also, he knows his sh*t. We love trying crazy new beers, and Travis had just the recommendation for us. On tap, nonetheless! It was the Previous Life gruit beer by Moonlight. Funky, herbal, and so unique. Like root beer without the sugar and plus some ABV.

Not to mention, Travis also knew the food menu quite well. He recommended the special of the day (i.e, the Monk's Daily Roast), which was grilled shrimp with basmati rice and some grilled veggies. It was delicious, but then again, everything we ordered off the food menu was delicious, including the corned beef croquettes, the kale salad, and the pumpkin seed crusted scallops. Generous servings and delicious, hearty food.

So of course, we had plenty of beer to drink along with our feast. Everything was well poured, with specially chosen glassware. Can't say anything bad about the food nor the drink.

However, it does get pretty busy. We attempted to walk in on a Friday night to grab a table and the estimated wait was about 45 minutes. Luckily, we were able to snag a few seats at the bar. Although the service was friendly and attentive, they were difficult to hail at times. Not a place to go for a quick meal.

Bottom line: Great beer and great food. Hope you come in when Travis is working! (And no, I don't even know the guy personally.)
author: Jade V.

description:
How did we get a table here so fast? I mean it was creepy, knowing how hard it can be to snag a place at this SF institution. Some intersection of timing, the fact that we were eating AND drinking, and the moon was in the house of mars or something. 

Amazing beer list, but they do seem to prefer that you purchase some of their amazing food. We go the burger and it was probably one of the best I've ever had. Cooking at home, I aspire to the amount of salt/pepper that was featured on my Monk's Kettle burger. Wish I was hungrier, as everything there looked delicious, but my wallet thanks me. 

Side note, the bouncer here was a pretty friendly guy.
author: Brian B.

description:
This is one of my all-time favorite restaurants and I was definitely a regular here when I lived in SF. Their beer list cannot be beat. On top of that, the food is amazing. As a vegetarian, I'm always hesitant about gastropubs-- they tend to be pretty meat-heavy. But the Kettle is different. I love their mushroom risotto, and their spent grain and chickpea burger is the best veggie burger I have ever had. Not to mention their UNBELIEVABLE warm pretzel knots served with melted cheese and whole-grain mustard. I could eat those all day. And for dessert, don't miss the chocolate bread pudding, but you may have to share it because it's pretty rich.

Yes, it's crowded here-- get used to it because they deserve the attention. Yes, it's expensive, but the food and beer are definitely worth it. I recommend showing up on the early side, putting your name down for a table, and then grabbing a seat at the bar and getting a beer and a pretzel knot. Or you could even order dinner at the bar-- not a bad option if there's only one or two of you. But don't let the crowds or prices deter you-- the Monk's Kettle is worth it. 

Also, I hear they just started serving brunch as soon as I moved away. MONK'S KETTLE, HOW DARE YOU?! The only flaw with this place when I lived in the Mission was that they didn't serve brunch, and of course as soon as I go to New York, they change that. Well, for all you San Franciscans, I bet their brunch is amazing. I bet it's the best in the city. How could it not be?
author: Lee A.

description: I love the beer selection here, there are a lot of great choices on tap and their bottle list is very extensive.
author: Max W.

description: This place is yummy! I went here with a group, everyone got the Monk's burger except me. They loved it! A couple people got a beer as well, and they described it as smooth. The waiter recommended a beer based on the weather and ended up being a good recommendation apparently. I got the Spanish tortilla - it was pretty good, I just didn't like the sauce. Overall, great experience! We were satisfied. BTW, Expect to pay at least $20 for a meal here.
author: Rosie O.

description:
Located right in the heart of the Mission, this pub and restaurant is the perfect date spot conveniently between several noteworthy bars.

Known for their huge selection of beer, Monk's Kettle seemed to have everything and more. The best part of the experience is taste testing, and I tried several, even if I ended up playing it safe with an IPA.

We started with some butternut squash soup, which was a decadent, not-to-sweet blend garnished with fresh herbs. A must during El Niño!

Next we split two entrees: the spent grain & chick pea burger, and the pan seared whole rainbow trout. Honestly, we couldn't have ordered better.

The veg burger had so much texture and flavor, and was topped with tzatziki, roasted red pepper, and pickled shallot. Such an intricate blend, and a hearty portion. Certainly something you'd want to split, especially given all of the filling beer you need to consume.

The trout was just as delicious, and a lighter dish that paired well with it's fennel puree-squash-apples-pecans-brown butter accompanying side. The ingredients felt wholesome and tasted delicious --- not something you always necessarily feel about your side side. It was warming, and the spicy and sweets aromas made for the perfect winter dish.

I'd recommend getting here early, because it's always packed. Start at the bar, and work your way to a table for a meal you'll long for again, long after the fact.
author: Rachel H.

description: Wowowow this place is a little gem, particularly if you like craft beer! The beer menu is several pages long, and yes they do have some wine as well. What I really liked was at the end of the menu there is basically a beer dictionary, which helped me pick the right kind of beer for my taste out of the many choices. Food also did not disappoint! Pretzel knot was da bomb.com and the burger mmmmm.. inside tables are packed just a little tight but I went early enough for it to not be too crowded.  Service was also really attentive and that is always appreciated.
author: Katie N.

description:
Things I ate here: 
-Monk's daily roast
-Chopped kale salad, dried apricots, toasted quinoa, almonds, pear vinaigrette 
-Grilled flatbread, figs, blue cheese, arugula, fennel with prosciutto 
-Old school pretzel knot
-Penn cove mussels, allagash white, garlic, shallot, basil 
-with a bottle of 2012 Pinot Noir, Klee, Willamette Valley

Not sure why we got wine when all the reviews said to try their beer. I really enjoyed the food, especially the flatbread appetizer. Highly recommend. We had to sit outside and the service was OK. Nice restaurant, would recommend to parents and friends and siblings and randos on yelp.
author: Juliana P.

description:
First of all, the beer list is out of control. It went on for pages and pages and pages and had all sorts of cool options like sour beers and ales infused with chilli, etc. 

The food was also excellent. The fried cornmeal oysters were a must-have. Often fried oysters no longer taste of the oyster itself but these absolutely did. The corn beef croquette appetizer was also delicious, but the burger was what made me a full convert. One of the greatest burgers of all time! Crispy bacon! Onion jam! Melted cheese! God, it was good. So good. 

The atmosphere was also fun and the servers were friendly. Last tip - ask for hot sauce on the side to dip your fries in! It is homemade and slightly sweet and totally addictive.
author: Sol C.

description: The best chicken soup that I have ever had!! This is NOT like Mom used to make.  The flavor of the broth is so complex, and the meat is so tender.  I love food, and soup is my least favorite dish, which I only eat when I am under the weather, but I would order this soup here any day!
author: Shannanigans001 ..

description:
Came here in a Saturday at 8 pm. Beer was amazing (according to my friends)!!!

The food is downright horrific. Where do I get started? The fries were thick and dry. The ketchup had no flavor. None. Even sweet and salty was missing. The garlic aioli was like eating bulk quantity mayo resembling elmer's glue flavored with garlic pieces. Revolting. 

The wine braised short rib was tasteless. It was also dry and tough in some parts. Unfortunately the kale is came with was bathed in salt (though flavorful contrary to the rest of the food here). The butternut squash purée cut the saltiness but there wasn't enough of it. My friends risotto was crunchy. Like...Saturday evening-rushed-dinner-entree crunchy. The sauce was passable if somewhat one-dimensional. Had some of my friend's salad and even the beets were bland! 

I felt disgusting the rest of the night because I was hungry when I got there so I ate a lot of food. Definitely disrespected my body. It's the next morning and I still hate myself.
author: Catherine L.

description:
Located in the mission, Monks Kettle is not one to miss for beer fans. Even on a Tuesday night it was very full since people went to eat as well. Since we had a party of 8, we had to wait a little bit, but the guy at the door was beyond nice! He was very accommodating and kept updating us on the status of our tables. His service stood out, and he tried his best to get the 8 of us together, so in the end we could sit together. 

The beer menu is amazing with hundreds of selection, and around 20-30 on draft. I really wanted to try the oyster beer, but they ran out, so I went with a coconut milk stout, which was refreshing, dark, and not too heavy. I love stouts, but sometimes the chocolate or espresso flavored ones get too heavy, so I'm glad the coconut milk one was refreshing and lighter. My friends got ciders and an espresso stout, which were all unique and amazing. This gastropub has beer I've never tried or seen before, and that is what will keep me coming back. 

The ambience is actually not too suitable for groups and is better for smaller groups or dates. The cozy and casual atmosphere combined with great food and drinks make it a good sit down place to chat although it can get easily crowded with the smaller space. 

I would come back to Monks Kettle just for the beer selection, but it is not my top choice in terms of ambience because I don't like smaller bars usually.
author: Annie C.

description: Great food, friendly staff, outside seating allows dogs & long list of craft beers! It's one of those places that makes you wish you live in the city. They don't have many craft beer restaurants in the South Bay, especially rare to have a long beer list. I had a delicious squash soup that was sweet, creamy & had a little crunch of garnished seeds & fresh herbs on top. I also enjoyed their burger, done medium rare (perfectly) with delicious caramelized onions & spring mix lettuce. The onions & lettuce didn't take away from the meat & sauce like many other places would so that was a big win. The fries were also done crispy & good. We'll be back!
author: Iris Y.

description: For me, Monk's Kettle serves the best burger in San Francisco. It can't get any better than this. Juicy, oily, and an amazing grill taste. Very simple with not too much toppings but this burger doesnt need it. The patty alone is a winner already. Great draft beer selection, too. Bit pricey, but worth it.
author: Tim B.

description:
This place was so delicious!! I had their mushroom toast and it came with burata cheese on top. The mushroom was perfectly seasoned too. I didn't feel the need to add salt which is rare for me. I'm a salt phene. Also, they gave a lot of mushroom, both whole and chopped up. My friend got the mussels and that was very good. The flavor of the broth was a little bit too salty but it was seasoned well.
I wish mussels were as fat and plump as oysters! The pretzel was different than any pretzel I've ever had before. It was flakey and warm and they served it with this warm cheese sauce. They also provided a slide of whole grained honey mustard. Delicious! Lastly, we had their sandwich special. It was a Mexican style sandwich with carnitas, guacamole, and more. They had so many beers on tap. I was overwhelmed but in a good way. Our sever was nice!
author: Ness H.

description: Great brews and great food. The fried chicken sandwich is exceptional. Not too much hipster attitude which is nice.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Holy s***!! Where the hell have I been?!

I took it upon finding a great bar with delicious varietals of beer. Hence, I stumbled upon Monk's kettle. Mmm...so good, I came back here a few times with friends. One in particular, I came back a bit drunk beforehand, because I was on Bart to trek it to SF Pride that weekend. Fun times! Anyways, hands down, I've found a spot that serves good quality beer. No! I'm not talking about beer you would find at a Safeway store. They have a really good list of beers, one person can't pass this place up. Aside from the beer selection, they also serve food. Seating is a little cramp, but I suggest to come here on a nice sunny day, sit outside, take in the view, grab a bite, and sip on a nice cold beer. You'll thank me later.
author: Fraulein C.

description:
What a cool spot pretty central to some of the favorite Mission bars! It's tiny but as a lot of personality and I thought the good was phenomenal.

It's a small spot I would call first to see if there is a wait - it was just two of us and almost 10pm so it was cool. The kitchen is open until 1am! I ended up having champagne and not the huge beer selection they have! So this is a pretty awesome place to try different brews!

It was two of dining and we shared all the dishes we orders. We started with the cornbeef hask croquettes which were so good! It comes with three pieces and had such a unique taste. Then we had the mussels which was my personal favorite...so delish and always fun to eat. They were in a white wine sauce served with bread you could dip it in. Pretty fantastic and a must try!

Lastly we had the steak which was serves with a type of Brussel sprout kinda dish and a sweet potato hash so good! I love steak and splitting it made this the perfect amount not to feel overly full.

All in all great!
author: Priya S.

description: Went with 2 great friends to this small and comfortable grill/tavern. It was outside dog friendly for Ace.  Food and beers were excellent.
author: Dan K.

description: Ok but over priced food.  If you're going to be a high end beer bar you have to have more adventurous beer recommendations. Allagash white is fine but I can get that at Costco.
author: Quinn G.

description: yes this is Pliny the Elder on draft! with a little rare sour beers: Sang Royal by Cascade aged on pinot grapes and  Avance by Allagash .. a dark sour with strawberries!
author: Jay A.

description: The beer selection here is quite good and I love the location.  The food quality and service is slipping.  I've been here many times but was pretty disappointed in my last two visits.  Time to find a new place.
author: Mark L.

description:
Joel basically invited us in off of the street, where he helped us look for a seat as it was crowded on a Tuesday night. We told him we'd come back when it died down a bit, and we're so glad we did! 
Sat at the bar & ordered our dessert, Shane let my friend taste three different dessert beers until she found one she liked, he suggested a Zin for me, which I loved. 
We ate (the dessert was amazing), drank, had great conversations & truly enjoyed our time here. 
Thaaaanks guys! You really made our last night in SF enjoyable. 
P.S. Joel, your wife is a lucky lady & Shane, I still think you have a fake accent. :)
author: Haylee D.

description: Yummm loved this place and the tavern-ambience. I came here with a couple girlfriends during a recent downpour night so it was a great-darky cozy setting for the night. To start we all ordered beers, which they have an incredibly huge selection of drafts and bottles/cans, along with the pretzels (1 for $6 and 2 for $11) and bone marrow. Pretzels were really tasty and yeasty. The bone marrow I didn't think had a lot of marrow to so and more just buttery liquid, but the mushrooms on top were pretty good. For our meals, two of us ordered the roast of the night, which was short ribs with some type of bread pudding and broccolini. This was so amazing and tasty. Huge portion of short rib that was all meat rather than laden with fat. Also paired really nicely with the beer they recommended. Our other friend ordered the mussels and she seemed to enjoy as well. Also there was a guy next to us who ordered the fried chicken sandwich and it looked amazing! I'll definitely be back here as it's a straight shot on the 22 from Cow Hollow ... if I lived close by I would visit more frequently.
author: Aryn C.

description:
An amazingly well curated offering of beers there.  I've always wanted to swing by here, but work and lack of free time seemed to be big obstacles. 

The beer list has many many pages.  I had a couple of draft and bottled offerings.  I snacked on their house pickles to go with my beer.  They were great and well-balanced.  

They had a "roast of the day" which was a pork loin.  I didn't get a chance to order any entrees as I had dinner plans elsewhere.  I will be coming back for more beer and to try out their meatier options.
author: Ed G.

description:
Always a happening spot for their beer selection, and I was finally able to enjoy their food recently! (It smells so good when I'm sitting at the bar.) Since then I've said this anytime the topic of burgers has come up aroudn me: Monk's Kettle has the BEST burger I've had in SF!! Granted, I haven't gone out of my way to get burgers (haven't gotten Spruce's), but I have been to some pretty legit spots: Chez Maman, Umami, Greenburgers, Super Duper (feel free to debate the authenticity of that...).

THE WAIT: We got there at 6:30pm on a Friday and put our name down. It was about an hour wait, which was better than we expected. There's plenty to do around there between shops and other bars, and the hour passed by all too quickly.

THE SERVICE: They were crazy busy, but our server was really cool, very chill.

MUST-HAVES: Burger, Bread Pudding!

DRINKS:
* Aecht Schlenkerla Marzen (Smoked Beer, $14) - 4 stars
Can't really comment for myself, but my boyfriend really liked this.

*Boon Krick (Cherry Lambic, $32 bottle) - 4 stars
A must-share for the girls. A very strong, tart, enjoyable bubbly for the girls.

NIBBLES
* Fries (hop salt, house mustard. $7) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-monks-kettle-san-francisco?select=R3WWxEEJQW1dG4Xbk6BOLQ#kXyH9u5sG5UOQ3WeOEGFJg
Great mix of soft chewy inside and a crisp shell.

* Old School Pretzel Knot (cheddar fondue. $4.50) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-monks-kettle-san-francisco?select=R3WWxEEJQW1dG4Xbk6BOLQ#NaLyIF8bVubc6PK7R3-hkQ
Perfect texture: soft on the inside with a smooth baked crust. Schmidt's has a slightly better one with a sharp flavor from their large chunks of sea salt, a little softer w/ more of that just-out-of-the-oven freshness. But Monk's Kettles' was still great.

STARTERS
* Chopped Kale Salad (dried apricots, toasted quinoa, persimmon almonds. $11) - 4 stars
I always love dishes with toasted quinoa - it adds so much to the texture. The nuts were great, the apricots added a bit of sweet/tart flavor, & the dressing was lightly coated on. The greens were chopped small, which made it easier to eat too.

* Lobster Bisque Soup (special) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-monks-kettle-san-francisco?select=R3WWxEEJQW1dG4Xbk6BOLQ#KzOaiCtsgMpv65mpyJy3Lw
This had a strong, fresh seafood flavor, & was pretty thick in texture.

MAINS
* Fresh Ground Burger (onion jam, aged white cheddar, & kale salad replaced the fries. $15) - 5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-monks-kettle-san-francisco?select=R3WWxEEJQW1dG4Xbk6BOLQ#FWY40WguGgp70Ak8SlDJPA
Wow! Once again, the best burger I've had in SF. Incredibly juicy, the bun was perfectly toasted yet soft, & everything was just wonderful together.

* Roasted Mushroom Risotto ($19) - 4.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-monks-kettle-san-francisco?select=R3WWxEEJQW1dG4Xbk6BOLQ#1OYiGyxpA-ERQjoG0qI_Aw
Really nice, thick, creamy - & mushroom wasn't too overpowering.

* Half Chicken Under a Brick (cranberry beans, kale, pickled peppers. $23) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-monks-kettle-san-francisco?select=R3WWxEEJQW1dG4Xbk6BOLQ#1AyQVHyciH6B2dkKlJBJUw
I tried a bit of chicken: it was very juicy & consistently tender even in the lean parts. It was all sitting in a plate of a thick flavorful sauce. A great dish of American comfort food, done well!

* Bavette Steak (sweet potato, brussels sprout. $25) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-monks-kettle-san-francisco?select=R3WWxEEJQW1dG4Xbk6BOLQ#lA-FxBTqESAjf0lHn8PAWg
The steak was soft & tender, & sweet potato was awesome.

SWEET
* Mini Beignets (seasonal jam, caramel. $8) - 3 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-monks-kettle-san-francisco?select=R3WWxEEJQW1dG4Xbk6BOLQ#2V8suggU7WrDN8fjEinA7w
Too much crisp! They're small, so there is very very little of that chewy inside. They were almost stale - biggest disappointment of the night.

* Dark Chocolate Bread Pudding (vanilla ice cream. $8) - 4.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-monks-kettle-san-francisco?select=R3WWxEEJQW1dG4Xbk6BOLQ#BTRKJJi3hSuhR87xrO_bDw
Our friend doesn't even like bread pudding, but she liked this! More moist than other puddings, breaking apart into pieces more easily (rather than being a more homogeneous texture that you could take a scoop of). Love that it's not overly sweet -the dark chocolate flavor was great, & the rich ice cream a wonderful complement!

Dinner menu: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-monks-kettle-san-francisco?select=R3WWxEEJQW1dG4Xbk6BOLQ#R3WWxEEJQW1dG4Xbk6BOLQ
Drinks: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-monks-kettle-san-francisco?select=R3WWxEEJQW1dG4Xbk6BOLQ#KU3TvEkwKkD-rO3mqXsKIA
Drinks 2: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-monks-kettle-san-francisco?select=R3WWxEEJQW1dG4Xbk6BOLQ#vGl4hkvYgMJZq9frRaZZ2w
Dessert menu: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-monks-kettle-san-francisco?select=R3WWxEEJQW1dG4Xbk6BOLQ#mjw5vX9n2W7eymi7N6S5kw
author: Ziyan C.

description: Beer list. Exceptional. Food. Pretty flippin good. My only gripe is that I had the Rueben that was on special but I've never had one with cubed meat. Weird. Made it difficult to eat. My wife had the Mac n cheese with truffle oil. Insane. Best I've had in the city. Bottled beers can be a bit pricey. $37 for the bottle we bought. Solid beer but will look for it elsewhere cheaper.
author: Michael O.

description:
I'm not sure why this place is so popular.

Didn't like the service. They only let you have a table if you're having a meal. I didn't appreciate that kind of discrimination - if you're in a group of 3-4 a table would drastically improve the group's experience rather than everybody sitting side by side at the bar... I think they should prioritize the customer experience more. We planned to order apps to share instead of a full meal, and they still didn't let us have a table, and there was a free table for the first half hour we were there!

None of us liked our beers that much, and my friends are definitely beer fans! Fries were good and very generous though!

My favorite beer bar is still Hopwater Distribution in Nob Hill - amazing beers without any pretentiousness.
author: Jeffrey Z.

description:
Great gastropub menu. Too many beers to choose from. Very busy - even on a Monday. There's outdoor seating with headlamps but inside is best on a chilly April nigjt. 

The pretzels and fried trout did not disappoint. 

Would definitely come back.
author: Jason F.

description:
It was definitely an experience. I came with a party of 5 an hour before closing time and the server ( Douchey Cheese Man ) was not happy. He rushed us to order quickly and kept pushing the alcohol. I know this is a drinking establishment but we were just hungry to be honest and this place was practically the only place open. 

With that said, I loved the food. The burrata toast is super good, the cheese board was pretty, and the burger was yummyyyy. Feeling bad, we also ordered a beer that came in a wine glass and I guess it was good? I'm not a drinker so I really wouldn't know. 

In the middle of the meal, another party came over and gave us a bottle of a hard apple cider because they were leaving and didn't get to it. It was funny but Douchey Cheese Man was not happy about this. He gave us this weird look. Anyways! Again, not a drinker so I guess it was good?

I would give 5 stars if it weren't for Douchey Cheese Man
author: E D.

description:
I'm actually sad to give Monk's Kettle a 1 star because I wanted to like it - it's like Abbot's Cellar but I consider it the original high end gastropub in the Mission (from the 2 years that I have lived here heh). It's small, cute, the beer list is respectable and the food looks amazing. 

The service however is terrible, they're pretentious to the point of being straight up rude. When I asked about the alcohol content in the beer, she pointed to the door and told me to get shots next door. Um rude much?

So the beer selection is pretty good but you can get better quality beers at Abbot's, more choices on tap at Zeitgeist (and cheaper). The wait is ridiculous, the prices are overly expensive, and the food and drinks are nothing special.

ZERO STARS.
author: Jess C.

description:
Wide, wide, wideeeee range of beer selection. Almost overwhelmingly so. But we came here because we got word that they had Pliny the Younger.

We sat at the bar and ordered Pliny but when the waitress came by with the glass, she told us it's only the Elder. Wompwomp. Had I known, I would've ordered from the overwhelming selection of beer. Oh well, next time.

We got the brisket & chuck burger ($17) and it comes with fries. We also got fried chicken sandwich w/ slaw ($17) and it also came with fries. Both were solid dishes and were very flavorful. Oddly enough, there's a $5 charge for subbing fries with salad. Some expensive salad!

Cool spot. I'll be back some day to try any of the many types of beer here.
author: Sandy T.

description:
Nice atmosphere with wide selection of draft and bottled beers. Local crowd feeling. 
We only wanted a snack and tried the pretzel knots... pshe... not crazy about it.
author: Coral B.

description: delicious food, wonderful service. ridiculous beer selection. one of my favorite spots in sf. :)
author: Vanessa D.

description: Love, love, love. Not your average pub food. We shared a plate of mussels, nicely done. I had an excellent carbonara, creamy and delicious. My husband had a juicy burger with a salad. Thanks guys!
author: Benjie N.

description:
If you have the patience to wait, this place is 100% worth it.

I like to start with the pretzel. It tides you over and the cheese fondue and mustard they serve it with is fantastic. (I licked the bowl once...okay, all the time)

It is also the hands down best fancy cheeseburger I have had. Usually my boyfriend and I get the chicken sandwich and burger and trade halves.

Plus, if you are a beer lover they have any and every kind you could possibly want, and incredibly helpful servers for suggestions and taste tests.
author: K P.

description: This place is a great spot for some food and some drinks. I've only been here for the drinks really lol. They have an extensive beer menu. I'm very appreciative of the chalkboard wall so I've left my mark there a couple of times. They have local SF Cellarmaker and that's always on point. Love their Curmudgeon from MI. Cool atmosphere and it's in a nice spot in Mission with other places to explore around as well.
author: Natalie M.

description: Great place!!! Stopped by after someone recommended it. Lots of Sour Beers and great food. I had the Chicharrones to start, which were hot a freshly with a Consecration beer. It was a great combo! Followed by a delicious hot Spicy Crispy Chicken sandwich and a Krieky Bones. Excellent choices!  Definitely will be coming back for more.
author: Brian Q.

description:
Solid gastropub in the Mission.

Pros: 
1. Vast beer selection with 5 whole pages filled with unique beers
2. Knowledgeable bartenders who will recommend yummy beers that are perfect for your palate. I asked for a lighter, citrusy wheat beer and I got an incredible recommendation
3. Friendly staff - I read a few reviews about how the staff is extremely unfriendly but fortunately, I had a great experience with both the bartender and the bouncer-esque man at the door who helped us find 2 seats at the bar 
4. Great spot to go to with a date or a few friends to catch up
5. Quality bar food and solid pretzel. I definitely enjoyed the pretzel but I am not sure it's worth 5 stars. Although the dough was great, it was a tad on the saltier side 

Cons: 
1. The bar area is pretty small and can get very full during peak hours on peak nights 
2. You can't get a seat unless you are planning on dining here - only bar seating is available for non-diners

I'd definitely come back when I'm in the mood for some gourmet beer and carbs. 

Happy Eating/Drinking, Yelpers!
author: Priya S.

description:
Four of us went in for lunch because of the reviews here. I like the atmosphere and the tap list is very nice but I would never ever eat there again. NEVER. 
That was the consensus among the four of us. Whoever was working the kitchen that day disappointed each of us and we all ordered different things. The pretzel was pretty good but I've had better and that was the best thing on the table for $180 (half beer).
If I were in the neighborhood I might stop in for a pint but Cellarmaker is only blocks away so maybe not. 
Gastropub my ass, just a nice bar.
author: Luda F.

description:
Amazing service and list!
The beer list is amazing with great rare beers
And our waiters were nice and attentive
author: Ty M.

description: This place isn't cheap, a burger sets you back 20 bucks. The burger itself was pretty good though. Nothing else to really say about this place. Probably not going back just because of the price of a burger
author: Victor D.

description:
Enjoyable, but not amazing. The charcuterie plate was ok, but by far not the best I've had. Had higher expectations for a place that's known for beer. 
The duck leg was really well cooked, and the lentils and sweet potato purée that went with it were great. The risotto was good, and the corn was clearly very fresh and sweet. 
With all the new places to eat in the mission, somehow managed to get a table on a Friday night without wait.
author: Rita K.

description:
Tried this place out on a whim last night. Absolutely loved the drinks menu. I got to try a mead for the first time, and the description by the waiter was perfect (important for anyone whose trying something they've never had). The mead was amazing as well; it had that honey flavor without the sweetness. My boyfriend got the white pinot, which was very light.

My food was scrumptious. I had the spent grain burger, and it was one of the best "veggie" patties I have ever had. The fries were nothing exciting, but were still well made. The mead paired very well with it; I would highly recommend that combo.

My boyfriend had the mushroom risotto. The flavors were lovely, but the texture was off. It was undercooked, leaving almost crunchy rice pieces, rather than the usual soft grains found in risotto. It was rather busy when we were there, but for a good restaurant that should be no excuse. The white Pinot did pair well with it. 

The service was great, despite how busy it was; the server was helpful and just attentive enough to not be overbearing. Overall a good experience. Will try this place again.
author: Cara W.

description:
The "OWNER" is so damn rude. I have never experienced customer service like this before. He quotated said to us "Don't come to my fucking bar if you're going to use my restroom without FUCKING asking" and we replied "we didn't know it wasn't for public use" and he said " DONT FUCKING DO THAT AGAIN" 

Let me repeat this and clarify this... A OWNER OF MONK KETTLE'S cursed at my friends... the WORST CUSTOMER SERVICE EVER. 

Don't go here. I really think this owner is RACIST AF.
author: Kenji Y.

description: Such a cute little restaurant! Came here on a Tuesday afternoon and ordered the daily sandwich, which had steak + arugula and a fried egg on top - it was a great combo (quality wasn't spectacular, but I enjoyed it). Their handcut fries were great! It's a bit pricey for the quality of the food (spent ~$22 on the meal alone.. generous portions though!), but I definitely loved the ambiance. I'd love to come back for drinks with friends instead of a meal.
author: Karen Z.

description:
Found this place by accident, but it sure did not disappoint! If you love beer, or even remotely like it, The Monk's Kettle is the place to visit!! You'll be blown away by their selection of beer on tap. Simply amazing!

I came here around 3pm on a Friday. I felt a bit weird coming to a bar solo, but at least half the people sitting at the bar were alone. So no biggie. I sat down and was helped right away. They do offer beer tastings with up to six or so different beers. I opted to get two glasses of one of their light beers that happened to be made locally. It was so good! Hit the spot. 

Service here was great as well. The bartender was friendly, but not over the top. I liked it!

I didn't try any food, but the people next to me ordered some and it looked pretty good. 

I would come here again the next time I'm in the city!

Cheers!
author: Michelle M.

description:
The only reason I'm giving them 4 stars, and not five, is because they are feelin' themselves a little too much and are douchey whenever they feel like it. They flex like they're some culinary frat that only hipster douches can apply for. Newsflash: your attitude blows.

Having said that, I will also say that their spent grain and chick pea burger, loaded with fromage blanc and onion jam rules my stomach. One of the best veggie burgers I've ever had. The hop salt fries are uh-may-zinggggggggg. 

I always order for pick-up, 'cause I don't wanna be surrounded by douchery, but unfortunately I even encountered the douche factor when I picked up my order this last week. The host let the bartender know I was there to pick up my order. This chick (short brown hair/tall) seriously continued making drinks for the next ten minutes, never made eye contact to let me know she was at some point gonna get my order, and actually never did. I had to ask a waiter, who tried to direct me to the same bartender. I told him she was aware and wasn't making any effort to retrieve my order, so he told another bartender to get my order. Oh yeah, they also never answer their pick-up order line. I've always had to call the manager's line to order......about 9 times just to get someone to answer.

Monk's Kettle, your attitude can suck it.
author: Gabriela W.

description: Love the ambiance, beer and customer service! They are very helpful and if we lived here we would come here all the time.
author: Katya C.

description:
I used to live across the street and was a regular here. LOVE this place. Even though it gets packed and the clientele can be obnoxious, it's still worth it. 

I'd recommend coming early so you can sit down in one of the booths. 

The food is delicious and they have a huge (HUGE) beer menu with a wide selection ranging from super local microbreweries to imported from far away lands, from $5 to $500. 

The staff is super knowledgeable and fun to chat with. Sitting at the bar can also be fun for this reason.
author: Julia O T.

description:
Great spot. Very friendly and knowledgeable bar staff.
Not hipster or overly busy even on a Saturday night. Great choice of beers and great snacks to accompany them. The pretzels and fried pickles were delicious.

Stay away from the Rasputin. It'll knock your block off.
author: Adam M.

description:
Was looking for a nice meal before a show at the Roxy theater and wasn't thrilled with the Monk's Kettle. 
 - Great beer selection but at 400% markup 
- Burgers were bland, soggy and fries were too salty
- Bartender was friendly but host and waitstaff were stressed
- There's a weird mix of decor with a mahogany bar, minimalist stone wall dividers that amplify sound, and freaky photos of mannequin heads

In short, neither food nor beer was worth the price.
author: Liz C.

description:
What a treat, what a treat! Like a kid in a candy store or on halloween! 

The Monk's Kettle is a beer guru, and I sure do love beer! Mostly IPA, Double IPA and Ales [but all beer is amazing]. 

My group of friends came here out of the blue because we wanted a place that served food and alcohol, they wanted mix drinks... but this was not the place for that. 

Great environment, very loud and loving, the people there are attentive and definitely know their stuff.

Three words for this place: PLINY THE ELDER

I fell in love with Pliny and Damnation since my boss bought it them and now they are amazing to me! Only place near SJ that actually serves this :D.

Their menu is small and short, filled with amazing food. From mussels, to half chickens, to lamp / pork and daily specials.

Their beer menu is however, is many pages long... full of great varity and different types.

I really want to go back, if you love beer... this is definitely the best place to go.
author: -Johnson- N.

description:
Come here for the beer selection and the room. If you're hungry, go somewhere else. 

The food has nothing special considering the $$. I had the chick peas burger ($17)... Nothing I couldn't make home. Meh. 

The service is not the greatest and it doesn't go with the more-than-casual atmosphere. If you're charging $26 for a single plate of food on the menu, at least offer some water. 

Not a good value for your money (for food), but great location and good place for beer.
author: Jose S.

description:
What a cute gastropub!

We got there on the early side (around 6), and we didn't have to wait for a table...and we got one outside on a warm fall evening. There are just a few tables outside which are great on the few warm days of the year. We were probably the only people at the restaurant not drinking beer, but that didn't stop us from having a great meal with wine. 

Pros:
- Kale salad with dried apricots was great. Big salad with a good balance of sweetness and acidity. 
- Great fries, thick cut and perfectly golden brown
- Delicious juicy burger

Cons:
- Croquettes were pretty mediocre. They were on the dry side and pretty bland.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Don't get me wrong, the beer and food were delicious. But everything else just kinda sucked, so 2.5 stars.

I had been meaning to try this place for a long time, but didn't bother because I didn't wanna deal with the ridiculous wait time. So one day, my friend was like "Let's just check this place out."

I went inside to put my name on their waiting list while my friend was heading over because I figured we would have to wait either way. The hostess then noticed and told me "I can't put your on the list until your whole party is here." (Pretentious much?) Just then, my friend showed up and we were told we would have to wait for like half an hour and they would text me when they were ready. It wasn't that long of wait, so we just stood outside to kill time. My friend swears that she noticed some people who were waiting after us were able to go in without having to wait because they looked like they were a part of the typical hipster crowd. Unverified, but I would believe this to be true because they probably think we're just two cheap Asians, which isn't a false assumption, but would be fucked up either way.

The place was had the standard hipster decor with the raw wood and metal...yadda, yadda, yadda. The beer bible was extensive, which was cool. I also appreciated the way they paired the dishes with certain drinks on their menu. My friend and I decided to order the Mushroom Buretta and the Daily Roast with the beer that would pair nicely with our meal. 

1. Beer: As someone who isn't a major fan of dark ales, I really enjoyed my drank, which came in a wine glass. (Ironic, right?) It had a slight caramel-y taste, which I had never experienced with beer before. 

2. Mushroom Buretta: It was basically a pile of mushrooms on top of a piece of thick toast with cheese, but it was delicious. The mushrooms were supple with a hint of sweet alcohol. But seriously, for 15 bucks, it should've been a loaf of bread.

3. Daily Roast: A pork loin roast with some veggies on a bed of polenta. The meat was tender and sweet (like the perfect boyfriend). The polenta was smooth and creamy. We knew what were getting into for 25 bucks, but I was expecting more.

The bill totaled up to like $70, which was ridiculous considering it was really only the meal of one person (an appetizer and main course); had we gotten anything more, it would've been crazy expensive. It's like we paid that much money only to leave hungry. Granted, they are like a "golden child" in the whole hipster restaurant scene, maybe I'm just poor. It's possible that if I had more money, I would probably "get it."
author: Alex Y.

description:
WAHHH! I miss it here so much! My favorite place to grab a few brewski in my favorite neighborhood in the city.

Food is always good here (order any of their sandwiches) and one of the best beer selection around! I'm not a beer snob by any means but their extensive beer list is nothing but impressive. They also have a full wine list as well. 

To me, service is equally as important as the food and drinks. Everyone that works there can easily become your best friend and I can be pretty hard to impress. Bartenders are very patient and knowledgable with their drink menu so don't be afraid to ask questions.

Let's be honest, they had me at "beer"
author: Jenn K.

description:
Do you like burgers? Do u like your burgers and buns burnt? Do you like tour burgers burnt by a chef chugging beers back to back ?well look no further. The monks kettle is the place to be. And I guarantee you the burger will have more burnt taste than all the delicious flavors advertised.

Second time here. I lived it the first time..second time was during a busier hour and I was not happy with my food so burnt.
author: Dede A.

description:
They do this amazing thing with poutine where they serve it with dog food on top. It makes me wonder... did they start with dog food and cook it real good. Or did they start with a great piece of pork and were like "let's see how much we can make this taste like dog food." 

Either way, five stars.
author: Quags M.

description:
I'm a fan as there are so many beers (and awesome ciders :P) but mostly since the drinks are awesome and the service was great. They were able to figure out what I wanted without me even really knowing and we had a decent amt of standing space (since we didn't eat there) in the back on a Friday night. We had just come from Limon.

Warning: some of the drinks are def overpriced....so don't come in expecting drink specials or etc.
author: Lily P.

description: We've since been back for lunch and you MUST have their burger! HEAVEN!!! Onion jam, ACME bun...what? Divine combo of commingling of flavors that had us thinking and having deep conversations about burgers for weeks! Yes we are "those culinary crazy" folks. Even got us to seek out the best recipe for making the perfect burger at home, which we've perfected. Though I still long after that onion jam...not to mention those killer fries. Wow, there goes all my hard yoga workouts for one perfect burger, Thank's Monk Kettle for making the most mouth watering burger that my husband and I literally dream about and have now set as a standard for all burgers. Oh how I crave a Monk's Kettle burger. GO, now!
author: Susan D.

description:
Hungry after rock climbing, it was hard not going to our usual fast and easy choice, cancun burrito. We've been wanting to try monks kettle for a while so we went here. 

Ordered 
-oyster fritters: creamy sauce 

-pretzel knot: baked or fried? Whichever way, it's awesome

-burger w bacon: loved their bun.. my friend said it was the best burger they've had

-mussels in white garlic sauce.. That broth is so good 

We had a hard time choosing desserts so we got both
-dark choc bread pudding w vanilla ice cream

-carrot cake
Both were good but I preferred the bread pudding 

Wash it down with
-cellarmaker stout
-black currant cider
I liked my friends stout over my cider. 

Great place to eat and drink. Ill come back again.
author: Raquel T.

description:
There is a pretty extensive beer selection! I am a huge fan of stouts and I love the espresso stout at Monk's Kettle. It's one of my life goals (#priorities) to be better versed in craft beers and this seems like a decent starting place. 

The bar area is pretty small and it is usually packed on most nights making it not so good for large groups. I came here on a FIRST DATE and managed to snag a table right by the window. The ambience felt cozy and the hustle and bustle didn't bother us much. I wanted to try the pulled pork sandwich but given that I look like a 2 year old covered in spaghetti sauce after every meal, I resisted. Everything worked out and now it's too late for the boyfriend to run away. I should go back for that sandwich.
author: Xinxin W.

description: This is a great place, although smaller than I thought.  I tried their fries and pretzels, both of which were excellent.
author: a f.

description:
This place is so cool! Their beer list is very extensive and I love that they have outdoor seating. We arrived around 9PM and wanted to sit outside, but they said the outdoor seating closes at 10PM and you have to order food with your drinks. We agreed that we would be out by 10PM.

The waitress was so funny and cool and she was super knowledgable about all the different beers! One of the people that I was with didn't like their beer so they recommended something else and I don't remember what beer it was but it was like a sweet cherry beer and it was SO GOOD. it tasted just like juice!

We also got the pretzel and that was really good. It's so odd how a pretzel could taste different but it was so fluffy and light. You should definitely try it!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
My perfect idea of a what a gastropub should be:
- An enormous selection of tasty beer (24 on draft; 2 cask ales!) including many local beers, and hard-to-find beers, like Pliny the Elder on draft. The bottle list is mind blowing
- A casual neighborhood feel; none of the stuffiness that some gastropubs emit
- Delicious food; a short but stellar menu
- A friendly and knowledgable staff, quick to make a suggestion or answer a question

I came here with my friend P before seeing a show nearby.  At 6 pm on a weeknight, we were lucky to find a spot - The place was jammed soon after our arrival, with a short line of people waiting; kind of alarming for a Tuesday!

I started with a Pliny (sooo good); my friend P with another local IPA. Despite the varied menu, we decided to keep it basic and ordered burgers ($15). Then we switched up to different beer styles (a session beer for me; a porter for P).  After our burgers arrived, we converged together on sour beers. (They have it on tap - I almost never see that!).

As for the food, my burger was phenomenally good: cooked perfectly to-order: juicy, flavorful, with a killer onion jam and a layer of aged white cheddar. The hop salt fries were fantastic. It was the ideal accompaniment to our tasty beers.

In short: Only one visit for me (so far) but they have me hooked big time. Just waiting for the next excuse...
author: Dan B.

description:
They know beer. I ordered the Afflegem triple from Belgium. It is super tasty, everyone at our table eventually ordered one. I'd heard the burger was good and so gave it a try. It was cooked perfectly and had a lot of flavor. I highly recommend it. We tried some appetizers. The pretzel was ridic but the mushroom toast was a little weird. 

The joint gets busy so come early and don't plan to stick around for long.
author: Kelly C.

description:
According to the website, the place aims to fulfill four objectives in providing a variety of beers to satisfy everyone's palette, brilliant customer service, proper beer service, and clean draft lines. Of those four objectives, they fail magnificently at number two.

Don't get me wrong, I wanted to like this place a lot. The décor and ambiance is really interesting and they do offer a lot of choices of beer and even a good selection of food choices but I got the crappiest attitude from their staff after they screwed up my order. Sure, the dude offered to put in my order, but when I asked him to cancel the order because I had waited 25 minutes, his only response was "okay" and then walked away. The most basic of decorum would probably be offering up an apology at the very least and I don't even get that? I understand that mistakes happen, but getting snubbed like that was just plain disrespectful. I mean, what? Am I not good enough to be a patron at your waterhole or has the 1,800+ reviews on Yelp has given them some over-inflated sense of ego? 

I'm sure they deserve a second chance perhaps, but when you screw the pooch on a Monday evening that isn't even fully packed, it leads me to wonder what kind of crap shoot a busy night would bring about.

The only nice person in the whole house was the doorman who actually greeted us with a smile and said goodbye with a smile. I didn't even have the heart to tell him how bad the whole experience was.
author: Ray L.

description: Cozy pub with one of the most extensive tap lists ever.  Literally some type of beer for everyone's preference.  Smart small bites list as well.  Definitely a gem that serves up some gourmet inspired dishes.
author: David C.

description:
Second time here and 1st time to finally write a review. This place has yet to disappoint. I think it's impossible. From their vast variety of beer selection to their deliciously outstanding selections of dishes served here. They even know how to pair beef and food. Amaze!!!

We had:

Cornmeal fried oysters with cucumber ketchup and their in house hot sauce

Corned beef croquettes with whipped bone marrow/lemon aioli

Grilled flatbread with figs, bleu cheese, arugula, fennel and prosciutto.


All were delicious but my top two were the corned beef croquettes and the grilled flatbread. 


I can't wait for another trip back to the city just to come there to dine out.
author: Helene K.

description:
This place has a nice vibe to it. Tried with with a friend of mine on a rainy Sunday afternoon (otherwise be prepared for a long long line). We ordered fries, a flatbread and drinks. Both the fries and the flatbread was very unimpressive. The beer selection is really good! I will come back to try the other items in the menu, but so far, I am not impressed. 
Oh, the small tables in the middle are so close to each other that 1) you are constantly hearing every word of your neighbor table 2) there is no way to slide between the tables to get to one's seat without your body parts invading into the next door table (if you weigh more than 150lbs, you will not make it through!)
author: Tina B.

description:
Overpriced... food was decent and it was so loud in there that my friend and I could barely even hear each other! They do have a wide selection of beers, though!  

This place is more like a bar scene than an actual restaurant. The servers don't really come around often so it's hard to even ask for a water refill. If you're into beer then this is the place for you.
author: Catherine C.

description:
Good beer selection in a very cozy and relaxed environment. It's bustling in here, but the staff is always nice and willing to help you pick from their vast selection.

The bar itself is small, so definitely do not try to come here with a large group. Overall this is a good place to grab a drink with some friends. Solid.
author: Chia L.

description:
I heard so much about this place that when I stumbled across it one Friday afternoon as I took the day off, I had to stop by for a cold one.  They have an extensive menu of beer, and I honestly did not know where to start.  I should have asked for a recommendation but I wanted to make an independent choice for myself so I did, I loved it - gosh, I can't remember what it was though!  

It was a medium-light draft beer that hit the spot as I had been walking a lot and it was nice and sunny outside.  Service was good and was attentive just enough as I just wanted to cool my heels before getting on BART to downtown.  It was such a nice, friendly spot where neighborhood folks stop by for a cold one and to catch up with friends.  I will definitely be back!
author: Maile N.

description:
When the Kettle first opened, I was in heaven.  A high-end gastropub a few feet from my home? I'll take it.  

The food was exceptional and the beer selection was great, very eclectic on both fronts.  But word spread and the place, which is tiny, quickly got overcrowded.  And as the place filled up, so did the egos of the staff there.  I've actually never despised a staff that's so consistently pretentious and rude, their egos only surpassed by their false knowledge of both the beer and cuisine.

I just never go here anymore.  The beer selections at more accessible venues have expanded since and who really needs 50 Belgian beers to choose from?  The waits are extraordinarily long for those dumb enough to wait 90 minutes and the crowd is filled with Marina ex-pats who are delighted the place is so expensive that it keeps out the commoners.  Yeah, not my kind of place anymore.

Oh, and did I mention the staff are arrogant douchebags? Yes, I guess I did.
author: Saminda W.

description:
5 words: best poutine in the city.

Seriously, try it!
