Their beer selection is also impressive. Try the Modern Times + the Staffe. Yum!
author: Sophie B.

description:
I had three dishes: the duck confit, the burger, and the chocolate bread pudding.  I'll start with the burger - awesome burger!  Very flavorful and cooked to perfection. When I return I'll definitely order that. Duck confit - big hard PASS.  The duck was overdone, the kale had too much vinegar and it burned the back of my throat, causing me to cough after every bite. I wouldn't want to order it again simply because I don't want to risk the same thing happening.  Chocolate bread pudding - it was good, but nothing out of this world. Tasted a bit like chocolate Rice Krispies (which is good).  Loves the toasted edges. 

The beer (Dubbel Allagash) was very good and paired nicely with the meal. 

Great service, but a little to cramped. I'm thin and I still had to squeeze my non-existent ass in between the two tables to get to my seat.
author: Jason M.

description:
Based on the 1600+ reviews, I decided this should be the opening spot for my friend to show her the dichotomy of the Mission. They arrived a bit before me, and I should have realized things would be nuts on a Friday night - the 2:30 hour wait for food was a bit of a shocker.

Fortunately I got inside to at least order a beer, which was standing room only at this point. The beer menu was impressive, but it took all 3 of us eyeing down the bartender before I could get mine. I quickly shot it down and got out there as I was effectively standing on top of a bar patron.

I would very much like to give this place a full review - but will try to find a time where I either walk and enjoy before the hour+ long wait.
author: Michael C.

description:
I eat WAY more burgers than I should. If it wasn't for the constant running I do, I'd probably be one of those Rascal-driving behemoths you see at Wally World.

So when I say that The Monk's Kettle has one of the best burgers I've ever eaten, I don't take that lightly. The bun was soft, the patty was juicy, the toppings were fresh, and the whole thing left me craving more. Seriously, it's on my very special list for top five burgers of all time.

But why no five stars then? Two things:
- It's super-duper-uber crowded. Even at 5PM we had to wait 45+ minutes for a table.
- It's pricy. I can understand $15 for a burger, but $10 for a Weihenstephaner you can get for $2 at Safeway? Please.
author: Casey S.

description:
Great beer selection - some are strong. As for the burger, it was actually quite good. We were seated down rather quickly, but the bar is a pretty chill spot to eat as well.

I'd love coming here again for a few brews. The staff are courteous, the water pours are quick, and the brews are just darn good.
author: Albert K.

description:
4 stars because

+ wide wide selection of beers!
+ I didn't have much interaction with the bartender but she was incredibly knowledgable on the beers. I vaguely gave her my preference of something with fruit and she asked the perfect questions and let me taste till I was satisfied. She also described the beers exactly as they taste! 
+ great ambiance, love it when everyone around you is having a good meal and a good drink
+ cool menu - I'm a designerd and while it's not the craziest thing, the drink menu is loaded with a glossary in the back. My boy and I love learning about wines and beers so  we got a kick out of figuring out terminology. 

Cool place to go, I'd definitely head over early or it gets crowded. If they take reservations, I'd make one too.
author: Leslie L.

description:
Came here this past Saturday during my foodie trip to SF.  It wasn't a planned stop, but we were looking for a place to rest our feet and grab a drink before Mission Chinese opened it's doors at 5pm.  When I pulled up Yelp on my phone to look for nearby spots, this place popped up and my cousin's husband said he'd been and enjoyed it.

It seemed like a cool, happening place and we were lucky to find a 4-person booth in the middle of the restaurant right behind the bar.  Its a total shame that my hubby didn't come with me, as he appreciates a good beer.  I found my glass of sparkling white wine perfect for early Happy Hour and even ordered ONE (1) fried oyster despite trying to save my appetite for MC because the menu description sounded so mouthwatering.  It was pretty darn good, and the order of fries consumed by my sister, cousin, and her hubby were hot, fresh, and crisp.  Definitely a great place to kick back... and the people watching was pretty fun too.  :)
author: Arti N.

description:
This place. GUH. It's a place of happiness, 

Every time I have an opportunity to to SF, I always make it a point to come here and indulge in their burgers. I can't even explain in coherent words how wonderful and tasty and fatty and comforting they are. I like their basic fresh ground burger - I think it is the combination of really great beef (cooked medium), and the aged white cheddar that makes it deliriously addictive. Combine that with super savory fries, it's a godsend of heartiness wrapped in comfort tied together with addiction. I know i sound dramatic but often people are when they are passionate about something. In this case, the great American love. And yeah, I think the simplest of things is also the hardest to achieve perfection. And the many times I have had this, it's been perfection. Never anything less than that.

Now, about this eatery. Aside from my much loved burger, they also have a good sized menu with plated options like Sunday roast, steak, risotto, etc. They have a large selection of small bites that's perfect for accompanying with wine or beer. Speaking of alcohol, they carry a lot of it. A lot of craft beers (scotch ales), local and Belgium, and their staff is lovely enough to go through pairings with you when you order your food. In the wine department, there isn't a large selection but it's enough to give you plenty of options. 

The restaurant itself is on the smaller side. They're more of a bar/pub than a restaurant but they have offerings of quality food alongside their drinks (hence gastropub), so it's really a place to check out if you're lurking around the Mission.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
Some people are born with natural artistic talent. Others well, they are meant to observe such talent.

A fun think about the Monk's Kettle is how the have a chalk board around parts of the bar. People pop things up for others entertainment. Nice touch.

It seems like this Gastropub is known for their food, but unfortunately I did have anything. I came here for some beers.

Pretty good selection but besides that, it's just an alright spot for a drink. 

Bartender took my order, I got my beer, I gave her money, she began to give directions to some gentlemen. I'm all for helping someone out but can I get my change first and go sit down with my friends before you do that. 

It's a decent spot but if you're just coming for a beer, consider options elsewhere.
author: Mitch E.

description: Long wait, but that pretzel is to die for. Also the risotto and the butternut squash soup were great! So we just went out to the Hideout at Dalva next door to have cocktail while we waited.
author: Deepika N.

description:
The food is pretty average and even a bit disappointing for the price. The burger was decent but could they find better bacon? The last time we went it was so tough that my knife wouldn't cut it. Tonight I asked for crispy bacon and it was as flimsy as raw bacon. The fries were so cold that we sent back both plates, and I never send back food. They didn't even bother to comp the $7 app. 

The service can be pretty disappointing too. The last visit they cleared away most of our empty beer glasses except for one that was nearly empty and brought the food out and the waitress almost walked away like we were all set. We had to get her attention mid-turn to order drinks.

It's a bit pricey and not really worth it. $18 for a burger and an extra $2.50 for bacon. Plus all of the beer will cost $10 or more when you factor in tax and tips. We decided to blacklist it. It's not as good as it used to be and the prices aren't worth it.
author: Chris S.

description:
Believe the hype.  And believe this: you might not know it yet, but you definitely want the "mushrooms on toast" which is almost like a slice of (non-tomato sauce) luxury pizza.  It's got some magical savory sauce on there, and a generous covering of melted burrata.  Two staffers recommended it and man were they right.  

The "daily roast" was some short ribs when we went, and our server recommended pairing it with the Anvil ESB, which stands for "extra special bitter" but could stand for "even, sweet beer" because this one was really sweet.  And in a good, balanced way.

We also had a few other beers (beer snobbery is kind of the point of this place) and our favorite was the "kellerbier."  Also enjoyed the "beer float" which is a scoop of ice cream, topped with a double-nitro dose of old rasputin.

Will come back here when I can plan to arrive again before 6:30 when the tables fill up!
author: Aaron M.

description: What a pleasure - lovely day to eat outside and partake in great lunch/brunch and more than many great beers to choose from. Also the strawberry jam is fantastic! And the service philosophy was always to 'say yes' to any ask we made for off menu requests - including jam (so terrific!)
author: Marcia L.

description:
Sorry, but unfortunately, I don't get the hype. It wasn't bad, but it wasn't as great of a place as I thought it would be either. 

The place is really small (just like everyone has mentioned, try to get here early to get a good spot), so if you don't find a spot, it can be really awkward to just be standing around and be in everyone's way. 

Only came here for drinks, so I can't really say anything about the food, although the menu was a little typical, nothing too crazy, but the food looked good. 

Drinks were ok. They specialize in beers, but I'm definitely more of a "give me your special beer that's brewed in-house" type of person. They had a very large selection and the bartender was very knowledgable, however, I personally thought that the many options deterred be from really enjoying the place because just picking a beer made me so stressed out. 

Anyways, if you like beer, this place is worth a shot. Is it worth the wait? No. Did it live up to the hype? For me, no.
author: Sam B.

description:
Last November, I flew solo to Belgium for the sole purpose of drinking the best beer in the world in its motherland. And for three carb-drenched days, I sat in pubs and at breweries tasting beer after glorious beer, ALL DAY LONG.

It may have been the best three days of my life.

IPAs, you can keep 'em... I'm in it for the saisons, the tripels, the Belgian strongs and my very favorite, the quads.

Imagine my delight (squeeeeeeee!) when I walked into The Monk's Kettle for the first time and found St. Bernardus Abt 12 on tap. This particular quad is widely regarded as one of the best beers in the world (see: http://beeradvocate.com/beer/profile/259/1708), so being gifted the chance to drink it in draft form was exactly that: a gift. They also carry Tripel Karmeliet in bottles, which I order if the StB Abt 12 isn't available.

The beer menu is wonderfully-curated with at least several standouts in each category. I'd probably visit more often if Monk's Kettle wasn't so perpetually crowded and loud, but that's the price of being popular. Also, don't pass over the food here - in true brasserie fashion, the menu includes accessible but elevated dishes that complement the beer... think pretzels and burgers, but also duck leg cassoulet and roasted chicken. And don't forget: the kitchen stays open 'til 1am daily!
author: Jelena Z.

description: Cute little joint that provided shelter from the El Niño. You can't sit at a table unless you plan on ordering a full meal. So we obliged. I had the fried chicken sandwich which is legit fried and breaded, and kind of bland when eaten by itself. The slaw and sauce definitely take it up a notch. The bun is chunky, on top and bottom. Too much for my personal taste. Not a big fry person but they were salty and crunchy. Personally, I think it's an overpriced burger ($17). Ambiance is chill, door guy is rad and server was reasonably cordial. Great for dates if you get a booth otherwise bar provides some intimate seating as well.
author: Tallestbird R.

description:
Finally!  After wanting to try this place for nearly 2 years, this little spot did not disappoint.

My boyfriend is a big Belgian ale aficionado, so this was definitely one of the best spots to hit up.  Their selection of beer (and beer on tap) is more than substantial and curated wonderfully.  I mean pages and pages and pages of beer!  Local breweries, Belgians (of course), stouts (my favorite), IPAs, cider, and plenty more that I can't even pronounce from all over the world.  

Located right in the heart of the Mission, you can't expect anything less than hipster chic.  The ambiance was warm and inviting; the bartenders are extremely knowledgable about the various types of beer and they were very helpful with recommendations because I had no idea what I wanted to drink; and to top it all off, the food was amazing.  I had the Duck Leg Cassoulet.  It was so tender and marinated to perfection.  I gobbled up the entire plate and I kept wanting more!

Overall, a very solid gastropub.  The space isn't exactly big, so do expect to wait a while if you want a table.  However, you can alway snatch a seat at the bar and order your food there as well.  Good food, good times, I'm sold!
author: Cecilia S.

description:
Great space, huge selection of beers, yummy food, good service.  

I like this place, and hopefully I'll find my way back here in the future.  I came here with my friend on a Thursday around 5:30pm, and thankfully it was before it got crowded so we were quickly seated at the bar.  I actually didn't get any beer, so I had two glasses of wine - a white and a red, both of which I enjoyed.  

We also ordered a pretzel which came with some yummy mustards, and it was freaking AWESOME.  This is something that I would not think to order myself, so I'm glad my friend decided to get it because it was really good.  Recommended.  We also got an order of large fries, which also came with mustardy dipping sauces.  Good, too.

I liked the vibe of this place and would love to come back here to try more stuff on the menu.  Just make sure you come a little earlier; I noticed that the place started to get crowded about an hour after we arrived, so best avoid that.
author: Vivian C.

description: A great place to go to spend 33.50 on a distributed beer I bought for 14, for example. More outrageous mark ups than wine in restaurants. At least that's for dining in. 25% off to go makes this the exact same beer I have for literally twice the price. Sandwiches are 16-18?! Doesn't get worse than that. They make Thomas Keller restaurants sound cheap! As someone who is not a sucker, I will go elsewhere.
author: Lawrence W.

description:
If you're going here to drink beer, by all means come in droves; I had a stout here whose flavor I won't soon forget (though the name has already flown), and in general they had a wide and impressive selection of beer. Our server was obviously really into the beers he was recommending to us and guided us well based on our preference. 

They had a slim and impressive food menu, but with only one vegetarian/vegan option (both at once; you know how it works) for the main course, and it was really good, though not gluten free. If you are a no-meat, no-gluten type, this is probably not the place for you. 

We sort of reluctantly ordered an appetizer, which blew me away with its awesome quality. It was mushrooms and cheese on a thick slice of bread, advertised--in a total undersell--as mushroom and cheese on toast. We couldn't have been more pleased with this appetizer.

Pro tip: The daily roast (if it shows up on your bill) is the daily special, whether or not it's actually a roast.
author: Christina R.

description: I had a burger here.  Yes, just a burger.   One might ask how a burger can be great, and I can only answer that they need to try this burger.   it really is that good.
author: Matt V.

description:
Excellent place for beer lovers.  Around 20 beers on tap and many many bottles (possibly 100+).  Kind of expensive but totally worth it (Pints $7-$10).  Didn't try the food.  

If you are a craft beer lover, this place must be visited!
author: Michael G.

description:
If I want attitude, I'll go see my mom.

If I want beer, I'll hit up the nearest frat party and dust off my college id. 

If I want a pretzel, I'll go to Wetzel's.

If I want dry fish, I'll open a can of Chicken of the Sea. 

Ok, so apparently I'm the minority here but there was nothing noteworthy about Monk's Kettle other than their pretentious staff, overpriced beer, poorly executed food (read: disgusting "daily roast" of fish), and the ridiculously overrated $4.50 pretzel (7x7's Big Eat List) which was essentially a dinner roll that you can get free at a steakhouse. 

Hmmmm, did I miss the beer made with unicorn piss on the menu?

OTHER NOTES:
*The most overrated place in SF I've been to. 
*Small and cramped. Not allowed to sit at a table until your entire party is there even if you order drinks and apps.
*Perfect for beer aficionados: 5+ pages beer selection.
*Food was 2.5 stars at most (due to chef change in 2011?)
--Pretzel ($4.50) was meh: http://bit.ly/18uYCtV. I prefer Wetzel's.
--Whipped Bone Marrow Bread ($9) was like a slice of levain with whipped butter: http://bit.ly/198ASb7. Popcorn was stale and drenched in oil.
--Charcuterie ($18) was mediocre: http://bit.ly/16Pn2KZ. Homemade apple compote was good though.
--The Daily Roast of Yellowtail ($25) was overcooked, oversalted and dry: http://bit.ly/198Beyv. It was just bad. So bad. 
--Chocolate Stout Bread Pudding ($8) was the best thing of the night: http://bit.ly/189k6eP. Chocolate-coffee taste which went will the creamy sweet vanilla.
*Our waiter was cool but the other staff were epitome of pretentiousness. Please don't talk smack about your customers in plain sight.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
A meal for 2 will be over $100.00. I wasn't all that impressed considering the price. We came here late night after a show at the Roxie, because it was close by. It's a very nice place inside, and perfect for a date night; very intimate and dark. They have a full bar, and a very cool selection of brews.

We got started with some beers (2) - Jahrhundert (500 ml) Dortmunder Lager Ayinger, Aying, Germany -$10.50 each - Pretty refreshing

Frech Onion Soup - $9.00 - Awful, awful, awful. It was way too sweet. I even told her it was too sweet, but she didn't offer to take it off the bill. Oh well. 
 
Duck leg confit - panzanella, blackberries, beets, golden raisins, radish, mustard greens - $27.00 - The skin was too tough. I don't mind parts of it to have that nice crispy quality, but it just seemed overcooked altogther.
 
Hanger Steak - asparagus, potatoes, carrots, mango, chimichurri - $28.00 - This steak was done perfectly. 

Chocolate Bread Pudding - $9.00 - This was the best part of the meal. Hot, moist, decadent bread pudding dusted with powdered sugar. It reminded me of a lava cake. So, so good. 

When we went to sit down, at the table beside us sat a couple with a very drunk young lady who hated her food, and refused to pay for it. How do I know? Because she spent 30 minutes repeating herself, going on and on about how "that's disgusting, and I should have to pay for this!" Over, and over, and over, and over. We were happier once they left. 

So, $102.00 later, I really enjoyed the $9.00 bread pudding.
author: Shane N.

description:
Okay, I'm going to start off with the fact that I'm not a beer person. I don't drink beer a lot, and I'm pretty shallow when it comes to beer. My favorite part about gastropubs with craft beer is that they usually have fun, hip food. That's me being completely honest.

I came here with my girlfriends and honestly had a great time. We got seated right away, surprisingly, on a Saturday evening. It became crowded right after though.

Food we ordered:
Cornmeal fried oyster, cucumber ketchup, house hot sauce: It was really good, actually. I love oysters prepared any way! The cucumber ketchup was kind of relish-y, and I loved it.
Fries, hop salt, house muster: It wasn't anything fabulous or special, but I always need my fries!
Chopped kale salad, dried apricots, toasted quinoa, almonds, pear vinaigrette: It was a solid salad. I loved the toasted quinoa on it! They added crunch, kind of like healthy croutons!
Mushrooms on toast, burrata, fine herbs: Honestly, I don't think it was particularly worth ordering. The burrata was too heavy. The toast was delicious, and so were the mushrooms, but it was just way too much.
Monk's daily roast, which was wild boar with mashed potatoes, cherry tomoatoes, and broccoli rabe: SO GOOD! Not gamey at all, perfect medium rare, delicious veggies.

Some of the food was just amazing, and others were just average or sub-par... It's a cool place, but not someplace I'd come back to if I fly back up there.
author: Patricia L.

description:
Came here for a drink on a Friday night. The place was packed to the rafters, with the two of us initially fighting just for standing room before scavenging seats at the bar. It's loud, loud as hell, so maybe don't come here on that intimate date night you're planning.

We didn't try their food, but the beer list was very satisfying. I got a strong (8% ABV) IPA that the bartender recommended to me (I do love me some hops), and it was exactly what I was looking for to round off my Friday night. Prices are a little steep, but I could justify them given the variety and the pub's location on Mission. We spent a fun hour or so here, complementing our conversation by eavesdropping on the people around us. All in all, a fun place, but just a wee bit loud if you were coming for dinner as well.
author: Leela S.

description:
Amongst the rifraf of the 16th St area, Monks Kettle is tucked away like a well-manicured big toe. 

I was suprised at how nice it was inside, given the liquor stores and dive bars surrounding. The wait was about an hour for a table (on a Monday night), so we sat at the bar and ended up ordering there.

The bartender was a tall, strawberry-blonde drink of water: attentive, informative. We ordered the mussels with a side of fries and the potatoe, pesto, goat cheese flatbread. Mussels first, my friend had a beer (not sure which one) but it apparently paired well with the mussels and crusty bread, so the dreamy bartender advised him to have a mussel, a bite of bread dipped in the garlicky broth, and a drink of beer for ultimate enjoyment. He did as he was told, and was very happy with the effect. I personally thought the mussels were lackluster, but he seemed to like them a lot.

We contemplated sharing a burger but were full once we had polished off the delicious fries, mussels, and the flatbread. Oh, that flatbread: it embodied my personal favorite flavors of pesto, salty rosemary potatoes, and creamy goat cheese. We couldn't finish it, so I'm going to nom on the rest for dinner tonight.

It's a classier gastropub so I was a little underdressed in my gym clothes, probably won't do that again. A bit pricey, $64 for all of the above, but with 24 beers on tap and pages more in the bar book, plus all the tasty options for food, I think it's worth it.
author: Crystal C.

description:
In my opinion, five damn stars! 

Here are the reasons why: 

1) 5 PAGES OF BEER SELECTIONS 
- It's hard to find places with a huge beer selection in SF. Monk's Kettle has the best selection with the best quality beer I've ever experienced in the city thus far! I love Belgian light beers & I was recommended the Jombe de Bois & I was more than pleased. 

2) BACON-WRAPPED SHRIMP W/ CRISPY POLENTA 
- Whats not to love about bacon?! The combination of the shrimp & polenta w/ the sauce they served was a bite of heaven. 

3) BURGER W/ ONION JAM & AGED WHITE CHEDDAR
- I have a serious hankering for burgers almost weekly, so of course, I had to order one at Monk's Kettle. It was DELICIOUS. I think the onion jam is what really did it for me. It was a nice touch. I've had bad experiences with burgers being too oily & imbalanced as far as taste goes, but Monk's Kettle created a well balanced, flavorful burger. It was perfectly medium-rare & not oily at all. 

4) MONK'S DAILY ROAST 
- My boyfriend ordered this. It was a roasted pork shoulder w/ butternut squash & fennel. The meat was tender & he was really happy with his dish. I was surprised because he's not usually big on pork. 

5) GREAT SERVICE
- We were lucky to have an awesome server who made the best recommendations. He was friendly & made sure to frequently check up on us. 

Overall, great experience. In my opinion, definitely better than those overpriced, overhyped joints like NOPA & Marlowe. 

We'll be back VERY soon!
author: Sylvia N.

description:
I hate giving 5 stars, I really do. And I considered giving them 4 because the place is always full, and kind of loud, but I decided I can't be the guy who penalizes a business for being successful, right? 

Look, The Bay has no shortage of craftlike beer houses, or restaurants, to be sure, but Monks Kettle has a beer list that will make your eyes go wide with excitement for really good prices. And the bartenders? They KNOW their beer and they're excited to talk about it! 

If you do want to go in and ask for a recommendation (which I have and its always spot on) know what style you like and maybe throw out a brand or two. Theyll give you 2 or 3 options and tell you why they're suggesting it. Go with it. Be good to these folks, don't hem and haw, it's too busy. 

I was in last night with 3 first timers, and our tender poured us a few "rounds" of samplers. Those glasses are f-ing adorable. No Sticky Monkey this time around but hot damn that Darkest Hour scotch ale was bomb. 

And the food. The food is always off the chain. One of the best burgers hands down I've had. I've also done the salads, which are great, the rissoto which is thick and hearty but a little heavy on the pepper, the scallops and the Monks Feast. Nomf. But I think the crowning achievement here is the pretzel rolls. Oh god so good.
author: Patrick M.

description: Thrillist was correct and this was definitely one of the best gastropubs that I've ever been to!  My fiance and I came here for dinner one night while in SF.  We each had the burger and it was delicious and by far one of the best I've ever had.  The beer selection was impressive, especially for an IPA obsessed beer nerd like myself, and I had a local IPA from Berkeley which was quite good.  Highly recommend this place if you're looking for a good gastropub in SF.  Also, a great place to come on a date, or just to hang out and grab drinks with friends.
author: Matthew V.

description:
Beer Haven.

Taps and bottles allow you to broadly explore the tapestry of beer styles that make up this glorious beverage.

Like many who come here I am constantly looking for new breweries and have exposed myself to dozens of brewing styles over a decade. Even with this robust knowledge there are lessons for me to learn within the pages of Monks Kettle's beer bible/menu. Oh if only I lives in the Mission District!
author: Bryan W.

description:
Took a friend out to go barhopping so I decided to take her here.

Monk's Kettle is always crowded but only because it's pretty small. We sat in the far back on stools. A place where you'd think you'd be forgotten, but the servers checked up on us pretty frequently.

We ordered beers. I ordered a boysenberry beer ($13) and she ordered a blanche de Bruxelles ($11?). They poured it out in front of us in nice glasses and left the bottle with us. 

While drinking, we kept looking at the menu and we kept drawing on the chalkboards they had available for our amusement. 

I honestly love this place. Great atmosphere and friendly people. I want to go back during lunch hour though just to try the food. Burgers and beers would be nice.
author: Sofia R.

description:
Silence.

That's what happens when four burgers arrived our table.  Nobody said a word.  Everybody put their heads down and chowed away, occasionally licking the beef juice off their hands and elbows.

5 minutes and 32 seconds. 

That's how long it took me to inhale my entire burger, beating three other men at my table.  When it comes to delicious burger (and ramen), I don't breathe.  I just eat. 

The perfectly cooked, slightly pink in the center burger patty harmonized perfectly with the melted cheese.  All the ingredients were fresh and well-flavored.  It was so, so good.

The beer was definitely a little on the pricy side, but they do have a large selection.  Our waiter was very knowledgeable in the types of beer they carry.  The end tab for the four of us was close to $200.  Be sure to order a "digestiv" to help sooth your stomach after that big meal (and four glasses of beer).
author: Peggy S.

description:
Love their beer selection and food. 
The tap is around 30 beers and bottles around two hundred. The beer menu is very well organized, once you got it is very easy to make your choice. 
Their burger is mandatory on the first visit but as you come back over and over you end up trying everything in the menu. Cornmeal fried oysters, pretzel, mushroom risotto and chicken under a brick are some of my favorites items in the food menu. 
It is a very small place so sometimes is hard to get in (specially on diner time) but it is worth the effort. Daytime or late night is easier...
author: Cristian L.

description: Cool atmosphere. We got the cheese/meat board...way to expensive for a tiny bit of cheese and country sausage that wasn't very good. Good beer tap selection. Pretty good wine selection.
author: Cortny R.

description:
Yes, it's extremely difficult to get a seat at Monk's Kettle on most evenings, but have you been here for lunch? On a Saturday? It's fantastic.

The menu is great--fresh seasonal salads, good stews in the winter. But really its about the beers. Just so many great ones, generally helpful staff and those windows that pour in sunlight on the nice days.
author: Paul C.

description: Had a memorable dinner last night. The night started off with the warmest welcome from Wyatt at the door and the friendliest and most efficient service by Lauren and Yuri. The ambience was comfortable and friendly and the cheese and beer pairing was fantastic. I got the "part time lover" pale ale and it was perfect. I wish we lived closer to this perfect spot. We would have been there all the time:)
author: Priya V.

description:
Came here late night by accident with friends and had a blast! 

The food is OH MY GOD delicious! The boys both had the chicken and us girls had the burgers. Everyone was eating their food with joy and satisfaction! The food is really good ! 

I love the vibe of the place, laid back yet trendy and the staff makes you feel very comfy. 

Oh and do try their carrot cake, you will fall in love, I guarantee it!
author: Tamara S.

description:
One of their top drafts is the Hibiscus IPA. I love IPA, the hoppier the better. However, I felt the hibiscus watered down and weakened the IPA a whole lot. 

The Daily Roast was okay....the brisket was super tender and all but I didn't care for it much. I liked their Fresh Ground Burger way better - very flavorful. But next time for a $15 burger, I'd expect them to not be stingy on the side of fries!
author: Briget P.

description:
Talk about a killer beer selection! Came here for dinner on a Friday, we thought there was no way three of us would be able to get a table but we were able to swoop a table right away. I had heard about their beer selection being stellar and constantly updating and I was not disappointed. I like beer but don't know a ton about it so I often rely on the server to help me pick. Our server was a total doll and helped me pick out a great IPA. 

The food was SO good, I wasn't expecting much just standard pub/bar food but was totally surprised by how good it was. The pretzels knots are unreal, I could have eaten a whole one to myself. We also got the burger, mushroom risotto and mussels. We shared everything and I was happy with all of our choices, I think the risotto might have been my favorite. 

Monk's Kettle has a super friendly, laidback vibe. I feel like I could have spent a few hours just hanging out there. It definitely gets crowded but they handle it well and it doesn't feel overwhelming. Can't wait to go back!
author: Lizzy U.

description: While the focus of this gastropub seems to be their draft beer, both of our visits were for a late afternoon lunch without beer.    Service was efficient and friendly with just the right amount of occasional stops by our table to see if we needed anything.   The smoked trout salad was better than expected as was the hamburger and french fries.  The french fries were particularly notable in that they appeared hand cut and while fried could have easily passed for baked with the visible absence of any greasiness.    Place has a nice vibe.
author: David R.

description: Visited this place after dinner with friends last night. The place is pretty tiny, but they do have a couple of outdoor tables. I didn't care too much for the place, but I'll give them a 4 star because the service was great and the staff that assisted us were friendly. It's also definitely more of a place for beer fans, which I'm not. They also have some wine available.
author: Trina V.

description: They have this weird policy that the tables are only for dinners. We (group of 4) stayed their for 1 hour. They gave us this isolated corner facing chalk board where you cannot communicate properly with other.  The whole hour we were they, most of their tables were empty. This is the second time that happened to us. We are prolly done with the place.
author: Sam P.

description: Hopped by Monk's Kettle last night for a drink and was very impressed. They have a wonderful beer list and it is a very cozy/intimate little bar. The service was a little slow, but the bar was very crowded (even on a Wednesday night at 10pm). It's definitely worth the 20+ beers on flight including some rarities and interesting finds. Definitely check them out if you are a beer snob! Also, I forgot to mention they also have an extensive bottle list as well! Great selection!
author: Lauren H.

description: Great service and excellent food and drinks. I had the trout and I could taste that it was prepared with love. I paired the fish with a refreshing crisp sav blanc. The food and drink menu have many excellent options. Good place for meat eaters and vegetarians alike, wine or beer lovers. There is no liquor at this place but like I said there are plenty of good options for wine and beer. My sister ordered a stout to go with her fried chicken sandwich and she said it was the best stout she has ever had. Our friend ordered the chocolate bread pudding with ice cream. It was delicious as well. My trout dish had great flavor with pecans, pear and brown butter squash. So amazing. From the door guy to our waitress, the service was friendly. Will recommend and will return! Thank you for the excellent food.
author: Mary R.

description:
The wait is always very long here. The pretzel bun is well worth it though! The staff are always nice and suggest great beers to try, try even brought more samples after I ordered a beer. It's kinda pricey and portions are small-medium, but still a great place for dinner.  

Wouldn't recommend the outside seating too much. The street smells like piss and that can easily kill your appetite.
author: Tulsi M.

description:
By god this bar has some of the tastiest beer that has ever been made (Evil Twin Imperial Donut Stout in particular). I was visiting San Francisco and I liked this bar so much the first time I went that I came back the next night. The bartender was extremely knowledgeable and made great recommendations. 

Further, they have an amazing selection of rare and delicious beers on tap. Even more of a crazy selection of bottles. Reasonably priced!! I could go there every night and never be unhappy. 

Only downside is that it's a pretty small space and I don't think you can sit at the tables unless you order food.
author: William W.

description: Street parking is close to impossible but there are private lots for ten dollars or so nearby. Bart is also within a five minute walk. The staff are friendly. There is an extremely large and tasty selection of beers and other drinks available. Wine is served in very generous portions. The mussels were okay, and the burger was cooked just right. The food also has nice accents such as bread that accompany the mussels toasted and complete with grill marks. The main attraction, however, are clearly the local beers.
author: Kimberly H.

description: This place would get 5 stars just for the beer and as a bar alone.We stopped by for some beers & a little something to eat. The beer was outstanding and the selection extensive.Then the food came....Amazing!!! Who would expect such a high level of food at a bar??? We ordered the pretzel knot & fondue, yum you cant go wrong with beer, pretzel(homemade) & cheese can you? Also had the cheese platter and the bone marrow on toast which was just soooo good, melt in your mouth  wonderful. On my next visit I want to go for dinner. Cant wait!!!
author: Karen R.

description:
This place is great. I've been there many times. The menu is small, but food is consistently good. Great beer selection both on draft and in the bottle. Some servers are awesome about pairing beer to your meal, and others are not as good. 

There's usually a long wait so plan on spending a lot of time there. If you sit in at the bar in the back you can draw on the chalk wall while you wait and enjoy a beer, which is awesome! Meals with beers can get a little pricey. Get the pretzel knots for apps... sooooo good.

I wish there was more space to stand while waiting for a table but oh well, worth it anyways! I'll be back many many more times.
author: Mandy A.

description:
Great dining experience here at the Monk's Kettle. We went on a Sunday night around 6:30pm and there was a 30-45 min wait for 2 people- I usually expect this kind of wait for popular restaurants even on an off night. The host took our name and number and we went next door to Delirium for a quick cheapo drink. When we were seated, the waiter let us take our time and didn't rush any part of our meal which I really appreciate especially at a busy well-known restaurant. 

We ordered the pretzel not- YUM and the kale salad with dried apricots and quinoa that was surprisingly delicious and refreshing. Then we split the bigeye that was outta this world. I'm not a huge beer guru but they are known for their awesome selection. If I didn't have thousands more restaurants to try in the mission, I would definitely go back!
author: Sarah H.

description:
Well. I really love one item on their menu, the mushrooms on toast. However, I've officially reached my tolerance threshold with their doorman. 

Congrats on being busy and all, but why can't you be nice about it??

I'm done. There are enough great restaurants in this city with warmer welcomes and friendlier way of handling wait times.
author: Nicole G.

description: Great service. They have large good choice of beer. The food is original and good. I recommend!
author: Alexis B.

description: Never going back here! My girlfriend was meeting 2 friends there for diner in a cold SF night. The rude waitress made her wait outside, even though there clearly was space inside for people to wait for a table.... Ah the awful service of most overly trendy places in the mission.
author: Mikkel R.

description: I went to SF with my boyfriend and saw this place on Yelp with the best reviews on a great beer selection.... and let me tell you it's a pretty great selection of beers on tap. Not only was the beer selection great, the atmosphere, the service, and the food-dont get me started on that, but I will anyways- was AMAAAAZING. The fries with the hop salt was perfection for any late night snack. The burgers are to die for and worth the price, but if you are going to get the steak(most expensive dish on the menu) I do recommend that you taste it with a great stout. If you are going to eat it without chugging it down with anything other than water than you definitely won't get the full satisfaction of the steak. All in all, if you are a beer lover and a foodie definitely try this place. You won't be disappointed.
author: Jasmine V.

description: I love this place.  I'm not a beer expert, but somehow Monk's Kettle makes me feel like I'm in the know.  The warm pretzel is delish and the burger is pretty fantastic.  A solid mac and cheese and a pretty darn good risotto. What more can you ask for when having good beer.  It gets pretty crowded so late night meals are the best option if you don't want to wait an hour.
author: Kamael S.

description: Kerri H did a fabulous job: she is an expert server and knows her beer upside down, backwards, and forwards!
author: Dan P.

description:
The service was amazing. From the front door ladies who helped us score some seats at the bar so I could finally eat (a one and a half hour wait at 10:15pm still!  What?!) to the two bartenders who took our order and served us beer and keep things light and airy, most of the stars go to you. 

The rest goes to the fried oyster with cucumber ketchup and hot sauce. That bite (I tried to savor it into two bites, but let's be real here) was amazing. That cucumber relish thing was so good and perfectly cut the briney-ness of the corn crusted oyster. 

Our burgers tasted good but mine was cooked too rare and the meal ended up being too soft texturally. The burger was mushy, the bun was soft, the onion jam didn't provide crunch, grease and burger juices were spilling everywhere. And the fries were SO salty.  Like someone had a heavy hand and then clubbed it to death with salt. 

Honestly if I didn't have the burger and just ordered more oysters this place would have gotten 4 stars. But im coming back. Some mushroom risotto and corn beef croquettes' got my name on em.
author: Walerz B.

description: The location, atmosphere, food, beer, service--everything--was scrumptious.  The Friend Finder and Velvet Merlin beers not only have great names, but also were delicious. And, they even gave us a glass of the Friend Finder on the house.  The staff was so darn nice and attentive. The mussels were the yummiest that I have ever eaten; perfectly prepared. My husband swooned over the pretzel and cheese fondue as well as the fresh donut holes.  We can't wait to go back!
author: Nicole J.

description:
I don't know how long this place has been on our "must-visit" SF list. Years and years probably. 

The beer list was impressive. I've never seen a $65 beer before, or an alcoholic root beer (it was tasty, by the way). Tons of sours. I will admit that I was a bit disappointed with their selection of witbiers and hefs. So I went with the Finnriver black currant sparkling cider and it was a nice balance of sweet and off-dry.  

The place was A LOT smaller than I thought it'd be. Luckily, we were able to snag seats at the bar. The bartender was friendly and efficient, though unengaging. The wall of glassware notable. We didn't try any food, but I hear it's good.
author: Christine N.

description:
I'm a sucker for upsells and these f*ckers totally got me. 

It's not that I like or expect upgrades or even have any kind of base level standard for service or products, but I just feel bad saying 'no' sometimes, especially after a 10 minute long spiel about the product their trying to get to me to buy that I just do the math in my head that if I just say 'yes', I might not be able to eat for a week, but at least I'll be able to get this person to stop guilt-tripping me into getting whatever it is I'm about to buy. 

On the night we went it was literally packed beyond the fire department's mandated capacity and the charm of the Midwestern-nice bartenders suckered me into getting this stupid drink I didn't actually want. You see, originally I'd wanted Tiger Blood from one of my personal favorites, Mikkeller, but was informed that they'd "just run out". Ok. Fine. I'll take a $6 or $7 Pliny the Elder, except instead of getting me that beer, the bartender went on and on and on about this other bottled Mikkeller beer that I just had to try and it's so exclusive and limited and blah blah in between slipping in that it's "kind of pricey". Finally, I give up all Pliny hope and just say 'yes'. Give me the f*cking whatever it is bottle for x amount of dollars. .... .... ... ... and then I get a wine glass with my bottle of beer poured in and a tab for $18. M*ther. F*cker. This drink officially costs more than my entire outfit, including skivvies. I repeat: F*ck. 

So I pay for the stupid thing and take a sip of this 'so called' suped up IPA and it's f*cking farmhouse as hell. Like syrup-y, sour, sweet, and a whole combination of other things that were nothing like he'd described in his beer rant. Poo. 

So now I'm sitting here feeling bad (like I would have in the first place had I not purchased the stupid thing after his 10-year long description) because I'm teetering between 3 and 4 stars after paying what I'd consider an absolutely astronomical amount for a drink that I ultimately hated, but was happy just to get kind service in a crowded bar that I'd normally expect to be ignored in. 

In the end, I'm going to give 4-stars with an imagined asterisk warning others of the upsell tactic here, since it appeared to be a common theme based on what I'd seen from the patrons that approached the bar after me.
author: Candice G.

description: Relaxed atmosphere, wonderful drink selection and friendly bartenders. What more can you ask for?
author: Jane H.

description:
Great Beer Selection, that on it's own is 4 stars. Fried oysters were okay, it was interesting to try their cucumber ketchup. You're not going to believe it but we mainly came here for their pretzels. I know what you're thinking, its just pretzels. It is so damn delicious. You're not going to regret coming here and taking a break.

Nothing can be better than a great glass of beer and a pretzel.

YUMMY!
author: Mia L.

description: Had a great lunch here in Labor Day, friendly bartender recommended fried chicken sandwich and I'm so happy I listened!   Moist, juicy, tender, still thinking about it!   Great fries too.  I'm not a beer person, and bartender helped me about (and I didn't feel condescended!).
author: Courtney M.

description: Amazing beer selection, fantastic service and delicious food. Had the pretzels and fries pickles and enjoyed the sunshine on the patio (dog friendly is always a plus!). Will definitely return the next time we are in SF.
author: Julie M.

description:
I believe that all good things are worth the wait. That being said, stand in line, Monk's Kettle will not disappoint. 

The beer selection alone deserves 5 stars. They have drinking glasses for each different type of beer you order. This place is legit!

I had to minus one star because although there were tables open, the hostess made us sit at the bar because all four people in our party didn't want to order meals. We had to squish into the bar to have beer and appetizers. We would have been in and out if we had a booth but sitting at the bar was crowded and insane so everything took a little longer.

Overall, excellent drinks and a great time!
author: Courtney O.

description: We breezed though here on a Saturday night and took a seat at the bar. Nice bartender with good suggestions. They have a great beer list, we were not eating so I did not pay attention to their food situation.
author: Eric G.

description:
We only drank here so only giving 4 stars since not sure how the food is. 
But as far as drinking places go this is a great place!!! 
The beer list is beyond crazy big!!! Great amount of drafts and good variety! The bottled beer list is divided by type which is helpful. The beers range in price! 
They have other options besides beer. 
It has a great atmosphere and part of the bar has a chalkboard which is was fun!
author: Allison P.

description:
The food is excellent and the beer selection is out of this world. But the service varies somewhat. Some nights the bartenders are your BFF's and other nights, they seem to care about anything but you. It wouldn't be such a big deal but since you can only have a table if you're there for dinner, when you are sitting at the bar right in front of several people, you expect the service to be a step UP, not DOWN!

Scallops and kale salad are both excellent. 

Love the ambiance, food, etc but I do wish the service were a bit more consistent.
author: Karen G.

description:
Monk's Kettle is fantastic. Tons of beer (draft and bottles), fancier-than-average bar food and awesome service. Personal favorites include the pretzel knots and risotto. Simply delicious! Can't wait to return and try more off both the beer and food menus.

We lucked out and got a table right away, but there aren't many of them. Be prepared to either wait for one or post up at the bar.
author: Lauren C.

description:
This place is aiteee. Came here on a Monday night and it was surprisingly crowded for being 5PM. This place is really small and cramped like most SF places and has a hipster vibe. They offer a large beer selection and the beers my friends ordered were surprisingly tasty. The food however was quite disappointing and expensive for what it was. 

The popular beef hash croquettes  with whipped bone marrow and aioli ($9) was SO bland! It only came with 3 pieces and we left one piece because it wasn't very good. My spent grain & chick pea burger ($14) was alright, the patty was big and the texture was soft and mushy. The best part of my meal was probably the hop salt fries. My friend's chicken sandwich was not bad either, the chicken was juicy but it had a charcoal-y taste to it. We all agreed that the regular ground beef burger was the best since it was moist and juicy and had an abundance of flavor (probably due to the bacon). However, it was $17 (extra $2 for bacon) for regular 'ol ground beef when I can get a truffle burger at Umami for 12 bucks...not exactly worth the price tag. We also tried the chocolate bread pudding and  I expected it to be much better. It didn't seem to have the same firm/dense texture as other bread puddings I've tried. This one was more like a wet sponge cake but it wasn't horrible or anything. I'd only recommend coming here if you want to grab a unique beer and maybe snack on fries.
author: Jenny O.

description:
Have always wanted to come here for the food and finally had the chance to last night. Came with a group of friends and we all ordered beers. As you are probably aware by now, this place has an insane beer collection. As a girl who likes mildly hoppy beers, I recommend the Modern Times beer they have on draft (think it's described as a hoppy wheat or something of that sort).

We ordered cornmeal fried oysters and pretzels to start. I don't normally like cooked oysters, but these were damn good - probably due to the relish type sauce that came on top. The breading wasn't too thick so the textures were good. We all agreed that the pretzel was probably the best pretzel any of us have ever had. It's shaped more like a roll than a traditional knot and comes with melty cheese and this absurdly good grainy mustard. Highly recommend both, but if you're gonna pick one go with the pretzel.

My boyfriend and I shared the burger and the duck leg confit. The burger was perfectly cooked and tasted great, but nothing particularly special. The fries are either too soft or too crispy - overall not very good.

The duck leg confit was soooo delicious. Served atop a salad with blackberries that paired well with the savory flavor of the duck. Highly recommend.

Overall I think this place is worth the hype if you like beer and you're willing to spend a little extra on food.
author: Amy Y.

description: Amazing service, beer , and food. It really was overwhelming to decide what beer to get.
author: Steve P.

description:
NOT IMPRESSED. 

EVEN PARKING IS A BITCH AROUND HERE. 

My friend and I came here for lunch today right as it opened. The first thing I saw was the huge shelf of beer glasses of different types. For a gastropub, this place was pretty swanky on the inside. 

Outside, I swear to god my friend and I walked past it looking for it because there's no FXXKN signs. Hella lame. 

FOOD: (-2)

Duck Leg Cassoulet - meat was falling off the bone and eh..could have been marinated better. I honestly didn't taste much seasoning in here than I did with the flageoulet beans. Meh.

Apple Beer - Not bad. I tasted more of the yeast than the apples. I honestly don't know shit about beer, so its whatever for me. 

Seared salmon with Crab something special - Tasted ok, its whatever. 

TOTAL: $84 FXXKING DOLLARS FOR LUNCH?!

Shoulda went to a taqueria...

Service: (-1)

Lady, you mumble too much. Half the time, IDK wtf you said. Too much beer before dealing with us? Eh...SERVICE SUCKS. 

Pricing for drinks here are hella overpriced. HOLY FXXK mang!
author: Jason C. J.

description: A friend and I came in here for lunch on a Saturday afternoon.  Our food was really good.  I had a great cheeseburger and fries.   Nice atmosphere and hipster place.   Great staff and servers as well.  Keep up the good work.
author: Ann R.

description: We got into town Monday afternoon and went to this place to grab a beer. Super intimate atmosphere and they have a ton of beers on tap as well as bottled. The bartenders were friendly and prompt. We had the fries, which were good. The ketchup definitely tastes likes it's made in house. Its a small space so seats at the bar are limited but we got lucky. Definitely worth checking out!
author: Lex M.

description: Management responded to my issue, and I hate to leave a bad review over one negative experience, when I have had many fun times in the past.  They have a great menu and usually a good vibe.  Try the fried oysters but ask for extra sauce, it's super tasty.
author: Ryan F.

description: Great bar, with more beers on tap than you can imagine. Great service and get there early on the weekend if you want to even get in the joint.
author: Aaron R.

description:
Delicious!!! Amazing food and the beer selection is fantastic. 

There's not as many beers as Abbott's Cellar, just around the corner, but who cares! You don't need that much choice anyways! 

The food is amazing.... There was 3 of us and we ordered the following: 
- Starters: Bone marrow on toast
- Starters: Mussels
- Mains: Burgers (x2 because they are THAT good)
- Mains: Scallops

The Bone marrow is whipped so its basically like butter, DELICIOUS BUTTER!!! And they give you pop corn on top and underneath the toast so that you can dip it in the melted bone marrow and taste all the goodness and fat like you've never heard of Weight Watchers before.

The Mussels....did I mention they cook it with Allagash white? Yeah they do that. And of course so are the usual suspects... garlic, chili, green onions.  But they do something magical with it.  If Gandalf made mussels, this is how they would be.  They are juicy and comes right off the shell.  And they are all strangely immaculately clean with none of the usual gunk on the shells or around the mussels.  The sauce was salty like the taste of the sea, but amazingly flavorful the bread (and yes you will want more bread!) it comes with has the perfect blend of crunchy and sponginess which is prefect for dipping. 

Burgers, these babies are pretty darn good. Better than Umami, closest to LA's Father's office Burgers, (which are the god of all burgers IMO).  I don't like burgers, so when there is a burger I do like, its generally pretty daymn good.

Your server may ask you "Would you like to add Bacon on that?" At which point, the only thing you should do is say "HELL YES!".  Yes, yes, you want bacon on that. 

The Scallops...Before I give you the actual description of what they have on the menu.  Let me take you through what I think would be the thought process in coming up with this dish... 

What are the most amazing things you can thing of: 
- Scallops (yeah that's delicious)
- Lobster (fuck yeah!)
- Duck fat (Oh yeah....)
- Potatoes (God's gifts to the Irish) 

Oh and we need a vegetable of some sort.... cherry tomatoes

Oh and of course... BACON!

Put this together and you get... 

"Day Boat Scallops, Duck Fat Potatoes, Cherry Tomatoes, Lobster butter, Bacon."  That is the official description on the menu. 'Nuff said. 

We didn't get desserts, at this point if we were to fill up with more awesome food, we would of exploded. 

My only negative that I could think of was that for $26 there was only 5 scallops on the plate.  In hindsight that was more than enough to fill me up. But $26 for 5 scallops does seem a little pricey. 

Would I go back here? HELL YES! 

Though get in early, they are a small place, so if you want a table or there's more than 4 of you, plan ahead!
author: Maggie F.

description:
Wow, this place is TINY!  That said, it's a solid place to hang out in the Mission.  There are always great beers on, and the food is excellent.

I tend to grab the cheeseburger with bacon, medium rare, when at Monk's Kettle.  It is quite possibly the best burger I've ever eaten.  So juicy, so delicious, and the bacon is an amazing add on.  My wife never added the bacon, don't know what she was thinking!

It is tight quarters in there though, some seating outside which is nice.  If you are inside, hopefully you are the type that likes to eat with strangers because even if you are at a separate table, you are about 6 inches from the next group.  In all, a great place.  A bit pricey, but the food is great and the beer selection always includes a few gems.
author: Scott W.

description: $9.50 for a Pliny and $17 for a fatty dark meet over cooked chicken sandwich ... I think that's the last visit to this overrated spot
author: michael p.

description:
I love this place!  After walking by here many times, and hearing good things about it, I came late on a Sunday night post a movie in Castro.

Lucky for me and my companion, there was no wait, the beer selection was wonderful and he was excited to try a Pliny the Elder for the first time.  We shared a pretzel and burger, both were delicious and hit the spot.  We also got a seat by the window and loved the dim, mysterious and relaxing atmosphere. 

Definitely a place I'll visit again!
author: Yue L.

description:
You know we really had a good experience here. Service was super nice, and staff is very knowledgeable about the items on their menu. The food was good also. We had the pretzel which was good; The fries were also good to average; The toast topped with mushroom was unique and tasted good; And finally the scallops dinner portion ($25), also good. Beer selection is pretty extensive. But I am giving just 3 stars because it just felt average to me. Nothing special. And it's a little on the pricey side.

If you do go, be advised that this place is tiny and you'll most likely need to wait. Our wait was not too bad..30-40 minutes for 2 on a Friday night. Big groups might want to think twice. I'd say go and experience for yourself, and decide.
author: Vol T.

description:
Overrated pretentious and pseudo-hipster. I've tried getting into monk's several times and it's always been overcapacity. When we decided the wait was too long one of the times, The host or doorman told us maybe we should go for a burrito. Clearly we didn't want a burrito, asshole. Keep your snark to yourself. 

When we finally made it to dinner one day this is what we got- Beer comes in SMALLER PORTIONS for The same price you would pay for a pint. The food was OVERPRICED and MEDIOCRE at best. Definitely nothing crave worthy or special. We got the bone marrow croquettes, the chicken sandwich, and the roast chicken. DRY and UNDERSAUCED but edible. The food came in SMALL PORTIONS and pretty much after everyone else who was seated after we were. We were only 2 people on a Tuesday. SERVICE WAS SLOW, and INATTENTIVE. Maybe the asshole at the door was right, next time i will have a burrito instead of waiting around for monks.
author: Carina K.

description:
If you like beer, this is the place to go. I've never seen so many beers on tap.  They do have some wines by the bottle and by the glass, but it's pretty limited, since this isn't their focus.  For me, the best part of the menu was the glossary in the back to study all these special beer related terms.

From the menu, we got corned beef hash croquettes, which were smooth inside, but I didn't really get the whipped bone marrow.  It wasn't amazing, but it was good to go with the drinks.

Servers are super nice and are pretty observant and attentive.  The wait on a Friday night for a party of 2 was almost 2 hours, BUT bar seating is first come first serve.
author: Marilyn H.

description:
I went there last night w/ my sweetie who happens to love IPAs like myself. We decided to do a sampler to see what we liked best. They had four on tap, but one had just run out. The bartender suggested a nicely hopped pale ale from Faction Brewing and three other IPAs for a sampler. We decided to go with his suggestion, then select our pints. The lineup was Faction Pale Ale, Grand Hill IPA, Idiot IPA, and Taco Hands IPA. All four were excellent. I went with the Faction because of the awesome hoppy aroma. It reminded me of Drake's Aroma Coma, but lower alcohol. Nice! My sweetie had the Idiot IPA.

We ate dinner earlier, so we ordered an appetizer of fries to share and they were hot, salty and excellent with our beers.  We were treated very well by the staff, but they were very busy, so the service was adequate but not excellent.

One negative. The place is small, and we ended up by the drafty back door. A new door seal would fix that problem and be more comfortable for patrons on those chilly nights.
author: Jay E.

description: Good selection of beers, service is a little pretentious, and desserts are just okay. It's a crowded small place.  I really wanted to like it though and think it is worth another shot.
author: Jaching H.

description: Best hamburgers in the city!!! They are part chuck part brisket!!! Yum!  They beer selection is unparalleled.  Definitely come for beer week when they tap new kegs.
author: Mark P.

description: Had walked past this place before, thinking to myself, "I ought to come back here." Boy, was I right! This place is the definition of a gastropub. Food is fantastic! Poutine has the most decadent pork gravy. The chicken sandwich we shared puts other fried chicken sandwiches to shame. It's not cheap. Beer and wine prices are on the high end, but it is San Fran. And I'd say it's worth the splurge.
author: Jason L.

description: Omg!! Their White mocha is sooooo yummy!! Must try :) So as their pretzel bread. It paired so good with the beer
author: Rainbow Y.

description:
I first saw this establishment come up on the Food channel and a week later, flew up to S.F. to try it out. 

This place has an awesome selection of brews. They have aged ones that have been fermenting for 3-4 years. Food here is solid, though the portions are a little small. While the selection is great, the pricing is a little high but I suppose that is the premium customers pay for such a wide range of brews.

I'll be back!
author: Amir A.

description: Food was quite tasty - would def recommend the oyster fritters - but was disappointed their staff didn't share the specials with us. We only leaned that there were specials after hearing them read to the table next to us. The food was plenty tasty but hearing these quite delicious sounding options long after we ordered our food really kinda put a damper on the meal.
author: Laura G.

description: Food was so-so but the main issue was the spoiled wine they served. When I complained about it, the snooty waitress said they almost never had such problems, as though I had made it up. I told her I drink wine nearly nightly and that both myself and my friend had tasted it and it was bad. She still gave me attitude but then returned and said that indeed it was spoiled (she and another waiter tasted it) but didn't have the common courtesy to compensate $13 from the bill for the horrible sips of wine we had and for dealing with it. The chicken sandwich was greasy and gross. Not a fan.
author: Kelly M.

description:
Ok, it's hard to find a seat, i don't belong to this city but I don't need to be very bright if i say the Mission it's overcrowded on Fridays and weekends right?
But, if you get inside and grab a seat, its amazing to open that beer bible called "menu" and figure it out what you gonna get. For me its fun, i feel like a 12 year's old kid in the early 90's picking a videogame in the rental store, just looking at the cover. Do you know what i mean?. Hey! and the food it's no bad at all, nice burgers. The service? Depends, one of the bartenders i remembered he was kinda rude, this was long time ago anyway, no resentment. Nice dates with my wife there...ohh so many memories.
author: Claudio L.

description:
One of our stops on a day-drinking adventure in the Mission.

Great assortment of beer and their food was unique and delicious but this place is a little over-priced. 

Friendly server who knew what she was talking about when it came to the beer!
author: Jennifer C.

description: Great food and service. We had a plum cider that was Great. We split the sausage and cheese platter followed by splitting the Bratwurst. Just the right amount of food for 2. Would definitely come again!!!
author: Justin F.

description:
*GASTROPUB (n.) a pub that serves high end beer/ food.   
Just saying, for those who were just as confused as I was by the description/ category The Monk's Kettle fell under.

Several of us came here on a Friday night and I can not reiterate enough that parking was horrendous AND they enforce the "whole party must be present in order to be seated" notion. These two are basically interrelated if everyone drives separately and are competing against one another to find parking, but either way, you can't get seated until the whole party arrives... sudden epiphany huh?

The beer selection was extensive and the wine selection was equally impressive. A whole book was solely dedicated to wine and beer options. However, they do NOT sell any other drinks- no hard alcohol at all. Prices varied, but I'd highly recommend checking out the cost before ordering because some fell into double digits.

In regards to food, we ordered the hop salt fries and pretzels for appetizers. Fries were hot and fresh, but it wouldn't be a worthy pub to frequent if something as simple as fries aren't perfected. The pretzels (fist size- $5 for 1 or 2 for $9) were fresh and doughy, but I highly commend them for the dips (warm oozing cheesy dip and their house mustard dip were orgasmic).

We also had the croquettes (the lime aioli kind of threw us off with the fried goodness), potato corn chowder (standard, typical soup), and some beef entree (nothing really mind blowing, tasty, but not almost $30 amazing).

Overall, a pleasant experience minus the wait time and endless search for parking.
author: Ada C.

description:
We Stopped By without reservation during the week and the place was busy, good sign! 

Two of us had the burger and one the mussels, and were pleasantly suprised, it tasted great! 
Unfortunately our server wasn't really on top of things and that is what causes me to give low stars I have given.

We didn't get our beer order until after we had gotten our food and only after asking twice where it was.

When two of us were done eating they removed our plates while the last person was not done yet and if she just set down her fork for a second our server came over and asked her if she is done.

This really rushed us and dampend our mood. If they would have been less pushy, we might have ordered dessert and another round. 

Therefore good food, but we won't be back.
author: Mareike B.

description: We only came in for beers and an appetizer. They had Russian River Temptation which I haven't been able to find for some time. Not only did they have a great beer selection, the service was really great. Would definitely return.
author: Rachel B.

description:
Beer Stop 28
----

Monk's Kettle is the second bar in the San Francisco area to focus on Belgium beer. They have a pretty large selection of beer, from many different locations across Europe. 

That is all well and good, but the prices are way marked up. I don't mind paying money for good beer, but damn. My girlfriend and I ordered an abbey triple (forget the brand) that was marked up by $20 bucks when compared to other beer bars in the city.

The service is iffy and the food seems to be a hit or miss.

Oh well.
author: Justin A.

description:
The Risotto made me wanna hug a stranger. 

The beers are quite delectable, and ... well, to be quite honest, i dont remember much after that. The risotto happened before the beers though, so take my word for it. 

Problems: The venue is rather tiny. I felt like i was sitting on the windowsill and halfway thru the door threshhold. 

Get there early, and expect a wait.
author: Anazette D T C.

description:
Pretty cool place with a WIDE selection of beers and some wines. 

I came here with my gf on a Friday afternoon before our dinner reservation elsewhere, just to have a snack and a drink. It was definitely nice. We just shared a couple of the fresh pretzel knots and a beer.

I definitely like the glossary of beers/wines/terminology in the back of their menu. 

It looks like a cool place for lunch or a casual dinner with buddies. I'll definitely try to come back if I'm in the area.
author: Henry N.

description:
I cannot say enough positive things about Monk's Kettle! I am a total beer snob, and this is hands down my favorite place to grab a beer! Their always-changing list of beers on tap is like no other, and the bottled beer list goes on for days. They also have so many delightful dishes, which also vary slightly depending on the season. Even the burger at Monk's is one of the best cheeseburgers you'll find! And perhaps the most important thing to know about this place - BREAD PUDDING!! It's no joke. I don't even like bread pudding, but I love theirs! Chocolatey goodness :) I've also always seen the same bartenders over the past few years, all of which are awesome! 

You should go get some bread pudding. Now. :)
author: Christine M.

description:
I picked a weird time to try out monks kettle at 10pm on a Tuesday night, but I had the best recommendations I've had in a while. Our server josh really appreciated beer, and when I asked him for his personal favorite beer flight he nailed it.  

Overall I had a great time. The beer was fantastic, even though I'm more of a wine man myself. the charcuterie plate was perfect to our pairing.
author: Leo T.

description: Beer menu is so good. And the burger was amazing when I had it a year ago. I hope nothing has changed since I went last. It was weird to get carded at a place like this tho. But I didn't mind.
author: Skye J.

description:
This place is incredible!  If you love food and craft beers, it's your Nirvana.  Xian the GM is very talented and attentive to the customers.  His recommendations are spot-on.  Our Irish waiter was personable and very professional.

We had the Off The Menu special yesterday (Game hen), poutine (to die for) and deep fried dill pickles.  Pliney and Funk Juice on-tap too.

Highly recommend Monk's Kettle to anyone looking for a great experience.
author: Kathryn I.

description:
If you love beer, you MUST come here! My boyfriend wanted to try this place out because of the bone marrow that was on the menu. We went in and saw that their beer selection was even better! there was such a wide selection and beers that I have not heard of that even when the second time the bartender came by to get our drinks I was still undecided! So take it to the professionals right? 

I asked the bartender for suggestions and he asked me the kind of beer I like. Now, I love dark beers, IPAs, lagers, you name it. After telling him the kind of beer I like, he not only suggested but simply said, "nope, done. that's the beer you're going to get" 

Gave me this amazing beer called Pliney the Elder, which I would say is even better than Guinness (if you didn't know that Guinness was the one of the best beer, then well now you know). 

...he didn't stop there. We then got an Old Speckled Hen, which imo would probably be how a Guinness tastes if it was a Lager. 

Anyway, enough about the beers! We ordered fries, average kind of fries but delicious for munchies, bone marrow, and something shrimp (not important!) The bone marrow was delicious and something I wouldn't have thought of trying. Buttery like taste and they serve it with popcorn. 

Overall, this place gets all 5 because of their amazing selection of beer, variety of foods, but most importantly the bartender. He was helpful from the overwhelming selections of beer, but not only that, he was funny too. Once he came by and saw that my boyfriend had finished his beer, he took the glass and looked at him like "this shouldn't be empty".  

Come here for good beer and a good time. But it does get really packed. 
What do you expect. Try the beer and thank me later, too.
author: Victoria K.

description: HUGE variety of beer in a small space. Absolutely love the sours... the food is not bad either. I'm a fan!
author: Aubrey Z.

description:
Situated on the bustling corner of 16th and Abion Street, Monk Kettle was easy to miss except for the small wooden sign that hung above the small black awning. I came here to meet fellow Yelper Angella S to celebrate her birthday, and was able to arrive early to walk around the block which eventually led me to this restaurant. The small interior was dark, intimate, with dim lighting and people bustling everywhere. The Lakers game was on, and the combination of an impressive beer listing and trendy atmosphere was a big draw for this high end bar which also carried an enticing menu for it to be considered a bistro.

While I waited for a table, the door man was friendly and knowledgeable about their dishes to make a few suggestions. We shared a Special Salad ($10.50) which came with mixed greens deliciously tossed with goat cheese and soft peaches with light vinaigrette dressing and a splash of champagne. It was the perfect starter followed by my entrée, the Seared Ahi Sandwich ($16.50) which was prepared with thick, sashimi grade ahi coated with sesame seeds pan seared on the outside and rare at the center. The sandwich was stacked with sweet wasabi-soy aioli with a soft kick and tiny pieces of pickled ginger and daikon sprouts served on a soft French roll. The combination of salad and sandwich was very good, but I wished the bread could be served warm to make it more appropriate as a dinner item. 

My dish also came with skinny fries, and by special request, came with chipotle ketchup, herbed aioli, and curry aioli for rounds of good dippin' (75 cents). The sauces were delightfully tasty as the chipotle ketchup and curry aioli were my favorites. Overall, the price was steep but in exchange the sizable ahi and a respectable level of sophistication in ways the food was conceptualized and executed made it worthwhile. It was certainly not your typical bar food and my glass of Belgian style Sumpin' Wild ($4.25) was good.

Our server, Zwingle, was decent and mildly friendly. It was not the most attentive service but the atmosphere was appropriate for the occasion while we stayed for quite a while without feeling rushed. Due to the size of the bistro, I think two noteworthy limitations would be their strict seating policies, which could be a turn off for some, and they also have a hefty cake cutting fee which I considered lame. 3.5 stars for the overall experience. I'd be interested in coming back to give them another try.
author: Daniel L.

description:
After 2 and half years... we did it. 
We did it!
We did it!
HOORAY!
We went under the freeway, and into the Mission to Monks Kettle.
yeah we did it. 
We did it.
We did it.
HOORAY!
up to the bar area
to our two top
yeah we did it!
we did it
we did it
HOORAY!
Swipper couldn't snatch our beers before we drank 'em.
we drank 'em.
we drank 'em.
HOORAY!
Then we ordered some fries and
a pretzel knot 
and we ate them.
we ate them.
we ate them.
HOORAY!

We did it. Good job team.
author: Emily D.

description:
I believe this place got on our radar through Yelp. We arrived here late on a Saturday night and the hostess told us it would be a 45 minute wait for a table.  We were starving and said that's fine. She gave us that 'nooo you didn't' look like we should probably go elsewhere. About 10 minutes later a table was ready...
Great Belgium beer selection! For an appetizer we got the daily pickle jar. It was a  1/2 pint glass full of random pickled items including carrots and grapes.  Awesome. I had the feta and spinach flatbread for dinner. I couldn't stop eating. So good! The menu was small, but it covered a good variety of choices. Service was attentive and knowledgeable.  I really liked this place!
author: Meredith E.

description:
Had the $15 burger and was really looking forward to it. The bun was crumbly and perhaps no fresh. The burger was over cooked and small. My wife had the veggie burger which was twice the size of my beef burger, but it was mushy and more like a vegan sloppy joe.  

I really liked the ambiance and the beer list is amazing. Will definitely go back---just not for the food.

They have a great heated outside area on the alley.
author: R C.

description: If you are in or around SF and have not checked this place out you should...well, if you are a beer drinker you should...food is ok
author: Danny and Christina M.

description: Orgasmic is the only word to describe this divine sensation. The food is life changing. Every day I go without the monks kettle is a day spent in utter agony. Monks kettle is my heroin. If I had a genie which would provide me with three wishes, I'd wish for three fried oysters. In a word: this place is fucking unbelievable!!
author: Ian B.

description:
Luck & an early buddy secured an early table at Monk's Kettle & wow, what a feast!

Started out w/ Spring Pea Grilled Flatbread - paired w/ Gose - this flatbread was schmeered w/ a puree of fresh peas & we could have eaten about 12 of these it was so delish & esp paired w/the Gose - a light German beer that is made w/ coriander & sea salt.  It completely complemented the light taste of the peas

Wild Mushroom Risotto was *outstanding* - so creamy & buttery & those mushrooms had the BEST caramelization!  This was paired w/ some Scottish Ale (I forget the name) that brought out the caramel & woodsiness of the dish

Veggie Burger is made from the very same Spent grain that they use for the "Death & Taxes" beer that is a recommended pairing & it was exceptional - the burger was firm yet full of texture w/ those grains & chick peas all combined into burger deliciousness
