Buddy #1 chose Steak & Braised Greens - super delish but super-small - the meat was cooked perfectly & the greens not too mushy.  She had chosen a porter to start & kept it for her dish as well - while she really liked the porter, she thinks she'll definitely have the experts choose next time

Chocolate Stout Bread Pudding - OMG was this tasty!  BF & I shared, Buddy #1 got her own.....I secretly wished I had got my own too it was so good!  Light chocolate flavor w/ an earthy tone - very custardy & pudding-like

The beer list here is completely overwhelming & we have every intention of trying out every one.....I see a lot of Monk's Kettle in my future!
author: Adrienne G.

description: Top destination for beer in San Francisco. They have a booklet they call a beer menu, equipped with glossary in back. Fantastic beer selection, nice cozy atmosphere, and great food. Just make sure you come in early as it fills up quickly. The space is pretty intimate so not ideal for any party over 4. I fell in love with some of my favorite brews at this spot. Be adventurous.
author: Clare B.

description:
Great beer, good food and seriously above average quality of service. I came here for the first time with a friend who has been here before, and fortunately it wasn't too busy. They told us 25 minutes for a table, but we immediately found seating at the bar and decided just to eat there. 

The beer was excellent and we each got a bone marrow "canoe" as an appetizer. It was served with popcorn that was drenched in the marrow, and it was amazing. I literally licked the bone clean. The french fries came hot and were pretty good. The main course we shared the roast of the day which was braised brisket with polenta and vegetables, and it was good, but not noteworthy. 

What stood out most in my mind was the service. Of the 4-5 employees we interacted with, they were all genuinely nice, friendly, sincere and helpful and seemed genuinely pleased to help us make our beer selections or discuss the food. It made me feel welcome and at home, and I will certainly go back.
author: Jordan C.

description: Stopped in for a quick bite before a play at the Victoria Theater. The greens salad and flank steak for 2 hit the spot. The salad was big enough for 2 to share, light dressing which was perfect and the cherries and nuts complement it nicely. The sauce on the flank steak was just light enough. Couldn't leave without trying the fries so we got these as an afterthought. The ketchup was delicious, not your ordinary Heinz. Will be back for sure!
author: Lynn U.

description: Delicious food. Great service. Thank you for being so accommodating to my food allergies. It's really hard for me to eat out without feeling inconvenient. Everyone was awesome and my risotto was amazing. My boyfriend ordered a sour ale and mussels; he said they were delicious! Thank you!!
author: Emily S.

description:
I've been trying to go to Monk's Kettle for months but it's usually crowded. Finally went on the Thursday before MLK around 8pm and lucked out by getting seated in a booth immediately! Be warned that this place is fairly small and usually busy so generally you are going to have to wait. Also note that they always ask if you are eating dinner or just drinking, I believe this is because the booths are reserved for dinner customers.

They have a fairly small menu of mostly upscale Belgian-inspired food and a BIG beer menu. Note that the imported bottled stuff tends to be more expensive here than the same beer at other places. For example my Tripel Karmeliet 330ml was $14.75! But hey, at least they _have_ Tripel Karmeliet.

Other than the awesome beer, I've been excited to try this place because of all the great things I've heard about their burger. It definitely lived up to expectations for me. It was perfectly cooked and extremely delicious! I usually only get bacon on a burger if it comes by default (trust the chef) but I'd heard people recommend getting it here so I opted for the optional bacon and was not disappointed, I would definitely recommend getting it. This burger definitely ranks up there with NOPA and Zazie for me as my favorite burgers in the city so far.

Also tried the fried oyster appetizer which was decent, but not mind blowing. Be warned that the dish is _one_ fried oyster, though our waiter was nice enough to warn us of this fact and ask how many we wanted to order.

The pretzel knot appetizer on the other hand was a definite win. It seemed like it came right out of the oven with a super soft and fluffy inside and perfectly crisp on the outside. It comes with stone ground mustard and cheese fondue dipping sauces.

Our waiter apparently forgot to put in our appetizer order, but when asked about them as our main dishes came he apologized profusely, rushed them out and didn't charge us for them which was great! It's goes to show that giving a little bit extra on customer service can really make sure your customers enjoy their experience even when things go wrong.

Also props to them for leaving a large pitcher of water on the table as well, I always hate having to wait for the waiter to come by and re-fill my glass.

Overall a great experience, I'll definitely be back for more awesome Belgian beer and the delicious burger.
author: Ely L.

description:
Something akin to a wine tasting bar for beer lovers, the servers are extremely knowledgeable about almost every beer on their comprehensive list. The beer menu must have been several pages long, definitely over 100 beers to choose from.. not the best for someone ADD like me. The server saw my trouble picking and suggested about six different beers to choose from. I still couldn't pick so he let me sample all six of them! Now thats good service. 

Also, the food here is fantastic. Get the pretzel and any of the burgers/fries. Totally addictive and goes well with the beer here.
author: Henry W.

description:
It was very delicious. I took a vegetarian burger + french fries and they were very good! The plate is huge! I shared it with my husband.
Kind staff, clean place.
author: Scilla L.

description: I didn't go for beer...the place looks excellent for beer. The dinner we got was really good! Wait staff not so good but...its a gastropub so who cares
author: Anthony S.

description:
This is a great place to come to drink and eat!!

We weren't looking to eat here but we lucked out on parking right in front of this place. I looked at the reviews on YELP and it was great!! We were really hungry because we just left the Ramen Festival without eating any ramen! I'm sure that we were annoying customers that demanded fast service but we were hungry!! AND THEY DID NOT DISAPPOINT! they were even seriously funny!

The food. We had the burger here. It was probably one of the best gourmet burgers I've ever eatten. I would seriously suggest it. The menu also suggest a good beer pairing for the burger which was an amazing combination. 

the service was so fast and they were really welcoming and the food delicious...

This place isn't cheap. SO BE PREPARED to spend a good amount but its not a super fancy restaurant. 

I would definitely come here again. :)
author: Christopher G.

description:
I stared my friend down for walking in late, but we had a good time once we sat down and she remembered that I was funny and not such a bitch after all.  She actually said this to me.

I had 30% off through BBE, and though it was a week day lunch, I ordered bone marrow and the burger.  Skip bone marrow but the burger was good. Friend's risotto w mushrooms and cheddar also good.  Good dishes were not so good that I would remember to come back from such easy-to-find offerings.

Cute spot. Service was friendly but uneven.  I'm not a beer fan and I didn't have any drinks with my meal, so perhaps the full charm of this place was lost on me.
author: Erika C.

description:
Finally came here on a Friday night after it's been bookmarked for the past few months. The food in the pictures on Yelp definitely won me over. But after circling around for 15 mins looking for parking and finding out those dishes weren't served anymore because they changed chefs, I was already disappointed. Luckily, we didn't have to wait in line, we grabbed the second to last table. But if we didn't get it, it would have been a 1-1.5 hr wait.

This is a great place if you like beer (it is a gastropub). They have a huge selection of beers and prices are just as various, from your normal $5 to $20+ beers. The beer menu can be overwhelming and it's a definite WOW factor, both because of the selection and prices on some of them.

They also serve food. Their menu is short and simple. What we ordered:
1. the pretzel knots (2 for $9 or 1 for $5)- if you look in the pictures, they're pretty small in size (especially for $5 each) I will admit they were good. Nice crunchy exterior, nice and fluffy in the middle. The dijon and cheese sauce were really good. I still thought I overpaid for the pretzel knots however.
2. Potato crown beef croquettes- the description sounded delicious, but I was unimpressed. I couldn't taste much of the corned beef. The texture was very nice, the mashed potatoes were very smooth and creamy. I didn't think the aioli complimented the croquettes very well, I would have preferred it without the lemon aioli.
3. Soup of the day- it was chicken corn chowder that day, pretty good.
4. Steak- it was good, it had a nice char to it and you can taste a smoky on the outside. However $25 for a few slices of steak. I rather spend that money towards House of Prime Rib if you know what I mean.
5. Fries- tasted like your ordinary french fries, the hop salt didn't stand out to me, but it sure made it sound fancy.

Overall, I might come back just for beer. I'll pass on the food. I definitely would NOT wait an hr or more for a table (which is typical on a Friday or Saturday night).

PS. They also won't seat you until your entire party is there. So make sure everyone is on time or you guys ride together. It's first come first serve for tables for entire parties.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
The place can get crowded but the atmosphere and lighting is intimate. No reservations and there can be a wait if you have a group. My friend and I chose to sit at the bar so we could talk to the bartender about the beer selection. 

Great selection of beers and the bartenders are really knowledgable! I didn't have any food here when I went, but it looked like pretty average bar food. 

I heard the beer selection changes often, so I'll definitely be coming back!
author: Winnie T.

description:
Great spot to grab a unique beer and delicious food (optional). We were lucky to nab a table without any wait, however the bar was completely packed. I dock one star because the smaller tables are very close to each other, making it difficult to get in and out of your seat if you're by the window.

I recommend getting the pickle jar (tasty bites of radishes, grapes, green beans, cucumber and carrots) - $5
Duck Leg Confit with strawberries and peas. An interesting combo of flavors that I hadn't seen before. The crisp greens and sweet fruit complimented the rich flavors of duck, delicious! The portion was great too, not too large but filling.

Had I not been so full, I would have ordered their mini beignets. 

Had I not had to go to work that night, I would have paired all my orders with more beer.

I was highly impressed at the efficiency and swiftness of service. Despite being overly crowded, our drinks and meal came out surprisingly fast.
author: Alyssa G.

description:
If there ever was a casual (semi coolish hipster) gastropub worthy of a five star rating it's Monk's Kettle.

For one, I love the name Monk's Kettle. It's catchy cool and should be the name of a hit Katy Perry song. Hey, could be worse...I'm looking at you Billy Joel.

My only mistake, I fell victim to a passing burger. I slipped right past our table and landed graciously a few chairs down from me. I had every intention of stepping out of my comfort zone and try anything but the burger. But it just looked to darn good to pass up. 

Anyway.....I did get to sample a few other food things.

The pretzel. Are you kidding me? It's out of this world! And I am an expert on all things carbs. The pretzel came with two different kinds of mustard, but delicious and the pretzel itself was the perfect texture, MUAH! It's as good as you will find back the Hofbrauhaus...and no, I don't mean the fake one in Las Vegas, I mean the actual real Hofbrauhaus back in Munch. If you've been you will know exactly what I am talking about.

The fried oysters were dangerously delicious. Deep fried to a golden brown with a nice crisp. But as mentioned, fried, so you do realize you are asking for a serious heart attack. Hey it's worth playing food roulette with you life!

Now for the burger. Yes, this burger may be the most underrated burger in all of San Francisco. Cooked perfectly to medium rare, the grass fed beef was absolutely mouth watering. The patty was topped with a slice of sharp white cheddar cheese which I must find out where they scored this wonderful dairy product.

The fries, oh boy! The fries! Just another awesome Monk's creation. If unicorns could make fries, it would be these. No garlic or parmesan toppings. Just perfectly crafted fried potatoes.

Save room for dessert and keep your fingers crossed for the pecan tart. Pair it with a zingy zinfandel and your night will come to the perfect conclusion. 

The one appetizer I wish we had ordered but didm't? Corned beef hash croquettes. How good does that sound!?

The service was spot on and friendly. I like when the waitstaff have strong opinions on both wine and beer. I loved this place and for sure will back again soon.
author: V B.

description: This is a very comfortable place to have a drink.  The selection is decent and the sample cups are just so cute.  I wanted to take them home but they said $6 each so I just left without them.  The service is not great but not bad.  They do give recommendations which is what drinking is all about.  When I'm at a bar, I want to try new drinks.  Life is too short to just drink the same old booze. Their chocolate cake is chocolate cake.
author: Byron L.

description:
Obsessed with gastropubs, so I've been determined to try out all the top ones in the city. Arrived here late in the evening around 10PM, but was still told there would be a wait for a table. Host was extremely friendly and took down my number to shoot me a text when seats became available. 

Amazing selections of beer, but not so much with wine. Ordered the bacon wrapped shrimp and the mussels. Food was delicious, portions were hearty, and loved the cozy atmosphere. I was really hoping to try out the mac n cheese, but apparently they no longer have it on their menu :(
author: Vivian D.

description:
Bacon Beer. End of story.

------------------------------------

Came here a year ago with my guy friends.
The room was small and it was quite a tight squeeze, but the atmosphere was nice. The lighting made everything have a light brown and gold tint to it. It was cute.

Three of us had the bacon beer - which tastes more like ham, but it's totally cool because it's not made with meat, it's from the barrel! So why complain? It's already great that it tastes even slightly like the tastiest food on earth.
The last one of us got a local cider - also super good.
I don't remember anything else we ordered or their names. Sorry.

The service was great. We were seated almost immediately. Both people who help us were friendly had knew exactly what we wanted even before us looking at the menu.

Would deff try this place again. Until next time...
author: Eileen ..

description:
I'm not a beer drinker so can't say anything about the beer here, but I know my friends enjoyed it. There is a huge selection! 

I'm judging based on the service, ambiance, & fondue pretzel I ate. We sat at the bar where there are chalkboards in front of you to write on. Pretty unique. You can play tic tac toe or hangman if you're on a date to break the awkward silence. Not that I'm saying that's what I did or anything...

The food smelled really good & the menu looked interesting. The pretzel snack served with cheese & mustard was yummy. I'd like to go back to try more things but I hear if you go during prime time dinner hours, there's a long wait since the restaurant is on the smaller size with only about 6-8 tables? I recommend going during off-hours like I did.

Service was outstanding. They made sure our waters were always filled & asked if we wanted another round before we were done with the first. I like that.
author: Alysha K.

description:
Great beer diversity. 
Couldn't taste the $17 dollar burger or chicken sandwich due to saltiness overload. Food is overpriced. Nice environment.
author: andrew l.

description:
The Monk's Kettle is a must visit when I'm in the Bay.  They have one of the best selections of beers from around the globe and the staff know their sh*t...these guys are serious about what they serve.  Ask your server what kinds of beer pair with your cheese and fruit platter's or just order random beers from across the Atlantic and enjoy a good conversation with your buds.

The place is small but worth a visit. 

Interesting fact: Throughout history the monks were the most educated in society and knew how to brew the best beers and wrote the instructions that were then passed down through the generations...we all owe a bit of gratitude to the monks.
author: Sam L.

description:
Throw a stone into the air and guaranteed that wherever it landed, there will be a bar with liquor. Monk's Kettle was something special, especially at its location. Surrounded by bars and pubs, the exciting night life, Monk's Kettle settled on a cozy corner providing all its patrons with the best of over 200 beers. They have the most epic encyclopedia of beers, from the light to the red. The foreign to the home state to the fruity and the bitter. It is quite an experience to be there and indulge into a lesson of good beer and hold to savory the peculiar taste of beer. 

There's limited tables and bar seating, so expect a wait if you come at the wrong time. I opted to walk in around 1200am, beating last call at 145pm. Showed id at the door, and settled into a corner for four. The interior was warm and welcoming and everybody seemed to be enjoying themselves. The relaxed environment was a different switch from the bar scene, where it was obscene noises and drunks was a good change. 

I don't even enjoy beer, let alone know anything about what to order. And that's when the wonderful staff came in and the waiter invited himself to our table and began building an individualize beer for each and every one of us. But before that, the bar treated us to a couple of dark ales, foams and belgiums to kick our night off. Each one of us describe what sort of drinks we do enjoy, then crafted and formulated what beers that they offered would be right for us. When the beer came, it was completely on point and it blew my mind. Never did I imagine I would enjoy beer like a regular, but certainly a first time for everything and always time to change my mind. 

I find myself having a high tolerance for liquor, but I wasn't ready for the high concentration in these specialized beers, especially the foam. God, the foam topped off the drink and it was delicious. Foamy and thick, giving myself a mustache with the warm beer oozing between my lips. So don't drink and drive, a couple of beers with get you going really quick. 

They offer a short, but elegant menu to be paired with their beers. A real hit were their side of fries, the black muscles (which were HUGE but a lot of the dish were just shells and not so much meat), the pretzel with the fondu (expect the one we had were smaller than yelp pictures, like the size of my fist rather than my entire hand) and the bone marrow was something out of this world! 

On with the service. On with the beers. On with the food. This is the place to come with hitting the 16th and Mission because there's no other like it out here. The prices vary, but honestly, what you pay is equal to or worth the value of the drinks/food. Made with perfection and sealed off with the perfect beer.
author: Winnie G.

description:
Very overpriced is the first thought that comes to mind. $12-$13 for a beer is a bit ridiculous if you ask me. I'm glad I tried it but not sure I would be enticed to ever come back again even though the food was alright. 

This place is SO tiny that you are literally bumping elbows with the person next to you too. I was there with a friend and we shared the house charcuterie and cheese ($12 for 2 items) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/g2ktKLz4rNTi8T5WUEUYuw#OSDaDPG3ZBr6vrVH68TaPA), the local greens, toasted hazelnuts, fromage blanc, and currents salad ($8) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/g2ktKLz4rNTi8T5WUEUYuw#HdAn6laKrnt1WT_M5l-Ydg), and the grilled flatbread, spring peas, ricotta salata ($12) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/g2ktKLz4rNTi8T5WUEUYuw#BrBoDBUgJ8bh4vG327innQ). 

The charcuterie was good and I really liked the homemade jams and mustard. They gave us 3 different soft cheeses but not enough salumi and bread to go with it. The salad was just ok since there wasn't much to it. Lastly, the flatbread was interesting with a mushed pea spread...I didn't love it but didn't hate it either. 

I was still hungry after sharing those dishes unfortunately.
author: Karen Y.

description: Super awesome bar with fantastic bartenders. We were visiting from out of town, and Carrie helped us find a bunch of local spots that were spot on. Their beer list is fantastic, with lots of unique options and their menu is great! I highly recommend checking this place out!
author: Meg J.

description:
If you're into beer you can't afford missing out on The Monk's Kettle. A great selection of drafts that range in style and origin. A carefully curated bottle selection. What I'm most impressed with is the bartenders here. They know so much about beer that they're not dicks about it. Instead you can tell they really want everyone at the bar to enjoy the beer as much as they do.

One thing to prepare for: bottles from lesser known breweries, or well-known breweries that you just can't find here, are ridiculously priced. No worries though, the draft selection alone will keep you busy for a night or two, and the prices are fair.
author: Marcus C.

description: The best place in mission for Belgian and German beer and a good burger. And it's open late! The burger rivals a lot of the celebrated burger places in the city. The balanced and selected beer list is pretty awesome. Not as comprehensive as Alesunlimited but is well thought out. The burger is just incredible, you have to try it. Split a flatbread and a burger in two with your SO/date/friend and it's quite a perfect pairing with the beers.
author: Andy J.

description:
Their beer selection is diverse and they have a great atmosphere; a blend of casual yet sophisticated enough to take a 2nd date. Has an encyclopedia of beers which makes you feel like this could possible though not probably be an educational experience as you knock a few back!

Never tried the burgers but they looks intense!
author: Brian P.

description:
Can you say BEER!?

Its the only restaurant that I've been to that has a binder full of beer choices. 
Var Nyce!

The place was packed and it took them about 40mins to sit us down.

The waitress who served us was very knowledgeable about their beers and had some great suggestions. The prices are very fair.

I tried one of their burgers and it was very very good.

I will definitely be back to try more burgers and brew.

Great find!
author: Hamid A.

description:
So I've been back here several more times because it's one of my friend's usual haunts and I've experienced more of their menu and I have to say, I'm much more pleased than my initial review.

The poutine is very solid and can be a meal on its own, although I'm not sure a plate of gravy, fries and pork shoulder should be something you want as dinner but if you do, more power to you, it's definitely big enough and filling enough to be called dinner. If you're not eating alone, I definitely recommend splitting this with a friend or two.

I tried the fried chicken sandwich and it was nothing short of amazing. Nice crispiness with a touch of spiciness. The coleslaw wasn't very acidic at all and provided a nice crunch and freshness. The pickles, I absolutely despise pickles with a passion, but these pickles were something else, it was actually very pleasant and I, to my disbelief, liked them. So if you're debating on what to get, get their fried chicken sandwich, it's surprisingly delicious and I can't wait to come back to have it again.

Their burger is another solid choice if you're debating on what to get. I can't say that it's a must-have burger like some other places but it is a good choice still and they do it well if you're in a mood for a burger.
author: Richard C.

description:
This is the place where my fiancée and I stop by anytime we are in the mission. The inside decor is nice and with the addition of the outside seating area, it makes it easier now for bigger groups to come.

This is a decent place to grab a beer. I feel that it is over priced. I think this place you are paying for the "ambience" rather than the beer or the food itself. The food here is not anything special. Don't get me wrong it tastes good, but it is nothing special. The beer selection is great, but the beer on tap selection is somewhat limited.

Overall I come here every now and then, but my stops here are becoming fewer and far in between
author: Moses L.

description:
Used to love this place but after tonight's experience I won't be coming back.

We were 4 waiting for a table.  The host kept insisting that the couple sitting at the chalk board was about to open up, (4 stools at a bar wall.

If it was the only option ID have been happy to wait but there were two empty 2 person tables right next to each other...

I pointed it out to him but he said he wanted to save those for 2 separate couples.  I said, yea but it would be much nicer to be able to talk to each other and more suitable for 4 people, where as a couple can still easily chat at a bar....

Logic was not his strong suit and he just started acting like a typical power trip bouncer.   

I almost left right away but decided the food and drink would be good and just deal.  We eventually Sat at the main bar after 20 minute wait during which time a table of four opened up where he moved a couple from the bar to this table...  Still 2 open 2 person tables....

It was starting to be a parent that he was going out of his way to not be courteous and trying to make each guest have a good time.  Also, 2 other sets of 3 and 4 came and left after hearing they could not sit at the open tables.

The entire time his logic was that if we sit there, when we leave 2 two person tables would be come available at the same time.  The entire time we were there there was at least one table open, usually 2 or 3 though.  

So I waited for the food, and it was no where near as good as the last time I came about 3 months ago.  The fried chicken sandwich was burnt and greasy at the same time, and the slaw and ketchup had too much vinager flavor. 

When we didn't order beers or booze since we went even facing each other, the bar tender said, out loud, great. 3 out of four not ordering drinks....

I've been a server before for 2 years, and this is not good service, it's not smart service, and it makes loyal customers never want to come back.

I can tell you, I will never come back here again, and warn you that if the staff makes an incorrect decision during your visit, they will make sure to make it worse the rest of the night, and pretend it's your fault.
author: Andrew S.

description: Food was great, but service slow and definitely has room for improvement. Nice location. Noise level OK.
author: Simon H.

description:
Unfortunately, I arrived for the "sour hour". It was a bunch of BS. After hearing about Monks as a top beer drinking spot, I must say I was let down--big time!

I've been drinking beer for over 20 years. I've seen and experienced the evolution of the beer industry over time. Maybe my expectations were too high for such an establishment. 

They had a fun-funky-little vibe for sure. As we walked-in, I think we were greeted by Jesus Christ himself (or at least a descendant) so that scored points with me--just purely for visual effect. The bartender was solid. Her recommendations weren't always on point but she was motivated and showed good passion for what she does.

I love a good IPA--the dankier the better! They had pages of beers to choose from but the one I wanted (Pliny the Elder) was not on tap. Shitty, considering the menu said it was last updated 7/25--the same day as my visit. 

So, I took a canned beer because apparently it was "Sour Hour" and they wanted everyone to drink their shitty sour beers (can you tell I'm not a big fan).

Not to be shaken, I trudged forward and asked for a few tasters. She gave me the Alagash (that I really liked) and a few others (that I didn't). 

For my second beer, I asked for an Alagash (that originally I saw came out of a tap right in front of me). A few minutes later, this guy comes from the back with a glass filled with bubbly/light beer. Looks good, I'm pretty sure it's what I ordered but sure as shit--no! I swear to this day it was a Hoegarden!

Now, I'm a fan of Hoegarden but that's not what I ordered. At this point, I'm taken offense to the fact that they're playin' me like a little bitch.

As a true beer aficionado, I know better. I just don't think they knew me. I had never been there before but in reality I'm a 41 year old man who'd been around the block many more times than these youngens' behind the bar.

You'll be happy to know that I didn't say anything. I was having too much fun with my 21 year old son (one of our first drinks together in a bar ever). There was not way I was ruining that moment over something pesky like this.

I did however feel compelled to leave a note about my experience here on Yelp. Monks is not a legit establishment. They do not deserve to be published as a top beer drinking spot in The City. 

Sure, they have lot's of beers (something like 200+) but they want to serve you want they want to serve. I'd rather go to a place that has just a few good one's, but yet I can really count on them to serve me what I order. 

So, if you're looking for 200 beers of bullshit--go for it! If you really know your beer and you like the beer you drink--go somewhere you can rely on delivering the goods. And, if you're not familiar, you can do better.
author: G L.

description:
Great food and beers.  Many breweries on tap and an extensive bottle list.  The food is stellar as well.  

Food Ordered: 
1) Corned beef hash croquettes, whipped bone marrow & lemon aioli, parsley
2) Penn cove mussels, allagash white, garlic, shallot, basil  
3) Fresh ground beef burger, onion jam, aged white cheddar  w/ bacon

everything was delicious but the mussels were the best thing we ate that night.

Would definitely go back again!
author: Jason J.

description:
A 10 person going away dinner on a Tuesday night, at a small hip gastropub in The Mission.

With a large party we were divided into two separate tables, which we were okay with given that the place was quite small. I walked into Monk's Kettle not knowing they checked I.D.'s and was quickly yelled at by the hostess/bouncer - not sure if she was one or the other but seemed like the latter assuming a host would've properly walked up to me instead of hollering.

We were sat quickly and the waiter was very patient with us. All 3 of us that sat at one table ordered beer that he recommended. We also ordered the warm pretzel that came with two types of mustards as a starter. I had the steamed mussels and the blanche de bruxelles that complimented the shellfish quite well. All of the items had layers of flavors and it wasn't just your average "bar food"-esque type of deal. 

Overall, very happy with the Monks Kettle and would recommend it to others; it's a great place to learn about beers. The menu was a simple page that had beer recommendations with each starter and main entree which was very helpful. And as a plus they have a modest wine selection and non-alcoholic beer choices.
author: Hannah T.

description:
Super cool beer bar with a laid back European vibe in the Mission area. This is coming from a gal who doesn't normally drink beer. I was here with a friend at 2pm on a Friday afternoon. Lots of friendly, early afternoon drinkers such as ourselves enjoying some beers there too. 

It definitely attracts a down to earth, diverse crowd. There is also a neighborhood feel to the place. Though I was not oohing and awing about all the beers on tap (since I am not a huge beer fan), a number of folks were very impressed by it along with the extensive beer selection menu. 

Definitely up for visiting here again and bringing beer fans with me!
author: Julee D.

description:
(See pics)

Review #1091.

Amazing selection of beer. Good if you know beer, then you will have a couple hundred to choose from. Good if you don't know much about the different kinds and taste (me) because they asked a few questions, which is like a personality test, such as whether you prefer light / heavy, sweet / bitterness, and they will come back with a couple recommendations.

The food here is on the meaty and heavier side, perfect for pairing with the beer. The three day ale bricked chicken with cranberry beans, and harissa was very juicy and great flavor, a dish I would definitely order again.

This is definitely a great place for lunch (early or late) and dinner. Lunch time the vibe is more chillaxing while night time is quite bustling.
author: T L.

description:
I was going to give it 5 stars but they didn't have "The Wehvwend". At first I thought it was just an honest mistake when the bartender asked me to repeat my order. (To be fair, this place featured a loud and lively crowd with romantic dim light settings so it's completely understandable that she didn't hear me properly). However, upon my second attempt, I excitedly and confidently restated my order, (this time in a much larger voice, hoping she could understand me better second time around) asked for "The Wehvwend" and again results came back negative. She didn't understand me and she said that they simply didn't carry it. 

For those of you who don't know, "The Wehvwend" is this amazing Belgian Style Quadruple Ale, 10% ABV, Brewed by the Avery Brewing Company somewhere in Colorado, USA. A divinely complex and beautifully layered beer with hints of dark cherries, currants, and molasses, complimented by an underlying spiciness. Sinfully smooth considering the high alcohol content.  

Long Story Short: I was really excited at first, then I was a slightly disappointed, then I was really happy again later because my date had such a great time. She was giggling at something while I was ordering, I'm not sure at what, but bottom line was that she was happy and I'm still real glad that I took her there. A couple drinks later, I asked her out and SHE SAID YES. 

she said Y E S  you guys. so who cares if they don't carry "The Wehvwend", Somewhere along from the ordering mishap to the end of the night, I scored myself a new gf! =)
author: Thankie S.

description:
Great and knowledgeable beer selection. Tasty food. Warm ambiance.  Oh, and they serve the beer in the RIGHT glass (yes, I'm a beer snob).

It's a bit on the pricey side for beers, but it's well worth it with their food.  They make the tastiest and juiciest burger I've had so far in SF.  Highly recommend.
author: Stefan R.

description:
I was in total awe of their Craft Beer selections.

I have been wanting to get to this place for some time just due to their draft selections. I was fortunate enough to get a spot at the bar and bellied up.  I ordered an oyster as an appetizer and the draft meister said a person who got the oysters recently found a pearl in it.  Good tip as I definitely didn't want to chop down on a pearl.  The cornmeal fried oyster was tasty enough and I regretted my decision when the guy next to me got a burger.  It looked amazing.  Oh well next time.  I knew if I got a burger I would be there a little longer and the parking meter in my head was a'ticking.  The meter maids were getting after expired meters pretty aggressively so I knew I needed to have only a couple selections and sprint back to my meter to feed it.  I'll BART it next time.

They have a decent sized bar with seating all around and they have a secondary seating area (bar-type) a little further back into the restaurant.  There are a few booths which seemed to be pretty popular and there were a few small tables sprinkled through the place.  Their beer selections were impressive.  They have a number of beers on tap and have a good sized book with their bottled offerings.

My first beer was Obedience Training by Moonlight Brewing.  It was a nice Brown Ale dark in color and nutty in flavor.  The 2nd selection was a beer I've had before but never on tap-- North Coast Old Stock Ale.  It's classified as an old ale and has a very unique taste.  I have enjoyed this beer in bottle form but I think I've been drinking it a little too cold.  I had this beer on tap and almost started crying it was so good.  There were so many nuances of flavor in this beer that I had not noticed before.  The flavor lingered in my mouth and was wonderful.  It was full of caramel richness with a little carbonation and a slight bitter finish.  Yum.  I'll have to make a trek up to their brewery sometime this year.  I truly enjoyed this beer on tap but it packs a punch at almost 12%.

By the time I finished my oyster and 2 beers I knew my meter was still ticking away so I decided to cash out.  It had gotten pretty crowded in there too.  The bathroom was a unisex and I hate those.  It's the only thing I really didn't like about Monk's Kettle so I can't really give it 5 stars.  I'll be back but I think I'll use a proper women's restroom prior to coming.
author: Webb P.

description:
Had friends in town visiting - and they had been told they HAD to go here. So, of course, I obliged because I'm always willing to try new places. I'm glad we went!! 

The place is very cute, dark styled but with lots of windows, and pretty small. They have about 30 beers on draft, and a whole BOOK of bottled beers that they carry. 

We got here around 7 on a Monday, and there was a 45min-hour wait for 3 people. Luckily the owner/manager of the bar, Travis, told us there was a group getting up at the end of the bar, and he totally took care of us ordering our drinks and making sure we got the table. 

I am NOT a beer person, but wanted to try something as opposed to opting for wine, so Travis asked me what kind of wine I liked. Based on that, he gave me two tastings, one of which I really liked it. It was the St. Bernardus Abt, which is a quadruple, I guess a type. It was delicious!! 

To eat I ordered the chicken sandwich, so so good. The bacon jam is amazing.

My friends ordered several different beers, all that they liked. They also had the mushroom risotto and the spent grain & chick pea burger and both raved. 

Travis was amazing, the good was great, and I had beer I liked. This is most def going to be my go-to place for craft beer with knowledgeable, friendly staff and good food.
author: Chloé M.

description:
I was expecting mostly belgian beers here from the Monks, but was pleasantly surprised by the "book" of beers they had available.  Lots of interesting choices on tap and a huge selection of bottles.  I suggest going for the beer "Flight" of the month/week (house selects 3 interesting beers to try in 6 oz goblets), not a bad deal to try several different ones.

What blew me away about this place was the food.  I was expecting normal bar fare, but it is so much more.  Their menu includes some interestingly prepared roasted meats and veggies... I really enjoyed the Monk's Daily Roast special, and my friend got dry-aged beef striploin.  The dishes are prepared nicely (not in a pretentious snooty way) and go together quite well, and the portions are just right... not too big.
author: Dan M.

description:
Great beer, amazing selection. 

Really nicely done food. Was going to order the roast of the day, but it had a long prep/cook time, so I opted for the pulled chicken sandwich instead, as I was aiming to not miss the last BART home. The sandwich was quite good; anything that has bacon jam in it is A-OK with me. 

This is the first place I tried sour beer, and it was fantastic. I had the Faro and my friend tried the Rodenbach. They were both excellent, and I highly recommend trying them if you've never before. They run a bit pricier than your average beer -- a bottle of the Rodenbach is $9.50 and the Faro is $13.75.
author: Patrick T.

description: Amazing beer, great service, cool ambiance, great interior and exterior seating. My friends liked the food though I didn't try it. Highly recommend!
author: emmanuelle a.

description:
I finally got to the try the food here. Last time I came I just had some yummy beer and the joint was too full to get a table for dinner.

We had these dishes:
1) Old school pretzel knot, cheddar fondue (I wish the actual pretzel were bigger, the pretzel to sauce ratio is unbalanced)
2) Fresh ground burger, onion jam, aioli, aged white cheddar, fries
3) Braised beef cheeks, polenta, horseradish
4) Cornmeal fried oysters, cucumber ketchup, hot sauce

All were rich in flavor and worth getting. Might even be too much flavor for some people.
They don't serve Mac and Cheese anymore--something they were known for.
This is because they changed chefs.

Valuable gem in SF.
author: Marlon T.

description: Great customer service. Wide selection of beers. The food is great too - not particularly for vegetarians. Good location and ambiance.
author: Lori P.

description:
Christophe Awards:
- Ambassadorship to Beer Landia
- Taste of California

A business that needs no introduction. Monk's Kettle is equally renown for their beer selection as well as their take on Californian New American food. Where else can you find an excellent kale salad and a fine slab of half chicken?

I split the kale salad and the mussels with coworkers before chowing down on the monk daily roast. I recommend all three. The salad had a sweet, salty, and crunchy topping to pair with the astringent natural Kale taste. Mussels were cooked in a delicious broth that demanded attention.

It does get busy, but there are plenty of good bars in the area. Plan accordingly.
author: Christophe C.

description:
A perfect execution of the gastropub - fantastic beer menu, awesome food choices. The pretzels were great, he had the half chicken and I the duck special both were delicious but the duck was the clear winner. Service was pretty good even with the place being packed. if you are looking for a quiet date nigh place, this may not be for you.

Food: 4/5
Service: 4/5
Location: 4/5
author: Sonya A.

description: the selection of beer here is the best. I had a Pliny the Elder, which is rare to find and such a high quality beer. thank you for having so many options!
author: Victoria L.

description:
Went there for my birthday for pre-dinner drinks. The ambiance is very noisy, cozy and welcoming. They had a bouncer/doorman/host. He knew exactly how much space was available (there isn't much to begin with).
I was with a party of 5, luckily the other 8 decided not to get drinks because this is not a place for big groups on a Saturday night. I had two beers; The Golden Monkey and Weihenstephaner Hefe. I liked both but the Hefe was delicious that I wanted more after the first sip. 

Overall a pleasant experience and I would definitely return with maybe a friend or two and try out their food. The menu looks overwhelming but if you have a particular type of beer that you like, just ask the server and they will be able to direct you to the right beer. 

P.S. The chalkboard wall needs an eraser.
author: Andrew B.

description:
I stumbled upon this place by complete accident after talking everyone's ear off about how much I wanted to visit The Monk's Kettle. We came to the city in search for some retail store and literally ended up parking in front of The Monk's Kettle and almost walked into it thinking it was the retail store we were looking for.

Of course we had to stop by to eat and for a good beer.

I am a little bit shocked at their prices though. Let the review show THIS PLACE IS WAY OVERPRICED FOR BEER. By that I mean sometimes as much as 4x to 6x for the same beer you can buy at BevMo. I would not come here again for the beer unless it was for tap or something very rare.

The food, on the other hand, was great. Their burgers are a hit and their appetizer dishes are both well made, creative and definitely gourmet for what is supposed to be a beer bar. I would highly recommend any of their specials since they're all good and food wise you will not go wrong here. Just don't pay an arm and a leg for the beer!
author: Lorrie M.

description: The poutine fried were pretty bomb.. But other than that it's just another overpriced hipster pub. Since I'm not a big beer drinker I asked the waitress what hard cider she recommended, she told me the peach sour cider was her favorite so I told her I'd try it. Turns out when I got the damn bill this cider was $28! For a glass?! Are you kidding me?! So ridiculous and definitely not worth going back.
author: brianna t.

description: Randomly yelped for a place while on vacation and this restaurant popped up with 4 stars and a big beer menu. Off we went and were pleasantly surprised at the quality of the service, beer selection, and food! Our waiter's recommendations were spot on (the braised beef cheek and the hamburger just as it is on the menu, no alterations) and they were able to immediately accommodate our party of 6 outside. Definitely highly suggested for beer enthusiasts and travelers alike.
author: Pauline T.

description:
Bookmarking!

Excellent bartender who offered a taster of the champagne and white wine, and with the few options for wine compared to beer, both were excellent!  The food was great, soft cheese, pate and salumi (However, I definitely did not get as much salumi as the pictures shown - maybe 6 slices of a half dollar size), mussels, acme bread, excellent jam, excellent burger!  As good as Nopa's burger, just a different style.    

Beers galore...no joke...I could start drinking beer with all the unique beer glasses for every type.  The boy got 2 beers from his Dutch-land, especially being his last day of work at his old gig, he was very excited.  I tried them both, excellent foam!

Small, casual, not too crowded on the weekdays.  The bar seating is very comfortable as well.  Will be back very often!  Can you provide sparkling/soda water soon?  :)
author: Candice H.

description:
We liked our visit to Monk's. The venue is small but the ambiance is good. Good service. Nice beer selection. Food was also great (pretzel, fries and pickles were what we tried... pickled grapes, what?!) Prices not too high (for SF). 

Tip: Try to go at off hours because this place is always packed.
author: Amy L.

description: I like this place. I really do. But I think it's overpriced for what you get. It goes without saying the beer selection is EXTENSIVE. But in our experience the descriptions don't always match the taste of the beer. Lesson learned: ask your waiter/waitress about a beverage before shelling out $$ for a drink you may or may not like.
author: Elle B.

description:
I've come up to the city often to go to Monk's Kettle. It's got an amazing multinational beer selection with a beautiful wooden bar to enjoy them at. The pace is slow and unhurried and the food excellant: I'm putting the burger as one of my favorite around.

However the prices are steep and the place does not have any room to accommodate overflow in the evening. I've been stuck sandwiched between a couple of friends trying to catch up and hostess for 40 minutes on a rainy night.  Go in the afternoon or early evening. 

Overall, I prefer  the Trappiste in Oakland and Toronadoes for a good beer menu but this is an easy walk from the Bart.
author: Soja-Marie M.

description:
This place is awesome - assuming, of course, that you like good beer and appreciate delicious food. If you don't like those things, this place isn't for you. 
 -- See e.g.: below dude's weird review about wanting PBR and Coors Light.
Yes, in fact, this place IS too good to serve such beers to you, nor is it their job to do so. If all you wanted was a Coors, walk less than a block in either direction to one of the perfectly cool looking dive bars and by all means, get yourself one.  But if you walk into a cool, trendy gastropub that prides itself on its unique and wonderful fancy beer offerings, please do not offend those of us with a taste for such things by being rude. It is not this establishment's fault that you found yourself among unfamiliar options and refused to be open minded (or bothered look up what kind of place it was before going).  [Rant over]

So, on to the actual review of this place. 
Easily one of the coolest restaurant bars in the city. Not only do they have an incredible beer selection from all over the world, but their food is also fantastic (and served until 1am! 

The servers are exceptionally knowledgable about the beer menu, and very willing to help walk you through it.  I am by no means an expert, and at first I found myself a bit overwhelmed by their menu. With zero pretentiousness, the servers both times I've been were very helpful in narrowing down beer choices that fit my tastes.  Despite it being super busy each time I've been, they never seem rushed or like they have somewhere else to be.  They are also casual, laid back and very friendly, without being intrusive or overbearing throughout the dining experience. The place is pretty small, with a long bar that takes up most of the space. But it is really cozy and cute, with a great neighborhood-y kind of feel to it. I wouldn't recommend it for a large group, but it's a great 2-4 person dinner spot or bar hang out. 

We wanted to share beers so that we could taste more, and instead of just giving us the two beers, our server brought four classes so that we could properly taste and share the beers we were getting. 

The food is also outstanding. You MUST try the mushroom and buratta toast. It is one of the most surprisingly delicious things I've ever had. We ordered it upon a recommendation from the server, with a little skepticism, and it was SO good! It is drizzled with a little bit of honey, and the flavors are truly wonderful. 

All around, a really impressive and lovely experience. This place competes among many great SF restaurants as a personal favorite. Could not recommend more.
author: Katherine D.

description: Perfect for the girl who doesn't know this beer from that beer. We came after having dinner across the street at Picaro and was overwhelmed by the beer options. My partner in crime loves specialty beers and so it took a while to narrow it down to the first  drink. After that, I promptly made him pick one for me and settled on a white allagash that proved to be perfect for this non-beer connoisseur. Also, points for the chalk board in the corner and ability to play hangman with friends while waiting.
author: Leina K.

description:
This is such a fantastic place. Worth the wait for a table anytime.

Everything on the menu looks so good that it's hard to choose, but the staff give great recommendations (same goes for the beer selection). If you can't decide, definitely ask.

I had the daily roast both times - hanger steak and king salmon - and both were unbelievable. Top it off with the bread pudding dessert and I'm in heaven.
author: Madeline P.

description:
In the neighborhood early enough to find a parking space.  Yelped to see what's in the neighborhood and decided on Monk's Kettle.  

It's quaint with ambiance lighting.  There are some booths and some tables with bench seatings. 

What we had:

Moonlight Brewing - Toast $6.50 - dark, Reality Czeck - $5.75 for me

Hop Riot $7.25 and Pliny the Elder $7.75 for 20 oz each for hubby

Cornmeal fried oysters, house hot sauce, cucumber ketchup  - $2.75 each - we had two each.  The oysters are small but the cornmeal crust was crispy and the sauce was good.

Seared diver scallop, bacon wrapped apple, raisin gastrique - $15 - the scallop was slightly overcooked but the dish was tasty.

Seared sweetbreads, parsnip, pickled apple slaw - $15 - it was delicious
 
half french fries - $4 - it was good

daily roast - $21 - $2 split charge w/ roasted potatoes, fennel and garlic that melts/spreads - quite delicious and generous portion

chocolate bread pudding w/ vanilla ice cream - $8 - yummy

hubby really enjoyed it so we'll definitely return if in the neighborhood.
author: Gloria H.

description:
This place sucks so bad that it swallows. Or maybe it sucks so good that it swallows. Either way...it sucks or rather the customer service sucked. 

I'm not going to get into it and bore you with the gory details. Let's just say we were rushed out of here and rather rudely. I guess it was a shift change or something but I felt a little bullied. 

Never again will I park my but at this establishment. 
Too bad for you Monk's Shittle. I love to spend money and you'll never see a dime of it. 
You lose!!!
author: Gabe T.

description:
Having been on my "to try" restaurant list for quite some time, I was lucky enough to be treated to a meal here several Friday nights ago to celebrate my new job! It's well known that the 'Kettle doesn't take reservations, but we came at about 7 pm, were quoted an hour wait, and just went across the street to Elixir to grab a quick cocktail.

Seated just about an hour later, the bf and I settled in for a really memorable meal. We started with the housemade pretzel and cheese sauce (carby goodness) and mussels, and then moved on to the real star of the show, the Monk's Daily Roast (that night was pork loin with cheesy...polenta/grains/grits/something soooo delicious). I'm usually a little skeptical to order a special if it's not super well described (literally on menu: Monk's Daily Roast), but this caught me off guard in the best possible way. The meat practically melted in my mouth, and we paired it with a sour-style beer that really brought the dish together. 

The servers were not pretentious at all, which I had feared a little bit since the beer menu is SO extensive, but we also ordered a pilsner and a hef to share and were really pleased with both.

The tables are really close together, so be wary of that, but the couple seated next to us did share their cheese plate, so no complaints from me!
author: Laura H.

description:
When I ate here recently with a friend, I took a photo.  And checked in on Facebook.  I liked it THAT much.  Being an old fart, I tend to shy away from social media as much as possible.  Monk's Kettle brought me out of my shell, for just a moment, to share with the world the awesomeness of the scallops.  Day boat scallops.  With lobster butter. Duck fat fried potatoes.  I think maybe an heirloom cherry tomato or two might have fallen in there, but hard to be sure. Oh yes.  And there was bacon. Muahahahahaha.  Oh yessss. There was bacon, alright.

That being said, we just came in for some drinks and a bite.  So the only other dish ordered was the daily pickle jar.  Since my fam is originally from Eastern Europe, I would like to think I know a thing or two about pickled...well, pickled everything.  I ate pickled things growing up that still haven't made it to a Portlandia skit.  These were "aiight", but nothing to write home to Mother Russia about.  The brine was too sweet for my taste, and sadly much of the contents of the jar remained uneaten.  And I don't like to waste food.  Ever.  Commie lessons die hard.

I'm sure I had this coming, but I had a case of the sniffles and opted for a hot tea instead of a beer.  I know, I knoooooow.  I should be ordering a fancy something beer to keep my cool kid card. I thought though, no, let's try a tea.  I asked how the lemongrass tea was, and the server scoffed when "tea" was uttered after "lemongrass."  "Ohhhhh, I thought you were going to ask how the Lemongrass Saison was.  Which, is amazing.  The tea, well.  It's tea.  It's nice."  THANKS for that insightful comment.  Guess what uppity server lady?  The tea was DELIGHTFUL.  Thank you very much.  

Still giving 4 stars for dimly lit and log-house chic geometric reclaimed wood art (yes, I looked up the artist and yes, I will probably buy some of her work) ambience, and the delicious scallops, just overall atmosphere.  Would be fun to go again and get a beer and be allowed back into the circle of trust again.  One day.  One day...
author: Michelle M.

description: If you like beer, this is a good place. It is pricey but it depends on how much you consume, since a single bottle is close to 1 liter or more. The menu is overwhelming, to be honest. I am not exactly a beer connoisseur, so I didn't know exactly what to get and didn't want to just take a chance at a bad tasting beer for that amount of money. If they had beer flights which let you sample different ones, that would be nice way of trying their brands. Luckily, the servers were nice enough to recommend and explain the different brands to us. Thanks! I would go back.
author: Edgardo V.

description:
Joie de Vi-vre. 

I began the evening eating marrow from a bone. Which, in retrospect, seems a foreshadowing. Good thing I didn't have two dem marrow canoes. No telling what would have happened. 

With Trouble, I enjoyed beef cheeks, a lovely mushroom risotto, said canoe. A pretzel. Beer of a variety I can't recall but I liked the first one better than the second. A variety I think broad enough to suit even the most discriminating palette. Sat at the bar so as to remind myself that I'll never be tragically hip Don't want to be, but even if I did, can't. 

Not cheap, not expensive. Wait and door staff friendly and good at what they do. I will definitely return. 

What followed defies description. I'd ask you to pinch me, because I feel as if I still must be dreaming. But if I am, if you pinched me, I'd wake up. 

So please. Don't pinch me.
author: Markus N.

description:
I've been here several times.  They never stood out to me as anything other that a pub with decent food.

However my entire conception of what this place is was altered by my dining experience my boyfriend and I had last night.  As diners we usually steer towards wine as it has the in credible capacity to enhance your meal when paired properly.

Last night we ordered the flat bread and charcuterie and the bartender suggested a beer flight pairing. 

The result was phenomenal.  It outshines all of my previous experiences and I think I may have found my new after work dinner spot. The concept of pairing beer with food is new to me and our bartender did a phenomenal job being our guide through our dining experience. 

Thank you to Jimmy,  I think that was his name, the tall ginger bartender.  He's great. If he's there you will definitely have an amazing experience.
author: Caitlin S.

description: This place has an amazing selection of fancy beers with fancy glasses that are fun to try, as well as a selection of food which is hit or miss to me. It is usually packed and can be a wait to get a seat and the noise level can be particularly loud as well.
author: Cody H.

description:
Amazing everything - Manzanita - smoked light beer local to Cali - excellent.

Sat at bar and had our pick of tastes from the draft plus the delightful bartender.

Ordered the duck special and muscle appetizer to share. Left totally wowed by the rich delectable experience, excellent service, and down to earth staff.

Xoxo! Enjoy!
author: Toni M.

description: You guys are fundamentally blowing it by not using your awesome pretzel dough for the burger bun. Btw, your $17 dollar burger tastes like a $7 burger at best. The fries are ok. The oysters were bomb. The pretzel cheese sauce and mustard are on point and should probs be an option for every dish.
author: Ross C.

description:
My supper here proved that The Monk's Kettle was another recommendation for City dining that clearly earned its reputation.

First, the beer: their bottle list is extensive, easily the largest I saw during my trip. That said, I stuck with draft, and their taps are well beyond respectable for breadth and quality; I had an Old Speckled Hen on nitro.

Then came the food.  I started with the old-school pretzel knot, which unsurprisingly came out fresh and hot and light, accompanied by a grain mustard and a mild cheddar fondue. It's on the large side, so share it out unless you skipped lunch.

My salad, the local greens, cheese, hazelnuts, and currants was also a portion large enough for a light meal in itself.  This sort of salad, with the contrasting C-textures (crisp, creamy, crunchy, chewy) and flavors is always going to win with me.  

For the main I went with the potentially least-interesting thing on the mains menu: the grilled chicken sandwich.  TMK shows you that this often derided sandwich is still a viable dinner when the chicken is cooked skillfully, the bread selected with care, and the fixins appropriately balanced.  This is a grilled chicken sandwich that will change your opinion of grilled chicken sandwiches. 

Table seating is limited, but the bar is more than comfortable.
author: Josh M.

description:
LOVE this place...everything except for the long wait. Too many people know how amazing Monk's is. It's cramping my style. It can really be a 2hr+ wait sometimes, but 100% worth your time. Go to Dalva and have a grapefruit soda or 2 (you will think me) at the Hideout in the back and time will pass more quickly ; )

The pretzel with creamy cheese is delicious (of course). The real show stopper is the burger. Oh my god. Just get the burger. Do it. It's juicy in the middle, with lightly caramelized pieces on the outside and the meat is seasoned so well is practically magic. It's mind blowing how they can pack so much delicious flavor into a burger patty, and not just salty flavor...a complex blend of very different flavors that make your taste buds sing.

The daily roast is out of this world too. I had the short ribs over mashed potatoes once. I was raving about how it was one of the best dishes I've had in SF...then my boyfriend started eating his first Monk's burger. He's not even a foodie at all, but he is a burger expert and he almost lost his mind eating this burger. He was literally moaning with every bite and looked so happy he looked like he was about to cry. He made it look so unbelievable I just wanted to drop my fork and launch across the table to steal his burger for myself. In the end, he finally came back to his senses and let me have a bite. Now I only order the burger so that I don't have the urge to steal his meal throughout our entire dinner.

The beer selection is like the menu at the cheese cake factory, but in a good way. It even has a glossary in the back, which is amazingly helpful especially for a wine drinker like me. This has to be the best beer list in the city. They have such cool beer that even I drink beer here. I don't even usually drink beer, so this is a big deal. Try some sour beer on your beer-venture here...it's crazy good. They also have the best glassware I've seen anywhere in San Francisco. Like one million different glasses for the different beer selections. 

In summary, go get the burger. Caution: you will never be able to go to certain places again: Marlowe, Umami, Roam...just to name a few. Sorry Marlowe. I love you too, but you have been slightly out mastered.
author: Juliet S.

description: Excellent beers on tap with an up-beat drinking environment. I highly recommend the soft pretzel appetizer. Great customer service as well.
author: Alicia S.

description: Decent food and great beer selection!  Would definitely go back.  The place is a bit cramped.  Very clean bathrooms.  :-)
author: Paul W.

description:
Unbelievable beer selection.  Amongst the top 10 in terms of variety I've experienced across the US. 

I had a tremendously delicious dark saison, currently on draft.  Simple appreciation of the beers is what most people do, these guys go into the nuances of how the beer was crafted as well as provide the proper glass for consumption whenever possible. 

The ambience is the only place I'd fault this bar.  I'm new to SF, so I don't have a lot to compare such bars to yet.  It was a big muggy, a bit awkward to sit at the bar.  The aisle isn't big enough for the wait staff to go through without being impeded by this drinking at the bar.  Else, this is a 5 star place.  

Love that there is no TV here!
author: Anand A.

description: i recently spent 3 days in San Francisco and ate lunch at the Monk's Kettle twice. The best burger and fries in the United States - and any other country I've ever visited.  The service is great and friendly - the atmosphere is relaxed with a cool mix of music playing in the background, but the food and beer is what will call you back.
author: Duke H.

description:
I feel like a kid in a candy store when I come in here!

So many beers, so little time (and ability to function after so many beers) - come for the beer and stay for the food.

Their beer menu is like a bible for beer worshipers - don't go expecting Bud Light because you won't find it here. I was really pleased with how well versed our waitress was about the beer and she offered us some wonderful suggestions. We tried:
Pliney the Elder (one of my all time favorite beers)
Reality Czeck
Heavenly Hefe
Tsjeeses
Jubel (10.0 ABV!)
Guldenberg
X-1 (my first time trying a sour beer - tasted like cherry pie!)
Double Bastard (11.2 ABV!!)

The food was amazing (and not just because I was buzzed off my gourd) and their menu offers suggestions on what types of brews to pair with your choices.  We sampled the following:

Appetizers:
Pretzel (this is a MUST have - we HAD to have more than a couple...okay, we had 4!)
Corned Beef Hash Croquettes - I really enjoyed this - savory, with a tender inside and crispy outside.

Entrees:
Chicken under a brick - GET IT! The skin was so crispy and the meat to friggin' tender and delicious.  I also really enjoyed the beans that came with the chicken.
Mushroom Risotto - PERFECT! The mushrooms were so good and the risotto was cheesy and amazing.
Burger - do you like burgers? Then GET THE DAMN BURGER! Get it with bacon. SO GOOD!
Bavette Steak - also amazing - ordered medium rare (and it came out medium rare!) and served on top of pureed sweet potatoes and brussels sprout gratin - never thought I would admit to loving brussels sprouts, but yeah...this was so good.

Dessert:
Dark Chocolate Bread Pudding - OMFG...YES!
Nitrogen Beer Float - Seriously...they used a pumpkin ale...spicy and sweet at the same time.
Cheesecake - another winner!

My only complaint about this place? I don't have the stamina to drink every single beer I want to when I come!  Solid place to bring your beer aficionados AND your picky eaters. 

Can't wait to go back!
author: Christy L.

description:
Burger, burger, burger! Give me a burger, now! I wish I was still in SF so I can eat one this instant. This seriously is the best burger I've ever had. I like my burger simple, where I can still taste how good the meat is. Everything about this burger is perfection, from the buns to the meat to the onion jam to the aged white cheddar. Oh and don't forget the hop salt fries! Yes, hop salt fries =) 

I came with friends who got the burger and another dish to share, but the burger was so good they ended up ordering another burger. Yes, that good!

They also carry an insane varieties of beer, a book of different kinds. 

I can't wait to eat this heavenly burger again. Drools
author: Mai-Tam N.

description: Amazing beer selection! Plus these guys know their stuff.  They even let you sample is a super cute little beer shaped shot glass.  OMG the burger here is amazing.  Definitely a must order.  Fries are okay, just regular fries, so I probably wouldn't order them separately.  The pretzel knot is great, even the sauces tastes better than regular sauces.  Only problem with it is that I ended up inhaling it, and it seemed to disappear in front of my face.
author: Tiffany C.

description: It's so crowded here!!! It's tiny but I think we waited an hour for a table! Great choices on beers and it's a bit loud so I wouldn't recommend it for a first date.. MAYBE a 2nd ;) wink.
author: Jenna L.

description:
reasons why I like this place 1. open late 2. good food (served late) 3. Beer heaven.
This place has a drinks menu that consists of 15 plus pages.  Draught, lagers,ales,fruity beers, spiced,sweet, sour, gluten free and the list goes on.....  We picked a few random ones and they were all good!  The food menu comes with beer pairing suggestions...there is dessert as well.  A small intimate place with a long bar and tables wrapping the edges of this place.  Can get a bit loud but overall but I was still able to carry a conversation without screaming.  I tried the regular burger and also ordered a chickpea version..both equally delish.  
The menu is pretty extensive which should keep everyone satisfied.  Next time I am going to try the mussels I saw on the menu =).  Super friendly staff, I enjoyed it here.
author: Helen C.

description:
After having some very sub-par beers and some dive bars in the neighborhood, my husband and I were fed up and wanted some decent food and a craft beer. I pulled out my Yelp app and found The Monk's Kettle within a few blocks of us, so we headed straight for it. When we arrived on a Monday afternoon, it was a packed house. There did not appear to be any available tables or bar stools for the two of us. We soon spotted a rather large table empty by the bar and as a server passed, we inquired about the table. At first he hesitated to give it to us, but we assured him we would be good customers. I am not sure what the seating system is, but a hostess or a sign would be appreciated. We pulled off our jackets and dived into the beer list.

It was the tail end of SF beer week that day, so there were some fun things on tap. I started with a Rodenbach Grand Cru, a Flanders sour ale. I also had the short ribs that day, with potatoes and roasted vegetables. It was the perfect warm, hearty meal to stand up the bold flavors of my sour. My husband had the daily roast, which was pork osso bucco and he quickly cleared his plate and declared it "amazing". 

The vintage bottle list, which are purchased to go, was very impressive. I took home a few Russian Rivers that we added right to our beer cellar. Top notch beer, top notch service, and wholesome food. The Monk's Kettle gets it right.
author: Sheena M.

description: This place is ok, if you can get in the door. I'm not a fan of beer, but in my experience the servers are very good about helping suit your tastes. Worth checking out if you can get there during an off time, but if there's a line, I would move along.
author: Katrina R.

description:
First best thing- Kari at the door. She knows her shit. It's one thing to know the restaurant, but it takes a real pro to know your customers.  Went in tonight and she told us it would be an hour to an hour and a half for a table. But if we wanted to sit at the bar, she told us to go stand by a particular customer. He was a regular and she knew his habits. She knew he would be getting up soon. She was spot on.  5 minutes after walking over, he got up leaving his (and the seat next to him) open.

Food: Salad was very good- nice crunchy glazed nut accents (macadamia's maybe) on mixed greens and perfect amount of balsamic.

Mussels were ok - over-seasoned for my taste. Nice for dunking bread in the broth but overpowered the  mussels themselves. Only reason I didn't give 5 stars.

Mushroom risotto was perfect. Best risotto I've had in a long time. Get it if you want to have dinner bliss. Even if you don't like mushrooms, you will after you've had this dish.

On the way out Kari asked about our dinner and really seemed to care about the answer. Not just lip service.

I'll definitely be going back.
author: Kez Q.

description:
Good beer selection, but come early if you want to sit and talk.

The fries made a good beer soak so get some if you need to remain relatively sober after drinking and don't want a full meal.
author: Megan E.

description:
Great service prompting the 4 stars! 

Good beer and wine selections but a little on the pricey side of life for what you get...
author: Bryce C.

description:
Mustaches, beards, & beer - they've got 'em all on tap. Yes, we hungrily waited a combined hour-something for one of our friends to show up then for a table to open, but we all agreed it was worth it.

Delicious entrees were had at our table, but what riled us up most were the appetizers. All I can say is, "Bone Marrow Boat" - if you haven't tried it, get it. If you're vegetarian or vegan or vegemite, bring a carnivorous friend so they can get it. It's a thick cross-sectioned bone with the marrow and fat soft, warm, and partway liquefied. It comes with little bread dippers and it's indulgent.

"Pickle Jar" was pretty funky, in that SF bohemian baja patchouli way. Maybe minus the patchouli though, but put the hood up on your baja. It wasn't just "pickles" like fermented cucumbers. It was parts of cucumber, carrot, cauliflower, string bean, olive, and basically whatever. It also wasn't just "pickles" like sour cucumbers. It was definitely sourish or somewhat fermented, but each kind of vegetable carried a sweetness through the pickleness. We supposed this to be due to a more natural preparation process than that of supermarket pickles. This dish took each of us by surprise in appreciated and not so appreciated ways.

"Chicken Paillard", whatever that means, came with bacon jam. Bacon jam is the type of thing you'd want on the side with any and every food, atop your dessert, and swished into your beer - it's that crazy and it's that good, judging by the reactions of those at the table who got the jean-luc paillard. We asked the waiter and learned that there have been staff meetings about whether or not to let bacon jam be an independent and requestable condiment. As their collective decision stands, bacon jam is exclusively featured pre-applied exclusively to the paillard.

Beers, beers, beers, hundreds and hundreds of beers. Among our rich selection was "1/2 Idjit" from Sweden. If you're nostalgic for the 80's... denim, synthesizers, big hair, over-accessorizing, Jordache, large hair, neon, cartoons, huge hair... if your heart beats for this stuff, 1/2 Idjit's your co-pilot because it tastes like straight-up Aqua Net. Remember that hairspray? That's this beer. Not that I've ever ingested hairspray, but the cloud of smell that envelops you when you're putting your hair on freeze tag notice smells 100% how this beer tastes.

Loved the staff. Totally nice, considerate of food allergies & preferences, deeply knowledgeable of the beverages, professional at pouring the beers, and our main waiter had the same name as my brother. In fact, I'd say the staff can be a little TOO good. My friends and I eat slowly anyway because we're mostly talking and laughing and taking photos. But as we got on into the appetizers, we kept wondering why the other stuff we ordered wasn't showing up. After a while, we asked and found out that our waiter had "coursed out" our items, meaning that entrees arrive once appetizers are finished, and so on through further courses. It's cool that in a Mission restaurant with a skinny jeans Am Appy dude at the door and fixies walking by outside that we'd get such thoughtfully polished service. But you know what? Just give us the food - pile it up on our table and clutter the place with everything because we're just hungry and we want to eat.

This place also has a small wall of chalkboard along the rear counter seating. Drawing in restaurants is always a good thing. Somebody draw me some bacon jam.
author: Dan B.

description:
Though not beer drinkers, the gf and I were craving some late night food, and Monk Kettle's menu looked far more appealing than a diner. 

Though they initially said it would be a 45min wait for a table (at 11pm), they ended up seating us within 10 minutes. We shared the very tasty nuts (my gastropub must-have), pretzel knot (decent), and veggie burger (so-so). 

Good service and atmosphere--we'll definitely return!
author: David Z.

description: Only had beer here, and I must repeat what others have said, the beer list here is intimidating. But its got every beer you could want, from as cheap as $5 a glass to $40 a glass, so all price ranges are possible.
author: Jon H.

description: Good food and beer. A little pricey for me though. More of a special occasion place.
author: Bill L.

description: The service was great, the food was really good and there are all kinds of beers to choose from. We had a great time here.
author: Joe B.

description: Had a fine time here when I was visiting from Seattle. We didn't have to wait for a seat at the bar (we were there kind of early, around 6:30 on a Saturday) and the bartender was very helpful (and not snobby) when explaining the extensive beer menu. This place is a mecca for beer snobs and hipsters, but the atmosphere was friendly and fun. Our beers were excellent and the food looked really good too, especially the burgers. I would come back!
author: Lisa B.

description:
I want to say the food sucked and the service was abysmal but I would be lying...it's too late to make that statement to keep people away. It was INCREDIBLE! I needed several moments after taking bite after delicious bite. The service was impeccable and attentive; not intrusively so either. Can't wait to go back and try EVERYTHING on the menu. If you love beer, this is the place for you. They even pair beer with the main...awesome.
My friend and I started out with the cornmeal crusted deep friend oysters that came with a cucumber ketchup and delicious hot sauce. Then we shared an order of 3 corned beef hash croquettes with a whipped bone marrow lemon aioli sauce that made me swoon!
We both had the roast special of the day which was braised short ribs with horseradish mashed potatoes and greens. It was a sublime dish all around. For dessert we had to have the beignets...too, too good.
Did I mention the service was spectacular and very friendly? They left enough room between courses for us to have a good conversation and anticipate our next plates.
By the time we finished eating (and we were the first people there at noon) the place was getting filled so I couldn't imagine trying to eat there at night.
My only complaint is my usual: the tables are too close together. When another couple sat down next to us, I felt like I was part of their conversation and vise versa. I know they want to pack the small place so I'll give them that, but it seems the latest trend in restaurants these days. Oh, and the music selection is great, too. 
My husband is in for a real treat for his birthday lunch coming up!
author: Mary D.
