description: We met some friends here for lunch twice now. There is patio seating now, which is awesome for dogs. I love the pickle jar, pretzels, soups and salads. Their daily sandwich is also good. And nothing beats the craft beers on draft!
author: Cindy T.

description:
I always enjoy eating here. The beer list is phenomenal and the menu, while perhaps not 'challenging' enough for the serious gourmet is nicely prepared and flavorsome. I enjoy the veggie burger, cheese plate, the ice cream beer float (yes!) I've heard good things about the roasts too.

Yes, it gets very busy and they don't take reservations (which is fine) but I wish they would maintain a list and phone/text you when you're table is free because usually the bar is full with people eating, and there isn't space to wait inside and have a drink.

Be warned - they are Nazis about having to seat your whole party too, but then the service - while being totally fine - isn't lightning fast so it bugs me that they wouldn't let 3 out of a party of 4 sit in comfort for 5 mins while we wait for our final guest.

For the two points above I've docked them a half a star.

The crowd can be a bit mission hipster douche.. but, well, it's the Mission. Having said that, i took my 70 yr old parents here once and the servers were extremely polite, respectful and visibly enjoyed the novelty of having older people in the house. Needless to say, Mum and Dad loved the fact they were more than double the age of anyone else in there.

This is just a good gastro pub.
author: Matt G.

description:
This is a nice little bar with friendly staff, and the beer selection they have is pretty impressive for such a small place.  They had some beers that you probably won't find at many other bars.

The only problem is that although its small and cosy, its just TOO small.  They have a few tables by the windows but those are only available if you plan on eating, which while understandable is a bit of a downer.  The rest of the area available for sitting if you are just drinking is either the bar, or a row of stools next to a counter.  So if you have a place in mind that you want to sit, you better get there early to grab it.
author: Nicole S.

description:
2.5 stars.

Maybe I am being too harsh since one shouldn't generally expect good food from a bar, but then again bar food is usually cheap and The Monk's Kettle is not.  When it comes down to it, $14 for a chicken sandwich with a side of fries is ridiculous.  Especially when the grilled chicken is sort of dry, and the two pieces of stale tasting sandwich bread are each 1-inch thick while the chicken and small portion of toppings/condiments totaled 3/4-inch.  My mouth couldn't generate enough saliva to break down that food!  Too bad because the bacon jam and mustard were a nice complement to the chicken, there just wasn't enough.  My date's dish was no better - the veggie burger was bland and also proportionately lacking in condiments.  He took about 4 bites and didn't even take the leftovers to go!  The side of fries were pretty good initially but over-salted, therefore contributing further to my dry mouth.  The much raved about pretzel bun was.... just a pretzel bun.  I cannot begin to understand why are people obsessed with it.

Oh yeah, and the beer...  While Monk's Kettle has a great selection, I still prefer City Beer and Toronado.  I mean, the same pint of Pliny at Toronado costs $6 while Monk's Kettle charges $8... not cool.
author: Beatrice W.

description:
For starters we had the pretzel and the scallops. For the actual entrees we had half chicken and the monks roast.

Loved the half chicken and the monks roast. I was a bit skeptical when the waiter recommended the half chicken, but boy was  I blown away!

For a table for 2 on a Monday we waited for about 45 mins for dinner around 730. This place is small and isn't meant for large groups. I would say a group of 4 if you want to eat here. It's a small place wit a large variety of beers! 

I don't remember the names of beers that we got but the prices ranged from 7-50 or even more. 

We chose this place for the large beer selection and I was quite impressed with their food. Win win! 

Took left overs home and brought it to work and my coworkers were talking about how amazing my food smelled. Will definitely be back! 

In case you were curious, for two people, our bill came out to about $100.
author: Sophie C.

description:
While the Mission is notoriously less of a "see and be seen" neighborhood when compared to its arch-nemesis the Marina, let's not lie...for hipsters and techsters and bro-sters alike, this is one of the happening spots to rack up your indie-cool points.  So what did I do to up my hipster cred?  Naturally, I sabotaged myself and took my mama here for lunch.

And man, does any other place live up to it's hype the way these guys do?

Let's start with the beer selection.  Obviously, it's incredible.  It is both ginormous and impeccably and carefully curated, with bartenders and servers who know each beer passionately.  The food, however, was a 10 on its own.  I had the grilled chicken sandwich with mustard-BBQ sauce, bacon jam, and some other shenanigans that I'm too lazy to look up, served with the hop salt fries.  Unreal.  This was one of the tastiest things I've had in years.  Paired with a Pliny the Elder, this was maybe the best lunch I've had since I've moved to the city.  Mama S had a chickpea burger that she similarly declared as incomparable, and is already planning her next trip back (paired it with a chocolate-y stout or something, I was geeking out over Pliny and didn't really notice).

Bottom line, this is a phenomenal place to stop by for lunch or dinner.  Weekday lunch had no wait, but perpetually long lines for dinner.  Always easy to grab a seat at the bar if you can wait around for ten minutes max, and as a bonus, you can play hangman on the chalkboard.
author: James S.

description: A great selection of beers! We came to taste the brews, so we didn't know they served food as well. I was told about their cheese plate,  so we will have that our next go round
author: Ness M.

description: I went to The Monk's Kettle for the Founders Brewing NorCal launch event. They had a good selection of Founders beer and had made a food menu to pair specifically to each beer they were offering. All the beer and food here is very good, especially the burger. The only thing I would say is to avoid the desserts, they are not good.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Good drinks. Nice ambiance. Great crowd and staff. Loooooong wait.

If you are a party of 2, you can easily hop a spot at the bar. With any additional compadres, expect a wait of 2+ hours. Our wait was 3.5 hours for a party of 4 on a Saturday night. 

We tried the chartecurie, pretzel, tomato basil soup, scallops, potato croquettes, kale salad, chickpea burger, beef burger, steak, and carrot cake.

The stars were the kale salad with toasted couscous, and the chickpea burger. Everything else was overly seasoned or just not spectacular. The drinks were great!
author: Grace G.

description:
Again - kitchen open til 1 am, which is huge! couldn't find another decent place in the area serving food around 10 pm on Thursday night.

Half chicken under a brick is superb.
Local greens is a great filling salad. 
Fries are very average, too thick and undercooked - no need unless you want something quick. 
Dark chocolate bread pudding is LITERALLY PERFECT. 

Try the Lips of Faith draft if you like a good sour sour beer. 

:)
author: Sonya Z.

description: the best place in the mission district. I like hang out there with cm friends good music and fun people. I love visit there for the vibe and love the night life in that area. most of the time it's full many lady's and not a lot of man so my kind of place.
author: Michael D.

description:
I was here specifically for the sour beer event that was part of SF Beer Week. I've never been to Monk's Kettle so I'm not sure how they regularly handle business. 

I waited for an hour outside waiting to get a chance to try some of the special sour beers. As people waited in line an employee came out and asked people if they were interested in eating or just drinking. People that requested to be seated for eating were seated before me because those seats opened up faster than the stools at the bar. A friend of mine joined me and he waited about 30 minutes with me before we got in. Unfortunately he had to leave and meet some people for a birthday party but another friend of mine was joining me. The staff would not let my other friend come in and join me as my other friend left. We couldn't just switch out one person for another even though I waited an hour and other people got to go in before me. The rigidity of the policy didn't really make sense to me. Two people waited to go in to drink for the special event that they were hosting and other people waited less time and got to go in before but I couldn't have a friend join me as another friend left. I feel that if you're hosting a special event you should make accommodations to serve those people that are there for your event. 

I was very frustrated and disappointed that my first experience didn't meet my expectation. 

The server was very friendly and gave us a great recommendation for a beer to try. Unfortunately I couldn't stay long since my other friend was waiting for me outside since the staff wouldn't let her in. I finished the beer, paid and left. Despite the delicious beer, I left with an unpleasant taste. 

We ended up bar hopping and enjoying other beer week specials at various bars that didn't have strange policies.
author: Daisy S.

description:
Pretentious and basically selective on who to choose to let in was the theme for the individual in charge of seating people.

How dare you? I'm blaming management on such poor oversight. This individual definitely needs to be skull f**ked or at least re-calibrated for his demeanor. 

For real beer, real food, and some honest to goodness real service, you can pretty much go anywhere else besides this place. 

Or if you want to be exposed to douchbaggery....this place is epic!!!! Come one...come all and see this douche bag work his magic as you walk in.

Will he surprise you with his hidden and deceivable words?
Or will he just ignore you and make you feel unwelcome?
Will he say one thing..and totally mean something else?
Who knows what this c*ck knocker has in mind for his next trick.

Stay tuned for another poor review from a concerned reviewer like myself.
author: Mike C.

description:
What to do for lunch on the long weekend? Come here. Not only did my friends and I get our food fixing, we also got our beers. (Being the beer connoisseur we are, not). 

As everyone mentioned, they have lots of beers. Too many that their menu is like the bible.   In enjoying the last days of summer, I settled on the Pliny the Elder IPA.  It was fruity, sweet, and refreshing.  It paired well with the tri tip steak that I ordered for may meal.   The steak was seasoned well and cook medium rare.  No complaints on the meat just the sides that accompanied it. The sweet potatoes were limp and the vegetable on the salty side.   

We also ordered the bone marrow as a starter.  Ordering one bone, it was larger than what I expected.   I love bone marrow anything. [Bone marrow = gold) But this one I found the execution and taste lacking. Taste wise, it could have used more salt. Also, a spoon with the dish would have helped scoop out the marrow rather than the butter knife.    

Overall this is a great beer place. With so many, I will be back to diversify my beer repertoire.
author: Marck N.

description: mussels + fries + pink wine + best friend = best brunch ever. cute waiters don't hurt either! :)
author: Sadie N.

description:
#50 on the 7x7 List: Giant pretzel with mustard

-Tasty?  It's a giant soft pretzel with stone ground mustard and housemade cheddar ale sauce

-Service:  Very good.  The bartender was good to give a sample when J was unsure of which of the kabillion beers on the menu to try

-Ambiance: Nice peaceful pub for a relaxing beer

-Worth the trip/try?  $9 for a pretzel is a bit steep, but this place is a must-go if you're at least curious about the 5 pages of menu dedicated to beer

Samples are served in midget-sized beer mugs.  The Poppy Jasper is a nice hoppy beer if you like the hoppy taste.   The waitress was in the know about the 7x7 list and was very nice about us sharing the one pretzel during lunchtime.
author: Winnie L.

description: This place is all about the beer ! The guy that helped me was very knowledgable and took his time to explain the different type of beers, what the beers were made of, and where it was from. I feel like I gave him a hard time because I couldn't decide which beer to get, but he was still really friendly and helpful ! Def coming back here when I'm in the area again.
author: Jimmy H.

description:
Ah-mazing. 

My boyfriend and I went for dinner last night and everything was great. We had been here for drinks before (beer and wine only) but last night we thought we'd try the food too.

Everything was good, I probably said this is the best _______ I've ever had, at least 3 times. I got a chicken sandwich with hop salt fries, my boyfriend got a veggie burger and we both got drinks (which were also amazing). 

If craft beer and/or wine are your thing, you'll love this place. Well, if food is your thing, you'll probably love this place, too. It's like pub food reimagined and super clean. 

We usually never get dessert but I looked at the menu and they had a stout bread pudding, we had to try it. I can honestly say I think it's the best dessert I've ever had. It wasn't too sweet and the flavors were on point.

If you come on a Friday night, there might be a bit of a wait, but it is worth every second!

DEFINITELY try this place if you are in the SF area!
author: Katlin L.

description:
The burger I ate here was the best I've ever eaten.

I eat a lot of burgers.

The beer selection is also pretty remarkable, and the servers are knowledgable about the beers.

Great service.

The burger. Get the burger.
author: Kyle J.

description:
I've been here a few times in the years since it's opened.  The variety of the beer is very good, but really the only thing going for it.  I've had dinner a couple times, and it was mediocre quality, overpriced, and nothing special. 

I stopped in today (easter sunday) with my wife and a friend.  They swapped beers and my wife made the mistake of saying one of them was 'more stouty' than the other (to her friend).  I then observed the barback (who was literally standing across the bar from them) start mocking / clowning them to the server/bartender.  I'm sure the word 'stouty' sounds lame to a beer aficionado, but talking shit about your customers while standing right in front of them is unprofessional at best.
author: Josh F.

description:
How perfect was it to come & drink here two days before my beer brewing class midterm... For once, something I learned in college is useful in life! 

Anyway, I have never been to a pub that served so many different types of beer! The staff was friendly, patient, attentive (despite the huge crowd), and extremely knowledgeable. I love the little glasses they give you to test some beer! And don't get me started with the dessert. The chocolate stout bread pudding with ice cream is pure heaven. They're freshly made... yum! My friend also ordered fries. What's nice is you can order half size, which is seriously equivalent to a normal size... they were extremely salty in my opinion, though.

The only downside to this place is it gets crowded & reaches max cap real fast... so come here early. and another downside: I felt like a total noob, not knowing what to order. Thank you, bartender (I forgot your name, sorry!) for being so sweet and helpful. I will be back!
author: Janet H.

description:
Incredible beer selection at this small yet beautiful gastropub in the middle of the Mission district. I was looking for the best beer selection bar around and Monk'S more than delivered.

The draft list was nice, but the bottle selection seems unending. Service was extremely friendly and knowledgeable. It does get very crowded but at least we had a blackboard and some chalk to have fun with while we enjoyed our beers.

I will go back to Monk's whenever I am back in SF.
author: Esteban P.

description:
Still the best burger in the city and best beer selection. I went yesterday with colleagues from Denver and Vegas and they were very pleased.

Excellent beer recommendations from the staff, as usual.
author: J S.

description: So many beers! If there was a beer heaven this is probably close to what it would be like.
author: Joe W.

description: The Monk's Kettle is a cool spot.  They have lots of beers and other drinks to select from, along with a lot of interesting sounding food.  The burger is pretty good, but it was overly charred on the outside which definitely detracted from it.  Like most places in SF, it's pretty small...so I can guess it gets pretty busy at night.  I'd probably go back to Monk's, even though my burger experience there the other day didn't really stand out.
author: Brian B.

description:
Been to Monk's kettle three times.  One weekday evening and one saturday brunch and the third was a pickup order where it all happened.  

Here's my complaint.  The host, a typical hipster, not disimilar to an old chinese person in china town, it's hard for them to be nice.  You can see the struggle and the burn because it's in their job description.  They usually fail, but they think they passed.  this "pissster" had the pinched face of "bitch" I've seen many times before.  I was looking very preppy coming from work and I did what causes the pinched bitch face.  I smiled and said hello.  Based on his reaction you would have thought I said "hey I wanna sit on your face?". 

I hate that one small moment of suck can be the biggest thing on my mind walking away from that place.  I say, fire the dude.  He is white, blue eyes, some facial hair, he does the door during the week.  He might even be owner...if that is the case, get to the back office and stay there!! Well, if not a firing a 2nd chance and a stern talking to.

The food is tasty,  but maybe a bit over priced, but it's what I was expecting.  I most likely return because the food is really good and all of the other employees have been cool.
author: D E.

description:
I've always been of the impression that the Monk's Kettle is overrated. I've tried to come for drinks on a weeknight at least 4 times, but the place is always jam packed and I inevitably end up at Kilowatt or Gestault instead. I assumed that my attempt to have a beer last night would end up in the same disappointing trudge down 16th to another establishment, but to my surprise, my date was able to snag us the high table by the door!! Surprisingly, it's protected from the wind and not at all a cold place to sit. 

Boy was I wrong about the Monk's Kettle. It's awesome! Pricey and overcrowded, but their encyclopedia of beers and the extensive knowledge of their bartenders makes it worth it. 

I tend to like dark, flavorful beer, but not bitter or chocolaty. Unfortunately, I don't know what beers fit into that category, so when I opened the beer menu, I was immediately overwhelmed by options. For those of you like me, don't worry, the bartenders here are AAHHMAZING. I described the type of beer I like and he immediately started flipping through the menu pointing out beers that fit my taste palate. 

I ended up getting:
+ Aventinus ($11.75) - a German Weizenbock (8.20% ABV) that was SO good. After pouring most of the beer, our bartender began to swirl and tap the bottle to get all the yeast off the bottom and into my glass. I had seen this before, but never knew why it was done, so he graciously explained the process.
+ Pauwel Kwak ($12.50) - a Belgian Pale Ale (8.4% ABV) that was also great, though I preferred the Aventinus. This came in an hour-glass shaped glass which was held upright by a wooden stand. Our bartender made sure to explain that this presentation is an artifact of horse-drawn carriage days when the men needed a place to set down their beers while in the carriage.

Note that NOT all beers are this expensive.  The Draft Sea Monster Imperial Stout also has a high ABV, but was only $4.25. I don't believe that prices are listed on the menu, so if you care, you might have to ask. Don't quote me on that though.

Overall, a very educational and delicious evening of beer. I can't speak to the food here, but I can recommend trying at least one beer from their long list.
author: Talia G.

description:
Best beer selection in SF (that I know of).  If you like beer, you'll love Monk's Kettle.

The beer menu is extensive so there's always something new to try.  I believe they change their tap often as well.  There's a glossary in the back which is cool whether you're new to beer or a seasoned pro and learn one thing new.  The bartenders all seem to know their stuff and can teach you things about the fascinating world of beer.  I've eaten here before, and remember it being ok.. but I'm always there for the beer.

Its a great place to go on weekdays with a couple friends to try new beer and talk. It also makes for a nice date if you want to do something slightly different- teaching someone about beer is always fun. Its not too loud in here which is good for convos.  It does get packed on weekends, so I'd just recommend staying to weekdays.  Its especially cool that its open til 2 all week.

Bottom line-  beer selection is the best. If you love beer, you should go! If you don't love beer, you will once you go!
author: Eric J.

description: Food was amazing!  We had the poutine which has pork and gravy with hand cut french fries and for our entree, we had the burger.  Probably the best burger I've had as it was a brisket/beef mix.  Beer choices were excellent with a lot of CA craft beer as well as some vintage bottles available.
author: Katie T.

description:
They're snobby about letting you in, especially of you're not planning to eat. 

But, tough to beat Monk's Kettle on its block if you are eating, and these things: 
- house made pretzel 
- burger (competed right up there with Mission Beach, be sure to get it with bacon)
- I also fell in love with a seasonal blueberry beer they had last summer but unfortunately it doesn't seem to be available any more.
author: Stephanie T.

description: Absolutely my fav beer place!! Had never seen a 6-page long beer menu! Awesome food too! Cozy and fun.
author: Fanny Z.

description: Small bar on the corner with a huge selection of craft beers. They usually have Pliny the Elder on draft, which is a rare find anywhere else.
author: Jacob L.

description: Came here on a Friday night and had to wait 40 minutes for a table for 2. It's pretty small here but there's room in the back to stand and have a one or two of their many beers. It's either that or finding a spot at the bar. Food is good. I had the mushroom risotto and the boyfriend had their burger. Both were very delicious. Service was exceptional as well except for the fact that one of the waiters told me that all of the beer listings were on tap. Hah what a fool.
author: Mable N.

description:
02.12.11

I can't believe I've been going to this place for several years without doing a review.  Maybe I don't really want you guys to know how much I like it so the place doesn't get more packed.

You go to Monk's for good quality beer.  The list goes on for pages.  Draft.  Specialty.  Broken down by types.  There is definitely something for everyone.

I went for the bottled Amber Ale - Stone something?  Super delicious.  Try it.  Just don't drink so much that it runs out before I get there.
author: Jenny L.

description:
WOW! A "pub" with GREAT food, what a win! They have a huge selection of beer if you can find a seat at the bar/actually get a table. We had to show up at 5:45pm to make sure we got a table for dinner. 

My friends and I shared a lot of food- all recommended by our SUPER friendly and energetic waitress. 

APPETIZERS
Fried Oysters- Not a fan but it was my first time actually trying Fried Oysters (I know, don't discount my review because of it)
Corn Beef Hash Croquettes- YUMMM!!! These were sooo good and came with a really good lemon aioli!
Mushrooms on toast with Burrata- A MUST GET! This was sooo absolutely amazing. The flavors were so rich and strong, I couldn't believe how delicious this dish was! They used really big and tender mushrooms which paired perfectly with the burrata. 

ENTREES
Daily Roast- The roast was my favorite out of the three entrees we got. It was very tender and flavorful and was paired with great sides! I'd definitely recommend this dish over anything else. 
Burger- Wow, this burger was so good! It had almost a sweet flavor to it which was really enjoyable. I've heard a lot of hype about this burger and I think it lives up to its reputation! 
Roasted Mushroom Risotto- This dish was delicious but really rich and heavy. I'd say it would be too heavy of a dish to have on your own and would only recommend if you're going to share/split with someone else. 

DESSERT
Bread pudding- UGH, this was so good but very rich. It came with a scoop of ice cream on top which went perfect with the sweet, warm bread pudding! 

Overall, this place is great for food but I only gave 4 stars because it's superrr small and hard to get a table. Even when you are eating, there's tons of people everywhere all squished into a small space. However, if you can get a seat here, I'd highly recommend grabbing some food here as well!
author: Victoria L.

description:
Anyone coming here should most likely note, it will likely be packed. Especially on the weekends, there's almost always a wait if you don't have a rez. 

However, unlike most SF restaurants, they don't give you that snotty attitude and I've always been run through much quicker than what they told me. I was told it could be a 45 minute wait (it's a small restaurant) and was seated in 15-20. A refreshing suprise. A few times, I was seated right away despite the fact that it looked pack. It feels highly efficient. 

And that doesn't even cover the amazing selection of beers (which you can hang out & drink while you wait). It could give Toronado a run for it's money. Awesome belgiums. The food is fairly priced, non pretentious and really tasty. A great date spot, friend spot or place just to grab a beer. This place has range and with exception of one slightly sour server gal I had once, efficient & friendly service.
author: minnie b.

description: Solid gastropub with really good food & great beers. Poutine was damn good as was the pate / charcuterie plate.
author: D B.

description:
3.5 stars. If you are in the mood for very good quality food and expensive beer, with a side of noise and a crowd on a Saturday night, this is the place for you!

Very friendly service dominates this rather small place. But the prices here for the great food will set you back quite a bit. Here's an unvarnished view of what you can expect here:

We four had the following:

Two Winter lettuce Salads, white balsamic roasted pear, toasted pecans $9 ea.

Two Fresh ground burgers with onion jam, aged white cheddar, acme pain de mie, regular fries $13 ea. One added the house-cured pepper bacon (two slices) for $2.

One spent grain and chick pea burger, fromage blanc, onion jam, acme pan de mie, fries $12

Two bottles of Belgian Tripel Karmeliet $14.75 ea. (these were 12 oz bottles! So good though -- a "Blond, robust, smooth, and fruity three-grain top fermented beer, refermented in the bottle. Brewed...after Karmeliet tradition with wheat, oat and barley. 100% natural. Has been brewed at Van Steenberge for Brewery Bosteels for some time until recently.")

One hot Apple Cobbler in a small pan with melting ice cream: $8

One stout brown Chocolate Bread Pudding with vanilla ice cream: $8

Verdict: almost everything was excellent. The only miss were the rather ordinary french fries were good but far from anything Belgium, not even served with a Belgian style dipping sauce.

A full side order of these MacDonald's-like fries was $6; so very overpriced, and we thankfully did not order one. The Monk's Cafe in Philadelphia http://www.yelp.com/biz/monks-cafe-philadelphia#query:The%20Monk%27s%20Inn  had all the beers AND the authentic Belgian frites to prove it, while not overcharging. 

Total: $112.30 with tax. Add a tip and you are well over $65 per couple. This quality of food (locally sourced, organic, etc), while appreciated, was not worth this cost on its face, but if you account for $15 for each bill was just the bottle of beer (net: $50) this might be on the moderate cost size.

Summarizing: two beef burgers, one veggie burger, two moderately sized salads, two beers, two deserts (each split) for over $110. Certainly a splurge; order a domestic beer Belgian-style (there are many MANY choices) and you could save some. But this place is renown for its beers, so why not try one?

Would I return? Maybe because the food (especially surprising was the very delicious the Spent Grain Burger) was really terrific. But will do so with a much bigger budget in mind.
author: Glenn H.

description:
20 minute cab ride from the Airport hotels.   What are ya waiting for??

the Food. the craft beer lineup.  All exceptional and well worth the trip!
author: Brian W.

description:
I have been going here for years and I honestly, truthfully, from the bottom of my heart, love everything about Monk's Kettle. They are on point with beer, food, great staff, and legit decor (see giant wooden fireplace mantel bordering the glassware). My advice for those who haven't tried Monk's yet is to visit during lunch hours when it is mellow and you can get in some good chat time with the bartenders for recommended beers to try (plan on having several!). 

For my small "yelp rant", I would like to complain about the folks who walk into Monk's and whine that there isn't any hard liquor or cocktails--for these people, I recommend paging your Uber driver to take you back to the Marina. Monk's is for real food, real beer. Oh and the wine is tasty too!
author: Nann N.

description: The best thing about this place was the cutie bartenders!! So friendly and helpful!!! Came when it was about to be closing time, and ordered a couple of pretzels. They were the best pretzels of my life! Fun beer selection. Definitely want to come back next time I'm in town!!
author: Veronica R.

description:
The staff is incredibly friendly and the food is consistently good. Its nice to have a spot to catch a quick bite and a drink. I wish there were more places like this in San Francisco.

The beer pairings are great! The bartenders have helped me branch out of my comfort zone and helped me discover great beers I otherwise would have never tried.
author: Jacklyn H.

description:
You know you're in a lovely space for sipping a bit of beer when your server wears a shirt from your favorite brewery and you wax rhapsodical together about what exactly might be on the menu there just this minute....Monk's Kettle is just that sort of spot, where you're bathed in beer love and wisdom and familiarity, and your pints or schooners or whatever ounce combination arrives in appropriate glassware and the length of the tap menu's just right to explore without losing your way.

We sauntered in for some pre-dinner drinks on a fairly busy Saturday evening, but the friendly folks working were kind enough to seat us at a table (provided we ordered food, otherwise we'd have had to cluster at the bar) and were willing to move in case a dinner party appeared. Fair enough! And the culinary nudge turned out to be welcome, as we ordered the charcuterie and cheese plate which happened to have thoughtful selections including a lovely little Cowgirl Creamery Devil's Gulch with the hintiest of chile pepper on the rind, and generous swathes of preserves and mustard swirled across the serving board.

A nice selection of beers appears in the binder (though most of the space is reserved for an extensive bottle list); about twenty taps, both domestic and international, with strong West Coast representation heavy on the Belgians. Lost Abbey appeared a couple of times, and the Devotion was my favorite pour of the night (after, of course, the Moebius). I also enjoyed Linden Street's The Resistor, as I'm always happy to get acquainted with local brews when I'm out of town, ones I probably wouldn't ever see in bottles at home. 

Drinks here aren't cheap...but the quality's excellent. I look forward to more visits, exploration, and wistful Hair of the Dog conversations in the future!
author: Hannah L.

description:
First off, this place gets mobbed on the weekends, so consider this fair warning: come on a weekday for lunch or an early weekday for dinner. From the chatter at the bar, this place is a completely different scene on a Saturday night.

That said, Monk's Kettle combines the refined atmosphere of a wine bar with the microbrew selections of your favorite dives. (Seriously, the beer menu is about the size of your average novel.) They're known for their burgers, which is an excellent place to start if you're not sure what to order, and nearly every entree comes with beer pairings. The pretzels came highly recommended by the friend who sent me here, so give them a shot too. 

Fair warning, the charm (of both the place and the bartender, who was incredibly friendly and helpful) may keep you here for a third or fourth round.
author: Kevin B.

description:
Great food, ambiance, service. 5 solid stars.

As the vegetarian, I ordered the spent grain & chick pea burger with french fries ($14). So delicious. Usually I become annoyed if the veggie patty falls apart easily, but this patty was filled with so much flavor and yummy ingredients that I honestly didn't care.

My friend ordered the fresh ground burger with fries ($15) and greatly enjoyed it.

& SO MANY BEER OPTIONS!! I ended up drinking a pint of the Allagash White, a beer from Maine (~$6). It is a great summer beer - light, a little sweet, and refreshing. Perfect beverage to wash down my veggie burger.

Also, best part? Ask to taste a beer and it will be served in a shot glass-sized bierstein. Actually, the cutest thing I've ever seen. Where can I get me some of those?!
author: Ruth R.

description:
Date & Time:  Tuesday December 23, 2008 @ 1:30pm
Company:  Michael
Crowd:  Hipsters some w/ Hipster Children & Middle-Aged Professionals in Biker Gear w/ Shoei Helmets & Vintage Moto Guzzi & BMW's Parked Out in Front
Vibe:  Chill
Decor:  Cool Cozy Tavern.  Wooden Booths for Quatre & Benches for Deux Separated by Granite Partitions
Service:  Nice, Helpful, Efficient
Imbibe:  Beer Pairings
Devour:  Special for Today:  Scallop Pie w/ Buttery Flaky Crust on Top that You Crumble on To the Pie Along w/ Salad & Lamb Burger
Note:  Will Have to Try the Charcuterie Plate, Mac n' Cheese, Bread Pudding Next Visit
Total:  $43.94
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
I was in San Francisco for a week and tried to come here everyday. We were staying 2 blocks away so we'd casually walk by in hopes to grab dinner and some beers. It was always so busy! 

Finally, our last night we walked by around 11 and saw two seats at the bar. Score!  I get why it's so popular. Insane beer list, food menu looks amazing...  Too bad we had already eaten and the bartender was super informative. We came for 1 and stayed for a few thanks to the great service. I can't wait to go back and try more beers soon!
author: Samantha S.

description: GREAT gastropub! Excellent beer selection and the food is just as good. The oysters were so good, we got another order, and I'm not a huge oyster fan, the chicken and burger were insane good. Get there early so you can find parking and get a good seat next to the Windows to take in San Francisco.
author: AJ N.

description:
Came in at around 230ish on a Sunday afternoon with three of my girl friends. We were welcomed by one of the bartenders as soon as we walked in, which was a good sign.

We all sat at the bar. Promptly served with our drinks. I didn't get a sense of pretentiousness at all.

What really impressed me was that I could smell, taste, see, hear, and feel every employee's passion about this place. The bartender was very knowledgeable about every item on the drinks and food menu. And whatever that was cooking in the kitchen smelled sooo flavorful and delicious! I'll make sure to order food on my next visit.

If you want to be a little adventurous, then try the sparkling mead. It gives a satisfying honey aroma.

Cheers!
author: farida r.

description:
I was thrown off by the two $$ price marker, thinking I didn't need to take out a line of credit to enjoy the massive, delicious baked pretzel on offer. The pretzel ($8.75) is hefty and easily shared between two people, and comes with a cheesy ale dipping sauce and sharp, grainy mustard. A must, despite the price tag! It's worth its girth.

The much recommended mac 'n' cheese was a bust. The portion was far too large for one person, and the sauce was bland and watery instead of sharp and gooey. I like my mac cheesy, not runny and this dish was very unappealing.

I have to reiterate that prices here are steep, so bring money. $4 for a glass bottle Coke, $8 for a pint that's half the price at Toronado or other beer haunts in the city (literally double the price) and let's not forget about the $9 pretzel.

Also, they were rigorously carding people at the door yet there were children inside. What gives?
author: Kat F.

description: This place has THE most incredible beer selection I have ever seen in my life. The staff are super knowledgable and will happily give you recommendations. Their vintage selection of bottles beer is very pricey ($65!) but the tastes are so rich that you will be savouring it for a while, so price doesn't seem too steep! It's got a really nice vibe, the food is delicious and they take walk-ins for bar seating.. It can feel a little bit hipster pretentious, but it is in mission after all, so what did you expect ;)
author: Kylie F.

description:
To be really honest, I do regret this check in at The Monks Kettle, as I have definitely been a big fan for the past couple years...(I've definitely dropped by here for drinks and for food 1-2 times per month since I moved into the city on Jan 3rd 2011).

In two years time I had almost consistently had almost decent service from Monk's table (and I'm an understated semi-regular, showing up with different friends 1-2x a month for drinks and food; typically 50-60/person for a quick dinner + beer. A price I considered worth it for admittedly slowish food and sub-par service, all explained away to LA and NY friends as "they're just a little busy").

I can't explain that away right now. It's 430 on a Saturday, and a group of 7 just dropped by for half our group to grab a late lunch/dessert and the other half to grab drinks at the bar and received the rudest service I've ever experienced.

I came if asking if 3-4 people could sit at a table for food and drinks, and if the other 3-4 people in the party could order a couple of beers each at the bar (value at about 30-50/person at the table and 20-35/person before tip at the bar).

We were turned away cold, essentially told that we should be turned to the street for those values at 4pm on a Saturday.

Not worth any stars for that service, but...

Sorry guys. The Monk's Kettle is just no longer worth the hype.
author: Emilynne A.

description:
Awesome gastropub in the Mission!
Although the space is small (ideal dinner party of 2), we got seated quickly on a Sunday early evening at around 6:30PM. Very intimate spacing between tables so if you require a lot of personal space, this may not be the place for you. 

Upon reviews, we decided on the following:
-Pretzel with cheese and spicy mustard: Yum!! I love bread and i love the creamyness of the cheese. Definitely not your velveta bright orange sauce. 
- Scallops: SO good. Evenly cooked and went well with the sweet sauce and sauteed kale and cauliflower.

-Lamb burger: OMG. I don't normally care for lamb due because it's usually too gamey for me, but this had not hint at all. Definitely tasted like grass fed beef. SO good. Will most definitely come back just for the burger!! Awesome side of fries that came with this dish too. Not thin cut and not steak fries, but just in the middle of the road. Nice and crispy on the outside and soft and steaming hot on the inside. Just perfect!
**UPDATE: A friend who vistied 2/14/14 told me it wasn't lamb. I had a feeling, but after reading all the reviews on Yelp, I had lamb burger on my mind :)


Although I've given up alcohol (gasp!), they have quite an extensive list of beers. Will definitely need to come back and peruse the menu in further detail the next time I am in dire need of some hops.

Note: They take AMEX cards! Horray!
author: Ling H.

description:
Amazing beer selection. The bartenders are quite knowledgeable and helpful.

The burger is also one of the best in SF. It's extraordinarily juicy. 

The vibe is an upscale pub -- loud, casual, but sophisticated.
author: Victor W.

description: Great beer, tasty veggie burger, and excellent appetizers. We especially loved the doughy pretzels with mustard and dipping cheese. Service was very prompt as well.
author: Elizabeth C.

description: The beer list is incredible! The food is good but a little pricy. The only reason I don't give then five stars is because the bar tender had a bit of an attitude. I'd definitely return though.
author: Ryan P.

description: Honestly, they have some of the best beer in the city. The problem is this beer is exorbitantly overpriced. Dining is fairly cramped, however, the burger was delicious. The poutine did not have any gravy, which was a disappointment, but otherwise not half bad. Definitely get here early if you want to sit down and if you are claustrophobic avoid this place at all costs.
author: Jim G.

description:
This place is stellar.  I'm talking knowledgeable staff, excellent service and an ever revolving beer selection and great food menu to boot. This place has it all. 

I find myself going back again and again for not only the amazing burger (cooked to perfection) and hop salt fries (YES these exists and they are awesome) but the friendly staff - who actually know how to pour beers properly and the exact stemware they should be in.  As a beer lover and self proclaimed connoisseur I appreciate this immensely and it's done right.

Something to note though - this place is always packed after 6pm, so prepared accordingly.

Bottom line: If you love a great beer selection and delicious burgers - you need to go. Immediately.
author: Lauren B.

description:
I was in need of something with rich earthy flavors, and Monk's Kettle had exactly the right solution. The bartender did a great job of discussing pairings with me, and handled my more-morose-than-usual state like a champ.

The half chicken paired perfectly with my smokey cider for an amazing primal/paleo dinner (the beans wouldn't be fully in line, but I'm a little flexible at this point). While the gluten-free and cider list was short, it had really excellent options that I'd never tried before, instead of a long list of the same old terrible standards. I will definitely be back!
author: Sam B.

description: Great, but somewhat pricey beer selection. 4 of us went for dinner and we thought the chicken and pork chop were the best of the selections. If you go on a weekend night, go put your name in, but be prepared to wait.
author: Leah B.

description:
If you want good beer, come here. If you want good food, this is your hood. Monks Kettle is LEGIT.

I came here with a friend and got a chicken sandwich with fries. You can't get much simpler than that. But I was super impressed with the food! The chicken was pretty moist and I ate all of my fries (which I almost never do for health reasons... but sometimes health can wait). It was really good! I have to admit, however, that it is pretty overpriced. I paid a pretty fat sum for a sandwich. I'd rather go somewhere else for food.

The nice part about Monks Kettle is the beer. The beer selection here is absolutely ridiculous. So many freaking BEERS. Our waiter suggested this pale ale to me and it was one of the best pale ales I've ever had. I wish I remembered the name! Wizard something...? Magic... whatever? I don't remember. I guess I'll just have to go back and ask that cute waiter with the cute glasses which beer he suggested haha. 

I'll come back for the beer, but maybe not the food. And definitely for the waiter.
author: Jade R.

description:
The Monks Kettle was my first meal in San Francisco, it was a Thursday night at 10 pm and there was an hour wait...ugh!!! 
Ok...Oh, you can call us when our table is ready?
Awesome!!! Andrew party of 4.

45 minutes later, we were called walked right over and immediately seated. I like it!!!

On to the decor, dark pub style but sleeker.

Beer: I hate beer, its gross and fizzy and smells funny.  
That said, our waiter totally rocked and was flabbergasted by my outright aversion for beer.  Minutes after taking the boys orders, he walked away and immediately came back with a kick ass Lavender something or other and an even better white something or other draft beer.
Sure i don't remember the names but I ordered it and drank the whole glass! Kudos awesome waiter!

The Food: Ohh so YumMmyy
The tomato soup was velvety goodness *****
Bone marrow - the butter of the Gods *****
Pan Roasted Halibut - perfectly cooked and served with scrumptious tiny potatoes *****

Overall thoughts:

Magnificent little find in San Fran and awesome way to kick off our trip!!!
author: Jackie S.

description:
This was our first stop on our night on the town in San Fran, suggested by my buddy's wife.  It's a little corner spot with a small bar and a few tables.  It has a very warm and welcoming vibe, I honestly felt like I was back in Belgium when we walked in.  

It was Saturday around 830, the place was already full.  We did manage to find a couple of stools of to the side of the bar.  The beer list boasted a huge selection and we tried about 3 each.  We also ordered some of the house fries and they really hit the spot.  What I appreciated was that there was a description of the beers offered, not too many places do that.  Microbrews and imports both rounded out the drink menu.  The food intrigued me but we weren't hungry for much more than the fries. 

The downside was the service.  We were sitting right next to the service station and obviously unattended to, and the three guys who kept looking at us did nothing.   When I finally asked one of them if we could order, he seemed very put out and annoyed.  (Sorry dude, we were there for beer.)   We were handed off to someone else who seemed a bit more friendly, and gave my friend a good suggestion when he asked. 

It is a sweet little spot, my kind of place.  Other than the initial service issue, it was great.  I'd gladly come back next time I'm in town.
author: Jeff S.

description: We decided to get out at the BART stop and start walking back home up 16th Street and hit up any place we thought caught our eye. Monk's Kettle was hopping so we ducked in. Like most places in SF, I was ID'd at the door which to me is a positive seeing as I just turned 30. Inside is a great open space with a nice bar. The beer list here is overwhelming and you'd be hard pressed to find something you didn't like. We ordered a couple small plates too which were really good as well. Met some people from Buffalo at the bar randomly and it felt very much like home. If you find yourself around here be sure to stop in.
author: Joshua C.

description:
So much to like about this place - lots of beer options, the mushroom on bread and charcuterie appetizers were GREAT, my beau's burger was GREAT. 

My big mistake was ordering the veggie burger - leaden, overspiced (cumin hell), bad mouth consistency, a failure on so many levels. And it reminded me throughout the night about how horrid my choice had been.

Every other entree I've had there - very good. The place has some good food. Veggie burger aside.

To recap: Go and eat. Avoid the veggie burger.

It is very loud. As the night progresses, you may run into more 'bros taking selfies as they try and lure in the one or two girls in their clique.
author: Scott B.

description:
This bar is good for a beer if you catch the crowds at the right time, but definitely not what I was expecting.

The gastropub is pretty small, allowing for almost no easy way to move about on a busy night.  Customers are packed in here at busy times.

This is by no means the best beer bar in San Francisco.  While the list is good, there are a handful of other bars in the city that carry the same selection of brews.

I didn't eat, but the dishes looked pretty experimental and tasty.

If you are looking for a quiet place to enjoy a beer in comfort, look elsewhere.
author: Brian K.

description:
Sorry to be a tease but 500 is going to be for a place near and dear to my heart and I'm still working on the review. 

I went back to Monks Kettle and the prices are only higher. I got what couldn't have been more than a five ounce pour of a Belgian quad for $10.50. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/g2ktKLz4rNTi8T5WUEUYuw?selected=65KcpmZbQTMSg5Lac-Y6gg This is the most expensive beer venue in town. The closest comparable place is Amsterdam Cafe where you get a full eight ounce pour of a better Trappist Belgian quad for $8. 

Seriously Monk's Kettle, I will walk the eight blocks to get a square deal from Rosemonde. 

I can't think of a single thing other than a pretty girl asking that would get me back in this place.
author: Manny F.

description: dinner for two and it cost me an airfare one way trip to LA. extensive booze list. pork sausage was pretty good, couldn't finish it though. the texture of the bun/bread reminded me of a German pretzel so that was a nice touch. bartender lady was super nice
author: Laurie M.

description: Amazing beer and great sevice.  The burger was probably the best I have had in a long time!  The whole menu looked great.
author: Lori Y.

description:
Packed and busy, but cozy. Staff was extremely attentive. Tasty beers and perfect polenta!

My friend and I couldn't get a space at a table or the bar when we dropped by, but we really wanted to check out their brews, so we were directed to a spot in the middle of the small space and given a drinks menu. Right before we could awkwardly ask, "Now what?" a bartender swoops in and gives us some great recommendations for tasty, tasty beers. It's a pretty and casual space, very comfy. 

The recommended rauchbiers were exactly what I was looking for, so much balance and body (one smelled like smoked gouda, lol, I was into it). And another recommended dark, vaguely coffee-like beer was a delicious pairing to the bacon wrapped shrimp on buttery polenta (perfectly cooked, all the right textures, and the polenta was a revelation since polenta had never made an impression on me until this dish).

The bartenders are so endearingly charming (not schmoozy charming) too. Seriously can't wait to get back there!
author: Imma D.

description: Amazing food (pretzels, risotto, pork) and knowledgeable staff. Best food I've had in ages. The mushroom risotto is heaven.
author: Neal L.

description:
Great food, and good beer selection. But - what is it about good beer that it's poured a) in a wine glass and b) in wine-sized volume?
It's beer, for crying out loud. Don't get all snobby on me with beer, however good it is. Pour it in a beer glass, in a volume that its brewers intended it for
author: Carel v.

description:
The first time I tried to go to Monk's Kettle I could not get a table. Well, I could have but who wants to wait 1.5 hours for one? And it looked like the second time was not going to be different except this time we arrived just as two people were leaving the bar area so ahead we proceeded for a journey through beers.

We just munched on some fries and drank beer, then I had a delicious bacon cheeseburger that the bartender recommended I try a smoke beer to go with it. Well played, sir, well played. It basically made the burger taste like a smoked bacon deliciousness wedged between beef, bread and cheese. But not in a disgusting way. In that kind of way when you get a wine pairing that's just right and brings out all sorts of flavors of food in your mouth and junk.

Be prepared to wait - unless you get there really early.
author: Andre L.

description:
Where do they get their beef? Heaven?!? Their fresh ground burger is as good as it gets. I can't get over how juicy and delicious the patty was. I would order it again and again. The server asked if I wanted to add bacon. I almost said no, until he mentioned they make it themselves. Sold. I don't even know what that entails, but how could I say no? The bacon was good, but nothing could outshine the delicious beefy-ness of my burger. The burger would have been just as great without.

As for drinks, they have a great list of craft beers. I told the server what I like and asked for a suggestion. I was very impressed by the beer he recommended. 

Now onto what the place itself is like. The Monk's Kettle is small. I went on a Tuesday night and it was packed. We put our name down and the wait for a table for two was over an hour. Luckily enough, a spot opened up at the bar and we didn't have to wait very long. We actually probably had more space at the bar than we would have had at one of the teeny tiny tables jammed in to the place. 

The somewhat claustrophobic feeling of the place is the only reason I can't give it a full five stars, but I would definitely recommend this place to anyone looking for a place to eat in the area.
author: Erica F.

description: Food is always amazing! Not only that, but the staff are always lovely and very welcoming - which is why we always come back!
author: Will R.

description: This review is for bar service. We went on a Saturday night around 11. The beer selection is overwhelming and fantastic. The girl bartender is awesome. I told her I like sours and a certain flavor profile and all 4 we tried were amazing. Wide range of prices but fun find to try new beers. I think I prefer the low key vibe so may return during the week instead.
author: Zara S.

description: Delicious beer and delicious burgers in a warm, friendly, and hip atmosphere. Everyone from the doorman to the bartender to our table server seemed to be in a great mood--especially for an early Monday evening--and all of them offered helpful suggestions about the dining and drinking options. I can't wait to go back but I will be mindful of other Yelpers' comments about how packed and crazy this place gets toward the weekends.
author: Lou S.

description:
The service this time was much, MUCH better. Friend and I walked in at a little past 8:30pm on a Thursday. We asked the host if we could sit at the bar but he offered us the little table by the door; thanks host, you're much better than the last guy! 

They were quite busy, but service was good. We only ordered beer because both of us had already had dinner. The wait staff was pretty attentive; they kept on coming back to check if we needed more beer. When my friend ordered the Strubbe's Grand Cru, the waiter gave it a perfect pour with just enough head at the top. 

So, why the 3 star review? Shit is expensive here. Now look, I know what you're thinking- "Emily's just a cheap ass." Well, just hear me out here. Draughts are more expensive and much smaller than the standard price and pour. Bottles are marked up between 200-300% of the retail prices.

Example 1: The 2007 Abbaye de Saint Bon-Chien was $17.75 for a 6oz pour. The retail price of a 22oz bottle is around $25-$30 (http://www.wineandcheeseplace.com/cart.php?target=product&product_id=6658&category_id=4)

Example 2: Bottle of New Belgium La Folie 22oz (retail $11.99 at WF) was roughly $30

Example 3: Pliny the Elder 16oz draught is $7.75. Most other bars have it for $5-$6

Example 4: Alesmith Speedyway Stout 22oz (retail $13.99 at WF) was $31.50

I understand that Monk's is a much classier environment to be drinking beer at than a regular bar, but with the classy comes the huge bill. As a beer lover, I'm a little adverse to this- I started liking beer because it was cheaper than wine and much more approachable, less snobby- beer bars and their staff and clientele are generally much more relaxed and easy going. Monk's is a great place, but its definitely upping the snob/price factor of beer culture and I honestly would rather spend time at a beer bar (Sycamore!) chatting with the bartenders about brewing or what their favorite local porter is.

Anyways, I guess it would be up to you to decide if you wanted to pay more than double the price on a bottle you can grab at the Whole Foods in Potrero after you leave. I, for one, am probably not going to be back too often.
author: Emily H.

description:
This is a classic gastropub with a niche in great, hard to find beers.  What sets this place apart from other places is the balanced approach to beer + food.  Other gastro pubs usually do one better than the other, but this place does both exceptionally well.

The draught beer selection favors smaller breweries, many from CA (San Diego to Russian River to Humboldt), though Europe and other parts of the country are also very well represented (there is a beer menu as is customary for gastro pubs these days).

The pretzel bread is a great starter as are pickles.  The burger and the risotto are also two staples that go well with the brew.  I liked the tuna as well, but my personal favorite is the veggie burger, which is the best I've had.

The final touch is the specials.  There is usually a special entree daily, and the meats (roasts) are almost always top notch with some creative combinations.

Bottom line: Nice staff, good food, great beer.
author: Vadim A.

description:
Delicious combination of classy pub food and fantastic spirits. I had the grilled Burger with Grilled bacon and the cleanest London Porter. 

I was astounded at how the Porter Cleansed my palet after every gulp and yet didn't sit heavy in my stomach allowing me to finish that fabulous burger.  I also tasted one of these plate with a wonderful mix of fruity and rustic flavor. And even with such drastically different dishes, the Porter overwhelmed them both. 

Fantastic.
author: Jennavive P.

description: AMAZING. The chicken under the brick is the greatest chicken in the world. Beer selection is good. Server was meh, but whatever. Cool atmosphere, cool area. Go eat the chicken, BYE! Ps- pair it with a Pliny the elder and die from happiness.
author: Lindsey S.

description:
I treat myself to Monks Kettle whenever I'm craving good food and great beer. Staff is friendly and helps with recommendations if you're ever feeling overwhelmed with their great selection.

It's nice, dimly lit and cozy inside aka great for awkward dates, etc. 

I love their brick oven chicken. Their appetizers are crazy delicious; my favorite is the mushroom risotto. So mouthwatering good.
author: Jesse K.

description: Great bar, always stop in for some good brews when I'm in town. The bartenders are always so helpful, the beer and food are great, and I love that they have outside seating. The only inconvenience is location and parking but that is expected in the mission.
author: Marie H.

description:
One of a few quintessential gastropubs in the city. 

Really tasty food + really good beer. 

The food is precise, very good quality & flavorful. The menu and the beer seems to change or rotate with what is in season. We had salads, and bacon & lentil soup. And drank three times as much calories in our beer then in our food.. until we got to desert. The time before that we had apps a strange cold rabbit pate', like liver worst only made of rabbit so it doesn't taste like liver, it tastes like rabbit, you know kind of like very mild chicken :) 

This is a crowded place, you want to get there during as off hours as is possible. But, it's one of the few places in this city with too many restaurants to choose from where we have been quite a few times. Because it's a special occasion type of place to bring visiting out of town friends.
author: Uva D.

description:
Great new tavern for the beer connoisseur. Even a curmudgeon drinker like me, who only drinks stouts. Well guess what? They have 6 stouts to choose from and none of them are Guinness (I say they bump it up to 7)! Although they only had one of the two on tap, the Old Rasputin, it was excellent. I found a kindered spirit as I accepted my stout, asking me what I had ordered. We then discussed how once you go black you don't go back..hahaha! He too was on a quest to go through all the stouts and the porters in a swift manner. For my non beer drinking companion, they had a black currant cider from Colfax (which I pass on the way to Tahoe and back) which was also quite excellent.

The place is super packed and unfortunately it was mostly guys. I counted four women which included the one I brought along. The atmosphere however is still lively and getting a beer was still quick despite the crowd. There's fun to be had while you drink, scribbling on the chalk board and the smell of the burgers from behind it were heavenly even though we had just eaten. If you're exiting from the back door, watch out for the good drop. I was looking back at the bar when I stepped out and nearly franked myself if it were not for my Jet Li like reflexes. I think this is perhaps my new fave Mission chill spot to drink. 4.5 stars. 
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Update, the've pushed the opening back to Dec

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
opening in Late November
author: Kim N.

description: There was a open table in front of us and four of us wanted to have drinks with small bites. They didn't allow us to sit since we weren't going to order main course.. Idiotic.
author: Vikrant J.

description:
Great food, huge selection of beers (tap and bottled), knowledgeable and friendly staff - what's not to like about this place? 

For food, try the burger or grilled chicken sandwich. The fries are also a must. 

My most recent visit here was to try Pliney the Younger. I was lucky enough to get a sampling of this rare beer. They were one of the few places in SF to receive a keg and it was gone in a matter of hours. 

I would not try to come here with a group. I would say max a group of 4 or you will end up waiting for a long time. But if you're looking to try beer are less common, definitely come here.
author: Victor D.

description:
Typically, I don't enjoy working for my food -- especially after a long day of travel and poor choices re transportation from the airport to my lodging. But, on one fateful Sunday, I was famished, cranky and in need of a beer. I decided to meet a friend at TMK and get some grub and booze. Dear readers, this is the point at which you should probably be scared. My terrible state of mind/being + the heretofore complained of hipster/bad attitude and long wait should have equaled a match made in heck. Thankfully for all involved, the situation played out in a much better way. 

It started on a rocky note. The place was packed, the young lady at the door had no idea how long it would take to get a table, some [redacted] at the bar was taking up two seats, and in our quest to just sit and get a beer, my friend and I were twice moved by the wait staff. Not fun. I could tell I was off of my game because in the midst of all this chaos, no blood had been spilled and all was well for the patrons and staff. Obviously, I was in a weakened state. Perhaps having pity on my emaciated/thirsty self, a kindly waiter gave us some decent Purgatory seating, water and beer menus. Seeing my feeble attempts to chastise a cat-eye glasses wearing, three-toned hair having, tight jeans wearing hipsterista for almost spilling a beer on my friend, I can only imagine that our waiter was a kindred spirit of a mean old man... and there's nothing sadder than a weakened old man without teeth trying (in vain) to yell at kids.

So, we got a table.

Once seated and committed to trying a couple of the less expensive saisons (Hen House, ftw), I got to the business of ordering. I spent my time in Purgatory wisely and studied the menu to know what I wanted. Like a boss -- BOOM -- fried oysters, pretzel and chickpea burger. Give it to me. Give it all to me! With every bite, I felt my strength return and bitchiness replenish. The cornmeal on the oysters added depth to a bivalve I usually avoid (I used to live in New Orleans; it's a long story). The pretzel is every bit as good as advertised. The cheese sauce needs to be a regular condiment in my fridge. The chick pea burger was a little dry and crumbly. It was hard to eat and a bit messy, even with the white cheese. I ordered it without the aioli, so maybe I had something to do with that (I don't do mayo, not even mayo with a fancy name). The onion jam was a unique note and I wished there was more on the burger since it tasted great and complimented the chick pea and cheese so nicely. I put my face into the side of fries and didn't come up for air until they were all gone. I walked into TMK a broken shell of a mean old man and walked out full recharged in my Mr. Burns-like ways. In a place that could have meant my doom, I was treated with the care and kindness I needed to cause trouble in the lives of others... and, isn't that what it's all about?
author: Johnny T.

description:
Killer spot
-I have been thinking about the pretzel knots for days. Gentle cheese dipping sauce. 
-cauliflower soup was awesome, maybe dip a pretzel knot in it if you are feeling wild.
-burger was perfect, add bacon
-beer selection was five star
-maybe go early if you don't want to wait
-great service
author: Bry G.

description: My husband and I are big craft beer and fine food fans, despite being parents to a toddler. We enjoy dining at gastropubs because they combine both elements. Typically, these sort of places aren't very child friendly, so we like to visit them at lunch time, when they are less busy. Unfortunately, every other gastropub we wanted to visit in San Francisco was either a  21+ establishment or was closed at lunch time, so the Monk's Kettle was the place for us to go. Par for the course, it wasn't child friendly- no high chairs or kid friendly foods. But, I was pleasantly surprised by the warm reception we received from the waitstaff. The beer selection here was phenomenal. The menu was a little small for my liking and the prices were steep. The food was mostly tasty, but my mussels were not that good.
author: Terri D.

description:
5 stars well earned for the best burger anywhere.  I don't say that lightly either as I spent 10 years in Chicago and have tried countless burgers (previous favorite was at Kuma's).  So if you go here you must eat the burger, don't even think twice about what to order.
Other pros
- Great draft beer selection.  I love places with good selections of beer.
- They will take your name down and text you when a table is open.  You can go slum it at delirium or some other nearby bar with seating.

Cons
- Very crowded and small.  Expect a wait.  This is easily solved if you show up early, put your name down, and go have a drink down the street until they text you.
author: Jon F.

description: The owner contacted me a corrected the situation.  I will revisit this restaurant, as I said in previous review it is awesome.
author: Sarah S.

description: This is a great place to try a beer and some meat and cheese.  They also have a daily roast.  The local greens salad is great and the grilled kale caesar looks amazing.  Great service too!
author: Roxann R.

description:
Very good beer. Food is good but Too expensive for what it is. $17 for flatbread??? It wasn't even very tasty. Barely any cheese and was bland. Spend a little more and get the flatiron steak. It was good. Perfectly cooked. The other annoying thing was that the flatbread and steak arrived at the same time. Which one should we eat cold?
Dinner for two is definitely $100 for two here without dessert. Much more if you indulge in $6 pretzels or an $8 order of fries
author: Priscilla C.

description:
Very cute, intimate space. 

I loved the huge selection of Belgian beers. Y especially loved that all the beers were served in their own special glasses. 

Mussels were great. I'd definitely get then again. The breaking on the oyster appetizer was tasty but I thought the oyster itself was a little over cooked. The pretzel was a cross between a soft pretzel y a buttermilk biscuit which was interesting but I wasn't 100% sold on it. 

Definitely worth a go but come early of you'll probably never get a seat.
author: Maya-Luisa G.

description: Awesome beer selection! And there is heated outdoor seating!  Can't wait to go back to try the food - the menu looked amazing!
author: La Tache T.

description:
This is a must-visit for any craft beer and beer lovers visiting San Francisco. You'll know you're in for a treat the moment you're handed the Bible that is the menu of beers here. You open it, see different chapters per se for each style of beer they carry. 

It can be a bit overwhelming and if you live in the state of New Mexico like I do, you don't know what to do when presented with such a wide array of beers, so many of which are impossible to get in YOUR ENTIRE STATE. 

Anyways, I started with the Pliny the Elder because, well, I'd have been foolish not to have. I'd had about a year ago and wasn't blown away, feeling that New Mexico's La Cumbre Elevated IPA was just as good, but this time around, I was much more impressed having it on tap. The sweet, citrusy hops were much more prominent this time around and despite the high hop content, it was still easy-drinking. Impressive.

I also tried a beer from Moonlight because I like their back story and because you can't find it in New Mexico either and this beer too was good, though the name escapes me.

Finally, I must thank The Monk's Kettle for introducing me to a new style, gose. I'd never heard of this style much less tried one before---I know, I know, beer amateur---but it truly impressed me. Like almost every other good German beer I've had, this Gose was close to perfection. Smooth, crisp, and pure. It's been a month, so all the details escape me, but I was blown away. Great beer. 

I didn't try the food, but it did look excellent, albeit pricey. In fact, that's my one complaint about this place (really a minor one) that the prices are a bit inflated. You could easily spend a small fortune in here on beers; I suppose many folks do.
author: Clayton A.

description:
Definitely worth checking out if you are a beer fan. The beer menu runs 7 pages long! The space doesn't stick out from it's location along 16th street but once you enter it has a very comfortable vibe. Our server was awesome and the food is very high end for a gastro pub.

Monk's Kettle has a great combo of beer and food. I was able to sample the Russian River Damnation beer. My wife is pregnant so she stuck with root beer. 

We had the cornmeal fried oyster, the old school pretzels, bacon wrapped shrimp, bavette steak, half chicken and day boat scallops. All were very tasty. This was my favorite restaurant we ate at while in San Francisco.
author: David T.

description:
We walked in around 8:30pm for a bite and some brews, and we were not let down.

There was an hour-and-a-half wait for a booth, but luckily, a couple of seats had just opened up at the bar, so we were immediately seated. 

DRINK
We stared at the beer menu--ahem, BOOK, for a bit and settled on our respective orders. Honestly, I could've closed my eyes, pointed at and ordered any beer and enjoyed it, but that's just me; I'm not too picky about a nice, cold pint.

FOOD
To start, we got the pretzel knot; it's about the size of a fist. It came with two mini ramekins: one with coarse mustard and the other with melted cheese. Mmm, melted cheese. It was gone within a matter of seconds.

I got the arugula salad with shaved fennel, beer brittle, and a lemon-y dressing (a much improved choice from my faulty order at Thai House Express the previous night). The beer brittle looked a piece of toast that had been caramelized in awesomeness... and beer; essentially a big, fat, sugary crouton.

My date got the burger, which came with an onion jam, aioli, aged white cheddar, and fries. I'll usually order a burger with cheese, but won't actually really taste the cheese. You couldn't miss it in this one; it was excellent. The fries were a touch salty, but that just went perfectly with the beers.

Our server-slash-bartender was super helpful, friendly, and patient with our orders. I'll be back to sample some more of their brewed hooch.
author: Adena B.

description:
My friend and I ordered a LOT of FOOD when we came here and we even had room for dessert!

Appetizer: Pretzel and pickled jar- Both very yummy but the pickled jar is such a small serving
Salad: Ambrosia Salad- SUPER YUMMY! Definitely refreshing and overall good flavor!
Dinner: Chickpea burger for my friend and Braised short ribs for me. Both very yummy!
I would definitely come back to try the BONE MARROW!!!
author: Claudine V.

description:
Beer! Beer! 
Oh glorious beer to the infinite!
And not even the frat kind!
Tall head, nice legs, fully body,
well bred and presented 
with encyclopedic acumen, 
My german(?) beer that I will never be able to pronounce) was a trifecta
And paired with marrow crostinis, briny capers and pickled garlic, 

I'd pledge this place in a second.
author: Emily C.

description:
Amazing Belgium beer selection...prepared to get drunk off beer after a few tripels.

I highly recommend sharing a cheese and charcuterie plate followed by the BURGER!

Great service, trendy vibe, in the heart of Valencia and 16th.
author: Chad S.

description:
Beer, beer, and more beer, please??!! 

I never cared for beer in the past. I thought it was disgusting & related it to big, husky construction men who chugged an entire six pack down after a long, hard day at work. For some reason, now that has changed. By no means am I a beer expert or do I participate in throwing down more than 1 glass. I just enjoy a good beer every so often. 

My favorite right now is a nice, cold refreshing glass of Blue Moon on draft, served with a juicy fresh orange slice. Yum!

However, getting past Blue Moon & getting directly on to the topic of Monk's Kettle. They specialize in variety... all sorts of beer variety. Their list is completely extensive. Extensive enough that their options fill two pages, in very small font might I add, on a crisp menu that is printed daily. They have beer for everyone~ light, dark, strong, fruity, organic, etc. The options just spill off the page.

Being a female, it's so hard to choose just one. So thank you to SF's 7x7 list I was able to narrow it down to @least a Belgian beer. When I asked for my light Belgian beer options, the bartender was kind enough to bring out two cutesy miniature mugs filled w/ Allagash White & the St. Bernardus for me to try. Although I enjoyed both, I opted for the Allagash White because it was lighter and had a surprisingly refreshing after taste. Go figure!

They even offer a list of Vintage beers that have been aging in their climate-controlled beer cellar. Fancy!

Monk's Kettle is a great cozy pub that offers awesome beer and even delicious food. I hear great things about their pretzels. It tends to get crowded, but don't all great places get crowded? Workers are super friendly & personable, even the bouncer in the front went out of his way to provide directions to the next spot I wanted to hit up.
 
Bottom line: Do it. 

Tips:
*Park @the 16th Street garage, street parking is a pain.
*They close @2am; kitchen closes @1am.
*You can play Tic-Tac-Toe on the chalkboard in the back. We did.
author: Joy A.

description: My first review of 2015 (please don't take my Yelp Elite away!, I've been really busy with nursing schoolz.) has to go to Monk's Kettle, which I tried last weekend with my college girl friends. Insane amount of beers to choose from (and wine and other drinks). Dim-lighting, cozy, kind of feel. Great for an intimate small group dinner or date, or you can be like us and sit at the bar and catch up there! Emphasis on SMALL group. We got there around 5pm on a Saturday, no wait, but after awhile, the place was pretty packed. Beers were good (we each had 3), decently priced to pricey. Will definitely come back!
author: Stephanie S.

description:
Not coming back, ever.

We got there and we signed up for a party of 4, after an hour and a half of waiting for the 4th horseman to show up he announced that he got a call to tend to the nether regions of a lady in need so he would join us for drinks after the deed.

We let waiters know that there will only be the 3 of us and they immediately tell us that if the 4th person decides to show up they will barre him from sitting with us. (we weren't expecting him anyway so we didn't make a thing out of it)

When we sit down they remove all the utensils on the 4th spot and remind us that the other person is not allowed to sit with us. Annoyed with the attitude we told the waiter: ok, if he comes by you can tell him that he is not allowed to take this empty seat.
the reply was: I can't do that! You are the ones that have to tell him!

so, nope list for monk's kettle.
author: Bea L.

description: Not sure how I've overlooked Monks Kettle for 9 years. Truly one of the best burgers in SF, and a delicious and unique beer selection. The place is small though, so make sure you give yourself enough time for the inevitable wait.
author: Matt D.

description:
Pork chop was awesome
O-M-G too many beers
Wait less than you think
author: Jennie K.

description:
The beers are incredible. I go with the same friend and after his lengthy discussions with the knowledgeable bar staff, I always drink something delicious. 

It wasn't until recently that I tried the food. Spectacular. The mussels were done perfectly in a lighter sauce. They managed to make even their charcuterie plate a delight with a choose your own blend of cheese and meat. Can't wait to try more. 

I have the best luck going rather late, after the dinner rush and sitting and ordering at the bar.
author: Margo S.

description: Terrible service.  We're very inflexible about seating and pushed us out the door before we were done.  Server kept grabbing stuff off the table that we were not done with.  Wait staff gave conflicting and rude instructions regarding my wife getting seats for our friends.  Really mediocre food for such lousy service.
author: Paul B.

description:
Superb beer selection. 

Beer snobs, this is the place for you! Came on a Monday afternoon so the vibe was mellow. Casual, hip atmosphere. Space is small with limited tables and bar seating, not recommended for large groups. They do not accept reservations, come early or go during off-hours.
