Incredible beer list, on tap and bottled. Bartenders are extremely knowledgeable, ask questions! You'll definitely learn something new. I had the Fullers London Porter (nitro) which was phenomenal. Well-rounded food menu. I had the burger which was satisfying. Enjoy!
author: Ashley K.

description:
The wait for a dinner table is so long. For a party of 4, we waited about an hour and a half. There isn't too much space to stand by the bar (since there are people sitting there too), so you're just kind of awkwardly standing around, blocking the narrow walkway. That being said, I think the wait was well worth it (especially because you can try their beers while you're waiting). 

1. Whipped bone marrow on toast. This appetizer was a little weird. The bone marrow itself was delicious. It was a little strange that it came with popcorn all over it (and not even good popcorn!). Also, the "toast" it came with was super hard and tasted stale. Regardless, we were starving so we devoured the entire plate. 

2. Some sort of cheese plate. This was delicious. Although, it also came with the weird, stale "toast."

3. THE BURGERS ARE DELICIOUS. 

4. The steak was also fairly good. Nothing too crazy, but cooked well.

5. Risotto. A little heavy, but very flavorful. 

I would definitely come back. The burger was delicious. Although, not sure if I would make waiting for food here a weekly thing.
author: Alice W.

description:
Tiny joint with a list of beers that is larger than their food menu!

The place is very small but not too hard to find.  If you come and must wait, they will give you a ring or text to notify you that your table is ready.  The lovely thing about this method that they use is, you can wander off to Tartine Bakery (on Guerrero Street) to get into another line..for warm chocolate croissants or any delicious pastry that your belly desires.

Going back to The Monk's Kettle...

They have a cute little set up..where you can write on the chalk board at the bar and play tic tac toe while waiting for your brew.  Every food item has a beer pairing, so I recommend that you eat something!  I had the Grilled Chicken Sandwich which had a smear of bacon jam and aged white cheddar.  They are generous enough to smear butter on the bread which makes it that much better!  The suggested beer for the Grilled Chicken was Saddle Back Ranch which was a light brew with a hoppy note at the end.  My friend ordered their Mushroom Risotto and it was divine!  I was jealous...and shoved my fork into their plate a few times!  The risotto melts in your mouth and for a second, you forget that you're really just eating milk, butter, cheese and rice.  It was that good!  She got the Bitch's Creek, which tasted like a lighter version of Guinness drought.  I would've tried more beers if my liver was not crying from the previous night...

Will definitely visit again.  They have great beers and a gigantic pretzel that I have yet to try!
author: Iver N.

description:
The Monk's Kettle is a true shrine of indulgence. A mega beer list combined with rich foods makes this a real gastropub.

I sampled the chile-honey hazelnuts, the fried oysters, and the fresh pretzel - all washed down with a hoppy small-batch offering from Sierra Nevada (I always like to try the rarer varieties from Anchor Steam and SN when I'm in town). M. had the chicken sandwich, with some really awesome thin-cut fries.

I'd recommend everything on the above list. The dinner crowd showed up starting a 6:30, so if you get there around 6 you should be able to get seated immediately (as we were). I'd be curious to try the $50 cellar beers sometime - when I have the coin!

Thanks Wendy S. for clueing me into this spot in her list of good beer in the Bay Area.
author: Foster K.

description:
4 big fat stars.

The food ranges from "damn this is expensive and good but where is the rest of it?" to "holy shit, this burger is fucking amazing" and the beer list is top notch.  The space is incredibly tight, so you're best off coming during an off peak time.

When Pliny the Younger makes the rounds this place has a line of the biggest waxed-mustache-having douchebags wrapped around the block.

All-in-all, this place is a solid stop though.  Grab a Pliny the Elder or a Death and Taxes and eat the $15 burger and think to yourself (or say out loud) "This IS a tasty burger!"
author: Meow S.

description:
Be prepared to WAIT!!! Came here on a Thursday night around 6:30 and didn't get seated until about 8. Good thing is that they text you when table is ready. Bad thing is you only have 5 minutes to run back when you get the text! Being that it's in the mission area, there were plenty of bars around - which is a good thing so u can kill some time while waiting. 

Service and food was mediocre at best! Our party ordered the roast pork - which was over cooked, mushroom risotto - which was on the salty side and overwhelmed by the cheese, and day boat scallops - which was again overly salted. 

3 stars only for the long list of beer menu! I would only recommend this place to try the beer, but NOT the food. Definitely not worth the wait. If you're a huge beer fan, this is definitely the spot for you.
author: Jeffrey N.

description:
The bartenders at Monk's Kettle are essentially beer psychiatrists. 

They will look you in the eye and ask you what's wrong, and how they can incorporate beer into a solution to make your day better. And you need to trust them with all your wallet. No other place can recommend a beer from that heavy bible that is catered exactly to your needs. 

That being said, it's BUSY as hell, especially on a weekend. We stood by the bar, and watched tables being turned as fast as a the revolving doors of a shrink.

Their food is delicious, and pairs perfectly with your food (this is where the beer psychiatry will also come in play). If scallops are on the menu, I would highly recommend it. That open kitchen is a siren song of smells that will not stop until the light's out.
author: Sharon F.

description:
I had one of those "moved-to-breathlessness" feelings from the mushroom risotto. Good food paired with beer. What could be better? The staff are really lovely and helpful people, not snooty at all. 

I was lucky enough to walk in and get seated both times I've been here. (I consider myself fortunate, as I walk by this place enough and always see people waiting out on the sidewalk.)

Try the Koko Brown Ale from Hawaii. ;) That's my shameless plug for the island, the brewery, and for the restaurant. It really is something special though.
author: Heidi H.

description: Servers are friendly and the bar has a nice vibe. Stick to burgers and simple choices. The risotto was terrible. Not a "gastropub,"
author: Matthew D.

description:
Incredible beer selection, quite disappointing food. Lovely outdoor patio.

While both food and beverage are expensive, the unique beers are worthwhile but the food is offensively bland. It reminds me of an old joke "The food is bad and the portions are small" because, even after spending $90 (including $20 for a mediocre burger), we were still hungry and dissatisfied. 

Would return to try more of the beers but would not eat here again.
author: Eljo L.

description: Always great Sour Beers on tap. The burgers are legit and very tasty. Kale salad is also really good. Nice place to sit outside and relax.
author: Lucas K.

description: Can't beat the tap selection. Food is great as well. Make sure you aren't in a hurry as there is always a wait
author: Joseph P.

description:
Toward the end of the bar a chalkboard separates you from the kitchen and big colorful sidewalk chalk is everywhere.  Someone before us treated us to vegetarian propaganda, a red crayfish of sorts, beguiling, pleading with us to "not eat me."   We should have drawn him a river.

The bar is presided over by an enormous mantle, ripped from a house on a rich hill and discovered at a quiet estate sale.  It must be 15 feet.  It framed a tall bald bartender brisk with whatever questions you had regarding the regional and exotic drafts. We mixed up our order and he sorted the beers by sight.  

I think I had the Maredsous Tripel or maybe Pliny The Elder?  The list is long and confusing for someone with little knowledge of beers, altogether overwhelming in such a fun way.

We arrived and the guy at the door was reading Murakami, and there was seating available to eat in booths, and at the bar, which seems like incidental minutia until you realize there's a swarming Valencia set that descends on the place in the early evening and it gets super packed with every sort of young software type, dressed up disheveled and perfect.

We stayed for a few sets of beers I'll never remember and dashed back into the Mission, walking past a Banksy into whatever was left of the day.
author: Jason A.

description: I had a great time with a friend and had some good beers. However, the burger was pretty disappointing and definitely diminished the experience.
author: M P.

description:
It is a small gastropub.  The service is good for the neighborhood.  The beer selection is extensive.

Four stars only because the food is a bit pricey for what you are getting and quite limited.  They have charcuterie, but I struggled a little bit with their menu of mains.
author: Daniel Y.

description: Douchebag hipster doorman not even letting in cute girls on a Tuesday night!  Seriously, a door list for a gastropub?  The Mission has officially jumped the shark.
author: Ted H.

description: The beer list is phenomenal, and our server gave excellent suggestions. The food was boring and overpriced. We had the burger and the flatbread. It was busy but they found a table for us within 20 minutes. The staff was very friendly and the bar had a nice atmosphere.
author: Hanna H.

description:
Pages upon pages of beers, friendly and knowledgeable wait staff, purse hooks underneath the bar and spicy ketchup....SCORE!

We went in hopes of trying a Russian River Beer we've heard so much about (Pliny the Elder), to learn they didn't have it on tap at the time. But that's okay, because we had MANY other choices. I ended up with the Chinookian (sp?) and it was quite tasty. 

We ordered food as well. I got the Lamb Burger and my oh my--it was AWESOME. I'd get it again. And again. I followed the advice of another yelper and requested the chipotle ketchup, you should do the same.
author: Marit S.

description:
So many beers to choose from, so little space. We randomly stopped by on a sunday afternoon, PERFECT TIMING! There was a few open seats and we were well catered to. I picked a beer that took a little extra time to pour (whoops) but it was delicious. The variety of beers makes for a fun and interesting experience, most are reasonably priced as well. The appetizers are small. But who's got time to eat when theres so much beer!?!?

This was our 2nd visit. The 1st time was on a Friday night at 8pm..BAD TIMING! It was packed inside and we had no choice but to pass. 

Choose the right time and you'll be a very happy beer drinker.
author: Cena V.

description:
I always try to find the best beer bars in whatever city I'm in. I live in Atlanta, so I try to find places just like the Brickstore Pub. The best in my book.

Monk's has about 20 beers on tap that vary significantly, from sour ales to high alcohol imperial IPAs. They don't focus too much on the sweeter beers, so keep that in mind.

A few bartenders served me and all were beer-educated like you'd expect. They have some stuff you wouldn't find in many other places, like Moonlight brewery which is a one man operation. Kudos if you've ever heard of it.

It's small, but cozy in here, and has a slightly belgian feel, but certainly more hipster. You may need a beard to even be allowed in here, but I'm not sure. Owning a single speed road bike might help your chances.

Start at the Toronado and then head here for more friendly bartenders.
author: Taylor A.

description:
BEER BEER BEER.
Forget the giant pretzel; I would go with the fries.  Forget two out of the three sauces with the fries and focus on the chipotle ketchup.  The other two are too thick anyway.

On busy nights when this place is at "maximum capacity", you'll have to wait a little.  I wouldn't coming in unless you get a seat at the bar because standing will only get the waiters angry when they try to maneuver around you.  Ideally, sitting down at the tables is best but at least half your party needs to order entrees.  I pleaded with the door man to let me order 2 appetizers and an entree but didn't get a budge.

The bartender has some sort of magic powers.  She asked me what I typically like to drink.  I told her light, fruity and occasionally a shot of vodka or tequila.  She nodded right away, turned around, and gave me a sample of beer that really suited my palette.  I didn't love it but for her to choose out of 7+ pages of beer just by my comments alone really showed supreme prowess.
author: Shannon L.

description:
A friend of mine chose this place for dinner on his birthday and I'm so glad we got to try it!

Wait was pretty long - about an hour at 7:30 on a Sunday night, but we went to another place across the street to get some drinks before we got our table and they texted us when our table was ready. The small size is definitely the only downside.

One of the best selections of beers I've ever seen! My whole group was able to try beers we'd never had before and were really satisfied by them. Food was amazing, and they suggest beers to pair with each meal which are a good way to enjoy the huge drinks menu. It's a little pricey for me to come back to too many times, but definitely try it out at least once when you're in the city! So worth it!
author: Kaysee T.

description:
This was stop #1 of 6 on our "crawl" through the Mission District before the recent Killers' Concert.  Since it was early, we were pacing (and were largely sober) so we limited ourselves to an order of the bacon-wrapped shrimp, the glazed hazelnuts, and a couple of beers (okay, maybe more than a couple).

The shrimp was excellent, still juicy but the bacon was crispy, and it was served on grilled polenta triangles.  This dish was good enough to get me to come back and try the rest of the menu.

The hazelnuts were delicious too, although I will warn you they serve you probably a good cup of nuts (in a sort of mason jar-looking thing).  They have a wonderful sweet/spicy glaze on the outside, and go down dreadfully well with a cold beer.  I could see spending a long rainy San Francisco afternoon at the bar munching on these and sampling the extensive beer selection.
author: Frank W.

description:
food: 2/5
beer: 5/5
service: 4/5

Monks kettle is right in mission district. I swear I wrote a review for this place already, wonder where it went... I heard a lot about this place from food critics and blogs, so decided to try it. I should have known this was going to be an over priced hipster place right when I walked in. The hostess will refuse to write your name on the sign in list until your whole party arrives. And then she counts the people who are there. Seriously? I can understand having everyone there while being seated, but I don't get the point of them doing this.

Over all, hyped up and extremely expensive. I would agree that the drinks here are great but everything else is mediocre. For a beer, mushroom appetizer (shared), and daily special entree the total came out to be around $50 per person.The place is so packed and loud that you don't even have a good dining experience.People were standing at the bar and the tables are smooshed up together. You are literally paying for the "hip" atmosphere. I would say that the food is decent here. But when you're charging $50 prices, make sure it is good quality and not something that's only marginally better than the taqueria down the street. But then again, you have all these bougie people paying $15 for 8oz of beer in a wine glass.
author: Cecile S.

description:
Just for the fact that we didn't have to wait AT ALL I am gonna give this place one more star--Oops, I'm already giving it 5 stars for everything else.

Went here about two months ago while visiting SF (my past and future city). 

First of all, they told us they have a new chef so that pretzel and mac n' cheese y'all were raving about are gone. Actually, the pretzel's still there but it's really just okay.

I got the bacon-wrapped shrimp with polenta and blood orange. I also got St. Bernardus with it cause that's what our server recommended I eat it with. Honey, it was maaaaaaahvelous. Everything in my plate just came together so perfectly it was food nirvana. Another server came by to ask us how the food was while I was savoring a bite and I almost told him, "Shut up, I'm having a moment." The beer went so perfectly with the meal, too. Honestly, not since then has a St. Bernardus tasted so good to me. The entire meal was just good flavor after good flavor.

Can't wait to go back and blow all my money--ALL OF IT--on this place.
author: Soleil D.

description:
Eat dinner at another nearby locale and then come over to Monk's Kettle to get your drink on. I've eaten here before and while the food is good, I don't think the prices really reflect what you're eating. It can be pricey, so my rec would be to eat somewhere nearby and walk over after dinner to enjoy a nice beer to top off your night.

Space here is definitely limited - so be prepared to get cozy with your neighbor and make some new friends because you'll definitely be close enough where it'll be awkward if you don't talk to the stranger next to you.

Their beer selection is pretty awesome and plentiful which makes it so hard to decide what to get!!!

Anyway, it's a nice little bar to visit and the servers here definitely know their beers! If you're trying to find a new beer or if you're looking to expand your beer knowledge, this is the place to go!
author: Julia K.

description:
Place is really cool. They have different type of glass for every beer. Their beer selections is very extensive. Staff is friendly, great place for a casual meetup with friends.
Like many bars in the neighborhood, this place is pretty small and cramped.
author: Nancy Z.

description:
Monk's Kettle is an interesting restaurant and bar. They have a very large selection of special beers. The great thing is they have little shot mugs tasting of beers. The waiter will try to find the right beer for you based on taste. The interesting and funny thing is they have a bouncer outside that cards you before you enter. A nice reminder that this is a bar rather than a restaurant.

Even though this is a bar, the food is just WOW! Really tasty and great. Went with the Monk's daily roast and it was steak that was really delicious. Soft and a smokey grilled flavor to it that went really well with the mashed potatoes.

Try to get here before 6pm. The line gets really crazy around 7pm even on a weekday. Tables are quite a bit harder to get so it's a lot easier to get seats at the bar for two. The wait is 45 minutes plus for a table before 7pm on a weekday.

Overall, this place is really packed. It's a long wait to get a seat. If it wasn't for the long wait and their no reservation policy, this would be a really cool spot to head to. They have really great beer and food.
author: Steven B.

description: The chicken under a brick and the pretzel is out of this world. Beer selection is top notch. We keep finding ourselves here over and over again! Do it.
author: Chauanh D.

description: If I was inside Monk's Kettle when the Big One hit, I wouldn't mind drowning to death in the flood of beer.  There's that much beer here.  Hopefully, some cornmeal-battered oysters will float by, too.  :)
author: Kevin W.

description:
UPDATE:  I've since enjoyed lunch at Monk's Kettle and really enjoyed the vibe.  I was on a strict diet and had the chicken sandwich, which I didn't love.  It was dry, but I was mostly annoyed that I couldn't eat one of their burgers.  My friends all had the burgers and they looked amazing.  The staff was great also!

I would love to give this restaurant a decent review.  Unfortunately, its the size of a small studio apartment and they don't take reservations - two factors that make them so annoying its not even worth trying again.  My partner and I have tried to eat there numerous times but there's always a ridiculous wait.  I know its super in to have a small place with like 87 beers on tap and a pretentious staff, but don't be afraid to be revolutionary!  Get a space that can accommodate the interest!
author: Daniel H.

description: Best bar/restaurant in SF!! Great staff/ownership and best beer selection anywhere!
author: Nathan F.

description:
+ : Varied and rich beer selection; simple and tasty menu.
-  : Fucked up seating policy (waitress: we will seat you if all 4 of you are here and not 3, me: can't the 3 of us have a dinner and the fourth person might join later; waiteress: no. She seated us on a table for four and removed the fourth set of silverwear. And this after 2.5 hours of waiting?!); rude waitress (a different one who was throwing the beer and the receipt on the table).

I really enjoy establishments who offer unique and tasteful food and beverages aas this one. However, when the people running it become too arrogant, the whole experience gets spoiled.
author: Alexander T.

description:
Went here on a Saturday evening with two friends, one of whom wanted to eat somewhere in the Mission. 

Two of us ate the burger, one of us had the chicken sandwich (all came with fries). These burgers are priced at $15 each. For 15 bucks, I expect a hearty, amazingly good burger. Unfortunately, what we ate was subpar compared to your standard 8 dollar burgers at any major chain restaurant. Based on our experience, it seems you're paying a hefty premium for the "cool" factor here. If you're looking for that, then come on in. If you're itching for an awesome burger, look elsewhere.

One other qualm: very limited menu. Considering they label themselves a "gastro" pub I was expecting more than just a tiny list of items. Heck, I have more choices at dive bars!

All this being said, the customer service was very good (thus the 3 stars rating). Our servers were nice, checked in on us, and gave us ample water without having to ask.
author: Juan F.

description:
This spot was rated by Brew Dogs as one of the top 5 bars in San Francisco for craft beer.

https://twitter.com/BrewDogs/status/385823996098273280/photo/1

I had already visited three of the other four and absolutely loved every one of them so I knew this place would be rockin. It was.

I didn't get a chance to eat but the environment and beer selection is top notch. They had Pliney the Elder on tap. What's better than that? Answer: NOTHING!
author: Wesley D.

description:
Here on a Friday night. OK food is pretty awesome, but if you are hungry do not come here. 5 minutes to take our drink order, about 30 minutes to take our food order. And and hour later we are asking for our bill. Other than those two times we were not asked about our meal or if we needed anything else. So service for the price was pretty shitty. 

They do have an extensive beer menu, but as a dine in establishment I would have settled for lucky chances for a quarter of the price and a quarter of the time it took the food to arrive
author: char b.

description:
If you're a beer snob, this place is for you.  And that's not a bad thing.

By no means do I consider myself a beer expert.  My buddies and I wandered in right before Wednesday's closing time of 2 AM, right after a fantastic session over at Moroc.  The bar was conveniently empty with it being so late.  We pulled up our stools and the bartender gave each of us menus.  I almost had to squint to read the tiny fonts.  Completely understandable.  There are over 200 fine beers at this place.  Being the complete non-beer snob that I was, I naively asked the bartender what her recommendations were.  She looked at me as if I was joking around.  Not really, but fine.  With her eyes wide open and her head shaking subtly from side-to-side, she asked "Well, do you prefer light, dark... or somewhere in between?" I responded dark.  She then chuckled and said "Awesome.  That narrows the list to about 150." 

That essentially had set the tone for a great time.  This chick knew her stuff.  She came with 3 recommendations, her favorites of the dark spectrum, and was able to give her reasoning and highlights of each in gory detail.  Tones.  Notes.  Flavors.  I swear, if it had been a few hours earlier, I bet she would have busted out with the food pairings and her take on global warming and how designers and architects are collaborating on developing a common vision to live with rising sea levels at the coastlines.

The 3 beers we got were the Rasputin, Ten-Fiddy, and Zantus.  All were great and strong.  Did I mention they were strong?  So strong, in fact, that the Ten-Fiddy and Zantus came in glasses that could be fit for the finest varietals.  All tasted like Guinness on steroids, with the Rasputin being a bit more malty, probably because of the injected nitro.

I'll definitely be back to get that beer snobbishness rolling.
author: Michael Paul C.

description:
What a wonderful place to sit at the bar and get real service. And by real service I mean that the bartender is knowledgeable, offers tastes to help you settle on something you like, and is just plain friendly. The got some great beers on tap, and I mean truly great options. Of course, some of the them are expensive, but that's the price you gotta pay when it comes to some of these pints. I like that the menu lets you know the serving size for each beer as well. I'm often disappointed at other places expecting a big pint glass only to be served a 6oz pour. I know that this is appropriate for some beers but I unfortunately have not yet acquired an encyclopedia knowledge of beers to always not what to expect. 

My only complaint is that this place is tiny and often packed so it's not easy to get in. Don't expect to be able to just swing by for a quick drink. This is not one of those places.
author: Stephen S.

description:
I really dig this joint.  It's small and can be crowded, but it's primely located in the mission district, has the kind of ambiance that just makes you thirsty and craving for  good quality hops and snacks, and attracts clientele from all ages and backgrounds.

The servers/bartenders really know their beers and dishes - thoroughly impressed with the level of mastery that the bartenders exhibited when I  asked about 12 different beers before I finally made up my mind.  They were patient, inviting, courteous and freaking beer-genius.  Where else do you find a place like this where you can sip on a bottle of saison fantome in such a comfortable environment while browsing through pages of their other beer selections for what to have next.  

I'll think of this place every single time that I have the cravings for good beers, snacks and good crowd.

Sante!
author: Mike P.

description:
Toronado's in San Diego is much like this place. I love love the beer. 9/10 food items are great but I dont like waiting and dont like eating really early or really late but they are always busy so makes it impossible to do dinner. Go for lunch they are open.

The servers really know their beer stuff they are great with suggestions. Dont go here if you wanna know how much your delicious beer is going to be.
author: Trisha V.

description: Walked in and grabbed the only open table when we were told "Thats not how we do things here". So we got up, I was explaining that my husband has a hearing disability so a table in the middle of the room doesnt allow us to converse. Finally got seated at the same booth but with the caveat that we might have to move if a party of four came in. Hubby ordered a coconut beer but it lacked in coconut flavor..my cider .....well they poured two inches in a wine glass and charged $9! Waiter wouldnt disclose price beforehand saying.."its like wine." We decided not to eat and left so they could have their precious real estate. We are not noobs to the beer scene, but rude attitude + ripoff pricing should not be the yardstick for hip bar eateries. We went straight to The Phoenix on Valencia and had an awesome drink and meal at a reasonable price.
author: Terri K.

description:
The Monk's Kettle!  I had read about this place when checking out places to visit in good ol' San Fran.  When my friend suggested we go there, I was quite excited to taste some local nor-cal beers on tap.  They happened to have Pliney on tap!  Was this beer going to live up to the hype?  Could it beat my beloved Dreadnaught from 3FLoyd's?  Well, it may not have been better, but that's for another discussion.  

This review is about the Monk's Kettle.  They have a very extensive and impressive beer list, and quite yummy snacks.  The cheese plate we split amongst 4 was quite tasty and kept us tided over till our excursion to a local mexican burrito joint afterwards. 

All in all, check out the Monks Kettle.  Great beers.
author: Carl B.

description:
This place is not bad, not sure if it's worth the 3 hour wait though (but I guess to be fair, the place is tiny and we did have 7 people...). We got there around 7:45 and put our names down. The woman at the door told us that they only had one table that could seat all of us and there was another group ahead of us waiting for that table. So we put our names down and they said they would text us when our table was ready. I thought that was a nice system as it allowed us to walk around and check out other places. 

Got a text a little past 10:30 telling us our table was ready. When they seated us, they told us that the table was going to be a tight squeeze. Luckily, we are all fairly small in stature and made it work. I think the table was only meant to seat 5 comfortably...

We started off with some corn meal fried oysters which were delicious. They are fairly sized so we split a couple of those.

I ordered the diver scallops with crispy corn and crab risotto. Scallops were cooked perfectly and the chopped bacon paired well with it. The risotto was bomb! It came presented in a way that resembled a mcdonald's hashbrown or rice crispy treat type of shape. The outside was slightly fried, inside the risotto was warm, soft, and delicious. I also tried some of my friends' bricked chicken and cumin rubbed lamb. The chicken was quite succulent and amazing. Wasn't too keen on the lamb though, seemed like there was more bone than meat. I also ordered a Belgium Pale Ale to go with my meal which was decent.

We had some major gripes about the service. Read Sophie Y.'s review for details on the incidents we encountered.

Would not recommend coming here in a large group. I think most of the tables here are meant to seat 4 people. It's worth a try for the superb food, but the long wait will keep me from coming from back.
author: Kevin N.

description:
The bone marrow was so good! The bartender described it as "beef butter."  It was served with toasted pieces of French baguette so you could knife a piece out of the "canoe" and smear it onto your toast like patee. It was so creamy, it smoothed out into oil and just fell into the pockets and crannies of the bread. Mmmmmmm! ($9)

The Charcuterie & Cheese plate was ok.  We got soft cheese, hard cheese, and wild boar salumi.  (Mix and match $12 for two, $5 each additional, $30 for all).  It came with toasted baguette slices, stone ground mustard with actual mustard seeds, jam, brazil nuts, and olives. The jam was good.  Everything else was just ok and nothing special.

Jared, the bartender was pretty knowledgable about the beer and helpful in picking out the right ones for my boyfriend and I.  He was patient and even let me sample some in these cute, tiny mugs.  Good service.

Wide selection of Belgian beer both on tap and bottled.  Food too, more complex than your typical bar menu.
author: Elise G.

description:
The Monk's Kettle has it all..... great food, excellent beer and spot on service.  

I found Monk's on Yelp and decided to go over an hour or so before I was meeting a friend for dinner.  The bartenders were great, and I tried a couple of beers while I waited.  The place isn't very big - but was able to squeeze in at the bar.  

Then my friend Deepa gets there.... so I go to close the tab...

Nope, they'll move your tab to the table.  Super convenient...

Next up, the food... wow, I think it gave the excellent beer a run for it's money.  Delicious.

Appetizers:
Roasted Hazlenuts - yummo!  and only $4, so you gotta try them, right?!
Pretzel with mustard and beer cheese, also yummo

Dinner:
Monk's Daily Roat-  perfect cooked pork loin with chiptole Crème fraîche, baked beans, some other beans and some spinach in a wonderful sauce

my partner in crime enjoyed the spent grain & chick pea burger. 

We finished out with the bread pudding, also phenominal.

All in all, if you're looking for a cozy spot, with great beer, attentive service and incredible food then look no further than Monk's Kettle.  I'll be back next time I'm in San Francisco!
author: Mat M.

description:
Best place to visit in San Francisco. Great atmosphere with amazing food and service. Not that hungry? Grab a stool at the bar and have some drinks and a side of fries. For me any place that has an amazing beer menu will always have a place in my heart. 

However the biggest thing to worried about is the wait for a table. This place gets extremely crowed during dinner time so be prepared to wait or have a reservation. Yes odd to have a reservation here but it'll save you from starving. But like I mentioned above it's worth it.
author: Roberto F.

description: Came here around midnight and was told that it would be a 45 min wait for a table...there were 3 tables open and no one waiting? so we decided to sit at the bar....during our entire stay 1 table was taken and the other two remained empty....Service and food was great, only frustrating thing was how a few months ago the owners posted claims that their other restaurant, abbots cellar would be closing, citing the rising min. wage as the cause.  Multiple employees had multiple beers throughout the night...which doesn't seem to be an issue for me, but left a sour taste in my mouth that they pick up the cost on free alcohol for employees but they shame the city for raising min. wage...still good food, ambiance and service...
author: John H.

description:
Prompted by a Black Boards Eats 30% e-offer, we headed over to Monk's Kettle for lunch as first time diners.  Concerned that we wouldn't find a seat, given the small size of the restaurant, we headed over at the opening time and were promptly seated, although by the time we left an hour or so later, the place was hopping and fully seated.

Prices for lunch entrees ranged from $13.00 - $26.00 and items ranged from hamburgers to scallops.  We started with a pretzel and then moved onto the bacon wrapped shrimp and finished with the scallops and meat dish of the day, all terrific choices.  

We'll be back and this time, BBE won't have to prompt us.
author: Rafael R.

description:
If you like a great selection of beer to go with a good selection of food...this is your stop. This is a little pub restaurant in the mission and is a great lunch spot.

The hubs and I came out to catch up with some friends and scored a booth table. The lunch rush hadn't come yet, but the place filled up pretty fast. All the beer our table ordered tasted great and paired nicely with our meals. I decided to have the mushroom risotto and it was fantastic. Creamy, hot and savory. It was super filling with all the cheese incorporated into the dish but it was great. This place offers up more standard pub type fare..but with a gourmet twist..offering uniquely mixed ingredients.

The service was friendly and attentive. The location is great, although parking can be kind of hard since it all seems to be metered street parking. The price is a tad high...but the quality of ingredients they use (at least in what I ordered) might just justify that. It's not a place I would come to everyday for that reason, but definitely worth a try.
author: Melissa C.

description:
This place is really great for you beer snobs. They have such a ridiculous selection of beers on tap and bottled, that it was a little overwhelming for me. Honestly, I LOVE sour beer and the ones I were eyeing were north of $25! Too rich for my blood.

I came on a Monday afternoon and it was pretty mellow so didn't have to deal with the line. Didn't get to try the food, unfortunate since everyone raves about it. Next time. This place is a little pricey for me given that I do enjoy the cold brew on a hot day but not really a connoisseur by any means. May stop back for the food.
author: Raina B.

description:
Good solid gastro pub in the Mission. 

Definitely one of the best known beer joints in town and the food is pretty good too.  Nice selection of apps (love the cheeses and the pretzel) and entrees (spent grain burger is great).   But really, you are probably here for the beer...Always have Pliny and a host of other rare / unique beers from US and abroad.  

And the service...it's actually quite good....Been in there a few times with my kids and they are patient and friendly as we have tried to craft something for our picky daughter.

Definitely a must visit if you are into beer and in SF.
author: JOHN C.

description: All the high ratings should give you the right idea that this place is great. The beer selection is phenomenal and the food pairs nicely. The seasonal menu keeps the food interesting and at peak taste. I like that they cycle through beer to give us a chance at a rare treat from out of town and locally. The service was outstanding with great recommends and attention. Do come here expecting a gastro experience at a fair value. I recommend a Pliny the Elder on draft, mussels, balsal fig flatbread, pretzel fondue, and bone marrow crouqette.
author: Jake C.

description:
This vibrant neighborhood gem was a recommendation from a guy at work.  It is a small place, so we had to belly up very close to the bar that seats about 12-14 people, then another 8-10 people standing behind you.  There's also table seating for maybe 24-26 people.  Cozy!

The beer menu is extensive so I took a shortcut and asked the bartender what HE would have to drink.  He poured me his current fave (which suggests the beer selections change often) which I liked.  I tried a couple other beer selections as well.  All good  Didn't know about the pretzel but I saw it on the plate that whizzed by me so I ordered one.  Nice with the brown mustard.  Burgers also smelled and looked good and I saw a lot of them pass by me on their way to the dining tables.  

What impressed me most was the friendly staff.  Seemed like a low-attitude, relaxed bunch of cool people which was a pleasant surprise to me given the place was jammed with folks standing around the bar making it almost impossible for anyone to squeeze past . . . particularly for the servers bringing food to the tables, and, for the table diners that had to squeeze by the bulging bar crowd.  Thankfully I prefer sitting at the bar where you get a good view of what everyone else is ordering and have a chance to chat with the bartender and learn about the current beers being offered..  

I'd definitely go back again for a burger and more brews in this cool, unpretentious place.  Could be a good weekend hangout if you're in the neighborhood.  For snobby foodies, I'd suggest coming here for a brew AFTER your dinner.
author: Larry N.

description:
My wife was charged $9 for half a glass of mediocre cider (the seever refused to give her the price when asked.  My IPA advertised as being.cocoanut flavored had no faintest notes of cocoanut flavor.  The menu had nothing for vegetarians.  And my wife tells 
me that the server fronted some major attitude.
author: Lorin G.

description:
It's $$$, not $$.  The food here is friggin good, but you will pay up.  I wish this wasn't the case because I would come here more if it was a bit more in budget.  The seared scallops with risotto was terrific, but I was still starving for a $25 dish.  Tons of beers to pick from (duh), so you can have fun trying all sorts of new goodies.  The bartenders are super friendly and helpful if you're confused.  Beers are a bit pricey too.  

This is a classy gastropub with a great vibe, tasty food, and tons of beers.  However, the price makes it a bit tough to swallow to make it an everyday go-to.
author: A A.

description: I was pretty excited about trying this place and the excitement quickly died after meeting the obnoxious, rude and arrogant staff. I sat at the bar waiting for my table and the bartender as usual was like any other San Francisco bartenders not friendly. Next I met a waiter who was also rude when asked a question. I was trying to get a table for 6 and 5 of us were already there but they wouldn't seat us till everyone was at the restaurant. Finally we told them we just want to sit with 5 people and eat. They sat us down but said they can't serve the 6th person if they show up later! Well the good thing about San Francisco is that there are so many other places to try so I am never coming back here again.
author: Rejina S.

description:
Came with some friends recently had a few beers which where very good porter beers :)

Shared the fries which where ok nothing special. Also shared a plate of cheese ,  bread, smoked ham pickled veggies and a couple other things which was a very nice appetizer.
author: Michael W.

description: Such a cool little spot. A bit snooty to me, with the doorman, but it's worth it. Excellent oysters, mushroom toast,  and tomato basil soup. Awesome selection of beer and wine, and my date and I loved the black currant hard cider. A bit pricey, but worth it. Excellent wait staff as well.
author: Emily G.

description: Have been here a couple times for drinks, once for food. Great atmosphere, decent food. Had the chickpea burger - didn't stand out particularly. Boyfriend had the chicken sandwich which was tastier. I recommend more for beers + night life than for eats.
author: Sarah B.

description:
I don't pretend to be a beer connoisseur, or even a beer dilettante, but that doesn't mean I don't recognize beer awesomeness when I see it. Monk's Kettle knows what it's doing, and executes beautifully. 

When a business does something well, especially in a heavily trafficked area, it'll inevitably be crowded. However, thanks to a Muni layover, I discovered the sweet spot for coming here: around 5:30pm on a weekday. It's late enough that you can drink without worrying about joining a 12-step program, but early enough that most people are still at work. Even on a Giants-in-the-playoffs game day I was able to readily find a spot at the bar to nibble on a (delicious!) pretzel knot and have a beer. 

So, this is a recommend - a strong recommend - but brace yourself for a line unless you have a little bit of time in an off hour.
author: Janna M.

description:
Off the 2010 Big Eat SF List, this is #50.

After heading to Tartine, we came here to relax and enjoy some beers. Oh my, their beer selection was massive. Too many to select from, but I decided to get the Koningshoeven Quadrupel, a rich caramel amber ale. It was delicious. I forgot what my friends got, but they enjoyed their beers as well.

We also shared an appetizer of Fried Green Tomatoes and it was awesome. The tomatoes were perfectly breaded and the sauce on top was yummy. 

I really liked the vibe of the place. Perfect place to hangout on a Saturday afternoon. Coming back for sure!
author: Rhoda G.

description: Very good selection, not great.  PtE on tap gets you 3 stars automatically.  I enjoyed the atmosphere and this is a great place to go to after dinner in the Mission District.  It is a little overhyped, but still recommended.
author: Bob B.

description:
Great selection of beer!  This place has become one of my favorites in SF but unfortunately, they do not take reservations for lunch/dinner so, I suggest you get there early so you can grab a table. 

The food is delicious and the beer list is never-ending.  It will take a lifetime to try out every single beer they sell...but I will do it!

I highly recommend Monk's Kettle to a beer fan and to anyone looking for amazing food in the city.
author: Liza B.

description: Large beer list. But food sub par. Chicken sandwich was burnt and too salty. Burger was dry. Too much salt on all dishes. Overpriced for the quality. 3-star only due to drink selection.
author: Anuj S.

description:
The Monk's Kitchen serves a delectable menu alongside a beer list to rival a Belgian beer fair.

The flatbread with broccoli, goats cheese and peppers was a reinvention of a classic vegetarian pizza - crunchy, smooth and a touch of salt.

Highlight was the half chicken with peppers that have been pickled in a pale ale. Yep! They are sweet with a tangy, vinegary, and mildly-spicy aftertaste. Sensational and highly recommended.
author: Seb R.

description: I stumbled on this place without checking Yelp reviews (gasp!) and was pleasantly surprised. The beer selection is INCREDIBLE and the food was absolutely perfect. (Great bar food is hard to come by!) Service was super friendly and speedy. Our waiter even let us taste a couple beers before committing to our order. I came with a girlfriend but I'm sure it would make an excellent date spot.
author: Christa K.

description:
With a formidable tap list, even more extensive bottle collection, vintage bottles available and good food, this place is the full package to me.  came in on a Wednesday afternoon, so very quiet.  staff was friendly and attentive.  had 3 small pours and a sandwich and salad. I only wish I had more time to stay longer
and try more!
author: Denise H.

description:
Lots of love in here.

A quote comes to mind
"Cooking is like love; it should be entered into with abandon or not at all."
 Julia Child

Not only has everything that comes out of the kitchen wow-ed me, the stuff out of the tap aint so bad either. I had an incredible light 'n spicy beer here called Voove. 

The best part was how I ordered it. They have a ridiculous amount of beer on the menu, I was feeling like the guy taking my order could probably pick something better than I could... I asked for some help. He asked me a series of questions all in the same format, do you like this ___ or that ___. 

I liked this game. What came out of this interchange was Voove, and a happy, hoppy me. 

The cheese plate is great to share with a group and comes with an assortment of spreads....a light strawberry jam...and several tangy mustard's. Toasted bread and olives are the cherry on top.

The chicken sandwich was also a favorite. I am not often impressed by sammies but I will be ordering this again soon. We always close with a crowd favorite- the carrot cake. It is unreal, and my description won't do it any justice. 

Many happy moments spent in this shadowy den of the Mission. Love.
author: Jocelyn B.

description:
Top reason why you should head out to Monks Kettle as soon as possible: Elbow macaroni, house-made cheddar ale sauce and toasted bread crumbs with house-cured maple smoked bacon sprinkled on top. I'm usually carb-averse but this baby had me salivating over every bite. 2nd on that list is a tie between the pulled pork and the ahi tuna sandwhich served with crispy deliscious fries. 

I'm typically not a fan of bars that only serve beer and wine but their beer menu was impressive with a little something on there for everyone. Their wine menu left much to be desired but I found a glass of zin I really liked and stuck to for the rest of the night. 

This is a fun laid back atmosphere where you come here to throw back a couple really good beers, catch up with friends in a chill setting and eat an extremely satisfying meal before you venture on to a more wild and crazy evening....or was that just me?
author: Kristy M.

description:
I feel bad writing this, because I walk by Monk's Kettle literally every day.  But upon finally going to this place two years after moving a half block away I was disappointed.  After an expensive, monotonous, overly big salad I was served a hamburger with consistency of Play Doh.  I could only stomach about three bites - and hamburgers are like Pokemon for me. (Gotta get 'em all!)

To be fair, the kind waiter took it off my tab, and my girlfriend's chickpea burger was good, but after spending $40 I expect better.  Two stars.
author: Dan S.

description:
Let me preface this review with I am not a beer drinker. So bearing this in mind please do not burn me at the stake.

My co-worker looooves beer so since his 30th birthday was here I decided to give this place a try based on the reviews I had read. 
Parking it horrendous in the mission so if you are going to try to park around here wisse which is a few blocks down is a kind of out of the way alley that for some reason had no one parked in it. 
It is easy to see that there is often a wait at this place. We managed to get off work early so we sat ourselves right away. This is the only reason I am giving it -1 star. The waitstaff is very disjointed. We sat ourselv and waited for menus then waited again an lengthy amount of time for someone to come back to get rink orders and given how we saw other people waiting we ordered our food right away too to avoid another long wait. It is hard to tell who is working and who isn't, and I def assure you the waitstaff is enjoying themselves as much as the patrons. 

For the beer lovers I can see this being paradise. They have what seems a million beers (literally the menu is about 30 pages long) but unlike alot of places that keep all these beers on tap many of the beers are actually bottled. I noted this because it meant you are not running the chance of getting an "old" beer. Unfortunatly for the non-beer drinkers you are prety sol. I know I know "if you dont drink beer waa waa waa" well w/e sometimes you have to make do for your friends. 

Both my coworker and I loved the food we had as well. I can not say this enough I will give my love verytime for a place that can do real medium rare burger. Soooooooo much happiness! My Co-worker ahd their pulled chicken and was quite happy with it. neither of us left anything on our plate. Their desserts made the night. I had the dark chocolate bread pudding, and if I didn't already feel like a waterbuffalo from the burger this decadant dessert was going to put me into a happiness coma. Sooooooo good and warm and happy and delicous. C-worker got the peach cobbler. Now it may be because he is male, it may be becaue he was three beers at an average of 18% alcohl each down, it may be because hes "pretty" but he was given the warning.. this is hot... and he proceeded to burn his mouth off. Hot means hot. The cobbler was just as decadent and delicous though.

So to sum it up:
great place for beers
great place for desert
not good for gorup bigger than four
need to have patience with the wait staff
need to be patient while waiting for a palce if you get thre from 5 oclock on. (they do take your number at the door and call you when there is a table open)
need to be okay with very close cozy quarters.


***Update BTW... Macaroni and Cheese is not on the menu... jus saying ;)
author: Meg N.

description: Great beer. Great bar. Good staff. Bartender was not cool.  We were here for beer week and he treated us as if we were alcoholics.  We asked for tasters instead of full pours.  Um, yes we are lushes.  We will enjoy brews elsewhere.
author: Jill S.

description:
Don't let the size of the sign fool you - monks kettle is not much bigger inside than the sign indicates! We arrived at 4:45 on a wednesday afternoon - there were three in our party and a fourth on the way. But , because our 4th wasn't there they wouldn't let us take a table. Ok so we  went to sit in the back at the rail all the while discussing the table policy because they were all empty!  Anyway, the owner overheard us talking and asked the bartender to give us a table. That was nice and we very much appreciated it.  But know that by 6:00 pm the place was packed and this was a Wednesday!  So, be forewarned...

Drink - carafes of water are placed on the table and refilled.  The beer, oh, the beer.  So many choices,  a nice beer flight is available, draughts are plentiful and varied.  There is a glossary that explains terms. Nice assortment of wines, hard cider and sherry.  Menu items are paired with suggested beer choices.  All in all great - but beware you could easily drop $100 in no time.

Food - all in all a nice selection. One minor complaint. The cheese and salumi plate was overpriced at $30 for what it contained, a few small pieces of cheese, about 5 .50 cent piece size slices of salami a couple of pieces of ham some bread and jam.  Do not order this.  However, everything else wed ordered was great: beef cheeks and polenta, flavorful, chicken paillard with great bread and delicious bacon jam, hamburger with onion jam done to order with a soft bun and diver sea scallops with crab risotto magnificent!  Also has oysters and soft pretzel knot. The oysters were crispy with the right amount of spice and the pretzel knot was crisp on the outside and soft in the center. It came with 2 dipping sauces, cheese and stone ground mustard.

Dessert - we were full but managed to share the chocolate stout bread pudding and one in or party had the beer and vanilla ice cream float.  Spectacular!

Pricey, but with the exception of the cheese plate, worth it!
author: Jaci G.

description: Nice atmosphere. Great beer selection. Burger was amazing, as was chocolate bread pudding and paired biscotti stout.
author: Courtney C.

description: It's good. But not exceptionally good. Had a bunch of small plates and a few beers. The fares were original but nothing truly out of the ordinary. And the ingredients were a bit repetitive. Also it was a bit pricey.
author: Ruben K.

description: What a great way to spend my evening. The ambience is nice, pleasant lively crowd. Had the veggie burger, one of the best I've ever had paired with the Orval  (Belgian style beer), making it that much better. The beer alone was delicious, a little sour with fantastic nutty finish. I've never paid so much for a beer! $14!  But I didn't mind. Went in at 7:30ish on a Wednesday just after the New Year, I dread to imagine how packed this place normally gets.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Second time coming here was on a Sunday afternoon right when they opened (noon) - it was definitely more enjoyable as most of the tables were empty and we weren't sandwiched in a tiny booth with 6 other people.

For 2 we ordered:
- Giant Pretzel 
- Duck "spring rolls" - they were actually on a fried wonton
- Lobster bruschetta
- Chicken sandwich

The duck was a little salty, but overall the food was good. I had one of the beer pairings for the bruschetta since I didn't care to choose from the ridiculous list of beers, but after ordering a second glass and finally seeing the bill, I realized each glass was $14!!!!.  That's literally the price of an appetizer, and I definitely don't have the palate to distinguish between a $5 vs $14 beer.  

Next time I'm coming here I'll check to make sure I don't select one of the ridiculously priced imported beers but overall I still think highly of the restaurant/pub except for the prices.
author: Leily P.

description:
This place is super delicious.

Not a huge fan of "The Mission" in San Francisco.
However this place is awesome and is worth every delicious bite of food and sip of beer.

Note* Parking SUCKS!!! 
I think I drove around the location five times before I found a spot.

My two favorite things in life are beer and burgers.

Order:
1. Hamburgers
2. Sour Beer

That is all.
author: Nathan B.

description:
Pros:
- They took down the phone number of one of the people in our group (we had 7 people total) so they could text us when our table was ready. 
- Diver scallops with crab and corn risotto was really good. Especially the risotto. Yum. 
- Pretzel knot was good! Really soft on the inside. 
- The foccacia that the pulled chicken sandwich came on was good. 

Cons:
- Super long wait. 
- They only had one table big enough for 7 people. And it was just about big enough for the 7 of us (we are all pretty small). We had another friend join us halfway through our meal and there was no space for her to sit at all. We ended up pulling an empty chair from the table next to us over, but we were immediately told by the wait staff that it was a fire hazard and we weren't allowed to do that, so we had one person standing for most of the time.
- The pretzel knot is not that big. 
- The pulled chicken in the pulled chicken sandwich was kind of dry and not really flavorful. Highlight of the sandwich was the bread. 
- Wait staff was not very friendly..
- The waitress messed up our bill at the end of the night. Yes it was kind of complicated because we gave her two cards and cash... but instead of charging both of the cards, she charged one card twice.. which is not that bad but what's worse is that she also forgot to deduct the amount we had paid in cash, so we could have been charged twice for a portion of the bill had we not pointed it out. Not cool =/

Overall, good food but not worth the wait.
author: Sophie Y.

description:
I have just watched True Grit, so I shall talk as if I am a stalwart cowboy, riding into the lonesome mountains, reckoning and figure-ing lonesome cowboy things with my stalwart horse. 

I very much enjoyed the establishment, Monk's Kettle. The gentleman stopping our party outside the doors was a surprise, but polite as he inquired if we wished to be seated at the bar, which seemed to be a 30 minute wait, or if our party was interested in one of the small tables set against the walls of the room. I reckon most patrons of this here establishment come in for a beer or two, as the wait for tables was a mere 10 minutes. 

The food itself was good if not anything exceedingly memorable. However, one does not come here for food. With one look at the menu one will notice the extravagant, incredible beer menu, or better yet, beer book, that marches forward, page after weathered page. Though I fancy myself a professional of sorts in those beers of a more expensive variety, I must say I was pleasantly astonished by the best beer menu, by far, I have ever lain my eyes upon from here to yonder and over the rainbow. The descriptions and content of this here menu did make love to my thirst, and ever since then I have not been the same man. Nor do I wish to return to the same, naive individual I was before I set foot in this establishment. 

Fill your hands.
author: Jonathan Y.

description:
Hmmmm....

I ordered a small $19 pot pie so I had very high expectations. However, I found it very disappointing as it was missing a key ingredient - corn! Put some sweet corn in the pot pie and it may be worth $12. 

I also ordered a recommended beer to pair my dish. I think it was the Affligem Tripel. It was okay. I was told that it was light and fruity, but it tasted like regular light beer. The glass of beer (~$10) costs almost as much as an appetizer / cheap dish. 

My friends, who like beer, thought the beer here was really delicious so I would give this place a try if you are a beer fan.

This place really needs to get some seat cushions for its benches. I was uncomfortable the entire time.
author: Margaret R.

description:
So, heard a lot of hype about this place. Luckily I avoided the long wait by going during off peak hours. I was able to get a table in the back.  There's limited seating at the bar, then some counter seats in the back as well as a handful of table. First come, first serve- no reservations allowed. The service was friendly and the beer selection is craftily presented in a beer binder with an extensive list. The breaded oysters were not worth the price at $3 a piece, the oysters were a fair size, but the flavor wasn't impressive. The cornmeal over powered the texture and cucumber ketchup was lackluster. The sweetbread dish was ok, however the creamy risotto was the best. It was filling and quite flavorful with good consistency.  Perhaps the larger plates are more interesting, but then you are too full to have more beer.  
I tried the Kona Coffee Porter and the Black Xantus flight (2009 and 2011 tastings) which were impressive.
The place seems little too pretentious- not necessarily the staff, but more the clientele. It's the Mission hipster foodies with their annoying loud and vulgar conversations that make the atmosphere distasteful. At 3pm I don't really want to hear about the next seating's sexual conquests.
author: Naomi K.

description:
I raved about this place to my wife for over a year. I've been a total of three times before I took my wife today. Never again after today's experience.

I've eaten here before and have always known that service is usually busy and thus the staff come by every now and then. The food and service though have always been five stars in the past. Here's where they went wrong today:

- Wife and I ordered our food, then a couple was set to the table next to us. For some reason, their main course came out before ours. They had burgers, we had a veggies burger and the mussels. Maybe ours took longer.

- Food came and my wife's mussels were overcooked. The mussels were sitting in a tiny amount of broth, the mussels near the top were the consistency of beef jerky, and the bread that came with the mussels to dip in the broth were burnt. Someone left her dish in too long as that would explain the very little broth she had, chewy mussels, and burnt bread.

- My veggie burger came out burned on one side, the other side was cooked properly. Someone left my burger on one side too long. The fries that came with my burger were really potato chips. You could see through the fries and they were crunchy. I felt like I was eating potato strings and not fries.

- Nobody came by at any and asked how our food was or if we needed anything. It was just, here's your food, dig in. Even when they came to clear the table, nobody asked how things were.

- My wife ordered the pickled veggies. Nobody bothered to bring them by. Thankfully we weren't charged for that.

I was very disappointed in this place. I used to enjoy coming here in the past. I will avoid it now and tell my friends how crummy the food and service was this time.
author: D M.

description:
Not for groups! Yelp is on the money with this! Cozy atmosphere is great for a date. Not a place to meet people or socialize.

Their wine list is spectacular! I had a Pommard from France and it was floral and served in a beautiful wine glass, quality! Glasses here are min $11.50 though. They have a few booths that can seat 4 people and a bar area in the back where people can lounge on bar stools.
author: Kathy S.

description: They get 5 stars for having Pliny The Elder. One of most sought after beers in the world. The Duck confit was stellar too. My vegan pal was thrilled with his dish. I was at an event with some friends from Texas, we went downtown and came here for drinks and dinner. Got lucky and got the last table before they went on a wait. That was around 530 on a Saturday. I shall return!
author: Lee F.

description:
My  boyfriend and i are not from SF, so when we found this spot we felt lucky!
He loves beer and i love food. Perfect!
Large selection of beer (he was in heaven).
The food was above and beyond.
The pretzel knot was amazing (just wish 2 came with an order)
and the best veggie burger i have had in a while.
The space is small and can get crowded, so get ready to sit really close to the person next to you! but that's the fun part about the place!
I will definitely come back next time we are in town!
author: M K.

description:
Why I marked this as 4 stars previously, I have no idea.

Food is pure awesomeness. The bar's small, but I like that intimate, beer-lovers-only-or-leave feel. People all about the scene and not true soul won't like this place (which adds value for me), because it's packed with care -- you can tell the owners and staff care about their customers and their product.

Beer is an out of this world selection (figuratively and literally speaking!). Bartenders are amazing. I think they all have Master's in the history and evolution of beer and a minor in hops 4-1-1- because they know their shiz. Ask them anything about beer, you won't stump em!

Great place for a date, friend meetup, or just a standard Wednesday pick-me-up. Please never leave the city, MK!
author: Tejal D.

description:
Draft Stone Pale 20 oz. $7.50. 
Arugula Salad $9.00
Total with tax $17.91
Total with tax and tip $21.41
I definitely would spend a few bucks more next time and get a burger. However, I do feel more healthy having gone the salad route. But then I was hungry again two hours later and I had pizza.  
Service was decent. I could tell he was kind of confused as to why I was getting a salad... It's okay, I was confused too. I didn't see the burger on the menu.
author: Dave L.

description:
I really enjoyed my visit to the monk's kettle.
I know nothing about beer, and the bartenders answered all of my (likely very stupid) questions, and helped me pick out a new go-to beer!
The burger was also excellent, as was the pulled chicken sandwich. 
I will definitely go back.
author: Cami J.

description: Wow, more beers than you can taste in a month of Sunday's.   That being said, I may try to get thru the menu and figure out what type of beer I REALLY like!  Cool pub environment I can recommend without hesitation.  Pretty packed, but comfortable outside seating was readily available on a cool night.  Service is attentive and no complaints on that front.  You should try the fried oysters!  While a cornmeal covered oyster isn't anything to write home about, the accompanying gastrique and pickled veggie made it a stellar dish.  Had the duck confit and roast of the day (pork shoulder) and both were excellent.  Go...you'll have fun!
author: Howard B.

description:
My buddy took me here, which is why he is my buddy. 

I spent a year abroad the the UK, but this has to be the best selection of beer I've ever had at a pub. The servers made some excellent recommendations for beers, and the pretzel knots were revelatory.

This is the kind of place I would be honored to call my local pub, if only it wasn't an hour away from where I live.
author: Alexander H.

description:
These guys really know their beers and their selection shows it. I agree that it is pricey but you are paying to have a huge degree of choice. If you have a benjamin just to spend on beer you can really tour the world while sitting in the Mission. I tried the Norwegian Farmhouse Ale which I've never had before.

I do find the atmosphere a little pretentious. The idealist in me would always like to believe that beer houses are very down to earth. The chalkboard at the bar helped a little with that. I think as we started scrawling on it the average maturity in the whole place sharply dipped. But I still can't help but feel a tiny bit uncomfortable in the place.

It's an irrational concern though. This is a place I intend to come back to and would recommend to a friend. So it's a 4.
author: Josh K.

description:
One of my favorite bars in SF, where you can eat great good and drink deliciously crafted beers. It gets pretty busy later into the evening, so try to snag a seat around normal dinner time! Then hop around the area for more drinks =)

They usually have great pairings with all the food on their menu, beers run around $6-15 a glass (even have gluten free beer, haha), and you can always have a taste of a beer before ordering it. Service is usually pretty good, the staff is great with food/beer pairings and suggestions.

BTW, their burger + delicious beer = happiness.
author: Alex R.

description:
This place has a great selection of beers...nothing compares to their menu.  But the way they run the place, really anal...ever heard of the soup nazi from seinfeld?  First time i go there, we meet up with friends and they say we cant sit with them even though they have two spaces open at their table...reasoning was "it screws up with the flow of things..". Its not a michelin rated restaurant, is Thomas keller working in the kitchen?  No, you're just a bar.

Second time, there were 8 of us looking to just get drinks at the bar...they dont let us in because they only allow 10 people to stand around the bar...really?  Get rid of the restaurant theme you got going, when you're known for beers, then what is the point of serving mediocre bar food?
author: Andrea D.

description:
Let me start off by saying at their scallops were impeccably delicious, tender juicy, fat, moist, a little crispy on the outside, and just a tad sweet.  I was in scallop heaven.  It came with baked apple wrapped with bacon.    OK, I know you must be wondering, then why 3 stars?

We waited FOREVER.  And I know that should not diminish the number of stars, but overall other than the scallops, nothing else was that great.  My boyfriend got some type of beef, which in my opinion was pretty average.  The drinks were alright.  I didn't get anything.  The service was not really note-worthy.  I think, overall, it was just overpriced.
author: Aly A.

description:
I came here after dinner hour to chill, and it was nice and dim. 

Even though The Monk's Kettle is known for their beer selection, especally Belguim ones...I like to point out that for me, as long as I order their fries with their housemade dipping sauces, any beer will taste mighty gooood! Seriously! Order their fries!!
author: Mandy C.

description: Good beer selection in the part of town you wouldn't expect good things in.  The pretzels were good but not to rave for.  It's meant to be more of a restaurant than a bar and they keep people out who would buy drinks and not food.
author: Jeff R.

description: Sparse seating, but a fantastic beer selection and warm staff made the wait worth it. I haven't eaten the food, but it looks good!
author: Gretchen S.

description: This place is really cool. It is like an old-timey pub with gourmet bar food. There is an enormous assortment of beer and the employees are very helpful in helping you decide which beers to try. We started with the pretzels for two. Great choice! They serve the pretzels with melted cheese as well as mustard. To go along with my draft beer, I indulged in the burger. It was really tasty. Not too greasy and cooked perfectly medium-well like I requested. Delisshh. The fries were great too. We heard from one of the employees that they are about to being renovations to the interior of the restaurant/bar as well as construction on an outside patio. We cannot wait to return once the patio is complete with our pup. We noticed they had already installed heaters outside so that's a plus! If you love beer, and a good burger, do yourself a favor and try this place out. It will not disappoint you.
author: Kelsey K.

description:
As I pretend to be a professional food critic and continue to hone my skills through unnecessarily long Yelp* reviews.  I often find myself torn between summarizing a single experience or taking my impressions and then contextualizing them with all of my restaurant experiences.  All things considered I think the latter is a more fitting way to review anything but sometimes a single experience stands out so much you just have to rave about that one.

The Monk's Kettle provided such an experience.  To keep this short and sweet since my Yelp* review will be lost in cacophony of SF's Yelp* population this review will be just over 600 words.  

My girlfriend and I ordered the charcuterie plate, the lamb burger, some french fries with an awesome dip selection and the fig and goat cheese bruschetta.  All things considered the food was very good.  The charcuterie plate had an excellent selection and was definitely not minimal.  The fig and goat cheese bruschetta was amazing; probably one of the best tasting things apps I have ever had.  The lamb burger was good but too much tzatziki kind of drowned the natural flavor of the lamb so it was more of a tzatziki burger and less of a lamb burger. 
 
The real experience is the beer.  We literally had the real champagne of beers (no offense High Life) and at $65 dollars a bottle was it worth it?  The answer is: I stopped caring!   How the food tasted at about half way through the burger was literally not applicable because I was drinking some of the best beer I have ever tried.   Every beer they picked out for us was a perfect compliment to the food or was some sort of unique and amazing beer that was cause for celebration.  It's not often that I drink a beer and want to high five someone because of how good it is.  I totally high-fived our bartender! 

Speaking of celebration apparently the night we were there is also the same evening that the Belgians celebrate their independence from the Dutch.  I don't know or care how historically accurate that is.  They gave my girlfriend a silly hat to go with an awesome Belgian beer she ordered and everyone is a winner because I got a good laugh, she got a good beer and a free hat.

When it comes to free stuff one thing you can rarely get at a bar is a free chemistry lesson.  Well lock down that bar stool because it's about get knowl-edgy up in here.  Not only did out bar tender(s) and server all know the beer menu inside and out and were very attentive but one of them was studying to take a test and gave the group I was sitting with basically a chemistry lesson that came with trying different beers to help describe the brewing processes he was talking to us about.  It was like hanging out with Bill Nye, Mike Rowe and a Belgian Monk without an accent.

On a completely unrelated tangent; the detractors of Monk's Kettle that complain about the restaurant being crowded need to take a deep breath and realize that anyplace in SF that is good will be crowded.  Almost every decent restaurant used to be someone's living room or a kitchen that was turned in to a whole restaurant.  It's going to be busy and with that being said yes there was a 45 min wait on Wednesday at 8pm.
author: Andrew K.

description:
If paying 13 dollar for a burger or 13 dollars for a single beer sounds reasonable to you then this is great place for you.

If you aren't a big drinker and can cook "comfort food" yourself then this place is a miss.

I will say the friend I was with who knows a thing or too about alcohol said that the choices here are like the college of beer with choice far better than the usual hipster swill of PBR and tecate and the selection is very good. So if you do like to chug the fine stuff, this is a good place for it.

The service was actually perfectly fine when we were there but it does appear to work there you must have facial hair, a love of plaid shirts and no body fat. But hipster bashing aside, our server was a nice helpful guy.

The friend really liked the burger which was the reason he wanted to come back here.

I got the beef cheeks and polenta. I like my polenta far more creamy inside even when it has been grilled on the outside, the cheeks of course were tender but a bit over salty.

The prices are pretty high for what they are serving but the place was packed with hipsters happy to pay it. If you like to drink and have a little food with your beer this is a good place for you. If you are dating a hipster hottie this is good place for you.
author: DeathandFood H.

description: Really good German beer selection, but beware: The bartenders won't let you drink from the bottle, they insist on you drinking from a glass. Um, no German would drink a lager from a glass. Beer snobs.
author: Lola P.

description:
I really can't type enough to describe how much I love this place. Amazing, AMAZING beer, chalkboards, and humble bartenders. 

GO TO THIS PLACE!!
author: Florence D.

description:
When you really want a wide variety of beers or if you are craving a specific beer, where do you go? Most people would say Toronado (I agree), City Beer Store (I agree with that too), maybe even La Trappe, but I would also say Monk's Kettle. Although this place is tiny, it serves up a rather extensive list of beers and has great food to boot. 

Last Thursday I was really craving Goose Island's "Matilda" and was searching Yelp to see where I could find it. It appeared that Monk's Kettle had Goose Island on their menu at one point, so I thought I'd give it a try. It had been years since I had been there anyway.

Lo and behold they did NOT have Matilda, but our waiter was willing to recommend something similar and it was delicious (at over $11 a bottle it better be!). All in all, I like this place. It had a laid-back vibe, great beer selection, and good food.
author: Melissa N.

description: A small space in the mission that serves some of the best beers on tap!  As a huge fan of IPA's and Russian River brewery, I LOVED Monk's Kettle.  Pliny the Elder on tap?  Sure!  I don't remember all the beers I sampled, but I loved each one.  Again, the space is tight and cramped, but oddly cozy.  Service was great, as was all the food we ordered.  I would definitely come back (and have) - there's a reason Monk's Kettle is one of SF's most popular spots for beer enthusiasts!
author: Angela R.

description:
One of my new favorite places in SF!

The beer selection is large and well thought out. It covers everything from Beligian to Sours. But what is even more impressive are the Staffs knowledge of all the brews, they clearly take beer seriously here. 

The food is comforting and very unhealthy. Good Fries, Good Burger, Good Soup, Good pretzel appetizer!

If you are down for an awesome night, then you should probably try this place.
author: Nicolas M.

description:
Well.......

+/-I had the mussels and they were pretty griddy. Obviously its a shellfish and it lives in the ocean. However..... tastin'  some grains of sand with at each mussel forces me to believe they dont clean them that well. Thats too bad bc they flavor was sooo incredible with charred bread. And they forgot to give me a little fork and waste dish for all the shells... common now.....

+Beers are good, expensive. Its a nice little gastropub that was open the day after christmas. 
+Servers were friendly

Conclusion: I would like to come back and check out some other things on their menu and try some beers if someone else is paying. haha.
author: Julia D.

description: I rarely if ever leave a bad Yelp review, but sadly this place is a shadow of its former self. We don't really appreciate being judged on whether we are worthy of a table based on what we order, and being ushered out based on how much we spend. Good bye, Rasputin float. We hardly knew ye.
author: Chris C.

description:
The Monk's Kettle has it all - great beer, food, staff & décor.  I've been to a couple places like this (Belgian style gastropub), but they all missed one of the elements; it's rare to hit them all.  It was pretty packed when we got there, and we were told it'd be a 20 minute wait.  Though the wait ended up being longer, we didn't mind because as soon as a spot at the bar opened up, one of the staff came over to let us know, and get a drink order started.  Everyone who works there is really friendly and accommodating, and it feels like you're hanging out with friends.
