The décor is really nice - love the wall of beer glasses, and the dark wood everywhere. 

We ordered the burger and pulled chicken sandwich.  The pulled chicken was yummy (but a bit heavy on the aioli), and the burger was phenomenal - perfectly cooked and tons of flavor.  I also loved the skinny fries!  

It's a small space, so I wouldn't recommend coming with more than 4 people - 2 is optimal.
author: Jessica R.

description: They literally have a bible of beer. Praise the Lord and can I get an amen! Since I am from Southern California and  a Pliny the Elder will run you an ungodly amount down at a bar here, I ordered one at a sweet $7.75. I tried out the cheese and charcuterie board and the hard cheese of the day for a goat's milk Gouda which until that moment I did not even know existed. Pair that with a wild boar salumi and some great homemade mustard and artisan style bread and I am a happy camper. The atmosphere is standard pub style, lots of hardwood and a general good natured sense of griminess but they were playing all Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers on the sound system throughout the duration of my meal so you will get no complaints from me.
author: Rebecca T.

description:
If you like good, overpriced beer and great Gastropub style food, you'll love Monk's Kettle. The wait usually isn't bad, the kitchen is open until 1am and the staff are very knowledgable about beer. 

I wish they changed their menu up a little more besides the daily roast, but that hasn't seemed to stop me from coming back. Their burger is one of the best I've had in SF, so if you haven't had that yet, do it.
author: Vamsi T.

description: My husband and I went to dinner at Monk's kettle tonight.  We have not been there for about a year.  We used to rave about their delicious burgers, nut mix, and great beer selection.  Much has changed!  A lot of menu items are gone, the quality of what remains has gone way down, and prices have skyrocketed! I went to order the nut mix, but was told by our waitress that they no longer make it and that they have made a few changes to the menu.  Why you would remove delicious nut mix from a bar menu? My husband and I both ordered the burger which a year ago was 17.00 with the bacon added on, which I thought was expensive but because it was so delicious I was willing to pay the price.  Now the burger is 17.00 without the bacon, and 3.00 extra for the bacon.  My husband ordered it medium rare and I ordered the burger cooked medium.  Both were served well done, and the burger did not melt in your mouth the way it used to.  Not to mention you could barely taste any bacon flavor from the puny slivers of bacon they laid on top that were as thin as prosciutto.  The burger we had tonight was a burger you could get at any pub for about 8.00.  Total rip off.  Our waitress was also MIA the whole time.  The front of house basically waited on us, which was nice but weird? I definitely will not go back.
author: Ashley C.

description: I am down with The Monk's Kettle. They have excellent food and just about any sort of beer, lager, or ale you could imagine. The only downside about this place is the low amount of seating. Sure, you have to put up with numerous hipsters and Valencia St. parking, but at least you get to indulge in a ridiculous amount of different beers in different glasses. Yeah, they're very particular about their glasses. Oh, and you know where you're at when you see the prices.
author: Danny C.

description:
Love love love this spot!! Found it on accident one night while walking around the mission. From the minute we walked in, everything was perfect! Beer selection, unbeatable. Food - fresh, local, deliciously prepared, upscale, well-priced, and creative. Staff - awesome! Shout out to Greg (GM) and the bartenders who have served us so far (Travis and Jared). So far we've gone every Tuesday for the past 6 weeks....and we don't plan on stopping!!  

See you guys soon!
author: zia s.

description: I loved this place! Even though I was one of the only girls here I felt very comfortable. I'm a huge Belgian  beer fan and they have a huge selection. This place would be ideal for a quick after work drink with a friend or even for dinner. I highly recommend the pretzels for an appetizer!
author: SaraH B.

description:
The Monk's Kettle literally has about eleventy billion options for beer which is both awesome and annoying. Asking for a beer reco is basically like playing 20 questions with the bartender; there are so many options he'll need to ask you that many questions to make a reco.
I do have to say, after my 20 question beer interview, I did wind up with a really awesome beer! Also ordered the burger which was juicy and flavorful.

If you want to come here for a beer or dinner, come in a small group (4 people or less). The space is relatively small, so it's really hard for them to accomodate groups larger than 4. (A group of 10 of us came here for a birthday dinner and we had to break into small groups in order to get seated....wa wa.)

I will definitely come back.
author: Alicia B.

description:
This place is a gem for Belgian style beer lovers like me. Only been here once while I was visiting from Southern California, but jeez what a treat. 

We went on a week night very late, like at midnight, as it wasn't too packed and we were able to snag seats at the bar for a good half hour, and the swooped on an open table.. Swoopin' ain't easy!

Snacked on a hugely salted pretzel with a toe due for cheese and mustard sauce. Maybe I was just drunk from all the beers I had consumed that night, but that pretzel hit the spot!

The beer list (bottled and on tap) is huge! There are beers from all different varieties, regions, etc. The bartenders sure know their beer damn well, so if you are unsure of what your preference is, I am sure they can hook you up with a taster or two to find the right beer for you. 

I would love to come back to one of their beer dinners, they sound right up my alley!
author: Summer C.

description:
Ah, Monk's Kettle. What happened?

One of my original favorite spots in San Francisco has truly gone straight down the tubes. The old menu is sorely missed, and the beer prices are now so ridiculously high ($14.75 for Rodenbach Grand Cru on tap?  come on...) that with the lack of a food option that makes sense for this kind of beer-based establishment, I would much rather go to Magnolia, Beer Revolution, or even Toronado. And don't even get me started on the door guy, that's clearly been covered enough here on Yelp.

BTW, I can go on forever about how superior the old food menu was, and how much more sense it made for this place. Clearly those in charge here are more interested in making the food here more wine-bar esque, and less gastropub-ish. That's fine, their decision. For this style of food though, there are far, far superior places to go to in San Francisco.

I will say though, to the server of the table of two next to us. Don't be a condescending asshole to people. If a couple people who come in who are really stoked on something no longer on the menu (in this case, the older, larger, superior pretzel), don't make them feel stupid about it. "Oh, you mean the ones that we used to just microwave from a box?  You clearly haven't been here in awhile."  A) I doubt that's true and B) Why go there and say that?  If you're so all about the new pretzel being better than the old version, let it speak for itself. 

And it does. It is very, very small, and unfulfilling, and much like The Monk's Kettle now, only half of what it used to be.
author: George C.

description:
Wowee! The portions are ridiculous here. I could've easily split my Pulled Pork sandwich. I'm not known to let good food go to waste though so I scarfed it up. My friend couldn't even finish her Mac n' Cheese which was also quite lovely from what I sampled. Our side of fries came with three different yummy dipping sauces. I couldn't get enough of the herb mayo (and I'm not a huge mayo person) and the curry flavoured mustard. So good.

If you like beer, you'll love this pub. The beer menu is quite large and so is the wine menu. The prices are a little steep though, I must warn you. It gets pretty crowded even on a weeknight. It's a good place to play catch up, especially if you're looking for a place to grab a drink.
author: Amy J.

description:
Definitely in my top 3 beer places in San Fran and the best in the mission. the 3 philosophers is up there with the best beer I had in the city so thanks to the bar tender for recommending that one!

My first experience here wasn't so good as my request for a recommendation from the bartender was met with a scowl like I knew nothing about beer, but subsequent trips were all significantly better so I'd say stick with this place as it'll quickly become your go to place in the Mission for quality beers, and a burger if you're feeling hungry.
author: Ben C.

description:
Great spot!

My father (who's quite the beer aficionado) and I went to Monk's Kettle on a Wednesday night at 10pm. We sat at the cute table next to the entrance window (no wait for a seat).

We ordered the Serpents Stout and the London Porter Nitro. (They had run out of the Evil Twins Red Ale - so we'll have to make a return trip.) The Serpents Stout was an impressive beer. The portion is a little less than you'd expect, but that's because the alcohol concentration is almost double that of many of the other beers on draught. Very full flavor, not too bitter. All-around a great beer.

The Porter Nitro should not be tried with the Stout because it will taste like water in comparison. But alone, it is light and smooth (almost the consistency of milk - I know, I know, it's terrible to think of milk and beer in the same sentence, but it does have a very smooth texture).

Anyway - will likely return - great spot for trying new beers!
author: Helen D.

description: Excellent beer selection and good food.  I recommend sticking with the burger, fries, or pretzel. Wash it down with a cask ale
author: Rick P.

description: Great selection I beer. Bartenders are knowledgable and helped me pick out just the right one, a chocolate stout.
author: Elena H.

description:
Four stars just for the beer selection. Pliny the Elder FTW!

Haven't tried the food here, but I'll have to come back sometime soon to test it out.

The place does get pretty crowded, so probably not the best for large groups. Even with a group of just 4, we were pretty squashed in the corner by the bar.

Still coming back for the beer..
author: Euna K.

description:
BEST BEER EVER!!!

Every time I have out of town guests, I make it a must to bring them here.  Although the place is quite small and stuffy, that's also the great appeal to this place.  Like a hometown bar with a big city vibe.  I just wish they had more veg options on their menu, but then again, this is more of a place to get a good buzz than full.

Cheers!
author: Lea F.

description: I ordered the fresh ground burger with onion jam and aged white cheddar. It came with a side of hop salt fries. I would say it was the juiciest and most flavorful burger I've ever had. It felt like it was melting in my mouth. Their beer selection is massive, so I asked the waiter for a recommendation. I don't remember which beer I ordered, but whatever it was, it was delicious. Thank you, Mr. Waiter. I wish I remembered which beer it was so that I can order it again. The ambiance was cozy and our waiter was great. I'll be back for sure.
author: Kalea K.

description:
Came here quite a while ago, but I can still remember their burger like it was yesterday (not really actually).

What I can remember though was that the burger was among the best I've had in SF so far. It was *really* juicy. I was hesitant at first because there seemed to be a lot of other interesting options on the menu, but I was ultimately pretty happy with the burger. The beer that was recommended with the burger was pretty good too (they have a ton of interesting ones on top).

There's a pretty cool gritty/hipster ambience and really reminded me of Father's Office in LA (which is a good thing), but the waitress we had wasn't exactly the most friendly.
author: Jono L.

description: Yes, it's a tad pricey and maybe not the quintessential Gastropub, but the food is usually pretty delicious. They have a great beer selection, too. A big part of the reason I'm shaving a star is because of the waitstaff: they can be pretty snooty sometimes. I'd say half the time they're pretty curt, bordering on flippant. I don't really eat out for service though; I eat out for awesome food, and they're pretty solid in that regard.
author: Eric E.

description:
I have to admit, I was a little nervous about this place. They don't take reservations, and, you know, it's a hipster joint -- which to my mind meant standoffish waiters in horn-rimmed glasses and scarf-clad lines out the door. I WAS DEAD WRONG.

The Monk's Kettle is a beer drinker's paradise in the Mission district, just a short walk from the 16th St. BART station. It's a small place with cute decor and chalkboards littered with beer family diagrams to educate the uninitiated. I went there with a party of 4 for an early dinner.

The staff and clientele were friendly and helpful. The bartenders went above and beyond to make sure we had a comfortable table and could get in and out just fine (my boyfriend is in a wheelchair). Patrons moved, bartenders escorted us, and owners spoke shyly about how they were the luckiest guys in the world for having this place.

Their beer list is, frankly, insane. They have a respectable tap list of seasonal and rare (to see on tap, at least) beers, plus a gigantic binder of their bottled offerings. Their prices range from a little under $5 a pint to $80 a bottle, with a few aged beers they've set aside since their opening. They have a rotating 6oz pour flight of 3 brews for $10; when I went, it was a nice little Whitbier arrangement with a prototypical example of the style (Biere de Blanco by Craftsman Brewing), one with a nice smokey undertone (Heavenly Hef, again by Craftsman), and one with a sour cast (Festina Peche by the much-beloved Dogfish). If you're scared of beer, or just don't like it, they also have wine, cider, sorghum beer, and other "lighter" alcoholic offerings.

They also have a full menu of nibbles and entrees, each with a recommended beer style pairing. My favorites of the night were the cornmeal oysters with cucumber ketchup, the beef cheeks with fried polenta, and the bone marrow boats with onions, capers, POPCORN (yes, popcorn) and preserved lemon zest. The bone marrow was SO GOOD; the zest lightened it up just enough, and the popcorn added the perfect crunch. A spelt burger and diver's scallops with grilled peaches and corn/crab risotto were also consumed, and I was told they were good as well -- I wasn't wowed by the scallops, but they were tasty enough.

Oh, and we had carrot cake with a sloppy, sour cream icing in a mason jar for dessert. NOMS!!

I only wish I lived in SF so I could visit more often...
author: Lindsay L.

description:
I went here at least a half dozen times while living in San Francisco for a few months. Pretty great beer selection, but holy hell is this place overpriced (even for the caliber and rarity of the beers they serve). Inside is cramped and tiny, and unless you can get a table (which they'll only allow if you also order food, which is also terribly overpriced), this place can be downright uncomfortable when it's busy. Other than the cramped space though, the ambiance of the place is nice.

The beer selection really is pretty good and among the best I found in San Francisco, but as I said the prices are very high, even for the beers they serve. There are literally beers on the menu which go up to $16 per serving -- per 250 - 330 ml serving, not a 750 ml bomber. This is for a type of beer that might cost $8 in a bar in Atlanta or $10 to $12 in a bar in New York City. Nonetheless though, the quality of beers available is where this place shines. The variety is fairly good, but the tap list is sometimes a little too intensely focused on Belgian beers. There are amazing beers from other countries in the world, you know, and there's no point in having four Belgian saisons on tap among a menu of 20 beers, no matter how good each of those saisons is... Overall though, I would still give the beer selection about 4.5 out of 5 stars.

More on the beer prices -- I just looked at their current beer menu on-line and had my opinion confirmed. As of writing this, the Rodenbach Grand Cru is on tap... for $13.75 for a 9 ounce serving. This is a beer which I've had at Toronado in the Haight for $8 for the same size.

The food is good, but again overpriced. The sandwiches on the menu start at $13, and if you want to get a bacon cheeseburger, it's $15 (the bacon is $2 extra...). It's a very good burger, but seriously, guys... The non-sandwich entrees start around $20, with some specials occasionally going up to $30. The first time I came here I had a scallop dish which was, I think, $28. It was also good, and I know seafood is expensive, but it wasn't mind-blowing or that interesting and I felt the price was too much for the dish.

The staff are pretty friendly and helpful, and they're happy to give you tastes of beers. Most of them are also clearly interested themselves in the beers they serve, and they can help you pick a beer you like. Ultimately, I ended up coming here over and over again, despite all the complaints I have, and I feel a little bit dirty only giving it a 3/5 instead of at least a 4/5. It's a love/hate relationship...

What would bump my rating of this place up more? It could get one extra star by cutting the prices of everything by about 25%, and another extra star by doubling in size. I know these are both common problems with places in San Francisco, but this place takes them to an extreme.
author: Josh M.

description:
I figured I had been harsh with this place after my second review so I decided to give it another shot because of the awesome beer selection.

I have already had problems with the hipster door host and thought "I bet that they aren't busy for lunch! I'll go check it out." Excited about how my new plan would help me avoid the crowds and the douche door dude I decided to head over. Boy was I mistaken...

I showed up and hipster man is there with a deserted restaurant. When I tell him that my friend and I want to do drinks at a table he sneers and responds "Well, if youre going to be here only for drinks, you can sit at a table. I mean, if you order food, I guess we can sit you, but if you're not ordering much, then you should sit at the bar. However, since its not busy and if you order food, i guess its okay that you sit. But we may ask you to move the bar." 

Really Monk's Kettle? Really? The only way you'll ever see me here again is to throw a party when this place goes out of business. Ya'll are DK'd suckas!
author: Carlos V.

description:
It's been awhile yelp, but the food at Monk's was so good. It was enough to motivate me to reel one out. 

Was told by quite a few people how good the food is here so when a gf suggested we do dinner here one night I was elated. True to their word, the food was bomb diggity. I had the aged chicken, and my friends had their famous burger and tri-tip. The burger was alright, but the the tri-tip was so good. Paired with a lambic-like beer, I don't particularly care for sour beers, but the combo worked strangely enough. I went with their Potteloereke, a dark, fruity, belgium and it was YUMMAY *drool*. 

Our table wait time was 1.5hours and truth be told, it wasn't even that packed. We ended up getting seats by the bar before a table was ready so we just ate there. No difference. I believe they even have coat/purse hooks. Hooray!
author: Alesia T.

description:
BEER, BEER, AND MORE BEER! They also have a decent selection of ciders.

As far as food, neither me or my friend were impressed. I had the pulled chicken which was okay and he had a burger which was okay. 

It's pretty loud in there so not sure it's a good date spot.
author: Jeanette L.

description:
A very good gastropub. (While I'm not sure about the technical definition, I usually define "gastropub" to mean "a bar that has seriously good food"). I happened to find myself here during SF Beer Week, so there were some interesting beer selections on tap. Had the bavette steak for dinner, which was excellent.

Tips: come here to eat, not to drink. It's a small pub, it gets crowded, and most of the seating is reserved for folks who are ordering food (so be one of those folks!)
author: Joseph A.

description: Do yourself a favor and get the pretzels. Get 2. Get 10. Delicious. And try the sour beer options, too. Great atmosphere, excellent beer selection, and did I mention the pretzels?
author: Jennifer M.

description: Dropped in on a whim and had a nice time. Maybe we got lucky, but we were seated right away and experienced quick service. I had an intense craving for a burger, so that's what I got. It was more than I wanted to pay for a burger, but I can't deny that it was very tasty. I went for the bacon which had sort of a pastrami-like flavor and quality. Really good. Great craft beer selection as well. I would be interested in coming back and trying some of the other food.
author: Ray L.

description:
Was there with my husband and a friend for lunch the other day. They make the juiciest burger i've ever had in my life. Our friend ordered the ribs and it was D-E-L-I-C-I-O-U-S!  It was cooked to perfection (soooo tender). The waiter told us that they slow cook the ribs in dark beer for hours! AMAZING!

Will be back for great beer and amazing food :D
author: Vickie Z.

description: First time going to Monk's Kettle and boy it did not disappoint. We came on a saturday night and got seated right away. Good selection of beers (I got a Pliny because why not?). On to the best part. I don't know what type of chef wizardry they got going on in the kitchen but the burger was probably the best i've had. All the flavors just blended together so well. We had the mussels which were also good.
author: Mike P.

description:
How this place doesn't have 5 stars, I will never know.  They actually deserve way more than that.

Then again the few low ratings that I read are pointless.  Seriously?  Your bubbly water wasn't good so you give them 3 stars?  Last I checked, this place wasn't known for their Perrier selection.

Seriously folks, this place is PERFECT.

This place is very small.  Expect to wait.  But expect to be rewarded greatly for your patience.

I feel like I was greeted with open arms the second I walked in the door; by both the wait staff and the other customers.  The staff here knows their beer.  When they didn't have the beer that I ordered, they quickly recommended a stellar replacement.  I'm a self proclaimed beer snob, but I gladly allowed them to make my beer selections for me, something I have NEVER done at another restaurant.  I was very pleased every time.

I asked another customer what they recommended to eat and they said the burger.  The bartender agreed but recommended adding bacon.  Both wise decisions.  The burger was cooked perfectly - well cooked outside, slightly pint inside, moist all over.  The white cheddar and onion jam were very complimentary, neither overpowering.  And the bun that held it all together was the crowning achievement - perfectly toasted, not too dense.  I can actually say that I don't remember the fries.  It could have been that I was blinded by my love for the burger, or it could have been the beer goggles from all of the excellent suggestions.

Oh yeah, and the bartender even fought with me for my seat at the bar when somebody else tried whining "but I was going to sit there".  I don't normally go the same place twice when I travel, but this will be my exception.  I plan to come here every time I'm in town.
author: Nick G.

description: Great craft beer pub with a solid selection. About 10 pages worth. Also has got some good wine by the glass. Didn't stay for food but it looked and smelt great.
author: Livia M.

description:
My friend took me here on a Sunday around 7pm.  The place was packed but good that there were two seats at the bar.  

The waiter was very friendly and gave us a lot of recommendations.  I got the Grilled flatbread with tomato braised chick peas and ricotta salata.  It was vegetarian and it was so delicious.  Good flavors and the all ingredient were fresh.  The portion was pretty big too,  

Too bad I don't really like beer, otherwise I will give five stars!
author: Liza T.

description:
Places like this make me miss Chicago. There are some things that SF does extremely well, but in my opinion, Chicago has perfected the art of the gastropub. Plus, since they are EVERYWHERE you don't have to deal with waiting over an hour for a table for two on a Thursday night. I'm a patient person, but that's a bit preposterous.

Still, the food was good, the beer list fantastic, and the service was great, so I can't really fault the place for being popular. Maybe this should be a lesson for restauranteurs to open more places like this, and a lesson for me to go for dinner at like 3pm on a Wednesday instead.
author: Amanda S.

description:
I was so ready to love the food but sadly, it was just okay.  The atmosphere was great, the service was great, I just wanted the food to be great.  I had ordered the mushroom risotto which was well okay.  The burger my fiance ordered was also just okay.  

I don't live in SF anymore but every chance I go up, I love trying a new/different gastropub.  Really wished the place would have hit the spot.
author: Mabel L.

description: Great food and service with an amazing selection of beer! A little small inside, but offers outside seating. Check it out on a sunny Sunday afternoon - the best time to go!
author: Omar A.

description:
We stumbled upon this little haunt on search for a drink and some good eats.  Boy, did we come to the right place!  Equipped with a four star yelp rating and well deserved of every one of them, The Monk's Kettle is a tiny pub with an impressively large amount of beer offerings from all around the world.  The bartender was very knowledgeable.  I got Piney and Elders (an IPA) while my cousin got the Rasputin ... something reminiscent of Guinness, but a little more bitter.  We also had a burger, cooked medium, cooked to perfection.  It comes topped with caramelized onions and a little piece of heaven.  We were raving about that burger all the way home.

Note: the place is small but cozy.  The bar spans about the length of the place and only has several cozy tables along the side.  The max capacity of the Monk's Kettle is only about 50 people, so leave your personal bubble at home!
author: Samantha W.

description:
This review's only for the beer and I am thoroughly impressed with the extensive list spanning 6-7 pages =D  The bartender clearly knows her stuff as she helped my friend pick a brew based on her preferences with other drinks/liquors (almost no experience with good beer).  I ordered the Tilburg Dutch Brown (a Belgian Strong Dark Ale) and was pleased with the body and honey undertones on the finish.  

The place is very popular which shows with the liveliness of the crowd on a Friday night.  The people are generally in their mid 20s to early 30s and quite approachable too (one girl offered her food recommendations as I was perusing the menu).  Unfortunately, I was too full from a potluck beforehand to try any of the food, so I guess I'll have to save that for my next visit ;)
author: Eric F.

description:
an impressive selection of beers, and artful pairing suggestions on the menu makes it easy to enjoy a delicious time for all. The space is really tight here, but don't worry, everyone here is nice and has good taste in something, whether it be food, beer, people, clothes, or music. Accidental conversational eavesdropping is not hard here when the tables are inches apart, so just embrace it and add it to your dinner entertainment. 

Would have gone the burger+beer route if I weren't so full off other random Mission snacks and pastries, so I opted for the the scallops + corn risotto, which was unique, daring, and tasty. I say daring, because on the menu description, they said "risotto", so I was expecting some creamy rice bowl bathed in butter, but instead came a slightly different interpretation: two lightly fried rectangles of corn-infused risotto rice. Not bad. I also say daring, because the menu description said "bacon", but the only two pieces of bacon I saw on the plate were 2 tiny, cute bacon bits hidden under some garnishing greenery. I almost missed them. Seriously, these bacon bits are what you'd sprinkle on top of chili, poached eggs, or ice cream if you work at Humphrey Scolombe, so I think it was fair to say that the menu was slightly misleading in omitting the word "bits" following the word "bacon" hahah ;]
author: Tuwie N.

description:
There is a man that works behind the bar that is probably an agent of Satan because he literally knows every beer, what region it comes from, and what it tastes like on the menu. How such a man can fit so much information into his brain nobody knows. He could probably write a doctorate level dissertation of the pros & cons of ipas versus wheat beers, but what do I know, I'm just a poor old boy that lives in his mothers dungeon. Plus, I don't read good... sorry, goodly.

Pro tip: There is a beer here that is supposed to taste of marijuana which, if you ask me, you have to try because how often do you get a chance to try a beer like that. Since mother hates drugs, thats a double whammy contre mother, take that you wench! (Which is ironic because mother loves, oh so loves, her Vicodin but I digress...) Oddly, I don't remember how the beer tastes, funny that...

Anywho, good friggin luck getting a table at this place, it's packed tighter than mothers bridge tournament Thursday nights. Just stand at the bar with Satan minion and try not to look him in the eye...
author: Kevin M.

description:
Now I don't usually post reviews (as you can probably tell from my profile) but the lunch I had here today was so lackluster that I felt compelled to post a review. Not only was the service awful (unfriendly and slow), the food was totally unexciting. Although the new menu looked great, the execution fell way short of enticing me or my friends to ever go back. 

What happened to the cute friendly guys that used to work there? Not that I need cute guys to serve me in order to be happy, but these girls made no attempt at all to be nice or accommodating. They seemed to assume that they'd get their 20% no matter what so why try. Frankly, that's BS. The best thing we had was the beer and wine. If you must, I say go for drinks and french fries. The rest is overpriced and underwhelming.
author: Brianna M.

description:
Very, very gourmet and high quality food including mostly american new and gastropub.  Fair prices on food ($10-25 per meal) and beer ($6-$$$$) . Enormous selection of esoteric european bottled beers, and good selection of mostly local draft beers usually representing across the spectrum of styles.

Friendly and extremely knowledgeable service.

Wait time estimates are generally unreliable here (but they tend to overestimate the time expected which is much better than an underestimate - so I recommend not being scared off by the usual 1-1.5 hour wait estimate during peaks)

This place has saved my date from ruination so many times due to how late they're open and how nice and intimate the kettle usually is at late hours.
author: Blake A.

description:
BEERS GALORE! This place literally has any type of beer you can imagine and in all size and shapes!

The menu here is huge. It took me about 15 minutes to read through the whole beer menu. The drinks are a little on the pricey side but its definitely something new.

We ordered fries and a sampling platter with bread, jam, cheese, and nuts. It went really well with the beers we ordered. The bartenders are definitely knowledgeable about what beers to get. I would definitely come here if you enjoy drinking beer.
author: Stephen C.

description:
This place gets a solid 4 from me! 

The good:
- EXCELLENT selection of specialty beers - I had the Old Rasputin porter... hmm reminds me of good times at San Diego's Hamiltons tavern/bar.
- mouth-watering food - I highly recommend the grain burger! Really flavorful and soft patty... much to my surprise.
- excellent & friendly service

The bad:
- very pricy (moderate $$)
- lack of street parking
- limited space 

Best to go for: lunch/early afternoon to beat the crowd 

Next time I have friends in town, this is definitely the place I will put on my list to impress them!
author: Camie K.

description:
The bottle prices are up there but the food, service and tap list make up for it. Kathy provided a wealth of information and was happy to help with any questions about beer or scotch that we had. she made the visit very enjoyable. 

Great place. Check it out!
author: Colin K.

description: This is always my go-to place for a burger! Whaaat? A bar for a burger? The beer is great and yeah, the burgers are awesome!
author: Maria I.

description:
Wow, I'm surprised by the high star rating of this place.  I must be spoiled in Boston with our fair number of reasonably-priced Belgian beer bars.  Monk's Kettle calls itself a Belgian beer bar, but had only a limited selection of Belgians and boy were they expensive, as were the non-Belgians.  Food was mediocre.  Belgian "frites" were...not frites.

Bottom line: Way overpriced.   Only a limited selection of Belgians and other beers you can get pretty much anywhere.  You're much better off going to La Trappe (also in SF) for a more authentic, MUCH more affordable, Belgian bar experience .
author: Anna P.

description:
What can I say?  I bought the t shirt.  

They always have a dozen or so great beers on tap and a very lengthy menu.  Their staff is very knowledgeable and can guide you to the perfect beer by asking just a couple of questions

I guess there are two negatives.  The first is that this place gets crowded.  The second is that it is expensive.  However, I am willing to look past both of these issues, but that is why I give it four stars and not five. I have my special time to go, but that's my little secret.

FYI-  their burger rocks.
author: Dustin S.

description:
I sure wish I would have happened to have a desire to eat when I came here; apparently, their burger is outstanding, argued to be the best in the wonderful city of Saint Francis. Well, when I drink, I just want munchies i.e. fries and the like.

This low-key gastropub does not seat more than about 4 to a table, so you gotta go in packs here.... maybe inhabit the entire bar with your group? The draft menu is not huge, but they really know how to source.

My Abbey Special (8 oz) Belgian-Style from Dubbel Marin Brewing, Marin, CA was just the perfect Belgian, providing just a touch of bite while boasting the most smooth, rich flavor you could ask for.

Grubbage is outrageous at this fine establishment. The fries gave hints of an upgraded Mcdonald's style tuber strips. The "hop salt" made them perfectly dehydrating on my tongue, and the really good whole grain mustard packed a punch.

The rather small pretzel was iffy at $4.50, but aside from price, the American stsaple was truly the perfect texture. It was piping hot, crisp, and tender. There was provided to us an amazing cheese sauce, to boot.

The Monk's Kettle is truly a phenomenal gastropub. It honestly fulfills that title to the max. For sure.
author: Solomon W.

description:
I am also really confused about the negative feedback for this place. I went here for dinner last night, and even though there was a 45 minute wait on a Wednesday at 8:30 PM, I was totally cool with it. I went next door to Gestalt for a beer and the SUPER AWESOME door guy who checks ID's called me when the table was just about ready. 

Shared dinner with a buddy: we split the mushroom risotto and the tri-tip over Brussels sprouts. Both were amazing, and I give particularly high marks to the Brussels sprouts. 

The main reason we went here was to have some beer: as expected, the beer list did not disappoint! Our waiter was super helpful in helping us pick out new stuff to try.

Regarding the door guy, who has sadly really taken a beating on here: after chatting with him last night, I totally want him to be my friend.
author: Liz C.

description:
Bricks and beans.

Few menu items have ever looked so appealing. Three day ale bricked chicken with cranberry beans and pickled peppers. Immediately sold.

Also immediate? The disappointment it didn't live up to expectations.

Chicken was generous (enough for two meals) but missing any hint of ale flavor. Beans were few and far between. Peppers were sweet and awesome. Wanted more than two.

Third star earned by the great service and the ambiance of sitting by an open window on a warm day.

Maybe the ale chicken just needed to be ordered with ale.
author: Jason B.

description: Absolutely fabulous selection of specialty and draft beers from all over, local and international. If you're a big beer fan, have some time and money to spare, I highly suggest the trek out to the mission to visit this place. The staff is friendly, knowledgeable, and more than willing to explain to you how certain beer selections differentiate if you're having trouble making a decision on their expansive menu.
author: Lisa W.

description:
this is one of the best bars in the city for beer.

the only thing that i have a complaint about (although not "really" a complaint), is that the beer selection is too vast.  THATS EXACTLY WHY i dont like looking at their beer encyclopedia...i just ask one of their many brew/beer specialists to give me a recommendation and leave it at that...

food wise...excellent!  always seem to be changing up their menu...everything from appetizers to entree's...the food there is always solid...always great!

our late night dinner went like this...

-braised beef cheeks, polenta, horseradish  $13
-burger, onion jam, aioli, aged white cheddar, bacon w/ fries $16
-seared diver scallops, crispy corn and crab risotto, grilled peach, bacon $25

loved all 3 dishes although the diver scallops seems a bit too expensive for only 4 small scallops...granted, the crispy corn and crab risotto was in one word...redonkulous.  so freaking tasty...will be heading back there very soon.
author: Kyu L.

description:
They must be rich, because they sure don't want my money!

I have tried, and I have tried, and I have tried to go into the Monk's Kettle and have a nice evening out, but each time they have tried even harder to provide me with the worst dining experience imaginable.

They beat me every time.

The Monk's Kettle is so skilled at defeating a potential customer, that the last several times I tried eat there I couldn't even get a table.  I am not saying that I went there and, whoops!, it was crowded and full and I had to wait.  I am saying that I went in on numerous occasions, put my name on the list, and did not get called for seating for several hours.  A three hour wait?  Nuts to that!  They have about four tables.  Do you know what it is when you open a high profile restaurant in the heart of the hip and happening Mission district and then only have four small tables to seat people at? Criminally insane.

Read the other Yelp reviews. Notice a trend?  Worst. Service. Ever.  They employ the most rude people imaginable.  I have never encountered such hostility.  They seem annoyed at you from the second you walk in the door (although with only four tables, why shouldn't they be?).  On the rarest of blue moons where I have actually been seated, the service was rude, snotty, slow, and downright offensive.  They have no pateince for you and no smile. They look down their nose at you and rush you through your meal.  They were not happy to see you come in, and they are angry at you as you leave.

They also charge $10.00 for a beer.  Yes, they have a great beer list, and they know it.  They mark up prices because YOU don't know what they are supposed to be.  Sure, the beers are hard to find, but the mark up is ridiculous.  Dinner for two?  Expect to spend $200.00 and dine on spit and attitude.
author: Brian L.

description:
OK, it's years later, and Monk's Kettle has a new chef. 

I went again, and everything was quite pleasant. The ingredients are good quality, and the food is generally good. 

I find the kitchen to be a little inconsistent, but when they're on they make one of the better burgers in SF. 

Pricing is a bit high though: now $14 for said burger.
author: Jacob L.

description:
I love to come here for a beer - they have a great selection of both bottled and tap, and the bartenders are super nice and helpful in their recommendations! They even let you sample some of the beers before you make your decision! 

It's at a great location in the heart of Mission, which actually can work against it: it gets really busy! Sometimes, it's super hard to come in and find a seat, especially because it is a pretty small bar. Tables are reserved for people who come in for food; if you only want drinks, you sit at the bar. 

I really want to come back and try the food sometime!
author: Lena Y.

description:
I blame my dad for my distaste of beer.

When I was young, my dad would invite all his friends and  have these "piss off the neighbors coz we're wailing on the karaoke machine parties"  

And guess who served them their beer?  Me. 

I had tiny hands back then so naturally carrying a bottle of San Miguel beer in each hand was a huge task for me.  

Dad let me have a taste of that San Miguel.  Instantly, I made gagging noises and went:  "this is what grown-ups like?!"  Then my innocent eyes looked at my dad's beer bellied, flush faced friends puking outside our door on their way home after the last song of the night (which is always, always Frank Sinatra's "My Way") and I knew I will never like beer as much as I like soda.

I had a rude awakening since coming to Monk's Kettle.  WTH have I been missing all this time?

We walked in an hour before closing time (open til 2am Mon-Sun) Kathy was our server.  She has the kind of easy going attitude you would want at your table, whether it's your first time at the bar or a seasoned regular.  This girl is helpful and reads people easily.  I was pretty open on what beer to get (read:  I didn't know what I wanted)  so I asked for her opinion.   I mean, with 120 bottled beers and 24 on tap, you wouldn't know what to do with yourself either.

She recommended Monk's Cafe ($7.75) -- product of Belgium that's light bodied (don't be deceived by that burgundy color, it is not bitter like the dark ales) with contrasting flavors of sweet and tangy that seem to blend really well.  Kathy was right on about that choice coz I HELLA LOVED THIS BEER!  She suggested Ginger Beer ($4.75) for my bf since he was driving. 

But before I lose focus on this review, I actually came here for the food so I can officially cross off something on 7 x 7 Big Eats SF list:

#50 Giant Pretzel with Mustard at Monk's Kettle

It's giant alright.  The size of this pretzel is meant to be shared.  (unless you haven't eaten anything all day!)  Generously salted, lightly toasted exterior, and a dense-doughy interior, which is perfect for sopping up the cheese sauce, and the whole grain mustard sauce is overwhelmingly robust in flavor.  Bf ordered the hamburger and fries and those were just okay.

Yes, there were times when I'm sure I knew, that I bit off, more than I could chew.  But I had to do it my way -- 

just so I can wash it all down with that HELLA amazing beer.
author: Janice C.

description:
Oh good heavens, this place is out of this world. Incredible food, staggering selection of brews, friendly and knowledgable bartenders, chill Mission atmosphere, and the prerequisite ironic shitty beer inclusion called "Grampa's Suds."

And if you're like me, you'll be lucky enough to meet a bunch of surfers from Cornwall at the bar. It's a clean well-lighted place. 

Every brew you try will probably come in a different glass.

Go forth and savor at the Kettle!
author: Christina M.

description: A wee bit overrated! Went there on a Friday night for dinner, and I was less than impressed with the food and service. Got there pretty late, so getting a table wasn't a problem, but that was probably the best part about dinner. At a gastropub like Monk's you would expect to get phenomenal mussels, right? Well, they weren't phenomenal. They actually weren't even that good. The flavor of beer was overwhelming, and the flavor of the mussels non-existent. Also tried the mushroom risotto which was alright. I'd recommend Monk's if you wanted to hang out with a couple friends in a loud, dark, lively place, and drink some great beers, but if you're looking for a place to sit down and enjoy a good meal and some great beers, you may want to try some place else...
author: Karuna S.

description:
OVERALL RATING = 9 / 10

The EATs:
     Seared Scallops, Bacon-Wrapped Apple, Raisin Gastrique ($15) = 9

The DRAFTs:
     Jolly Pumpkin Luciernaga "Firefly" = 9
     Allagash Fluxus = 9

ATMOSPHERE = 8

SERVICE = 8

APPEAL = 9

The Luciernaga - A Belgian-style pale ale that's very Belgian-yeasty, if that makes sense. Crisp carbonation, balanced alcohol, and a nice sour-y sweetness (granny smith apple?) from the Belgian yeast. The guys at Jolly Pumpkin know how to make their Belgian beers. No wonder its so dang expensive. 

The Fluxus - The guys at Allagash know their stuff as well. This biere de garde is on the same level as Jolly Pumpkin's Oro de Calabaza and Russian River's Perdition. It's smooth, man.

The Scallops - This dish comes with two golf ball-sized scallops (like the ones from Costco) and one slice of apple, bacon-wrapped. That's three pieces going for $5 each. I had to chuckle when I saw it cause I felt seriously played for my money. Then I took a bite of the scallop. The outside was fried to a nice thin crisp and the inside was juicy and tender. The raisin gastrique (if you're awesome like me and don't know what gastrique means: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gastrique) served as a fantastic marinade for it. I took my time and savored the four bites it took to eat both scallops which proved to be the best I've ever had. The bacon-wrapped apple served as a great side pairing (gotta try making this sometime soon). The price didn't sting as much after enjoying the dish (still stung though). 

Cheers!
author: Royce Y.

description: Overhyped! Ordered the burger medium rare and it came out dry. It looked like they had the bacon cooking and drying out all day. I enjoyed the beer I had but I think this places needs to market itself more as a tap house than a gastropub since the food was not worth getting given how overpriced it was.
author: Mario G.

description:
Four stars for their beer selection but three stars for their food (at least my only experience there).  I think three is more of a true rating, IMO.

I was really anticipating having greats beers here and I did.  This place had 24 beers on tap.  I had so many to choose from (170-200 at any given time) that it almost made it hard to make a decision!  I opted to go with the Fillers London porter England.  5.4% ABV served in 20oz  glass for $8.25.  This is an English Porter.  The aroma was excellent. Very nice roasty flavor.  Tasted like a sweeter Guinness.  Almost chocolate-like very smooth and rich in flavor.

My waitress/bartender was very pleasant to deal with and recommended the Bourbon Barrel-aged Black Couldron.  This was an Imperial Stout served in an 8oz glass. 8.0% ABV for $5.25.  This beer is brewed in Idaho.

She said my choice (the porter) would overpower my meal but it certainly didn't.

I ordered a Turkey burger.  It was pan-seared with organic tomato, organic lettuce, and red onion.  It ran be $12.50.  The burger wasn't the greatest.  It certainly lacked flavor/seasoning, so I just added some pepper and ketchup.  I still wish it hadn't tasted plain.  The bread was a bit more on the stale side.

A few cool things about this place - You can see the kitchen from the end of the bar.  The decor is pretty cool.  It isn't super flashy nor is it boring by any stretch.  Even if you think it sucks, the beer selection here will take your mind off of things and help you concentrate on drinking.

The place had 5 booths that fit four people each and about 20 bar stools. It looked like it had adequate standing room for roughly 50 people, although, the max capacity is listed at 49.   

This is a smaller place that I thought before I visited, but they have tons of beers and some decent food selections.

For my second beer, I went with the St. Ambroise Oatmeal Stout from Montreal, Canada.  This was a bottled brew and had a 5% ABV.  It ran me $7 for the 12oz bottle.  Not a bad beer. I dig.

This beer had a flat, but not a bad, aftertaste. Was hoping of more of a sweeter flavor something like Sam Smith Oatmeal Stout, which I love.

The service was excellent. When I arrived, at roughly 3pm on a Tuesday, only 2 people were seated having some drinks. In about an hour, 5 others arrived.  

I sat at the bar and watched their 32" flat panel near the entrance.

I'd definitely go back here to have some awesome brews.   This is a must if you are a beer snob like me and are ever in San Francisco.
author: Brian B.

description:
My first official night as a resident of San Francisco. After spending the afternoon shopping for items to furnish my dorm room in the Mission I was famished! I yelped local restaurants in the area and this on came up first. I read the menu and decided I must go.
I am not much of a beer fan, so I can't comment on that... BUT I will comment on the ASTOUNDING food that I ate and the great cider drank. 
Heart set on the mushroom risotto after reading the reviews... I knew I had to start with something healthy... so why not Kale Salad? 
Not your every day Kale. It was delicious, although I do normally love Kale to start with. But there were so many textures and flavors in this salad my palette was satisfied... Along with my Barred Rock Cider which was mild and subtle in it's sweet/tartness. Very refreshing.
Yes, I did stick to my guns as intended and ordered the Mushroom Risotto... I was not disappointed at all. First bite... my tastebuds were exploding. Seriously amazing. I did not plan on eating my whole entree... was hoping to take some back to my little mini fridge and save for today... but that didn't happen. My belly was very happy after dinner was complete. 
The service was great and very attentive. The gal at the front was really friendly. I was just a party of one and sat by the front window. Amazed at how busy it was... but the place is relatively small and with such an extensive selection of beers as well as phenomenal food, why wouldn't it be busy. Lots of people left because the wait for a table was over 30mins. So, suggestions... come with the expectation of waiting... and have yourself a drink. 
My only reason for not giving Monk's Kettle 5 stars is that I'm on a limited budget being a student and all. I justified this dinner as a treat for finally moving west, knowing this dinner would be over my normal budget... I think yelp had it listed as $$ but it's definitely pricier than I can normally afford. I'll need to save this one for special occasions or just drinks- or splitting a meal when I meet someone worthy. ;-)
Enjoy!!
author: Alexandria S.

description:
I don't drink beer, but they have a nice cider selection and I'm now a big fan of the black cherry version they sell.  However, this place is all about the burger. Go there now and get one with bacon.  You can thank me later.  One of the best (if not the best) I've had in SF.  I honestly don't even know how it could be made any better.  Just delicious.  I'm drooling just thinking about it and I just ate dinner. Mmmmmmm.

One of the many reasons I'm learning to love the mission.
author: Ali B.

description:
Monk's Kettle is one of my favorite bars in the world. The impressive beer list is - well, impressive. The list rotates frequently, but the Weihenstephaner White Hoplosion (currently on the list) is definitely worth a taste. The staff is knowledgable and friendly. I had the fortitude to ask our waitress about a special brown beer on their list called "Bitch Creek." She put on a big smile and told me it was one of her favorites - and it soon became one of mine.

Their prices are a little high. I suppose that's expected considering how rare or special some of their beers are. Also, the menu has become a little less vegetarian friendly since my first trip there in March 2010. All told, however, I'm positive I'll be making a visit to the Monk's Kettle every time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Mike S.

description:
I want to wrap this place up and take it home with me so I can enjoy it every.single.day. Holy %%#%$# this is good. 

5 stars for beer selection. 

5 stars for the awesome bartender. Girl knew her beer, was friendly and was quick on those refills. 

5 stars for the food. Quick bites of the pretzel and fries with a side of cheese sauce. NOM. 

5 stars for the atmosphere. LOVED. 

This place fills up quick, get in and get a spot, you won't be disappointed.
author: LeeAnn N.

description:
Had dinner here the other night. No reservations so beware--- 
millions of beers available but majority appeared to be bottled not draft.
I loved that each beer had its own special cup.
We started with oysters which were very tasty. We also had to try the pretzel since everyone was raving about it-- agree a must get!
We also split the scallops and crab polenta which was very flavorful. It is a small portion especially for the cost and the polenta looks like...hashbrowns, it was good but we were expecting a bit more. Overall great, cozy place for beers and apps; I dont know if I would have dinner there again
author: Nicole S.

description: Okay, I had to bump it up to 5 stars because I had the pretzel the other day. OMG!! Ask for extra cheese sauce. You won't regret it!
author: Lulu B.

description:
Terrible, awful, nasty service.  I have seldom been treated so rudely in my life, and certainly not when arriving with friends to eat what ended up being a several hundred dollar meal.

Overpriced and pretentious as heck.  They look down their noses at you and make you feel two inches tall.  What is their problem?  So glad you know so much about beer! Aren't you special?  Ugh.

This is not based upon one experience, but several.  I give up.  Yes, they have hard to find beers (but so does PiBar, just a few blocks down) and to food is...meh...it's okay.

Egad is this place expensive and rude.
author: C H.

description:
As always, the burger and fries is delicious especially with the house spicy brown mustard. I got bacon with the burger this time and it was also very good. We also tried the roasted mushroom risotto with aged white cheddar which was delicious and rich (in a good way, but perfect to share). 

I really do love this place and think their burger is one my favorites in San Francisco.
author: Julie T.

description:
Who doesn't like a beer list so long that you're convinced the server accidentally handed you a 19th century Russian novel?   Don't worry though.  If you don't know what to order, just ask for a taste.  They'll give you a sip in a tiny beer stein (so adorable).  For those of you with more sophisticated palates and know what you like, they have everything from sour beer to limited release beers from Evil Twin.

The food is amazing too.  Be warned, however, you can drop some serious money at this place without evening realizing it.  

My recommendations:
-Seared scallop, bacon wrapped apple, raisin gastrique - The saltiness of the bacon and scallops is balanced perfectly with the sweet acid in the apple and raisins.

- Braised beef cheeks, polenta, horseradish - The perfect, hearty dish for a cold SF night.  Perfectly cooked polenta with melt in your mouth shredded beef cheeks, and a little horseradish for a nice kick.

- Seared veal sweetbreads, pickled apple slaw, parsnip -  Your basic fried bar food taken to a higher, almost ungodly, level.

- Apple Cobbler, caramel, sweet cream - Another dish that is perfect for a cold rainy night in SF.  A great way to end the evening.

What to pass on:
-Bone Marrow Brûlée - I love bone marrow like a hormonal woman loves chocolate, but this dish was a miss for me.  The brûlée, which consisted of liquid fat and butter, was served at room temperature with a crispy bread that did nothing to soak up the concoction.  Also, the brûlée was too thin to be spread onto the bread and just ended up creating a mess.



BONUS TIP:  Go early and don't bother bringing a big group here.  This place is perfect for a date or catching up with an old friend (preferably the kind that eats meat ... the vegetarian options are limited).
author: Lara O.

description:
I'm really sorry to post this but it had to be done. 

I was celebrating a friend's birthday. We went to Monk's Kettle, a specialty pub known for a very wide selection of rare and fine Abbey and of Trappist Belgian beers.  As this friend of mine is very interested in the brewing process and the unique results, needless to say, he was excited to be there. We ordered two $17.00 dollar "Rocheforte" beers as well as two other steeply priced beers and a side of fries.  

Upon looking at the menu we discovered that we might as well be dining, since the price of the libations equaled that of the dinner options. It made no difference- it was a birthday and we were happy to be there. The atmosphere was right, the place was packed but with a more mature crowd and the environs clean, elegant and attractive.
It wasn't until we were approached by a server who told us that since we were not consuming food we would have to hurry up our taste-testing and make the table available. That is when the night took a turn for the negative. This was upsetting since we were spending more than those eating dinner at the tables adjacent to us.  

In my opinion, there is no way this situation could have been better handled. The server should never have approached paying customers with such a rude, arbitrary demand and if the establishment intends to reserve tables for dining only, then signs must be posted and the price of the beers must be lowered. Paying $17.00 for one glass of beer and then being shooed out of my table because I didn't purchase a $9.00 apple pie is utterly absurd and a little infuriating. Did I mention that my small group and I had to wait for a table for one hour?

If this get's filtered, that's really too bad
author: Toby V.

description:
Went here for dinner and beer with friends on a weeknight. It wasn't too busy and we were seated quickly. The staff here are both friendly and helpful/informative (from the waitstaff to the doorman).

For food we had their current arugula salad (nice touch with the grapefruit and pickled onions), the burger (a reasonable size instead of mammoth) and a strawberry shortbread for dessert (not too sweet, well made whipped cream and shortbread).

The beer selection was quite good albeit a bit pricier than La Trappe (or it seemed so anyway).
author: Solomon B.

description: This place gets super pack during lunch/dinner. I have to say that the burgers were made by a perfectionistic from the meat,aged cheese, the bun and of course the French fries. I have to say as a native Texan, this place has to be one of the best burgers i have ever tasted.
author: Hoang N.

description:
I'm here to talk about the mussels. which is a small plate. and not like a small (tiny) plate from most $$ joints. a small plate that could be a dinner if you weren't that hungry. 

mussels tasty and fresh, and the beer-y buttery delicious sauce they had over them. a-ma-zing. 

get em. 

Also had an allagash white (amongst a wide selection of beers,),   the flatbread and some chicken sandwich. the rest of the food was good enough, but nothing to write home about. 

come in twos. sit at the bar.
author: Jessica P.

description:
Food and beer pairings? In my pursuit to learn more about beer, I was intrigued by this restaurant of course! Since I was in the hood, I decided to try my luck at getting into Monk's Kettle on a Friday night. Last time they said the wait would be 2 hours. This time they said 1 hour. We got in 20 minutes later. Thanks for calling and texting! There's no room inside to wait so we found shelter at the bookstore across the street.

What we ordered

1) Mussels, Belgian ale, garlic, basil, toasted acme levain
- The mussels were so good. The broth was rich and divine. Yummy.

2) Bone marrow canoe, toast, parsley, lemon
- I don't have bone marrow often. It was on the oily side and reminded me of pate. Fun presentation but I'd skip it next time.

3) Malt crusted tri-tip, braised sweet potato, beurre noir
- The meat was very succulent. Salty and rich. I would have liked a neutral starch to go with this. Or more beer! Still delicious though. Just needed something to balance it out.

My drink: I had the Allagash Belgian-Style Witbier as was recommended to go with the mussels. I do like Belgium wheat beers/white ales which are light and pleasant. I wish I could have tried more of their beers but alas I had to drive.

Verdict: Definitely would go again but only if I could have more beer. :)
author: Mary W.

description:
Love Monks Kettle! They have amazing specialty beers on tap, that you can taste if you have never tried them before. 

I didn't order food here but the menu looked awesome. 

I will definitely be coming back for apps or dinner with a yummy beer.
author: Talia M.

description:
Monk's Kettle is a great place to grab a beer after everything is all said and done. If you love and appreciate the different selection of beer, this is the place to be. 

Don't recall his name but he gave extremely great service and had an awesome beard! He talked us through which beer we should try and everything was great. 

Our friend bought a large bottle of sour beer. They were half way through and accidently spilled the rest.. party foul.. But the awesome bearded server cleaned it up right away and kind enough to give a different glass of sour beer. What an awesome service!

Lastly, they have a chalk board that people can draw and play hang man! Definitely coming back here again!
author: Hideo M.

description: The food was decent - the staff was unwelcoming and inflexible. Traveled from outside San Francisco to meet a colleague and made the mistake of arriving early. Was seated by one server but then was told I shouldn't have been seated since my party wasn't complete. Was joined by an additional party member to make a total of three people and was glared at consistently to leave once our dinner dishes had been removed. The beer selection was good, but I was unable to unwind due to the constant badgering by the staff- I can get a good beer at some other bar. Too bad. I had such high hopes.
author: Carrie B.

description:
5 pages of beers?? WOW.
Mac and Cheese?? WOW. http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/tMZJhgBnM7MQ1SAYEgmaQQ/l
Chicken Pot Pie?? WOW. http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/KUcEZr79LsioYk9EHje3lQ/l

I was going to give this place 4 stars for two reasons: 
1) The bacon in my mac and cheese was SUPER SUPER salty.
2) My mac and cheese came out lukewarm -- wasn't pipping hot.

But I'm giving Monk's Kettle 5 stars because:
1) The server noticed my pile of bacon left over in my cast iron skillet which once housed my mac and cheese and asked if I didn't like the bacon. I told her that it was good and the bacon gave the mac and cheese a nice smokey flavor but it was way too salty. Upon receiving our bill, she took off the charge for bacon. Two thumbs up.
2) I was somewhat peeved that the mac and cheese came out rather lukewarm but I thought about how badly my tongue would be burned had it been pippin' hot. I scarf down delicious mac and cheese. If my mac and cheese had portions of it that was slightly cold, I would have thrown a fit. 

So all this talk about Monk's Kettle's mac and cheese definitely puts it up there. It's great competition with Luna Park's mac and cheese as well as some of my other favorites. The BF ordered their Chicken Pot Pie and was well pleased with it. He also stated that he didn't have to fish around for chicken bits b/c there were tons in there! Yay :))

I'm definitely coming back and upon my return, I'm going to get a basket of fries with three dipping sauces (ketchup, and 2 aiolis) AND I'm going to order their mac and cheese again. This time, without bacon. It is absolute heaven since there is a breaded crust and every bite is cheesey. 

Peep the cheesey-ness: http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/QSRFRaU4pLZ_UWG6fRL7Zg/l

I'm in love with Monk's Kettle's Mac and Cheese and you will be too. YUM-O!!
author: Heidi C.

description: Belgian beer, a buddy and a chalkboard is all you'll need to occupy the next few hours. Doesn't hurt that the Roxie Theatre is right next door!
author: Garett T.

description:
I'm a definite fan of gastropubs and for those of you who like a good beer with some tasty food, this is a great place to try out! First off, the restaurant is located in an incredibly upbeat and lively part of the Mission District, which definitely adds to the lively vibe this place gives off in the evening. However, after arriving with three other friends on a Friday night around 7 PM, we were told that our wait would be THREE hours long. The long wait was by far the biggest turn off for me, but I'm glad we decided to stick it out and try it out. To justify our decision to stay, the fact that there are plenty of bars in the area made the wait a little more bearable.

If I only had to rank the beer selection, I'd definitely give this place five stars. The selection is by far one of the most impressive i've seen thus far in my relatively short time as a 21 y/o! There's an entire binder with a index and terms glossary in the back of the binder that details each and every type of beer that this place has to offer. Without a doubt, I'll bet you can find something you'll like. It took us quite some time to just go through this menu.

As for the food, I wasn't overwhelmingly impressed, but my burger was tasty and the waitress' beer suggestion went well with my order. However, due to the long waits and small capacity of the restaurant, I don't think that the food was worth the wait. All in all, I was a bit disappointed with my overall experience here, but am willing to give it another try. Especially because of how many beer options there are. Note to self: avoid weekends and late dinner hours.
author: Cheston W.

description:
I used to really love Monk's Kettle, almost obsessively.  Obviously their beer assortment is impressive, and the food used to be too, but sadly not anymore.  

There is a new chef in and since then I have been disappointed with each and every dish I've had there.  Literally, every single dish, I can honestly say I can cook better than that.  I really can't understand why it's so bad, and that hard to say because I really want this place to succeed.  

The one word that came to mind for the food was DRY: the veggie burger had the texture of sawdust and the bun had next to zero sauce/dressing.  I had to ask for ketchup, aioli and pickles just to give in some sort of moisture (no tomatoes because they were used for a starter dish and they didn't have enough for me).  The cassoulet was beyond dry too, and this is a dish that is supposed to be oozing with moisture.  The beans and vegetables in it seemed raw uncooked, and without flavor.  Huge disappointment.  And the chicken pollard was actually a pathetic interpretation of a chicken sandwich -- how is that not mentioned on the menu!?  The menu needs to be more thoroughly explained, and the food need to be MUCH better.  Sorry to say it guys, but I think this place has had it's time.
author: Britt X.

description: Pretty chill spot to meet a friend and grab a drink. Def young hipster vibe inside too, but I like that. Only problem I have is the limited amount of seating.
author: Sonlay V.

description:
OMG I am in love with the beer selection at this place.  There are so many to choose from.  It seems like you could make a career in trying all the different types of beer that they offer.

Then there is the food.  WOW!  I was really impressed with the level of care that they took in pairing the different foods on the plate to make a delicious meal.  They even offer different beers that will pare will with the meal.  This is a must try place
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Monk's Kettle embodies the term gastro-pub.

Atmosphere is comfortable, even homey. Service was friendly, knowledgeable. The mussels and fries are spot on, and the rest of the menu is balanced and appealing.

Beer selection, the clear focus of the place, is overwhelming -  a great thing for the initiated. For the uninitiated, the restaurant's servers and menus provide a helpful approach to pairing beers with the food (not condescending).
author: Jeffrey P.

description: Beer selection, food and wait staff was good. What rubbed me  the wrong way last night was  some guy with a beard carrying boxes that bumped me not once but twice with out excusing himself or asking me to allow him to pass. Early in the evening not half empty. He appeared to be a manager. I mean really? Someone didn't learn manners or what hospitality means in the restaurant business. There is a lot of competition in this town and some know how make you feel comfortable and welcome. To bad MKs leadship is short on this order.
author: Tim P.

description: Pretty small and packed - we were in the way regardless of where we stood until a few stools opened. Regardless, staff (everyone that we encountered) was really friendly and knowledgeable on a somewhat overwhelming menu of beers. We ordered some snacks as well which were a perfect accompaniment. Looking forward to coming back soon!
author: damon k.

description:
My mom, brother and I went here for lunch this past weekend following my brother's graduation from USF (yay!). Of all the restaurants in the city, this was his first pick for his post-grad meal (he had been there before, my mom and I had not). 

We LOVED it. We started with the pretzel rolls, which come with delicious whole grain mustard and an amazing cheese sauce, for dipping. They were the perfect compliment to each other and we couldn't decide which one we liked better! My mom and brother both got burgers (ordered to different done-ness, and they both came as requested), and I got the mushroom and Fiscalini cheddar risotto, which was perfectly prepared and very tasty. The fries (which came with the burgers) are topped with hop salt...what?! Best idea ever. At our waiters suggestion, we tried them with the leftover dipping sauces from the pretzels...another great idea. 

The beer list deserves its own mention. I wish I lived up there so I could visit often (daily?)  and try a different beer every time. I got the London Porter Nitro, which was perfectly poured and so delicious. There were so many more that I wanted to try. 

Perfect atmosphere, insane beer list, and delicious food - I can't wait to go back!
author: Laura Z.

description:
I loved this place, and I hate beer. I didn't publicize this when I was inside, of course. That would be BLASPHEMY!

Staff and other customers were great. Very knowledgable and just friendly. I really wouldn't consider it overly hipster for being a gastropub. Everyone I talked to was really down to earth and helpful with items to order, how to draw a unicorn, etc. Yeah, they have a blackboard in the back. Once I discovered that it was over.

Yeah, maybe a little more $$$, but if you like your beer, you'll be all over their menu. It's huge and it's in a cover that makes it look like a dictionary. I pretended to read it for a while until I gave it to someone who was actually planning on drinking beer. 

I was so comfortable, I called someone who worked there Dad. That may be a little too comfortable, but hey, when in Rome?
author: Christine T.

description: This is a great place to sit back with a beer and chat with friends or people watch. Their beer menu is one of the biggest I've seen. They only offer one type of cider but it was very good. The calamari sandwich was amazing, and the pretzel with cheese was also tasty. Im a sucker for good sauces and they didn't disappoint. I've heard it's hard to get in at night, but the four of us met up there around 12pm and got an outside table with no problem.
author: Marie L.

description:
Closed for renovations till Sept 19th! Sadface. however, their sister restaurant is open, and just a few blocks away. Abbot's Kitchen is on Valencia btw 18/19th, and two doors down from Dandelion chocolate. If you like chocolate, try the Old Chub, it tasted like Good Life Choices.

Will be happy to visit Monk's Kettle when it's back open!
author: Casey G.

description:
The maltyiest IPA I have ever had! So much great beer in this place.  On top on that the best hipster toast in the known universe! 

Make sure to leave your mark on the old school cool chalk board.
author: Buck C.

description:
Came here on a Sunday afternoon around 3pm... no door guy, so I can't comment on that (other yelp reviews mention a mean door guy) nor can I comment on not getting a table (since we walked right in and got a table with no wait).

So from my perspective, this place was AWESOME.  The food was delicious, and the beer selection outstanding. The staff was super friendly and laid back. A great bar to spend a lazy Sunday afternoon.

Will definitely be back!
author: Michelle L.

description: Try the cassis flavored beer. Its interesting , in a good way. For my entree I had the spare ribs. i thought it was going to be a lot bigger but the pieces are a litle small. The flavor is really good however. If you have a big appetite you may be disappointment. I was still a little hungry after but I filled up with beer and coffee.
author: Kenson K.

description:
Monk's Kettle has it all. Not only an amazing list on tap, but also in bottles. They hand you a clip board with pages on pages of beers with descriptions not only on beer, but on each style as well.

The place is small, but if you get a seat don't leave. There is just too much to try.

Also monthly??? beer dinners. I wish I lived closer. My now go to spot for beer in SF.

Just to top it of the service was so friendly and knew their beer. All the recommendations were spot on.
author: Erin S.

description:
Poor customer service.....

We didn't even get to go in and already we're turned off by this place.  We chose the Monk's Kettle for the decent reviews and the guys' love for their beer. 

Sure, it's a busy friday night and we didn't have reservations for our party of 6.  But instead of the host saying something like he apologizes for not having any tables available he interrupts us and rudely says, "nope, your party is too big and as you can see we are all booked for the next 2 or 3 hours".    2 or 3 hours?  Which one is it buddy?  So we ask if we can just split our party then, 3 and 3.  He says, "nope can't do it, doesn't work that way".   What the hell does that mean?  It doesn't work that way?  How hard is it to set up two tables for a party of 3 each?  He then says that they are all booked for the rest of the night.  Um, didn't you just say you were booked for the next 2 or 3 hours?   What a douche.
author: Bernadette M.

description:
This place is a gem.  I wanted to give them four stars, but they get five for their outstanding customer service.  Here's why:

I arrived for dinner with a friend on a Friday and the place was unsurprisingly packed.  The guy at the door who was managing the waiting list was calm and well-mannered and helped me find a seat at the bar while I waited for my friend.  He kept us posted as to when the next table would be ready, and also offered us the option of eating at the bar but we decided to wait.  In the meantime, the bartender helped me select a beer and based on my vague descriptions of what I liked, let me sample a few and picked a really nice one for me.  Water was given and replaced without question.  

When we got to our table about an hour later, the kitchen was handing out free (and delicious) fries and pretzel knots because orders were backed up and meals were coming out slower than usual.  The service was warm, friendly and accommodating and checked in on us frequently without being obtrusive. 

Our food arrived about a half-hour later (really not that delayed) and it was delicious!

We had:
1) Malt-crusted tri-tip with brussell sprout hash ($24)
2) Spent grain and chickpea burger with salad ($13)

Both were plated beautifully and delicious.  I'm mad for home-made veggie burgers, and this unctuous, flavourful patty was one of the better ones I've had in the city.  I really liked the onion jam it came with and the salad, rather than being an afterthought, was a smaller portion of their fresh and delicious local greens, toasted hazelnut and fromage blanc salad.  The tri-tip was tender, nice and red in the middle and a good portion after the fries and beer we had consumed.  

This place had a good reputation, and deservedly so.  Great bistro food, amazing beer selection and excellent service makes it worth a visit and worth the wait.
author: Sabrina B.

description:
Monk's Kettle, WHY YOU NO HAVE MAC N CHEESE ANYMORE? Unless I'm mistaken, by all means correct me. But seriously, I'd come here for the mac n cheese alone and the garlic aioli their fries come with is a nice bonus. The mac n cheese was of the beer-battered bread crumb crust variety and crazy cheesy delicious goodness. And now it's off the menu. WOE. 

But you can still get their fries and peruse their crazy selection of beers. If you're missing the taste of that one beer you had in a pub in Manchester, while on a study abroad pub crawl, this is the place to find it. Or try 50 other beers just like it. They'll let you taste test a beer if you're unsure of ordering and they serve it in a little tiny beer stein, mimicking a shot glass.  I need to make it a point of trying one of their lambic beers.  

Last time I was here, my friends and I waited over an hour and a half to wait for a table, which I feel like is the norm unless you want to sit at the bar, which is not feasible with large groups of people. This place is tiny and fills up quick and they don't take reservations. Followed by the aforementioned beer, my friends and I had actually written the guy at the door with the clipboard a note and made his co-worker give it to him. He handled the note with aplomb and now I can never show my face there again. Especially since they don't have the mac n cheese anymore. MK gets an extra star for dealing with me and my friend's drunken shenanigans.
author: Dena R.

description:
Fuck you, fuck your smart ass door guy, fuck your limited non-alcoholic beer selection (they are not all created equal!).
 
Now that I got THAT out of my system--no wait, there's more. What the fuck is up with your bitch-ass door guy for refusing to seat people at a table for drinks and desserts? "are you having dinner?" "just drinks and dessert."
