"oh I'm sorry, the tables are reserved for dinner." drinks and dessert vs drinks and dinner...let's think...if desserts are the same prices as entrees or starters then who cares WHAT I order? Really. Maybe the average dinner tab is more? But what if your entire table each only orders a salad...presumably you're not going to micro manage THEIR order? Can salad not constitute dinner? Well then why can't dessert? As the main Mission slinger of bacon mac'n'cheese, the nutrient-packed iceberg blue cheese wedge with bacon, and lamb cheeseburgers, with bacon, it obviously isn't my health you're lookin' out for. 

If your entire staff didn't comprise assholes, I'd have kicked down more stars...the food is good. It is even great, on occasion. 
That said, nowadays when my crew and I approach the front door...if we see said door guy (who other reviewers, several times over, have described)--we all start cursing and, without hesitation, head to Luna Park--albeit less delicious, but you can order whatever the fuck you want...at the comfort of a table, even.
author: Michelle C.

description:
I just love this place!

I've been here several times and it's just as fantastic as the time before. The beer selection is superb and the food is wonderful. I don't know how many people would pay $4 for pickles, but from here... for me... All. The. Time.

Every entree I've tried has been delicious. I've had the brick chicken, burger, tri-tip, seared scallops, pork belly... Yes, I've been here quite often. And everything I've had was just so tasty! 

It's a small but cozy establishment. The staff are very polite and friendly. 

Come for the beers, stay for the food, leave with a smile. 

I'll be back soon for sure.
author: Shauna Y.

description:
Pretty cool pub. Slightly hipster scene, excellent beer selection, friendly staff both at the door and at the bar. You put your name in for a table, at least on weekends which at least make things fair. Can get crowded, but once you get in it's a pretty chill place. 

Didn't try the food, so can't comment there. 

Bottom line: Will return to try food and check out the beer selection, would recommend to a friend...
author: Travis S.

description:
Great gastorpub!  We stopped in while waiting for sando's from a local joint and got an opportunity to enjoy some beer from their really good selection and to be floored by the pretzels.  

I like to believe that the Germans invented beer and pretzels, putting them on par with the ancient Egyptians, Greeks and Chinese for contributions to the development of society.  If my crazy notion is true then The Monk's Kettle took the next step and have delivered near perfection.  The warm salty pretzel bun that will be placed before you is something of legend, especially paired with a tasty brew.  I could easily devourer a half dozen of these baby's a day!

Sitting at the bar feasting on pretzels and beer also gave me a change to check out some of Monk's other offerings which all appeared to be very nicely prepared and sparked plenty of interest for me to come back and check out more of the menu, with a pretzel leading the charge of course!  I can see five stars in the near future with some more sampling
author: Eric L.

description:
* The meals were pretty good, but for the price I expect better. We had the salmon and the short rib
* The pretzel appetizer is great, but be warned, it's tiny
* The beer selection is the best thing about this place
* The environment in front of the restaurant is rather gross. It looks like the Armageddon just passed through and no one is willing to clean it up

Summary: I'll return for a beer...maybe an appetizer...but not for dinner
author: Captain B.

description:
Stay away from the robiola! It's a mixture of cow, sheep, and goat cheese. My friend stated it best, "it tastes like zoo in my mouth." Really. The appalling scent of animal that hits you when you enter a zoo, that's exactly what it tastes like.

Otherwise, the pretzels are good and the beer list is extensive and expensive.
author: Sophia K.

description: I am writing a review based on the service here. On a Sunday afternoon we wanted to get a quick beer. The bar was busy so that was not an option. Three empty tables with no one else waiting and they would not seat us unless we spent more money on lunch. Pretentious staff so go and get a beer somewhere else.  Plenty of places in the Mission.
author: G A.

description: If your a beer person then this will cover your needs. Good food. Atmosphere and beer is the draw!
author: Ronnie M.

description:
So my girlfriend and I rolled in here on a Friday at a HappyHour-esque kind of time and snagged two seats at the bar pretty quickly.  We each ordered a beer from the gigantic beer list with a little direction from a knowledgeable bartender and waited for 2 friends that we were meeting there.

The tables were all filled and they had a bit of a waiting list going.  The bar had every seat taken and one of two people standing to get a drink.  When my friends got there the host at the front wouldn't let them in (2 tiny women), but then right afterwards let 3 large guys in to the bar area, who had no reservations, and proceeded to stand behind the people at the bar and block the entire aisle.  After 5 minutes or so, my girlfriend came over to grab them, he let them by and they easily stood at the end of the bar with us without blocking anyone.  However, at that point we were all pretty put off by the host, so we quickly downed the beers we had and headed out to somewhere friendlier.

I hate to call one person out so obviously, but until the host went on a power trip we were having a pretty good time here.  Some people are built for customer service and some people aren't.  So Mr. 5ft tall with a ridiculous mustache working the door...You might want to take a page from any of your bartenders on how to talk to people, or think about a different profession.  There's a nice way of telling people what the situation is, and then there's the way you were handling it.  Hopefully he was just having a bad day, but some of the more recent reviews might suggest otherwise.

So anyways...we pounded our beers and bolted out of there and headed for Blackbird.
author: John S.

description: Great beer, great Belgian pale ales (and I dont even like beer). I've had some amazing conversations with friends at this place. I wish they had more space so that the wait times are smaller.
author: Balu V.

description:
All right, so you hear about the pretzels at The Monnk's Kettle.  And you hear about all the different glasses for different beers- which, in my twenty-odd years of drinking beer I have not once been able to appreciate the subtle differences in beer glasses.  But that's beside the point: they have a ton of different beers and serve them in the "appropriate" glassware, so you can bring your beer-snob buddies to tMK and be cool.

But the winner for me was the service and the cheeseburger.  Oh my lord, the cheeseburger was a wonderful surprise.  In fact, the minute I walked in I saw a couple of burgers going to tables and knew that this was no ordinary bar burger.  This was going to be special...and my god, it was.  Perfect bun-to-meat ratio, ingredients that complimented rather than competed with the sandwich...it's just such an enormous shame that the fries seem like an afterthought.  Don't get me wrong; the fries are good.  Just not quite worthy of sharing the plate with that cheeseburger.  Please note: if you are a "slightly pink in the middle" burger eater, order it MEDIUM.  I was glad I erred on the side of caution because my MEDIUM burger was cooked a perfect MEDIUM RARE.  What is it with "gourmet burger" joints downshifting the wellness on burgers?  Why does MEDIUM mean MEDIUM RARE in the world of restaurant burgers.  Yo no se.

The bartending staff is exceedingly polite, cheerful, and eager to please.  Seriously, the bartender/waitperson who helped us should be in the running for "Server of the Year for the Entire Universe".  She was very, very helpful and accommodating to our fairly lubricated group that may or may not have been a little...er...well, let's just say that we all could have lived without more beer.

So go to tMK.  It's a lot of fun, full of delicious beer, and from what I tried on the menu I can say I was very pleased.
author: Ben G.

description:
The pretzels!  That's pretty much all you need to know.

One star knocked off just because it was so crowded, we couldn't get our group of 8 to fit in there, and had to get our pretzels to go and eat them outside.
author: Jenna L.

description: Delicious and intriguing food with a wide variety of beer both on tap and in the bottle. Loved the atmosphere and the service was stunning. Perhaps a bit cramped but a great place to grab a bite in the Mission.
author: Benjamin C.

description: The service was average to annoying, the food was OK but this place gets 5 stars for the only thing you should really be going here for...the beer!  They have a ridiculous amount of bottled beer here.  Good selection of draft too but the bottled selection is unbelievable.  I've been getting into craft beers for a few years now but I was humbled by their menu.  WTF!! Beer lovers paradise.  You can get carried away too because they have beers from 8 to 60 dollars a bottle.  Anyways it's usually strong stuff...peep the alcohol content you only need to drink 2-3.  I'll be back you belly busting pieces of manuch! I mean that in the nicest way!
author: Ramon L.

description:
New menu is a fail. My friends  and i used to go for the mac and cheese, burgers, pretzel, and beer.  the pretzel is now small lame and expensive( dude, flour is cheap).  The burger is one homogenous soggy texture with no options. The mac n cheese is gone. I guess they still have beer, but I will never leave work early on a friday to beat the crowd to get my fatty treats again. 

Somebody made some bad choices that is driving their core customer away. goodbye!
author: Ryen A.

description:
The hype is warranted; this place is fantastic. I could go on and on about what makes this place so great but others have already put that out there so I'll keep it simple:

-Awesome lineup of rare beers from some incredible breweries
-Really accommodating, friendly service that is equipped to make great recommendations based on your taste preferences
-Creative menu that's executed very well (we had the burger, the veggie burger, roasted nuts, and pretzel--all were delicious

Is it a bit pricey? Yes. Is it worth every penny? Yes.

If you haven't been, you should get here.
author: Steve B.

description: Wow. I liked SF for so long, including when I lived in San Rafael, but now I LOVE it. A very crowded, long line, tightly packed place, but somehow the ambiance works, very Cotswolds pubby, and a little politeness and patience goes a long way with the door staff, who got us in and seated in just a beer's time, which was fine since the beer list (presented bound in old encyclopedea covers) is BEAUTIFUL. Had several amazing brews new to me (which is a big deal to me, as I have had over 1,500 different beers reviewed so far), and the food was ding-dong...who is it?...AWE-SOME!
author: Dave H.

description:
We were very disappointed with the new menu, which is decidedly more pretentious than before.

The Monk's Kettle used to be the place in our neighborhood to get well-prepared, wholesome, unpretentious food.  We should have known those days were over when we asked about the new menu/chef, and the waiter told (warned?) us that they were trying to compete with other restaurants in the area.  Translation: the simple, well-made chicken sandwich with bacon has been replaced by "chicken paillard with bacon jam".  The tuna steak sandwich with fries (which was pretty much perfect as it was) has been replaced by "tuna tomba with cauliflower puree and turnips".  Which was not bad, to tell the truth, but at $23, calling this a "large plate" is quite a stretch.  

Again, it's not that it's bad food.  It's just that in a neighborhood filled with inventive but pricey (and at times "chichi") restaurants, it was really nice having one place offering simple, classic comfort food prepared really, really well.

I don't think I'll go back for a while, unless maybe for one of those delicious pretzels (and of course the beers).  If I'm at 16th and Valencia and I want to be surprised by what I eat, I'll go to Bar Tartine or Range or Maverick or Delfina or Commonwealth or any of the other dozen or so top-notch restaurants within a 5 minute walk.
author: Ritik C.

description:
Loved the food and the beer.  Tried a lot of each around the table.  One person raved about the burger and the soup o' the day which was French onion.  I tasted that and would have ordered one myself had they not closed the outdoor seating at 9:30 P.M.  

Tried the kale salad and charcuterie plate which were great.  Had a couple of Moonlight beers which was a nice find for an out of towner.  With the added patio seating it seems like they were seating on Saturday night almost immediately.  Did question the whether the patio is a great idea as the people watching in the Mission yielded two fights from our front row seats...Would have stayed and eaten and drank more but as I said the patio service ends at 9:30.  Good service, and plenty of warning that our time was running out.  We decided to head elsewhere at that point, inside was packed and had a larger group.
author: Jake G.

description:
Sorely disappointed with tonight's experience at Monk's. Six out of seven members of our party had arrived, but they still refused to seat us. The host gave us a time limit of 5 minutes for our seventh person to arrive, otherwise the seventh person would be unable to order food. What kind of a policy is that, and why do they have to be so strict about it? No one was behind us in line...

Not to mention the seven of us sat in a 6-person booth, and they refused to add a chair at the end of the booth. Of course I had to be the fourth person squished on at the end. Needless to say, it was quite an uncomfortable meal.

The service during the meal was decent--not great. And the meal itself was pretty disappointing. I ordered the toasted farro with mushrooms, which was hardly enough to constitute a full meal. I ended up eating half of my boyfriend's burger, which wasn't as fantastic as other reviews made it seem.

So my recap would be:
*Unnecessarily strict seating policy
*Mediocre service
*Nothing special about the food
*TINY PORTIONS

Probably will not be returning anytime soon....
author: Catherine C.

description:
Well... good luck getting in... BUT if you actually manage to get seated in this restaurant the size of a postage stamp it is DELISH.

I don't even know how to describe the beer menu. It's like you were used to the standard 12-crayon box your whole life and suddenly someone put the 64-crayon box in front of you and you can't even think of what to draw that would require so much color... that being said, the waiters are totally willing to give you suggestions (and lots of them) if you describe what you're looking for a little bit.

Frankly, I would've loved just a Blue Moon but I think I would've gotten some mustache-d frowns if I chose something so pedestrian... [hipster-beer-snob-alert] 

Although if you can take it seriously and order a fancy, craft beer - it's awesome and well worth it.  I also think the food at this place doesn't get enough cred... yes, it's a bit expensive and it takes FOREVER to get your food, it really is amazing. I had the scallops and shared the short rib and they did a great job - lots of flavor, great presentation and appropriate portion size. 

Be warned - because there is so much of a selection, they will run out of certain beers.... 

Lastly, it can get loud and yes, if you show up after 6pm on nearly any day of the week there will at least an hour wait...
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
Beer: Huge beer list although pricey and no lagers on draft last night. 3 of us drank the same pilsner as that was the only non-hoppy/ non- ridiculously priced pint there. 

Food: Burger was very good but it was definitely a small pile of salt fries  (why skimp?).  The croquettes were stellar and one could make a meal from apps alone... Didnt try the pretzel balls with cheese fondue but wish i had...

Ambience:  packed, trendy, loud-ish with a tv going with baseball... We had to wait an hour plus to sit but the host did his best to get us in before closing and everyone that worked there was nice. 

Honestly, was a little shocked when dinner bill came because the experience was not worth that much.  Maybe go back for beer and pretzels but not to eat a meal...
author: Dee T.

description:
Don't even bother going to Monks Kettle.  After seeing a feature about it on Unique Eats I wanted to try out the fare and was sorely unimpressed.

When did bad food, poor disinterested service and overpriced beer become trendy?

The food was really horrid.
author: Perry V.

description:
This place is great.  In addition to the awesome beer selection, they have some amazing food.  We went there on a Saturday afternoon around 2-3 and it wasn't terribly busy yet.  The waitress was right over and got our drinks.  She was very knowledgeable about their beer menu and she was able to make sure that everyone at our table got something that they liked.  She even brought us little samplers to make sure that we were going to like what we got.

Our group ordered the pretzel knots and garlic fries to share.  The fries were just the right amount of salt for consumption with beer.  The stoneground mustard that came with the pretzel knot was amazing.  For the main food, I got the scallops and my wife got the mushroom risotto.  Both were delicious. The scallops were prepared perfectly.  I would have liked to see one or two more on the plate as they were not the large diver scallops, but rather the smaller bay scallops. 

For dessert, we shared the carrot cake with our friends.  It was unique and the cream cheese frosting was almost like a mousse.  

I would definitely come back here and recommend it to my friends - just watch out for some of the prices of the beer!
author: David S.

description:
If it ain't broke don't fix it...

That old saying is sometimes true, but sometimes not. With Monk's Kettle the jury is out...

Gone are the days of warm, individual skillets of Panko Crusted Mac 'n Cheese with House-Cured Maple Smoked Bacon and Cider Brined Pork Chops. We now have Roasted Mushroom Risotto and Braised Beef Cheeks on Polenta Cake with a Horseradish Cream. 

The jury is certainly out. It's like comparing to apples to oranges if you really look at it. Where all the dishes fit into the "gatropub" cateogry of fare we can see the former two dishes as being "grub that's done up" where the latter two dishes are "done up grub" with the higher culinary flair.

My latest visit here was my first with the new chef, Adam Dulye. I admit it was quite a shock that things have changed and the heralded Mac 'n Cheese that I call tops in this city is GONE. But I have to admit, most of the "done up grub" we ordered was damn good. The waiter contended the risotto would make me forget about the old mac. It almost did, but not quite. 

I will be back to one of my all time city favorites to see if I can deliberate some more. BUT I will also start my search for Kevin Kroger and his Panko Crusted House-Cured Maple Smoked Bacon Mac 'n Cheese!!!
author: Al L.

description:
This is a review after a 30-minute stint and one super delicious beer waiting for a larger party to arrive.  

So between me and my boyfriend, he's the wine guy and I'm the beer girl, so you can imagine my excitement when I walk into Monk's Kettle and am enticed with a legit looking pub, beer taps lined up, and a slew of guests sloshing back beer in appropriate glassware.

It is a really tight fitting space, so if you don't have a seat along the bar or at a table you can expect to be in the way of the knowledgeable, and super hardworking servers.

In a place like this, you would expect that it would take an hour to get a drink, but a really friendly server asked me if I wanted a drink within 5 minutes of standing there.  I didn't even have to do the stare down! Unlike the Tap Room in Seattle, you could tell she loved beer and wanted to offer her personal recommendations according to your tastes.  I prefer Stouts and Porters, so she recommended a Black Cauldron.  Hello, delicious!

I asked if I could taste some pumpkin ale they had and she comes back with the tiniest little beer mug filled with beer.  Think beer mug perfectly suited for a chihuahua should your chihuahua drink.

Unfortunately, they couldn't fit our entire party in on a Saturday night so I sadly had to leave after just one beer.  But I will definitely be back!
author: Regina B.

description:
Crazy long beer list!!! Great atmosphere - intimate, dark and fun. Good food (especially for a pub) - burger, pretzel, and risotto were all awesome. Expect a LONG wait unless you go on an off night. Worth the wait to try at least once.

Beware- in bad neighborhood. Someone got their bike stolen while we were eating dinner...be careful.
author: Jenna Q.

description:
We came here for dinner one night during the week. It was pretty crowded with the evening rush, but we were able to grab a couple seats at the bar while we waited for our table. 

The atmosphere was very nice, while still being casual and hip. The decor has the feel of a London pub, but with lots of chalkboards scattered around for customers to draw on while they drink.

The Monk's Kettle has a *very* extensive beer menu. It can be a little overwhelming, especially if you're not an expert, but they offer samples and the waitstaff and bartenders are extremely knowledgeable about their products.

When we got seated, we took our drinks with us and ordered dinner. The menu is a bit short when it comes to food, but it's all delicious. We got the pretzel appetizer, which came with a variety of very flavorful mustards. I got the mushroom risotto, which was amazing - a nice heavier food to eat with beers. Each entree comes with a list of beers that complement, contrast, etc...the food. Our waiter was very good at helping me choose the best beer for my food that fit my tastes. The food came quickly and we were never rushed, even while the place got pretty busy.
author: Amelia B.

description:
Any restaurant that serves a giant pretzel automatically gets a five-star review. The good thing is, The Monk's Kettle never goes downhill from there. 
The main waiter there is quite a pleasure to work with, sitting down next to you on the bench to joke about beers and menu selection. He recommended a fabulous, limited edition beer on tap, called Golden Gate, that crossed somewhere between a champagne/cider, but with a saffron bite. 

Pulled-pork sandwich to die for!!! And our waiter was smart enough to grab the leftover cheese dip from the pretzel for me to use as a dip for my fries. 

Heaven. Love. I might grow fat and old here.
author: Alita M.

description:
I had walked by here countless times yet had never gone in.  I finally had a chance to go while on a date and it turned out to be there perfect place because there is no room for awkward silence... yeah.... I am loud like that. Anyhoo, it was awesome. The selection of beer is very extensive, the staff is quite knowledgeable and the mussels are some of the tastiest I have ever had... it was the sauce! Yummy. 

I would go back and try some more of the dishes.
author: Amelia M.

description:
Chill environment
Great staff
Variety of beer
Located conveniently in the "gentrified" Mish

Oh - the burger is SO good and juicy!
author: Christina C.

description:
I finally came back and had a full meal a couple months ago. I'd been back for beers and fries before, but didn't want to review based on just that after my initial review of the sort of dinner i had.

To be fair, service has always been great at this crowded place. The waitstaff is friendly and they seem to know their stuff. The food was really good (holy crap the bone marrow!) and i definitely enjoy myself there, regardless of whether or not i'm eating.
author: Phuong M.

description:
In my ideal world, Fridays would be part of the weekend and an inexpensive and harmless teleportation device would allow people to travel from Portland to San Francisco in a matter of minutes. According to some news sources, the transporter is just a few technological brow furrows away. For the skeptics among us and during the wait in the meantime, there is the Monk's Kettle. The Monk's Kettle is such a Portland kind of restaurant, it can only be located in my other favorite city.

The space they use on 16th used to house a slightly dingy but lovable burger joint. Since the burger joint's trip to the fryer in the sky, Monk's Kettle has taken the general idea - a nice place to get a burger - and dressed it up. Dark wood booths with an array of planks to support you and your dining companions line the walls. The bar holds a liver-busting amount of taps. And the food, for fancypants pub fare, manages to make even the most jaded and ironic of Mission dwellers mmm with glee.

There are burgers. There are some more involved dinner entrees. There are also fries that come with ketchup and two kinds of aioli dipping sauces. There is a breaded mac 'n cheese that you can add smoked bacon to and served in a little cast iron skillet that, if it weren't for the amount of heat it can retain, you would probably lick clean. There are also pages of beers to be selected, ingested, traded with friends, and adored like woodland creatures. I had an oatmeal stout from somewhere in Central California, which I was afraid would add too much heaviness to my meal consisting mostly of starch. But the stout had such a subtle, sweet tone that it provided a hoppy retreat from all the potato and noodle options sitting on our table. But there were so many beers to choose from that it would have been very hard to come up with an unhappy combo.

Since Portland is the land where myriad beers roam free to be paired with hearty meat and cheese dishes, I got a welcome taste of home in my home-away-from-home. Forget greenhouse gases, scientists, get on that teleporter!
author: Kimberly V.

description:
Menu update fail :(
No more funky flavoured ketchup trio for the amazing fries was the kicker for me. They lost a couple stars due to (as someone else mentioned) the revamped menu now means fancier ingredients, complex foodie lingo and increased prices. What happened to that old adage?- If it ain't broke...
author: Alyssa H.

description: My wife and I had been wanting to eat here so we came in this past Friday evening for dinner. Our first server was apparently getting ready to go off shift because we were neglected the whole time. She was in a hurry and really rude. she also forgot to order part of of meal and we didn't receive it until the new server (who we did not know was taking over until the end  ) came up to us. I am writing this review because of the biggest offense was, we ordered the nightly special that was on the board. It was not mentioned by her, OR the board that it had mushrooms in the meal. My wife who is highly allergic to them took a huge bite of mushrooms! we told our new server about this, he apologized  and was really nice but  didn't even comp our meal. she couldn't even eat her dinner! My wife was ill that evening and if she had eaten more she would have spent the night in the hospital. all that, and  we were still  stuck paying a hundred dollars for a meal that was inedible. We won't be back.
author: Mister M.

description:
Great dining experience. I had a large format beer with a group, accompanying a nice burger. 

I have only one complaint of this restaurant, nothing to do with the quality of the food or beer. The server ran the wrong check, requiring a second charge to my card. Maybe next time the server could be more careful.
author: Kyle S.

description:
Came here for lunch on a Wednesday afternoon (shhh don't tell my boss I went beer drinking for 2 hours) as every other time I've come by this place is packed and impossible to get a table.

Anyhow, got the burger (with bacon of course silly!) because a burger without its best friend bacon is simply incomplete....delicious! If you've ever had the famous Father's Office burger down in LA (and what other reason would anyone be down in LA other than for food) the Monk's Kettle version gives it a run for the money. Nice hearty beef, salty cheese complemented by sweet caramelized onion.

Also ordered the house charcuterie and cheese, which was so-so, pretty standard in my book and unworthy of the $30 price tag. The pate which I always look forward to kind of just fell flat. I will say that the strawberry jam accompaniment was phe-no-me-nal.

Let's see, well we got the bone marrow "canoe" as well, if only real canoes were this tasty. They do a nice version of bone marrow here keeping things very clean and simply and the popcorn is a really nice touch for a bit of saltiness and as a vessel for capturing any oily goodness that makes its way on the plate. Lastly tried the pretzel which puts all other pretzels I've had to shame although I've only had the stuff you get at the movie theaters. The mustard the comes with the pretzel is seriously bomb.

Oh...and yea totally had some beer too, but that's for another review :)
author: David H.

description: One of my favorite "new american" gastropubs in SF. I try to make it a point to visit this place everytime I visit Cali. Great interior, adult vibes, delicious brew, great food!
author: Orlando B.

description: Awesome place! It definitely has the best beer selection in San Francisco. I was not a beer drinker until I tried Lost Abby stout. It was delicious. The only bad thing - you cannot get it in Iowa. :( Already cannot wait to be back!! And they have awesome food, too. My husband swears that their daily roast is the best thing he's ever had. My favorite is meat and cheese platter. Staff is very friendly. And did I mention their bathroom? It is the coziest bathroom I've been to in San Francisco - super clean with candles. :)
author: Anna D.

description: Really good, but super expensive for what I got.
author: Brook F.

description: Had dinner with Thomas. The food was fantastic! Duck Confit, the daily roast (braised short rib), flat bread with fig prosciutto and arugula. Our server Kai outdid the food. Super friendly and polite but not overbearing. The new outdoor seating with heaters is great, too.
author: Dustin D.

description: Big let down at my last visit, which albeit was back in Nov 2012, but now that I'm back to Yelp reviewing I had to update.  Gone is the Fullers, and seriously nothing more inventive than Allagash.  We still had fun, but minus points for the smaller less creative beer roster, and the food was meh.
author: Jina S.

description:
Argh, if only they hadn't changed their menu!!!!!! No more pork chop and no more mac & cheese. 

After glancing at the menu, I went for the mussels. Meh, they were ok.

4 stars for the beer selection and recommendation by the bartendar. I told her what I liked and she was spot on. Would only come back for beer.
author: Janelle L.

description:
I honestly don't know how they justify their prices.  Sure, the beer selection is great, but what they charge for it is just not grounded in the reality of a town where good beer is part of the culture.  $5.50 for a 10 ounce (!) pour of Allagash White?  Please. 

Food quality is just decent, with the entrees being just passable (and nearing the $20 dollar mark).

I'll definitely return if I have a visitor from out of town on an expense account.  Otherwise, you can find numerous beer bars in San Francisco without overpriced pours, and you'll have enough left in your pocket for a legitimately good dinner (oh, forget just drinks with a large group--you'll have to sit for food).
author: H C.

description:
My girlfriend and I went to the Monk's Kettle for my Birthday on a Sunday Evening.  This was EXACTLY what I was looking for. 

The setting was great. A table for two felt private enough to converse, yet open enough we could experience the rest of the room. The beer list was a bit overwhelming at first, but the details given on each type made selecting a beer fairly easy. 

When my girlfriend (not a typical beer drinker) needed help selecting beer, the server was able to select the PERFECT one with 5 simple "this or that" questions.   We also experience him doing the same with a table next to us, just as impressive. 

The food was... wow.  

We both had pretzles, which although tasty, were not the same that we saw in other yelp photos (much smaller). 

I had the "burger" and it was by far the juiciest burger I have EVER had.  Onion sauce, bacon, and meat just came together perfectly.  

For desert we went with the Carrot Cake in a cup..... THIS ALONE IS WORTH RETURNING!  The single best carrot cake type food I have EVER had.  Perfect texture, went great with beer, and was the perfect polish on our meal. 

This is one of those places I will be coming back to in subsequent trips to SF.  If you like beer and pub food, this is the place.
author: Julian S.

description: As one of the highest rated bars in SF, I had to try it out. I did not try the food but the bartender was friendly, helpful, and they have a large beer selection on hand. Nothing wowed me about the place but I would return based on the friendly service and great beer.
author: Justin R.

description: Delicious pretzels. Great beer selection, friendly servers. Only downside is it's very loud.
author: Beth B.

description:
Pretty good place to sit and relax.

We had ordered a few beers and an order of fries. The fries were sooo good with the ketchup and their mustard dip.

Bartender was nice and friendly as well.
author: Scott N.

description:
I had a late lunch here on Sautrday with a friend of mine from San Diego, the service was truly outstanding.  We were acknowledged by all the staff that walked by us and everyone who worked there really cared about our experience.  We got the pretzel, so salty, warm and tasty.  The Scallops some of the best that I have ever had and the Roast of the day.

I will be back again and again, more then worth it in a town that has so much great food, but to also have such great, genuin and friendly service was icing on the cake.
author: Meg G.

description: i dig it! i'm not a fan of beer or alcoholic beverages in general, but i am so down with the food and the vibe. the whipped bone marrow was so gluttonously good. and the burger was on point. i will absolutely be back with my bf so that we can try some food/beer pairings. it's just his kind of place!
author: Regina C.

description: Great place for tasty craft beers on draft! Enjoyed a few although we didn't have the opportunity to stay to eat. Our bartender was okay, not the friendliest but tried to let that bug us too much and enjoy those tasty beers!
author: Mindy N.

description:
I like Monk's Kettle but I wouldn't go out of my way to go there.  If it were, say, 4pm on a Saturday afternoon and I was craving a nice exotic cold one and I'm already in the mission, then sure I'd go there.  If it's 8pm and I want a beer then no to Monk's Kettle.  Why? Well, if you're gonna go at that time, you should be prepared for a looooong wait.  And by the time you sit down, you probably already had 2 beers.  They make a killing on the poor suckers that are willing to wait for a table or a seat at the bar.  No one wants to just stand around twiddling their thumbs.  It's a good thing their selection of beers is impressive.  There were pages and pages of it and with style descriptions and country of origin.  While I'm a total beer novice, I did appreciate trying to pretend like I knew what I was doing when ordering the beer. 

As for the food, the fries are delicious.  It comes with the usual ketchup and a mustard sauce.  I'm an aioli girl so I had to ask for it since it doesn't normally accompany the fries.  The burger wasn't half bad either.  Carmelized onions and aioli mmmm.  It was a bit on the smaller side, though.

Overall, not a terrible experience but I wouldn't wait 1+ hours.
author: Karen N.

description: Came here for beers and dinner on our first night in San Francisco. We wanted to try a place with a great beer menu and this place has that for sure. They had a great selection of local beers not available to us on the east coast. The bartender was also super nice and very helpful. I'm only giving it 3 stars because everything is VERY expensive. My husband's 6 oz. beer was $14. His burger was also pretty over cooked. But we still had a nice time and had some yummy food and beers.
author: Kelly D.

description:
I read all the hype on Yelp about the pretzels and couldn't fathom how a pretzel could possibly be THAT good. But, it was. I would come back from the pretzel alone, though the rest of the food was good too.

The tables feel a bit cramped but it's a fun vibe and of course the beer selection is amazing. I think it's absurd that they don't currently offer a sampler option. Maybe someday!
author: Priya N.

description:
As the reigning duke and a long-time fan of Monk's Kettle, it's about damn time I left a review.  The Monk's Kettle is a true San Francisco gem.  It fits a surprising number of needs - whether you want a bar to chill with your friends, an intimate space for a date, a delicious late-night meal, or a snack and an insanely well-specified brew, The Kettle has you covered.

These cats know their beer.  It doesn't matter how well you know yours - they are super helpful and friendly and will find you something you like.  It doesn't matter if you walk in and say your favorite beer is Pinot Grigio, these guys will find something for your palette.  The beer menu updates frequently, and the selection is top-notch.

The food at Monk's Kettle has always been a big draw.  a big, rich New American menu has been the staple, but they recently got a new chef and a whole new menu, to which I cannot yet speak.  Of course that makes this paragraph completely useless.  You may skip to the next one.

I gotta give a shout-out to my homey Sayre - bar manager and beer buyer extraordinaire, Sayre has been advising me on liquor choices since our college days at the Red Room in Santa Cruz.  Now a Certified Cicerone (http://www.cicerone.org/), Sayre is the single most knowledgeable beer enthusiast - nay, professional - I've ever met.  He and his colleagues at The Monk's Kettle do an amazing job of running a top-notch establishment.  Look at me I sound like a shill.  It's all truuuueeeee
author: Oliver N.

description:
I don't typically drink beer. 
I don't typically eat pretzels. 
I don't often come here due to the guaranteed over-crowding, which means a wait. 
I don't like waits. 
There is one restroom. Not one per sex. Just one. Which, coupled with a beer joint, means a guaranteed wait. 
Again, I don't like waits. 

Nevertheless, a hot pretzel with cheese sauce (skip the mustard - trade that ramekin in for a second cheese sauce ramekin), sans salt, a Trois Pistole or two or three, a rare late afternoon getaway = that's SF living. I'd like to come here with a friend anytime.
author: Jen H.

description: Chicken schnitzle was delicious! I can't say enough good things about the food here. There's a small selection but the entree's are very high quality. And there are a ton of beer and several cider options to go with them!
author: Ashley C.

description:
Beer for you, your friends and their mum.

The best bar food you'll ever have, paired with the best beers from all over the world- it's incredible. I first tried the Monk's daily roast and paired it with Ölvisholt Lava Stout from Iceland (Perfection) and later came back to try the three day ale bricked chicken with cranberry beans and pickled peppers paired with Speedway Stout (brewed from coffee beans from my neighborhood in San Diego!!!). Calling this place epic would be an understatement. Oh, and did I mention there's a beer here that's brewed with a pepper similar to habanero? Check it out if you get a chance, I guarantee you won't regret it.
author: Cameron S.

description: Best meal I've had in SF. Got some corned beef hash croquettes w/ bone marrow sauce, OMG!!! The best burger I can remember, and really super delicious risotto.
author: Melville M.

description:
I was really excited to try this place, and sadly, I don't think I ever will. They just made me so furious yesterday...

Two friends and I (three of us) met up here for drinks and dinner. We had a drink at the bar while we waited 15 minutes for a table. I had heard there was always a wait so I wasn't surprised. After we sat down, a fourth friend decided to join us and stopped in. As he went to sit down with us at our table, the hostess stopped him and informed us that The Monk's Kettle has a policy of not allowing four people to squeeze into a table which was designated for three (but could easily fit four). We asked if we could move to the table next to ours set for 4 and she said no. We would have to put our name at the bottom of the list, it would take another 20 minutes to get a table for 4. We asked if she could please make an exception or else we would have to leave and she said "no, no exceptions."

Well obviously we couldn't leave our friend just hanging in the Mission alone! So we had to leave! And we had all hauled our asses all the way out there! What is up with service in this town!?!?

I know this place takes itself seriously, but its a gastro-pub! PUB! As in, meet friends and sit and chat and have drinks and be merry. Not as in, stuffy, rude servers who make you feel ashamed to be there.

So, in sum, another stuffy pretentious Mission establishment that would prefer you to be on the street rather than in their establishment.
author: Blond E.

description:
My beer infatuated brother-in-law is in love with this place.  He's sort of a shut in so in order to get him to join us for a meal out we usually have to assure him he will get excellent beer and meat.  He's a regular here and I can see why. 

Long and narrow, easily crowded.  Nice antique looking bar of dark carved wood.  lovely. 

I think their beer menu is 7 pages long with nice explanations of the types of beer.  The waiter is knowledgeable and patient and will give you samples of the draft beers in these wee little beer steins upon request.  Decent food menu geared towards meat eaters but some solid vegetarian options too.  Sister and brother-in-law went for the burgers, I had a bite and it was a perfectly juicy, cheesy, bacony bite.  I ordered the bone marrow canoe and a salad and my partner had the beef cheeks small plate.  The bone marrow was beautifully presented, but sadly very disappointing.  There was probably 1/2 teaspoon of actual marrow and it lacked the rich flavour or texture I was anticipating, instead it was just rendered fat on toast with parsley leaves.    Salad was also a bit uninspired with about 3 tasty bites and the rest was dry bland lettuce (not even crisp and fresh).  The beef cheeks on polenta was very rich and tasty, but not a meal.  I'd say stick with the entrees and skip the small plates unless you're not hungry at all.  

Our server was extremely patient as brother-in-law had tons of questions and was a little spastic (enthusiastic, very very enthusiastic), there was a moment or two that I thought the server was offended or confused but he handled himself well and made excellent recommendations.  Thanks dude.
author: Sj C.

description:
The BEST BREAD PUDDING that we have had anywhere is SF!!

This quaint little gem came to us by a recommendation of the "local app"! We were in the Mission, looking for a place that served food late, on a weekday, and boy are we ever thankful that we tried it out! We have been back many, many times!

While it is a tiny space, and oft times, a wait out the door, the food, ambiance and service never disappoints... (Except for the isolated exhausted server that we encountered once...) there is a huge bar, which is first come, first served, with a full menu. 

I will write a full review of our next meal. 

In the meantime, TRY THE BREAD PUDDING, thank me later!
author: Beau M.

description:
This place is phenomenal.

Food:  I read the reviews after our visit, so we didn't have the pretzels. Now I have to go back. I had the daily roast and my friend's had the hamburger. They claim it was the best burger they've ever had. The daily roast was a pork shoulder that was perfect in every way. I feel compelled to go back every day to experience whatever roast they've prepared for the day. I'm pretty sure they won't go wrong.

Beer: The selection is fantastic with something for everyone. Their pairings are by style instead of a specific beer. At first this felt phoned-in, but now I see that their confidence in their food and beer menus derive this approach.
author: Tiffany T.

description:
I went to the Monk's Kettle for dinner with my husband on Wednesday night at around 7pm.  When we arrived there were no tables available, but we were quickly able to get two seats at the side bar area.  This place is very small, and it was tough to stand while waiting prior to scoring the bar seats as there is not much room between the bar and the seating area.  However, despite the size of the place, they have an extensive books full of beers and in addition they also have 10-15 beers on tap.

I tried three different beers while here and none of them disappointed.  The one thing I did notice is that the pricing of the beers here seemed to be a little bit on the higher side.  However, since they have a great selection that could be overlooked.  For food to start off with my husband and I shared the cheese plate and then I had the soft pretzel. The cheese plate was large and contained a good variety of cheese as well as a meat, mustard, and various jams.  It contained more then enough bread to spread the cheese on (which is something I find some places try to slight you on).  The bread was toasted lightly and was nice and crispy.  The soft pretzel was served warm and came with a nice spicy mustard and a cheese sauce.  

For the meal I ordered the three day ale bricked chicken which was amazing!  The chicken was cooked perfectly and was very tender and juicy. The light sauce surrounding the chicken gave it a great flavor.  My husband had the burger which looked pretty good, but I am sure it probably was not as great as my chicken!  Overall, I highly recommend this place and would visit again if we are in the area.
author: Erin G.

description:
stopped in here for a quick dinner while in SF on layover.  The bartenders here know beer pretty well...but this is coming from someone who is not really a beer connoiseur at all.  The roast sounded delicious, but unfortunately they ran out as we were giving orders.  The alternative was a duck confit roast, but I opted for the short rib instead.  It was pretty good, hearty and filling.  it had an odd taste to it though, which I never pinpointed, but that odd flavor actually paired well with the beer they recommended.

I had a great time here meeting new friends and eating here, but the one drawback was the service  They are very strict about their "capacity" and letting people in...so when we initially got there, two of us were trying to join two others already there, but we were asked to wait outside for a few minutes.  It was no big deal...we were initially just going to head elsewhere for dinner, but then they ended up being able to get a table for us.  They even stored luggage for two of us (since we were in SF on a layover).  

The speed of service at the table was more problematic.  The waiter came by initially, but then we didn't see him for about 20 minutes after we were ready to place out order.  When we finally grabbed someone to say we'd lost out waiter, they did send someone else prompty to take our order.  They also explained that the waiters had taken a food break (seems like poor timing).  However, after ordering, our food took at least another 30 minutes to show up, if not longer.  It was delicious and worth the wait, but if you're hungry and must eat quickly...I recommend considering a different place.
author: Jerry F.

description:
This place is simply the bee's knees. Great selection of beers I've never ever had, and an amazingly knowledgeable staff - this is a place where you don't simply order your beer - you learn about it and become one with it. 

Make sure to engage your waitstaff - and ask them about all the different beers. There's one beer I remember them saying that had citrus notes, and another one that had notes of banana. Yeah - bananas. No kidding. For real.

And the food was also amazeballs - I had some chicken and also got their pretzels. Holy crap. Their pretzels were disgustingly good. Crap - I just might have to go there right now.
author: Jaki L.

description:
Monk's Kettle used to be an old standby favorite -- when you were in need of some serious comfort food and a good pint. I would dream of the mac & cheese along with the handmade ballpark-like pretzel. 

Today, I'm extremely disappointed with Monk's menu change. Gone are both the mac & cheese and large pretzel. I asked the staff what happened to the 2 classic menu items and they kept telling me, "we have a new chef and we changed the menu." On top of the fact that the prices went up with the new fancy menu. 

I'm sorry Monk's Kettle, you've lost a loyal customer. I liked you just as you were -- when you were a good old neighborhood bar serving great food and beer. So sad :(
author: Aya O.

description: Came here for lunch, really would have walked right by seeing it was mostly a bar. Glad I did not, the burger with fries is so soft the beef just melts in your mouth. Did have a beer anyway, great selection on tap. Would definitely dive in again.
author: sammy l.

description:
FINALLY got a table - usually, we go there and it's at least an hour to an hour and a half wait. The only reason why I would squeeze myself into the place was for the Mac 'n' Cheese (or Crack 'n' Cheese). However, they've changed their chef AND the menu - WTF? Big G was mourning the loss of the pork chop from the menu. Sigh...

The beer was expensive. I mean, I'm no beer aficionado, and it was truly delicious beer (I tried two unpronouncable German frosties), but definitely on the pricey side. As was the food - esp. for the Mission.

Still, the mussels were good, and I sopped up all the sauce (good sign). Big G got the burger, which he said was "okay" (he still ate everything, though), and the chocolate bread pudding was worth the extra belly roll fo sho.

Service was great - the host was friendly and kept us in the loop re: the wait for our table, and the server was friendly and efficient. 

Still, shame about the change in menu and the higher prices after two years of trying to get to sit down for dinner. Oh well...
author: Mi M.

description: I was here during a work trip to Buffalo in the middle of winter...I was so glad that we found this place. The food, the beers and the atmosphere definitely kept us animated and warm!! I should be going back to Buffalo this summer, and when I do, I will make sure to stop by this place again!!
author: George M.

description:
This is one of my favorite beer bars anywhere...

The staff knows a lot about beer and can tell you a number of nuances in what youa re tasting or drinking. I love that there is a constant turnover of beer and always something new to try and taste/enjoy.  In fact they have mini steins (1 oz tasters) to see if you want to get the beer on tap that you are intrigued by. The beers are not well known like a Spatan or Guiness, however they are International and great beers that are not commen in the US like a Bitburger, Radeburger, etc

Perhaps its obvious I like Kolsch and Pils' but they have a large selection on tap of 20-25 beers/ales and a number of additional brands in bottles.

The place is a lil small, but it is definately cozy and almsot always filled to overflowing... Almost everyone gets something to eat with their beer, but I have only had the garlic fries which were really good with thebeer I was drinking at the time...
author: Schel H.

description: It was my first time here.  My husband and I went with a few regulars and beer fanatics.  We showed up at 3:30pm on a Sunday which is the best time to go.  It's bumping but not crowded, we got seated immediately.  The lunch rush had past and it was too early for the evening craze.  The waiters are super knowledgable about the beers and provide plenty of free tastings.  I'm not much of a beer person but managed to find a few beers that jived with my palate.  It started with what do you like to eat?  I answered chocolate and fruits.  We found some stout and fruit-based beers that were delicious.  Also, I recommend ordering the 'Chile and Honey Roasted Hazelnuts' appetizer.  The veggie burger was decent as well.  It's made with grains used to make beer.
author: Zaina O.

description:
This place is awesome. It's open late, has a hefty beer menu and good food served to 1am. Fantastic.

I don't think I go out of the way to come here to have dinner or make a big deal of it, but it's certainly a perfect place for a low key midnight snack. I had the baby arugula salad with aged thin sliced asiago cheese, apples and candied walnuts. The salad was fresh and tasty, with bold surprises of big peppercorns in the tangy vinaigrette dressing. The apples slices in the salad were a little mushy, and I left most of those behind on the plate. Larry had the pulled pork sandwich full of lots of flavor with super crunchy, probably double fried fries. We washed it all down with a Belgian pilsner and a black currant cider brewed in Colfax. Everything on the menu is comfort foodish, with pot pies, mac and cheese, sandwiches, soups and salads, all with appropriate suggested beer pairings. It's all prime food for a pre- or post-bar crawl night in the Mission.

Service was a little slow and actually absent within the first five minutes of walking in, and that was OK because we were still deciding on beers from their extensive list. Once we were tended to, the food came out with the drinks in decent time. Two brews, a salad and the sandwich came out to $34.
author: Chelsea P.

description:
I cannot believe I am doing this... Giving a 5 star to a place I had always thought was some overhyped bs. 

Boy was I wrong.

Try this: girls day out brunch with untypical beer courses paired with unexpectedly nourishing, clean foods. Plus sweet as heck service with a PhD busboy to boot.
author: Mandy S.

description:
Great place for beer!  The selection of European beers and American Micros is phenomenal.  There are a few pedestrian models if you look carefully.  I saw PBR AND Tecate.

At any rate, you ought to be in Monk's Kettle during drinking hours if you like non Macro brews.  The menu is organized by Lagers and their subspecies, Ales and their sub-species, Belgians and their sub-species, etc.  Half of my entertainment while drinking here was browsing the 5 page menu.  That's a 5 page menu of beer!  We didn't eat anything, but the food looked really good.

I also recommend sitting at the bar simply so you can engage the nice folks behind the bar in a bit of dialog about favorite beers, favorite styles of beer, etc.  They know their stuff.
author: Nelson W.

description: This must be one of the best beer bars I have ever been to. And I've been to Europe. It's got a large menu with superb and exotic beer choices. I got a rauchbier (German smoked beer), something I very rarely see. Then I got a Belgian ale with apple, and a sour brown ale. It's a nice place to sit: not as rustic as beer bars can get. Lots of young people were here and the vibe was electric. I had some great conversations.
author: Jason G.

description:
I've been here a few times and it's always packed! Always! It's great because they serve food until 1 AM and have great beers and drinks. It's a great place for a small or large group. The dining is very casual and the staff is always friendly and fun. 

BEER is the key element! Lot's of it here! 

FOOD - The grilled quail w/ peach BBQ is off the hook! The braised beef cheeks with polenta are also yummy!!! 
Definitely a late night spot! 

P.S.  If there is a wait you can always put your name down and go out for a drink somewhere else.  They will call and hold your table.
author: Priya B.

description: I've only been to the bar at Monk's Kettle and have never indulged in food. They have a good beer selection, both bottle and draft, but man do they overcharge. $8 for Pliny the Elder when it's made less than 2 hours away and yet I can get Pliny in Portland for $5? Yeah no. I'm not sure where the mark up is coming from on their local beers. I understand a higher price for imports and rare beers but come on. On the plus side they are one of the few bars open in the Mission before 5pm for day drinking that isn't a dive.
author: Cori W.

description:
I was meeting Jen T for din last night and she suggested the Monk's Kettle. I was excited to try something new. I arrived around 7pm and the place was packed. I found a couple of seats at the bar and suggested that we just eat there rather than wait for a table. Lucky..because the bartender gave us great service...(and it turned out that they offered us a table as we were finishing our dinner). 

The Monk has an extensive beer list but the list was short for wines by the glass. I had the Malbec and it was decent. 
I ordered the seared tuna sandwich with Aioli on the side...I got a side of aioli and a sandwich packed full of it. No biggie..a few scrapings later the sandwich was edible. I did have regrets of not ordering the pot pie and the giant pretzel both looked more delicious than my sandwich.  We had to wait awhile for our chocolate cake but it was definitely worth the wait. My experience wasn't magical..but I'd visit the Monk again.
author: Mimi T.

description:
I came here with a friend upon another friend's suggestion. Our dates for the evening were quite enthusiastic about the beer selection and I had the opportunity to try some of the different kinds offered. I'm not a beer fanatic, and they all tasted the same to me. Hm.

After moseying our way down from a saloon up the street, we were lucky enough to get a table. Service seemed to be a bit slow, but it was decently busy there. I ordered the filet mignon, which was one of their specials for the day. They cooked my steak bloody rare like I requested, and the actual meat was delicious. I think the server mentioned that it was local organic. I ate every little morsel on my plate, yum yum.
author: Grace Y.

description:
Crazy library of beer!  Was overwhelmed by the choices but luckily the super nice & knowledgeable staff came and saved the day w/ recommendations by asking you a series of questions.  Super chill tavern vibe.  

Our selection of drafts went well paired w/ these delish bar bites:
Braised beef cheeks, polenta, horseradish 
Seared veal sweetbreads, pickled apple slaw, parsnip 
Fresh ground burger, onion jam, aioli, aged white cheddar, fries

Will definitely have to bring some more friends!
author: Dorothy L.

description:
In a world where pub food often includes nachos and chicken tenders, it's nice to stumble upon a gastropub that fancifies standard favorites.  The small dishes seem to pack more flavor than the larger ones, but that's a good thing since it encourage longer nibbling periods of more tasty beer drinking.  Speaking off, very impressive beer menu and I suppose some people come here just for it without ever trying the food.

Giant Pretzel: You can tell a good pretzel when the outer skin is crunchy and the innards are moist and chewy.  Extremely hot to the touch when it arrived, this high end bar food tasted great in the cheddar dip (way better than cheez whiz).  The stone ground mustard was nice too, but my attention drifted towards the cheese mostly.

Mac & Cheese: I think I've been having way too much mac & cheese around town and have thus become very picky nowadays, but I blame on the fact that every fancy comfort place places it on the menu.  This mac & cheese was definitely up there, served in a hot skillet with a good crisp layer of browned bread crumbs.  Under the hood was some creamy goodness and the bacon add-on definitely upgraded the awesomeness.  My only wish would be for more melted cheese on top.

Pork Chop: The most expensive item on the menu, really?  It was a good chop no doubt: thick and juicy with nice grill sear marks.  Could have stood to have some more glaze as the flavor was a little a bland.  The cheddar scallion potato pancake was super dry and felt like potato particles rather than the shreddings of a typical potato pancake.  The brussels sprouts weren't caramelized enough since only a few of them had specks of crunchy outer leaves.

Chicken Pot Pie: Not really a pot pie since there was no pastry on the bottom, so more of a chicken ramekin with a pastry crown on top.  A tad on the small side, but packed with flavor.  The broth was super creamy encasing very fresh tasting peas and carrots.  Some pieces of chicken were tender and flavorful, but a few tasted skanky... I'd suggest not putting in the back meat cuts.  The pastry crown itself had some nice herbs to it.
author: Adam B.

description:
The Beer Gods were smiling on us last night. My friends snagged a table when they arrived around 7:15. When the rest of our group rolled in at 7:30 the place was packed to the brim and was still full when we left at 10:30. The booth was comfy and big enough to fit six people... as long as those six people are good friends who eat off of each others plates and sip each others beer. We are.

Our rockstar of a waiter was taking care of all the tables by himself so things went a little slow, but in a happily taking the time to appreciate all the beer and food kind of way not the antsy, I want to get out of here already kind of way. He said they weren't prepared for the amount of people coming in on opening night (not even the official grand opening last night) so I'm sure things will run smoother once they're open for a while. Even with the amount of people he kept checking up on us and made sure we had plenty of beer.

The winner of the night was the BBQ pulled pork sandwich... I just had a taste but will definitely be getting that next time. The bruschetta with wild mushrooms and cheddar was also amazing and I heard from the other end of the table that the burger and veggie burger were both great. I wasn't thrilled with my ahi tuna sandwich, not bad just nothing special. I'm looking forward to seeing a bigger dessert menu. I like cake with my beer.

And the beer. My god the beer. I tried the Blue Dot IPA first... a pretty good, mellow IPA. They were having trouble with the keg so I switched to a favorite I've only seen at Toronado before - Bombay by Boat IPA and it made me happy to be alive. My stout loving friend just about fainted when he tasted the Old Rasputin Stout - Nitro. Besides being simply astounding in its size, the beer menu was well laid out and had thoughtful explanations of each type of beer. And for Christ's sake they have a quote about beer by Plato written on the chalkboard! 

So go, try lots of good beer and save room for me at the Kettle.
author: Brandy H.

description: Delicious food, but be willing to pay an arm and a leg! A once-in-awhile treat.
author: Rosanna W.

description:
You like beer?  They have beer.  Lots of beer.  Excellent beer.  Goes  with the great food.  I have heard from several people that since the chef came the food has not been as good (I was sad to have missed the mac and cheese which from all accounts was to die for) but I will say that my marrow canoe may have made up for the loss.  Is there anything better than marrow?

The homemade pickles are definitely worth a try, very nicely done.  I had the tomatoes and flat bread after grazing on everything else.  My dining companions thoroughly enjoyed their lunch as well.  Definitely worth another stop.
author: Lyn B.

description:
Sunday evening, walking around Mission after dinner at Cha Cha Cha...thinking about going to Delirium for a cheap drink...and saw a nice fancy wine bar place across the alley.  Go in, sit down, look at the extensive menu...and notice its all BEER!!!!  A hundred of them.  WOW.

Boy bartender, wearing a retro shirt with "TED" name tag was awesome.  Poured us a couple beer tasters, super friendly, and CUTE.  He recommended Duchess de Bourgogne, this beer taste like the sangria I just had....omg...so good, but dude, it's a $10 - 8 oz beer...lol, it better be good.  Girl bartender, looking kinda annoyed, not at us but in general...not too cool.

Order fries and bruschetta since we just ate.  Mushroom bruschetta, absolutely awesome...this is me talking on an already full stomach since we'd only just walked from our dinner at Cha Cha Cha...lol, yes me and my best friend...we are pigs.  Fries were just the regular frozen bag fries, with a skimpy amount of aioli...we kept having to ask for more.

So 5 stars had there been more aioli and girl bartender been nicer.


Update 4/27/2008:
Looking for a light dinner and a drink I recommended this place to my other best friend.  She loves beer.  So four stars again!  I think they changed their fries.  They were much better.  Bruschetta again...since I realize I don't want to eat  most of their choices. Its was good again, so there is some consistency here at Monk's.  I shared a chicken breast sandwich with my friend.  Usually I do not eat chicken breast, turkey breast...breast in general.... but hmm...good amount of cheese on that sucker, lots of pesto aioli, and bacon...so it wasn't dry and it was actually pretty good.  Ooh, kudos to the tall white bartender with curly hair...served me a new beer that topped the Duchess de Bourgogne.  My new beer is "Monk's Cafe"....yummy beer.
author: Jenny K.

description: Pliny on tap, good eats, nice servers, decent prices.
author: Cameron A.

description: Stopped in here after reading a few yelp reviews. Had dinner and a few drinks while sitting by the chalkboards. Once the staff saw us they were very helpful with recommendation for beer and food. Ate a few pretzel knots for an app and then a chicken sandwich and mushroom risotto. Both were very good portions and were tasty. If you go expect a wait but don't be shy and look for a seat in the back .
author: Philip P.

description:
Allow me to first say that I have never eaten here. 
Ok... so I went here on a first "date" and there was nowhere to sit.. we had to stand at the bar which was ridiculous and over crowded. 
Alas, someone left and we had somewhere to sit....
Love all the fancy shmancy beers that they offer, though I was a nerd alert and went with a Blue Moon.... but they have little mini beer glasses that are adorable and I will post the pictures.
The next time I tried to take someone here they wouldnt let us in b/c it was over crowded; which I wasnt mad about because honestly they should have done that the first time......
I will go back when I am in the hood...
author: Liz C.

description:
So. Much. Beer.

My only complaint is that the wooden benches become uncomfortable around the third beer.  Anyway, the staff is very attentive, and the beer menu is enormous.  You may want to get there early, as the pub is very small.
author: Christopher C.

description:
A good place to grab a bite and beer, but I feel its slightly over rated. 
And careful of which beers is suggested to you and you go with... My friend and I asked for a suggestion.. I think the beer we drank ended up being $15-$18 each :P

The food is good... if this were somewhere else, I would give it 4 stars, but there are so many great places to eat in SF, I feel 3 stars is good for Monk's Kettle in sf.

Staff can be friendly, and not... depending on the person/hipster serving you... not a reflection of the establishment, more so the mission "This is place is cool and I work here, so yeah. Whatever." attitude. 

A chill place to go to and grab a bite, bring a date, or just hang with the buddies as well. 

Also, it gets crowded... can have quite a wait, so go put your name down prior to your stomach grumbling, have a beer next door while you wait to squeeze in there.
author: Anish B.

description: Been here twice already and loved it both times. Even though I arrived near closing time, they still provided the same great customer service. The scallop was amazing and there's a great selection of beers. I wasn't in the mood for a burger when I went, but I'll definitely try that next time. It can be cramped but I still liked the overall quaint atmosphere of the place.
author: Michelle P.

description: 4.5+ star review. A little pricey, but super fresh food and amazing beer selection. Their pairings are artfully crafted, and even if you're eating at the bar the bartenders know the menu as well as the servers. It's small, so finding a place to sit sucks, but it's worth the wait.
author: Ryan H.

description: Staff is horrible here! First a guy with brown hair and a beard walks up, and says lemme' see what I have, never comes back. We had a group of 4 and asked for a table, three different people came up and said ok we'll see but never came back. We asked again and were told its 45 min wait, however we saw six 2 top tables available. So again we asked if we could put two 2 tips that were side by side to make a 4 top. Tall guy, tattooed, black hair, snidely said "oh well no because we have more people that need 2 tops that come in". WTF hello paying customers are here and nobody else waiting. So in essence he is waiting for "maybe" customers that MIGHT come in while we stand there appalled by what he has just said. Even if he had let us sit at the tables there would have been two 2 tops available. We felt discriminated against bc we are gay and weren't hipsters! I hope to email the owner about this, because I know they don't know their staff is turning away paying customers and making them lose money. Too bad because I'm spreading the word via social media to avoid this place. There's too many good placed in the city to put up with this horseshit. And fyi snide wait staff, you work as a waiter, get over yourself.
author: Risque B.

description:
Unlike others here, I would give props to the service and the beer selection, but not so much for the food.  The beef cheeks and polenta were good but not great. The burger and fries average.  The bright spot on the menu was the chocolate stout bread pudding with vanilla ice cream.

We will definitely go back for the beers but probably before eating somewhere else nearby.
author: Joe M.

description: Best veggie burger I've ever had (weird for a place like this, right?). The beer selection was amazing and the waiters beer recommendations were spot on.
author: Aubrey O.

description:
2 words: BEER SELECTION. 

I love my beer. I'm also very picky about my beer. If you're at a bar with a choice of great brews like Firehouse, Stone, etc. and I see you ordering a Budweiser, I WILL give you the stink eye. 

One of my favorite beers is Stone Pale Ale -- very hoppy, very crisp beer. None of Stone's beers are for the faint of heart. You remember that "Bitter beer face" commercial from many years ago? Yea, if you're not used to hoppy beers, Stone will do that to ya.

What's crazy about Monk's Kettle is that, yes they have my favorite brew, but that's not even one of the strongest or even the hoppiest of brews there. It's the equivalent of a fine restaurant with a world-renowned wine list -- This place has the most beers I've seen on tap outside of Yardhouse (which sadly, they don't have in NorCal). Just about every beer on tap is GOOD, too.

Oh yea, the food's pretty decent too. Goes great with.. what else? BEER!

This place gets very crowded at peak times so expect a LONG wait!
author: Kazu O.

description: Great beer, funny, nice informative bartender. I went there for lunch, which is probably the way to go, just tasted a couple plates, great flavor but some of the dishes were too heavy for me. Appreciated the beer selection, would like to see a greater variety of domestics from the midwest/northeast, overall great beer
author: T O.

description:
Cozy gastro-pub located a mere couple of blocks from the 16th Street BART station.  It's clean and relatively quiet compared to some of the other Mission bars where you pretty much end up yelling at the person next to you in order to maintain a conversation.

Decent beer selection, though overall, a lot of beers seemed to be priced on the higher range of what I would expect them to cost.  Perhaps there's a premium for being a hipster.

The only annoying thing was that even at the end of the night, we couldn't be seated at a table because we weren't ordering food.  It's a little off-putting since our group was probably spending as much, if not more money, on alcohol than someone who is buying food.
author: Marcin M.

description: Great selection of craft beers. Be sure to check out the beers on draft. It's worth going just for the beer selection, but the food is excellent too. They add a creative twist to their food, so even something as simple as a burger or chicken sandwich is much more than your standard pub fare. It is rather small and doesn't have many tables, and it tends to get packed, so be prepared to wait at peak times, but the staff will try to bring you a beer while you wait. Great service. Worth the wait and well worth the drive from the South Bay.
author: Susan S.

description:
Chef changed earlier this year, which worried us because the menu also slightly changed. BTW, we come here for good burgers and a nice beer. That's it. Nothing else.

Anyway, the new chef's burger it really really really delicious. So delicious that we had to write a note on our receipt to compliment the chef (first time we've ever done that!). My boyfriend and I agree that it's hands-down the best burger we've had, even better than the intense cheese spread burger from Bar Tartine. We don't even consider going anywhere else anymore at this point. Why pay $11 for a mediocre burger when you could pay another $4 or so for an excellent burger, right?

If you want a good beer and burger, come here. Be warned that the wait after 6:30 Thurs-Saturdays is pretty long (at least an hour), especially if you want a table. I'd recommend just eating at the bar if it's open. Though it's worth the wait anyway.

Also, service is always quick and polite. I also very much appreciate that the guy that handles the waiting list will call your cell phone when your table is ready, so you don't have to just wait there for the entire hour.
author: Angela H.

description:
Monks Kettle was absolutely AMAZING!!  Although, there was a 45 minute wait to be seated, it was totally worth it and I could see why.  Who doesn't want a spot in this place.

Their beer menu is pages and pages long.  Although I am a beer HATER, our waiter was able to suggested a beer I actually like ::shocked::.  

The food was hands down the best I had in San Fran.  Their bone marrow was FIRE!!  The burger was juicy and just perfect.  Even the soup was to die for.

I wish I lived in San Fran just so that I could go to this place more often.
author: Monica C.

description: This is one of my favorite bars in the city. Unbelievable rotating beer selection, great food, and a super friendly staff. Only negative is it can get pretty crowded at night but thats not a fault of the bar. Come here during the day and the experience is much more pleasurable.
author: Ross S.

description:
I was in the area with my parents (boy, were they struck by all the hipsters) when we walked by The Monk's Kettle; the windows were open and the delicious, wonderful, heavenly smell came wafting out as we walked by.  I INSISTED we give it a try, and we most thoroughly enjoyed it.

Each of us had something different (I had the special for the day, tuna, my mom had the brick chicken, my dad had the burger) but we were all silent throughout our meal, save for the occasional chiming in of "Oh my god, this is so delicious."  My tuna had such a wonderful flavor and consistency, the veggies and potatoes were perfectly done, and there was this sauce...OH that sauce!  Another thing all three of us enjoyed were the pickles (strange, I know).  They pickle their own stuff, and my dad couldn't stop raving about the string beans.  Try them.  You'll know.

My only complaint was that the service seemed really really slow.  But, honestly, it's not that much of a complaint; we were there in that odd between-lunch-and-dinner hour, and the easy pace that we got our food gave way to great conversation and bonding with my parents.
author: Addi M.

description:
An endless and unique beer list and excellent food, what's not to like?  I don't make it down to the Mission often but when I do, a trip to Monk's Kettle is always in order.  

They have an ever-changing list of beers on tap and hundreds by the bottle.  Its a great place to try something new.  The wait staff and especially the bar tender can recommend beers to try based on your tastes.  I always get interesting recommendations. 

The food menu is short but interesting and all good.  

This place is not good for groups over 4 and you should arrive early to get a table as they don't take reservations. It can get really crowded and tight on the weekends.

If you are searching for a great beer place in the city, Monk's Kettle stands among the best.
author: Ben Y.

description:
We were looking for a good lunch when we wandered past this place. It's small but we found seats at the bar. The selection of beer is outstanding and the people who work there really know about beer. They guided us to some good choices.

The food was amazing. We had the flat bread chickpeas and chicken sliders. On my! This was good food. Good sized portions and oh, so tasty. I"ll be back.

P.S. It only a couple of blocks from BART - easy to get to.
author: Ben Y.

description:
Oh my heavens! First time visitor tonight - I loved it so much I may have to come back and Yelp it again tomorrow! 

My mouth is proposing to the cook and my eyes are seducing the wait staff and I've only just begun.

Jonesing for a *really good* hamburger after 11pm in San Francisco can be a lonely experience -- the few places that serve a late-night burger don't do it WELL, and they sure as hell don't have rock star beers to pair with them.

Tonight I managed to park right in front of Monk's Kettle, and wandered into a gastronomic wonderland.

Samichlaus on tap PEOPLE!!!

The burger was incredible, juicy, thick, tasty, and seasoned with a lenient hand - served with a sophisticated onion jelly on a truly impressive fresh-baked roll. The aioli was an ephemeral and light unctuous treat that just barely graced you with its garlic genius before teasing you to dip another of the perfectly crisped fries.

No kidding - likely the best burger I've ever eaten. Seriously.

To round out the night of indulgence I ordered the pot de creme... creamy and rich without being overly-fatted, it was exactly what was needed to get me to finish the last of my Samichlaus.

Will I be back? Of course.

Should you go? NO. Really. Don't go. I don't want to have to scramble for a seat :)
author: SisterMable S.
