description: An amazing selection of Belgiums and other styles served by folk who know their product inside out. Crowds often pack the house, so be prepared to stand with your beer unless you're sitting down for some supper.
author: Norman G.

description:
Our "friendly" bet put me back $$ but it was well-worth it, despite the agonizing 45 minute wait.

D: There must be a TV inside since this is a bar.

L peers in.

L: Oh you're right, there is a TV!  I doubt it's playing anything sports related, this isn't your average sports bar. [with a smirk]

- In unison -

"Wanna bet?"

"Let's bet dinner!"

L & D shakes on it.

Upon entering, I took a quick peek at the tv.  
It was showing college ball. 
a%*$

Despite my failed attempt at a free meal, this unassuming Mission hipster staple held a surprisingly high standard for their simple bar fare.  

Although their organic fresh farm to table approach wasn't awe-inspiring to say the least, their vast selection of discerning foodie approved dishes were rather astonishing.

Items ordered:

Cornmeal fried oysters, house hot sauce, cucumber ketchup

Salad of frisee, roasted beets, grapefruit, pickled red onion, candied pecans 

Chicken paillard, bacon jam, frisee, acme focaccia, fries 

Three day ale bricked chicken, cranberry beans, harissa 

Harissa? Cucumber Ketchup? Bacon Jam?

Simply put, Monk's Kettle will satisfy your every whim whether it be an exotic Belgian brew, a classy $15 glass of beautifully rich Cab or endless plates of sophisticated and complicated dishes blending interesting flavors in the midst of a happening bar scene in the middle of Mission.
author: Lisa W.

description:
Absolutely love Monk's Kettle.  Order the burger, they're the best. I've only been here during lunch time but I've never had to wait to get seated.  Food is great and service is fast. 
Ambiance is a little on the loud side but well worth it.
author: C R.

description:
I went on a pub crawl for my 30th earlier this year. This was my last stop. I was really hammered, but from what I remember the food was good and the beer was EXCELLENT. Though beer starts tasting better the more I have, so it's really hard to tell. I do remember certain things, like the bartender buying me a beer for my birthday (THANKS!) and people politely ignoring me as I couldn't really speak without saying, "hey, you know what? It's my birthday". 

They do this thing while pouring your beer that's really quite fancy and impressive if you don't know what they're doing (right here!).  But seriously, this place was awesome as they put up with me, servered a great selection of beer and had a very cool atmosphere.
author: Eric N.

description:
New Year's Eve with no dinner reservations once again- when will I ever learn? 

After hopelessly driving through the mission trying to find a place for our party of six, I remembered Monk's Kettle.  And thank goodness, because otherwise I'm sure we'd have been eating burritos for dinner.  I was as a little worried about the limited menu (giant pretzel, anyone?), but it was open and they even had a table ready for us in seconds.

The place is small, but has a nice ambiance with a long bar and tables/booths off to the one side, and a semi-open kitchen in the back.  The owner and waitress were incredibly helpful with suggestions.  

Huge menu of beers, with the beers on tap being a better value than bottled.   My boyfriend tried the Bear Republic Hop Yard Rye, which he loved.  I had a black current cider and a friend had a tall glass of Pislner Urquell.  

The charcuterie plate consisted of pate, salami, prosciutto, some type of dried out pulled pork (everything was great except for this) and just a few slices of bread, which was clearly not enough for our table of five.  They had no problem bringing out more bread for us to eat with the pate.  The salads were large enough to share.

They had a NYE menu along with the regular menu.  The two special entrees listed were crab cakes and steak. Most everyone at our table ordered the NY steak at $22, which came with sides of mashed potatoes and chard with bits of bacon.  This was definitely the dish everyone was left raving about, especially the perfectly cooked cuts of meat.   

One friend had the crab cakes, which at $14 for two cakes and nothing else, was not nearly enough food to be listed as an entree.  I had the shrimp pot pie topped with a phyllo crust, at $15; it came chock full of seafood, though the flavors were standard.   

For dessert we tried an amazing chocolate fondant made with beer (!) and the chocolate cheesecake.    In all, a good meal.  And much thanks to Monk's Kettle for saving what could've been a horrible New Year's Eve!
author: Joanne G.

description: Great bar! And Great Food! The line is always long during the weekends as expected. Cocktail list is in depth.
author: Antonio I.

description:
Stopped by Monk's Kettle last night for the first time in a while. I was able to grab a seat at the bar in short time and asked the bartender for a recommendation - he poured me a taste, I liked it and so got a glass. Unbeknownst to me, he poured me the most expensive beer on tap ($13.75) It was good and maybe he based what he gave me on my info to him (I wanted something similar to Kwok) but I did feel a tinge of up sell when I finally saw a menu and noticed the price.

On to food - I had the lamb burger which was fine, the patty had great flavor but the meat was lost in the giant bun (and what seemed like half a head of lettuce served with it) Fries were hot and crispy, really solid and addictive.

I dunno, I really want to love Monk's Kettle but once again just ended up liking it. It's a great place to try some unique beer but you will definitely pay for the privilege. I still think La Trappe is a better option for the Belgian beer lover who isn't a millionaire.
author: phil h.

description:
Fuller's London Porter actually poured correctly!!! What a revelation!

This place is just awesome! amazing beer selection and awesome food (Make sure you try the cheese plate).

Down side: always crowded, they won't let big groups of ppl in.
author: Pawan R.

description:
Love the endless choices of beer. 

Great gourmet burgers to go with the beer. Nice chill spot for happy hour/dinner
author: Shivani S.

description:
Good beer...check.
Good value...that's a negative Ghost Rider

Got a second visit to this place.  The food was actually decent...though not a standout in the Mission.  Some people have been knocking them for it.  We had a special salad with some nice bitter greens and peaches...yum.  Also a respectable, although not amazing chicken pot pie.  Although they did do a proper puff pasty which makes me a happy man.

But what is up with the beer prices!  The beer is good and tasty, but these are some of the worst values I've seen.  When you look expensive compared to Suppenkueche, then you know you're in trouble.  Their Franziskaner Dunkel, clocking in at over $10 for a pour is almost double most other places.  So, if you want fancy beer, go to the Trappist in Oakland, Suppenkueche, or your other favorite joint in the city.  We're at 3 stars now.

Actually, I just subtracted a star thinking about the service...down to 2.  The service sucked.  Some hipster automaton was the waitress for the entire restaurant!  Long waits, no smiles, no friendliness, no water.  Thank god I was at this place with a cute boy :)

Dinner + 2 beers each = $85
Value = bad.
author: Ian P.

description:
Stopped in on a Tuesday night with a friend.  We were more hungry than looking for drinks & happy they serve food until 1 am (noted!).
We had a small salad, pulled beef on polenta and a hot caprese of sorts.  It was all yummy and the servers (we had 2) were both great.
I didn't expect such a *nice* place on 16th & happy to have discovered it :)
author: sUper j.

description:
Just because there is a line does not mean it is amazing. It can be all hype. THe beer list is outstanding, but a bit overpriced for some. The food is good but not what it should be for the cost.Great ambiance and experienced waitstaff. Friendly on a crowded saturday evening. I just think the food could use some help.
cheers.
author: Tamrin H.

description:
***Good***
Food = 4 / 5 stars. 
Beer Selection = 10000000 / 5 stars.

***Bad***
Gets crowded b/c its kinda small.

***Recommendation***
Bar Hazelnuts and a "Work for Tips" beer (brewed with Redwood blossoms).
author: Nick K.

description: Great beer selection and the food is super delish! Love the burger on the menu, definitely add bacon and an egg. It will make your day! I also love their truffle fries and always order an aioli sauce in addition. Yum! Go there in an early afternoon to secure seats because it tends to get crowded quickly.
author: Yina M.

description:
897 previous reviews - wow. Well here goes 898.

I got McCarthy's ale as it was probably the only thing that was under €5. We shared the fries, best fries i have had yet especially with the dips.

The bartender was shockingly knowledgeable and explained the brewing process, taste, history of the beers we pointed out. He let us sample them in leprechaun sized pint glasses which was rather amazing.

Side note:
It was an evening of too many times in my life colliding. My friend is from San Francisco but lives in Dublin and I was the tour guide for here. 

I used to live beside this pub so it got a bit overwhelming seeing images of my past.

 A guy from my hometown in Ireland was at the bar and we commiserated about our county's defeat... 

With all those periods and places in my life colliding at once, I must admit I felt rather lost... But the beer dissipated any soul searching.
author: Annie L.

description:
I mean really! This place has some nerve...
It's been sometime since I've visited Monk's Kettle and I must admit I've never been a fan BUT the hubby and I decided to check it out. There's always a ton of people - which I don't get, maybe ALL first timers?

We start off with the cheese plate. RIDICULOUS! You choose from 2 different types of cheeses. They have some nerve charging $13.50 for 2 small slivers of each cheese. The smallest slivers ever! Then they packed the board with tons of bread. I was offended.. For this very reason I won't come back - even though my complaint is hardly over. 

Then I ask our server how the black bean cakes are (sounded interesting).. It's her fav on the menu. I find this hard to believe.. Reason: They tasted like sand cakes.. Yes like the chef went to ocean beach and brought back the finest sand with him to prepare these tasteless sand cakes.. awful!

The beer was the best part, but I can get great beer anywhere in the hood. I'm over this place.. not going back.. EVER!
author: Monica S.

description:
We just needed a mid-afternoon snack and were wandering around the Mission, so we stopped in to the Monk's Kettle. I'm so glad we did.

The pretzels were amazing, the fries were delicious, the pickles were tasty, and the beer was outstanding. I had a Two Weeks Notice, and it was soooo good, with a very unique flavor.

I'd love to come back for a meal or another snack sometime. Apparently it's always super busy though!
author: Emily M.

description:
This is a fairly cozy place, it's a little hard to find but I really liked the old-fashioned London pub atmosphere.  

Great service - the waiter was friendly and prompt, not to mention hilarious.

I came here specifically for their famous pretzel, which comes with cheese fondue and special dijon mustard.  Apparently they are used to people coming just for the pretzel now, because the waiter was all, "So did it meet your wildest dreams and more?"  

Yes. Yes, it certainly did, and now all other food is ruined for me.  

That pretzel was melt-in-your-mouth soft, fresh, and served steaming hot, like the savory version of a fresh Krispy Kreme donut.  It went really well with the cheese fondue (it went well with the special mustard too, but I'm just not a mustard person).  

I'm coming back for more.  And the waiter is awesome.
author: Bee M.

description:
I really wanna give this place three stars or less because it's hard enough to get a seat here as it is.  Why would I want to exacerbate that problem by encouraging more people to congest this intimate venue?... Oh alright ...[Sigh]. In good Yelp spirit, I'll fess up to the smashing place that Monk's Kettle is and to what I was hoping would be more of a hidden secret than a hopping hang out.  

Holy smokes, the beer selection is absolutely out of this world!  I had a special stout the night I went named something like "An Arm and a Leg," appropriately so; as big and bold in flavors as an arm or a leg, it's likely that you'd give up one or the other for another glass.  The fries and soft pretzel appetizers I had were just so-so, but the hip vibe and beer more than made up for it.  If you can stand to wait 45 min or so, on a packed friday or saturday night, hell, almost any night, this place is worth a try.  Otherwise, be smart and try to make it early before the cue forms.
author: Paolo M.

description: Went here with an acquaintance who is a huge beer person. I love beer but can't see myself spending more than $20 for a bottle of beer. He ordered a bottle that was $130 and gave me a taste and honestly, I didn't see what was so special about it. Stuck with Franziskaner and split a chicken pot pie that was to DIE for! I might just go back if I'm in the area for the pot pie and I don't even usually like pot pie. It was too crowded and I felt like people were on top of me but I guess that's how it goes in a lot of places in the city. Don't come here if you are clausterphobic when it is busy.
author: Beini Q.

description:
I just want to say that I thoroughly enjoyed my experience at this place. It was for the BF's early birthday and we both loved it. 

But there were some exceptions, so we'll get those out of the way first. It got pricey quick (but it was for a special occasion so I let it slide), it got packed quick and there was only one bathroom - it is a tiny restaurant after all.

But the beer selections are phenomenal, the ahi sandwich was scrumptious (and I don't use that word a lot) and OH! the fantastic fresh baked chocolate cookie in a skillet ... and the bread pudding too! Yes, I got TWO desserts! The beer I loved the best was the Scottish beer called Traquair. The servers were very knowledgeable about the beers even though the ones our server suggested paled in comparison after that Traquair. 

I highly recommend finding alternative transportation there as parking is typical frustration Mission-like parking. Also get there early, like 5 or 6pm to get little to no wait time. The atmosphere was very pub-like (close, warm, friendly) and I loved the little chalkboard where people just drinking could doodle. Just keep it clean people! Meh, there won't be too many kids there ... have at it!!! Ha ha!

If you're looking for WAY more than your typical choices of beer and basic but ever so tasty pub food this is the place for you!!!
author: J. C.

description:
No doubt, the beer list is phenomenal.  Everyone knows that.  There are few places you could considering going to before Monk's Kettle if you want to try some quality beer.

But I wouldn't say the same about the food.  It's not that the food isn't good - my girlfriend and I both enjoyed our meals, and the menu is well constructed to match well with most types of beer - it's just not the best for the price.   I'd call it more of a pub with (overpriced) food,  than a gastropub.  

My $25 beef short rib was not worth the price I paid.  The scallops we split as an appetizer were delicious, but considering the three small scallops and single slice of wrapped bacon went for $15, I can't say the value equaled the quality.  My girlfriend enjoyed her faux beef burger, but it didn't blow her away (it was priced more normally, however).

I'm not saying I won't return to The Monk's Kettle - I definitely will - I'll just go in with a different mindset.  I think the perfect thing to do is to drink beer and split some of the smaller plates.  The price will be more reasonable, and you'll enjoy great brews and appetizers.

My quick tip is to get there early or go on a week night, as it's a small place and the wait can get pretty long.
author: Will A.

description: There isn't much to say as I've been here three times and only drank here once as the other two times, my man and I were completely overlooked and ignored.  I wanted to like this place...Unfortunately, I don't like my drinks with a side of attitude.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
Pretty pricey, OK beer. This is coming from my major beer snob husband. Burger was delicious!
We were there at a weird time so got a table right away-bonus!
author: Jessie O.

description:
This is a great place to bring people. The bartenders are super nice (especially for the Mission) and there's an enormous beer selection. Some might call the beer expensive, but truly, it's high quality stuff and I've 100% paid more for the same beers in other restaurants (cough, Public House, cough). $5 for an Allagash White on tap is ok by me.

The food is universally pleasing and American, which is why I like suggesting this place when I'm doing dinner with friends. The Ahi Tuna sandwich is out. of. this. world. Also mac+cheese plus bacon. Yum.

They don't take reservations, but they'll take your cell number and call you when there's a table so you can pop over to another one of the 45 bars on the block while you wait. I personally prefer to wait there so I can drink as much good beer as possible, but it's a small place and you're definitely in the way of the wait staff. Would be tough for a really large group, but if you're a 4 top you're golden.
author: L C.

description:
I finally got to try this place after months of plans that had fallen through - when finally, victory! I had a table reserved at Monk's Kettle and was ready to eat and drink my heart out.

It was the kind of Friday where I just wanted to drink myself into a tasty beer oblivion - I really could have drank anything -  but I was pleasantly surprised when both the beer and dinner were both amazingly delicious.

I had the burger with onion jam, which sounds slightly weird but is actually amazing. Surprisingly, this was one of my favorite burgers of all time. It was admittedly a little greasy, but the meat was cooked to perfection and  the onion jam added the perfect amount of kick. The fries were to die for.

Monk's Kettle is crowded, but it's a fun spot with attractive bartenders. It's worth a shot.. =)
author: Genevieve W.

description: I have loved Monk's Kettle for a long time as a cozy, but beautiful place to come for a fancy or unique beer with a date, but I now I'm singing its praises for the food as well. I had the arugula salad on a whim, and it turned out to be absolutely amazing. And I am a major salad snob. The lemony dressing cut through the bitterness of the arugula, and I was happily surprised that they didn't overdress it like so many places do. It was fantastic, and the beer, like always, was also great.
author: Diana H.

description:
It's like a bad relationship your girlfriends have been telling you to get out of forever.
He is a d***. 
He is bad for you, your girlfriends would say.
But you just adore him.  

Monk's Kettle is kind of like that for me.

I was once one of those relatively lucky people who could eat whatever she wanted without getting fat....only until Monk's Kettle re-introduced me to the magnificent yet extremely fattening world of beer . Now I'm doomed,experiencing the agony like the rest of America - battling against temptations (and losing the battle most of the time). Now I have to ask cliché questions like, "do these jeans make me look fat?" 

Monk's Kettle doesn't even offer that great of food, expcet maybe the french fries with awesome aioli dip. 
Monk's Kettle isn't even all that affordable. 
Monk's Kettle is crazy popular and often crowded at desirable hours, so he is available to me during the "late night booty call" hours only. 

But ever since I left SF, all I can think about is the rich Belgium ale at Monk's Kettle. 
That nice and dim space with shining beer glasses so easy on the eyes....the understated sexiness!
That chill attitude - hey, I'm still open and available for you even after you work til midnight...(the kitchen is open until 1AM).

I think I'm going to give him a call back.
author: Nana N.

description:
3.5 stars.

If this place lived up to its menu or its promise, it would be an easy 4-5 stars. But there are problems.

(1) Price. Some beers are weirdly overpriced. I'm not talking about the exotic beers that you can't find anywhere else. It's fine by me if they're overpriced.

(2) Price. Some of the food is weirdly overpriced. Tri-tip with potatoes and greens for $24? That's about $22 more than the ingredient cost. Gordon Ramsay would be proud.

(3) Kitchen. Although the menu has promise, the execution is inexperienced. On one visit, I had a lamb burger. Good presentation, garnish was fresh, taste was fine but ... the burger leaked juice like it was a ripe orange and I'd poked a hole in it with a straw. When I finished, I had a puddle that filled the bottom of my plate. If you're using frozen meat, that's cool, but you might want to mix in some bread or starch, or fork them when they're cooking, or something. On my most recent visit, I had the abovementioned $24 tri-tip dish. The potatoes were cooked perfectly (awesome!), and the meat was excellent, but although the veggie (a stringy relative of bok choy) was tasty, it was served whole and slightly undercooked, and I was picking it out of my teeth for an hour. More disappointingly, the sauce reeked of raw garlic. Pardon me, raw garlic on beef and potatoes?

So, I dunno, it's a cool place to spend $50+tip for lunch and a buzz, but I'm not sold yet.

One of these days I'll find a place in the Bay that is as nommy for a beer lover as Philadelphia's Monk's, or Georgetown's Brickskellar, but ... not yet.

Still, tweak the prices, and get a more experienced chef involved, and you could have a real winner.
author: Joseph H.

description:
Let me start off by saying that the food is delicious.... once it finally shows up.  

The problem with this place is that they need to figure out if they want to be a gastropub, a restaurant, or a beer bar.  Their menu is too big for a bar menu, the space is too crowded for a restaurant, and too pricey for a gastropub.

That said, paying 17 dollars for a 6 ounce pour of beer is highway robbery.. especially when it is a microbrew from portland, not some crazy belgian trippel that has been poured over the asscheeks of some hundred year old monk to "improve flavor"


TL:DR- 
Slow Service
Pretentious
Overpriced
Delicious Food
Not good for groups
author: Julien E.

description: Oh why do we get bloated from beer so easily? There's so many good choices of beer that you can only try here! Their list of beer changes as well depending on what they have brewed. This is a cozy lil spot and they serve food as well.
author: Nancy N.

description:
I love this spot, never a bad a beer and always some great food. A quaint cozy spot that get busy real fast in the late hours. Great beer will cost you so Just make sure you have the funds. The service is great and I love their pulled pork sandwich. 

They also have different beers at times depending on the supply and season. Have a beer for me and then have another!
author: Samuel B.

description: Good food. Mmm chicken pot pie (sadly seasonal, assuming it ever returns). Interesting drinks. One of our friends ordered a beer that tasted like meat. If you can get that here, you probably can get anything here.
author: Heather R.

description:
Excellent, knowledgeable bartender that helped us interpret the extensive beer menu. Gave us tastings until we settled on something we wanted a whole glass of.

Seriously fantastic burger ($13) that came with pretty good skinny fries.
author: Catherine H.

description:
The name, Monks Kettle conjured an image of a Germanic kind of restaurant, picnic tables, big breasted fraus serving 1L steins, but instead what we got was more of a modern bistro sort of feel. Despite my preconceived image being shattered, and it being a lot smaller than I expected, everything in this place was top notch. Now I should add that my friends and I hit this place on a lazy sunday afternoon and even then there were plenty of people in there, but there were still a couple of empty tables. 

The beer list is extensive and the polite and professional servers had obviously been schooled in the beer selection and the various pouring techniques. I had a Duvel (not very adventurous, but a nice glass, and an easy start), then we moved on to what could be this bars signature beer, the Pauwel Kwak, which comes in a glass that can only be described as a miniature yard, and it's own wooden stand (see attached picture). We also tried to order a beer described as an "Eisbock" in which the water in the beer  is frozen and the ice removed to increase the alcohol content to about 12.5%, unfortunately they had been out of this for a couple of weeks and had not received a resupply yet. I will be keeping tabs on that as I just want to have tried an Eisbock. 

Beyond the beer, the food was heavenly, this included a couple of baskets of fries which were thin, crisp and delicious, a giant prezzel with beer/chedder dipping sauce, a fried goat cheese with tomatoes and garlic on baguette slices, and a mushroom brusectta. Everything was delicious and paired brilliantly with the beer.

I imagine on a busy night, and yes I've heard this place gets very busy, the service could suffer, but for us we had the perfect sunday afternoon here and i could not fault the experience.  

Oh, and did I mention they are open until 2am and their kitchen is open until 1am!
author: Karl L.

description: Very cool gastropub with a lot of delicious beers on tap and food. Small and usually a wait though.
author: John L.

description: Really enjoyed this place - a great beer list, and the food is pretty decent. We were looking for a place with food and good beer where we could bring our one-year-old to meet with friends, sat outside on a nice day and Monk's Kettle was perfect.  The pretzels are a great way to start accompanied by a beer.
author: Erin S.

description:
Great date spot, kinda crowded on Saturday night (super actually) and for good reason - superlative beer selection (undoubtedly unrivaled in this small town) page after page, rife with descriptions in detail akin to fine wine, dinner menu complete with pairings. 

For a meat-centric menu I like how they don't punish the vegetarians with crappy sub par meal solutions... Our waiter was fantastic, pointing my companion and me to the out of this WORLD veggie burger (cheese throughout all melty gooey so you "get a little of everything in each bite") and I had some kinda expensive and dainty lentil thingy - it was also divine. 

Imbibed on lavender beer, started off with olives from 'old henrys farm' the 90 year old man who Only Grows Olives - waiter said he normally doesn't like olives but these are so good they are the foundation of the Exception. 

We also became very fond of the blue cheese apricot jam combo - wooot.

Also, I had mushrooms, and enjoyed them. And I hate mushrooms, so, alls good at the Monks Kettle. 

Good branding identity and atmosphere too. Oh and a sexy freckled bartender, yee haw!
author: E W.

description: I love the cooking at this place...which is what I go for.  I am on a medically required very low sodium diet...not an easy customer to accommodate, but the wait staff and the chef always take the time to work with me to produce something delicious that I can eat.  Moreover, in the spirit of true hospitality, they always make me feel that it is their pleasure to meet the challenges and they are warm and welcoming.   Couldn't be nicer.   Couldn't be more delicious.  Couldn't be more appreciated.
author: Karen Z.

description:
Was in SF briefly on my way to NYC.  It was the first meal I had in the US since I left about half a year ago.  My sister recommended this place and she did not disappoint.  

The place is small to medium sized restaurant.  The bar took most of the space.  The decor was welcoming and cozy like a laid back modern pub.  Alot of wood.  Alot of people just standing/sitting at the bar talking and drinking.  Like 8 small tables.  

The beer selection was vast.  I didn't know that much about beer but I did enjoy that they had rec under all the dishes they had.  So if you for some reason did not want to ask the waitress so a rec you could have something to go by and try out their numerous beers.  I'm sure there has been alot of reviewers detailing the types of beers they serve so I won't really wanna attempt to do a poor job at explaining what they have, but simply said it's has anything you would want. 

I ordered the toad in the hole.  It's basically really awesome sliced sausage on top of a pancake in a metal pan thing.  It was tasty.  I totally recommend it.  For the main course I got the tri-tip and duck oil potatoes.  That was crazy good.  Meal was tender and the potatoes very delicious.  

The food and the selection was great as was the beer they had there.  I would totally go back again.
author: George L.

description:
When the beer list is longer than the food menu, you know you're in for a treat.

My friend just brought me here the other night, so this is a review based on only one visit, but it was so amazing I had to write about it anyway.

It was a Monday, early evening, so the small venue hadn't gotten crowded yet, and even when we left a few hours later, it still wasn't packed but it was completely full. Only a limited amount of seating besides the bar, which is still small.

The low lighting and clean interior let me know that this was going to be a nice dining experience, but not too pricey.

The guy behind the bar came over to bring us menus and take our orders. He was very good about waiting for us to figure out what we wanted and give us time to consult the menus. When he brought out our beers, he had the appropriate glasses and excellent wrist movement for pouring. It was an amazing treat to watch.

We ordered our food and drank and talked. The music was low and nice and the conversations of other patrons floated around us without being too loud. Unfortunately the item I ordered off the specials menu was incorrectly listed and they were not preparing it that night, so I switched to the chicken pot pie. My friend got the BBQ pulled pork. The food came out piping hot and delicious.

All and all, i really enjoyed the relaxed atmosphere with a nice beer, delicious food, and good company. I'm sure the place gets louder/crowded on the weekends as it has an excellent location and a selection of beers that rivals just about anywhere. There is truly something for everyone on the beer list :)
author: Cat F.

description:
If you're tired of being manhandled, pillaged and raped just across Albion on the sidewalk in front of Delirium, stop on by this place for a nice, quieter scene.

Some of the reviews complain about the prices, but guess what - I will gladly pay $4+ for a good beer because it scares all those $hitty Pabst drinking hipsters away!

Aside from further gentrifying the Mission by bringing in a place like this, it is welcome in my mind in a slew of taquera's, corner stores and dive bars.

As a vegetarian it is nice to see them give effort to cater to us, but I still have yet to try their options for a meal.  I did however have a giant hot pretzel that came with a nice cheese sauce AND a nice stone ground mustard.  Let me tell you, that mustard alone was worth the entire price of the pretzel!
author: Jason F.

description: Cute bar! Good atmosphere and selection of beers & wines. Bartenders were very attentive. We didn't eat but the food looked amazing so will definitely come back.
author: Kelly M.

description: Awesome menu, awesome drinks. Even their side salads were amazing. A little expensive and a bit of a long line on a Saturday night, but totally worth it.
author: Kim K.

description: The Abyss 2010 cellar aged and the chocolate bread pudding = Life is complete. Charcuterie plate was amazing... Get the terrine. Tons of hard to find brews on tap plus a whole vintage section.
author: Katie H.

description:
OH MAN. The beer list here is awesome. They also have a huge selection of glasses so that you  can get the full effect of the aromas and whatnot of your beers. Though this place is in the Mission, it is quite the classy spot to get a couple brewskies with friends -- it is a tad pricy though, and can get super crowded.

AS FOR THE FOOD. I got the chicken burger--it had peppered bacon (AMAZING. GET ANYTHING HERE WITH BACON) . Sorry that was my inner fat kid that couldn't help coming out...I dunno what they do to the bacon, but its extra amazing here.

My friends got burgers (great) and salad (average). I'd definitely say go for the appetizers if you're gonna chat over some beers--mac n cheese, and the huge pretzel with cheddar beer ale sauce and mustard yum yum yum yum.

Thanks Monk.
author: Samantha R.

description:
New place indeed, and headed in the right direction. 

Many folks gave them a bad review based on service quality... which is an absolute mystery to me considering every aspect of our experience was solid. 

Me, my concerns are I'm seeing the food as a bit overpriced for what it was. Sure, they have some exotic beers that are bound to be pricey, but for the prices they're charging for eats they need to bring the offering up a bit more.

I'm going back.
author: Joe R.

description: This place was a lucky find this last Labor Day weekend.  My boyfriend and I went out in search of dinner around 9:00 and nearly everything was super full or was closing soon.  We ended up here at about 10:00 pm, got a seat at the bar pretty easily (they have Pliny the Elder on tap, omg!!) and had a drink while waiting for a table.  Dinner itself was absolutely wonderful.  He had the burger, I had mussels and both were perfect.  The white wine sauce with the mussels was the best I've ever had and the prices were very reasonable.
author: Amber Y.

description: We came here for a mini-celebration on a Thursday night. It was fairly packed but we found a place at the bar and we're blown away by the beer selection. Also the staff was incredibly patient and helpful with our questions (allergy issues). They recommended the "half chicken under a brick" and made the mussels for us without garlic. EVERYTHING was delicious, service was courteous and prompt. We'll be back--I can see how it would be easy to spend a lot of time here!!!
author: S H.

description:
Because it's become the hipster hangout, you can no longer get in to eat.  And last time we were there, we noticed significant changes in the food.  The lambburger was dry and overcooked.  The fries were definitely pre-made frozen ones.  

It's too bad that this happens so often with restaurants -- they become victims of their own success.  They're busy, people love them, so they become lazy.  Bleh.
author: kevin c.

description: They don't really advertise flights, but that's what we came in wanting. The bartender said he'd see what he could do, then created a custom flight based on our meal and then explained the reasoning behind the ones he picked. To top it off, he only charged us $10 for the flight. We were impressed with the service and enjoyed the food and beers too.
author: Mariel P.

description:
Some things just keep getting better with time.  Some things age well.  Relationships can be that way.  Some start all red-hot and exciting, and then, one day, you're glancing across the table and you think to yourself "Has this person ALWAYS been incapable of having even a single significant thought?  Have I really gone this long without noticing this?  I would jab this steak knife into my thigh if it would end this conversation right now so I wouldn't have to endure even one more second of it."  Some start all hesitantly, in screwy fits-and-starts, and then catch like the motor of an old Motown muscle car, content to purr delightedly for years so long as you regularly add fuel and lube.

I really can't help you with the lube part, which I meant totally metaphorically, BTW (submitted for your consideration: compassion is the sine qua non lubricant for any well-oiled relationship), but if you need fuel, Monk's Kettle is the place to go.  And when I say that, I principally mean that you need to go there ONLY and SOLELY when I'm not there, because there just isn't that much seating, and I always feel weird when I have to throw people out.  I mean, I still do it, but I feel weird about it.

You can now find me at The Kettle (I will also accept "TMK," but only when used completely ironically.  Thankfully, this is The Mish, and half the residents only know how to do things ironically.) on an almost weekly basis.  It took a long time to convince me that this was a relationship worth working on, fostering, fondling, enriching, extending, expanding.  Did I just say fondling?  Did I just write something as though I was having a conversation with you where I couldn't just glance up at the screen and know what I had typed?  Yes.  Yes I did.  And I'm okay with that.

The food is fantastic.  The beer selection has been cited as a cause for relapse in 5,329 AA meetings (for awhile, they had an on-site sobriety buddy/mentor/sponsor/coach/whatever the hell you call those guys, but they discontinued it because even they kept getting hammered and drunk-dialing college girlfriends.  (Sample excerpt: "When I returned to the laundry room and found that you had carefully folded all my clothes that I left in the drier for hours, that's when I knew you and I were meant to be together forever, you whore!  Why did you leave me?").).

Listen: there are a lot of places in this city where you can go to experience snobby bartenders, get overcharged, eat crappy food, and generally be treated poorly.  It's just like that string of horrible, abusive, unhealthy relationships you've been in over the years: you can keep doing the same dumb crap that you've been doing, or you can lose that zero and get yourself a hero.  [People totally still say that, right?]  Me, I say life has enough pain without self-inflicted Bad bAr Relationship Syndrome (or BARS, for short.  All rights reserved.).  Do yourself a favor, and follow my lead.  And if I see you at TMK [I'm makin' it happen!], I'll buy you a drink.
author: Ben P.

description:
I recently discovered this place through a friend a few months ago and I've come back so many times since then. I don't really know where to begin other than this place is AWESOME! This place has a large beer selection with an updated menu every time I come.  The staff is very knowledgeable and will explain the differences and recommend something for you if you ask. They will even give you a small sample if you like. My favorite beer so far is the Belgium triple, aromatic, smooth, n packs a punch if you have 1 or 2 too many!

Since the place is rather small and gets busy, for best service and dining/drinking experience, come on the weekdays around Tuesday or Wednesday.
author: David H.

description:
Ok I think I am in love. My favorite bar in the area has been the Rose and Crown in Palo Alto for a long time. This place reminds me of that, except with better food. An enormous beer selection in both bottles and really interesting taps too. The staff here is very knowledgable too. I heard recently that they actually have a beer sommelier who I think I actually talked to. Pretty knowledgable and enjoys his job :) Anyways I ended up with a russian imperial stout from stone, which in my opinion is sort of tasteless but potent. The potent part was what did me in, so I then sort of forced myself to eat a burger and fries before I left. Holy crap was that good. I was wanting more of the burger on my way to the next destination sooo much. I will return. 

My only problem with this place is that it's loud and crowded so it is sort of hard to make it a regular spot. But if only it were a more open atmosphere I would be here I think at least once a week.
author: Greg G.

description:
If I had one night left in San Francisco, this is where I'd be, closing it down. I'd probably cry, too, when it was all over.

Owners are great, Sayre kills, and Adam the chef knows his craft. I look forward to their monthly beer dinners, well, monthly. Looking forward to Abbots, too.
author: AP R.

description:
oh wow every morsel was delicious. And despite the variety of dishes they serve up - serious meat, exotic-sounding fish, cheeses, tasty salads and totally awesome desserts, the quality was top-notch through and through.

Indeed, the service was lacking, but they almost get away with it because the food did come and the beer was flowing. Expect a wait, definitely before and possibly during your meal, but if you can stroll down the street or grab a spot at the bar and savor the appetizers, it's worthwhile.
author: Anna D.

description:
Came here Friday night to continue my bday celebration with fantabulous friends who also love food. 

we came and waited by the bar for awhile. i had the belgium buffalo stout and thought it really smelled great, but my friends thought i was crazy. what's crazy is the beer and wine selection at this tiny place. Who knew it was so outrageous! 

we shared the bruschetta and appetizer plate and portions were fairly big and yum. i then ordered the pork chops, my friends had the pulled pork sandwich, the flank steak sandwich and beef short ribs. all were very good. i really loved my Brussels sprouts and potato pancake. mmm. is it me or are Brussels sprouts the latest rage along with "reduction"? 

anyways, good portion, not too heavy and not too greasy. SMALL place, very crowded. they played odd 70s action music in the background and it you could hardly hear it cause there's many conversations going on.

service is great. friendly staff, but they were always busy. 

thumbs up: atmosphere, hip-mission area, beer selection, menu, portions
thumbs down: SALTY!!! Maybe if I had more beer, but I felt like I drowned in the ocean at times. ... and pesky parking in the area unless you're lucky .. and you find one and shout, "MONEY!"

anyway,
author: Lauren Y.

description:
Monk's Kettle is one sweet place to grab fine Belgian ales.  The down side is that it'll cost you on average $10 for 8 oz.  The food is delicious, but they're not fooling me in purchasing an $8 pretzel!  If you're going to charge 8 bucks, it better be bigger that what they're currently serving.  Although the entrees and sandwiches are perfectly prepared, the place hurts the wallet when you leave $80 lighter for 4 drinks and 2 plates of food.

Nonetheless, it's a cool place and their selection of Belgian ales is fantastic.
author: Lisa R.

description: This restaurant was totally something that I did not expect.  The food there was not great and not worth what I payed for.  We ordered some kind of spicey almonds and we were told we would for sure enjoy them..yuk.  The Steak plate we ordered came with a small portion of meat and when I asked for some kind of sauce/topping to put on my meat, they told me they did not have any,,I then asked for atleast ketchup and they told me they didn't have any of that either.  I do have to say that the side order of mashed potatoes we ordered were delicious and that was the only item that deserved a 5 star rating.  The beer pairing with our plate order was terrible!!
author: Melissa N.

description: Had I been more in the mood for beer, I bet this review would be more exciting.  I know what you're thinking - how could she not drink beer there?  Will have to next time.  The lunch food was pretty good - fancier/pricier than I expected for a place like this.  I had the scallops which were nice but didn't blow me away.  My friend had the dish of the day which ended up being rabbit which she was raving about.  The daily pickles were tart and tasty (who thinks to pickle a grape anyway?).
author: Pam S.

description: If you don't know which beer to try, just ask for a flight! My friend and I both had a flight of 3 beers each, that way we could share and try 6 beers total. Good times.
author: K R.

description:
Large selection of beer, great warm-feeling ambiance, and absolutely excellent service. The bartenders knew the beer list inside and out, and they gave excellent suggestions judging by your likes and dislikes. The service was very accommodating and friendly!

We had the meat plate and the cheese platter (pictures uploaded), which were both delicious! Candied pecans... Goat cheese, with a few craisins, dipped in honey... *closes eyes*  MmMmMMmmm...

This place isn't really the greatest for big groups though. The largest group they can accommodate is 8 people, and since people like to lounge around and enjoy their beers all night, it may be a few hours before your group will get a chance to sit if there is already another large group.
author: Carol L.

description:
Came here for dinner on a whim with a couple of coworkers, expecting standard pub fare. When we started pawing through the substantial beer menu, we knew we were in for a treat. Pliny the Elder on tap? This evening's off to a good start.

Although beer drinking was the priority, the food menu proved to be equally tantalizing. Cornmeal-fried oysters were particularly tasty and really whet our appetites. Although we went the "boring" route with burgers, these were some seriously delicious sandwiches. The meat was a perfect medium-rare, and the bacon and onion jam combo made every care in the world melt away.

Expensive, but worth every penny (just keep an eye on those pint prices after two or three). I keep finding excuses to come back here with the uninitiated. I've yet to be disappointed.
author: Dan B.

description:
Not gonna lie, we didn't go here for the beer. We wanted a late dinner, had heard good things, and we were in the neighborhood. 

We ordered mussels off the small plates, and the tri-tip with brussel sprout hash.

The mussels were excellent.

The tri-tip was up there with one of the best I've had. Cooked and seasoned perfectly. Service was fine.
author: Jacob P.

description: I met some friends here last weekend for a pre-holidays dinner and drink session. They suggested this place cause they know I'm a craft beer lover and a foodie. The place was packed but who cares. If I'm out at a nice place with friends, I'm in no hurry at all. We enjoyed a few great brews while waiting for a table. Our bartender, Kai, even recommended a really great beer from Utah that I hadn't had before. He also threw out a homeless dude that was being a douche so extra props for that. Anyway, the beer selection was amazing. Huge draft selection and a bible of bottled beverages that are perfectly described, if you haven't the foggiest as to what they are. After we got a table, we ordered food. Their small plates aren't very small to our surprise. We ordered a goat cheese salad, steamed mussels, a garbanzo bean veggie burger and the amazing pork belly. Not one item we ordered was even mediocre. My only tip is to order some extra toasted bread for your mussels cause it's effing bombalicious dipping it in all the leftover sauce. I'll def be back again. I'm waiting for them to get the 120 Minutes back on tap, which they said should happen very soon.
author: Brian C.

description:
Be prepared for a long wait if you come here at night! Especially if it's Friday night, as the wait for a spot at the bar is usually a half hour, and a table is over an hour.

I also think this place is just slightly over-rated if you're coming here for anything else other than the beer. It's true, their beer menu is enough to stare at for hours on end without being able to come to a proper decision, but the servers and bartenders are very knowledgeable can help you make the right decision!

In terms of food, it all seems just a little over-priced. Got the pretzel knot, fries, the bone marrow boat, scallops and the short rib. I thought the bone marrow boat was a little skimpy, as it's a huge bone, but it feels like there's only enough marrow for maybe 2 of the toast points they give you, not four. The scallops were a HUGE dissapointment, as for $15 I got three little nickel sized portions of scallops, and some unidentifable veg wrapped in half a piece of bacon. Fifteen dollars, and sitting at the pass for a good 5-6 minutes as I stared at the plate and prayed it wasn't mine? I think not. The pretzel knot is solid, as are the fries, and the short rib was pretty good, albiet a little stringy.

All in all, a solid place to come to unwind on a Friday night, if you don't mind the loud conversations going on around you, slightly overpriced food, and an amazing beer list!
author: David H.

description:
Over 300 beers.  This place by far has the largest beer menu I have ever encountered.  I was pleased to see they had 3 Kolsch beers!

Our server was fantastic.  He was knowledgable and attentive without being overbearing.  

The food is also great however a bit overpriced.  We ordered the muscles and scallops.  Each were somewhere around 13 or 15 dollars.  The plate only came with 2 scallops.  I would love to give them 5 stars but their food was pricey.
author: Claire M.

description: Great place to grab some good craft beers. We stopped by for a few drinks before dinner. Luckily, we were able to grab a place at the bar as it was packed. We also got a jar of the daily pickles to snack on. The food looked pretty good. My kind of place!
author: Thomas P.

description:
Came here again, this time after dinner. It was much more crowded this time since I came at night rather than on Saturday lunch like last time.  Nonetheless, after standing around for a bit, we were able to get seats at the bar. Then, as we started ordering food, we were ushered to a table. I didn't think the wait was unreasonable at all.

I got the Yakima Glory (10 oz) Black IPA Victory Brewing for about $5. Delicious beer! It's definitely a kick in the mouth best accompanied by some salty french fries in my humble opinion. 

They also had a Genmai Ale in a bottle. Genmai? Ale? Not my cup of tea, but our waiter said that it was his favorite ale ever. It was interesting and worth a sip at least. The flavor was more bitter and less floral than hops.

My still hungry friends ordered a chicken pot pie and a burger. I smelled the chicken pot pie and thought it smelled awesome, and it started making me a little hungry. I stole the french fries from my friend's burger, and they were cooked just the way I like them: crisp on the outside and soft on the inside. We split the Charcuterie Plate, which had subpar prosciutto but AWESOME duck prosciutto. I had no idea that duck prosciutto even existed. It is amazing.

All in all, I really like this place :) It's hard on your wallet though, harder than I would like, and hence 4 stars.
author: Wendy S.

description: liked the food, and the beer selection, excellent service...(the bad) $60 including tip  for two sandwiches, 2 lowest price beers and one glass (lowest cost wine)
author: Phillip T.

description:
I can see myself spending a small fortune just on the beers ( rabbit was alright a while ago. on the unremarkable side. bone marrow left me wanting. so mostly the beers).   

But the place is so sweltering its knocks off any buzz you've got going.
Any beer drinker should know this. 

You dont want your Goose Island stout with a side of hot air. It ruins the gulp.   

The wait for the table is well worth it that way you can ask the waitstaff to open a window for you.

( Again. Yes, the place is sweltering and not just from the people-exhaust ! )
author: Bridgetta R.

description:
Great location and tasty food. Slightly busy and cramped at certain times. 

Make sure to check the price of beers that the server recommends, last time we went we ended up paying over $60 for 3 beers that were recommended without knowing the cost. 
That was the only drawback, I think that if you're just going for beers and bits the server should tell you if its significantly more expensive than beers normally served on tap.
author: Tasha A.

description: We were so exited to try monks for our friends birthday! We got there early enough for a group of 5 or 6. I understand it is small we were prepared to wait and drink. The jerk door guy said we would have to wait outside. Wait what? We can't stand at the bar and drink? No. Ok we will take our business across the street. We gave them our $400 instead. On top of it he bad mouthed the other table of 6 saying they were giving him problems and assumed we would be the same. Shot severe attitude at the birthday girl. In a city filled with choices and tons of places to eat not smart to be so rude. I'm sad to say I can't even review the food that I have heard so many wonderful things about. ;(
author: Jennifer O.

description:
Really confused about some of the negative feedback about this place's customer service. 

My boyfriend and I went for dinner last night (a Monday) and were greeted at the door by a really pleasant guy who took our ID's, and started a nice conversation when he realized he and my boyfriend hail from the same city in PA.

Our waiter was nothing but helpful in answering any of our questions, and was polite and courteous.  They do move pretty quickly (which in my mind is great, I don't need the waiter hanging around my table all evening) so potentially that could be misinterpreted for rudeness/lack of courtesy?

We were also there on a Monday night (the place was fairly full, but we did not wait for a table) so maybe seeing how it would be again on a weekend evening would change things. 

Anyways, the timing of the meal was great, we did not wait long at all for apps/dinner/dessert.  They had a really interesting "new American" menu that all sounded wonderful - I got the mushroom risotto which was everything I wanted (comforting, cheesy, great bite form various mushrooms, and a hint of brightness from a few red peppers) and my boyfriend got the tri-tip over brussel sprout hash (tasty crust on the steak and so satisfying hash).


And the beers!! Oh hooray (This is mainly why I wanted to go). Great selection, and some interesting ones that I want to try!

It really was a great meal and experience! For sure going back.
author: Meg L.

description:
Four-and-a-half stars. :)

One day almost two years ago, a date knew that I was a big fan of beer so she surprised me with a first date to The Monk's Kettle. (Don't worry, I won't tell you a mushy story about how we are still together, blah, blah, blah.)

Ever since then, this is my FAVORITE gastropub to introduce friends to:
+ A great variety of delicious beer from just about everywhere
+ Very knowledgeable staff (management must really quiz these guys)
+ Large windows for people watching and sunlight
+/- A large (single) bathroom in the back
+ Delicious food (I usually go for the veggie-type burger. Although, I recently sampled my friend's butter bean cassoulet and it was very good. I will need to order a whole plate of that stuff to myself next time.)
author: Ileana H.

description: This is the cutest spot ever. Cozy and intimate. Hella beer. Wish the food was on par.
author: J. R.

description:
I really like this place, it has a great vibe and the beer menu can't be beat.  We asked the server for beer suggestions and everyone was happy with the outcome.  Love that they have Pliny The Elder!  The pretzels were excellent and they arrived piping hot with a stone ground mustard and cheese dip for sides.  I will say that you do need to stretch your idea of a pretzel b/c this one is more like a pretzel roll than a traditional pretzel.

However, the other appetizers we ordered were a total disappointment.  Both the ham croquettes and goat cheese flatbread were bland and in need of some seasoning.  I couldn't taste any ham in the croquettes and there wasn't enough of the sauce they drizzled on the plate.  I think they may have been frozen and not made on site.  The flat bread had a few dots of goat cheese, greens and potato and the bread was too thick and overpowered the whole thing.  We didn't even finish it and when the server asked if we wanted it wrapped we said no it wasn't very good.  He didn't seem to care and just said ok and took it away.

I would definitely return for the beer alone and will be much more careful about what food I would order.  There is too much good food in this town to eat something bland and overpriced.
author: Lisa K.

description: I feel confident endorsing this place for its beer selection alone. In fact, I lean heavily toward thinking that as wonderful as their suggested pairings are, the food menu could be pared down a bit. Had a good -- not great -- burger, but I look forward to coming back and being a bit more adventurous with the options. It's a nice, cozy little space, so be prepared to hear others' conversations and have yours heard. Don't take that as too much of a negative, though, for it's all part of the fun atmosphere.
author: Eddy P.

description: We took an Uber to go to this place. I simply loved it. Its a small place but have a huge selection of beers. If you are not sure which one to pick, you can ask them what kind of beer you like and the servers would suggest you one. Husband ordered the Burger and i ordered the Risotto. I LOVED the risotto. Its not as simple as it looks, i have had i t a lot of places, some make it more smoky and you can smell from 2 miles or some make it too salty that you can't even eat. The Risotto here was to die for. It had right amount of salt, cheese and herbs. Hubby loved his burger and the beer that was suggested. We would love to come back again
author: Madhuri D.

description: good food, big beer list, opened late, and I love the bread pudding
author: Adrian A.

description:
Came here on a Wednesday and it had just right crowd - busy but not packed. It's a hipster pub: quality beer selection, soccer on TV, burgers that have gone gourmet - all set against decor from West Elm or Crate Barrel (hey, it is in the Mission after all). 

Although this place looks like it would serve the perfect martini, they're beer and wine only. However, the beer/wine list comes in a 1-inch binder with a 3 paragraph introduction of beer, sour beer, vintage beer...I never made it to the wine chapter.

I had a great smoky lager and a full bodied porter with a juicy burger. Skip the carrot cake dessert and go for the dark stout chocolate bread pudding. Next, contemplate your next gym workout after all the carbs you've had.

Service was great - the waiter even ran down the block to return a forgotten scarf I had left behind! I'll definitely be back here again, perhaps after my next 2-hour workout.
author: Anne D.

description: The beer list can feel somewhat overwhelming to a novice, but it's arranged in a very approachable manner.  The staff has always presented themselves as knowledgable and willing to help.  The food is consistent and typical of Mission-area establishments (I mean this positively).  The prices unfortunately make this is a place I frequent less-and-less, opting for other establishments closer to 26th and Valencia (pizza and rotating 7 taps) or, say, in the Lower Haight (where bikers and beer-snobbery abounds).
author: Paul S.

description:
Strangely I had never been to The Monk's Kettle until two evenings ago. And while I didn't get to stay for the full gastropub experience, I did get to try two outstanding beers: the Raging Bitch Belgium-style IPA and then the Red Barn Saison Farmhouse Ale. 

It's a small space; the bar itself seats about 20, and there are maybe 3 booths for dining, so I'd recommend going in early, or even for lunch. The good thing about the intimacy is just that - you can talk quietly with your friends or make some new ones - everyone there is beer lover so you already have something in common. 

I wish I got the name of my bartender. She called my saison selection a "pretty" choice, so we had a good laugh over my manly rough and tumbleness, or lack thereof. Long story, short: I got over it, 'cause that beer was just about perfect.
author: Nish N.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE. I'm neither cool nor hip but I love beer. Oh. And food. And they are great at both.

Please keep Pliny in stock and I'll move in. Pretty please move to a bigger space at the other end of the mission corridor. I'm tired of standing.

Thanks for the additional tips, Yelp, as they are not "good for dancing." :\
author: Tracy Y.

description:
Beyond 5 star beer selection.  It goes on and on.  I asked the server about a farmhouse ale on draft that I had never heard of, and he turned into the human beer-o-pedia:  it was beer traditionally made after winter, before a farm has a new harvest, made with the last remaining grains, so it tastes like a horse blanket.  It would sometimes get bartered to laborers because the farms wouldn't have money yet.  Mmm, horse blanket.  I wanted something earthy to go with the veggie burger I ordered and the server sure did a great job helping.  If you're looking for a beer adventure and you're a tycoon, this is a place where you can blow $50 on some of the finest beers known to mankind.

Looks like meat eaters would do well.  My veg burger was a nice try at something hand made, and huge, but not super well balanced with flavor, too "beany" and fall-aparty.  At the price, I wasn't that pleased.  It was just OK and loses a star.

My friend took care of dinner as a well deserved reward after we hustled a truck of furniture around town for 5 hours.  (I got paid in beer with the beer that was made to pay people with.)  This was quite a hustling place too.  I didn't mind too much, but just be aware of what you're going to get.  Tables are packed in tight enough so you bump elbows with strangers.  Music's not loud but the crowd is.  If you wait outside for a table like we did I hope you're not afraid of germs or the 16th street creepshow.  One moon person wouldn't take "no" and I got a stream of swears at my back when I blocked him from nagging change from my friend.  Another moon person decided to orbit us swearing aimlessly at the air.  It's just what people do in the Mission, don't be alarmed.  Monk's kettle is a pretty good place to go and I loved being here with good company.
author: Pat L.

description: A focused little gem with great beer selection, good food, really well executed service/atmosphere.  Prices are a bit steep, but many of the selections feel like they'd be hard to find elsewhere.  Food is quite good, gastropub stuff.  Chicken sandwich with fries was 13, so not everything breaks the bank.  Fresh baked (or re-baked maybe) pretzels are now smaller and more puffy than some of the review pics show, but they were good.
author: Patrick S.

description:
If it were between beer and wine, I'd pick wine, since it's like water to me. So you're wondering why I'm reviewing Monk's Kettle?  90% of the place is beer, no. True, but I'm writing this review for one very important item.

Monk's Kettle has the best soft pretzel ever!!!

If you love carbs, pretzels, and cheese, Monk's Kettle is your place, best pretzel to date!
author: Terrine B.

description:
Great beers, knowledgeable staff, excellent burger!  
Gets really crowded on the weekends (obviously).  

Still love this place!
author: Deb S.

description: I came here for my birthday on June 2nd. We went after a dinner at Andalu, which is right up the street. I am a big beer person and I have ALWAYS wanted to try this place. I ordered the Allagash White, from Witbier Allagash, Portland, ME. It was quite delicious. I wasn't able to handle much more (It was my birthday and we had a bit too much fun earlier), so we decided to come back for lunch the next day. Seeing the place in the day was great. I love the decor, the feel, and just about everything else. The next day I had one of the their burgers, which were really really good. They have this bacon jam that is just delicious. I also ordered a Aecht Schlenkerla Helles,  Smoked Helles Heller, which is one of the most interesting beers I have ever tasted. It had a smokey flavor and reminded me of being at a campfire.  This place has so many beers, and there isn't enough time in the day to try them all, so I will definitely be back.
author: Raquel A.

description: This is a great place to come for a beer with your friends or a meal!  They have a great selection of beers!
author: Laleh J.

description: The beer gets 4 stars, food gets 3 stars and the bar guy (tall, lanky, blond/red hair w/beard) gets 5 stars for an overall 4 rating.  The beer selection is extensive and impressive.  Check.  The food is good to pretty good, nothing to write home about.  (note: only had the charcuterie).  The guy at the bar was absolutely fantastic. Double check.  Not only did he really know his stuff, but he was extremely attentive and accommodating which is a rarity these days.  His customer service attitude - without the sometimes typical beer snob meets barrista know it all badittude - really put me in a good place. I will be back.  A worthy stop.
author: Kenneth E.

description:
I had high hopes for this place, but all three times I was disappointed. I was surprised first by the service and then by the beer prices. I think this place's selection of beers has gone to it's head (or maybe they have horrible suppliers.) Most beers here are well over twice as much as other bars / restaurants and up to three or four times more than beer stores.

Take the Aventinus (a wheat doppelbock) from Schneider-Weisse brewery in Germany for example.

A 500ml bottle:
$3 to $4 from stores like City Beer / Whole Foods
$6 - from Lucky 13 (and even the "Mission Dolores" bar in Brooklyn)
$8 - from Suppenküche
$12 - from Monk's Kettle

How can they charge this much? I could understand if they had cheap food, but their food hovers around 10+ for salads, 13+ for sandwiches, and 22+ for entrées. The food was ok. I guess maybe they are trying to make this more of a dining experience then a beer destination, but with such a large beer selection, you would assume having a beer here would be easy. But this is not so. The place is always packed, narrow and if you're interested in a beer and some snacks, they'll stick you at the bar. Even toward the end of the night when a few friends and I wanted to sit at one of the 3 empty tables with some beers, they insisted that the tables were reserved for people eating dinner. Really? The place is winding down and you don't want our business? I guess the $100 or more we would spend drinking our beers in 20 minutes was just not enough for them.

For a better selection of beers and food, I'd go to La Trappe.
author: Alex L.

description:
Love this place!

It can be very busy, and they don't seat large groups, but then again this place is pretty small! It's definitely worth the wait if you want a table. I've never been disappointed. Everyone is always very helpful if you have questions about anything on the menu or beer! They have a great selection so if you love beer this is your place!

Food is amazing, love the pretzels!

Can't wait to go again!
author: Jaymie M.

description:
Beer list consisted of four pages of some great selections of American craft beer as well as some excellent European imports.  Most beer selections were bottled, with about 10% of their beer on tap. 

Food was excellent but a bit pricey, along with the beer.  The place is not large and seems to have become quite popular, so be prepared for a wait anytime near the dinner hours. 

Easy to get to with a BART station near by.
author: Gil D.

description:
Great selection of beer; beer pairing with food is awesome! Fried Oysters -  a must try!

Fun place in mission!
author: Avi S.

description:
Tip for Friday nights, get there super early not 7ish like me. The place is tiny and packed, and if you turn too fast you will knock someone out. The cool thing is that you put your name and number on the wait list, and the guy will give you a call when they are ready to seat you. This worked to our benefit because we could check out some other places. I thought the staff there was very nice, even with how busy they were. 

I had the burger, pretzel, and tried my friend's chicken focaccia sandwich. The pretzel was a bit overcooked but the cheese dip was awesome and made up for it. Burger and sandwich was packed with flavor and I could taste all the fresh quality ingredients used.
author: Jen K.

description: Great Hawaiian stout with spices here! This place has great atmosphere too. The food items were a tad pricey, but it would be no harm to come here once in a while. Everything else was good. Monk's Kettle is legit. Not bad at all.
author: Maximilian R.

description: Nice gastropub.  Great beer list (craft & Belgians).  Mussels were great.   Get the fries with house made mustard.  No reservations.  Friday night wait 45-90 mins.  Take a walk or grab a drink at a nearby bar...they will text you when your table is ready.  Parking is tough,  take BART.
author: Lyn W.

description:
Even though I'm a vegetarian who doesn't really like beer, I did like the Monk's Kettle. Yes, there's a wait. Yes, it's crowded. Ok, it can get pricey. 

I don't care. The pretzels and fries are worth it.
author: Leelah P.

description:
I came here simply because it was rumored that Monk's offered a gluten-free beer.  I was very pleased with the over-all experience I had on a Saturday evening.  After a 45 min wait we were seated and immediately greeted by our server.  After making a drink selection from the 586(3336$56 page beer menu, we asked the server for some GF dinner recommendations.  After a minute or two, a man approaches our table and introduces himself as the Chef!  Magical.  After eliminating the millions of foods I'm either allergic to or just strongly dislike, he suggested I try the burger, sans bun, with a side of grilled polenta.  I added blue cheese and "onion jam" to the mix and was amazed to discover that this was quite possibly one of the best burgers I've ever had.  Pair this meal with a bottle o' St Peter's Sorghum Beer and you'll find yourself in gluten-free heaven.  

My date ordered the "daily pickle" appetizer and although I thought it was hilarious that this was even an option....  it was awwwesome.   I'll be back.  Ohhhh, I'll SO be back.
author: Selina I.

description:
Excellent food!  I don't drink beer, but I hear it's pretty good too :)

Minus one star only because the wait is always so long.
author: Richa A.

description:
A nice corner bar. Clean and classic but somehow modern on the inside. Naw, it's just timeless. The interior works for both a pub and chic bar, but the service wasn't pretentious about it. Music was a great mix of indie that I'd never heard of before (then again, I'm not an indie-pop aficionado, classic rock, and even some older pop classics. A little something for everyone. Like I said; timeless. 

I went with the bone marrow and the beef cheeks with polenta. Both were what I was hoping for; meaty and reeking of that unctuous, lip smacking goodness you want in your roasted and braised dishes. 

I'll admit there was something of an intimidating about the beer menu. It's wordy, but then again they're trying to let those of us not in the know about beer know something about beer. 

Will I be back? Oh yes. The food was good, service was accommodating, and the beer was plentiful. I'll be back for sure.
author: Jay V.

description: Very loud and crowded. Beer selection is great. Very overpriced, I'd say at least 1-2 dollars more than regular dive bars for the same choice. Food menu is quite limited, unless you want to pay $25-30 for a plate of roasted chicken and steak. I probably won't come here for fancy food, but this doesn't even really meet the "gastropub" level of food. We ordered the only 2 choices on the dinner menu that's less than $15. And you look around, that's what everyone ordered too: Grilled Chicken Sandwich or the Burger. That tells you how much people like their food.
author: Angela Y.

description: This review is long overdue. Absolutely amazing food and drinks. It gets crazy busy so get there early or be prepared to wait. My favorite trick is to put our name in then walk around the corner to get Bi-Rite. Who says you can't get dessert first? The pretzel knots and cheese dip are heaven, the burgers are great, chicken focaccia is delicious...okay, everything is really delicious. Their beer list is equally impressive. Although I am not a beer drinker at all, our server managed to find one that I liked: The Golden Monkey. I was thoroughly impressed. This is my go to restaurant in the Mission. I visit as often as possible.
author: Kari G.

description:
Went here for Sunday night dinner. I'm not the biggest beer fan, but the pear cider was delicious.

We ordered croquettes to start, which were pretty great. Then we both had the chicken sandwich. It was a really good chicken sandwich, but if I were to do it over again I'd get the burger (which received rave Yelp reviews). 

My boyfriend ordered the chocolate bread pudding for dessert. It was like a moist, rich brownie with ice cream. I had to fight him to get some spoonfuls in. It was the prefect dessert for anyone who gets chocolate cravings--delicious.

The venue is small but cute. We ate at the bar, and the bartender was so nice. He joked around with the customers a lot and have great recommendations. Glad to have this as a go-to in the neighborhood, though it seems to get crowded a lot.
author: Eliana D.

description: Went for the Pliny, but the food was great, too.
author: Jo P.

description: I truly believe that the charm in this establishment is that it is cozy and not too big.  People should really just come to understand that this is not a good place for a group unless you get here early or get extremely lucky.  Overall, I try to come here as a party of two or execute patience.  My favorite times to come are for pre-dinner drinks or for a late night-cap.  Less of a chance for a wait and my whole focus here are the beers and occasional late night dessert.  If you have a hard time deciding or need help, the barkeep is more than happy to help and extremely knowledgeable.  Oh, and get the pot due creme to eat alongside a porter... Heaven.
author: Jenn N.

description: If you want a burger at 11pm in the mission, you have no choice but to suffer the terrible service at monk's kettle. I have never seen worse service in my entire life than we received here. It sent my friend's date running, inconsolable the way we were accosted by the staff.
author: Dan C.

description: That pretzel knot was fantastic!  The french fries with house mustard and aioli were off the hook AND.... daily pickle jar with pickles grapes!  Took my breath away, literally, needed to cough, spit, sputter and catch my breath. Wasn't expecting a pickled purple grape!   Go back?  YESS!!!
author: Heidi T.

description:
Just an overall awesome place. Terrific food, friendly staff and pages, pages pages pages pages of beer.

The staff here always amazes me with their extensive knowledge of everything it is that they are serving. I'm by no means a beer snob, but let's just say don't expect Bud Light to be on tap here. Instead, why not treat yourself to a brown ale that has an astonishing 12-13% ABV.

After only a few glasses of beer here I always look at the ABV column to make my choice...) and having some of their cooked to perfection fries, I'm ready to call it a night before midnight even hits. In this type of instance, I don't even care..
author: John B.

description:
Why ask if I'm serious if you're going to put it on the menu? Damn straight, I want an Oly!

Listen, I'm a beer snob/nerd/dilettante just as much as the next lady, but when it's been 10 years since I've had an Olympia, and you have it on the menu, I'm going to order it. And don't tease me when you bring it to the table and try to impress me with (incorrect) facts about the brewery. You should bother to try all of the beers on your menu before making fun of your customers.

Why the 4 stars? Great beer menu, great food, and otherwise all around sold place. If I lived in San Francisco, I'm sure this would be a regular on the beer-lunch rounds.
author: Heather H.

description: Overpriced food and beer.  Nothing really positive to say about it.  Our chicken sandwich had about an ounce of chicken on it and our burger was raw mostly inside and the chef was irritated and stared at us when we sent it back.  The bartender/waiter was condescending.  I asked for a reasonable priced pale ale, his choice.  He asked rolled his eyes at me and asked "How's does $12 beer sound?"  Um really...I guess I am in the SF.  Why is it okay that people in this city equate service to mean "They tolerated us being there."  It makes angry and I don't want to be angry when I go out to eat.  I want to be nice to people and I want them to be nice to me.  The fries were good but I won't go back.
author: Amy H.

description:
My first visit to The Monk's Kettle was great! Our bartender made sure to pour us exactly what we wanted by trying out a few different types of beers that were on draft. From there, I left it up to him to pick out my brew. He did a fantastic job. It totally hit the spot and he was very informative. Considering I don't know a whole lot about all the different types of beers here--I found that to be the best way to get a drink that you like. There is nothing worse than be stuck with a pricey bottle of beer that you aren't enjoying that much.

I did not get a chance to try the food, but I know I'll be back, so I'll have to taste something then. Also, need to come up with something better to doodle on the chalk boards surrounding the bar. All I had in me last night was a few squiggly lines and a heart shape. If you like beer and want to try something unique--go here!
author: Nichole P.

description: Yum! My friend and I came here around 11 and it was packed! It's a cute gastropub with limited space and very interesting dishes. Their beer selection is fantastic! I was drooling but we were so tired from walking all over the city, I didn't get a chance to try the beers..next time! I ordered their burger. So delicious! Fresh ground meat with onion jam, aged white cheddar and hop salt fries. I added bacon which was $3 but worth it. I took a bite of that burger and instantly my mouth was flooded with delicious flavors. The onion jam added a sweet taste and the aged white cheddar added dimension to the dish with the sharp flavor! I found the fries way too salty for my taste which was a bummer because the fries sounded promising! The burger was equally tasty the next morning, absolutely cold. You gotta come here. Also, the kitchen is open until 1 am which is great for people who are out drinking and want some delicious and interesting food thats beyond your basic concept of bar food.
author: Nicole A.

description: I love their beer selection...it is incomparable, BUT I was there two weeks ago and I happen to review my credit statement last week and even after giving a generous tip the waitress thought she should have been tipped more so she just added an extra $10....WTF!!! I never check the bill or my credit card statement but I'm glad I did this time.
author: M R.
