description: Overrated. Much better bars/restaurants in the Mission to be had. Recommended as a one-drink type stop. Food is underwhelming. Can't beat it on beer selection though.
author: Crystal J.

description: It doesn't get better than this place. The beer selection is terrific and the food is fantastic. The staff remembers you when you come back and are always friendly. This place is going to have a long, successful tenure in San Francisco.
author: Sunil R.

description:
I wanted to like this restaurant more, especially since they have 24 beers on tap and over 150 bottled, but the saltiness of their veggie burger knocked down the rating.

Pretzel Knot - solid appetizer; doughy on the inside and crispy on the outside

Fava Bean Brandade - this was a winning dish!  Loved the fava beans, mushrooms and grains that sat beneath the brandade

Spelt and Chickpea Burger - unfortunately this was extremely salty... too salty for me to even enjoy; accompanying fries were perfectly crisp
author: Jessica P.

description: Great beer selection but they were out of the one I wanted. Still - they've got a little bit of everything and a good selection of Belgian-style ales and San Diego beers which are the best.
author: Paul M.

description:
This is the most savagely crowded bar I've ever seen in my life. There's not even really a good place to stand. The drinks were alright, but I'm not in love with the place. I'd go back if someone else I was with wanted to go, but I wouldn't propose it myself.

I will say that they have good craft beer, but it's only the most expensive ones.
author: Kurt W.

description:
The atmosphere was cool and the beer selection great. The receptionist was really nice so it all started out nicely. 

What ruined it was the manager/waiter with the pretentious hipster beard telling us repeatedly that the bar is closing in 15 minutes. Dude, once is enough and I see the clock in front of me and don't plan on overstaying. After I told him he doesn't need to repeat himself, he confronts me with a tough look and says, "You can leave now."   What a frickin' douche bag.

I realize you need to be somewhat methodical in getting people out, but that's just no way to treat a customer. It's really too bad that he ruined the whole experience like that - but that's what I'm going to remember about the place.
author: Ken M.

description:
If you're super duper serial about beer, this is a definite destination for you. They have all kinds of rare, exotic, and expensive (mostly) ales, lagers, brews, and batches. 

They also give you free tastes of things and those bartenders are up on their beer game. I tried a cider here that was unlike anything I've ever had before. And man, those samples, though small, do add up to a nice buzz.

If you want to splurge for some finer beers in your life, this is a great place to go.
author: Sunny M.

description: ALL KINDS OF BEER HERE! I REPEAT...ALL KINDS OF BEER!!! BELGIUM, FRENCH, AMERICAN, GERMAN, ETC. Nice relaxing atmosphere, great service, you can order food as well. Didn't eat here cuz I wanted to try a couple more beers. You will not regret going here. Not too big of a bar, but its worth the wait if  you have to. We came here on a Monday night so it wasn't too bad BUT it started to get packed around 8pm.
author: Jacqueline C.

description:
about a year later, we finally get around to eating here. As I suspected, the food is indeed good. Hormone free meats, a menu mostly poised around seasonal ingredients, and the selection- OH, the selection of beer, ale, and other bubbly alcoholic refreshments!

JR and I have very similar desires when it comes to food, so we both ordered the cup of vegetable corn chowder and a burger, medium rare, with fries. The soup was wonderful, surprisingly. Light, yet creamy, chock full of flavor- the potatoes were stull in nice little chunks and didn't disintegrate, they even roasted the corn, which was a little bizzarre to me (corn in December? Who cares- it was sweet and delicious)!

The burger was really good as were the fries, ah, the fries I spied last time we were here! The meal was everything I had hoped for. You gotta love it when a place meets your expectations, 100%. Why can't the rest of life be that good?

The only drawbacks to this place is the wait, due to the size. We've tried to return twice since our meal in December, but ended up venturing elsewhere as the wait was over an hour long. Such a tiny place (and a tiny kitchen, I might add- the chef is a magician to churn out such good stuff in a place the size of a shoebox!) of such popular status makes it difficult to show up on a whim. Still, I'm not deterred. Belgian ale for lunch, anyone?
author: Mortiche W.

description:
I'd give this place 5 stars if it wasn't so freaking  difficult to get a table in the evening. 

This place does it for me. The food is great and reasonably priced. The beer is what you would expect.  What makes this place special is that there is a craft brew stewardship at work....  they have beer dinners monthly to showcase stellar brewing all over the US. I love that the patrons and staff abound with beer knowledge. It is all about promoting what is unique in brew. When I was there once, they had one beer infused with different hops - you could order the entire flight and savor the nuances of floral aromas. 

Who does that?
author: Layla M.

description: Met a friend for a beer here when I was in town recently. What a fantastic tap list, and the cheeses/charcuterie were to die for. Small, cozy. And the waiter/bartender said "cheers" with every interaction!
author: Renée D.

description:
Monk's Kettle is one of those places that you hear a lot about, but it's always so jam packed that it's hard to make the trip.  We got lucky with a table on a Sunday at 5, and stayed for dinner.  

There's no arguing about the beer - quite simply, they've got one of biggest and eclectic beer menus that I've ever seen.  And it's not like your average been garden where they've got all the standards beers in addition to the far out ones.  The most familiar beer on the menu as far as I could see was a Lagunitas special brew!

Food is a different story - we had the cheese plate as an appetizer, with the triple cream and blue cheeses from California.  This was pretty decent, although how difficult is it to arrange someone else's product on a plate.  The accoutrements (honey?, balsamic vinegar, musty salad greens, toast, unripened pear) looked pretty but were a little disappointing.  My lamb burger main was also decent, but really had nothing special going for it.  My friend had a pulled pork sandwich with apparently the world's sweetest BBQ sauce.  Quite edible, but just not exciting.
author: Robin S.

description: Great gastropub to go to too at any given time. The food is great, and each item comes with a beer style recommendation. The bartenders and servers are great at helping to choose what kind of beer you might be interested in when you go, and they do indeed have an excellent selection, both on draft and in bottles.
author: Varun B.

description:
Enjoyed an early dinner there yesterday. The bartender who was also serving the seated section was engaging, kind and very informative and helpful in considering their wide array of drafts available and how to pair it with the food. 

I had the Octoberfest which was fantastic beer. Started with the pretzel knot which paired with the beer cheese fondue was great. Pretzel was hot, crisp and salty on the outside soft and chewy on the inside. The mustard on the side didn't pair as well as the cheese. 

The chicken sandwich isn't worth the time. The chicken breast was barely a 4 oz. portion if that and covered maybe half the bread which left the thick crust on the outside by itself. The only redeeming factor is there was leftover beer cheese to dip the crust into. 

Colleague got the hamburger which he said was very good. Both sandwiches came with fries which were solid, but nothing to write home about.
author: Michael I.

description:
Update:  Maybe they have my picture at the door to make sure I never make it through it?  I dont get it, Ive been denied entrance about 6 times total, either because it was too full, reasons described in review below, or because the host decides, no joke, that the two people he allowed in before me and one friend were the last to be allowed in.  I saw plenty of room to stand up.  Never again Monks Kettle!  I wish it weren't true, but Ive been snubbed one too many times.
-----------------------

First off, I used to love this place soo much.  I'm not the type to complain about one experience with a rude waitress, but this time I have to.  My BF and I went there at about 4pm on a Saturday.  There were a few tables open and I asked the waitress for a table, since we were going to have some appetizerS and a few beers.  She told us that the tables were reserved for full lunch entree patrons only.   WTF!!!  We were about to get at least 2 or 3 appetizers and at least 3 beers each and this twat waitress refused to let us sit down.  

Now I am a rational person, so no, I'm not lashing out because I was upset.  She told the same thing to another couple who then went somewhere else.  I would understand if it was a busy dinner service but this was 4:00 we're talking about.  Now if this happened twice in a minute, this must happen all the time and the owners should definitely know about this, which explains the single star. 

I hope I can finally go here again and not get treated like I'm lucky to be there.  This waitress (with an attractive piercing in her face) really needs to get her head out of her ass and think before talking.  

Oh, and the beer selection is one of the best I've seen and the food is incredible....dammit!
author: Mike H.

description: Excellent beer and food.  Stopped in on a business trip for a late lunch and was happy to find Pliny The Elder on tap.  A good spot for a gastropub lunch or dinner - highly recommended if you're a craft beer nerd or foodie.  For the record I despise the terms gastropub, craft beer, and foodie....
author: Perry H.

description:
You have to put your name down- no reservations- and the guy who does this kinda sucks. He says he'll text you when your table is ready, but he'll fail to tell you that having AT&T as your carrier means you wont receive the message in time and will likely be stuck waiting an addition 30 to 45 min. He sucks because he is well aware of this fact and it happens quite often. So long story short- give them a verizon #, or hover around the entrance.
Now as frustrating as getting into Monks Kettle is, it has absolutely earned these 5 stars. Best bacon burger I've ever had in my whole life. This burger embodies San Francisco- it's an organism for your mouth ;)
author: L P.

description:
First off, yes, the beer selection is amazing.  There's no disputing that. Two stars for the beer...and for the big pretzel.  

Where I take issue is with the size of the place and with the staff.  We went here last night to celebrate my fiance's birthday.  There were 8 of us.  We were told that all 8 needed to be present to get a table, but that we couldn't be seated together.  Ohhh Kaaaay. It actually worked out fine, but don't plan on coming here with a group larger than 6.  The host literally had no idea what to do with all of us. 

Once we were seated (after well over 90 minutes and several expensive beers from the bar), we were rushed to order dinner immediately. We had planned on a nice, leisurely dinner where we could drink, catch up and just enjoy hanging out.  Instead, after our plates had been cleared, our server informed us that he had been instructed by his manager to "move the table along" because there was a very long wait and he couldn't just let us sit there and drink.  With all 8 of us consuming beer after expensive beer, I couldn't believe that the management would effectively kick us out because we didn't want to order any more food, but that's exactly what happened. After waiting an inane amount of time for a table, we were hustled through dinner and then shuffled out the door after expressing that, YES, we wished to spend more money there.

Fine, jokers. We made a quick decision to take our little group 3 door up the street to Gestalt.  

But before we left, I made a quick stop at the bathroom (seriously, there's ONE bathroom in the whole place). I overheard our server bitching and moaning to a coworker about my fiance and the conversation they had about the table.  Look, I get it...I've been a server and I've certainly complained about a customer or two, but I ALWAYS made sure that the customer was not within earshot of my whining.

Gestalt is a bigger bar, with more space and cheaper beer.  We promptly ordered 3 LITRES of HopStoopid for a grand total of $18.  Granted, you won't get quite the selection that you'd find down the street, but I'll gladly take a reduced beer menu and decent service of Gestalt any day over the pretension and poor management of Monk's Kettle.
author: Jayne G.

description:
Worth the wait. Extensive beer selection and good drunken food. Last time we went, my wife's soft pretzel came out as a clumpy mess not resembling a pretzel at all. I mean it tasted good but why the hell would they serve that and not say anything!?

Anyway, good place overall.
author: Ramin R.

description:
1st off this place is tiny, but once you get in it is worth it. I just started drinking beer and be being a novice beer drinker the bartenders where very nice and patience with all my questions. So the 1st beer I landed on was the Aphrodisiaque Sweet Stout Basserieit was so smooth and tasty, but it was only 6 oz and at $9.50 a glass I had to switch beers to Fuller London Porter, just as smooth. I came here with a buddy, so after an hour and half waiting for a table we were ready to eat.
My friend got the Sashimi grade Ahi and he let me have a bit and it just melted in my mouth. I ordered the Elbow macaroni in a cast iron skillet (see picture) this was so good, but so much one person can't finish this on their own. During dinner I ordered the  Allagash White, Belgain-Style. Ever beer I tried was amazing.
I was out here just for the weekend and I found myself coming back to this place on the second night because the food and drinks were so good.
author: Derek W.

description: This place is fantastic! Excellent food and service (they even helped us pick beer that paired well with our meal). I consider the prices quite high, but I am willing to pay a little extra for good quality. Overall a great experience!
author: Danielle G.

description: This place is great!!! The food is amazing and they have a large beer selection. Totally worth checking out if you're in SF/ Mission area.
author: Ruby K.

description:
Item #50 on the 7x7 List: An obscure Belgian beer at Monk's Kettle. 

When I went with Jeanne Y, S.K. and several other friends to eat our way around the Mission, I expected this stop to be a short and easy one. We were wrong. They have an overwhemingly (is that even a word) enormous selection of imported beers that I had never heard of.  Fortunately, one of the bartenders walked us through the menu and helped us find some real gems.  Seriously, he was incredibly helpful and answered all nine thousand questions we shot at him about the various beers.  The people there were generally super nice.  My favorite was the Echte Kriekenbier Brouwerij Verhaeghe (sour ale and, yes, I just copy/pasted the name from the website).  

Although there are many options on the menu that are under $10, some of the beers on the list can be pretty expensive.  For instance, all of our eyes initially went to the Lambics but at $15-61 a bottle, we decided against it.  It helped us branch out in the end, but just know that this is not the place to go if you're looking for cheap beer.  You go for the good stuff. 

We also tried the pretzel (which was on last year's list).  I'll admit it. I have never been a fan of pretzels. I always have thought that they are unnecessary carb overloads. However, the pretzel at Monk's Kettle was absolutely fantastic.  Everything about it was perfect.  Even better than the pretzel was that mustard that it came with.  I've always loved mustard, but I never knew that mustard could be that fabulous.  Put them together and you've got a whole lot of awesome going on in your mouth.  

All in all, we stopped at eight places on our fooding trip around the Mission and this was our favorite.  The place was cute, the atmosphere was fun, the people were nice, the beers were great, etc.  There wasn't much seating, so I can imagine that if you're not there early afternoon like we were, it'd be pretty crowded.  Nevertheless, I'd love to come back to Monk's Kettle and try the food.  The pictures of the hamburgers have made me particularly hungry as I write this review.
author: Alea G.

description:
What a solid spot. 

The Monk's Kettle has great beer, knowledgeable bartenders and moderate prices. I haven't tried the food, but I overheard other patrons talking, and the feedback was overwhelmingly positive. 

Some highlights: large beer selection, fun chalkboard to write on (if you're relegated to the secondary area) and cool crowd of people. 

The negatives: not the cheapest place to drink. Also: it gets PACKED in here (and I didn't even go on a weekend). Don't come here with more than two people after 7pm and expect to get seating. 

I'll be coming back to here for more Belgian brews.
author: Tom A.

description:
I really liked the ambiance in Monk's - dimly lit with candles, but there's way too many people! (Maybe this attests to how great/popular it is?)

Anyway, the beer selection is phenomenal and the bartenders give great recommendations. I had the reality czeck and it was a light, tasty golden liquid in a tall, pretty oblong glass.

Anyway, the reason why there's only three stars is that the service was just okay. I expected to be more friendly about giving you tastings (btw, they were super cute - they were served in shot glasses that resembled beer glasses).
author: Christina C.

description:
First of all, I'm not sure whether I should consider this a gastro pub or not. They place less emphasis on their food than on their beer assortment. 

Imported beers are overpriced by about 30%. I am overwhelmed by all the beers they offer. However, their draughts are all local and bottled beers mainly come from Belgium. I feel you should concentrate the list more on a few specific brands and offer a broader variety from different top beer brewing countries. Why not stock Czech beer? Why not have a few more German lagers and some British ales? 

The food is kept simple and straight forward. Decent, but nothing to rave about. The "Bretzl", should not just be served with dips... omfg! The Bretzl is NEVER the main dish, guys. Bread dipped in mayonaisse is kids food!  If you really wann do the Bavarian thing, then do it properly and serve a Bavarian breakfast dish: Paulaner or Augustiner Weiss Bier with a Weisswurst, sweet honey mustard and a Bretzl on the side. 

Understandably, their wine list sucks. But, honestly, there never is an excuse to not offer good value house reds and whites by the glass. The wines on offer I would actually use to clean the bar and drains with. 

Atmosphere is great. Location is great. Service is great. Not sure why a brewery place needs a bathroom that puts guests into a psychedelic mood with incense though! 

un abrazo
;)
author: Sebastian C.

description: We called ahead, and still had to wait about 30 minutes or more. I was slightly intoxicated by the time we got our table, but what I remember was that the food was great, and decent portions. Staff was friendly, and knowledgeable about the drink menu. The space was cute, cozy, and small. Everything was expensive. Drunk me, would have rated this place a with 5 stars. But the reasonable side of me, gives this place 4 stars, for being overly priced.
author: Michelle G.

description: I had the Monk's Daily Roast and it was delicious!!!!!!!! You need to arrive early because it is a bit crowded and small inside! I would recommend this place for their food and diverse selection of beer.
author: Kat P.

description:
I have to say that their mushroom risotto is perhaps the best in town. Okay, thinking that it's a simple dish, and not too exciting, this dish will lift you away from your booth. 

Decor is nice and simple, Booths along with a bar with an array of beer taps. If you're looking for a premium beer selection, come here. They would probably have what you're looking for. Remember the wine list booklet you get on your table while sitting in a nicer restaurant? Well, this place have such thing for their beer. Insane. Well, I love it!

Oh, they have a stretch of blackboard in the back of the restaurant near the restrooms, so you could always doodle while waiting for the stall.

Great service. Non-judging awesome bartenders who'll still ID you.
author: Rika P.

description: Solid place - if you want to find some of the best beers in the city, and wouldn't mind having some delicious food to go with it, this is the place. Had the burger (w/o bacon) and a 'death and taxes' beer. Both were excellent. It would be great if they had outdoor seating.
author: Nicolas B.

description:
Listen up Yelp peeps, Monk's Kettle is the shit!  I know, I'm so gangsta.

I get it, the whole gastropub thing is totally trendy right now, but please don't let that scare you away from hitting this place up.  I discovered Monk's about two years ago and it's still one of my favorite places to grab a beer at in the City. Oh, and in case you're wondering, the "City" is a cool slang term that only San Francisco hipsters like me are allowed to use.

Now why do I like this place so much?  Well I'm glad you asked bitches.  Peep it:

BEER SELECTION:  Dope!  Seriously, if you like beer hit this place up.  The selection is ridiculously awesome.  Don't believe me?  Ch-ch-ch-ch-ch-ch check it out:  http://www.monkskettle.com/images/beer.pdf  

Whenever I go here, I always go with the Signature Ale, Santa's Little Helper (sorry folks, I'm a huge Christmas nerd) and/or the Orval Trappist Ale.  I also have to give a special shout-out to the Hitachino Red Rice Ale.  It's not as good as the other beers I just mentioned, but what kind of Half-Asian would I be if I didn't name drop it in my review?  Besides, I would never disrespect my family or the Shaolin Temple.

SERVICE STAFF:  The service here is always awesome.  The place gets pretty busy, but the staff is very attentive and you never feel neglected.  More importantly, all of the male service staff members always seem to be sporting some really cool facial hair.  Suspicious or mysterious?  You decide!  That being said, I wish I could grow a beard. :(

FOOD:  The beer selection is awesome, the wait staff is efficient and the layout of the bar is cool.  So that must mean the food is horrible, right?  Well, here's the kicker, you blow up the third statue (that was for you Nate)...er...what was I talking about again?  Oh yeah, the kicker is that the food is actually really good too.  Dare I even use the word AMAZEBALLS.  Okay, I will.  AMAZEBALLS!  Yup, Monk's has some awesome grub and most of their items compliment the beer that they offer on their menu perfectly.  Just like Oprah, here are a few of my favorite things from it:

The Premium Gold Lamb Burger - It's served with lettuce, tomatoes, fresh red onions and a cucumber mint tzatziki sauce on a Metropolis sesame bun.  Yup, it's the tits.  You also have to make sure you eat this while drinking either a ESB or the Belgian Strong Pale beer.

The Giant Pretzel with stone ground mustard and house-made cheddar ale sauce or the Fries with chipotle ketchup, herbed aioli and curry aioli.  You're in a bar right?  So how can you resist the bar food classics like fries and pretzels?  The answer to that...YOU CAN'T!  I'd suggest eating these items while drinking any of the Pale Ales they offer.

The Premium Gold Angus' Flank Steak - It's grilled to order and served on a Metropolis Italian baguette with blue cheese aioli and organic baby arugula.  Yup, it's aces.  It tastes like an elf dipped in Unicorn blood, which we all know is OBVIOUSLY DELICIOUS!  I'd recommend having any of the Pale Ales or Dry Porter with this burger.  Believe Dat!

Pot Pies - So the pot pies change week-to-week and you don't know what they're going to be serving until you get there.  In the past, I was lucky enough to get the Scallop and Lobster pies.  Both of them were AMAZING and if you wanted a "different" type of meal to go with your beers, I'd say to give one of these bad boys a try.

DESSERT - Sorry boys and girls, I haven't had desert here yet, BUT don't trip, I have had a couple of their Desert BEERS.  OH SNAP!  You should totally check out the Midas Touch Golden Elixir and/or the Mirror Mirror.  I got both of these beers because I liked their names.  I wish I had a cooler reason then that, but I don't, so deal with it.  However, you'll be happy to know that both of the beers are good, and you should totally try one of them if you are in the mood for a sweet tasting brew.

Well there you have it, the awesomeness that is Monk's.  I've always aspired to be a beer drinker, but growing up, I always preferred hard liquor.  I guess it had something to do with the fact that I could get faded without having to:

1.  Fill my stomach up with all of that beer.
2.  Feel super fat and sluggish while I'm drunk.
3.  Use the bathroom (piss on a tree or alley) every 10 minutes.

As I've gotten older, I really started appreciating what beer is all about.  I guess I started looking at it in a different light when I discovered that there is more to beer then just Schlitz, Mickey's and Old English.  Monk's is really one of those places that helped me appreciate how great beer can be.  So just like Da Band did for Mysterious, I gotta big up Monk's Kettle for hooking that shizzle up.  DY-LAN! DY-LAN! DY-LAN! AND DY-LAN!  In other words, Monk's beer selection is just like my Jean-Claude Van Damme DVD collection, huge, awesome and Belgian.

HOLLER.
author: Ray-Ray B.

description:
The decor and coloring is magnificent.  The menu is exquisit.  Very rich platters both small and large plates to accomodate any sized party.

Oh and the beer.  Good golly the beer!  Rich, lush, delicious options.  I could easily spend way too much money here.  

Only downside is the space.  it really about 5 tables and a bar so there may be a wait given what day you attend.
author: Francesca H.

description:
Burger, pickle and beer - oh my!

Gotta go back for the excellent assortment of beer!  The staff knows their stuff and didn't make me feel stupid as I asked a lot of questions about the different beers. 

Meat eaters: have the burger with fries!  Finish it off with a BEER float.  WTF?  Delish.
author: Jimmie L.

description:
Woweeee! I love Monk's Kettle! My man and I have been on a beer kick lately, and the beer selection here is top notch - some are a little pricey - but if you're on a budget you can certainly find something to satisfy.  

If you're a carnivore, you'll have no problem finding something tasty to nosh on, but I also found the menu to be surprisingly veggie friendly as well. You don't often find that in a gastro-pub, so I was stoked.  

For tables of more than two, be prepared to wait for a bit. Luckily, half of our four top got there around 7:30 on a Friday night and we only had to wait about an hour. The staff is really friendly an inviting, so that, coupled with the beer or two you have while you wait, makes up for it.

Will definitely be returning the next time I'm in San Francisco!
author: Katie F.

description:
I have been here a dozen times. There are lots of good spots in SF but none have failed to disappoint me eventually. The Monk's Kettle is the standout exception to this rule.

At times I've waited hours, at others, been seated right away. The information offered by the person up-front has always been reliable. The food is really good....best pub food around. The crowd is...well, crowded, but a nice slice of the Mission. I've always felt satisfied upon departure. Three cheers for the Kettle. Four stars for good menu, good service, good food. The fifth star is for failsafe consistency.
author: Deano M.

description:
This pub looks really nice and the beer selection is amazing. I thought the list of beers was impressive and then I realized it was only page 1 of about ten pages. This place definitely gets five starts for selection, and four or five stars for ambience. But, and this is a big but - the service was appalling - insulting, from all the staff.

The doorman (doorboy) was gruff and unwelcoming, our waiter was condescending and not very helpful and finally, before we were finished our drinks, the pretty (but surely not too bright) waitress took away our glasses because the place was closing; we got no warning of closing time and ther were plenty of other customers there. It was probably the worst pub experience I've ever had, and I'm Irish and know my way around beer and pubs.

Anyways, shame, as this place has potential, there's just no focus on service.
author: John M.

description:
Monk's Kettle, you were doing so well.  And then you blew it.  

Picture the scene.  It's a rainy Saturday night after 11pm.  Tons of bars are popping, but all the seats are taken.  Other places are closing.  We find Monk's Kettle and snag seats on stools near the back.  Pretty good deal.  Well, lots of seats were open pretty much the whole time we were there, but that was for the dinner crowd.  Oh, right.  The 11:30pm dinner crowd.  Graciously, Monk's Kettle frees those seats up at 1am.  So around 12:45, my back is aching.  All I want is a seat with a back.  We have finished our beers and while, we didn't order a second round, I was certainly open to another.  That's when I asked one of the bartenders if we could snag the table across from us that had been sitting empty for a good half an hour.  His response was the sweetest get the hell out of the bar if you aren't going to get another drink ever.  I didn't realize there was a timer on how long you one drink would get you in an establishment.  If the place was bumping, I'd understand.  It was not.  So, yes, we left.  I will have to be dragged kicking and screaming to come back
author: Jeremy G.

description:
I'm not a beer drinker but Monks can convert you. Like wine, it's about learning what to drink and how to appreciate. I got a little schooling.

- Tripel Karmeliet - Pale in color, crisp and easy to drink, with a sweet finish. Bottle from Belgium. Pretty good.
- Supplication - An American Wild Ale, this had a golden brown color with a sour cherry taste due to the wild yeast used. Bottle from Russian River Valley, CA. Distinct flavor that grew on me.
- Allagash White - Belgian-style Witbier aka pale yellow wheat beer with citrus notes. On tap. Very light and refreshing. 

Of course the beer was paired with food.
- Monster pretzel with mustard & cheese dipping sauces ($8.75). LOVED it. But that's because I like warm soft pretzels. Reminds me of Philly.
- Grass Fed Beef Burger ($12). This was ok. It was a burger.
- Coleman Pulled Pork on Kaiser Roll ($12.75). Sauce was on the sweeter side, but super tender shredded pork. Gave great contrast to all the other savory and bitter items we were having.

No room for dessert, but I'd come back and explore both beers and food. Fun atmosphere. Chalkboards for you to draw on while you wait for a table. Friendly and knowledgeable wait staff. Easy place to hang with friends. Thumbs up or rather bottoms up!
author: Cindy W.

description:
i came here with a few girlfriends a couple of months ago. we shared the giant pretzel (OF COURSE), ate dinner, and knocked back a few beers. I ordered the blanche de bruxelles and my friends both ordered that for their second beer because it was just THAT tasty. i tried to order a hef in a glass but was quickly corrected (apparently, because they are unfiltered, hefs are better out of the bottle so you get the sediment and stuff - who knew? apparently, our waiter).

ANYWAY, the beer was so darn delicious and so was the food. i love the dark, cozy atmosphere and the prices are moderate, depending on what you order. i think this place is pretty unique and will definitely be back!
author: Rachael S.

description:
If I were to rate this establishment purely on their beer selection and food I would easily give it 5 stars, but unfortunately those are not the only variables that make up an experience. Here's my saga...

I sat down at a table with another person and our first exchange with our waitress was:

waitress: "will you be eating with us today?"
us: "no, probably not but we would like some beer"
waitress: "ok, but just so you know when it fills up and I run out of tables I will have to ask you to leave."
us: "uhhh, ok"

While we were surprised by this exchange we didn't dwell on it. Fast forward an hour and we had another person join us, had ordered a total of 3 rounds (including one beer that was $14.75), and ordered appetizers. Unfortunately when the bus boy brought us napkins and silverware he spilled an entire beer all over my brother and my coat. Accidents happen, but we were surprised by the lack of concern and interest in making the situation more comfortable.

Fast forward another hour and a 4th person has joined us and we try to order some more appetizers...our waiter said, "sorry, but I can't get you more food. You can order more beer, but I can't serve you food; there is quite the line building up outside." What!? This totally floored us. 

I went and paid for the bill, we spent $160 there in 3 hours...they didn't charge us for two beers. No offers of paying for dry cleaning or anything. My brother and co-worker had words with the manager. I didn't hear the exchange, but I'm sure my brother wasn't very nice; however, given that his crotch was still completely soaked in beer he deserved a bit of leeway in my opinion.

Bottom line: love the beer selection and appetizers, not a fan of how the staff cares more for the waiting patrons than the paying customers they already have.

UPDATE: Since posting this review one of the owners contacted me and deeply apologized. He offered to pay for our dry cleaning bill (which he stated should have been offered at the time of the accident) as well as clearly stating the house policies, "it is house policy that any customers sitting at tables must be ordering full dinner service". This is due to their very limited seating and huge demand for those seats. Given that accidents happen, sometimes people have "off days", and the fact that one of the owners followed up with me...I am upgrading my review from a 2 to a 4.
author: Brandon B.

description:
Amazing beer list and the best soft pretzel I have ever eaten (comes with two dips)!

Gets crowded, so expect to wait at least a little bit unless you want to sit at the bar (you still might have to wait).

The beer is not cheap, but the place is totally worth it. (many of the beers you might be able to find at Whole Foods)
author: Elaine S.

description:
We had the exact experience as reviewer 'Jayne. K' below. The server was an absolute fuckhead and kept rushing us and telling us there is a long wait. We waited a long time to be seated as well. So i don't see why we should have a leisurely dinner over beer with friends. You don't exactly come to a place like this to be treated like you are served a charity meal. 
The beer selection is long, but not exactly great. The servers don't know shit about it either. Over all a hype that will die soon. Save your $ and go to La Trappe. The staff there is awesome and so is the beer.
author: Karthick S.

description:
Monk's Kettle is fooling everyone with its long beer list and even longer waiting list. More does not always equal better. 

The food was not extraordinary. Good thing the $9 pretzel was tasty. Otherwise I'd feel pretty silly spending $9 on a pretzel. Oh wait...

Perhaps the experience at the door soured my experience from the get go. Am I the only one who's tired of boys who act superior because they grew an ironic mustache?
author: Reese A.

description: Came here with wife while prowling for some late-night eats in the Mission. We'd been before and were underwhelmed, but this time we ordered The Burger. That beauty just overtook Tee-off as my favorite burger in the city (though they are two different beasts...maybe not a fair comparison). Pricey, but man is that burger good. Over-eager servers are a bit much, but once again, that burger...Oh yeah, and they have about a hundred-thousand different kinds of beer. Great spot if you're searching for a delicious finale to your Mission outing.
author: Matthew Z.

description:
Walked in here because Limon was closed - and I'm glad I got a chance to check this place out. We came to each lunch - but I would come back again more so for the crazy beer selection (Dogtown Pale, Lagunitas IPA) and the toasty Metropolis wheat bread. 

I won't be getting the white bean soup with bacon and sausage again - because the soup was 90% sausage. I think you could have made 3 huge links out of the amount of sausage in my soup.

If you appreciate beers, grab a seat at the bar and let the dudes suggest a couple new ones for you.  

4 stars for the beer. 2.5 stars for the food. 4 stars for the bread = 3 star average. Cheers!
author: Jessica C.

description:
The daily pickle and the wild ales are the best thing about this place. I love sour and fermented tasting things and those really set this place apart as someplace where I could find the unusual and unexpected. Also awesome? Many of the menu items feature goat cheese - a plus for my cow cheese intolerant wife. The staff was friendly and knew their stuff AND were not hesitant to share information, answer questions and check in to see how we were. 

I had a beer whose name if forget but it tasted a bit like whiskey and was amazing. Also had a taste of Moonlight Brewery's 2 Weeks Notice which was crazy good and the wild ale called Supplicant out of Russian River.

For food we had the pickle of the day, the stuffed dates (super good but almost too rich), the burger and the risotto. It was all very tasty but the pickle was what stood out. 

It was a good experience for sure.
author: Cindy E.

description:
A friend took me here for their outstanding beer selection. I was highly impressed by the beer list and the bartender's knowledge. She recommended some good beers for us. I even got to try mead for the first time (hot fermented honey/water) which was interesting. I haven't seen many places that offer that. 

I didn't have a chance to try the food this time but I heard their fries are delicious. The place was quite busy but we didn't have a problem getting seats at the counter after waiting for a few minutes. A good bet might be to order food, which will get you a seat at one of the tables outlining the place. 

I would definitely recommend the place if you're in the area, looking for a good selection of beers and a cool little place to chill for a bit.
author: Al B.

description:
Let's see here:

1) Giant pretzel with mustard and cheese sauce
2) Fries with ketchup, mustard, and white sauce
3) 7+ page menu full of beers
4) 2 blocks away from a Bart station

Did I miss anything that describes the awesomeness of this place?
author: Ronald L.

description: After over a year on my bookmark list and several attempts at scoring a table at Monk's Kettle I finally had a chance to eat dinner here this week. I didn't realize that MK is all about beer and beer tastings - pretty cool and unique in my book. Our server really knew her beer and was very helpful. I tried the burger and loved it - the aioli was great and the abundance of caramelized onions added an extra kick. The scene is pretty good here too, would definitely go back. We lucked out and got a table right away but I think for the most part plan to come early to put your name on the waitlist and either enjoy a beer at the bar or a nearby bar.
author: Gina C.

description:
Great place to pair great beer with good food :-)
I love their Braised Beef, it's definitely a must :-) 
I love the atmosphere and the design of this restaurant :-)
author: Conor L.

description:
More beer options than you'll know what to do with.  Their knowledge is amazing, tell them what kind of beer you like and they will reel off at least a few to try. If you're nervous about commitment try one of the little beer shot samples.

The Wee Heavy and the London Porter were great. You think a Guinness has head, wait till you have a them pour you a Porter.

A little expensive for bar food, but still quite tasty. But you're there for the beer not the food.
author: Chris B.

description:
This is my favourite place to eat in the city!  And absolutely one of the best places to try exciting beers that aren't readily available!
They have a killer veggie burger, which is often hard to find at beer bars...
The only drawback is how extremely popular it is and how crowded it gets.  But it's well worth putting yr name on the wait list.
author: Leila-Anne C.

description:
nice place to hide !  

food is alright.

service (Nolan) was very friendly ...he makes you feel welcome
author: Martin C.

description:
Haven't been in a while...allowed me to realize the MK is actually 5 stars, not the original 4 I gave it.  Crowd control not a problem as you just show up and leave your name and cell number, grab a drink across the street, and they call you when a table is ready.  Hassle-free.
Oh, really, yum food as well?  Don't mind if I do!
author: Luigi D.

description:
We headed over after our taco teasers at La Cumbre taqueria...

Beers, relaxed decor with a bit of modern lines, an attentive wait staff, an even more attentive and welcoming maitre-d and did I mention BEERS? All freakin kind of beers, I loved it!

Move aside Father's Office because the Monk has a stock of brew that is sure to please any beer-noisseur. On the other hand, I'd have to concede that the culinary mash-ups at FO throws a stone in the Kettle.

Not to say we still didn't drool over the thick bacon bits and crunchy crumbs of the cheesy macaroni nor over the savory, fresh flavor of the arugula/smoked trout salad...both paired well with our brews from grandpa's suds to belgian pale ale and ending with an english stout. 

No complaints, nice crowd and a perfect hump pleaser to our evening of food quests...now it was off to our finale at Delfina!
author: Susan A.

description:
Annoying 2-hour wait aside (we hung out across the street until they could seat us) and cramped indoors, this place is fantastic.

Amazing beer selection and delicious food.  I was very pleased with everything that I had and my burger was delicious.

The coffee-stout beer was a real winner.  I normally don't love beer but this one was delicious.

I'd go back for sure.
author: Ankur P.

description:
I thought The Monk's Kettle was an exceptional place to dine and enjoy some great beer.

I went a couple of weeks ago with a friend on a weeknight and it was packed! Luckily she got there early and put in our name so we could grab a beer across the street. They were nice enough to call her cell phone once our table was ready so we popped over and were seated right away. 

The place is really really small but somehow the staff makes it work. When I had gotten up to go the bathroom I had a chance to see the place from the back and I was so surprised to see how well the staff worked in such small quarters while still allowing their customers to enjoy themselves.

The restaurant is dim with a lot of wood and a beautiful bar with a fantastic selection of beer. Like I said, it's small so there isn't a ton of seating and the tables are small and very close together. However, I liked the crowd that was there that night. 20-30 somethings filled the place with lively chatter. 

Enough about the ambiance, now the food. The menu is very interesting and offers an array of dishes to satisfy your taste buds. We ordered an appetizer which was seared goat cheese, spinach and bread. I love goat cheese and this was great goat cheese. I then ordered the Lamb burger with fries and it was exceptional. I was really impressed because it was cooked just right and I loved the flavor of the meat and bread; nothing else was needed. I also tried some beer but I can't remember which one. What is really great is that they have beer and food pairings on the menu to help you navigate through their extensive beer list.

It's kind of pricey place but the food was definitely worth it. However, the beer was just as expensive as the entrées which was a bit odd to me, but I still enjoyed it.

I will definitely be back to check out the rest of the mouthwatering menu.
author: Denise S.

description:
I was surprised at the long list of beers that they had available!  They have a lot of Belgian and foreign beers which is always a plus in my book.  The bartenders also knew the selection of beers extremely well. 

We also tried the house-cured magret duck prosciutto.  It was comparable to the one we used to have in Paris.  My hubby was in heaven with his Belgian Beer and duck.  

I will have to try the food next time!  Definitely a great place for drinks and hanging out.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
It pains me to give this place a 3-star review, but...

The good:
* Huge selection of beers.
* Good atmosphere.
* Good location.

The bad:
* Queues. No phone or opentable reservations, usually 45-90 minutes wait if you arrive after 7pm.
* The food isn't great. I've had a burger with overcooked crunchy bacon, a vege burger which was extremely bland, tasteless pasta, some other vege dish which was so dry it was unpleasant. It's trying too hard, it's not working, and it's not a one-off.
* I understand that imported and/or speciality beer is expensive. I really do - I'm a veteran of beers of the world, festivals and such, but the pricing here is absurb. I really cannot bring myself to spend ~$25 per 24oz for something I could have bought 90% cheaper in the host country. Which brings me to my next point...

The ugly:
* Feels like I'm being nickle-and-dimed for beer serving size. Some draught/cask beers are served in 20oz glasses, but other "authentic" British ales in 16oz. Yeah, those authentic British 16oz servings. Most ridiculous one was a stout costing about $12 for 6oz. It wasn't a joke, but should have been.

Now that I've been an SF resident a little longer, I don't find Monk's Kettle as unique as I did at first. You can have a similar experience in plenty of other bars in town, at a fraction of the cost, without all the pretense, and albeit with a much smaller menu.

(Edit: I write British 20oz servings, which is pretty much authentic - I meant 16oz was wrong :)
author: John R.

description:
I was out with a buddy for lunch. We had never heard of the place before; we were just walking by and thought that it looked interesting. Right place, right time. 

Buddy had the burger, I had the Chicken Paillard. Both were delicious. We also ordered some of their house mustard for our fries and it was great. 

It was a good find that we weren't looking for. I will definitely return.
author: Robbie S.

description: This place is just too crowded now. They serve great beer and food, but I can't remember the last time I showed up and actually got a seat. They don't take reservations, so you have to just show up and hope for the best. They don't even have a space to wait in, so you feel like you're always in the way. And if you do get a seat, it's too loud and crowded to be comfortable. Today I went and was told they were at capacity, so I couldn't even wait for a seat. I probably won't be going again.
author: Thomas M.

description:
Great staff and amazing beer selection.  Was here back in July and I am just getting around to publishing this.

We stopped in for a quick drink and was happy to see the bartender tasting each of the new beers for the single purpose of knowing how to describe the beers correctly to customers.  Now THAT is dedication.
author: Chris D.

description:
Its been sometime since I was last hear and I don't know why I strayed off for so long, the BEER selections have grown and are even better. The folks behind the bar know their stuff and the menu remains consistently good. 

The Mac'nCheese with bacon is amazing, the lamb burger and pulled pork are out of this world and when you to match this up with BEER there are no words. 

Glad this place is doing well, will be back sooner than later.

Drink Up!
author: G R.

description:
I should give it four stars for the unbelievable 1.5 hour wait.

But it was so damn delicious.  Best lamb burger I've ever had.  Seriously.  I challenge anyone to try and beat them at this game.

And can they really have a different glass for every different beer you order.  And can the waiter do some weird firestarting motion with his hands on the beer bottle to get the foam out and at the right consistency?  Yes, Virgina, they can.

What an unmatched experience!
author: Darin G.

description: Good service, great selection of beers, and decent selection of food to go with it all. I'm sad to be moving outta SF in a few weeks and having to leave this place behind without getting a chance to really try everything they've got to offer. They have nice booths for a small group of 4, but it IS a tiny place so expect to wait! Coming in on a sunny afternoon for Sunday Funday beers and burgers really made my day.
author: Erin M.

description: Very cool atmosphere. Definitely a dive bar. Huge selection of beers (if you are unsure of one, suggest what you like i.e. wheat and they will recommend a tasty one for you). Had fries too which were good. I would come here again. Low key, bartenders were chill.
author: D C.

description:
I am a foodie and I love good beer so a restaurant with delicious appropriately priced food and a mile long beer menu is truly in the words of yelp "Woohoo! As good as it gets!"

The soup was tasty. The pretzel hot, soft and perfect. The pork-chop is probably the best in the city and certainly the best I have ever had.

With all the delicious beers to try it is easy to rack up a long bill.

I recommend the bread pudding over the chocolate sampler (trust me).

Also- If you don't mind sitting down early to dinner try and go early (before 6pm) especially if you have more than 2 people in your party. It's a small place and an hour wait with no one waiting ahead of you is a reality... especially because people like to linger.
author: Alex W.

description: Pretty good,  menu was a little boring considering the beer menu is amazing.   I guess since this place is labeled gastropub, I expected more diversity, but the menu is still mostly burgers, sandwiches and salads.
author: Michael E.

description:
I feel like i should join the priesthood or campaign to be a pastor at least after comin to this place every time. Been here a handful of instances and i can truthfully say that it is as good as it gets for a place that serves beer (like all 250 kinds) and food. 

So every time i go, i get the Golden Monkey, pretzel and fries. The GM beer is sooo damn good with its exotic spices but the crazy thing is is that its brewed in Pennsylvania. yea, i woulda thought it was from Sri Lanka or some shit being that I didn't think Penn had any local monkeys to begin with. The pretzel is to die for with its cheese sauce - the sauce is the boss and i usually ask for extra to dip with my fries and fingers. The fries are plentiful and they are served with chili ketchup, curry mustard and garlic aioli dipping sauces. 

The place itself isn't that big but if you get there early at a table, you're set. the service is great, the staff are friendly and know their beers and how to provide great service and the food is just down right good. I have to admit that i have yet to try the actual meals but since i know one of the chefs, the little food servings and trinkets that keep coming out to surprise me and my crew keep me fed enough to not worry bout the rest. 

Every time i leave we get spoiled w/ some sinful dessert concoction - 1.root beer bread pudding with dark chocolate ice cream over a bed of light caramel. (boo-ya)  2. mint chocolate chip cookie baked in a cast iron skillet served with vanilla bean vanilla ice cream (bang-bang) 

Yea, I'd come here over, and over, and over, and over, and over....(get the rant?)
author: Nick V.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants in the City. Fantastic craft beer from all over the world with a great menu. 
Be prepared to wait. It can be up to an hour and a half. But with all of those beers you'll be plenty occupied and nicely buzzed by the time they guy at the door taps you on the shoulder and shows you to your table.
author: kris m.

description:
The reason for two stars is because:

1. The food wasn't that great, especially for a gastropub.  I got the sashimi grade ahi burger.  I don't know what grade it got but I had a better burger at the grand lux cafe in Vegas.  I got the beer pairing that went with it... nothing.

2. We were told it was a 1.5 hour wait.  That's fine because the reviews were stellar (again not sure why) but we ended up waiting 2.5 hours.  Not only that but the host was rude to my friends until he realized how badly he messed up the estimated time.

It's a nice restaurant and a good location but honestly for SF, you find that everywhere.

Monk's Kettle you don't get only one star because one of my friends ordered a salad that was delicious.
author: Z C.

description:
I've been told San Francisco lacks a good gastropub culture.  When someone from out of town tells me this, I immediately slap them and point them towards Monk's Kettle.

Violent fantasies aside, if you're like me and enjoy things like a vast selection of beer and great food, then you need to make an effort to try this place.  

You'll probably end up waiting for a while to get a table, especially if you come with a few friends, but that's why they take your phone number and why there are so many bars around 16th & Valencia.  Just be sure not to fill up on crappy beer at other places or get too drunk, because you'll want to savor every moment at Monk's Kettle.

Definitely try the Ahi tuna sandwich and the lamb burger.
author: Zhi Q.

description:
Unfortunately, my experience at Monk's Kettle was an extreme failure.  We ended walking out and finding a different venue due to the staff.  To start, the host/doorman's attitude was very pompus, rude and showed no care for customers.  When I told him that we had a party of ten, he immediately told me that only 2 people would be able to let in the restaurant, and the remaining party would have to wait outside.  Since it was early, and my party had not arrived, I asked if we could sit at the bar.  He said that was ok, but again, if any more of my party came, they would have to wait outside.  While he was saying this, parties of 3 and 4 were walking in without any problems.  So, as we are sitting down, we decided to put our name down for a table of 5 because not everyone wanted to eat.  Being people who work in the industry, we wanted to compromise, where we had a table for the few that wanted to eat, and the others would remain at the bar.  Instead of working with us, he flat out refused to take my name down for the waitlist.  

Then, my friend did come, her hands were full as she walked in the door.  We were sitting at the end of the bar neat the door, and i made some room for her to put her bags down.  The host/doorman proceeded to come up to her and say, "Excuse me, in this place, we ID" and pulled attitude that she did not have her ID out fast enough.  Again, identifying her, while people walked in without issue.  

After all of this, talking to the bartender was also an exprience.  I noted that it was my birthday, not for any "free" item, but because I was in the festive mood.  She looked back at me, and said, "Honey, I hear THAT a lot" and just walked away.

I understand the establishment is small.  I understand that they are busy.  We were just a bunch of beer enthusiasts that wanted to come celebrate my birthday.  The staff is completely rude.  Unfortunately, they lost our business that night, not to mention a $500 tab that one of the servers could have sold.  

I know they have a lot of customers, and probably dont care about the loss of a few... just it was extremely disappointing.  There are other places in the city that have amazing beer menus and I suggest trying those instead.
author: Lynne S.

description:
While I have been living in SF for a little over a year now I had never been to Monk's Kettle until this past weekend. I have to admit while normally I am truly impressed with SF establishments I was starting to notice a lack of comfortable, fun, clean and intellectual pubs. For instance Harry's on Filmore is none of these. But rather a soulless meat market for those who need to be gawked at and have men ruffle their feathers like peacocks in heat......  Anyway back to Monk's.....

So you can imagine how pleased I was when a friend (ex anheuser busc employee) called me up Saturday afternoon and said lets meet me at Monk's.

The place has a fantastic beer menu and the knowledgeable staff is amazing. We arrived at 5pm on a Saturday and there was already a 1 hour wait for a table (only about 4 booths). So we placed ourselves at the bar and proceeded to drink a few amazing beers. When we got the hunger itch we ordered one of the best tasting pretzels I have ever had in my life.  

This place is a must visit! Could be in my top 10 places in SF.
author: Ryan B.

description:
A+ for ambiance, D- for pricey pricey pricey-ness. 
Just go and order something on the menu that is relatively cheap and sit there for a while with a friend. 
Strangely enough, although the veg options were scarce, the veggie burger was the most amazing veggie burger i have ever had. I don't even like veggie burgers. But this one was very very good.
It's also usually got an incredibly long wait, particularly on evenings and weekends. Despite this, the service was friendly, and the bartender gave explanations of the beers I hadn't heard of, and thus helped me discover that winter brews are not bitter even though they're dark, but are in fact, rather yummy. 
Great date place, if you're into that sort of thing. Great friend date place, too, heck.
author: Bean H.

description: This is a great place. Good beer selections and good food. The whipped bone marrow is my favorite. The pretzel is good, except for the cheddar fondue. It's way better with the mustard. Overall, the food could use more improvement. The flatbreads aren't that interesting, the crust isn't that good. For a gastropub, they should work harder to pair food with beer. Should give more suggestions and persuade customers that this beer or that beer is good with this food. Besides that, the chocolate stout bread pudding is fantastic. It's not heavy.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Monk's Kettle has a killer selection of beer, there is no arguing that point and their food is acceptable, especially when you have a few pints in you.

BEWARE: read the beer menu and check the prices before ordering. They use certain bottled beers to pad their margins, which was confirmed by the staff.

I paid $7.75 for a pint of Pliney the Elder, entirely reasonable for draught Pliney in a restaurant. The cost for Blind Pig by the bottle . . . $12.25! $8 would be reasonable for 20oz Blind Pig, but $12.25 is r*pe.

I'd recommend Toronado in the lower Haight and some killer sausages at Rosamunde next store.
author: Bryan W.

description: Enjoyed the burger it was delicious. We came after 10 pm & it was packed. Also there's a great selection of brew to choose from.
author: Purple H.

description:
Went here with cute boy but the other reviewers are right, your date will be competing with the waiters,  bartenders, etc. and they know their shit.  It's not like going to Best Buy to talk tech.  It's like going to HOPE, dorkbot, or noisebridge to talk geek.  You will get steered right on all things beer.

Most comprehensive beer list ive seen as well!  Toronado just may have been ousted by Monks Kettle! 

The fries are perfect! Thin, salty, not too greasy and comes with 3 different sauces.  Chipotle ketchup is best!  

Small but the host is efficient and will find you amongst the teeming masses when your table's ready.
author: X X.

description: Probably my fav bar in SF...loads of choices and very knowledgeable staff. Usually is pretty crowded because many others must also consider Monk's a true oasis of this neighborhood. They even look like they have some serious food here, I even noticed a veggie burger...looking forward to returning.
author: Mayur A.

description:
I know a great time to go to Monk's Kettle without any wait: Mondays at 6pm! You're welcome. Another pleasant surprise is that the food is really good! They always have special pot pies of the day (or week?) so you're not really sure which one you can order until you arrive. I've heard they have served chicken and lobster pot pies before which both sound delicious but yesterday I got the one that I really wanted to try, SCALLOP! I saw it on the menu and I was sold. 

I'm not really a beer drinker though I aspire to be one day. I just like sweet drinks and beers are usually not. The waiter gave me a "shot" of a sweet beer they had and it was actually pretty okay! It did have a sweet lingering flavor and a nice maple after taste. I ended up with the Black Currant Cider. The waiter said it's the alcohol's soda and it tasted like fruit soda. I will work my way up to beers next time around.

My friends' ordered the Lamb and Steak Burgers which were both excellent. Who knew a bar would become my to-go burger joint? The fries were also thin and flavorful. But the scallop pot pie was the real highlight of the night. It was stuffed with huge succulent scallops, swam in a rich, creamy chowder with carrots, potatoes and peas, and topped with a buttery crust. It's luxurious comfort food at its finiest.

Dessert came in bread pudding form with a root beer float syrup and vanilla ice cream. The cold ice cream was much needed for the steaming hot and sweet pudding. I loved the crispy edges and soft insides of the bread. A few moments later it was gone. Not bad for a Monday night at a bar!
author: Julia T.

description:
Yesterday, a girl friend and I stopped here at this busy watering hole for a beer and eats. We noshed on the gigantic pretzel with their own cheddar ale dip and stoneground mustard plus the french fries with three dips (spicy ketchup, curry aioli and a creamy herbed mayo). It was fitting for a nooner. 

I ordered a glass of Kolsch while she had a Bitch Creek. That's right, I said it. We were amongst locals who came here to eat, smooze, shoot the shit and drink to their hearts' content as the rain poured down heavily in the City. 

I'd come back here again.
author: Mika D.

description:
Small atmosphere but big beer selection!  Food was stellar for small menu.

I'm not familiar with European beer so I relied a lot on the staff.  Our Waiter had great suggestions for beers based on what I usually drink.

Great atmosphere if you can get a seat.
author: Liv S.

description:
The food is amazing and the craft beer selection is expansive.  
The only downside is that they do not take reservations, and the wait for a table is always super long so come ready to wait at least an hour.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
I went here with friends for lunch on Monday.  We ordered the following:

- Chicken Sandwich w/ Brie (4 stars) - Melted brie, aioli, and bacon = heaven.
- Mac & Cheese (3 stars) - A little watery for my taste.
- Lamb Burger (2.5 stars) - Not too gamey, but could be juicier, nothing special.

I didn't have any beer, but the English Pale Ale that my friend ordered was pretty tasty.

Atmosphere - Really nice wait staff (your typical SF hipster), this is a relaxing, cozy place to commune with good company, esp on a rainy day.
author: Vicki K.

description: Awesome selection of beers. The offerings are a bit pricey but worth a visit if you're into different brews from around the world. The food was great as well. Perfectly done burger with a side of kick ass fries (although they were a but stingy w the fries). Went there for lunch so not sure what the vibe is like in the evening.
author: S B.

description:
Unbeatable beer selection and unique tasty menu.

Cons: Pricey, small.  Good luck getting in late or with a big party!
author: Andy A.

description:
I never knew how to define the type of restaurant the Monk's Kettle until I ventured to London last spring. The joints that are all the rage there are known as "gastropubs". Simply put, a gastropub is a bar/pub with good food. 

The Monk's Kettle is wonderful because it's so consistent: the food is terrific, the service is excellent, and the location is in the heart of the Mission district. The only thing consistent about the place that always peeves me and those dining with me is the wait. But, let me tell you friends, the place is well worth it (hell, go to Elixir for a few cocktails and everything in the world is right again). Starters like their baked goat's cheese and beet salad are phenomenal. They have a tasty and lean lamb burger (I loves me some lamb) that I find myself ordering time and time again.

The place is great for date night or a night out with friends. I strongly recommend making reservations if you plan to dine there on either a Friday or Saturday night.
author: Rodney P.

description: The burger is back! Last one I had was in 4th place to Mission Bowling Club, Luna Park and Slow Club. But the one I had last night put it back in to first place. Woo hoo! Delish! And the salad that they paired for me instead of fries was delish even though I hate mixed greens. The hazelnuts and goat cheese made it yum. Beers are still massively overpriced without a quality less expensive option. Oh and if you're going to sit at the bar you need to be OK with people rubbing up on you and banging you with their elbows and bags.
author: Nicole O.

description:
This was my third experience here, and first for a sit down meal. The 6 of us got stuffed into a booth despite all the empty nearby tables. We asked for a little more space at the tables and got a snarky response from their little hipster door guy equipped with a mustache years beyond his own maturity.

So we moved forward as complacent sardines, and got our beer order in. They've got a nice selection of draft and bottled beer to please the choosiest of beer drinkers.

We took the small plates route and ordered pretzels, delicious. The wedge, was a mess, completely submerged in gloppy dressing. Fries, were good. Mac N Cheese was a total fail, had to remove the top from the salt shaker and give it a full seasoning. It merely consisted of the same cheese sauce from the pretzel poured over elbow macaroni with some bread crumbs. The ale cheese sauce makes sense with the salty pretzel, but was very bland with macaroni. Nobody was disappointed with the chili.

This is a brewpub, that serves pub quality fare. I'm okay with that, but the prices of the food reflect a finer level of dining and quality that just wasn't present.

For $30 a person, you'll get 1 beer a few bites and leave feeling there's something more to be desired.
author: Shawn S.

description:
A fantastic place to blow $50 on the best Belgian beers you can find in San Francisco

The 'great'-

Beer selection.  Hands down the one place I'd love to be at every single weekend should money (and liver condition) permits. 
From Paauwe Kwak, Affligem blonde, Westmalle dubbel to hundreds other beers this place remind me of that period of bliss I experienced in Europe for college

The 'good'-

Atmosphere.  Due to its small size the place is always lively.

Location. Right on 16th st between Valencia and Guerrero, perfect location for a stop during a night out in the Mission.

Service.  The staff are very friendly and helpful.  Of course they are also passionate about the beer and that helps to keep you occupied.

The 'bad'-

This is a really small place.  It's almost impossible to get in on Friday and Saturday night unless you come early or late.

Price.  While it's tempting to order food to satisfy your munchie it will burn a hole in your pocket.  Stick to the liquid bread my friends.
author: Andi H.

description: This place was great. The chicken sandwich I had went perfectly with the beers they had on tap. Might have to swing by here one last time before I move from San Francisco.
author: Rey L.

description: I love this little intimate jem in San Francisco. The food is so delicious and the presentation is unique. The Mac and Cheese is perfection. Its a bit pricey but oh so delicious.Expect to run into people constantly because its small on the inside but its worth it. Monk's Kettle's vibe is worth the money your personal space violated.
author: Simone N.

description:
A great Gastro-pub in the heart of the mission. If I werent such a dive bar aficionado I would frequent this establishment much more. Monk's has a beer list that would make your taste buds sing and also twist your tongue! There are ales, lagers, IPA's, ESB's from all over the world at your fingertips. I do love my Belgian ales and usually cannot go wrong with the Rochefort 8. 

Only downside is that its alwyays cramped inside and to be honest, some of the beers are quite overpriced!
author: Jason W.

description:
Pros: stellar beer selection.  Excellent, friendly and accommodating staff.  We arrived about 7:30 pm on Saturday night.  We got on the wait list for dinner and sat at the last 2 spots at the bar and ordered beers. They told us a 45 minute wait, but before we even got our beer, they had a table ready for us.  We had 2 waiters but they were both great, very knowledgeable about beer and able to make recommendations.

Cons: pretty crowded, cramped, and loud.  Food was just OK.  They only had 2 vegetarian options on the menu - chickpea burger and risotto.  (I actually did NOT verify if the risotto was actually vegetarian, but all the ingredients listed on the menu were.)  I had the risotto and hubby had the burger.  It did the job, but the meal was nothing to write home about. 

Next time I would probably come for just beers, or beer and a cheese plate and/or dessert, not during meal time.
author: Shannon A.

description: Came here just around lunch time and the place wasnt that crowded. We were quickly greeted by the bartender and then handed us the extensive beer menu. I was completely blown away by the beer knowledge this bartender had. this guy must be some kind of expert genius when it comes to beers. atmosphere was great and a general good vibe throughout.
author: John N.

description: Went here last night with some friends and was treated so rudely by the female manager with blonde hair at the end of the night !!!! I've been in the restaurant business for 18 years and would never have been rude to customers like her!!!!!! I think it's time for her to think of a new career if she can't be kind to the people that make her paycheck!
author: Billy D.

description:
Incredible beer selection and very good food!
The interior has a British pub feel, with dark wood counter and furniture.

But I guess that pretty much summarizes the best parts of Monk's Kettle.
Otherwise, the place is almost always goddamn crowded so good luck finding a seat. At least there are other bars around while you wait for a table to open up.

Perhaps because it's so crowded, the service tends to be slow and occasionally spotty. I've also had a time when our group was rudely turned away by the door man because the place was so crowded.

The price isn't particularly friendly either. The beers tend to be overpriced for what they offer. The food meets up to it's price though!

In the end, I do come back here on a regular basis for the beer selection and food.
I visit during off hours, but the wait is still always aggravating for me.
And I HATE waiting.
author: Rei O.

description:
When this place is full it really isn't fun to stand squeezed in the middle of where the waitstaff are walking back and forth, and get yelled at for being a fire hazard. All while tables are empty for people who are eating.

Go somewhere else...
author: L B.

description:
The Monk's Kettle was a great place for a great beer!  The beer menu was extensive and easily laid out to find your beer of choice.  Small place, so definitely get there early.  

Food was great - got the pretzel to start - the beer cheese sauce was so delicious that I wanted to bathe in it.  Cheeseburger and fries were solid.  Would definitely go back!
author: Sari O.

description:
BAD FOR LARGE GROUPS! (over 6 ppl)

pros: it's in the mission, so you can wear whatev.  kitchen is open late night.  beer list is over 4 pages long of small type- pretty intimidating if you're not looking for a specific type, + no samplers where you can try a whole bunch, although they will bring you a shot glass-amount of beer to taste upon request.

cons: here it's not cool to drink beer out of the bottle.  i guess when the beer costs $13 a bottle, you need to treat it like wine.  small + crowded restaurant:  booths (there are maybe 3 or 4 total) seat 6 ppl max, + even then it's squishy.  we were 6 ppl at a table + a friend stopped by so we pulled up a stool for her but then we were told fire code regulations prohibited etc. etc.  they let her sit at the counter next to our booth, which was awkward.  she left pretty quickly after that.  fries are fabulous, but burgers are pricey ($14 on avg) + good, but not amazing.  the desserts, however, ARE amazing- oatmeal raisin cookie cooked in a skillet w/vanilla ice cream + organic peach bread pudding w/vanilla ice cream.  

summary: go for the beer + desserts.  bring no more than one person.
author: Zoe L.

description:
oh my gosh - love! came here with a friend for dinner and it definitely was a wait, but it's so worth it (plus you can give them your cell # in case you want to wait elsewhere instead of the street).

this is seriously a treat for any beer drinker or even those who aren't - my drink of choice is usually red wine, but what's great about monk's kettle is that they serve their 750ml bottled beers like wine. on that note, we got the upright five per the suggestion of the server (i love belgium beer), and it was hoppy & delicious!

aside from the beer, the food is great! one of the things about gastropubs is that they're secretly good at making food. we ordered the bone marrow, which came with popcorn and bread. i wish the canoes were deeper (which is everyone's wish), but this was yummy! then, i got the diver scallops and crab risotto cakes, which was incredible! the scallops were cooked perfectly, but it was crab risotto cakes which made my night. i don't like risotto in its natural form, but as cakes they're amazing!

last, but not least we got dessert, which was a beer float - all i can say is that you need to try it to complete your monk's kettle experience!

i will definitely be coming back for more!
author: Marjie T.

description: I love the ambiance and the staff.  The beer prices are amazing, but the food selection is a little limited.
author: RA R.

description: Awesome gastropub. Mouth watering chicken.
author: Kevin P.

description:
This place delivers time and time again for me and I find myself becoming a huge fan. First, the staff is great here. They have a vast knowledge of their product, take care of every customer with extended courtesy and friendliness, and always seem to be there at the right time. Using their knowledge is key to finding a beer you've never had before and will not regret it. For a place that specializes in great beers, Kettle has a decent wine list for those of us who prefer another option. 

I do wish that the burgers were a little larger (the size of the patty) but otherwise great stuff! The number of tables and places to sit and eat can sometime be an issue with this happenin' place. If you're willing to wait you will enjoy!
author: Gabriel R.

description: Decent beer selection, though the prices are pretty high. Atmosphere was average bar. They invite you to write on "chalkboard" walls, but they are not really chalkboards, and writing on them is nearly impossible. Didn't try any food, however.
author: Stephen B.

description:
Finding a great gastropub is hard (and I live in Orange county, so it's really hard to find a superb one), but The Monk's Kettle is definitely one of my favorite's.  

I was impressed with the beer knowledge I found with the staff, the superb food I had with my beer and the amazing desert.  

My friends and I waited about an hour to get seated, but it was well worth the wait.  We ended up eating dinner for a few hours and time flew by.  

I'd love to come up here again when I come back to San Francisco.
author: George U.

description:
I really want to give these folks more stars, but there are just too many little things detracting from what could be an awesome place.

1.  Too crowded.  Not they're fault per se, but it does detract.  

2.  The food is good, but only good.  In this town it has to be better especially for the prices they are charging.  There are plenty of other places with better similar cuisine at much lower prices.  

3.  The service leaves quite a bit to be desired.  Just because you're busy doesn't mean you can take patronage for granted.  Nothing is more offensive to a customer.  Apathetic is the best I can give them here. 

4.  On the plus side, their beer selection is fantastic.  

We will probably pass eating here again.  The last experience was just too loud, too crowded and too mediocre.
author: Russell D.

description:
I was very impressed by their beer selection, despite it being a touch pricey.  Super friendly staff.  I wish it had a cozier feel to it.  But with only a handful of tables, and really NO standing room, its one of those places you kinda peek into, wish you could have the patience for, and then find something else.

great beer though. and i'd go again for another experience.
author: kristopher y.

description:
Dear Brothers of the Order of the Kettle,
Praise be to you, my beer saviors.  Deliver me from the evils of my job, and thank all that is holy for the respite of your gastropub cloister. I'm eternally grateful.

I don't think I'm alone in these sentiments - your packed house every night is a testament to how well you're being received.  Over 600 reviews on Yelp is also telling.  You've got our attention.  What's more, San Francisco seems to be enamored with your extensive selection of beers, your persona, and your pub grub (some of which is de-lish).  

That nearly a third of the past 100 reviews are either mixed or disgruntled is a bit more prognosticating.  Be wary of shifts like this in customer satisfaction.  Your service, refined and helpful that it is, shows signs of wear - you've copped a bit of 'tude, and it's not quite what one hopes to find at a place that bills itself as once or twice removed from a monastery.  You can be high brow about recommending hard to find brews, but you shouldn't stray into snob territory.  And, that your "host/hostess" is misconstrued as a bouncer (or worse, vice versa) is going to further act as a deterrent.  You're not a club, you're a pub.
