Pub's don't need bouncers, just ornery bar wenches that will soundly put you in your place when, for example, you reach behind the bar to refill your own glass.  (I would know nothing about this.)  

Next, your prices are riding a very thin line between what's acceptable given the quality/selection and what's slightly insulting.  Do you really need to overcharge when you're raking it in hand over fist?  Your food is great, prices notwithstanding.  I agree that the pot pie, the mac and cheese, and the pulled pork sammy are the perfect medicine when imbibing vast quantities of perfectly fermented brews.  But really, $8 for a pretzel?  Here's a thought: serve them for $5 from a street cart outside the front door to the people waiting in line to get in.  You're guaranteed to placate people for the long wait, and then your pretzels will sell like hotcakes.  Otherwise, as a stand-alone side dish, it's really not all it's built up to be.

Lastly, I still love you.  I can bear with the lines, the waits, and the crowds just for the pleasure of your selection of beers and your grub.  But do us a favor and lighten up.  Life's too short, and we'd like you to stick around for it. 

Amen, brothers.
author: Nils E.

description: Great spot if you love beer! Not like pound bud lights kind of like beer but Belgian beer, craft brews, and like to taste various styles kind of like beer. The beer list is one of the most extensive in San Francisco.
author: Jay W.

description:
This place is small, crowded, but still pretty great. They have a nice selection of beers and not entirely focused on Belgian-style. It's nice to go to a place that has a specialty, but still showcases the great stuff we have around here (The Trappist and La Trappe both almost exclusively have belgian-style).

I had a new "steam" style beer that I'd never tasted and had a Firestone Walker Reserve porter, both appropriately sized and pretty yummy.

The food was OK. My burger straightforward, the beet salad just OK. I'd say that the food is a little expensive (salad $12, Burger $12) for what it is, but I suspect they have to deal with the beer/food  ratio required by many liquor licenses in some way.

Staff was friendly and attentive. I'd definitely come back for the beer.
author: tjay f.

description:
Great beer.  Decent food.  Rude hostesses.  2 hour time limit on tables, which means they will tell you to leave after an hour and a half, even if you're spending a lot of money (over $100) as I was.

And the thing was, there was no line at all.  And we weren't being rowdy.  On the contrary, we were drinking some pretty pricey stuff.  And eating.  It made no sense at all.  But it was insulting.

A number of reviews say this place is expensive, so a great place if you have cash.  I'd disagree, because while it is expensive, they don't know any better than to treat their customers like it's some cattle call. 

Good beer, but other places have equally good beer and better food without the insulting attitude (Bar Crudo, heck, even Hubert Keller's Burger Bar).  I won't be going back.
author: Kevin G.

description: Great choices of Belgium style beers. Prices here are not cheep so expect to drop a pretty penny or two. The place is not big so you'll find your-self standing or waiting for someone to vacate their seats :)
author: Jova E.

description:
I don't know what a gastropub is but I certainly enjoyed this place. I tried the "Get Up Offa That Brown" brown ale by Golden Road Brewing. Dee-liscious. I'd really just come in to ask the bartender where the young folk liked to hang out because I was recruiting for a TV show, but ended up staying a while. The bartender was AMAZING. Super bubbly and nice, kept my water glass at full (she was also the cutest girl I saw all day in the mission). 

So, go. Great beer selection. Friendly staff. Unpretentious.
author: Ismael A.

description: Awesome selection of beer and great food! I mainly go for the beer but the food is amazing if you are looking for both.  Make sure to be prepared to wait though on a busy weekend night though.  Don't let that deter you though as it is worth the wait.
author: John R.

description: Great spot. Highly recommended. We had Claire as a bartender and she really knows her beer. Ask her anything and she can help you find the beer you are looking for or tell you about beers you are curious about. Extremely knowledgable and kind.
author: Alexandra B.

description: It's nice to go to a beer bar where the beer is poured in the proper glass and no matter what beer you order it is delicious. Awesome beer, a knowledgeable staff, & an amazing soft pretzel no one can ask more than that!
author: Marie J.

description: Phenomenal hamburger, delicious pork chop, and a fantastic baked goat cheese appetizer.  Oh, and they have a lot of really good beer, too.  The Monk's Kettle is further proof that the Belgian beer and "New American" food crazes are still alive and well.  Throw in some hipsters and you've got yourself a guaranteed hot spot.  Great choice for a fun night out and a tummy ache from the absurdly rich food the next day.
author: Laurence W.

description:
People are saying it is a good place. Yes, it is! 125 different flavors of beer, good atmosphere, and decent food. They apparently gained more staff, besides the waiter, the food runner helped us to get attention as well.  

The down side is that it is overprice. I agree with the other review that the price is almost double compare to other places in the mission. However, if you want a place that is full of beer selection, it is the place to go!
author: Michelle W.

description:
There's only one drawback to this place:

Everyone loves it.  I think, I hope.  We had to sit at the bar because tables were limited to those eating entrees.  Alright, the bar turned out to have a nice nook, and so it was fine.  

The beer list is pages and pages long and contains a great variety of beer from many different places.  

The food is fantastic.  I can't remember what I had, but it was definitely great, savory.  (It was, essentially, a steak sandwich, but way better crafted than my language will do justice at the moment.)

The atmosphere was dark, candlelit, and cozy.  It's not a very large place, but it seems to manage the sound so it's not too loud, and also (even though I didn't eat dinner at a table), seemed to allow some level of privacy at the tables.  

Of the two times I've been so far, the service was great.  It was definitely better the first time, when the server introduced himself and said he would take care of us.  Both servers were knowledgeable about the beer (very important), and service lacked any significant errors both times.

I can't wait to go back.
author: cyndi t.

description:
I have to go gluten free so my choices were cider or gluten free beer.  Glad that they have that, although $15 for  single beer is a bit steep.  (next time I'll check the cider prices)
The one gluten free beer they have is: St. Peter's Brewery Gluten Free Sorghum Beer, which run about $5 retail. Available at bev mo and such.
The service was very good and they seemed to be very friendly with the water. We sat at the bar so missed the line.
author: Bo D.

description: I love their food. I particularly crave their burgers and olives. I hear they have some great Belgian beers. It seemed like the staff was very knowledgeable about their selection of beers. I say "it seemed" because I'm not a drinker :)
author: Tina F.

description:
I. LOVE. THIS. PLACE.

It is my bo-bo Cheers.  Everybody there knows my name, BECAUSE I CAN'T NOT COME THERE ONCE A WEEK.  

5 pages of beer?  BEER GEEKS, REJOICE!

Organic everything?  PRIUS DRIVERS, REJOICE!

Delicious gastropub food with excellent beer pairing suggestions?  FOODIES, REJOICE!

Yes, I am a fan. Things to not miss:

     *  The lamb burger.  Oooooh, yes.  I've experimented at home and I think the secret is seasoning the lamb with ample coriander and parsley, and then double-whammying that with a bitchin' cucumber-dill tzatziki.

     *  The fries.   I'm the kind of person that individually ketchups their fries, and then uses "ketchup" as a verb.  Except when I'm at Monk's Kettle.  The fries are THAT GOOD that I do not even consider ketchup (though they do come with excellent aoli's and a chipotle ketchup).

     *  The cheese plate:  an awesome deal and uber-foodie artisanal sampling.

     *  The salads:  generally, are great, large, and micro-greenish.  


The downside?  Oh, yah.  The line.  But sit at the bar, drink more beers than you intended to, and all will be fine.
author: Lopa V.

description:
It's in a fairly unkempt, sort of Street Chic neighborhood. However, don't let the surroundings fool you. This is a top of the line beer bar! They've got some really remarkable beers. They had Old Rasputin XI nearly two years after it's release and Duvel Green. The problem? Their beers are insanely expensive. This is in no way cheap, and not even a little pricey, it's damn expensive ($14 for some 8 oz pours)! Look at some of the bottle prices and you'll see my point. Which makes me think that it clearly is catering to an older crowd.

The establishment itself is very nice. Lot's of wood, with a beautiful bar! Proper glassware is served with all the beers.

The tap list really isn't the best I've seen, but it's good enough that it makes me interested. The bottle selection is really where they shine. I really wish they weren't so expensive, cause some of them are fucking gems! Yes, they have their fair share of very pedestrian beers, which are slightly more reasonably priced. Luckily for me they poured me an 8 oz glass of what was advertised as a 4 oz pour, which was really cool of them!

I had a sausage sandwich, which was quite good. Definitely better than other ones I've had, so that was a plus. My wife described her chicken sandwich as "good in theory." Guess it just didn't deliver the goods! The food is also very pricey and for the price it really doesn't deliver. If my sandwich was $8 instead of $15 I would've been in heaven.

Will I ever go back here? Only if someone else is paying! The prices just kill it and for as good as they are it's just not worth it if you're on any type of budget.

------

I would give this place 3 stars based on how overpriced they are, but anywhere that has beer this good, regardless of price gets an automatic 4 stars!
author: Benjamin F.

description:
Despite my tight jeans, love of flannel and my black converse shoes, I still believe that I am not a hipster.  And thus I hadn't been to Monk's Kettle because I figured it was some pretentious hipster hangout.

But managed to walk in last night around 8:30 and get a seat immediately at the bar.

The bartender was super helpful in offering recommendations and I didn't find the beer to be overpriced considering the quality.  The bartender allowed us to sample a couple beers before settling on the next round.

So yes, I'd definitely come back here for more beer.  And for dirty hipster love.  You should come here too.  For both.
author: Evan L.

description:
I was going to round up from 2-1/2 stars because a server was terrific, but the single unisex bathroom pounded it back down to 2.

The beer selection is wide ranging and excellent though strangely heavy on the IPA's for an establishment trying so hard to associate itself with Belgian and Trappist Ales. My biggest complaint is that the entire beer menu is ludicrously overpriced. The food could be cheaper considering the quality and quantity, but the mark up on the beer is absolutely  sinful. Whomever is posting reviews only listing the price range at $$ is doing the community a disservice. 

It is just about impossible to avoid a comparison to Le Trappe in North Beach, and the Kettle pales in every way. How a similar place in one of the most expensive parts of town can produce a better dining and drinking experience for less than one in The Mission is a mystery to me.
author: James S.

description: If you want pretentious staff and ok food...dine at Monk's Kettle.  This is a pub with a stuffy wine bar attitude.  Dude...it's beer!!!  (I prefer Rosamunde's beer selection and staff the end)
author: ada l.

description:
I can't believe I haven't written a review for this place yet. We went to dinner here and it took a while to get a table, but the bar was more than happy to ply us with beer and wine while we waited. 

Once seated the service was great, the food was good, and the beer selection was to die for.....

If you are a beer lover you should give this place a shot!
author: Alisa S.

description:
I will start by saying the beers were delicious and the ambiance was cozy. The host, waiting service, and staff made this the MOST AWKWARD dinner I have ever had. Similar to other comments, I met a group of friends there but were told the party was too large.  The host was quite hostile about us not squeezing people in at the table and said if he had known the party was so big they would have told us to go somewhere else. 

We honestly respected that there are fire codes and it's a small place, but we tried to have one person stand at the end of the table, out of the way. We had the waiter say it was ok, then another staff member come and said it's not ok and the waiter was "just being diplomatic."

We ordered appetizers and a round of beers and were talking when the waiter came up to our table and asked if we were going to order anything else. We said we weren't sure and then he said that the host should have told us that we have to order dinner. We understood that they have a busy establishment, and were going to order more food/drinks until the waiter said, "Everyone would like to sit at a booth all night and drink a few beers, but our wait list is three hours long... but go ahead and finish your beers at your own pace..." 

We spent no more than an hour there and they made it clear that they wanted us OUT because we were not running up the tab fast enough. We really wanted a second round of beers but decided they clearly do not deserve/want our business -- I do have to mention that our tab was still close to $200 after that one round and three appetizers (including the more than generous tip we still left).

Honestly, I am not picky about service at restaurants, but I have never been to any restaurant where they are so blatantly rude! I think we would have had a better experience as a group of three or four, but I will never recommend anyone to go there.
author: Kristin S.

description: Gets packed fast so come early. Best beer selection in the Mission but a bit pricey.  Food was decent.
author: L T.

description:
Love that they have a beer somelier to help you with food and beer pairings! The waitress was incredibly helpful in helping us select beers.  

We ordered the ahi sandwich and pot pie. For dessert, we had the oatmeal raisin cookie w/ice cream and the bread pudding

The sandwich was yummy. If you can imagine a sashimi sandwich with aoli sauce that was pretty much what it was and it was oh-so-delicieux!

The pot pie was delicious as well.  And their deserts were to die for.  If you have a huge sweet tooth like me, you'll love the oatmeal raisin cookie served hot and gooey!
author: Donna M.

description:
Let me start by saying that if money is no object, this is a 4- to 5-star place.  The beer selection is great and the food is amazing.  You can find great limited beers like The Bruery Papier and Russian River Supplication way after they're gone from all local stores.

Unfortunately for most of us who aren't Bill Gates, the Google founders, a big-time professional athlete, or an evil, greedy investment banking executive, money is a thing.  Well, that is, until we go to Monk's Kettle.  After that, the thing in our wallets that was originally a bunch of money will have completely disappeared.

This place is really, really, ridiculously expensive.  Bottles of beer that you can get for $12 at City Beer, Healthy Spirits, or even Toronado are going to run you damn near $40 here.  They mark up beer like most nice restaurants do with wine.  Now let me just say as an aside that the reason I have a problem with this is not because beer is an inferior product.  I think a great beer is at least the equal of a great wine.  I just think that 2.5x or higher wine mark-ups are insane and people are crazy to pay them, and I enjoy the fact that great beer can still be had with a great meal for a reasonable price.  Not at Monk's Kettle.  You're going to be paying (and I read directly from their beer list) $35 for an AleSmith Speedway Stout (usually $12), $11.25 for a Duvel (usually $3.50), and $28 for a Lost Abbey Judgment Day (usually $10).

Reading these prices off their menu is really quite startling.  Makes you jump out of your seat and yell, "Shit dogg!"  For you British people out there, that's roughly the equivalent of "Blimey!" or "Crikey!" or "Crimony!" or "Blikony!" or whatever you crazy people say.  They occasionally have a half-price happy hour where their prices actually fall into the same range as City Beer's or Toronado's.  This is the only time I'd recommend going here if you just want good beer.  Otherwise there are far better options nearby (see 2 sentences before this).

However, if you can take the wallet hit and want to impress someone with great food paired with world class beer, this is the place.  I had some really excellent food there.  There simply aren't many things better than great beer and great food.  Last time I went, I had a charcuterie plate, a creamy bowl of tomato soup, and a pulled pork sandwich, along with a La Trappe Isid'Or, a Ballast Point Sculpin IPA, and an '05 North Coast Old Stock Ale (reasonably priced surprisingly!).  All were incredible.  Monk's Kettle can really wow you, but you're going to have to hand over the majority of your paycheck for the pleasure.  Oh yeah, and it gets crowded and they don't typically take reservations.  Go before 6:30 for a weekend dinner unless you want to wait hours for a table.

Now if you'll excuse me, I'm heading to Monk's Kettle to shell out $85 for a beer dinner.  D'oh!

*Final note: I should also add Jermaine Dupri and Jay-Z to the list of people who don't think money is a thing, since they had a song specifically called, "Money Ain't a Thing."
author: Nick D.

description: Awesome beer selection, expensive but tasty food. A little cramped inside but service is great.
author: Mark K.

description:
This is an incredible place to go for a lazy rainy Sunday.  The bf and I parked ourselves into a cozy booth and enjoyed some deliciously complex beers.  We also slowly ate our way through the fennel pork sausage, the mussels, the housemade meatloaf grinder, and the coffee pot de creme.  The waiters were knowledgeable about the beer and the food.  Everything tasted well-balanced and fresh.  The meatloaf is actually ground beef stuffed into a roll which was a pleasant surprise.  I recommend asking them for their house-made mustard.  It tasted great on the roll and with the fries!  I also especially loved the coffee pot de creme - great texture and not too sweet.  It is a must-try.

I'm knocking off 1 star for the mark-up on the beers.  I appreciate their extensive selection, but the prices are kind of a rip off.
author: Carmen L.

description:
Maybe you haven't heard but.... I like beer. 

Monk's Kettle has plenty of it! And good beer too! Aligator is sooo happy. :-) 

As for food everything I've had so far (about 5 things) have been delicious. The mac n cheese is very creamy, kinda like a Velveeta sauce. I'm more of a "real cheese" mac n cheese, but it's still very good. The steak sandwich is really really good. It comes with a blue cheese aoili that is delicious. The baby arugula salad is also very good. 

I highly recommend coming here if you are a beer fan. If you're coming for food, come early and be ready for a wait. If you're coming for beer, then be ready for the crowded late night weekends. But, it's worth the wait. 

Also, it's a good place to take your man on a date (has a very simple, modern man decor and style to the place). Even if he orders a salad and you order steak. :-)
author: Ali R.

description:
Second on a run of eight restaurants and stops on the List (AH, did we really manage to pull off eight in a row?!  I am a glutton, and I LOVE it!  See pictures here: http://pineapplebread.wordpress.com/2010/05/25/the-list-an-8-restaurant-marathon-through-the-mission/), Monk's Kettle was probably my favorite of our stops in our quest to get as many 7x7 List items in our bellies in one day.  

The extensive beer collection and knowledgeable bartender truly impressed me, and I definitely want to go back sometime soon.  

PS, the pretzel and mustard were amazing.  The mustard, especially, was delicious.  I would just eat that mustard straight up with a spoon if they'd let me.  Hm, maybe next time I go, I'll just ask for a beer with a side of mustard . . . :D
author: Jeanne Y.

description: My friend took me here for lunch and this lil ol place is actually pretty decent. For all you beer lovers out there, there's an extensive list of beers so you'll be quite satisfied. I got the pulled pork sandwich and damn it was good. I tried my friend's mac and cheese with bacon bits and before you know it I kept asking for more.
author: Diane L.

description:
Talk about a perfect place for a date with your bestie!  Initially there was a short wait for our table but that's normal and we didn't mind.  After eating there, I can say it's worth it even if there is a long wait.

We had the chili as an appetizer.  It's vegan, it was delicious.  We chose to add the optional creme fraiche.  The chili lasted about 5 minutes.  Great chunks of veggies, had a little kick but nothing overly spicy.  Mmmm.

Blubie had a lamb burger with a cucmber yogurt sauce and I had a steak sandwich.  Both were super awesome.  Often a steak sandwich entails overcooked, chewy meat so I tend to skip it.  But this place was pushing such a good vibe I went for it.  Good calldo.

They only have beer and wine, but they have lots of it.  If you want cocks, maybe put your name on the list and then hop across the street to kilowatt while you wait.  :)
author: Emily T.

description: The staff is extremely friendly and helpful. They enjoy helping you find the perfect beer for your tastes buds. The decor is super warm and inviting. The beer selection is outstanding!
author: Kristi D.

description:
Small jam packed, but well worth the wait.  I've been here on a Tuesday and Wednesday night, and both nights we waited on the longer side.  The first thing here is I like how the host provides actual estimates and takes down your #.  No bullshit, uneducated guesses.  

We ended up waiting up to two hours once, and when we sat down, the server brought over a complimentary app.  Nice little touch.  I agree - the beer here is on the pricier side, but keep in you're not drinking bud light and having 209483208 to get slammed.  It's a nicer establishment.

Foodwise, the french fries are delicious.  I've had the muscles and ahi burger, which are both delicious.  I shared the lamb burger once, which was decent but didn't really stand out.  

Can't wait to go back and try the lobster pot pie, I've only heard great things.

This place is best for parties of 2, but totally doable to be a 4 top if you're willing to put your name down and walk to another spot for a drink.  

Oh and an added bonus, the servers and bartenders are pretty hot.
author: Laura H.

description: I went here on my last full day of vacation, this past Friday. My mom and I sat at the bar and had a really great meal. We had a super adorable waiter/bartender as well. Their burger was everything you'd want in a burger, although it was done a little more on the rare side than medium for me. I know, I know, I could have said something but apparently I didn't care THAT much because I couldn't stop eating it it tasted so good. White cheddar, onion relish, how could you stop? Anyway, I know I was supposed to get beer here and I love beer, but I just was not feelin it at the time. However, if you come here and drink beer, I don't think you will be disappointed as there are plenty of selections ;)
author: Anna T.

description:
#50 on 7x7's SF 2009 Big Eat: Giant pretzel with mustard at Monk's Kettle: check.  

The pretzel was enough for 2, and a bit too salty for me.  I scraped all the salt off and preferred dipping it with the cheese than with the mustard.  I have not had a chicken pot pie since I was a child and got a few bites of it here. The crispy, buttery layer on top sealed in the heat of the creamy soup inside.  

Upon the recommendation of our waitress, I ordered the Duchesse de Bourgogne- a beer consisting of fruity, sour, and tart flavors.  I was looking for the blueberry beer that I had the last time I was here, but unfortunately they were out, so opted for the Duchesse.   At first the Duchesser was good, but as it sits, it becomes sweeter, almost like concentrated juice.  
 
The chalkboard at the rear is always fun.  Plus, it's right where the kitchen is so you smell everything that's cookin in there!
author: Lisa C.

description: I love monks!!! This is my favorite place to eat and drink in the city. It's small, so don't come with a large group. The veggie burger and regular burgers are your best deals, but everything else I've eaten there is always top notch. Come back often because the beer and food menus change pretty often.
author: Ana Y.

description:
Ok what the hell is the deal with Monk's Kettle? I hear all the hype from my friends and I read that their big pretzel is on some list of top 100 dishes to try in SF before you die. It's because of all this hype that I waited a (long... very long) hour and a half to get seated for our party of 5. I told everyone in my group: "Ok guys, their big pretzel is supposed to be awesome!"

So we order a few beers, a few of the house burgers, and the big pretzel. Ok the pretzel was a tremendous let down. Was it a well-made pretzel? Hmm, I guess so. Was it worth $8-9 (I forgot exactly how much but it was around there)?? HELL NO. I swear that the pretzel is just as good at any movie theater or Auntie Anne's for a quarter of the price. Monk's Kettle's pretzel is one of the most overhyped, overpriced food items I've ever witnessed. 

Anyways, their burgers were OK at best. The bun was way too cold and thick... at least toast that shit first so I don't bite into a thick layer of cold bread. The burgers were well cooked, but it was overall just a so-so burger. I probably have eaten better burgers at my family BBQs every 4th of July.

One good thing is the beer selection. I really liked the house amber beer they had there (forgot what it was called). I got 2 pints of that & would definitely like to try more of their beers.

All in all, though, Monk's Kettle was an absolute disappointment. If you just want beers, I think it's fine. But if you want good, quality bar food, there are A THOUSAND better bar restaurants all over SF.

Don't. Believe. The. Hype.
author: Roy C.

description:
Wait, this is the beer list and not the menu? over four pages of bottled and draught beers listed by type and clearly listing the APV and origin of location.

I came here however, for the burger because I heard it was one of the best that San Francisco offered. I got mine cooked medium, with mushrooms and bacon. It came medium well however, but still tasted great and the fries were cooked and salted perfectly. 

The only thing I found odd was how the bartender did not really want us to sit at the tables, and when our group of 6 exceeded the amount of chairs- we weren't able to get an extra one. And when I finally ordered my drink, I watched her open it and do about six other things before bringing it to me, which didn't make sense because it was just busy work. 

I wouldn't say I would run here to get dinner and a drinks, but it wasn't the worst place to go.
author: Marissa F.

description:
I'm not a big beer person but if I were, this place would probably have gotten 5 stars.  But, I still loved it because:
a) The bartender was the coolest!  I told her that I wanted to try something new, preferably wheaty, smooth, and not too hoppy - and she totally hooked me up w/ a crazy good german beer that I can't remember now.  But she poured the bottle in this funky way, explaining the process and why it was done that way to help bring out the flavors.  Very cool.
b) The giant pretzel was SO GOOD.  Definitely worthy of the Big Eat list.  Fresh out of the oven - crispy on the outside, soft and doughy on the inside.  And the mustard and cheese sauces - soooo yummy!  

I've got my eye on their Mac and Cheese w/ Bacon - I will definitely be returning for that in the near future!
author: Cindy W.

description:
In my mid-twenties I got fat. . . basically I looked normal but I was fat.  My BMI index resulted in my doctor saying that I don't look overweight but I am as dense as a sack of flour.

So in my late twenties, I stopped drinking beer (and switched to scotch).  I stopped eating out (and started eating my own cooking).  The lack of hops and hatred for my own cooking, along with a push to being much more active, helped me lose over fifteen pounds.

So what does this have to do with Monk's Kettle?  I'm back to loving beer.  I can't live without good quality Belgian or German beer.  Monk's and Suppenkuche helped me embrace my need for a frothy, cool, thirst-quenching pint of the world's finest brewed beer.  Not to mention that the food is above-par as well.  The lamb burger is excellent and they have a mean pulled-pork sandwich.

But be sure to try a few from their extensive menu of lagers and ales, especially if you like the Belgians. . . some favorites include: Echte Kriekenbier, St. Bernardus and Trappiste Rochefort.  It's crowded on the usual busy nights, but they try to accomodate.  The guy at the front will even call you, if you decide to grab a drink across the way.
author: E L.

description:
I normally don't drink beer (I'm a cran-vodka type of girl), but when we do go out to places like this I would always ask for a sweet beer.  I asked the bartender if she had Lindeman's Framboise and she said no, but she had something that I would like.  It was the Duchess de Bourgogne.  It was a great beer, not too sweet like the Framboise and you could still taste the alcohol.  

We ordered the pretzel, which was made perfectly,  but WAY too overpriced! Almost $9 for a pretzel!!!
author: Michelle L.

description:
I'll leave my reaction to the Chicken Pot Pie to my friend, David Cross -- http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ApmvDU5RmyY.  This dish was a perfect lesson of quality over quantity -- only a small golden cylinder, but the creamy spoonful of vegetables, chicken, & dough were executed to a T.  

Dutch Brown Belgian was a great partner to the pot pie, but there was a wide selection of beers that would have been just as suitable.  

I also sampled my friends' flank steak sandwich and organic veggie burger, giving the nod to the latter.
author: LJ W.

description:
3.5 stars

Great atmosphere, friendly service, awesome beer selection. The mac was ok - kinda pricey at $12 but HUGE portion...cheese sauce was pretty good. Skirt steak was really good! 

Only dings are that it is super small, no resos accepted and the parking situation is horrendous. I think my next get-rich-quick scheme should be to open a 10-story parking garage in this area, good god. Still, a very cute/nice gastropub with good food!
author: Adrienne C.

description:
When we were walking up to Monk's Kettle I thought we were walking into Delirium. Passing by, the smell of despair wafted out into the crisp autumn air of the mission district. But we walked by and into Monk's Kettle.

My first impression was that the staff had a lot of irony in the facial hair arena.

Monk's has a fairly robust selection of beers. There are quite a few more belgium beers on draught in San Francisco than in San Diego. Which is fine, but it's not always my cup of tea.

The standard size is the 20oz Imperial Pint, which I'd like to see develop as a trend throughout the beer serving world. 20 ounces of Pliny the Elder is a fine way to set the evening up properly.

We also ordered the soft pretzel. Served with a rich cheese sauce and some mustard based side. This isn't your county fare soft pretzel, but they didn't reinvent the wheel here either. It's still entirely comforting to dip salted bread into cheese, there's just a little extra panache that's worth checking out.

My only complaint is that the soft pretzel was north of $8. So, unless you're serving that pretzel wrapped in a New York Strip, it just seems inappropriate to charge that much for a pretzel.
author: James G.

description:
One of the -- maybe THE -- best beer selections at any sit-down restaurant in San Francisco. The owners know their stuff; and whether you fancy top-notch American craft beer or a superb selection of Belgian ales, this place is for you. You'll even get your beer served to you in the proper glass.

Other tips:
Their pulled port sandwich is excellent.
The French fries come with three dipping sauces -- all very good.
The place is small; so, if you can, come by some time in the middle of the afternoon. That's my practice, and I've never had to wait for a table.
author: Arthur C.

description:
I'm not sure if my lunch at the Monk's Kettle reflected the typical experience there. I chanced upon this gastropub on a lazy Sunday afternoon, devoid of the crowds, the long waits, and the bouncers that many other reviewers have complained about. I thought I had stumbled upon some hidden gem in the Mission, which, judging by the reviews and crowds, is clearly not the case.

First and foremost, the beer list is extensive and excellent. There are a number of great choices on tap, as well as many bottled Belgian ales, lambics, tripels, sour ales, even gluten-free beers, etc. well-organized on their menu. Servers were knowledgeable and helpful. I would warn, however, that some of the prices are erring on becoming exorbitant. 

The food was overall tasty, upscale pub food. I had a California Cassoulet special that was creative with organic tomatoes, if a bit on the dry side. My friend's pulled pork sandwich was delicious and just what you'd expect with a good beer.

I would definitely return here, though would probably stick to "off" hours to avoid the crowds.
author: Britt M.

description: Our friend in San Francisco brought us to the Monk's Kettle on our whirlwind tour.  Very good beer selection, among the most varied that we saw in SF.  We stopped in for a drink on our way to our next destination for the day.  I believe that there is an emphasis on belgian beers here, but they still have lots of local beers and beer for all types of palates.  Bartender was friendly and helpful with selections. Did not try the food, but would certainly return when we have more time on future visit.  Only drawback was the size of the place, which is tiny, as most people had to wait for a table.  Due to the size of the place, I would be surprised if they take reservations.
author: Andre B.

description:
I'll come clean - I'm British, so I love my pub food (and cider). A few friends had raved about Monk's Kettle and the menu looked great, so we took our chances and ventured down there. We only had to wait about 20 mins for a table and the door guy and staff were really friendly. Can't fault the beer and cider we ordered (although the prices were eye-watering).
 
We both ordered a hearty meal - and were both pretty disappointed. The game hen was ok but bland and nearly flavourless. The pork chop was also pretty lacking in flavour except for being smothered in an overly-sweet sickly sauce. I love pork and beer/cider sauce but everything on my plate was overwhelmed by the sauce's flavour. The potato cake tasted rather cheap. The garlicky brussels sprouts with bacon were delicious, though.
My local back home does an amazing Sunday roast dinner at £10 a pop - these entrees were $20-$25 each and I find it hard to imagine how on earth they managed to cook food so flavourless.
 
I don't like basing reviews on one meal and I'd come back, but maybe order a burger or cheese plate next time.
author: Annie C.

description:
Monk's Kettle is the perfect place to try that organically produced Colorado-brewed Scottish-style beer in a colorful can with a long inside joke name that you you don't really get that you have always wanted to try.  The beer menu here is nonsensically long, and you will never drink your way through it, especially given the long waits it often takes to get a seat here.  But the Kettle is worth the wait.  

Not only do they have a well stocked and organized beer selection, but the food is fantastic.  The giant pretzel with cheddar sauce is necessary starting point, but everything else I have tried is also good...fries, mussels, you name it.  Most recently I had the lamb burger (medium rare) which was lean but flavorful.  The beef and turkey burgers here are also very good, and I still reminisce over a seafood pot pie I had here over a year ago which was a morsel of divine inspiration (monks, please please bring it back!).  I want to go back to try the lobster pot pie they are currently featuring.

Service can be hit or miss, especially when the place gets crowded, which is the only thing that keeps this place from 5 stars.  Unlike some others here, I have never had problems with the door staff, who will take your cell number and call you if you when a table is ready if you want to grab a pre-drink drink nearby.
author: Aaron S.

description:
I like Monk's Kettle but I think it is overcrowded and overrated.  The beer selection is huge and I applaud that.  

The mousey doorman is pretentious and makes the waiting experience a pain in the ass.  I'd rather get a seat at the bar than be sat by you.  If you happen to sit near the kitchen there are cool chalkboards that you can play hangman and draw random shit, that is always fun.

The giant pretzel is like a overpriced giant pretzel, the only thing that redeems it is the cheddar ale dipping sauce which is delicious.  Their regular burger is good, their lamb burger is mediocre.
author: Skye W.

description:
This is a beer universe. Beer all the time. That is its nature. There may be other universes based on all sorts of other principles, but ours seems to be based on beer and salty foods.  

Monk's Kettle is a celebration of beer, a universe unto its own, as the 6-7 page beer menu denotes.

But there is food here as well. As lavish as the food is described on paper, and despite the attention paid to its preparation, it clearly plays second fiddle to the brews. Just compare the 2 page food menu to the beer menu, which is continuously updated and affixed to a clipboard. No chef can change the fact that a pretzel is a pretzel or a french fry is a french fry. It's really all about the beer, any foods are really pretense to embellish the experience of drinking fine imported beer.

Is it always worth it? The crowds, the price? Almost unequivocally. Yet both are just prohibitive enough to  provoke serious second thoughts unless the night's agenda calls for beer, and extravagant beer at that. Then there is no question. After all, we live in a beer universe.
author: Alan F.

description:
AMAZING!! 5 Pages of beer is almost like being in Heaven. 

We had a group of 5 on a Saturday night at 11pm and it was packed inside. We waited for a short amount of time before we were sat at a booth. 

Here's the food:

Fries: Can't go wrong but you're definitely an overachiever if you're putting a curry aioli as a dipping sauce. It went from good to perfect with that curry... 

Pretzel: Fresh and hot out of the oven. Served with two different types of mustards. Delicious with beer.

Here are some of the drinks I remembered having:

Tokyo: Strong, fragrant, and strong... That's all I can say... It tasted almost like a liquor. A 4oz pour can definitely get a light weight like me buzzed.

Reality Check: Fresh, refreshing, and pure wonderful in a glass. 

Hitachino Red Rice: I love Hitachinos and they carry two variety right now. Red Rice and the classic White Ale. Definitely hit the spot. 

Hard Apple Cider: My cousin has a super low tolerance for alcohol so she ordered a hard apple cider. Tasted delicious, like a spiked Martinelli's apple cider.

These are all the names that I can recall. Nat the owner is extremely gracious and all of his staff are amazing servers on top of having a wikipedia of beers in their brain. 

They are packed so be patient. It is well worth the wait. You will understand why people don't want to leave when you do get inside. 

Nat! We will send Terry over to deliver your togo order! Please keep him there and feed him drinks and pretzels! I will be back soon for that Magnum!
author: Wanster L.

description: Yay for the mustard. It comes with charcuterie (duck prosciutto was the best) and the pretzel, and is amazing. Mustard. Mustard mustard mustard. Oh yes, and the beer - great selection.
author: Angie C.

description:
This is definitely one of those places that if you are not familiar with the area you can easily pass it by.  

This place has a really cozy feel, the decor and atmosphere is really inviting.  They have a really great beer selection and a decent wine selection.  We started with the Pretzel Knots, which were amazing; nice and doughy.  Both the cheese sauce and the mustard were tasty.  The Daily Pickle was good; nice brine, more like a half-sour.  Not only do you get cucumber, you get string beans, cauliflower, and cocktail onions.

My wife ordered the Chicken paillard.  The chicken was tender and was very flavorful; I only had one bite, but it seemed to be a marinade on the sweeter side.

This is where they get dinged one star.  I ordered the burger, which was good, but they failed to cook it to my desired finish; rare to medium rare.  The first bite was extremely juicy, but after that first bite the burger was void of any moisture and was medium well.  This is the 2nd establishment I have been to in 2 weeks where they are known for a great burger and this is the 2nd time I experienced an overcooked burger.

The shoestring fries were perfect.

We have every intention of coming back, but I will be a little more demanding if the burger can't be cooked as asked.
author: Shane C.

description: I had high hopes for this place, but it was not as awesome as I had hoped. Biggest gripe, the beer prices are exorbitantly high. Also while the food was certainly good, for the prices I would expect them to be just a little more attentive. For example they switched the medium rare and medium steaks in our order. With was not that big a deal, but for the prices they charge these kind of mistakes should be avoided. We really liked the atmosphere of the place. And I would go back for a meal and a drink. I would not plan to go there to hang out an evening with a group of friends however.
author: J R.

description: Had the candied bacon wrapped shrimp and polenta paired with a russian imperial stout. Wow. So yummy! The folks here know their stuff, i will defa be back to try more!
author: Sean S.

description:
My, how this place has changed.

Way back, when the Mission was still a Hispanic neighborhood, this place was a Mexican bakery.

Then it shut down and changed into something else.

Then it became a burger joint that served some pretty good burgers and philly cheesesteaks.

Now it's Monk's Kettle!

I gave you a bit of the history just to show you why the set-up in this place is kind of weird. You walk in and you're stuck. There's a barstool (and a person sitting on it) immediately in front of you. You have to turn left.

After you turn left, there are tables. You must turn right.

To your left are tables, to your right is the bar. Keep walking...

Finally, bar ends and changes into 'kitchen.' There's like 3-4 seats and a counter next to the bathroom. There's a blackboard too. That's it. Eat your heart out.

Oh yeah, and the beer selection is out of this world!! Food's awesome as well - aim for the burgers, please.
author: Ken L.

description:
Terrible service sum's it up. Went in for a quick beer before dinner at Puerto Alegre. The beer was borderline flat. I told the bartender and he said he would have someone look at in. Meanwhile, I'm sitting there with a flat beer and was offered absolutely nothing to replace it ,or  even told when/if there would be any conclusion regarding my pint of flat beer.

15 full minutes later and now a flat, and warm, beer sitting in front of me I flag down a waitress to get our check because the bartender was busy stuffing his face and completely ignoring us. 

I wouldn't go back to this place unless forced to. I'm sure there are other, more competent, bartenders working there but with so many good bars in spitting distance why bother with the crappy service and flat beer?
author: Bryan M.

description:
We went to this place last night to grab some foods and beers, but i am rating only the food though cuz i am not a beer fan. 

We ordered Sesame seed coated sashimi grade Ahi and Premium Gold Natural Angus' Flank Steak sandwiches with fries. I am just only giving 2.5 stars for the food cuz I've experienced better in other places. My Ahi sandwiches was not stood out  if comparing $16.50 for this order. Also, on the Flank Steak didn't have much beef really and again this dish cost $ 13.75 

Moreover, this place isn't good for a big party due to a tiny  table.

Service is just ok though.
author: Sasitorn O.

description:
Came here with a smallish group for a Saturday night dinner. The beer and food were fantastic, though I can't give 5 stars due to high prices and cramped quarters. That aside, it is still definitely worth coming.

We arrived and put our names in for a table. We were told it would be about 45 minute wait, so we gave a cell phone number and went next door to a bar to pass the time. After about 30 minutes we realized all of us have AT&T, meaning none of us had any service, so I went back just to check on progress. Luckily, the host said he was just about to call us.

Our waiter was prompt and fairly quick, but most impressive was his knowledge of the beer menu. He was able to help the indecisive ones  in our group pick a beer based on tastes and qualities they like in other beers (though he did generally recommend toward the more expensive, but can't blame a guy for doing his job).

For food we all went somewhat "tapas" style of a couple pretzels and a couple orders of mac n cheese that we all shared. Probably should have gotten something more substantial, but the high prices turned us off.
author: Kevin M.

description: Prefect place to grab a Belgium beer.  They have over like few hundred different kinds of Belgium beer, (approximately?)  One of my favor hang out place in the mission.  They also have a full menu as well,  kill the buzz before last call.
author: Jade P.

description: Very impressed with this place. Not just because of their enormous beer selection, but how good the food is. I have consistently had the burger, and I have never been downed from it. Get it with the bacon, and match it with a beer (if you do not know how to pair the burger with a a nice brew, just ask!). I do also here good things about their mushroom risotto. Definitely coming back for seconds, thirds, and man they are open til 1am!
author: Howard J.

description:
Took a couple tries to hit on a beer that they actually had in stock, but hey, what can you expect when they have about 8 billion beers on the menu.  The beer can be sort of pricey, but it's okay to splurge on quality once in a while.  Probably not the best place to get shit faced though...

Fries were made less generic with unique dipping sauces. . . who knew that curry aioli would go so well with fries?  Mushroom and brie tart seemed a little overpriced for the small portion size . . . the mushrooms were probably organically grown at some special self-sustained farm or something.
author: Jenny R.

description: Great for taste-testing different beers. I'm not even a big pretzel fan but there's was delicious with the dips.
author: Roxy B.

description:
My first, only, and last time at Monk's Kettle occurred this past Saturday, when a few friends from out of town and I went on quest for some good brews.  The door guy is so f#@king rude, I was at a loss for words--definitely did not make a good first impression. There were 6 of us and he demanded that at least three of us had to to be eating. WTF? It's 11:30 at night, and the amount of money you charge for some of the beers would easily make up for it. I get it, you're a small establishment, blah blah blah, but don't be a dick about it.

So half of us aborted the mission when went to another bar down the street and once the rest of us did make it in, the help was genuinely nice,  so that's where the 1 star is going to. Our server was knowledgeable and attentive. He just needs to tell his cohort, the door nazi,  to lose the 'tude. Seriously, in this economy?
author: Joe C.

description: Fairly good beer and food ( but expensive) but service is not what I'd expect - asked for an extra scoop of ice cream for my brownie since two teaspoon sizes clearly wasn'tenough - can do for an extra $2 after having spent over $100 - give me a break!  But no, that was the rule!  And the waiter changed after that and they wanted us out of there asap after that.  I guess they have too many patrons to give a little service.  Goodbye!!!
author: Rick D.

description:
My boyfriend and I are working on a relocation to the Mission and every time we go apartment hunting, we end up getting drunk...in a classy way...here at Monk's Kettle.

I usually have a few glasses of Syrah while he tries basically every exotic beer he can fit in his skinny belly. The same bartender has served us all three times we've been there and I hope she will consider being my best friend because I have a friend crush on her for realz.

Also...she said it was a one day only thing but we had Fried Pickles...and good God so effing delicious. Can't wait til I live here!!
author: Jen T.

description:
Just got back from there. If you can get a seat at this place, it is awesome. I had a lamb burger, and quite a few good beers. The waiter knew what he was talking about, and gave me great advice/suggested great beers that I haven't had before.  The cost of many of the beers is slightly higher than you'd expect for normal beers, but it is worth it.

If you feel like spending a little more money for good beer and pretty good bar food (The lamb burger with grilled onions, cheese and bacon turned out great), then this is the place to go.  My friend says this place is usually more croweded than it was, so that is one minus but otherwise check it out.
author: Jeff L.

description:
Why does a 5-table joint need a host?

Okay, y'all say the food and beer are outta this world, but what I want to know is how you made it past the idiot with the clipboard?

Because when I rolled up, I was stopped at the threshold by a small-ish, clipboard-toting youngster who seemed genuinely overwhelmed by the teeming crowd of his 12 bar-stool, 5-table empire. 

He was all, "uh, excuse me...?" when I steamrolled past him. Who even noticed him?

"Uh, er, are you on the list uh, er...?"

"The LIST???" Replied this Diva, dear readers.

"Uh, er, you gotta have a seat um, er..."

"You mean like these two empty bar stools right here?" Your Diva indicated two free bar stools. Meanwhile, Clipboard Imp's attention was caught by a drunken woman who body checked said Diva in the breastal area.

"The words you are looking for," your Diva purred, "are EXCUSE ME."

Clipboard Imp was now at Threat Level Orange. "Um, er...UM...ER...!!"

Your Diva, dear readers, decided to own the two empty seats at the bar.

"Um, er, I think like some other people were like um going to like sit there...UM...," Clipboard Imp limped, in his own way authoritative.

Your Diva thought about the sound he would make squishing under her stilettos. One quickly found Monk's Kettle to be quite tiresome and left, never to return.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
My boyfriend and I went Beerfest last November and the only beer that stood out in my drunken state was the Eisbock Aventinus.  Have you had this beer?  It is the nectar of the gods.  

Before giving Monk's Kettle a try I checked out the menu online to see if they had the *glorius* Aventinus.  They do.  It was the first thing that I ordered (yes, I know it's more of an after-dinner beer, but it was Tuesday, so whatever.)  My girlfriends ordered Judgement Day from Lost Abbey (dark, rich, slightly bitter) and Two-Week Noticie from Moonlight Brewing Company (light, and wonderful rosemary notes.)  Don't ask me what we had after that, because I honestly don't remember.

For noshing we ordered the pretzel which was yummy and from what I hear much better than the last pretzel - but it was cold on the inside.  The daily pickle was vinegary and crunchy and refreshing.  Next was the buttermilk battered fried rabbit.  The flavor was delicious, but the rabbit was a little tough (and I know my rabbit, I grew up with old-world grandparents and a whole grip of bunnies that we raised for food.)  The rabbit comes with homemade sauerkraut that is the bomb.  The burger was out of this world!  Order this and get the bacon, you can't go wrong.  

I was a beer and a half deep by the time I got to the sausage, but I remember it being juicy and perfectly cooked.  I think they make it in-house.  

For dessert, stout bread pudding.  I thought I wouldn't have room for this, but I couldn't resist.  

Service was a plus, too.  From the guy at the door who was polite and organized, to the bartender who knows his beer to our excellent waiter.  

Thank you!  I'll be back with my beer-loving boyfriend!
author: Michelle P.

description:
Went for a late meal on a Friday night and found a seat at the bar.  The one next to me opened up fairly quickly so by the time my friend got there, we were all set.

I really enjoyed the spinach salad we started with.  The dressing was great and all the ingredients went together fabulously.  The scallop pot pie was essentially a chowder with a biscuit on top so it should've been great but  it was too fishy.  The pulled pork sandwich was a little heavy on the sweet bbq sauce so I wasn't really a fan.

The beer selection is fantastic and the service was great (Hi, Kathy!) so I'm sure I'll be back but I'll probably just stick to the drinks and salads.
author: Seong P.

description: This place was just ok for me. Come here for the drinks but don't expect much of the food.  Our entrees weren't very flavorful, and my husband's pork was overcooked.  We loved the carrot cake though, which was moist and had a really light cream cheese frosting.  Yum!
author: Julie P.

description:
I've been going to Monk's Kettle since it opened. The food is great... I especially like the pretzel and the burger.  And the fries are perfectly crispy and tasty.

My one complaint is that the portions have become consistently smaller over time. The biggest disappointment is the flat iron steak has shrunk to the size of a flat hockey puck.  I definitely felt ripped off after paying $21 for about 4 bites of steak.
author: Tuffy M.

description:
Yummy selection of beers. 

Pretzels and cheese sauce are awesome.

My salad was boring and overpriced.

The big ass cookie with ice cream ruled it but was overpriced.

I think this place is a little pricey for what it is...if they dropped the price point a bit, I would give it four stars.
author: Christina S.

description:
The food is okay, some interesting ideas but nothing great.  

The reason to come here:  Beer.

Yes, boys and girls, they have great beers.  I like the Fullers, myself.  The bartenders should steer you in the right direction.  

The drawback is the size, it's fairly small.  If you're a party of four you're golden, more than that and you're in trouble.
author: Jess S.

description: This is hands down my favorite spot in the City! It's one of the first places I take my friends too and out of town visitors :) the entire staff is incredibly friendly. You don't have to feel afraid about not being informed about good beer when you walk in, they are more than willing to find a beer that you will love :)
author: Blake L.

description: I never write reviews, but I had to once I ate at Monks Kettle. The braised beef cheeks were so savory and tender. The beef just melted in your mouth - amazing! A must try!
author: Espie B.

description: Awesome for beer connoisseurs. This place has wide variety of beers on menu. Glad we discovered it today. My husband tried the Helle Weisse, it was a good German beer. We liked the cosy ambience as well.
author: Soup N.

description:
My first Yelp review ever finally gets a boost, three visits later.

A taste of the burger was delicious as always, as was the pretzel with the cheesy/buttery (i.e. "how can it possibly be bad") dipping sauce. I stuck with an arugula, feta, apple and vinaigrette salad, but the simple little meal (paired with a London Pale Ale) fit the bill on an annoyingly damp Sunday afternoon.

The service put it over the top this time. Our server was friendly, patient with our beer-pairing questions, and was zippy with the check at the end. I'm pretty much never coming back when it's busy, but I really do like it a lot.

Still on the expensive side (it *is* a place with a lot of imported beers that cost $10 and up) but we were treating a buddy nice enough to help move an enormous couch.

Seeing as how I've come back twice already, it's probably fair to say I'll do it again before long.
author: Tara R.

description:
There is not much to say here. This is the best beer place in San Francisco. It is better than Toronado and the food here:
A. actually exists
B. Is fucking delicious

Don't worry if you don't know much about beer. When you go there just holler at the bartender and tell him what normal crap you are used to imbibing and he'll hook you up with a magical liquid masterpiece along the lines of what you would normally enjoy. Furthermore, Monk's Kettle is one of the places that will go a long way in changing my perception of service in the great city of San Francisco. Feel free to ask questions about beer but be prepared to hear a passionate and truly engrossing answer that can only be given by someone that has truly honed their craft.

This is a top 5 spot for me for sure.
author: N S.

description:
So excellent! I never "plan" to go here, it always happens when I'm walking somewhere around 16th and Valencia and remember "Hey! Monk's Kettle is right around the corner! Let's stop for a great beer and snacks!" The two times I've been here, that's how I've ended up inside. 

Their beer list is huge. Seriously....it goes on for pages and pages. A little intimidating for those who don't truly know their beers, but they make it easy. Option 1: choose something on tap. Option 2: order food and take the beer pairing that they conveniently list on the menu. Helping the process along too are excellently detailed notes on each beer's type, brewery, ABV and general trends for particular types if you really have no idea what makes a pale ale and a pilsner different. 

By far, my favorite beer here is Reunion '09. It's a Double Wheat Beer from a brewery in San Leandro. It is the perfect combination of lemon/orange flavors seen in many wheat beers, with just a touch of hops to surprise you and make it interesting. 

Lastly, order the mac and cheese. And add bacon. Bacon makes everything better. And this mac and cheese didn't really need anything to make it better in the first place.
author: Jenna H.

description:
Went here on Saturday afternoon 5/15/2010 to celebrate GL's birthday. Immediately scored a table in the packed place by pure luck. Beer menu is IMPRESSIVE. About 5 pages of small type-- easily over 200 bottles to choose from. Draft selections around 20, all unusual and interesting. Something for any kind of beer lover here. 

I stuck with the draft Porters and Stouts. All excellent.

Food was also very well done. Quality suburb, presented well, prices as expected. Service was attentive and good. 

Overall: One of the best, if not the best, beer place in all of the Bay. Happy birthday Mr. Lucas!
author: Jason S.

description: I have only enjoyed beer here, and the beer selection is very good!  definitely a high end beer pub, word on the street is the food is great too, but I have yet to experience that yet.  Soon I will and re-review later......I had a stout from deschutes brewery I think it was called obsidian, it was great, I liked it a lot!
author: Jae L.

description: Dear Monks Kettle you are not too good to serve a PBR or Coors Light. I don't care that you have over 100 beers on tap. All I wanted was a PBR or a Coors Light, I've probably tried over 50 beers before, I still like PBR and I still like Coors Light or Bud Light.
author: Nicholas A.

description:
Wonderful beer list.

I would definitely go back, but don't order the pretzels. They're very tasty, but they are tiny and about $5 a piece. Seriously?
author: Raul A.

description:
This is a hard review to write, because I wanted to like this place so much.  So rather than go into the various ways this place is disappointing, I'm going to talk about Bar Bambino and Jack in the Box instead.  

When I want a nice drinking and eating experience in the Mission, I am going to go to Bar Bambino and not to Monk's Kettle.  I'm going to trade in a great beer selection for a great wine selection, because I appreciate being given a table w/o being pressured/forced into ordering an entree, as if no one ever goes out for dessert or appetizers.  

And if I want a healthy meal, I'll go to Jack in the Box and not to Monk's Kettle. Because Jack in the Box is one of the countless fast food establishments that doesn't think I should have to pay more to substitute a side salad instead of fries.  They extend this basic consideration for my preferences and health out of simple gratitude that I have decided to spend my $6 there amongst my numerous options.  Too bad Monk's Kettle disagrees.

M's K is greasy, expensive, and short on customer consideration.
author: Luke M.

description:
"You have basically used up your time at the table."  

To my disbelief, this is what we were told the other night AFTER spending no more than 30 minutes scarfing down two entrees and having our rude server empty our sparkling wine bottle by pouring it everytime he walked by (if a single sip had been taken) in an obvious attempt to turn the table over.   Allow me to explain.

Celebrating a friend getting into school, we arrived to eat dinner and celebrate over a bottle of bubbly.  The food arrived in approximately 10 minutes, so we clearly had a few more glasses of sparkling wine to drink by the time we had finished our burgers.  While we were finishing the wine, a friend stopped in to share a glass and congratulate my other friend.  Upon sitting down and asking if he could order an appetizer and beer, we were told that, no, actually, we had to vacate the table because they "determine the wait for tables by figuring the amount of time that two people will take to eat and leave." Um, ok, but did you not just ask us if we wanted dessert about 3 minutes before and we declined?! So, let me get this straight: we could have ordered dessert, but  our friend was not allowed to order a drink/appetizer?!  When we (politely) expressed our disappointment to the server, we were told that, we had "used up our time at the table".  I exaggerate not.  45 minutes after spending almost $100 on a bottle of sparkling wine and two entrees, we were asked to vacate our table. 

Did I mention that, up until 5 minutes before we paid and left there was an empty table in the back!?!?!

This is perhaps the worst service and treatment I have received in my decade of living in San Francisco.

I will not be back and will warn everyone I know to avoid Monks Kettle!
author: SL N.

description:
A couple of friends of ours went in for beers last night - their experience was less than acceptable. It seems that in their display of affection for one another ( she was casually sitting upon her boyfriends knee/lap) at the bar. As usual it was crowded! The bartenders found this unacceptable - not sure why? She was told it's not that kind of place and asked how old she was??!!!! Wow, really? Then the bill was promptly delivered to them. Well, ok then. They can take a hint.

Ya think yacoulda handled that a tad better?? What is up with that?.

We, my husband and I, are long standing residents in the Mission - really, like 20 plus years. 

No business from us or anyone we know.

Good luck with that attitude though...
author: Lil B.

description: One of the brewers at Anchor Steam recommended Monk's Kettle to us and we weren't disappointed.  The bartenders had detailed answers for all of our questions about the brewing process and styles of beer.  For example, they taught us why Belgians are much better served by the bottle rather than by draft.  Their beer menu was impressive in terms of quality and rare-finds.  You can easily find a drink for $5, if you're willing to pass up the opportunity to have something better.  I liked that each section of the beer menu had an introductory page describing the history and process of making that particular style.  The interior of the restaurant has a sort of a rustic modern feel.
author: Steve O.

description:
I've probably been turned away from the Monk's Kettle for lack of space more times than I've actually eaten here.  Now normally I hate that kind of thing, but I don't hold it against the MK, because they've got what I crave and that means I'm their helpless bitch.  Where else do you have a choice of 5 kinds of porter?  From Concord's Black Diamond Imperial (which takes the sweet chocolaty factor to a typically Californian X-treme) to the much more conservative but equally blissful Fuller's of London.  Then pair that with the best damn chicken-bacon-brie sandwich on the planet, and you have an idea of the realms of ale-soaked deliciousness you can enter.  I'm not even going to get in to their famous giant pretzel, which has been cited to death already.

If you come at a remotely popular time, just be ready to wait--an artisan cocktail at Elixir should fill the time nicely.  In fact, between the two of these bars you may never need to leave this block again.
author: Wes M.

description:
It's like a wine bar - except, it's a beer bar?  

This is no ordinary bar.  With an extensive 7 page list of beers to choose from - this is the place to be for you beer connoisseurs.  Even my fancy-beer loving boyfriend was overwhelmed.  Luckily, the waiter was both knowledgeable and willing to lend a hand.  I had the oatmeal stout and the boyfriend had an equally tasty libation.  We ordered our drinks and food and within 10 minutes - both had been served.  For being super packed and small (claustrophobes be warned) - that's some serious skill.  

We both had burgers - I had the angus burger with blue cheese and carmelized onions.  We both had fries with the special dipping sauces (delicious - except for the ketchupy tasting one).  The boyfriend had the lamb burger - which was surprisingly refreshing.  While its definitely no NOPA (delicious defined) burger, I have to say for a place that concentrates most of its efforts on the beer selection, the burgers were pretty darn good.  Props to you Monk's Kettle!
author: Jean A.

description:
Do you enjoy trying to cram yourself into tight spaces, fighting through crowds of apathy-chic hipsters who sneer as you reach past them to get a menu, obligatorily noting that the beer list is "amazing," before paying for a 10 oz beer the price of any other place's microbrew pints?  Probably not in principle.  But would you do it for connoisseur cred?  Then maybe you're one of the people crowded 4 deep in the couple-feet-wide space between the bar and the tables when I try to be fair and check out this revered little place before adding it to the most-overrated list.  Maybe you're even at Monk's right now.

But probably not if you're reading this.  So my advice is not to bother.  I've lost track of how many times I've tried to go to Monk's when well-intentioned friends who know I like a good beer suggest that we head there.  It has been between 5 and 10.  EVERY time we have struggled to make it inside the bar because of the crowd, no matter what day it is or how few of us there are in our group.  What then quickly becomes obvious is that no one on staff gives a shit whether you get anything - on a list for a table, a beer, any kind of acknowledgment.  You're on your own.  So if you can fight your way to the bar and get a bartender's attention, your reward is a high quality beer with a high price tag that you will clutch close to your chest because you are packed in tightly enough that you can't move your arms.

At least that's how it was until a few days ago.  I was on a walk around the neighborhood with my girlfriend, not even planning to get a beer, and passed by Monk's.  Almost no one there.  Huh?  Maybe we should get a beer?  I'm feeling wasteful, so I say yeah.  

We step in, answer the host (they have one?) that we'll just be having drinks and get asked for our IDs.  Now I'm not the type to complain about that practice, but my girlfriend and I are both very obviously at least 5 years older than the guy asking, no matter what his silly looking hipster "ironic" moustache has to say about it.  And it just so happened that she didn't have her ID.  Turned away.  Another success for Monk's Kettle in assuring that I don't go prodigal even for a moment.

Seriously, don't bother.
author: Josh C.

description:
The beer selection is awesome -- definitely no complaints there.  The bar tenders are obviously well trained on their extensive selection of beers, and they were very friendly.

As far as the food goes -- I'm not overly impressed.  I had the salmon sandwich.  The salmon was cooked rare (the menu said medium.. but this is obvious subjective) and served on a roll with an olive tapenade.  Honestly the flavors weren't all too compelling, and the dish was way over salted.  I think the salmon was heavily salted, which when combined with the olive tapenade created a perfect storm of sodium.

But I will absolutely try them again.  The beer selection is awesome, after all.

P.S.  Street parking on mission is your best bet.  We ended up parking quite a few blocks away only to realize on the walk to the restaurant that there was tons of street parking on Mission (between 16th and 15th).
author: Robert P.

description:
I was going to impress the girl by taking her over to the Indian ice cream place, but along the way I smelled burgers.  We studied The Monk's Kettle and headed in for an early dinner.  They have a huge selection of beer.

This place has hipster cred: a billion upscale beers, and all the waiters are "cool" especially the guy who hangs out at the door sporting an extremely well-groomed 19th-century mustache.  At least, I assume he works there.  To be sure, I'm talking about well-groomed hipsters with decent-paying jobs.  You know, dot-com employees who commute from the city.  I think the accepted terminology is poseurs, which is nice because they aren't as annoying as "authentic" hipsters.

The menu features a few different burgers, presided over by an executive chef so they're a bit pricey to boot, but not hysterically so.  It would have been nice if instead of shoestrings they served fat Belgian-style frites, maybe with a mayonnaise-based sauce, but then I was recently spoiled by such a place in Philadelphia so one can dismiss my pretensions.

The most memorable part of the meal was when the girlfriend asked if she could have a Coke or Pepsi, and the waiter explained that they didn't have those commercial beverages, but they could serve her a Jones Cola.  Later, it took a waiter some minutes to make change, as he seemed stymied by having to interact with the newfangled late-20th century electronic arithmetic device.  You can't fake that kind of tragically hip charm.
author: Danny H.

description: Cute local San Franciscan place. Good place to hang out and grab a bite and catch up.
author: karen w.

description:
The best beer selection in the city probably. Cool vibe, ultra cool super cute tasting mug, pretty good food. 

Nice "beer sommelier" servers and the service is solid. We always love their fries with curry and basil aioli, and their barley wine selection.
author: Kokoro I.

description: This place is crackin. Live. Busy like crazy, and great staff. Food is excellent. Great place to grab a drink and a nice meal. Skilled chefs working there.
author: John G.

description: This is a great spot to taste some of the most obscure, never heard before, crafted in small batches, craft beers. They even do beer pairings with your food. You like beer, you come here now, until 2am, because businesses cannot serve alcohol after 2am. You want food, then you wait because there are a bunch of other people who want food too. The Monks Kettle needs to be bigger so that it can serve more beer to more people.
author: Vien T.

description: Love it! Just love it!  Yummy beer called reality check and yummy medittaranian appetizer.  I would recommend this place to everyone!  Whoo Whoo! LOL
author: Salonje R.

description:
Great gastropub! The beer list is exotic and requires guidance from the staff -- and they're great at what they do. I sat at the bar and watched them for quite awhile and the experience of ordering was a lot more like a wine/sommelier interaction than a beer/bartender interaction. They'll ask you what you like to drink, return with a couple of tasters, and you get to refine your decision until you're happy. 

The food choices ranged from burgers to mac n' cheese to bruchetta to skirt steak. The danger with a lot of pubs that have a serious focus on beer is that the food is often a greasy afterthought. Not so at The Monk's Kettle... We ordered a bunch of food and it was all tasty and well executed. 

The service was friendly and knowledgeable. The space, though small, was a pretty good mix of bar seats, booths, and small tables. Highly recommended and I'm definitely looking forward to going back.

The one downside (more of an indication of the area than the establishment) was that parking was truly a bitch.
author: Scott S.

description:
If you like a great selection of beers paired with thoughtfully prepared great food, this is the place.

I stop in here on almost every visit I make to San Francisco. I love the feel of the place. (It reminds me of my local in Brookline, MA.) The feel of the place is not enough for a five star rating though. From the bartenders to the servers to the folks at the door, every single person I encounter when I am there knows their beer.

The food is top notch, too. On my most recent visit, I had a pretzel to start and a lamb burger (sandwich) for my meal. The burger was such a simple thing to make, and it was well spiced and juicy.
author: Steve S.

description: I love beer and I really want to like The Monk's Kettle, but there is just something about it that is very off-putting. Their beer selection is certainly unparalleled, but my problem is with the staff. They are very knowledgeable, but it crosses the line from informative to pretentious. When you ask someone what kind of beer they like and then proceed to tell them that what they like isn't good, it isn't helpful, it's belittling. One of the biggest reasons I prefer beer is that it lacks the pretentiousness of wine (not that all wine drinkers are pretentious, but it is hard to talk about wine without coming off snooty). The Monk's Kettle instills that same snobbishness into beer that a lot of people bring to wine. For me, that is a sin and deserves two stars.
author: Jeremy J.

description:
First off, a big THANK YOU to Ethan F. for introducing me to Monk's Kettle that I was finally able to introduce to my lovely wife.

Good food.  Very knowledgeable about beer.  They served a cup of tea my wife enjoyed.

MK offer a hearty gastro-pub menu that is not complicated but executed well on all fronts.

Having lived in England for 10 years and spent a lot of time in pubs, bars, bier stubs and other places that serve beer I tip my hat to staff who are extremely knowledgeable about beer, take beer very seriously and have fun whilst pouring.

I almost fell out of my chair when my wife looked across the table, smacked her lips and said, "...nice cuppa tea."  I'm guessing that Monk's Kettle uses filtered water and introduces non-ordinary loose tea to scalding hot water.  That's all a good cuppa requires and I would encourage all SF restaurants to copy this particular page from the Monk's Kettle book.

We very much look forward to another seating.
author: Jay D.

description:
The beer selection here is pretty killer, and the food usually okay...pretty expensive, but usually yummy. However, if it's an off day, you do feel kind of gypped...per usual anytime you dine at a gastropub as opposed to a good ole' pub. 

Definitely check this place out if you're craving good beer and order a pretzel if you're on a budget....

Hopefully the LOUD-TALKER who sat not very physically close but very loudly close to us the last time we were there is from out of town and is not a frequent patron. To this person: 

Dear Very Annoying LOUD-TALKER, 
I am crossing my fingers as LOUDLY as possible and hoping VERY LOUDLY that you are from anywhere but here...
Sincerely,
A Very Annoyed Normal-Talker,
Who Only TALKS LOUDLY TO YOU
author: Elle N M.

description:
We were in the mission for the afternoon to explore the area a bit and get some food since we both had the day off.  A friend had recommended this place so we sought it out once it came time for dinner.

This place was good, but not amazing.  For the mission, it's a bit pricier than I expected, but certainly not a place i would consider expensive.  We both got burgers and beers.  The burger was decent but not amazing and the beer selection is great...quite a few on tap in addition to a few pages of bottled beers to choose from.  The place is tiny which gives it a fun atmosphere and the service is great.  I'm not sure I would make an effort to come back here, but I was certainly satisfied with my experience.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Left our name on the wait list, they said 45-hr, and theyd call us. went back after 1.5 hours (almost passed out due to hunger), and theyd given our table to another customer. 

twats.
author: MJ R.

description: I have loved everything that I've tried at monk's kettle!  The beer pairings and perfect  and there is plenty of selection.  The dishes are interesting and the salads have some flavorful and unusual toppings.  I only wish they had some more vegetarian options, I would be sure to come more often!
author: Angie I.

description:
WOW i really really want to like you Monk's kettle however i do believe your ego is getting in the way. 

dear Monk's Kettle, 
       why does your service always suck? why are you always rude to your customers? why do you always give people shit for wanting to order slowly or small amounts of food, i didn't  realize that your idea of dinner means ordering at least three dishes? why is the guy at the door whom is suppose to be helping people find a seat or be a"host" a total douche?
