you folks at MK need an attitude adjustment. not going here any more...the last three times i've gone all you give is nothing but rude douche-y service! again i really really want to like you. at last, no more service from me or recomendations for your crappy estabilshment! 

check your self before you wreck yourself!
author: .Strapped ..

description:
The food was great the service was better!

What could i possibly write that has not been written about it. BEER, FOOD, YUM!
author: Ryan K.

description:
We have now devised a system of judging a beer place by it's pretzels... no really, it's a system that works. Pretzel making has much to do with yeast and all home brewers know - one must respect the yeast. But I digress...

Monk's Kettle. The famed MK. Fab food, Fab beers... make that 7 pages of the menu dedicated to beer. Based on our pretzel-beer ranking, they rank in our highest ranking of one gigantic pretzel (which they serve, very well done at that). 

The staff is super helpful and they are knowledgeable enough to recommend your next beer like a good sommelier pairing you with a good wine.

So why only 3 stars? it's house policy related... they charged 18% service even though our group ate at the bar- a mish mash of friends who arrived at different times, and ordered at different times (some ordered right at the bar). 
We never had enough seats at the bar and for a group service charge I would hope no one was eating standing up, which 3 of our guys were.

I can accept that some beers, while super delicious, are special imports so it gets pricey...

I can accept that it's a small space and it gets crowded...

I will even come back... 

But I will never, ever again send a mass email to friends, while I'm sitting inside Monk's Kettle, saying how much this place rocks and they should come round for a beer (so they can eat/ snack standing up and be charged a group charge)?! Not fair!
author: Joyce L.

description:
5 stars for the beer; 2 stars for the food.  I'll buck convention and round down to 3 stars.

Excellent beer selection; prices are what you would expect to pay for high-alcohol-content drinks.  

As for food, the "bar food" seemed to be the good stuff - great fries and giant pretzel, but the steak sandwich and flank steak entree my friends ordered were not stellar.  Not bad, just not excellent.  I had the pulled pork, which was ok.  I'd be happy to give the menu another try on my next visit, though.  

And I'd absolutely come back here for the beers and the pretzels.  

It is a tiny place, but it didn't bother me.  Just hang out, order a cold one, and enjoy.  The place has a nice vibe, despite the young'uns all around us.  I'm not even on the other side of 35 yet and I felt a little old being out with the TGIT crowd.  But that's my problem, not yours... enjoy the Monk's Kettle.  It's a cool spot.  Good luck parking, of course.
author: Aneesh B.

description:
Get there before 6:30 and you should be good. Any time after that? The wait for even 3 people is 1.5 hours or more... I think the host is exaggerating, but that's what I overheard. Thank goodness for arriving early.

-EXTENSIVE selection of beers. Pages and pages worth in tiny font!
-New chef so portions are smaller...
-Knowledgeable staff. Very helpful and patient.
-Old Yelp photos have photos of a pretzel about 3 times the size of what's given to you now... Sad face. Still very good with the mustards to dip it in.
-No more mac&cheese or chicken pot pie.... Probably because of the chef change. Such a disappointment....
-Selection of hard and soft cheese. A few shavings of it with bread, spreads, and nuts. The hard tasted like sharp chedder and the soft cheese was a fancy brie.
-Handcut papardelle with ham, peas, and cream... Very very rich and filling. Nothing too special about it. Truthfully, I didn't know a papardelle was a type of pasta.
-Pork belly. Sizzling pan, tender, small. It allowed each of us to get one full bite of the meat. 
-For a lightweight, get a Smith's cider. Loved it! Light and refreshing.

Overall--
-EXPENSIVE. Small portions. Great beer. All that for $80 between two? I wasn't full... Had some Frijtz down the street. More on that later!
author: Rosanne L.

description:
I'm not going to sit here and say that I wish Monk's Kettle served wine, or I wish it was a little bigger and more roomy, or I wish the beer menu was a little less daunting. Yes, all of these things are true, but for what it is, Monk's Kettle is pretty freaking awesome.

We went last night around 9:30, just for another drink and a snack. There was a tiny table by the door, so we had a seat. The service was spot-on and fast. I'm not a beer snob, and after I've had wine, it's not usually what I'd choose, but I found a lovely Barleywine on the menu and went with that. 

The portions are ridiculously huge, and the beer selection appears unrivaled. And the location on the 16th St. corridor can't be beat. 

And the pretzel? I could have eaten my face off a few of them.
author: Rachel F.

description:
Great city dining- perfect place to experience the culture of food in SF. 

I LOVE Kraft's macaroni and cheese. 

I NEED Monk's Kettle's macaroni and cheese. 

*add a great imported beer from their tap (and juicy skirt steak) and you got a tasty, nostalgic meal from your childhood- all grown up style! 

There is no reservations though, so you quickly find yourself looking like Pavlov's dog in the corner as you wait for a table. Well worth it.
author: stormy s.

description:
Food coma... seriously!
I went here for an early dinner with my brother-in-law who was in town for business and had heard amazing things about this place. Since they don't take reservations, we decided to go SUPER early, think 5:30.

Although early, it was perfect timing! We only had to wait about 15 minutes for a table, during which time we enjoyed our first beers of the night. I have to say, I loved everything about this place, so there won't be any negative comments in this review, just pure adoration.

Once seated we started off with the pretzel that everyone and their mom has raved about on yelp, as well as the french fries (I have a hollow leg when it comes to french fries... LOVE them) Both appetizers were amazing, love all of the dipping sauces, especially the spicy ketchup (love me some spice).

For our main entrees (although we were both just about full at this point with the two apps and beer) he ordered the cheeseburger with blue cheese and I had the pulled pork. They offer the option to replace the fries with a side salad, which was definitely a great choice after having fries for an app. Our meals were delicious! My pork was amazing, being from the south, I have been craving BBQ for some time now and this helped to satisfy it just a bit. We weren't able to finish our entrees (again due to sharing two apps between two people, waaaaaaaay to much food).

Besides the food, there were various other factors that won me over about this place. First off, they have a beer list that goes on for miles... but rather than an overwhelming list of names you can't pronounce, there is an organization about them that helps a beer novice like myself make a more educated guess as to what to order. AND they have gone out of their way to pair all of the food on the menu with a beer, even the apps! Such a nice touch! The waitstaff is incredibly friendly and helpful, especially when it came to deciding what to order.

Overall, I really loved the layout of the restaurant, you don't feel like you're on top of each other, it has a very balanced layout. AND there's a chalkboard that you can draw on if you sit along the wall! I was so excited about this when I saw it (even though we were seated at a table). I just thought it was so creative!

Clearly, I would recommend this place to any and all beer lovers, its a great place that's low-key but high-quality! Just go.
author: Emily S.

description:
I wanted to try the food, but we came here for a drink post Cha Ya.
I don't drink beer so this whole experience was kind of wasted on me.
I looked through the novel they called a drink menu, and finally settled on the black currant cider.
It tasted fine.
Like cider.
The place was super crowded and you can't sit in a booth unless you're eating, so we had to snuggle together near the restrooms.  This is also where the waitstaff tally up their receipts, so every 2 minutes or so we were being bumped the staff or people waiting to use the can.
However, this was totally fine and understandable because the area is so small.
I would definitely like to return to try the food, specifically with people who were beer snobs.
And the space is beautiful!  I especially love the wood carving things of the lions or whatever they are behind the bar.
author: Meh M.

description:
Knowing that the owners and management will likely read this, I would like to rave about the service my girlfriend and I received last Wednesday (the 21st), early evening.  I was a fine dining server for 5 years, so trust me when I say I know what I'm talking about.

I wish I had gotten the name of our server, but she seemed to be the lead bartender.  Not short white girl who really knows her stuff.  On three separate orderings my girfriend and I just gave her some tasting notes we'd like to have, and each time this girl delievered with something we truly enjoyed.  She was prompt and friendly, yet still professional...not too folksy, which we also appreciated.

From an owner's perspective, you have to love her.  When we wanted a beer to match with the always amazing pork chop, within the style of beer that we wanted, she turned us onto one of your most expensive selections.  We were happy to shell out the cash, because she was that damn good.  I knew it was an upsell, but I didn't care.  We had a really great time, I only wish we could find seating on a more consistent basis.  Message me if you need further help tracking this great server down. Thanks!
author: Dan R.

description: Great beer selection, had a draft on tap that I've been looking for for two years (Yellow Tail Pale Ale from San Diego), so that was fortuitous. The pretzel and pickles were good, the fried oysters were alright.
author: Jesse G.

description:
I read that Weekly article.. I don't mind it, but I certainly am not a fan of that vile energy that comes from knowing I am going to a place that I will end up reviewing.  As a business owner, I would start walking on eggshells for one, worrying about the way people are looking at the space, or if they take business cards so they can slander a place later.  I also don't get why someone with a problem or that knows they are going to write a bad review wouldn't approach the manager about the problem.  It is possibly because a lot of yelpers aren't looking to help a business or actually relate the poor experience to the one person that matters: the manager.  It might be that some yelpers like to bitch and moan and they would have regardless of what restaurant they have been to.  My two cents.
-------------------------------------------------------------

I really cannot imagine rating a place like this any less than 5 stars.  It is a brilliantly run bar that has worked incredibly hard with who knows how many distributors to give you a solid selection of some of the best styles of beer in the world.  It is the perfect gentrified brew pub.  There are others in the city that I won't mention... if you are thinking of any hit this.  

A couple things:  We walked down and sat at the bar.  The barkeep was in the WEEEEEEEEDS and looking a bit panicked, as we overheard him apologizing to another pair about the wait.  He never looked at us once in 5 minutes.  I am happy to say this is where good floor management needs to be aware, and the guy was right on it. 

I could go on about the beers for a long, long time.  To a beer enthusiast the menu is rich and has a lot of depth, and is exciting, if not overwhelming to go through.  For a "lite" beer drinker you may want to save your money and go to 7-11.  The menu will confuse you.  If you are an enthusiast, you will welcome it.

I dare say I was a bit slackjawed by our server.... elegant but informal... .  She was knowledgeable, informative -- professional but not too familiar.  Adjectives shmadjectives.  We liked her quite a bit, yes we did.  Possibly as she was incredibly warm & cute as a button

Food... could have dropped the stars here, but I am not going to mess with an awesome chef that has a vision in a wonderful restaurant, or one that wears tie dye pants.  Burger and bacon was a bit overcooked, and the burger sat on an artisan bun that dwarfed the burger.  It wasn't nearly enough to actual consider caring about... I ate my blue cheese bacon avacado burger with messy relish (but no *actual* relish.. yes I like homonyms)

My reviews are stupid long, I know I need to rap it up.

We got the cheese plate with slices of bread a wee bit too large for the cheese offering, and a large portion of candied walnuts and a few chiffonade thin slices of apple.  I would have like to see a bit more creativity or depth on it... but the Bleu d'Auvergne and Double Gloucester were quite good.

The last point brings me to the Mission.  I don't venture there at night, I just become a judgemental bastard.  What is it with me... I listened to far worse music and dressed far worse than these people intoning various dead subcultures, but I just don't get it.  It's like a cultural dead end.

Whatever the case, you are in a place where they have spent unnecessary hours toiling on phone calls with distributors, working hard to get incredible beers from all over... 

and this chump walks in and orders a PBR.  I mean... Delirium and their funky illegal ass grillin' is across the bloody street.  I am sad that I am at a stage where this innocent chap who has done know wrong gets judged by me.  Trust me I am working on it.... 

but PBR?  at Monk's Kettle?  It's like walking into the Louvre and immediately asking for Thomas Kinkade or Dale Chihuly.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
Oh, Monk's Kettle, I'm still fantasizing about all the food and beer we had a couple weeks ago - everything was just absolutely delicious!

We've never been to a gastropub before, and honestly, I never thought you could be served really good food in a bar - but Monk's Kettle was definitely an exception.  

I'm a fan of Belgian beers, so when I first heard of Monk's Kettle and all their selections of obscure beers, a large selection of them being Belgian, I was definitely intrigued.  My bf and I were in the Mission, about to head back home, when we made a last-minute decision to grab dinner somewhere close by.  Why then, what a perfect opportunity to try this place!

We had no problems with crowds or wait since we got here around 5:30PM on a Thursday night.  We ended up ordering the mac & cheese with bacon, asparagus soup, and their skirt steak marinated in Pale ale with a brandy & green peppercorn sauce - all with beer pairings!

Everything was delicious!  We both thoroughly enjoyed our dinner!  We even topped it off with their apple cinnamon cobbler for dessert - possibly one of the best cobbler I've had!  My bf agrees, and he's not a fan of cobbler!

Will definitely be back, there's so many more beers, and food, on the menu to try!
author: Crys L.

description:
Great place - my husband is a beer snob/home brewer. His fellow beer snob friend was in town, so we decided to finally try Monk's Kettle. 

I am so glad we finally made it in - great food, fantastic beer and really great service. 

Pros:
- I loved everything we ordered - asparagus chowder, mac n' cheese with bacon, sausage/patte platter.
- Fantastic beer selection. The beer snobs were in heaven and I was happy with my Allagash. 
- Friendly, efficient staff. 

Cons:
- Narrow restaurant that gets packed when busy (especially during the late afternoon hours)

I am definitely planning to visit Monk's Kettle again in the future. I'm already craving another order of that fantastic mac n cheese.
author: Jennifer U.

description: Great beer, great fries, obnoxiously aloof bartender who prioritizes drying glasses over serving beer. Good place but not as cool as it thinks it is. Sort of a microcosm of the "new mission."
author: Mike H.

description:
I came back here 2 months ago and it completely changed.  Before, it was a cool low key place to chill with a lot of beers and a knowledgeable bartender.  Now, it's transformed into a wanna be club: loud music, long wait, and a VERY RUDE BOUNCER.  What kind of brewery/restaurant has a bouncer?  Seriously???  

The Bouncer wouldn't let the 2 of us in (even though there was plenty of space) until we promised that we would just grab some beers.  Then, he ran inside to yell at us for sitting down for ONE minute at a table so I can look up an address in my iphone.  He kinda kicked us out.  It was my friend's birthday!  

Given that their food isn't good, you'd think they would try to hold onto their service and low key vibe.  If I wanted to go to a club, I would stumble a door away in ANY direction; it's the Mission buddy! *eye roll*
author: Caitlyn K.

description:
Relationship Status with Monk's Kettle: It's Complicated


Oh MK (Monk's Kettle) we have shared some great times over the years, but  after Saturday night, I think we should see other people...

First when I brought my 4 friends over for drinks at 11pm (2 of them from Ireland) you quipped at me that you were full and that if we wanted a table we had to order dinner... Now I understand if you were full, or perhaps if it was 9 or so with a line out the door, but your doorman looked so bored with no line and there were 3 tables open and the bar had no seats for us.  But I didn't want to fight so we said "Ok"

Next we were greeted by Pepe the awkward large man with the small beret... Who did not say Hi or good evening, but rather gave us the menus and told us we had to have small plates and not snacks... I was confused because you had always been a bar to me with great snacks, I was lost  :(

But again not wanting a scene we ordered what we could, the cheese platter with burnt baguette chips, the watered down soup, and the $8 organic salad made from what looked like Trader Joe's ingredients in one of their oh so delicious prepackaged containers (A great lunch I must add and twice as much portion as MK)  Pepe was not pleased I think he was hoping we would all order the large plates...

And when we peppered poor Pepe with questions like "What kind of Pilsners do you have?"  He replied with "Lots"  which was the extent of his english, he only spoke in sentences with 7 words maximum, and brought out the most expensive one he could find... He definitely graduated from upsell academy!

And then you forgot one of the beers, which is completely forgivable, it happens to all of us.  Except you did not say "Sorry" or any form of apology, you simply said "Oh" then disappeared and later the bus boy came by with the AWAL beverage.

No I'm sorries, no warm cheeriness of a local pub, just sadness...

I am sorry MK I think we should see other people.  I am running with a younger and livelier crowd.  I have been seeing Gestalt and Sycamore and they fulfill my needs... I am truly sorry but I think we are through...
author: Bradley S.

description: Came here with a group of four. It was a little crowded when we arrived. We just had beer(s) and apps. A must have is the cornmeal oysters, it will not disappoint. Beer selection was wild but our waitress recommended some good ones. She was very knowledgable of the beers and was very friendly. Would definitely come back when I'm in the area again.
author: Domingo O.

description:
The beer and food selection was just right and absolutely delicious. The decor was, in my opinion, very tastefully executed, clean and extremely comfortable.

I'm giving it three stars because it's a bit expensive for the amount of beer poured and if you're only drinking beer, you can only sit at the bar. This, in my opinion, is a bit weird seeing how they come off as mainly a beer bar and not a restaurant.

I'd definitely come back for the beers but I'd want to sit in the corner booth:)
author: Matt D.

description:
For those of you who have frequented Monk's Kettle over the years and are shaking your heads at my two-stars, I think you should go one more time to understand the disappointment that is the new Monk's Kettle.  I can only guess that Monk's landlord has either raised their rent through the roof, that the talent at Monk's has gone and started a good restaurant elsewhere (Oakland), or they've been quietly purchased by Applebee's.

I think I'll start by talking about the pretzel.  if there is one thing besides beer that people think of when they hear Monk's Kettle, it's the pretzel.  When the waiter dropped what I can only describe as a dinner roll on a fancy plate in front of me, the looks from the regulars around the restaurant suggested that we were experiencing a collective mourning for what had been a decent restaurant.  I don't know if it used to be made in house, but the "pretzel" has been outsourced to some bakery that I'm sure is inexpensive and delivers on time.  And that amazing stone-ground mustard sauce that would follow you into your dreams at night they've turned into watered-down Frenches.  I remember that mustard used to sometimes catch your nose and you'd gasp.  It doesn't do that anymore.  Is the "pretzel" any cheaper you ask.  Guess.  It just amazes me that they would destroy something which is such a core part of their brand.

As someone else mentioned, the menu has changed in a bad way.  Its all bland boring food whose basic components at Chinese restaurant would be $5, $6 a plate but you dress it in a different oil and throw in some French words and suddenly you're in for $17.  And I don't say that lightly.  All the components are things that can hang out in a refrigerator for a while, nothing that had to be fresh that day, and no skill required in anything they're doing.  Their entire kitchen staff could quit tomorrow morning and by the afternoon, they could have a new group of guys producing the same food.  Hence my Applebee's jab earlier.

As for beer, as for Monk's just as a bar and accepting that the food has become secondary, I don't even think Monk's succeeds there anymore either.  If you really know beer, you know all the brands, how it's made, etc., Monk's probably has something special for you.  For the majority who don't fall into that niche, the wait staff is going to push you to keep having beers that are pretty expensive and you probably won't appreciate.  It's not a place for discovery.  I think the economics of running a bar in the Mission have pushed places toward having expensive beers which allow high margins and then, for some reason, PBR so they maintain some ridiculous street cred.   So, on this point, I can't single out Monk's.  At the same time I think the beer I had was $13 for an 8oz pour.  And if I could remember the name one of you might point out that its some rare special beer, but whatever.

If there's one thing I'd like to express in this review, it's my disappointment.  It's one thing in the Mission that was once special and is now not.  And it's part of a trend that you see in places like Grub and B3 where it's all marketers and sales people, but no artisans.  I guess its all part of the changing economics of businesses in the Mission, but still, I would have liked one last pretzel.
author: Luke C.

description:
Yeah, I know it's heretical, but I came here and didn't order beer. Hopefully the Monk was cool with that.

I had the mac and cheese, which was good, although it wasn't the creamy kind. More the kind that is crispy on top and a bit thinner inside. I couldn't finish the whole thing - fairly heavy. 

As I write this review, I actually have visions of mac and cheese in my mind. Maybe that means I should come back?
author: Dana L.

description:
Easily one of my favorite places in the City.  

First off, it's tiny.  Don't bother coming here with a party of more than 4 people.  Second, the beer selection is the best I've ever seen at any pub/restaurant/bar etc.  It'll take you a good 10-15 minutes to read it through and by the end you'll have at least 10 you'll want to try.  

I just love the whole ambiance of the place.  They never rush you or pressure you to leave and the waiters and waitresses are truly beer sommeliers.  Every recommendation has been spot on.

And as if the beer wasn't enough, the food is actually good.  I've had the burger and the pot pie and both were great.  I wouldn't come here for the food alone, but I think they do a great job for a place that really just seems like a pub.
author: Courtney N.

description:
I totally love this place but I've tried to go with my girlfriend three separate times now, both early, mid-eve, and late, and it has always been completely packed, so much so that we couldn't even stand inside to wait, or wait at the bar, or way in the back, much less get a table.

The pack-age is really a problem.  It's totally packed.

In case I didn't make it clear, this place is so packed you basically shouldn't expect to be able to get in.

It is cool and has great food and an incredible beer selection.  If you can get in you will like it.

Good luck getting in.
author: Walter K.

description:
The hype is true for this one.  Tasty, creative food, a great beer list and a friendly atmosphere make it a great spot.  Too bad it's so small!  We were there on a Tuesday and while it was pretty empty when we came in it was packed by the time we had finished our meal.

I had never seen beer suggestions on a menu before -- it's a nice, helpful touch.
author: Hélène M.

description:
Monk's Kettle is my go to place for any night of the week. If only it wasn't always packed. Beer selection is ridiculous, albeit a bit overwhelming on certain nights. 

They have a lot of Russian River brews, which makes me happy. Pretzel makes me happy too (although sometimes I wish they'd put less salt on it).
author: Kevin L.

description:
You all know Auntie Anne right?

The pretzel queen?

Well, apperently her nephew works at The Monk's Kettle and has taken her pretzel recipe and beaten her at her own game.

Holy be-JESUS the pretzel here rocks.  

Served with a side of cheese sauce this simple combination of water, flour, salt, and liquid addictive cocaine still makes me shutter with delight.

Even after, let's see, 24 oysters, about 7 glasses of wine, three cocktails, and a full dinner, Grace and I still had room for a twisted pile of warm steamy love.

Do yourself a favor.  

Get to the Kettle, order up some stout, and get three of the pretzels.  

Two to eat, and one to take home to be placed into a frame and positioned on top of your mantle.  

Good luck parking in the mission on a busy night.

Rise.
author: Archie R.

description:
Monk's Kettle is a great place to grab a few beers before you head out for the night. The bar area is slightly small and could fit a limited amount of people. All the tables are reserved for people eating. They have a great selection of Belgium and German beers on tap. Between 4 of us, we tried 5 different beers and they were all good. The one that stood out was the Alaskian Smoked something - the one with the killer whale as the keg head. It had a strong smokey taste, almost like smoked salmon haha, but it was different and good. We also got the pretzel that came with a grain mustard dip and also a cheesy dip. 

Overall, I had a great time here. Next time I will try the gastropub of this place.
author: Marcus L.

description:
I'm a little biased because I'm a bit of an alcoholic, but this is fast becoming one of my favorite places in the city.   Any spot that has a selection of 100 bottled beers is a winner in my book  (BevMo doesn't count because you can't drink there, but I do love that place too).    In addition, the cozy German-style beer house makes it's an awesome place to just chill with friends and catch up over some really great brews.

Beers that I've had there that are delicious are (i) Aventinus Weizenbock, a chocolately, roasted dunkelweizen, (ii) Weihenstephan Dunkelweizen, (iii) Lost Abbey Gift of the Magi.  Don't drink too much of this one or else you'll be knocked out :)
author: Quinn W.

description:
Came here once a couple years back and really don't see the hype. The parking here is horrible, don't plan on coming if you can't get here by 7pm. The wait is also horrible, waiting in line for a table just to be packed in like a sardine. 

The food is better than average, but considering the price and the portions it better be.
author: M C.

description:
A true gem in the Mission and a must for beer lovers. It's a small place and usually crowded, so you might need some luck to get a table or seat at the bar.

I came on a Saturday afternoon, so it was pretty slow. Perfect time to kick it with a friend a few good beers. I started with the Black Cauldron Imperial Stout from Grand Teton Brewing Co. Super jet-black with strong flavors. A bit syrupy for my taste as I prefer creamy stouts, but still pretty good. I also got a glass of the St Bernardus Abt 12, which I have had previously from a bottle, but never on tap. Sooo good, totally worth the money. Very clean, smooth, but strong (10.5& abv).

We didn't order any food as we had previous been at Tartine and Pizzeria Delfina. This would be a great place to drink away a few hours on a lazy weekend afternoon. ;D
author: Kenny J.

description:
Another fantastic achievement in the often impressive SF craft beer scene.  Monk's Kettle is a must visit for anyone looking to explore a broad range of US craft beers and huge selection of hard-to-find imports. Very pleased to see there was almost nothing on the drink menu that I would consider conventional -- instead it was very well thought out and researched.

Very crowded on a Friday evening (as expected)... however the door guy did a good job of keeping the numbers inside at a manageable level. He overstated the wait (by a significant margin) and three of us were able to secure a standing spot at the bar in 10 minutes, a sitting spot at the bar in 30 and a table in only 45 (note, I had a beer in my hand for 35 of those minutes, so no complaints).

The bartenders were sweet and friendly -- and not the least bit condescending. They were more than willing to pour a taste and made great suggestions to boot.

The waiter was similarly professional, engaged and all around cool.

The food was pretty standard high-end pub fare. Nothing to write home about, but nothing to complain about either. Generally a good compliment to the awesome beer selection... but definitely room for improvement in terms of creativity and overall execution.

I will definitely be back... but no hurry.
author: Andy S.

description:
It's cool that there's a gastropub in the Mission with a very wide selection of bottled beers. It's unfortunate that it's far too expensive to drink here more than once in a blue moon, well enough to eat. Spendy, indeed.

Although they have some excellent foreign stuff, it's absurd not to have one beer from Wisconsin on a five-page beer menu. 

If you're not wealthy and want good, dark, reasonably priced European beers on tap -- visit Gestalt Haus next door.
author: Adam Z.

description:
Yelping friends of the Bay Area nosed this place out and we discovered its lovely nature together on a brisk Sunday evening, not unlike Sunday evening March 8, 2009.  A four top by the street window was waiting for us to come.  It had previously ensconced itself in a wholly noxious musk, but when we walked in, the host found that the table was glowing with invitation and promptly sat us down, the rest of the place completely stacked with human-folk and perhaps a beatnick yeti or two.

The beer list is four or five pages long.  Their tap selection is average, really, when compared to the best (in Southern California, at least, and Falling Rock in Denver or Monk's Cafe in Philly), and their bottle selection is pretty good, especially for Belgian brews (hence the kettle being chattel of a monk, I suppose).  Because it is not always available down south, I availed myself of three imperial (yes, imperial, sweet!) pints of Pliny the Elder from Russian River, wincing at eschewing the Belgian specialty of the place just slightly.

The server was knowledgeable of the beers and was able to provide good advice to a fellow diner in a very friendly and helpful manner.

The food was a hit.  The menu is not very large but everything seems worth ordering.  We decided to start with a cheese plate, matching a blue cheese with Iberico cheese.  They complement the cheese with pear slices, a wedge of preserves, candied walnuts, honey, and balsamic reduction.  With flavorful beers, this is an excellent choice.

The locals went with the big pork chop doused with a mustard cream sauce and accompanied with a potato cake and brussels sprouts and bacon.  A beauty and they were not dissatisfied in the least.  It became two meals for one of them.

I went with the lobster pot pie, which was served with a big, square, fluffy, puff pastry and greens atop, and Sooz with the skirt steak with a red wine shallot butter, demi-glace, mixed greens salad, and fries.  The pot pie was a traditional pot pie except for the puff pastry, which was a tad difficult to incorporate into the dish but worth the work, and the large, luscious chunks of lobster.  Comfort food yet new food.  Very cool.  The skirt steak was perfectly cooked, very flavorful, and I liked the taste of the fries mingled with the demi-glace.  

For how crowded it was, service was pretty good.  If you want to imbibe liberally and dine heartily, be prepared to drop a pretty penny, but also be prepared to love it.
author: Robert M.

description:
come for the beer............not for the food!! please!!!!!! ---- not for the food.

came here with the pure intent of eating dinner --- bad idea (and sadly, MY idea). 

i was pretty impressed by the pages and pages of beer and wine. i can tell that it would make any beer lover very happy. although i can't stand the taste of beer, i threw myself into the kettle and ordered some julien fremont cider. i then learned that even if something is called "cider," it will not necessarily taste good. (it tasted quite unfortunately like decaying rotting wood) 

after taking a sip which quickly wiped the smile off my face, i then instead put hope into the extremely overpriced food that we ordered --- old school pretzel with cheddar fondue and house mustard ($5), buttermilk fried rabbit with house sauerkraut and apple mostarda ($15), and the fresh ground burger with onion jam, aged white cheddar, acme pain de mie, and fries ($13) with added house cured pepper bacon ($2)

i enjoyed soaking in all the pretentious but appealing descriptions on the menu, but i forgot to be wary about the obvious food presentation exaggerations. shame on me. "mostarda?" - MUSTARD. "acme pain de mie?" - BURGER BUN. "cheese fondue?" - CHEESY SAUCE. "buttermilk fried rabbit?!?" - CHICKEN . ok just kidding about that part...but actually not really. the buttermilk fried rabbit, tasted exactly like fried chicken. even worse. i could taste absolutely no flavor. and there were only 4 small pieces, each the size of a small pickle. the sauerkraut was invisible.

what is the deal with the "old school pretzel"?!?! it is literally the size of a golf ball!! when the server brought it to us, we at first thought it was free bread, and i was even about to ask for some butter. splitting this mini pretzel ball between us was pathetically hilarious. and the (lack of) flavor? it tasted just like a french roll. $5 for this. F*** our lives. 

the burger was the only redeeming dish that we had, but it was not enough to salvage the sins of the other two plates. the patty was very small (though juicy). the fries --- oops, i mean, "pommes frites!" -- were unacceptable -- pale, limp, and undercooked. and when i asked for some more ketchup for the tragic fries (in addition to the tiny two-ounce dish of it that they provide), the server was like "you want one MORE ketchup? in addition to the one that you have NOW?" and then proceeded to never bring out any more ketchup.  

i know i don't deserve to fully judge since i'm only emphasizing on the food. i know that the all the glorified food on the menu is supposed to pair well with the selection of unique beer and i appreciate the thought put into the whole presentation of monk's kettle, but it really did NOT find a place in MY heart.
author: Jessica C.

description: Sorry monk's, you used to be the place where I love going to for the somewhat less unpretentious food and awesome MAC n cheez. Too bad u feel that to " compete wih restaurants in the area" u had to sell out and scratched out the MAC n cheez altogether because its simply not chic. Andvwhat do u replace it with? Mashed up weird cheese medley risotto... yuck! Big ol German pretzel became a nubbin of a pretzel knuckle and you were like "who wants a baseball park pretzel!" ... no you di-n't just dis baseball park food! and god knows what other unsatisfactory items on ur now fully pretentious (and less passionate) menu. Ur a gastropub or at least not mine any longer.
author: Inez W.

description:
This is quickly becoming one of my favorite places in the city since they have: A) great beer, B) good food, and - this actually matters - C) staff that know what the hell they are talking about. You can just sit down at the bar, tell the bartender what kind of beer you'd like (malty, not too strong, with a bit of hops), and they'll present you with a tasty beverage fitting your requirements (a nice American Brown, for example). They will also give you a glass of water and refill it diligently when you decide to go through a couple of Imperial Stouts in a row.

Now, I see there have been several complaints that Monk's will only seat people if they are having food. I have no particular problem with this -since they only have a few tables it makes sense for them to save it for dining patrons. And you should try to dine here, because the food is quite good most of the time. Sure, I didn't care for a couple of things one time or another, but it's very consistent overall.

The decor and ambience are really nice, especially the wall of glassware behind the bar. And yes, they will match the glass to your particular beer whenever possible. Belgian Strong Dark ales just don't taste the same in a regular pint glass. I also love the chalkboard that anyone can write on and suggest the beers for the menu.

Monk's has a twitter account (@monkskettle) and they post daily to announce the menu specials and the new beers on tap. One thing to note is that some of the beers are overpriced, meaning that you could get the same beer elsewhere for cheaper. e.g. Duchesse du Bourgogne is $12 vs $7 at Shotwell's a few blocks away. I'd suggest going for the draft menu first as it has the best bang for the buck.

Overall, this is a really nice addition to the gastropub line-up in San Francisco (La Trappe, Magnolia, etc) and I'm looking forward to the exclusive 5-course beer-pairing dinner they are doing this Wednesday.
author: Andrei Z.

description:
Two Truths And A Lie...

Truth: This evening at Monk's Kettle, a (kind of hot, or was it just me?) carnie from Coney Island stood on the bar and hammered a 5" nail into his nostril. Then, he yanked it from his dome and proceeded to insert a power drill up his nose over and over, as everyone watched in terror.

Truth: With pages and pages and pages (and pages) of beer that you really want to drink, comfy/upscale ambiance, damn tasty food, and fun personable servers Monk's Kettle is a guaranteed homerun any night of the week.

Lie: It's not that crowded. Don't worry, you'll totally get a table.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
Great place to buy a rare beer from a place you've probably never visited. The selection is pretty great although I'm at a loss when a bottle of beer costs more than I spend in a night.

The french fries are SO GOOD with 2 different aiolis and a tomato-chipotle sauce. 

Our group mostly ordered the veggie burger with a side of green salad, and although the patty was flavorful and moist, the bun on which it rested had a lot to be left desired. It tasted stale. 

I'll definitely be back to try other items on the menu and to have some more obscure beers!
author: May T.

description: I didn't really eat there besides the fries and it was really good. I had a couple of interesting beers and I loved them all. It  was a very cool and casual place and the chalkboard was entertaining to play games on.
author: Nhung T.

description: Cool place and good food. Lots of beer selections but they are over price IMO. There are better beer places out there in SF. My only gripe is that i felt so ripped off after. The bartender introduced my friend and I to a $20 beer from the cellar. Raving about the taste and complexity. Sure enough we caved in and bought one. The taste was phenomenal. 3 years later I go back and the price was the same, figured this is the way it works with quality beer. Just today after having dinner in Santa CLara 45minutes from SF, I ventured into my neighborhood liquor store due to the "we carry microbrew beer" sign outside. Sure enough there it was, the $20 beer. However this time the white rectangular sticky price tag on top of the cap was $6.99, WTF?!
author: Corey T.

description: If beer is what you want, then beer is what you'll get here - HUNDREDS of them! Small, cozy and lively! Definitely a must try for beer aficionados!
author: Carol J.

description:
Food is good, but a bit over priced. Which is what all my friends said of the beer. The selection of beer is impressive, and I guess that causes the prices to go up for alcohol. But that really does not excuse the prices for food. 

I had the turkey burger, which was large and tasty. But it was not $11.50 tasty. It is a burger and fries. There was no fois gras or truffle on the thing - it was a turkey patty on a decent bun. Fries were thin and crispy. The giant pretzel was indeed giant, but it really just tasted like an over sized Superpretzel that you could get at the ballpark. And again for $8, I would be happier getting a mall pretzel for $3. 

I did enjoy the names of some of the beers. My friends ended up ordering "Pliny the Elder" and "Poppy Jasper" mainly because they sounded like Lord of the Rings characters. However the verdict was that while the names were whimsical, the beer was pretty meh. Monk's Kettle is really small and the place fills up quickly so I recommend going early or on off-peak times to get a table. You can get a turkey burger anywhere, but Pliny and Poppy might only be found here.
author: Dana H.

description:
I have some problems with this place. First off, the beers are crazy expensive. Obviously this does not seem to be a problem for their business based on how crowded it was when I went there to meet a friend on a Friday night. I dig Flemish brew and was anxious to try it out. I guess it is a case of supply and demand and as long as there is demand they can charge what the market will bare, but I felt like I was getting shafted. The food was also good but overpriced for what you got. 

This leads me to my next point. The high prices probably reflect the demographics of the patrons, which at this point appear to be high-paid Marina/Fi-Di types who expect/don't care if they are being ripped off. Hard to fight against that.

My third issue was how openly rude/hostile much of the staff was. This place is hella crowded and when I was standing near the door the bearded-one bartender said to me in a wormy little voice: "Excuuuuse YOu!" I guess I was in his way. I would have taken off right then an there if I hadn't been waiting for a friend. More rude, patronizing help than I could shake a dead cat at. 

In summary, the experience was very much full of the monied douchebaggy "New Mission." I guess my kind is no longer welcome around there anymore.
author: Christopher V.

description:
Yeah, the beer was good and there was plenty to choose from. But the food was mediocre and overpriced, the service was invasive and rude, and most of the dining area forces you to sit uncomfortably close to other patrons. This place is totally pretentious and uncomfortable, and really not distinctive or special enough for me to see why.

Worst of all was the treatment we got from the waiter. My partner and I  ordered everything on the menu that worked with our dietary restrictions, which wasn't much, but still enough for a meal (I don't complain to restaurants about this, and it's not my quarrel with the place). But when we ordered, the server was visibly disappointed and insisted on leaving the menu on the table in case we decided to order more (he didn't do this to the people to our immediate left and right). He showed up every five minutes to ask if what we'd ordered was enough. So condescending. The meal was $30 and the bill was over $60 - how much do I have to spend to be good enough to eat here? It's a freaking bar!
author: Morgan P.

description: Had their bone marrow app last week only there was no marrow. Server said bones were seasonal. For real! If there marrow less then don't serve them; especially in San Francisco.
author: Deb A.

description:
no longer recommended. i heard the food menu had got all fancy and expensive, but that i could still go for the beer. well, the beer has sadly also gotten more fancy and expensive. a third of the draught beers were over $10. That's just uncalled for. Almost half of the entrees were over $20. 

I have no reason to go here anymore. I can get food that's just about as good and costs far less at Rosamunde, which also has a wide and varied beer selection that doesn't cost nearly as much. Even the newly opened Sycamore has great food and beer selection. Or Pi Bar, whose pizza is only eh, but has a very affordable price point and tons of great beers. 

And I know you don't like to rush people and I understand that, but you have to draw the line somewhere. When you're a small incredibly popular place you can't let people hang out at your tables for three hours when people are planning their schedules around your quoted wait times.

It's really beyond me why the Mission needs another high-end restaurant. While I havent had much of the new menu, I have very little reason to believe I couldn't get most of the same things for hte same price prepared better at Bar Tartine around the corner. Or fo ra bit more, Foreign Cinema.
author: Mark A.

description:
Amongst beer joints in San Francisco, Monk's Kettle outshines most others, as far as selection goes.  

The first time I walked into this place, I was handed a 4 page menu with small fonts, listing page after page of beers.  Beer, beer, and MORE beer!  

Generally, they have on tap approximately 20 or so beers, and the rest of the menu consists of bottled beers from, literally, all over the world.  Belgium is the superstar of this menu, but basically, if there's a particular type of beer you like, you can rest assured that Monk's Kettle has it or a version of it on their menu.  This secures them a strong 4-star rating from me.

What throws them into the 5-star category is that their food is quite outstanding as well!

It's a small place, which always leaves me scratching my head as to where they can store all the kegs they must need, and you can basically peer into the tiny kitchen from the bar.  But what that kitchen can pump out is SERIOUSLY impressive.

Their burgers are delicious, large and piled high with a huge, juicy chunk of ground beef.  Their fries are fresh, and while they are rather thin-cut for my liking, I have to admit that they are tasty nonetheless.  Their pork chop was fabulous, and while this is not normally a dish I'd order with my food, this is where Monk's Kettle begins to emerge as a "restaurant" more than a bar.  Their steak was also delicious, cooked as requested.  

But best of all from that tiny little kitchen is their Giant Pretzel.  Seriously - with whatever beer you choose off of their menu, this is something you MUST order and try.  Served with several dipping sauces, this piping hot pretzel is precisely what your abdominal cavity craves as you sip down your outstanding foreign beer.

Generally speaking, I usually order stouts or porter here.  The bartenders are always very friendly and more than willing to offer you tastes of a variety of beers.  They are also really knowledgeable about their beers, which is crucial if you're going to offer hundreds of beers to your patrons.  I've followed their recommendations often without disappointment.  They also stock Delirium, usually on tap, which is perhaps the best thing to come out of Belgium, ever!

It's small, and it's packed here.  Parking is impossible from Thursday to even Sundays, which is typical of the Mission.  It can be noisy, and on some nights, what they call "standing room only" is reminiscent of a sardine can - if you can even get in at all.  Still, I find that Monk's Kettle is one of my favorite hangouts in the city, which, I guess, says it all.

It's worth whatever you have to endure to have a drink or meal here!
author: Grace K.

description: Watched the cooking channel and they the raved about the mac and cheese - WHAT - no mac and cheese???
author: Eunice S.

description: When Monk's first opened I was in total heaven. Now it's too crowded and the new menu just isn't my speed. I tried a salad there a few weeks ago and the darn mustard dressing nearly burned my lips off!! Oh and their giant pretzel has been replaced by a smaller version. That's ok, I didn't really need 300 calories worth of bread but the cheese beer sauce that accompanied it will be sadly missed. Sorry Monk's you might still have a great selection of beer but you're too expensive and the wait is too long.
author: Shara H.

description: Good vibe and service. The food is always good - be sure to start w/ the warm pretzel. Be prepared to wait for a table.
author: Vicki L.

description:
My fiance took me here for my birthday. I do like the beer selection as I started having some flashbacks of my trip last summer to Belgium and Germany. The staff was very friendly. 
I just didn't care much for the food. It was not bad but not great. I thought it was very pricey for what it was. The pretzel was good but it's nothing compared to the pretzels in Munich. 
The beer was also a little ridiculously priced (mainly for the bottled ones). I understand it costs money to import the beer but I think it would make much more sense to go to Beverages and More to buy that beer as opposed to drinking it at a restaurant.
author: Nir B.

description: Though I am not a go-to beer person, there is always a time and taste for it and MK is the place.  Whether you are stopping in for a quick brew and bite of their pretzel and cheese, or committing to a few flights and their burger or brisket, the food stands up to their thoughtful beer bible.  To avoid an annoying wait, pop in for a late lunch and avoid the crowds.
author: e w.

description:
First thing's first:  a shout-out to the super organized, most friendly door guy of any joint in the Mish, who also happens to have the most epic mustache this side of the Mississippi.  

Places offering menus that include alcohol percentage contained in beer (Monk's Kettle included)  = places I am going to frequent most.  Because, hey, I'm more likely to spend $8.75 on a pint if I know I'll be chugging a brew that's 10% abv.  And there's nothing wrong with that.

Food's delish but a little pricey.  Hint:  order a basket of fries for like $5.  There's A LOT of fries contained in said basket and they're way better than the crap they sell down the street at that scary McDonald's.
author: Christy J.

description:
I wish I hadn't gone here AFTER drinking at Zeitgeist...then again, maybe it's a good thing; otherwise I would've left with a hefty chunk out of my pocket.

Went here on a BEAUTIFUL day with some friends after sitting at Zeitgeist, having a lazy afternoon.

The place is small and maybe even a bit too cozy, so in most cases, packed. Best to try to get a table or grab a seat at the bar; otherwise standing room is not really an option. But the look and feel is very authentic. The bar is classic, sleek, but with a bunch of surrounding oak making it have a more manly feel whilst keeping it elegant.

The group of us all grabbed beers from their never-ending list of beers (ranges from $7 to $50+) and had the following munchees:

Appetizers:
- Giant pretzel - so warm, perfect softness, and GIANT! The accompanying cheddar ale sauce and stone ground mustard made the pretzel complete; a lil' hint of cheddar, with a quick lil' kick from the stone ground mustard
- Elbow macaroni n cheese - uses the same cheddar ale sauce as from the giant pretzel. To be honest, although that sauce was paired phenomenally with the pretzel, it wasn't enough to satisfy me as part of the mac n cheese. It was a little too mild/bland, more cheddar was necessary.

Dinner: I can't remember what everyone else got but I ended up just getting the wedge salad (I was craving it). It came out looking fine, but for some reason didn't satiate that craving I was having for it. Something was a bit off, I think I had wanted a couple of more tomatoes or something; and there was too much bacon.

I think overall I give this place a 4 because of the atmosphere and the EXTENSIVE beer list (BIG BIG BIG LOVER of beer...so i'm a little biased). I definitely want to head back and have more of a meal instead of just a salad. They have an intriguing menu, each item with a beer pairing, so I'll definitely need to head back. Only thing that kind of bugged me is the price. The beer price, ok understandable since they are rare/unknown/imported/etc. but $11 for a salad and $12 for a side appetizer sized mac n cheese seemed a bit crazy to me. Irregardless, maybe I won't be making this place my FAVORITE spot to go to often, but I'll definitely be heading back for 1. MORE BEER 2. an actual full meal to accompany the beer.
author: Jung-Ah Y.

description:
Monk's Kettle? YES PLEASE. 

Although I didn't see any monks or their kettles.. likewise catchy name. Started with the most amazing pretzel ever.. I seriously LOVED it. I will go back.. if only to sit at the bar sipping a Hitachino White Ale ($12?!) and eat a pretzel. 

The beer is a bit overpriced. My fave beer (as mentioned above) is $8 at Bar Johnny on Polk but $12 at Monk's Kettle. However, the selection is incredible! 

After the pretzel we had the grilled asparagus and prosciutto. . The asparagus was drizzled in a delicious lemon vinaigrette however the prosciutto was wayyyy too salty for my taste.

After eating both of those I was stuff. But WAIT here comes the pulled pork sandwich we ordered. I took two bites but was too full to eat more. I'm sure it was good.. although at this point I couldn't take anymore. 

All in all I really enjoyed the meal and beer. I also liked the beer pairing suggestions on the menu.
author: Sarah W.

description:
I was sloppy shitfaced piss tickled belligerently stumblefucked drunk halfway through the first page of the beer list.  And if I remember correctly, there were 10 or 12 pages.  

This place has arguably the best beer selection I have ever seen.  Alas, I am admittedly not a beer snob.  Perhaps more of a "BSiT;"  I aspire to be a beer snob.  So maybe there are better selections elsewhere, but I am not aware, so please, shoot me a message so I can check that place out, too.  I tried a Mexican beer I had never heard of, I think.  I remember something being very tasty and it wasn't the barstool as my upper lip caught the edge of it on my way to the floor.  My ninja-like reflexes are severely impaired after a few beers. 

I do know I tried the lamb burger and didn't much care for the mint mayo or whatever they put on it.  Beware if you aren't a fan of wacky juices on your meat.  Get it on the side, because it really made the burger ... interesting.  Everything else was fantastic.  Mac and cheese was awesome, broccoli soup was awesome and the fries were great, too.  I will definitely be headed back very soon!
author: Sean O.

description:
I haven't really had the food at the Monk's Kettle. I mean, I had their french fries with three dipping sauces. It was really tasty. The dips were simple, but exactly what I love, and the fries were well done, fresh, and not oily. The beer selection is mainly why I hopped into this corner bar, and I was not disappointed. There are so many beers, so many kinds, and so much I don't know, that I was pretty overwhelmed. Thankfully, when I admitted this tidbit to the bartender, he was kind and helpful, even though he was busy as all get-out and fighting over some deafening din. In the end, I went with a grainy, but biting Belgian ale, whose name escapes me, and I got to sample a couple of other selections as well via the lovely people with whom I was sampling the Kettle for the first time. 

There were not enough seats for all three of us, but there were two stools at the end of the bar, so we took 'em and I stood until one more stool opened up. It was not a big deal to me, but the crowdedness did become a bit intimidating at times. Tables are for diners only, but per usual, you can order your grubs at the bar as well.
author: Shannon F.

description:
Came here recently on a sunday afternoon.  It was busy but not as packed as it would be during the evening. They have a pretty vast selection of beers and allow you to taste them in these little glass mugs.  They didn't have a bunch of beers that we had inquired about, so that sucked.  So, I had to settle for a pale ale they had on tap.  We also ordered a pretzel and fries.  Both of these were delicious, especially the curry sauce ( one of 3 sauces)  that came the fries.  Wined up dipping the pretzel into the curry sauce (vs the cheese dip that came with the pretzel).  The pretzel was super yummy and very fresh.  Highly recommend the BIG PRETZEL from Monk's.  

Saw entree items arriving at some of the tables and some folks at the bar had burgers/pork chops.  It all looked really good.  I'll have to wait until next time to try Monk's dishes.

Overall, I had a good experience here. The bartenders were friendly and the costs were medium.  They do have some very expensive beers and wines for those with bigger wallets and more discerning tastes.
author: Ka C.

description:
After a day of drinking, I came here to hang out with a girl and eat a pretzel (on the 7x7 list). This place has a cool atmosphere, but I would never think to have a large party here. I once tried scheduling a mini-reunion here on a Thursday night, but the wait for a party of four was over an hour. They don't take reservations, and the venue is quite small.

I don't care about pretzels, but this wasn't bad. It's soft, and I like eating the giant cubes of salt. It paired well with the Amber Ale. We also got the fries, which came with three sauces. None of the flavors were huge. She liked it better than I did.

My favorite thing was the creamy tomato bisque. I have a soft spot in my heart for good tomato soups. I'd like to come back for dinner to give it a more accurate rating.
author: Huey K.

description: The food really does justice to the beer they pour out here.  Starters (pretzel knot, pickled vegetables) were excellent and mains were equally awesome.  The chicken paillard comes with bacon jam and yes, it is as delicious as it sounds.  Another thing I really appreciated, the staff are a helpfully perceptive bunch and more than willing to spend some time nailing down what kind of beer you really want.  They'll provide samples in tiny little mugs and suggest similar bottled or draft beers til you figure it out
author: Taylor J.

description: Went here for dinner and ordered fries, the mushroom bread, and flank steak.  While the food was decent (although quite pricey), the service was terrible.  We sat down, got our beers and fries almost immediately, and then waited for over an hour before our steak and bread came out.  We saw a couple sit down next to us (after the first 15 mins of waiting), get their food, and then get offered dessert and pay.  Then another couple sat down and got their drinks before we were even checked on.  Finally, we were told that our ticket was "up next," and 15 minutes later it came out.  When we finished the meal and payed, I asked to speak with a manager, who said that there was nothing she could do since we "waited too long to bring this up."  As someone who worked as a waiter for 4 years, I haven't seen service this bad in a while.  Disappointing, though the food was decent, I will not go back here because of how bad the service and response to our complaint was.
author: Paul P.

description:
mmmmm! so much yummy beer! i dont even remember the names! hahaha. all i know is that the DARK one... the really thick dark one thats stronger than normal beer.. was DELICIOUS!!! nom nom nooom!

the party i was with also ordered food... beef cheeks with polenta... A+. their burgers.. another A. the pretzels seemed to be PRETTY DAMN popular there as well... but.. eh.. im not really a pretzel person. but maybe ONE day... when im drunk and craving it... hahaha

they DO get super busy and parking is a major bitch. but if you go early to put your name on the "waiting list", you get seated a lot earlier. space is small too, but the people working there are really nice and are very willing to make recommendations for the night!
author: amelia g.

description:
I burn my fingers every time I go to Monks Kettle because I can't keep my hands off of the giant pretzel long enough for it cool... aside from that I always have a great experience here.  The staff is very friendly and helpful in navigating their vast list of exquisite beers, plenty of great food options, warm vibe, and always a good crowd.  Hard to get a table sometimes, but wait for the bar if it's just two.  

If they were in my hood, I would be a regular.
author: seema s.

description: This place is cozy and gets packed in waves. I can't imagine what this place looks like on the weekends especially with the impressive beer list.  The draught menu isn't too crazy, but they seem to have been carefully selected by someone who knows beer.  I was most excited about the sours that they had, which is hard to come by in SF.  There was a whole page dedicated to sours! The bartenders/wait staff were attentive and nice, and even bought a celebratory beer for my bf! Nuts were spicy, fries were good though the hop salt was undetectable to my taste buds, pretzel knots were delicious delicious delicious (get the pretzel knots, they're worth all your money and space in your tummy).
author: Linda L.

description:
Monk's was a great experience, service was slightly sub par, but beer selection was good.  The little lady ordered the ribs and I had the lamb burger, both with great flavor.

The only thing that sucks is that it's true about SF, it was terrible to find parking, we gave up the first go around, ended up back there at 5:30 to beat the crowd the second time around.
author: daniel m.

description:
I went here with a group of friends from SoCal.  The place is a bit small but they did their best to accommodate the seven of us.  We couldn't sit together at a table because we would have to wait about 40 minutes so we just decided to gather over at the bar area, which was fine for us because we just wanted to drink beer.

With that, I love their beer selection.  This is a place for beer lovers!  My friends and i tried different types of beers from sweet to hoppa to bitter sweet. LOL.  It was definitely a treat for us since we love BEER!

One of my friends did order a burger there, it was like any other burger I tasted--ordinary.

Needless to say, another group of friends and I came here again the next night and I did not complain because I know how good the beer is.
author: Nants L.

description:
I was excited to take my husband to Monk's Kettle because he loves beer and knew he would appreciate an "obscure Belgian." 

Highlights: Great service, very knowledgeable bartender, and finding a beer that I liked among their very extensive and awesome selection.

Lowlight: Not being hungry enough to order any food. 

It was a Monday and right around noon, so we were the first ones there. The bar tender was nice and very helpful to me as I do not know my beers at all. He asked what I like and let me sample SIX different beers before I settled on one: the Gouden Carolus Easter (8 oz) Belgian Strong Dark Ale Brouwerij Het Anker, Mechelen, BEL. This was before I realized the alcohol volume was a whopping 10.0%--the reason, he said, they do not serve that beer (among many others there) in a pint glass. My husband opted for something else, but I can't remember what it was, but I know he it was bottled and he liked it. 

Tip: I've been here on a Friday night and it is PACKED. If you don't know your beers and want to experience the same great service we did, go early or for lunch.

In sum, we'd like to go back to try their mac 'n cheese, a pretzel, and more obscure Belgians.
author: Ali A.

description: The scallop's were good as well as the burger. But the pretzels were incredible and the beer selection was awesome. You will have to wait for a seat but its worth it. Relax and enjoy the environment.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
new menu is terrible and its way way way too over priced .. i see a lot more comments like mine in the past few since it took new ownership .. if you are the current owner of monks kettle .. please read these reviews .. because your riding a sinking ship !!! 
changes need to be made stat ... you can get the same exotic (and local) beers at PI down the street on Valencia and 25th for 1/3 less price .. and its bar is way bigger and more comfortable ... and if you want selection just got to toranado ... 
this place wont be open this time next year !!
author: Micah W.

description:
The Monk's Kettle solidifies the fact that I'm not a huge beer fan.  Though I still drink it on occasion, it'll never caress my palate like a fine wine can.  But beer junkies will find themselves like a kid in a candy store, as there are pages and pages of all kinds of them.

There's not much seating, and I can't speak to how their weekend atmosphere is, but I appreciate that I can always count on them to be open at 4 p.m. to swing by after a crummy day at work.  Its location, within walking (or stumbling) distance to BART, makes it easy to get to.  The music, laid back staff and clientele, ensure a relaxing time.  Best of all, they don't skimp on the quality of food.

The fries are thin, hot, and crispy--order as a side, and a myriad of dips are included.  If you choose only one food item to accompany your libation, this is it.  The spinach salad, mac n cheese, and veggie burger (a.k.a. the fried patty of veggie goodness), I can attest to all being delicious.  Come to think of it, everything I've seen come out of the kitchen has looked delectable.  If this is bar food, this is bar food at its finest.

That giant pretzel is next on my list.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
Lots of dope beer, and knowledge dope-beer servers. It gets kinda packed during peak times, which can make getting a table annoying. 

Aside that, their beer and dipping sauces alone are worth checking this spot out.
author: omar y.

description: Definitely worth the wait. They have incredible food and a great beer selection to go with it.
author: Gabe S.

description:
After having failed to enter at 12:30am on account of how full the place was, we came back at 1:00am to get in, which we were able to do without a problem.  We were quickly seated and given the extensive beer list (we were told the kitchen was closed) and waited.  

I didn't mind having a moment to look over the beer list, but we were given more than ample time before the waiter returned, took the orders for three of our crowd of 6 and then left.  Wait, what?  Ten minutes later he came back (it was now 1:20am) and finally took my order, which arrived another 6-8 minutes later (now 1:28am).  Upon delivering and opening the bottle of Russian River Salvation Batch 5, he knocked over one of the other bottles beer on the tables.  Considering the cost of these beers, we were expecting some recompense, but only really got a bar towel and a meek apology.

To make matters worse, I was given less than 20 minutes to polish off the 750ml bottle of 9% ABV beer with one other person before being booted out because, as it turns out, the clock there runs ten minutes fast (so according to them, I received my beer at 1:40, not 1:30 and needed to be out of there by their 2am).

All in all, the beer was great, the service was highly mediocre, and the clock needs to be set to the right time (my watch was set to the atomic clock in Colorado, the official govt time, a few days prior, and being a Japanese digital watch, it wasn't wrong)...only in SF do bars intentionally close EARLY.  

Beer prices are high, but these are good, rare beers so that is understandable.  Would like to come back and try the food, but this place is obviously hopping.  Nice to know there is another sit-down place that serves food until 1am (ahem, 12:50) besides the Brazen Head in the Marina.
author: Eric M.

description: Solid, if slightly overpriced gastropub.  The burger is awesome, and so are the fries - I probably ate more fries here than anywhere else (not such a good idea the next day).  They also have a great beer selection, and the staff is super friendly.
author: Josh Q.

description:
Visited here on a very rainy Sunday afternoon, looking for one of their famous pretzels and ... uh .... beer.  

We found the pretzels and they were delicious, doughy, chewy, salty and warm.  As for the beer ... yeah, i guess we found some of that too!

In fact, we found about 12 pages worth!

Sadly, I'm not much of a beer guy.  I like beer enough to drink it once in a while and I know what I like ... but I'm definitely not an expert.  Nevertheless, you don't have to be an expert to recognize that Monk's is a place everyone who drinks beer (including and especially experts) should visit.  They seem to have something for everyone and then some.  I can't even remember what I tried (sorry) but it was a strong brew from Alaska and it was very tasty.  Monk's literally has HUNDREDS of beers to try from all over the world.

One of my new favorite food memories is a dark beer with a warm pretzel, on a cold and rainy day in beautiful SF.  

Two thumbs up for Monk's!
author: Rick B.

description: My wife and I went here last year after seeing this on a Food Network show called Good eats,  it's either on Food Network or Cooking channel.  Being a huge fan of trying different varieties of microbrews,  it didn't take much to convince me to visit here.  My only disappointment was that they no longer had the beer flavored Mac and cheese that I saw on the show Good eats.  Besides that,  the risotto was delicious,  rabbit sausage was great,  and ah,  all the brews and varieties of wine was off the chart.  For all who visit SF,  def come check Monk's Kettle out,  price range,  kinda expensive but well worth the money.  For two of us,  our bill was a little over 80 but consider what you're getting.  It is a great place.
author: Jonathan T.

description:
I stopped by here with a friend after hearing all the rave reviews and we were of course stuck in a queue for open seating.  Nevertheless, got a pint after some suggestions from the bartenders.  Fantastic.

Plus their food is pretty top-notch too.  You've read it before, but the mac n' cheese is divine (that's right, I'm straight and I said divine).  

So - four stars - great food, great beers, helpful and knowledgable servers/bartenders.   On the minus - small, always a wait, bit expensive
author: Mark J.

description: Possibly the best beer selection I have seen outside of Belgium! I mean really extensive. Not cheap but verrrry tasty! Small place and was really busy. My guess is that its always busy though. if you want to sit you will have to get there early or get there lucky!
author: Adam O.

description: A beer lovers paradise! It has the most impressive beer list I 've ever seen.But let me stress I wouldn't give it four stars unless the food was good.Had the lamb burger which was excellent as are the fries.The location is a little dicey.Get a window seat at lunch and you can count on sustained entertainment.I would be reluctant to go here at night but that may be an outsiders perspective.I'd note I came via BART.Tell the family they are going to the Mission Delores (nearby and worth seeing) and get yourself here for lunch.I should note it is not cheap.It is worth it.
author: John K.

description:
The atmosphere, the beer, and the menu make this place a superb selection at first sight and first taste.  The monks behind the kettle made our night memorable.  So much brew!  I feel like I found in the Monks Kettle a perfect place to bring guests from out of town, as I did last night.  It also seems to be the right local hangout.  We felt comfortable all night and never felt rushed to leave.

The staff are extremely educated and fun.  No matter what, you will find many beers that you'll enjoy.  I found two new local brews in one night that savored and would order again.

I ordered the pulled pork.  It was low on the amount of meat, but high on the flavor meter.  I tried the steak and was impressed.  Same for the scallop rice dish.  And I'll never argue with a big soft pretzel - with a scrumptious saucy cheese and a tangy spicy mustard to dip in!

Thanks to the Monk's Kettle...See you soon.
author: Erin F.

description:
For whatever reason I had been avoiding the MK maybe b/c it is so nice looking and I'm into dirtier places for some reason.  Anyhow, after house shopping in the Mission I met up with Andrei and we compared notes on homes over a few brews.

They have a really nice selection of beers and the staff is pretty hot - I mean knowledgeable.  Gotta love when the cute bartender can talk beers and shares her own faves.  

Anyhow, I digress - the prices you can probably beat elsewhere, but this is more about a relaxing couple hours trying out new beers and if you like, enjoying some pretty tasty eats.  I had the burger and it was pretty good, while the fries were super tasty too.

A good choice if you are looking for something mellow but are also open to trying some new bevvies - just tell the bartenders what you are into and they'll point you in the right direction.

Bonus points: we got free Underberg shots after our dinner and drinks - score!
author: Gene X.

description:
Went back to monk's kettle a few days ago, a few more things to add to my previous review:

Started the night with a Trappiste 10 -- slightly too strong for me, should've maybe done a Trappiste 8 instead.

Also had an Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbier Ur-Bock with an order of pork chop.  This beer has a beautiful aroma of bacon (but doesn't taste like bacon), strongly recommended!  The chop was very nicely prepared as well.
author: Bill T.

description: This was a great place to chill and have a beer with a friend. It was in the middle of a Saturday and no crowds. Devoured a basket of fries and a pint of Reality Czech (which I totally chose because of the title) while doodling on their chalkboard. Also, good service.
author: Theresa S.

description: Crazy beer selection, including a fantastic 3-beer flighting whereby they choose. And the food was really outstanding (pulled chicken sandwich and beef cheeks). Definitely worth a trip.
author: Eric T.

description:
Monk, your kettle is delicious.
(That sounds dirty, huh?)

Tried The Monk's Kettle last night after walking past it and staring longingly on many a night on 16th St.  We arrived around 8pm (on a Wednesday), which seemed to be peak time, as the crowd gradually thinned out as the night wore on.  We sat at the bar (first come, first served) and ordered beers (duh).  I tried the Siamese twin-- a very Belgian-y belgian beer, and the bf had a Poppy Jasper.  Both were excellent.  My warning would be to check the alcohol percentage listed next to each beer-- they vary from about 4% to 10% for the draught beers and believe me, that's a BIG difference.  The Stone Pale was also good, but less interesting.  You might want to ask to try the IPAs before you order-- some of them were REALLY hoppy.  But the selection is fabulous, most of the beers are local, and you will definitely find something that you'll love. 

Dinner was equally impressive-- the mac and cheese was one of the best I've had in the city-- creamy and cheesy and salty with a nice panko crust.  The lamb burger was good, although I was kind of expecting it to taste like a gyro.  It doesn't, its more of a smoky, gamey, lamb flavor.  Which was good too.  Fries are thin cut, crispy and well-seasoned.

A bunch of us planned to meet at Monk's for drinks, and although we had a nice time, I generally wouldn't recommend doing anything at this place with more than 4 people.  Its crowded and narrow and there's not really a space to stand without being in the way.  

But for dinner and drinks for two, you can't do much better.
author: Kristin P.

description:
So I have had varying experiences at Monk's Kettle. 

The first time I came, I was disappointed with the mac and cheese and the mussels  I ordered were too smelly. (2 stars) 

The second time I came in... my friend and I stopped by for a late night snack. We ordered the cheese plate (some kind of cheddar and another softer cheese)... it was LOVELY! The cheese was served with great bread, spiced nuts, fruit, a delicious little salad.  We also got the giant pretzel. After I brushed off all of the salt, the pretzel paired with the cheddar ale sauce was divine. (4 or 5 stars)

The last time I came in, I got a veggie burger which I didn't think tasted very good and I also saw them deep fry. I definitely wouldn't have ordered it if I knew it was going to be deep fried. (2 stars)

Overall.. I would have to give Monk's Kettle 3 stars.... go in late... order the cheese plate., pretzel, rare beer.. you may have a 4 or 5 star experience.
author: Natasha P.

description: They have a fantastic, overwhelming beer selection. The food is fairly good, if a little pricey. I recommend the burger for the best bang for the buck. A small, cozy place, it's a great place to meet one or two friends, but don't bring large groups.
author: Olivia P.

description: I had lunch with a client here this past week and while I had heard of it before I wasn't too sure what to expect.  Monk's Kettle is located around a ton of other great restaurants but what sets it apart is the beer selection.  Since I didn't go here for a beer I was itching to have one but I read through the menu and there were a ton of beers on there and great descriptions of each of them.  The lunch menu was pretty extensive for a small place as well.  I had the skirt steak sandwich and it was good.  The service was a little slow but there were a lot of people there with minimal workers so it was understandable.  I'm looking forward to going back and trying the different beers out.
author: Blake B.
