description: wow, what a great beer selection! I am not a beer fan, but I was impressed with the menu. We tried Smoked Beer from Germany, which had a strong smoky flavor. It was a perfect choice as we had a steak for dinner. Scallops with risotto were also delicious.
author: Natalia G.

description:
Welcome to my office! I mean, the Monk's Kettle. My stepdad and I come here nearly every week and have "meetings" over brews and frites. But seriously, I didn't just tell you that and give away our secret spot... 

This is the upscale, yet unpretentious, version of Toronado. Yes, that means you are going to pay more. But doing so receipts the premiums of helpful, polite bartenders and a nice, clean environment. (Well, until you venture back outside...) The Kettle still boasts over 20 brews on tap, plus they offer an extensive 5+ page menu of bottled selections. While the bill of fare occupies just a single page, the ingesta is nothing short of spectacular, especially considering that yes, you are in fact dining at a PUB! The menu also features complementing beer picks for each entree. Nearing happy hour and later, MK gets really packed so expect to wait a while for table. Just don't too many of you start coming during the day, I like it earlier on when it's not crowded.

P.S. Kids are welcome so long as you don't sit at the bar. But if you're toting around hungry little ones, I wouldn't suggest trying to eat here with the dinner wait.
author: Miranda R.

description:
We waited for an hour to be seated, but it was well worth it!

Our waiter was fantastic, recommending beers that he thought we would like based on our initial requests (he didn't like the combo of what I ordered with my food, so suggested something that would fit better. He was right!), and even brought us a treat when my friend asked about it. He couldn't have been better. 

I can't wait to go back and try some of their appetizers, which I didn't even notice on the menu, and more beer.
author: Annie F.

description:
I love places that love beer!  Don't know how much I can add to all of the reviews already posted though.

Service:  Very good.  The guy working the door took our name & ph# and gave a very good estimate of how long before we were seated.  Went for a walk & came back about 15 mins later.  He was nice enough to come out and tell us how we were doing on the list and how long it would be.   The rest of the staff was just as plesent for our dinner there.

Awesome collection of beer, and a very cool selection of beers on tap. 

Food - very good & served hot!

Too bad this place is soo far away or this would be my regular hangout.
author: R P.

description:
Great selection of beer and our server was very knowledgable about them....  if you like belgium style beer, must visit... 

Food was decent... little salty but decent... 

Will go again if I am around...
author: Sumit B.

description:
Meh. 

It's like that nice guy that looks good on paper but no one wants to date.

3 stars for the actual beer list (impressive) but that's where the dazzlement ends. It lacks a fun vibe, the place is really small, and the service is always really slow for a joint this expensive. I don't know that I've ever called a bar BORING before, especially one in the Mission...but there you have it. I don't think people read poetry here, but it sort of feels like they should. For serious beer, I'd rather drink at Toronado, La Trappe, or City Beer any day--more fun and better beer!
author: Britt M.

description:
Great, all-organic food.  Cozy, laid-back atmosphere.  Incredible (by which I mean insane) beer list.

But LORD, overpriced!

We'd been waiting for weeks for it to open, and then once it did, our plans to try it out were foiled at least twice before we finally made it in.  The first time we just had beer, which was a treat, given the extensive and varied list.  But kind of an expensive treat.  The next time, we stopped in for beer and dinner, which was fantastic!  I had a burger made with all-organic beef, organic spinach, and organic goat cheese, all of which was incredibly yummy and nicely done.  But I think that we paid somewhere in the neighborhood of $70 for two meals and a couple of beers each.

Which is sad, because the food was really good.  I've no problem spending $70 on a good meal, IF it's truly worth the money.  TMK was good, but not $70 good, which is probably why we haven't been back for dinner, and only once for beer.  And in spite of the extraordinary beer selection, most of what is on the list can be got at City Beer Store for a much more reasonable price.
author: Angela B.

description:
Went here for my first Brown Ale beer ever!  it was fantastic.  the beer wasnt even on the menu which was recommended by the friendly server.  ask for the brown ale that is in a bottle and is poured in a wine goblet!!  it's so delicious.

as for the food, i have no clue but it sounded great and look killer.  I wish i had gotten dinner here and if so, i probably would have given this place another star.

great atmosphere (maybe because it was Pride weekend)  I had a couple guys look my way :)

I cant wait to go back and try their food menu and glaze through the extensive drink menu.  it's one of a kind!
author: Zach S.

description:
This place is awesome!  

On my first visit with my boyfriend, it was SO crowded.  The wait for a table was over an hour, but we actually managed to squeeze our way on to the bar next to some very friendly ladies.  On the second visit (late lunch time), there was no wait.

First time around, I had a turkey burger that was delicious.  It had a lot of seasonings in it that overpowered the turkey meat a little, but it was still tasty.  My boyfriend had their Angus burger, which he thoroughly enjoyed.  I don't even remember the beers we had because their menu is HUUGGE!!  I think they have over 200 kinds of beer...its insane.

Second visit, we shared a lobster pot pie and macaroni and cheese (its not called mac and cheese on the menu, but who are they trying to fool...its mac n cheese).  The lobster pot pie was really tasty.  VERY rich.  And for some reason, every bite that my boyfriend got had a piece of lobster, where as I got no lobster! He ended up giving me his lobster chunks.  It was really good.  Tasted like a lobster clam chowder.  The mac and cheese was good, but I think I'm a little biased.  The friends and I visit T-Rex in Berkeley quite often specifically for their mac n cheese and I didn't think Monk's compared, even though my boyfriend disagreed.  It tasted more like alfredo pasta to me....WHITE CHEDDAR...its the way to go!

Service is great!! From sitting at the bar the first time, we noticed all the workers coming together to drink a little cup of beer.  I asked them what they were doing and they said it was a morale booster..."GO TEAM!" kind of thing.  Any restaurant has beer breaks for their workers is a definite WIN in my book!! How can you not have good service after that?

I would definitely recommend this place to anyone and everyone.  Just be aware of long waits and no parking...eek!
author: Kelly D.

description:
Definitely worth a visit if you're a beer fan. They had a great selection of fancy international beers (I don't remember which ones I had, which implies that a good time was had). 

I had the salmon sandwich - it wasn't amazing but it was decent. The idea of a salmon sandwich is borderline silly in some ways so I guess it serves me right for ordering it. The waiters were all very friendly and helpful - my dining date was friends with one of them so we got dessert on the house - I think it was a cobbler of some sort with a ginormous scoop of ice cream. Again, it was ok but nothing mindblowing. 

I like the feel of the interior. Seems intimate and would be good for a first date I think. Well, the interior and the beer...
author: Alli J.

description:
Even a non-beer lover like myself can find a beer to enjoy at Monk's Kettle. And I sure did. A Dunkel was drunk. 

My friend and I had a very pleasant experience at Monk's Kettle; our server, who's name begins with an S and I forget, was extremely helpful and knowledgeable about all beers on the menu. And there are A LOT of beers. We each told him what types of beers we enjoy, and he promptly recommended a few to try. Easy. 

We ordered way too much. The pretzel was good. I don't understand why it's on the 7 x 7 list though- I preferred the cheddar sauce over the mustard. We also ordered bruscetta with fresh heirloom tomatoes- however, I was unimpressed as the bruscetta was 2 large pieces of toast rather than small, easier to eat pieces. Weird. 

By the time I got my pulled pork sandwich, I was almost too full to eat it. It was yummy though, the pulled pork was tender, sweet, and very spicy- just how I like it. It had a complex flavor to it, which I enjoyed. The bun could have been a bit less dry and more toasted. 

Overall, I highly recommend the Monk's Kettle to beer lovers; I thought the menu had a great selection of dishes and had trouble choosing, which is always a good sign in my book. It would also be a good place for a sexy yet casual date, I imagine. Hitting on a bit of the trendy side.....I did enjoy the dark wood, dimly lit atmosphere.
author: Laura D.

description:
I love Monk's Kettle! It's beer for every mood, something to suit most everyone so I like suggesting it for at least the novelty of a huge beer selection. I only wish there was more bar room or standing room for people imbibing the beer. Basically it would be perfect if they had a magical cozy beer garden out back. 

As for food, I've tried the pulled pork sandwich. It's delicious and well-made but I still think about the best pulled pork I've ever had and compare all against it. It comes semi-close to that standard, but in the grand scheme of things, the pulled pork at Monk's Kettle is still way better than a majority that I've tasted in the city. So I do recommend it.
author: Faye P.

description:
Any place that carries DogFishHead is alright with me. They have alot of other great brews too. Get there early though because it gets packed. The food smells and looks great too, but I have yet to partake.
Minus a star for standing room only on weekend nights, they should limit the entrants.
author: Sean K.

description:
F this place.
I made plans with 5 friends to go by for food and drinks on my birthday night. I called ahead to see if we needed reservations and they said we didn't. We were not sure how many people would order food, but the seating policy was that half of us would have to in order to get a table. I guess that's fair enough, but the door guy was rude, and the place just looked packed with the obnoxious, upscale Valencia crowd which has been gentrifying the Mission. Forget it. We went a few doors up to Gestalt, found a table with no hassle and had cheap sausages and good beer.
author: R H.

description:
Yummy Yummy Yummy- and that is for the beer.  Amazing selection, Sayer the Cicerone knows his stuff and will totally set you on the right path to beer heaven!!!  Some beers can be pricey but then again you get what you pay for.
Yummy Giant Pretzel - a perfect partner to one of the many wonderful beers!!!!  Check it out
author: C H.

description:
The Monk's Kettle reminds me of Helmut Newton.  The restaurant takes beer to an upscale and fashionable place in the very same way Helmut Newton made pictures of naked women upscale and fashionable.  Good stuff!

The formula for this restaurant works something like this:

1. Secure location in The Mission
2. Collect a bunch of tasty beers from around the world.
3. Make recommendations on which beers would go best with your well prepared meal.

You see, this concept is shameless appropriated from the notion of wine pairing, which has been around for years and years and years.  You could easily take that same formula and swap the word "Mission" for "Marina" and "Beer" for "Wine" and still be successful.  Mix up a few words and you've got a fresh concept.  

It's just another uniform, but damn if the principles don't still work.
author: Christopher K.

description: Delicious beers, one of the best burgers in the city, and a cozy atmosphere. Only drawback is that there's often a wait for a table! But, you can try to squeeze in at the bar while you wait, or window shop at some of the local stores.
author: Amy W.

description:
Leave it to a pub in the Mission to serve the best bowl of vegan chili that I have ever had.  Top it off with a side of cucumber, heirloom tomato salad with a blast of rocket lettuce and French feta and you have a winner.

The DH, ole connoisseur of pork that he is, went with the pulled pork sammy and house recommended micro brew.  Delish.  He was happy.

Everything is local and fresh and yadda, yadda.  Political sensibilities aside, everything tasted great.
author: K W.

description:
Meh. Lots of beer but I don't like beer much. And their beer is all very expensive. There was a very good South African red wine that was reasonably priced at $26 a bottle, and the three of us enjoyed it very much. But one plate of black bean cakes, 3 burgers, one beer, and $100 dollars later and I gotta say...it was ok but not really worth the cost. I mean, it's the old Kelly's Burgers space. It's freezing cold. It's not fine dining. It's simply fine. 

I don't mean to say that it was a rip-off, it just wasn't a great value. My burger was good, but not $13 good. And the black bean cakes were delicious but at $8, that equals $4 per cake, and they're not THAT substantial. 

I would probably stop back in for a drink at the bar but I'll save my $13 for a front porch burger that's made from Uruguayan beef and comes with bacon, cheddar, and all the fixings. Save your money and come for the impressive selection of beer and the ambiance.
author: Autumn K.

description: Still great for a few beers and the most amazing pretzel ever. I really love this place. They always have accommodating waitstaff, and a yummy cheese plate! :)
author: Nikki M.

description:
I'm a beer snob. A big snob. So at this place I felt right at home. I am always pleased with myself when I can recognize and have tried many of the brews on their extensive list. Self esteem or snob booster? You decide. 

I think we were lucky and got to sit down right away on the edge seats of the bar. I was fully expecting a wait and to be semi-ignored being in the corner. I was definitely wrong! The service was outstanding. We got plenty of times if we were okay and it made it feel like I didn't have to take the attitude of "you snooze, you lose" when dining at other places. 

Beer = Amazing. I love Belgian Strong Darks and they are bit hard to find in a bottle. They had one on tap! Blissssssssss. 

My chicken sandwich with bacon, brie, garlic aioli, lettuce, tomato, and onion. WOWZERS! I never order chicken sammies in fear they will be dry and tasteless. (Makes me feel like I'm on some kind of diet). This one, with the promise of brie and bacon, sounded pretty sweet. It was moist and delicious! It also had a blackened  char grill marks on it that gave amazing flavor. 

I'll be coming back. Again and again. I definitely want to try out more apps and beer pairing events!
author: Tina P.

description: I had been here a few times and really liked this place, mostly for its beer selection.  However the last time I was here, it was a crowded weeknight at 7pm, there was a mouse running around below our feet, we told the guy at the door and he didn't seem to care.  I'd only had two beers and an appetizer and wound up getting sick about 30 minutes after leaving.  I'm not one to get sick and can only think this place isn't the cleanest.  Most likely wouldn't go back.
author: Kevin C.

description: I came here twice during my 2 1/2 day trip to SF. Awesome beers, friendly staff, delicious food. It's tiny so you're lucky if you can snag a bar stool, otherwise be prepared to wait a bit for a table. Chalkboards in part of the bar were also very entertaining.
author: S Y.

description:
The best thing to get here is the basket of fries with 3 dipping sauces.  For $5, it is a steal!  You get a HUGE amount of fries.  A friend and I have tried to finish the entire basket (along with another appetizer) twice -- and failed miserably both times.  I ate until I felt like throwing up, but I still wanted more.  They are so good!  I am still holding onto hope that one day, I will be able to defeat their basket of fries.  The chipotle ketchup is awesome too.  You should ask for it even if you just get a side of fries with your sandwich.

The other most awesome thing is their mac & cheese - delicious!  Oh, and their beer selection is great, of course.

The only downside is that it is a tiny place, they don't take reservations, and there is always a wait (even at 3:00 pm!)  The fries are worth it tho...
author: Leslie L.

description:
Superb beer list, including some great IPAs on tap.  Knowledgeable and friendly staff.  The food used to be pretty good, then last year they revamped the menu and now it is excellent -- try the housemade pickles, the pretzle, and especially the 3 day ale-baked chicken and the amazing fries.  

The Kettle is packed in the evenings -- we love to come in early and enjoy the crowd.  Despite the numbers, it still feels like a cozy place where you can relax and savor your time.
author: Doug G.

description:
Monk's Kettle surely occupies a little corner of Beer Heaven. I sat at the counter gaping at the 10 or so beers on tap, the majority from local Californian breweries. I flipped through the several pages of bottles they offered, divided by style, many of which I've never encountered before. (Biere de garde? American Wild Ale?)

The bartenders were impeccable in their knowledge and very friendly, and when I mentioned that I'm visiting from the East Coast; what should I try that I can't find anywhere else, the bartender eagerly provided a mini-flight of draughts and extensively gave the back story on each. That's great service. 

I'm glad I stuck around for a while because there was a tasting of Old Rasputin later on. It got pretty crowded and Monk's Kettle isn't spacious. I kept my bar stool, tasted even more amazing beer and got some Tcho chocolate to cleanse my palate. It seemed that they have these sort of events often.

Monk's Kettle FTW!
author: Rita E.

description:
The preface to why I'm giving this place 4 stars instead of 5 stars is because I haven't really tried their food...but no doubt I will be back and hope to give it another star!

Came here last name for SF Beer Week as it was the first stop of the Coney Island Brewery Pub Crawl.  This place had a list of fantastic beers on tap, most from California in honor of beer week.  I was impressed not only with the list but with the amount of glasses they have for the beer!  This is not your typical pub with out type of pint glass, folks!  The whole wall behind the bar held a plethora of glasses, using the correct glass for each beverage.

This place is quite cozy....yes, that means it's pretty small so if you're planning on coming here to eat (or even get a seat at the bar) I suggest you come early unless you plan on waiting.  There's also no real waiting area, so you're forced to stand outside.  Lucky for us, we got some of the last bar seats.  The crowd seemed very cool and un-hipsterish despite the fact that it's smack dab in the middle of the Mission.

I've heard great things about the food and I can't wait to go back to try it!  I struck up a conversation with the gentleman next to me who praised the food saying it was slow food (I'm still not 100% sure I know what that means....) and had ordered this amazing dessert...which I can't remember what it was called but it had to do with caramel and bananas in a cake fashion with double rainbow vanilla ice cream on top, garnished with fresh mint.  Um, yeah....amazing.  He let me have a bite and I seriously had a moment....FUCK YEAH, so good!

Definitely check out this place if you're in the hood.  If I lived closer I'd probably call this my home away from home...warm and cozy and tasty. :-)
author: Melanie N.

description: I've only been in SF for a bit under three years, but in my experience Monk's Kettle has the best burger in San Francisco and an amazing selection of delicious and unusual beers. A bit pricey for sure, but the quality food/beer & solid staff make it worth the expense.
author: James G.

description:
What a bummer!!!  I was sooo excited: beer, (fried) veggie items on the menu, and a dark little bar.  When we walked in, we weren't greeted.  But, we didn't think much of it because it is a bar -- even though they do have table service.  We sat ourselves at a counter near the bar and waited.

...and waited.

...and waited.

Finally, I got up and asked the bartender for a menu.  He gave me a blank stare and said, "yeah, sure."  After a couple minutes, he came back with one menu for the three of us.  We asked for more menus and the drink menu and they eventually came.

Then, we waited.

...and waited.

...and waited.

The couple next to us had to flag down the server for some water -- they had been there just as long as we had -- and forced him to take their order.  We, being the serious diners we are, made eye contact several times with the server, the bartender, and some other guy who looked like he was a server but who knows.  All the while, we were peering into the kitchen and saw all of the food coming up.

Anyway, we left.  I doubt they even noticed!

My boyfriend shook his fist outside, that's how mad he was.

PS:  People, don't bring your screaming baby into the bar!  Please.
author: Tamara M.

description:
An excellent beer selection partnered with delicious food at reasonable prices makes this a required visit for anyone.  Sure, it's a bit of a yuppie hangout but what else do you expect in the mission?

I'm pretty sure I came here at least three times on three consecutive days and it was always packed.

The espresso stout comes highly recommended.
author: Denis Y.

description:
#50 On the "Big Eat SF" list  - Giant Pretzel and Mustard.... ehhh...

BUT the burgers, amazing! The fries and CURRY dipping sauce? amazing!! Seasonal bread pudding (seasonal, ours was banana) lovely... and a Rocky Road cookie in a tiny cast iron pot? Adorable and amazing!

also, amazed by the waiter who asked my friend what she likes for beer, in terms of "dry or wet" and "thick or fuzzy" etc, for beer, not wine! They have an endless list; I'm not a beer person, but my friends were in heaven!!
author: S V.

description:
I would love to give this place more than three stars, but I cannot, in all conscience, bring myself to do so. Sure, it's a lively,cool chic, space that that serves excellent beer and pretty good food. The black bean cakes were light and delicious and the vegan chili was good (but could have BEAN more spicy - ha!). The pretzel was large and soft and probably worth returning for. 

And, all in all, I had a great time. I will probably be back some time.

So why so stingy with the star count? Like many people, I have always been wary of turning into my parents. God bless 'em. They are the kind of old-timers who would fret so much about the cost of dinner, drinks, anything really, that they could never enjoy a place that they thought was too spendy or just a bad value.

While I am not quite there yet, I do find myself reluctant to pay 8, 10, 12 dollars for a bottle of beer, no matter how delicious or well turned out it may be. No way can I call that a good value. 

At those kind of prices, I was bitching and looking around for somewhere to get a lap dance. Mum would be proud.
author: Kingpin X.

description:
What a welcome addition to the neighborhood. Rasha was in this space for far too long with the most mediocre food, and always empty. Finally they bailed out and The Monk's Kettle has moved in. With 125 beers on the menu (30 on tap I believe) along with excellent descriptions and alcohol content information, a knowledgeable and friendly staff and a nice vibe, I can see this place sticking around. It seems to fill a niche we don't really have in the neighborhood - upscale beer joint. 

Food offerings are fairly limited, with one side of the menu being all apps and the other side containing a few salads and several sandwiches (Between Bread.) There is also a potpie of the day. We tried the charcuterie plate with duck pate, artisan proscuitto, salami, cornichons, stone ground mustard, toybox tomatoes and toast points (very tasty) and burgers, once with blue cheese and one with bacon, while our pal ordered the pulled pork sandwich. 

I liked my Niman Ranch burger a lot and thought, while not perfect, it was a very worthy rendition that tasted house-made (loose-packed meat in a burger always gets my attention). It came on an Acme bun with various fixins. The hubby wasn't as happy with his and said it was overcooked but the bacon on it was delicious. That being said it was only their 2nd or 3rd night open so we'd go back and give it another shot. Burgers came with decent fries. There is a really interesting tuna sandwich on the menu that I will definitely be back to sample (confit of ahi tuna, capers, cornichons, shallot, Jacobs Farm tarragon and chervil served open faced on toasted La Brea baguette with house salad ). YUM.

Nice addition to the Mission.
author: margot b.

description: Loads of Belgian beers, not much else.  Risotto soaked with butter, burger okay but overpriced.  Pretzel knot good and if I did go back it's the only thing I'd order with one beer.  Nothing more.  Hot and stuffy inside. Yeah, the door guy was a douche.
author: Kris P.

description:
There are thousands of restaurants in this fine city that somehow manage to serve food and drinks to their customers. There are thousands of restaurants in this fine city that somehow manage to acknowledge their customers. Unfortunately this place was not one of them for us when we went there a few nights ago. We came in from the cold looking for some spirits and a bite to eat, found a seat at the counter and waited. We waited for menus and ended up having to ask for them, we waited for a drink list and ended up having to ask for that too, we waited for someone to take our order but ended up just leaving after half an hour.

This was an exceptionally frustrating experience for a few reasons:

1) Who goes to a restaurant/bar for 30 minutes and isn't able to get a drink?
2) A guy who worked there kept hanging around and talking to the table behind us completely ignoring us.
3) We made prolonged eye contact with everyone who worked there to no avail and had to ask for menus.
4) It seemed like it should have been such a great place. They have a fantastic drink menu and the food looked so fresh and delicious.

So in the end we decided to book it and visit a restaurant that actually served us food and drinks. Don't think I'll be back to the Kettle.
author: Chris T.

description: Lets keep this straight, and to the point. This place is a bar. This place serves beer. Some beer is expensive. If you are looking for a good beer come here. Great atmosphere. Clean bathrooms. In a versatile location so you can walk to other places. What more can I say. Definitely a good vibe area. Not big on bars so I don't have enough credibility to give this place a perfect five stars.
author: Vinay S.

description:
Great beer selection, cool atmosphere, super packed on Saturday night.

Great to try a few great Belgian beers, I didn't even know there was Duvel green label, but how about that!
author: Michael E.

description:
Came here on a Wednesday. Place was packed. I mean not even that much room to stand. The beer selection was vast and expensive as all the other reviews have pointed out. I blame the price on the Fed not the bar. The Fed keeps lowering the interest rate my beer gets more expensive when it's imported from Europe (don't travel to europe right now). 

One mistake they made here was having dinner tables at this place. The wait staff has to fight through the crowds to serve their tables and is constantly saying excuse me. I really empathize with them. I hate taking the BART at rush hour cause I don't like crowds. I can only imagine how tired they're after work.

This place is definitely on my go to bars when I'm at 16th and Valencia. Please set your expectation right and get ready to pay 11 bucks for a beer plus add a tip to that =). Yeah it really does hurt that much.
author: Michael S.

description:
You know how when you're a kid, people tell you that beer is an acquired taste, and you'll learn to love it eventually? And by the time you graduate college, everyone has acquired that taste. Except you. Well, actually, that's not you, that's me. I'm not even close to the I-drank-so-much-beer-that-I-love-it-now-club, but goddamn that Belgian Pale Ale is delicious. I could drink a tubful of it right now. 

Though I'm totally unqualified to rate bars, this is the only one that both Boyfriend and I have given the thumbs-up to. Good beer for him, clean and quiet enough for me. Atmosphere is unpretentious but comfortable, and oh did I mention it's not one of those really fucking dirty bars? Plus great beer? What are you waiting for?
author: Gloria L.

description:
I don't think I can add more to what others have already said.  Truly the beer and ambiance is what makes this place so great.  Aside from the packed wait for a table (for obvious reasons), it is a chill spot with waiters coming around ever so impressive with their knowledge of allmost all the beers on the menu in front of you.  They're all friendly, and I might even say that they surely are better than the wine snobs at some of the specialized wine places.  Who doesn't like a beer spot?

The food offered is in a pretty consistent menu which offers a lot of pairings to corresponding beer.  The fries and pretzles with the specialized salami made a great night snack and where do you find tiny ass pickles??? where?
author: Vincent K.

description:
Great beer, yummy food. Prices are a bit steep for the brew, but the vast selection and knowledgeable service more than make up for it. 

I had the lamb burger, which was pretty much smothered in awesomeness. It made me realize that even if I did flip a 180 and suddenly decided to become a vegetarian, memories of this burger would keep me from committing. You usually do have to wait a bit for a table (and parking in this area is a pain).... but just take a seat at the counter and the time will be up before you know it. 

Beer me. You know you want to.
author: Whitney H.

description:
We came here while visiting my sister in San Fran - and it was great.  There was a wait, but eventually we got a nice booth to chill and enjoy the bustle around us.  

Honestly, I can't remember the beer I got.  All I know is I had the best chicken pot pie of my life.  Hands down.  Creamy filling (not gooey), full of flavor and amazing pastry top.  The pretzel was really tasty, and inspired a debate over the relative merits of mustard as condiment of choice.  My husband got an espresso brew and it was great...other beers were consumed...fun was had by all.
author: Anne M.

description:
You know that old adage of "too much of a good thing is never good?" I wouldn't normally apply this to beer, but I think it could be true for this place.  Don't get me wrong, I think it's great they offer you such a huge selection...but unless you're a connossieur and can whimsically peruse the 4 page list of beer and have 20/20 vision in low light...this is the place for you! 

Sure, I like beer...but I like the light variety where I can drink 12 cans of it and still not have a buzz.  Which is why I don't drink it as much anymore, since I like to get right down to business these days...so if you ever want to buy me a drink, it's bourbon on the rocks please.

This is the 2nd time I've been here...my memory was a bit fuzzy on why I was hesitant. We ordered the charcuterie plate, the argula salad and fries to share.  I remember last time I ordered the pork entree.  Once finishing the food...I remembered it all.  

First, the charcuterie plate wasn't horrible...but as a lover of cured meat...it wasn't very good compared to other places.  The fries were good, but too over salted.  The argula salad was bland bland bland...even the apples and candied walnuts couldn't help it.

Here's my opinion on the Monk's Kettle: I feel it should just be a bar that only served gourmet, but affordable bar food (fries, wings, finger foods, etc.) and NOT salads, sandwiches or entrees.  The space is too cramped, the food isn't that good and the beer is their starring role. So why not just keep it simple since your beer list isn't?

Oh...and there was ONE waiter for the entire place. It was packed on a Wednesday evening and this just won't do.
author: Freckles D.

description:
I went here on a Saturday night and it looked packed. Luckily we got a table rather quickly. 

The beer list was amazing. I haven't heard of most of the beers so I loved it that I got to try something new. We ordered our appetizer and beers and they came really fast. The pretzels were delicious and the beer was great. 

We ordered our entries and they came pretty quick. I couldn't wait to dig into my mushroom risotto expecting it to burst with flavor and leave me wanting to lick my plate clean. Well the best way to describe the risotto is right before you are about to kiss someone new and you expect it to be wonderful.....but it sucks. Come  on, we have all been there. 

The waitress came by to check up on us and we said everything is great, but I thought it was just me being picky. The risotto tasted like old bland over cooked rice. It had no flavor and I was SO happy to see salt on the table, but salt wouldn't save this dish. 

My friend asked me how my food was (his lamb was perfect and he did lick the plate clean) and I said, its bad. He tried it, and confirmed that the risotto was just plan bad. I was fine with not eating (leaves more room for beer!)  and just sat there. 

The waitress noticed I wasn't eating and asked if anything was wrong. I told her its nasty and she got me a salad, which came quickly and was wonderful!

Over all, I would so go here again. I bet the nasty risotto was a fluke since everything else was great.
author: Karen B.

description:
4 stars for the beer list and the decor
2 stars for the confusion:   you have to put your name on a list if they are busy for a table, but no one mentions that when you walk in.  We walked in, sat at the bar for a little bit, and then sat at a table that just emptied.  A member of the staff came over and washed and reset the table and gave us a menu, but then someone else came over and told us that there was a list for the tables and that we would have to go back to the bar. 
But of course there were no seats, and the place isn't that big. 
I really want to go back on a weeknight just after work and check out the vibe then.  They definitely have four and five star potential.
author: E P.

description: Went here for a friends birthday n  boy was it crowded. Got lucky n got seated at a booth. Lots of beers to choose from... Oh man! What to pick what to pick! I really love there fries and there burger was freaking mouth watering! Pork chops smothered in gravy with crispy baked brussel sprouts with bacon... yummm... and to wash it down with a cold glass of triple karmelit... uuummm ummmm good!
author: Shirl C.

description:
Here's the deal.  The place was fine and one of the bartenders was actually very cool (blond dude). But the host and one of the waitresses were so rude that I simply won't return to this place.  If they fire the waivey haired jerk who told us that a waitress would be there to serve us (despite the posted signs that specify otherwise), maybe I'll go back.  But the waitress, who shouted at many to move and get out of her way... including at least two pregnant women, never helped anyone but herself.

Now, I know what you're thinking, its always a two way street, it takes two to tango, gotta check your 'tude at the door.  And the truth is that my entire party of 6 was so mellow and non-attitudinal that I was absolutely floored at the way we and several other people there were treated by these two employees who acted like they own the place... and for all I know the do.  If the real owners want to let me know these people are no longer employed there maybe I'll give it another shot, but otherwise businesses like this don't deserve to survive in the highly competitive restaurant/bar biz in SF. 

I typically don't review based on a single experience, but with this place, I have no choice.  I'm not going back anytime soon.
author: Brett C.

description:
I'm wavering between giving The Monk's Kettle somewhere between 3 and 4 stars, as there were many pluses to my first time experience here last night, though there were a few negatives -- consider this review a 3.5-er.

The first thing I noticed when walking in was the whole cavernous masculine feel to the place: dark woods, retro-style lights at the bar, leather cushions for bar stools, high ceilings, huge slabs of marble.  And of course the second thing I noticed was the tempting smells wafting from the kitchen.  Mmmmm... this girl was hungry!

My party of 4 showed up on a very cold night in San Francisco -- a kind of cold that the likes of me does not recall experiencing before in the city.  Well, perhaps The Monk's Kettle is aptly named, as it was colder than a monastery in here!  We thought after being seated at the table near the very front of the house that we'd be able to escape the bitter chill that kept coming through the door whenever a new patron would walk in, but, oh no -- it was freaking freezing, Mr. Bigglesworth!  On two separate occasions I could visibly see the breath of one of my dinner-mates -- not a good sign while dining indoors.

But I digress...  I thought the food was great.  I ordered a Niman Ranch Burger with Monterrey Jack Cheese and thought it was really tasty.  My dinner party also ordered both dessert items, and though I didn't try it, they felt that the Fruit Cobbler fell short of their expectations.  The Chocolate Lava Cake, on the other hand, was rich and decadent.

I'd like to come back with a slew of friends and have a few beers, but the place is incredibly intimate (read: small) and maybe only on a school night would it work to accommodate a group of my friends.  A beer I tried that's worth mentioning: I absolutely loved the Coffee Porter and would definitely recommend it!
author: Katie C.

description: Crowded, crowded, a long wait  with sometimes too cool for school door person, and burger was greasy, greasy. Wine delicious though, and I am sure the beer is too. However, there are better, more accessible places.
author: Uda W.

description:
I studied abroad in Germany and developed an obsession for pretzels and beer enjoyed in tandem.  Monk's pretzels are not quite what you'd get from a German bakery, but the sheer size of them makes up for that.  I also had the butternut squash soup,  which was really amazing.  The baked mac and cheese that my boyfriend ordered completed our feast of comfort food.  The suggested beer pairings were much appreciated and worked out really well.

A combination of realized anticipation, cozy ambiance, and warm delicious food on a rainy SF night made me almost-giddy-happy throughout the whole experience.  I can't wait to go back to re-test the lenses of the rose-colored spectacles I was obviously wearing that evening.
author: Nisha P.

description:
If I told you that I found a beer place that has amazing real food, not appetizers and burgers, you'd think I was drunk.  The Monk's Kettle is jam packed with a beer list that rivals Torranado's and has a staff that is well educated on differences and pairing with your meal. The restaurant/bar makes great use of the former diner space and they do have a television for those looking to watch some sports over a brew.

The food menu is filled with appetizers, sandwiches, and entrees with a separate daily specials menu.  On this visit we went with the "Deconstructed Caprese Salad" (a nice refreshing salad with more than enough mozzarella balls and chopped heirloom tomatoes) and Mac N Cheese (one of the top three in the SF with it's creamy and sharp taste) to start.  Being a little full beforehand, we ended up sharing the Arctic Char (off the specials menu) and it was cooked to perfection sitting on top of a sauerkraut-like vegetable relish and a creamy white corn side.  It's a dish like this that separates Monk's Kettle from the other breweries in San Francisco that serve decent to lower quality food.  

I'm coming back for a burger, fries, and a couple of beers of course!
author: Jason A.

description:
I popped in with a friend on Wednesday night around 8pm and was seated immediately at the bar, which in my mind is usually one of the better seats in any house.  The night was starting out pretty good!  Plus, we had some delicious beers with which to tantalize the palette while we made our food decisions.  Yep, good times.

Ooh - and I do love the decor.  On one wall, is a floor to ceiling glass shelf with all the different kinds of beer glasses, because yes they do serve all the beers in all the right glasses.  Well, I wouldn't know if it was the wrong glass since they have like 50 beers on the menu, but they were all different glasses at least.   On the other wall, is a row of booths and over/between each were the coolest lamps I'd seen in a while.  They were the ugly rental apartment glass lampshade style ceiling lamps, but sandwiched two-to-a-lamp together vertically like a clam shell.  Maybe I'm not doing it justice, but it was definitely a nice detail.  And I did feel very well lit.

We split a wedge salad that had real bits of bacon, creamy dressing, and crisp iceberg lettuce.  And then we split the burger with white cheddar and mushrooms on top.  The best thing about getting cheese with the burger is  they use a pile of grated cheese instead of a regular old slice like they do at most places.  We had the bar seat closest to the kitchen, so I was scoping things out.  Maybe it's psychological, but i think it tastes better.  Cheesier, fluffier.  

And the beers!  I barely knew where to start.  But based on my love for Racer 5, I decided to try another one of their IPAs - the Green Flash.  Eh, it was alright, I'll stick to the Racer 5 in the future.  But then I had the Old Combine, by recommendation of the bar tender.  Still a little sweet, a little hop-y, but super refreshing.  I'll definitely be ordering that again!
author: Audrey T.

description:
After an hour wait for a table, one word to describe my experience, impressed! The food was amazing, the service was quick, and the atmosphere was filled with HIPNESS in the best use of the word imagined. 

I used to work at a pretzel place and the pretzel with the cheese sauce was and is one of the best I have had. I then had the french fries and the macaroni and cheese, DELICIOUS and filling. The portions are big, so share among others, as I did.

I had no idea this place existed and usually, waits hinder the experience for me, but I loved this place. There are a lot of people and it is noisy, so be prepared. If you can't handle noise, just eat the pretzel, it is so worth it!

I can't say enough about this place. I don't even drink beer and I loved it! Now, that is crazy......
author: Christopher W.

description: Pliny the elder on tap... need I say more?  Good food, cozy atmosphere and the typical "we don't care if you ever get a seat" SF attitude.  Definitely worth a wait!
author: Buck B.

description:
My people come from a land of blood sausage, cabbage, radishes, gnomes and beer. Gnomes are really the only bad tasting thing on the list. Unless, of course, they're braised in beer and served on a bed of cabbage. Delish!

This location used to be the home of Kelly's Burgers - the best damned burger joint in the Mission. Then one day Kelly's closed and I could no longer soothe my late night, Kilowatt fueled craving for seasoned fries. Some time later it became some lame Thai place - because the Mission REALLY REALLY needs another Thai/Asian restaurant. I never went there. It was too lame and it made me cry inside thinking that some place could try to occupy Kelly's. It closed.

Now it's Monk's Kettle. Eh - not bad. I've eaten there 3 times now. I think it will be a long time before I go back. Reasons, you may ask?

1. On my first visit with 2 friends, we arrived just after the too hip for me to read Guardian published their review. We arrived at 5:45 right after work and got THE LAST 4-top in the place. Our waiter was awesome and knowledgeable and welcoming. We had 3 small plates and split the pulled pork sandwich. By the time the sandwich arrive, the place was packed to the rafters with super-awesome-cool hipsters trying to pack 9 to a 4-top and chatting loudly about how super-awesome-cool Monk's is. My friends and I intentionally finished our meal slowly and ordered another round of beers just to annoy the crown of tight-pants/ironic shirt wearers who were eying our table. Beer was Great. Food was Great. Service was Great. Crowd was Poo.

2. My second visit was with co-workers. We went for lunch. The place was empty. The food was Good. The service was Good. The beer was Great.  I was not excited with my chicken sandwich though. But I wasn't paying, so whatever.

3. My third visit was on a Saturday at lazy late lunch time with the Love of My Life.  He hates Niman Ranch - and Bill Niman (just because the label says "organic", you sheep...). He loves beer and charcuterie. We both loathe bad service. My wonderful waiter from the first night had turned into a patronizing hipster. Is there something in the Mission air? Because of the Love's personal "Ban on Niman" - our choices were limited to charcuterie (a quite healthy portion of yum), pretzel (get extra cheese sauce if you can), and mixed greens salad with blueberries (the best fruit). The food was Great. The beer was Great. The server was Hipster Poo.  

I recommend this place to Hipsters between 6pm and closing time every night of the week. Crowd on in and admire your collective cool. 

Everyone else should check it out - at least once for a pretzel and some great beers you might not find anywhere else in SF.
author: Bunny H.

description:
I really like this place: good food, great beer, great ambience, near my house. Four stars.

Two stars is because not only will you spend all night waiting for a table, they can't even tell you how long it will be. Last time I tried to go there they told me it would be an hour forty-five. They called two and a half hours later, by which point we had gone elsewhere.
author: Channing M.

description:
I must begin by saying I was only able to take two bites out of my vegie burger because I was so stuffed from the four amazing beers and the perfect mac'n'cheese...oh yeah, and the heaven in my mouth muscles.  

so I got to re-live it all this afternoon when I heated up my leftovers and began my decadent experience all over again.

whoever thought of dipping french fries into a creamy curry sauce rocks!! I give Monk's 4 stars just for the fries.

If I could I'd give more than 5. That's how happy this place made me.
author: Kat R.

description: 2 stars for food (boring, nearly unremarkable), 4 stars for beer selection, 4 stars for weekday service and attitude, 2 stars for weekend attitude. In short: come here to drink on a weekday.
author: christine c.

description: Came across this place in search of a late night dessert in the Mission district.  Couldn't have been happier to discover hundreds of available beers (including champagne beer - who knew?) and a yummy set of desserts - including a cookie cooked in a skillet served with vanilla ice cream.  The place had a fun vibe with lots of young professionals meeting up with friends and enjoying the food.
author: Kelly N.

description: The beer is great. It was fun to try recommendations and have them be amazing. The menu fails, and fails in pricing more than flavor. $15 for 5 tiny bite size pieces of rabbit?  4.50 for a 6 bite pretzel??? Give me a break, I want enough food to offset the beer I want to drink. $33 in food wasn't enough to feed one person enough to drink 2 beers. So sad. I really wanted to love the place
author: Dulci K.

description:
My first edit! So, in all fairness, I came back to this place and had a good experience. Had to bump it up a star. Still nothing to rave about. And it was practically empty as we came late in the afternoon on a weekday. However, we enjoyed ourselves and our beer. Had the giant pretzel, which was basically a frozen pretzel heated up. I don't know why I expected more. Guess I wasn't drunk enough. Maybe then I wouldn't have cared and it would've been just what I was looking for. Anyway, I guess this place is good when the 'scene' aint around.

**edit*4.28.08*edit**

Um, can we say, Pretentious? I did let curiosity get the best of me and with all that buzz, my boyfriend and I just had to check it out. That's pretty much all this place is worth. 

I liked the bar and chalk boards in the back. I liked that there were many beers to choose from. But, it seemed like they were just trying way too hard. 

First off, no one noticed when we walked in. We sat down at the bar, and then we were noticed, but simply ignored. It was the strangest thing. Finally someone came to take our order, but how can we know what we want when no one has given us menus yet?! So we ordered beer while we waited for the menus and then ordered dinner. But there were two different people behind the bar, and they clearly weren't communicating. So there was confusion about the check, is it int he computer or not. But how the hell should we know? We just want to eat dammit. 


The food choices were weak. I mean, how many more gourmet burgers do we need in this town? In the end, it's just a burger on some special bread (though I do love La Brea Bakery). We did order it-- again, out of curiosity. That and I just wasn't in the mood for a giant pretzel. We were hungry. Wanted something more substantial.  We also got the chaucuterie plate, which when it first came out looked pretty hearty. I'm used to seeing those dainty plates with like a dab of patte and a slice of salami for $19. But this one had plenty of meat, pickles, all on a bed of arugula. Too bad it didn't taste like anything. The salami might as well have been from your local Safeway and the duck ribletts were so bland, which is why they had to serve it with cranberries. It's not thanksgiving. Nearby Il Couz's chaucterie is loads better.

The best part of our experience was the bread pudding. That's about the only thing worth coming here for. Warm, soft, sweet. 

You want beer choices- go to Toronado, it also lacks the smug SF attitude that gets old-- fast. You want a gourmet burger and some other late-night hearty meal options-- go to Liverpool Lil's. 

But you want to check out a typical Mission scene and feel cool with a $21 bottle of beer in your hand that has some cute little graphic label, imported from Japan.... then be my guest, and come here.
author: Nina H.

description:
Hah, I just read a review which inspired me to write my own. A yelper said that the rude door guy wouldn't let her sit at a table and order drinks and dessert. A similar situation happened to me here...A friend and I came in to Monk's Kettle late on a Tuesday night for drinks and food. Half the tables were empty. We asked for a table for two. The door guy asked if we would be eating. I replied I would. Then he asked if my friend would also be eating. She replied she wanted to order an appetizer. His reply "well you both have to order entrees if you want to sit at a table." UM OKAY WTF. This major douche bag has GOT to get fired for that attitude. (It's not the sweet little door guy with the dark curly hair)...  

If I come here again, i'll make sure to write out my food and drink order for the door guy,  total it up and ask  if I've spent enough money to sit at a table.
author: Rebecca S.

description:
This used to be one of my favorite places, but I feel like they have been slipping a bit.  On the plus side, the staff is very knowledgable about their beers.  But, the selection hasn't been the best, and I think the food quality isn't quite what it used to be (it used to be top-notch so it's still decent).

Even though it's harder to get to, lately I've been getting my beer fix from La Trappe, Toronado, or The Trappist (Oakland).

But still, if you haven't been here you should still give it a shot.
author: Bill W.

description:
Best place to enjoy a Belgian Beer in SF.  And they have tons to choose from.

Atmosphere is nice - I love the wood and big booths, but the place is kinda small and feels extra crowded when its busy.

Food is really good, too - especially the pretzels.  Oh my god.  MMmmmmm...
author: chad n.

description: Good beers,but mostly overpriced (except they did have supplication on tap for $6... pretty good find).  I'm not sure id go out of my way to come back just for drinks, but I would like to try the food again some time. If your in walking distance then it's worth a stop.
author: Matthew H.

description:
NOTE: this is thus far only of the bar; it was too crowded to try the food.  This will be updated posthaste.

The first thing you'll likely notice upon entering, if it's full, is that the place is damn loud.  This is really the biggest downside.  If it's full of people, the Kettle isn't a good place for conversation.  If you just want some damn good beer, though, you've found one of the best spots in SF.

The beer selection is huge.  They've got a whopping 30 taps, serving a fantastic selection of micro brews and some of the best Belgian beer in the world (the St. Bernardus Abt 12.  Seriously.  Wow.  There aren't words.)  And if that's not enough, there are I believe 5 pages of menu devoted to nothing but bottled beer, organized by style, with descriptions of each variation, and all listed with their respective alcohol percentage and place of origin.

The owners are happy to talk beer with you (they clearly love the stuff) and they've got little sample glasses so you can try the selections on tap before choosing one (most of which are served in 20oz glasses).

The only other downside?  A lot of the bottled beer is damn expensive.  The number of $12 bottles is fairly remarkable.  But then, ultra high end Belgian and German beers just aren't cheap, and are damn hard to find this side of the pond.  And a few of them come in half-liters or 750s, which makes up for it.  Better hope you're thirsty.

So the Kettle itslef: there's a big bar along one wall, with some fantastic carved wood detail.  Opposing it are a bunch of wooden & stone booths with cool ambiance lights between them.  There's a ledge with stools along the back, faced with chalkboards and chalk for patrons to express their drunken creativity.  There's only one bathroom, but it's shockingly swanky.  And there's a bunch of delicious sounding, rather fancy locally-sourced organic food that I look forward to sampling that they serve until 1am!

Oh, and did I mention the enormous selection of beer?
Go drink some.
author: Don H.

description:
Had a night out at Monk's Kettle in the Mission last week and can't recommend it enough - go there.   Eat Drink and Be Merry for god's sake.

Very short review:  TRY THE POTPIE!!  Best I've ever had.  

Slightly longer version:
Potpie:  Flank steak with creamy, peppery sauce topped with a flaky-on-the-outside but chewy-on-the-inside square of puff pastry.  It changes every day. 
Pulled pork sandwich:  this was good, both the pork and the slaw could have been more flavorful/spicy.  Nowhere close to the version at Bell Tower on Polk. 
Garlic Fries:  Yum.  And still tasting them the next day. 
Bread Pudding:  Perfectly moist. 
  
We had the bartender choose draught beers for each item, and I wish I'd remembered what we had (um...).  The only misstep was the beer my friend had over dessert, but he went against the bartender's suggestion on that.  MINE was fantastic.

I will be back there savoring a hot, comforting potpie on the next rainy day.  And a beer or three....probably just before a stumble across the alley to Delirium.  Again.
author: Pamela J.

description:
My fav neighborhood restaurant.  Hands down.  I love it, love it, love it.  And I actually appreciate the wait - it allows for some cocktail/beer time at one of the bars in the area.  

Put your name and number down on the waitlist and the awesome hostess will call your cell when your table is ready.  Awesomeness. 

Some beers are too expensive, but there is such a wide selection, you can budget your alcohol consumption.

I love their take on pub food.  I never feel "guilty" after eating at Monk's.
author: Laura G.

description:
This place was a great night cap to an evening. The wait staff is great and very punctual even though it was a super packed Thursday night. The beer menu is insanely good and sort of intimidating with all the choices. 

I definitely want to return and have dinner here as the food looked amazing.
author: Ryan K.

description:
We came here to celebrate an anniversary, casually. We had been wanting to come here for a little while on a number of high recommendations.

We sat right away at the bar on Friday night. The bartender was so knowledgeable. The menu for beers, ales, stouts was pages & pages in small font, so he asked Stephen what one of his favorite beers was. Of course Stephen couldn't remember the name, but it was Belgian, and he'd had it in a bar in New York ;*p. So the bartender gave him some tastings in these tiny beer jugs. Too cute. I had a sauv blanc, which was perfectly grassy, from the short list of wines.

We started with a cheese taster (Chimay and Basque - these were the bartender's favorites - and Stephen and I were in heaven), and a spinach salad with dried cranberries and tahini sauce. It was incredibly yummy. I usually don't like raw spinach, but tahini matches it so well. 

After our starters, Stephen moved to another delicious, but darker and heavier beer (stout?), and I switched to a syrah - to go with our (well, Stephen's) pork chop which was practically heaven, and the special ahi tuna pot pie, which was warm and comforting and delectable on a cold night.

We finished with dessert, as the bar was getting super-crowded, and we kept floating on happy-friday and happy-tummy cloud.

We will visit again - I forgot to mention the regulars there - the bartenders seemed to know them well - their drinks and favorite starters, too. The service was extremely smooth and very engaging for us. It seemed like our server/bartender was sincerely concerned. He also had very good manners. That is always appreciated, since people come in the door with any number of things on their minds. Oh, and we got to meet the chef. That was fun - he wasn't a skinny chef, and as he walked back to the kitchen (which is visible to the bar and some tables) the bartender said "As they say: Never trust a skinny Chef!" hee hee. In this case, true.

I highly recommend The Monk's Kettle!
author: Holly F.

description:
Highlights: giant soft pretzels with 2 dipping sauces (a creamy aioli and grainy mustard sauce) with an insane selection of beer. Can't really beat this combo. 

It's a tiny place, so secure your seat at the bar or grab a table early, especially on Saturday night. Wish they had more pilsner/lager varieties (until I acquire a consistent desire for porters and stouts, especially early in the night) but overall a solid list for any true beer connoisseur.
author: Kelly R.

description:
Had a Jolly Roger and a baltic porter with a spinach salad.  I regret not getting something starchy to go with the first beer because it was much stronger than it tasted.  Of the two beers, I liked the Jolly Roger a lot.  My friend's description was spot on: "It's like a wall... a wall of FLAVOR".

It was already crowded by the time we got there, but we sat at the bar and had a drink while we waited for a table.  It's a little too loud to have a casual conversation, but I bet it'd be a really nice place to hang out in the early evening / late afternoon.

Entrees were about 10-20, and beers started around 6 I think.  I loved that they listed the volume next to the ABV and price.  My mind just started sorting by all the numbers.  The list of beer is really long, so it'd take several trips to try everything out.
author: Jerry C.

description:
Best beer spot in SF! Hands down.

I feel at home when I come to Monk's Kettle. I dunno if it's the coziness of the spot, the welcoming staff, or me always going home w/ one or two satisfying beers in my belly- but either way, I love hanging out here.

Last time I came by, I asked if they had a random beer that I had just tried the day before (Redemption), and low and behold, they had a nice big bottle of it w/ my name on it. Their list of beers is as extensive as it gets, and to top it off, they have a chalkboard up so that patrons who'd like to suggest a beer can jot it down for them!

Our server was kick ass- keeping my glass nice and full and even making his way around the bar just so he could hear my order better! He also played it cool when my tipsy friend spilled his beer- our server swooped in w/ the quickness and was gone in a second!

The fries here rock too! Crispy and a perfect match for my beers. I hear that their entrees are killer, so next time I stop by, I'll have to be sure to bring my appetite!
author: Tiffany M.

description:
Excellent beers and excellent food.  This place has a solid selction of craft brew on tap and in bottles.  They rotate the taps and bring in new beers all the time.  The wait can be annoying at times but once you have a spot to sit - you will have some of the best beer in San Francisco.  

Get the pretzel - fresh baked and delicious.  I love the Fuller's London Nitro Porter but have had several other excellent brews here as well.
author: Moe J.

description: I'm now addicted to this place. The food is amazing (highly recommend the chicken sandwich), and the beer selection keeps getting better.
author: Vishay N.

description: I'm sure the food is good but it was a waster of time. I went for a "lamb burger" based on a Yelp search, but when I got there I found out they haven't served lamb burgers in two years. Is there some way Yelp can stay up to date?
author: Al G.

description:
I believe great restaurant and bars are always stumbled on by "word of mouth". In my case this exact thing happened all on one random hungry night in the mission. 

First off I'd like to mention that not only does this bar have a superb selection of beers of all kinds, but the grub (as they say) is quite a one-two combo of deliciousness.

I personally recommend any of they're burgers or chicken sandwiches, yum.
author: Peter S.

description:
So disappointed with the new menu. Yes, of course I miss my old favorites, but this was a place I would bring out of town guests with the unpretentious atmosphere, amazing beer selection and amazing food. 

We went last night and found the new menu to our surprise and tried to have an open mind (though silently sulking about not being able to have my mac and cheese). Our waiter seemed on the defensive from the start about the new menu as I'm sure he's been getting an earful. So, I asked for his recommendations and we ordered what he suggested. The small plates we got (fennel sausage & trotter and tail cakes) were really bland and lacking flavor. The burger on the other hand was flavorful, but not the big juicy burger of Monk's Kettle past. We also had the house salad, which had good components, but I don't think it was dressed at all and was completely dry. In the past, the soup was always the highlight of our meal and we were just too afraid to try it.....maybe we will give it another shot, but it has definitely fallen out of our list of top spots.
author: Jill S.

description:
Let me preface this review with one extremely important piece of information. 

Quite possibly the best Mac and Cheese I've ever had. God damn it was good. (bonus 1 star) 

Now, moving on. 

Monk's Kettle is a cute, very small spot that's claim to fame is beers and foods that go along with said beers. Fun idea. It's essentially a tiny brew co. type of place that skews a touch on the "we're fancy" side. The food (aside from said mac and cheese) was ok (a touch pricey) and the beers I had were indeed very nice. 

One gripe I kinda had with the place is, considering how small it is, how crowded it is, I have no idea whey they also have the music up so damn loud. The place is small and noisy as it is so I guess the thought is they'll just pump up the jams and it'll all work out. Considering the vibe everything else is going for, you'd think the place would want a bit more subdued dinner atmosphere. 

Not that I know anything about running a restaurant. 

Aside from that, pretty good times.
author: Andy A.

description:
It took forever to get a table here! The hour wait was actually closer to two. But the host was super nice and they have a ba-jillion beers to occupy you while to wait for your table. The staff is super knowledgeable. I tried two different white ales b/c their my favorite. The food was so delicious! Worth the wait I'd say. My wedge salad was everything a wedge salad should be...not a nutritious thing on the plate, just blue cheese-bacon-creamy dressing goodness. We shared fried goat cheese that was a little bit of heaven and my dining companion had a chicken sandwich that put all other chicken sandwiches to shame. 
I'll be back for sure but next time I BART it so that I can get nice and sauced sampling their beers while I wait 2 hours for a table.
author: Aubs J.

description:
Monk's Kettle is DA BOMB!  I don't really drink beer, but I love, love Belgian beer- so Monk's Kettle is a God send with it's huge beer list from every price point.  I highly recommend the pull pork sandwich... amazing, amazing.. perfect when you just want good comfort food and a good beer. 

Monk's Kettle will always have a special place in my heart, because I was have a beer on election night when we finally got Obama... it was a wonderful place to be- surrounded by different people with opinions and having great beer.
author: Nezza F.

description: Beer, beer and more beer. Came here pretty tipsy, so don't remember much. Seems like it is only beer, which is fine by me, 'cause like to wet my whistle in many ways (wait, that sounds kinda odd) oh well. I would like to come back and try some of the snacks/food.
author: Shira O.

description:
BEER! So...much....beer! 

I've been here twice, both times on a Friday night and the crowds are usually out of control. The beer selection is the only thing that would keep me coming back to this place, seriously it's like six pages long!

My advice is to do what we did. 1) Get your name on the list. 2) Give the host your phone number. 3) Drink at Gestalt for an hour. 4)  Go back to the 'Kettle when they ring you.

...okay, so we've now worked our way through the crowd and we're sitting down enjoying our beer in awesome beer-specific glasses. Tasty burger, veggie friends give the veggie burger a so-so review & pot pie of the day filled with rabbit is an apparent hit! 

Arrogant Bastard Ale & Fuller's London Porter on tap coupled with a bazillion other interesting beers will keep me coming back.
author: Nate R.

description:
When a business is situated on 16Th Street right next to The Delirium and across the street from Double Dutch, you can imagine my excitement. 

You can also imagine my excitement when this business turns out to be a restaurant (!), with awesomely unusual beer (!!), with a cool staff (!!!), and has bar food with a classy kick (!!!!). 

The Monk is surely doing it right.
author: Cindy H.

description:
I live a few blocks away and have been here a number of times. One of the best beer selectons in the city. Also good food - I generally get the pork chop, have also had and enjoyed the lamb burger, the pulled pork sandwich, and a number of the salads.

Only disadvantage is that it is so busy that even during the week there is frequently a wait. This is mitigated somewhat by the fact that there is often seats available at the bar.
author: Stephen B.

description:
Over priced and over rated. Save your self $60 and skip Monks Kettle. The only thing worse then dropping $8.25 for a pretzel is that I was stupid enough to order one. You can buy a whole box of super pretzels at the super market and they are virtually the same. Burger was average, my wife liked the chicken pot pie (I thought it just tasted like pepper). 
Only reason I gave it two stars was for the beer selection.
author: Andrew D.

description:
This review is about the food, not the beer (i know....weird since this is a bar).  The bricked chicken is amazing...seriously you need to try it. fried oysters were awesome as well.  duck was decent, mussels average, pickle forgettable, and fries above average.  

overall amazing food for a bar and the beer menu was something like 5-6 pages long so I'm sure they could find something that you would enjoy.

check it out but they dont take reservations so it's a bit of a wait during the busy hours.
author: Paul C.

description:
I had lunch at The Monk's Kettle today.  I'd planned on eating at Ti Couz, but its closed its doors after 16 years in business!  Sad.

Anyway, I had the pot pie of the day which happened to be seared scallops.  Scallops in pot pie?!  Yes.  And it was delicious.  The crust was flaky and savory and the sauce was a perfect fit for the scallops and peas.  I've got to find out when they'll serve this again!
--
It's about time a place like this opened in the Mission.  I've been to The Monk's Kettle three times already this week and I plan on going back soon.

If you like beer, you're in the right place.  I recall that they have 20+ on tap and over 100 in bottles and the staff knows their shit.  

On the downside, the food and service have been spotty so far.  I had a very good salad one day, with currants and almonds, and some tasty mushroom soup, but a mediocre Niman Ranch burger one day and a veggie burger another day that was completely unsatisfying -- like a pile of lukewarm, mashed-up lentil beans stuck between two slices of bread.  Bread was damn good, though.  I almost forgot to mention -- the french fries are superb.

The first night I went, the bartender was slow and seemed distracted.  Nice guy, but just wished he had been more attentive.

The Monk's Kettle could be better, but I'm not complaining.  It's all about the beer.  And the fries.
author: Daniel S.

description:
Go for the diverse beer selection and a wait staff that actually knew how to recommend unusual and solid pairings.

The food was rich and soulfull and stood up well to the beer.

Why not 5, the wait, the wait the wait...ouchie.

Tip, go early
author: Ken p.

description: Best burger in town. Love the onion jam. Great beer selection. Go late Sunday afternoon for no wait.
author: Lindsi K.

description:
Finally, something done with this space to make up for the loss of Kelly's Burgers!

Seriously, they've done remarkable things with the place.  Its dark and woody and gorgeous.  The food, while a little expensive, is great.  And the beer selection is awesome.  I had something called Toast Malt Liquor which was much better than it sounds.

Highly recommended.
author: Steve S.

description: Fantastic beer list and a mellow atmosphere.  A great upscale bar, which is tough to find in that part of the Mission District.
author: Bob C.

description:
Eighty dollars for lunch. That's right, ya heard? I had two beers and my girlfriend had three and we SPLIT a burger, and it was EIGHTY DOLLARS FOR LUNCH. 

Yeah, I get it. This is the place where you can find all the Belgians that you can't find anywhere else, and they cost money to import over here. I get all of that. But they have very few $5 pint options in case you don't want to spend $10 per beer. 

And let's not even talk about the burger. It's $10.50. To add cheese is $2.00. To add bacon is $2.00. To add onions is $2.00. When all was said and done, we ate a $17 burger that was disgustingly undercooked and on a hard, cold bun that was far too large for the patty. You gonna charge $17 for a burger, that shit better be flawless. And when I politely asked the owner if he could throw it back on the grill for a couple more minutes, as the patty had just mooed and taken a shit on my plate, he stared at me snottily and said "So you want it more done then?" Um, yeah, that's usually what people mean when they ask for it to be thrown back over the heat source. 

One thing I will say, we had a very adorable server who was very attentive. Nothing wrong with the service here. It's just ridiculously overpriced. This is not your hang-out, feel-good Mission bar. This is a bar that should be in the Ferry Building where you expect lunch to cost $80. I say jump on the 22 Fillmore and get thee to the Toronado, where you can get a sensibly-priced pint for $5 and a properly-cooked piece of meat at Rosemunde for $4.

***Amendment to review: the friend with whom I ate at this restaurant is friends with the owner of Monk's Kettle. The next time he went in, the owner mentioned reading this review and asked my friend to apologize to me for my experience here. I bumped it up another star because I appreciate the attempt. That's decent customer service.
author: kdub ..

description:
One day a man hit my car.  We exchanged information.  Fast forward to that night.  I want to go out in the mission. We go to Casa Nova, I open my wallet and I see a dark man with a mustache (I am a blonde lady).  Little did I know that "hit my car guy" and I actually EXCHANGED drivers licenses.  Drats.  Can't get into that bar.  So we head to The Monk's Kettle.  They get one star because they did not card me, thus I was able to get in with Awwad's license.  

There are so many beers to choose from.  I choose one from the hefe category.  It is good.  I really like looking around and seeing all the different types of beer glasses that they have. Some big, some tall, some small....  The place is small and full.  It is an awkward place to stand at the bar, as there is no room for that.  We put our name on the list for a table, though we just came to drink.  

We end up getting a giant soft pretzel.  Delicious.  Almost as good as the one's I remember from Price Club where you get to spray and put on your own salt.  

I end up knocking a picture off the wall (yup, good night for me).  It drops with a boom.  Everyone stops and stares.  Beer spills.  The Monk's Kettle people think it is their fault and replace the spilled beer.  Very nice of them.  

Overall, The Monk's Kettle is an enjoyable experience.  The things I did not like:

Too small (but so many bars in SF are)
Too (as some one described it) pottery barn for the mission.
Some of the beers are gross and you do not know until it is too late.

Things I like:
Accepted me as dark man named Awwad
Giant pretzel
Replaced Beer.
author: Brittney B.

description:
* * * Review for drinks only * * *

Came here for drinks after dinner on a Sat. night.  Looking for something mellow and something new.  

Great beer selection.  Great location.  Decor inside was the offspring of a tavern and Pottery Barn.  Prices were a bit much.  It's beer!  Don't misunderstand, I like artisan beers as well as PBR, local micro-brews as well as Belgium ales.  But for beer, I'd recommend Toronado on Haight.

Last note, the service was great.  Our server and the bartender were friendly and helpful.  If you get overwhelmed by their beer list, ask for recommendations and a taste.
author: L Y.

description: what can you say....great food, killer beer selection on a pamphlet sized small print booklet....cherry chocolate beer, elder flower beer, too much. Food menu designed around the beer.  hard to go wrong....excellent desserts.  my complaint is the pricey charges...not a regular hangout for me....but a great place for beer lovers
author: Ral S.

description: Perfect!!!!  I went to several places in SF looking for a place that was doing great beer with great food and I found it at the  Monk's Kettle.  Had pretzels, burger, & a cheese plate with a flight of Hop strong beers.  Everything was top notch, including the friendly/knowledgable server.    The interior had character and was very clean and comfortable.  It was nice to see a restaurant doing things right!
author: Jason B.

description:
My friend and I have been trying to eat here for a while now.  Unfortunately, the few times we tried...the wait was over an hour - and the parking sucks.  What can you expect though - it's the mission...picky parkers need not apply.  Fortunately, the parking gods were with me today after I dropped my friend off to see if there was a table.  But to no surprise...the wait was almost two hours.  Right when we were about to decide on another spot, my friend notices a couple of empty seats at the bar - judging by the foot traffic at this place, I wouldn't be surprised if it gets like "get your game face on" (the recent 49er ad campaign) in there...MOVE B*TCH!  GET OUT THE WAY!

Long story short...if you can score seat or if they're willing to serve you as you pop a squat - go for it!  I recommend the Mac 'n Cheese above all else.  We all think we have an idea of Mac from the wonder years...but this place will set your taste buds straight!  I can't wait to take the little lady here to share the gluttony!
author: Derik P.

description:
What a fantastic little place!  I went here with my husband and two other Belgian Beer loving friends.  It is a small place and it it quite popular so there can be a wait for a table.  However, we could not have been more pleased by the waitstaff here.   Our waitress was friendly, quick and knowledgeable.  She really knew that beers here and was able to describe and offer excellent suggestions.  

We got there around 6PM on Sunday and put our names on the list.  We ordered some beers wile waiting.  We did wait a very long time for a table.  I don't consider this the fault of the restaurant.  They can't really help how many people show up.  They did try to get us seated as quickly as they could and even comped us appetizers that we ordered while waiting.   They totally didn't have to do this, but it was an incredibly nice touch that engendered even more good feelings about this warm and cozy place.  

The beer here is also not cheap.  However, it is because they are specializing in beers that aren't cheap and are also often difficult to find.  If someone doesn't LOVE good beer, they may not appreciate it enough.  However, if you are a beer lover, this is the place for you.  One beer that they currently have on tap that is truly special is the Rodenbach Grand Cru.  Our waitress brought us over some samples since she thought we would like it.  She was correct!  All four of us ordered our own it was so good.  We are pretty big fans of Flanders Red Ales (we are currently brewing one at home) and after we told her that, she made sure that we tried this.  It is a bit sour, but very pleasantly mild and a bit malty.  Yum!

The food here was definitely tasty.  We had the charcuterie plate and fries while waiting.  Both were excellent.  We then all had the hamburger for dinner.
