We saw other people ordering it and knew it was something we needed to try.  It was one of the best hamburgers I have had in a long time.  The bread for the bun was especially good and the burgers were juicy.  

After writing this novel about how much I love this place, I will definitely be back.  My budget doesn't allow for this to be an everyday place, but if it did, I would be here most days.  The fact that I can't afford this place everyday is probably a good thing for my waistline.
author: Kate B.

description: Great, unique food and beers. Loved the atmosphere, and our server/ bartender was awesome!
author: Jennifer V.

description:
Cool place and would come back again...

Lamb Burger (tasty) and Grotten Brown (developing a taste for Belgian beer).

Only negative is parking but it's The City so just figure it out (lol).
author: Francis M.

description: When you say a beer name, the bartender says it back to you in a questioning tone with more pretentious pronunciation, like he was only barely able to discern which beer you said due to your unforgivably gauche accent.  I like that.
author: Paul K.

description:
Incredible beer selection!  24 beers on tap, most of them local brews I hadn't heard of.  We tried the Baltic Porter, the Jolly Roger (an imperial brown), the Velvet Merkin (an oatmeal stout), and the Artemis (an herbed ale, using mugwort [artemisia vulgaris] and I forget what else in place of hops).  All of them were good.  The beer list tells you everything you might like to know before you order -- type of beer, where it's brewed, and ABV.

The food was on the pricey side but impressive.  The chicken pot pie was maybe the best I'd ever had, and the black bean cakes were scrumptious.  The mac and cheese was a little salty for my taste, but my date (a bigger mac 'n cheese aficionado than I) loved it.

Even on a Monday night, it was reportedly an hour and a half wait for a table, but we were able to snag seats at the bar after only a few minutes of hovering.  The place is fairly cozy, holding only about 50 people, which might explain the long wait.

We'll definitely be going back here, maybe for late lunch on a weekday when it's a little less packed.
author: Sam S.

description:
A+ beer, A - burgers.  Limited menu, nothing creative, but if you want highbrow beer, this place is better than most.  

Unfortunately, I've never found a seat other than the rickety stools in the back, even pretty late on a weeknight.  It's not the comfortable place that it seems like it should be.
author: Ben A.

description:
Went here the other night and i must say i had a very splendid time.  The beer list got me hard (IT WAS HUGE!), and the food looked amazing!  Ordered some fries here and they were terrific, wish i would have been hungry for more!  I look forward to coming back to this spot!  

"Did you see the size of her tits? Talk about Astronaut Farmers!!!"
Stephen Hawking
author: John B R.

description:
How many different types of beer are there?  Sure, you're familiar with terms like "lager" and "pilsner" and "ale", but do you have any idea, any idea at all, just how vast the world of beer truly is?

Let the Monk's Kettle be your guide.

The beer menu is presented clipboard style, with the 20+ beers on tap listed top front.  Following that are pages and pages which list their bottled beers.  The beers are organized by type, with a nice little description accompanying each one, so you can easily understand the difference between the bock, the doppelbock, the hefeweizen, and the weizenbock.  You see?  That's just four types of beer right there!  And there are so many, many more! 

The service is excellent, the food amazing, and the atmosphere lovely. Go.
author: Mariah M.

description:
Do not make the mistake I came very close to making.  Don't leave! This place is VERY crowded.  Like, you can't stand anywhere without accidentally dry-humping everyone around you and dancing around servers and people on their way to the head.  

But, don't let the crowd sway you to look for a quieter and roomier eatery.  The food and beers here are well worth dry-humping strangers for, and hell maybe you could use it?   

The beer list is giant, and you may not know what to get.  Have no fear, the servers and bartenders are very accommodating with recommendations.  Is not at like Toronado where you may get kicked in the shin for not immediately knowing what you want .  

This place has fantastic food.  I tried every dish at my table, and they were all equally impressive.  Service was great too, but don't expect to be in and out of there.  You will be waiting for your table at dinner time. Enjoy!
author: Shawn S.

description: Love this place! Glad my friend is obsessed with Kevin Rose from Diggnation. Apparently he use to go there and she was hoping we would run into him...? Since that drunken night we have been back for lunch and I loved it. I tried the grilled chicken sandwich with bacon and brie. So yummy! I asked the waiter to recommend a beer and his choice was perfect for me - Old Speckled Hen. That's some good beer! I love the laid back vibe of the place & I'll definitely be back.
author: Nicole F.

description:
This place is so ironic because I always meet the coolest people here.  We talk about our bikes and where to get the best vegan bratwursts, and the like, which just adds to the whole ambiance.

I just moved out to San Francisco from my hometown Cudahy, WI, not too long ago, and I've already made so many friends here over a few cold pints of my favorite beer.  Their food is great, too.  Reasonable prices and solid portions.  I highly recommend The Monk's Kettle.
author: Stephen G.

description:
Amazing beer selection.  Not a drinking spot I can afford to patronize on a regular basis, but a new go-to spot for super fancy $12 beers.  The novelty is fun, but I guess it's mostly wasted on me.  I appreciate the concept though.  So-so food.  The atmosphere is sort of dim and cozy, but even though the place is packed, it's kinda chilly.  The service seemed stretched a little thin - our waitress was scrambling to take care of everyone, but the bartender (not very busy) forgot to get me a beer I had ordered.   

(Insert one of those classic Yelp rants about gentrification in the Mission).  

I'm sure they'll do well for themselves.
author: Natalie S.

description: Knocking off a star because when we didn't order drinks, just food, the service became extremely inattentive (I assume because we were less lucrative). The waiter didn't write down our order and completely forgot it. Otherwise good, kale salad and bean soup were great, fish perfectly cooked and vegetables still deliciously crunchy, burger juicy and tasty. Daily pickle jar a bit oddly spiced and too sweet. We went at an offpeak time and still had to wait for a table for maybe 15 min, but it seemed longer because there is nowhere to stand and every person coming in or out shoves you while you're waiting.
author: Tiger P.

description: As far as beer places in SF go, this is one of my favorite. Went with some friends, we each tried three different beers (so I got to taste 9 total) and they were all amazing! The staff is attentive and know a lot about what they have on tap. We only went for drinks so I am looking forward to going back for food. Its a smaller place so if you don't want to wait forever to snag a seat at the bar go during a week night and keep your party on the smaller size.
author: Shanna T.

description:
SOOOO close to five stars, I wish there was a 4 and a half star... the only thing is SOME of the servers are such little snots!  

Aside from that AMAZING beer selection, I want to try them all!  It gets super crowded though, so if you don't like people hovering over you while you eat I would say don't go!  

BTW the cheese sauce (mac n cheese or for pretzel dipping) is amazing phenomenal!!!  They should have that on tap (actually that would be gross), but it's THAT good!
author: Nicole S.

description:
Felt the need for an update here on this one.  Since my last review I've gone here quite a few times for a drink.  The staff seems to know us and even if they don't they act like they do, which I like.  They make really awesome recommendations on what to drink and know quite a bit about how each beer is made.  I'm a total geek about this stuff, so I love that they don't just HAVE the beer, but they KNOW about what they serve.

I also ordered a burger recently, and it was darn good.  I still can't do the pies and pastry, but would happily eat another 1/4 lb of meat here.

My only real problem at this point is that my girlfriend and I always say "let's go to Monks Kettle", get all excited, walk over and then realize we'd have to wait an hour.  We can't even get in for a beer at this point.  I'm happy they're that busy, but miss sitting at my newly discovered neighborhood bar.
author: louda l.

description:
Evening host is service sucks.  Perhaps all the accolades are going to their heads.  Avoid this place if you're looking to feel welcome.  If you could care less cuz it's a pub and you want good beer and tasty food I'm sure you'll enjoy as I did... until last week. Wish I could give 2.5 stars cuz its OK; choosing 2 instead of 3 cuz I'm still pissed about Thursday.

Okay... a few months ago I visted this place for the first time w/ co-workers.  Mid-day, not crowded; we sat and enjoyed the place for a few hours.  Apps, salads, lots of beer and lots of SKILLET COOKIES!  I was impressed w/ the service and even grew a small crush on the bartender/server(something sexy about the way he poured the beer. LOL)  I had been raving to people about the place ever since.

We returned last Thurs & again were seated quickly (any party over 5 should avoid this place during peak dining hours).  Had the same experience with the beer and food.  Different server but he was cool.  However, the host essentially kicked us out of the place.  There were 5 of us.  We paid our bill and took care very good care of waiter.  3 people left to drink elsewhere just as two others joined us and wanted a quick beer and a skillet cookie (the cookie is what made them decide to beet us there).  The host, clearly upset, says to them "Are you two new?" "We're approaching peak so you can't take up this table just for beer or whatever".  As if how dare we try to order more?!?  We politely left... never been treated like that in my life.

I can find great beer (Beer Revolution, The Trappist)... Let me know if you know where I can get a good skillet cookie in the bay  :o)
author: MisPriTee T.

description:
I love this place! I never thought I'd be willing to pay wine prices for beer, but the Monk's Kettle opens your world. 

It IS the world! The world of artisan beer, and sheer delight to the senses. The staff is well informed and eager to heighten your experience. You can pretty much randomly descibe any sensation you would like to have in a glass and they'll bring it to you. Impressive!

Another plus is that the food is delicious (granted on the several times I've been I haven't steered far from the Greek style lamb burger). Do not miss the fries with its accompanied sauces!
author: Ivy H.

description:
Totally styley, totally casual, massive beer list, hearty organic food.

Two could give their pretzel a run for its money though...
And the veggie burger needs some reworking. It's pretty bleh.

Everything else is sweet.
author: Melanie C.

description:
My veggie burger was pretty damned good, but not worth 11 dollars.  ELEVEN dollars!  Is the dollar really doing that bad?

I even asked for a $1.50 slice of cheese on my burger.  I couldn't help it.

Oh yeah, the beer.  It was good, but places with this many beers always stink of pretension.
author: Braden T.

description:
I was not impressed with the food.  It certainly wasn't worth the 1+ hour wait.  We had the veggie burgers and they sort of fell apart.  E.g., I picked up the bun and the patty broke into 10 pieces on my plate.  It would've been fine if the 10 pieces all tasted wonderful, but even morningstar patties tasted better than this.

On the plus, they do have a nice wine and beer selection.
author: Sid D.

description: Monk's may be ok for exotic beer choices served with a pretentious attitude  but the prices are on the high side and the food can be nasty.  Definitely stay away if you're a non-meat eater as the veg burger is an inedible, pasty mess.
author: Crabby J.

description:
Gastro Pub - what a great idea! I wish we had more places  in SF that serve good beer with good food. Pizzas, burgers, and chicken wings - get old sometimes.

Monks - has a overwhelming selection of Beers from all over the world..they even have a bottle for 60 dollars for the ballahs! If you are a beer lover you need to check this place out. Some bonuses on the food menu - lamb burger, salmon sandwich, special - sausage sandwich..that with a Belgian or German brew = heaven

Get here early  - place is small and fills up!
author: Christian S.

description:
Quick! Come here before the Belgian beer trend is completely overdone and annoying. I'm not being sarcastic.. really, squeeze your way in here, the selection is incredible. Chouffe, Duchesse de Borgogne, St. Bernardus, and Maredsous are just some of the fine selections on tap, and the bottle list is enormous, including Foret, Fantome, Westmalle, Orval, Piraat, Duvel, and my most favorite of all: Rochefort. Clearly the emphasis is on beer exploration and education, which might explain the absence of the fantastic but by now very well known Chimay. They even have all the silly brewery-specific glassware, like the crazy Kwak bulb that rests in a specially designed wooden holder. 

'Twill be a shame when the crowds at these places overshadow the delicious beer experience. Decent food too.
author: Tom L.

description:
As a girl who loves her Guinness, I loved this place EVEN THOUGH THEY DON'T SERVE GUINNESS.  That said...

It's a pretty neat little place in the Mission off 16th and Guerrero. The inside is reminiscent of a quaint old... well, pub. Beautiful wood booths and bar and decor. Near the back is more bar seating but with blackboards upon which you can sketch or graffiti to your heart's content. 

HUGE amazing beer, lager, ale list that made up for them not having Guinness. If you want to try something, they'll bring a little taster out in these cute little baby beer mugs.

I had the Beamish stout - yummy. It was like the love child of a Guiness and Boddingtons. My friend had some fruity rasberry beer that was on tap and also quite delish.  My roomie joined us for some reputedly awesome IPA's, though we girls definitely made our bitter beer faces after trying a sip. 

Food menu was above-par bar food. We got the fries with 3 different sauces were only $5.  The curry aioli was interesting and the chipotle ketchup was great.  The charcuterie plate  was delish with duck prosciutto, pate, soppressante, beer sausage... now that is my idea of a meatfest.

Oh, and you HAVE to order their pretzel ($8). Our-resident-New-Yorker approved it's New Yorky genuiness. I was too busy stuffing my face with it dunked in their beer mustard to disagree. THAT GOOD.

Can't wait to go back for more beer tasting.
author: D k.

description:
I've been to Monk's Kettle twice. Both were good experiences. They have an extensive beer list, and although they were out of the first two beers that I ordered, they still had more (and better) beer options than any other bar I've been to in SF.

Also, the wait staff is personable and helpful, which is important to me. They notified me when a keg of one of the unavailable beers arrived.

It was pretty crowded, but that's to be expected from a new bar w/ good atmosphere.

I haven't eaten there yet, but I will. And I'll probably like it.
author: Wes F.

description:
I had none of the bad service problems that other reviewers had, but then again I went here for lunch, not dinner, and there were a couple of empty tables. The waiter was great and very attentive, there were some beers on tap they were out of due to the busy weekend but he readily suggested replacement beers for the types we were interested in. GREAT selection of beers.  We had the black bean cake appetizer which was really delicious. I had the shrimp pot pie. I have never had pot pie before so I didn't know they are normally very creamy, which I'm not that into. It was good for what it was, especially the filo crust on top. I'm looking forward to returning and trying something else. My husband had a burger with fries, he loved the burger and I loved the fries. 

Also, the place is beautifully decorated, they did a great job with the remodel.  Will definitely visit again.
author: Lisa Marie G.

description:
I went late on a Thursday night for drinks expecting to wait around  for a small sliver of the bar. The date and I were surprised, however, to find a cozy table for two right by the window. 

The place is stylish, a little loud and a little crowded (I can imagine the last two items getting exponentially worse on the weekend).

But to the main event: the beer.  They had a very very solid beer menu. I am a big believer of drinking what's on tap- even in a place with tons of fancy bottled belgians.  Because after all, one *can* just buy a bottle at an upscale liquor store for much less and curl up at home- when I go out I like to see how these beers taste on tap.

But I digress. The beer: a great selection of local, regional and European. I had the St. Bernardus on tap (this is the first place I have seen in on tap since Amsterdam). And the Drake's Imperial Stout on nitro. I am not totally sold on the nitro concept but I am a sucker for a Big Dark beer. The date, who hates beer (yes he is awesome for humoring me) enjoyed his Fox Barrel Black Current Cider.

The service was fine, if a little slow and the bartender was nice and helpful. I will be back to try the food, which looks a bit expensive but really not that bad. I mean, ok, $12 for a burger is a bit intense but it costs $8 at Applebee's, so for a few bucks less you can sip a bud light. But that's not why you came to Monk's Kettle.
author: Rebecca A.

description:
Maybe my new favorite place.

Veggie options galore, and very flavorful.

5 page beer menu.  Can you ask for more?
author: Darryl S.

description:
I'm a bit conflicted on Monk's Kettle.  I like the idea of a quality gastropub in the Mission, and I really like the interior design of this place.  But I have some issues...

1.  Forget about going here during peak hours.  Way too crowded and loud.  But being wildly successful and popular is not the fault of the restaurant.

2.  Very nice beer selection, but I would say it's severely overpriced when compared to SF's world class beer bar, The Toronado, which admittedly has a different vibe.  Most of the draft beers were over $10, which seems ridiculous to me.  I did get some great 10 ounce stronger beers for what I consider a fair price.

3.  The food is priced similarly to Magnolia Brewpub, which has better food.  I had the burger, which was overcooked for "medium", and really sabotaged by the lame bun.  You can't have a great burger without a great bun, and Monk's Kettle, your bun just sucks.  See the bun on the Magnolia burger or the Absinthe burger for inspiration.

4.  What is it with the hipsters and bridge and tunnelers that pack this place night after night?  How can they afford to eat and drink here?

Bottom line, worth a visit now and then, but I think Magnolia Brewpub bests this place in terms of food.  Magnolia's beers can also be outstanding.  

You can also slum it and get a sausage from Rosamunde Sausage Grill (which comes in a bun that is divine) and walk it over to the Toronado and have many of the same beers served at Monks' Kettle for much less $.  Of course, then you have to confront' the Toronado's rather gross bathrooms.

Update:  Since I wrote this review, the Rosamunde Sausage Grill has opened up on Mission and 24th.  Go there.  Beer selection that is just as good, but about 35% cheaper, nice ambiance, excellent sausages, and... you can usually get in and get a table!
author: Paul S.

description:
One of my stand by places to go. Love it. 

I prefer to go on early saturday and sunday afternoons before it gets crowded, and sit at the bar.
author: Ben S.

description:
My burger (and my companion's burgers) was quite good and the beer was delicious.  I left the place having been there for three hours (90 minutes of waiting), my lips were chapped and red from the extremely salty fries and I sounded like Sam Elliott after yelling over the noise.  

Still it was pretty good...
author: Aaron D.

description:
I'm taking the time to write this just to warn you that the service here is sub-sub-sub-standard these past few months. The food is great. The atmosphere is terrific. The beer selection is second to none. But the service sucks.

Don't wait or put your name down, they forget you exist. The servers are utterly uninterested and pretty short when they speak to you, if at all.

The last three times I've been we've sworn not to go back, including last night. But it keeps happening because the food saves them.
author: Steve C.

description:
all of you who told me their burger was good are fucking retarded! their beef burger is awful. i picked it over the pork bc of you assholes! it was one of the worst burgers i've ever had! it was like licking asshole
now their pork was amazing. the brussels sprouts are great too!
the fried ocra was ok
author: Christopher L.

description:
This place was 1/3 of a fabulous evening:

a) Monk's Kettle
b) Dalva (for cheaper beer.  I know.)
c) Roxie for 'Guest of Cindy Sherman.'

I'm partial to the Trappist, in Oakland, in terms of amazing-beer-drinking-establishments.  Monk's Kettle serves good grub, however.  I'd say if you're more extroverted, you'd like Monk's Kettle better---It's loud & crowded & a bit of a party.  

If you're a bit more introverted & into a more ambient, darker look---try the Trappist.  Or don't...cuz there's about 6 chairs there.
author: Holly F.

description: Burger was good, fries a little bit too cooked but good anyway. Beer was okay. Only three stars for my first visit, it was indeed very crowded and very, very noisy (probably due to the reflection on the marble that surrounds you). The place is beautiful anyway.
author: Benjamin O.

description:
I review everything in context.

This is a solid 4 star place. Great food and great beer selection. The staff is great and they actually can give out good suggestion on beer.

The ambient is great, just a little loud, and the seating are booth, no big group.

I would like to go back on a lazy afternoon and sample a bunch of beer.
author: Alice C.

description:
We were looking for food after a drink, you know, so we could drink some more. After stopping by a few spots, a hostess from another spot (they were closed) sent us over to The Monk's Kettle. 

The beer selection was good. But we were already tipsy and didn't order any. So I will have to update my review...

But the food was good.The pulled pork sandwich was so good. When I am dining with friends, I usually play halfsies and we switch a bite or two. I gave my girl Moni 1/4 of my sandwich. She commented that I should've put the slaw in the sandwich, but I do it bit by bit for each bite.
Her sandwich was OK, she asked for medium well but one of her slices of steak was pinkier than she likes, but the skinny fries were good.

The setup of the spot was good, they cymballed a few of those retro light bowls together for decor. The bathroom was clean, which makes it a great place to drink beer since it runs through me faster than water. I will come back again for the sandwich and to visit that bathroom a few times.
author: Cheryl D.

description:
Great place to eat if you can get a table. But who needs food when you can have beer? It's often at capacity since this is a small place. The beer selection is great, although the stuff on tap is so good I've never gotten too far down the menu. 

The menu is full of stuff that goes down easy with beer. Pretty decent pricing if you stick to the sandwiches. Can't say I'm a fan of the zany dipping sauces, but Heinz 57 is close at hand.
author: John M.

description:
I still drool thinking about their massive beer list. I'm annoyed that I can't remember what beer my friend ordered--it had a delicate, floral aroma that I've only experienced before with wine.

Also, their sandwiches/burgers pair PERFECTLY with beer. It's like a gourmet juggernaut, and you're forced to eat the whole thing and revel in food coma when leaving the restaurant.

If only it wasn't so crowded and hard to get a table on weekends....
author: Richie K.

description:
I had a friend in town to visit, so I thought I'd take him here as I heard it had a great selection of beers. Well, it does. In fact, if you like beer, this is pretty much the motherlode. The fact that the beer list is given to you on a metal clipboard and has as many pages as a home loan application is proof enough.

We had to wait for about 20 minutes, so it wasn't too bad. It's a small-ish place, but has a warm atmosphere and the service is great. Even though we were just there to pound beers (and a $32 bottle of beer...ouch), the food smelled so good we had to order something. We ended up just getting fries, but damn....those were good-ass fries! And the aioli dipping sauce (one of three they gave us) is reaaaaaaaallly good. Rich as heck, but it's so worth it.
author: David H.

description:
Another true SF gastropub: a deceptively small spot that serves  turkey burgers, fries  -- and vacuums money out of your wallet.

Partly because the drinks are good, but pricey.  As is the grub.  The beer menu is the most formal bit, and there are mini-essays under each beer that read like tags at a museum exhibit.  This is like the anti-Toronado, where they also have plenty of beers.  But there there is no fancy binder, just a chalkboard, and you either know what you want, or the bartender does not recognize you exist and you stand there looking lost.

However, the turkey burger is the best I've had, not that it's hard to beat most of them out there.  But it was fresh, spiced, and without that weird gamy taste.
author: ed y.

description: Great concept, but disappointing in execution.  It's more crowded than La Trappe, costs more, and service isn't as friendly.  Granted, they also have a great selection of delicious Belgian beers, but the only reason I go is because it's in the Mission instead of North Beach.
author: Jori P.

description:
They serve food really late!   So when I'm hungry and it's after 10pm (or 11!) this is one of my favorite places to go.  Their homemade sausage (special of the day), and the pot pie was excellent.  There is a very extensive selection of beers, and they will let you taste  a couple before ordering.
It's usually crowded and with a nice selection of friendly customers.
However, I was once insulted by a server here. I was asking for beer recommendations, and he was upset that I wanted to select a beer according to the color. I prefer beers that are amber colored or darker. He said that had nothing at all to do with the taste of the beer (!), and wanted to describe the taste only in terms of hoppiness and  malt.
author: Meredith G.

description:
I went here a couple of weeks ago with a few friends, and was very impressed. It's a bit on the pricey end of things, but is definitely worth it. They let you sample beers and wine so you don't have to waste time and money drinking something you won't like. 

Romantic atmosphere, warm and cozy, candles everywhere, and a wooded cabin feel. Great place to go with a date, or with a small group of very close friends.
author: Michelle G.

description:
High fives and three cheers! 

The Kettle was so gut-bustingly awesome that we ordered three rounds of appetizers before settling in for our dinner choices. After reading so many scathing yelp posts about this place, I was a little scared about the wait time and brusque staff, but everyone was incredibly nice and, although our wait for a table was quoted at 40 minutes, we got in there in under 15. 

The biggest drawback to this place might be that the beer list (at 20 pages deep) is too long, and that's a problem I'm willing to deal with!
author: joe b.

description:
Having read all the reviews on Yelp, I was skeptical about this place. I expected it to be overcrowded and overhyped. I was pleasantly surprised. The wait staff was friendly and the beer selection is excellent. We found a table almost immediately. This was Sunday night before President's day so it could be that some people didn't have the day off (suckers!) or there were a lot of people out of town for the long weekend. 

Its a welcome addition to the mission.
author: Abhi S.

description:
Potentially the most diverse craft beer (both draught and bottle) selection in The City. They've got ales/lagers from Belgium, Germany, the UK, and the US as well as some more esoteric brewing locations.

If you came here to eat, get the giant pretzel. If you just came here to drink, get the giant pretzel. My burger was cooked to order on a ciabatta roll with Point Reye's blue cheese and paired perfectly with a strong I.P.A. The overall impression I had was good food, but not exceptional. This place is really mainly about the beer, and in no way is that depressing. 

The space is pretty small and when crowded it becomes surprisingly difficult for some people to figure out that while the bar seating is first-come first-served, there is a waiting list for tables. The fact that this arrangement is the case in almost every restaurant in the Mission, let alone The City doesn't seem to factor into the logic. This leads to the repeated humorous spectacle of someone scoping out a table for 20 minutes, swooping down into it, and 5 minutes later being told to vacate and sign up on the waiting list.
author: Joseph R.

description:
gods gift to San Francisco.

The food is top notch, everything on the menu is solid.
My favorite is the Grilled Chicken Sandwich yet there is so much more...try the giant pretzel or the fries or the macaroni and cheese...

The pork chop dinner is amazing, one of the best I've had.

and the beers?

holy crap, there are so many beers to choose from, from so many countries and variety...normally I can see someone getting dizzy from all the choices but the staff is so knowledgeable and friendly...they will walk you thru and even let you sample some of the many varieties.

in all, Monks has become a staple in my San Francisco travels. I frequent it usually every weekend with me girl and we are always made to feel like part of the family there.

this place kills...end of my story...thanks for reading.
author: Dean M.

description:
My favorite bar in the Mission thus far! Just love the atmosphere, the beer selection and the bartenders. We didn't order food, but they do serve pub-like items (mac and cheese, burgers, fries) and from what I saw, it all looked fantastic. 

Beers aren't cheap but it's a great place to go if you're bored of the typical draft beers. They have about 10 different types of beer on tap and then over 50 bottles to choose from. Crazy. Questions? The bartenders are happy to help you choose.

The space is cozy but I think they monitor the standing room and if it's looking too packed they won't let people in. 

If you can, snag a seat by the chalkboards towards the back.
author: Yee-Shing W.

description:
I would definitely give monk's kettle 5 stars if it weren't always so crowded/popular!

They have a great selection of beers.  I find their food to be okay, but the main draw for me is definitely their wide selection of beers on tap.

I do like the pretzel a lot- definitely can be good if you are waiting for a table to open up but need to eat something with your beer.

Prices are pretty reasonable.  There definitely is an upcharge compared to what you could pay for the same beer at Toronado.
author: Jeff A.

description: I really wish they were less packed, I'd definitely come more often. The food is good and they have a nice beer selection. Everything I've tried in the past few visits have all been good, the vegetarian chili was way better than anticipated.
author: Mars C.

description:
I'm basing this review purely on the beer... and it was dee-frickin-licious.  For a new place still working out the kinks, I think they're doing a bang-up job. I haven't ever walked by when they are open that the place hasn't been filled to the RAFTERS. Sure there's the lure of the new, but that beer list is to die for -- and I've barely made a dent. Can't wait to try the menu, and I'll make an appropriate update when I do.

As for the service... ours was great!  Friendly, accommodating, and exceedingly patient, especially considering the press of people and level of chaos around. They seem to have put some signs on the bar area just by the kitchen indicating there is no wait service there and to order from the bar, so maybe that will help mitigate some of the confusion I've read here. 

People... if you don't like beer or crowds or noise -- the first step inside the place should have warned you off!  Those of you who love good beer (and an apparently excellent menu of things to go with it), and don't mind the bustle of a new Mission "hot spot," head on in. You won't be sorry!
author: Kyle M.

description:
Food was great. Service was average.

I wish they took reservations. They told us it would be a half an hour wait but we ended up waiting for about 50 minutes. While waiting, we decided to have drinks at the bar and when our table was available, the man told us he couldn't transfer the tab to the table so we had to settle it there. Mild inconvenience and a tad bit annoying when the place is super crowded and everyone is waiting around for a spot. I'm sure he had his reasons.

The food was delicious with really good portioning. I highly recommend the giant pretzel. The cheese dip is melted love in a dipping bowl. Yum. The waiter was really nice and attentive.

Another plus: Right across the street from Kilowatt and next door to Delirium. Twas a very convenient night out.
author: Jacinta H.

description:
I definitely did not expect this place to be as good as it was. My boyfriend and I stopped in for dinner last night and were wowed all the way around - great service, delicious food and reasonable prices.

The inside is pretty small - there is only seating for about 30-40 people and the tables are kind of on top of one another, but there is still a certain charm to the decor. It feels like the modern version of an English pub, but somehow cleaner and more charming. We only waited about 10 minutes for a table, and the host was very friendly and accommodating, 

We looked over the beer list for several minutes before making a decision - it was about 6 pages long! The bartender was nice enough to let me sample a few before deciding.

Upon being seated our extremely friendly server, Brad, came up and told us about the specials. He was very knowledgeable and made everything sound absolutely delicious. We decided to split the caprese  salad, which came with awesome house made mozzarella. I had the pan seared chicken with mushroom sauce, fingerling potatoes and asparagus, It was amazing and perfectly cooked. My boyfriend had the duck - I'm not a big fan, but he really enjoyed it. 

We finished out beers halfway through the meal, so Brad came up and gave us several suggestions. He also brought us each two samples of his favorites to pair with the meal. I never knew food could actually be paired with beer the same it is with wine, but the flavors definitely complemented each other.

All in all it was a wonderful experience and I plan to make this one of my go-to spots in the Mission from now on!
author: Lindsey S.

description:
The highlight of The Monk's Kettle is their amazingly large beer menu. It is five pages long and contains everything from PBR and Anchor Steam to Gueuze and Scottish Ales. They even have a gluten-free beer! Yes, this list is dominated by Belgian beers but they have something from almost every area of the world. The food was brilliant--I had the skirt steak with green beans and a green salad. The steak was melt in your mouth tender and the green beans were some of the best I have ever had. 
However, the wait was outrageous. This is a good place to come for a beer with a friend or two, but heaven forbid you and your boyfriend show up at 7pm on a Thursday with the intention of having dinner. We waited for almost an hour and a half for a table. I would suggest coming either really early or after 10pm if you want to eat, otherwise, just have a beer at the bar.
author: Steffany F.

description: Great staff, tasty food, wonderful beer selection! My only complaint was that my server suggested a beer to me which wasn't on the menu and it came out on my bill at $23!!!! I've never even heard of a beer that expensive. She should have warned us when she suggested it, especially since it wasn't on the menu and we were ordering the cheapest food on the menu- we obviously weren't out to spend a fortune. Other than that, a great experience!!!
author: Nicole M.

description: Jaw-dropping beer selection, from local niche brews to palate-stretching imports. The small-plate mussels and pretzel dishes are highly recommended.
author: Sean C.

description:
Six of us went in at about 4 p.m. on a Saturday, hoping to skip the rush. We did. The burger I had was awesome, so was the pretzel. 

After racking up about $150 worth of beer, apps and entrees, one of the four servers who came to our table asked if we wanted anything else. We said we might have another round of beers. He said, "Well then we might have to ask you to find some bar space..."

There was no room at the bar. There was no line of people waiting for our table. Oh, and one of the people at our table was a six-month old BABY! (Very well behaved, I might add.) We took the GTFO hint our server was throwing at us. 

Good food, some servers are extremely well-versed in their beers, others are a bit rude and not subtle with the hints to get out and go.

If you're looking for a good spot to enjoy yourself with friends on a weekend, this might not be it.
author: Brian K.

description:
Lots of people have already told you that they like this place too.
It's small, so you'll likely wait or need to sit at the bar unless you're lucky.
Suggestions: Keep the Belgian doubles and triples in stock and on tap.
And don't over-charge too much for them.  Yes, they can be rare, but not that rare.
Food's better than average bar food.
Cheese plates and a big pretzel for your vegetarian friends.
Bedankt.
author: Kev M.

description:
This place has a clipboard full of beers. Not only a clipboard full of beers, but a description on how all of the different styles are brewed. It's a wonder I'm not an expert on beer by this point. Odd. I think there is something to be said about not mixing alcohol with studying, because we read through the descriptions every time we go. Still, no brew mastery.

I've never accurately counted, but they must have about 20 beers on tap. The best part about beer is finding a bottled beer you have tried, but on tap. The difference to me is monumental. It could be placebo, but they always seem to have a different heart: sometimes better, sometimes worse. It's like...when you were a child...visiting a playground with a kid you hated, then a kid you loved, or vice-versa. The experience is completely different. In one instance, you enjoy the beer and, in the other, you ...wind up beating your playmate senseless for throwing sand in your eyes till your mother has to take him to the emergency room. What? Oh yeah, large selection of bottled beers, as well. Whew!

I've never had a problem with the staff here. They are all very knowledgeable about the brews and tend toward a less snobby approach. You won't feel harassed for your lack of knowledge. If you fear the snobbery just tell them you want a beer and you don't care what. They will usually bring you something worth drinking. My girlfriend and I have both tried this and weren't disappointed. Trust me! Wait, you don't have to: try it yourself. When you see the clipboard full of beers, you will thank me.

I have no complaints about their food. Only once, have I sat at a table. Usually, if the place is packed, there is a place at the bar which runs for several meters. Consider this as an option to waiting for a table. You won't mind.

Once, I moved from the bar to the chalk board side of the bar and my tabs got messed up. When we tried to settle up, our tab was hopelessly quagmired. They were more than courteous and we wound up fine, probably paying less than we should have.

OF PARTICULAR INTEREST: Grab a seat at the bar, in front of the chalk board, toward the taps. The chefs' hands, who prepare the food  on the other side of the board, are just visible. It gives an odd, almost surreal theater to the whole experience. And you think, I could totally steal some of the chef's bacon. I could totally order that. The pretzels are pretzels, but hot and scathing to the touch when they come to you.   

Monk's Kettle: Don't fuss none as you aren't want to. You are five stars.
author: Seth B.

description: This place is an excellent gastro pub. The food here is top notch, but not cheap. I really enjoyed all of the offal dishes that this place offers. They have a great selection of beer on tap too.
author: P K.

description:
My boyfriend is a big beer nut and I've been trying to get him to come here for months. We finally got to go with a few friends, and it was exactly as I'd hoped - a great beer mecca for the true beer lover!

First, be warned that this place is small. I recommend going early if you want dinner - there are only a few tables and a small bar, so if you don't grab a table or seat at the bar you're going to be out of luck. The place is cute and has a great bar. 

Next, there is a huge selection of beers - 24 on tap alone! That doesn't include the bottle selection - very good! My boyfriend loved all the beers he ordered, including what the waiter suggested. Our friend also really enjoyed his beers.

The food is good pub food but high class - we ordered the charcuterie  plate, which came with pate, various slices of meats, pickles, mustard, and bread - delicious with beer! I also ordered the potato corn chowder, which was so thicky and creamy and savory. I love that the bread came toasted. For our entrees my boyfriend ordered the lamb burger, which unfortunately was a bit more gamey than he liked, and I ordered the bacon salad, which is a lettuce wedge with cherry tomatoes and bacon bits. My lettuce had a bit of the light pink that comes with being slightly aged, but still tasted fine.

Overall, the food and environment were great, and the selection in beers make up for the lack of space.
author: Katherine P.

description:
This place probably isn't that bad, but I was pretty disappointed since I had seen the advertisements in some of the beer-nerd monthly rags for some time and was excited to finally check it out.  When I got there the service was flat out frustrating.  The place was packed and a table finally opened up and it took them forever to clear the table, even though we had told the bartender and a host-type person that we wanted a table and had put our order in at the bar to get things started, but that we wanted to move to a table.  We finally just sat down at the table because we were tired of standing in the way and the girls eating behind where we were standing were getting tired of the concussions our elbows were inflicting on the back of their heads, which made us feel like assholes for standing around.

I was excited to try the vegetarian burger because as a former vegetarian, having a veggie patty made by the usual three brands every restaurant carries gets boring quick.  If they had bothered to tell me it was jut a pile of cold soggy beans stuffed in a bun I definitely would not have ordered it.

And a waitress never came by asking if we wanted more beer.  We would have filled up the owner's cash box pretty quick if they did that thing where they come by and say "can i get you any more food or drink?"

Also adding to the disappointment was the fact that I was at Toronado a few days before, then Trappist somewhere in between, so by the time I got to Monk's Kettle none of the beers on drought were new and exciting.  I'm not a fan of bottled beer, I go to beer bars because you can't get good droughts anywhere else.   When I don't care about service and just want good beer I go to Toronado, for some reason I was expecting more out of this place.
author: SC ..

description: Awesome bar! Got a seat right by the window which opens to the street and it was amazing. There are so many beers to choose from and it was a great place to start our bar hopping.  I didn't order any food but the fries looked incredible.
author: Casandra R.

description:
I went here last week with a friend. 

The food was great ! Delicious really. Not a complaint. We split the asparagus with prosciutto (YUM), I had a pulled pork sammie (YUM) and the friend had a salmon sammie, which I did not try. But our beers were good - not sure if we picked the right ones for the food choices, but yummy nonetheless.

We also managed to arrive exactly 5 minutes before everyone else - we had speedy and quick service! 

I took a star away because of the following: I realize it's a beer-haven but I don't know the first thing about beer. The server was so unhelpful, unfriendly. I knew that may be the case going in - so I am not too perturbed. I just wish he had helped me pick out a cool beer - or at least learn a little. Maybe next time I'll just bring someone savvy.
author: Kristine R.

description: The selection of beers is fantastic. The grain/chickpea burger was very good, it reminded me of a falafel a little bit, but thats good. The place was so crowded I didnt think we would ever get a table, but they had one ready right away. The waiters should get double pay for how they have to work through that crowd just to get orders to the tables. Monks Kettle is a must go if you like everything thats good and cold brewed.
author: Gregory R.

description: I disagree with the post that the new menu is not good.  I went last night with my friend and the food was even better then the last.  More sophisticated, better paired with the beer...wider seafood selection.  Had the dungeness risotto, cornmeal oysters and mussels.  The mussels are the BEST I have ever had in the city.  Amazing.  And the service was outstanding.
author: Jaemi S.

description:
Call it similar to a beer garden. The servers act as sommeliers, they know their extensive beer menu. It's one of the most distinct beer menus in San Francisco, and for a light beer drinker like me who has friends who drink A LOT, it fits everyone. 
The inside of the Monk's Kettle reminds me of a pub scene of Harry Potter (that's the best example I could give you) Maybe it's because we went in when it was raining... but very much a pub of men and women drinking around a warm cozy wooden atmosphere. 
Now the food.. it what gets you. There are tons of bars around San Francisco, half of which serve food. Than out of those half only a third is good with another third being fried. The Monk's Kettle WINS BIG. Their farm to table aspect mirrors much like Town Hall Restaurant in the inner city. The charcuterie and cheese plate is the best mix I've had for bread and cheese... the cheese menu changes for what is in season, so does the charcuterie.. It's served with toasted nuts, house jam which is amazing, house mustard that tastes much like a dijon, and acme bread. So yummy!
We also had a small plate of the mussels, mixed in Belgian Ale, garlic and basil and again served with that delicious bread. The servers a re great, well traveled, we could have conversations about anywhere! 
I'll be back here so many times now.
author: Jacqueline L.

description:
Oh my goodness, how have I not gone to this place till just a few weeks ago? It's quickly become a weekly haunt.

They've got the most amazing selection of beers I've probably ever seen.  Though a handful of other places have more beers, the sheer variety of specialty and microbrews here is phenomenal.  They have a bunch of beers on tap that change regularly (daily?) and then a very large selection of bottled beers.  Occasionally, they even have a cask ale which is what I had the first time I went and I wish more people would order it so they would always have it.  If you've never had cask conditioned ales, you've never had beer the way it should be drunk.  Probably the best thing about the place is the amazing amount of stuff the bartenders know about the beers they have (and even about many they don't carry).  They are truly beer connoisseurs.

[As an aside, one of the many beers I've now tried there and have fallen in love with is Brother Thelonious Abbey Ale from North Coast Brewery.  I suggested a couple of non-beer drinkers to try this beer and they also loved it.  The point is, even if you think you're not a beer lover, come try out something here and you'll be a convert very quickly.]

Oh, and how can I forget the food.  Even if it's just the fries or giant pretzel that are perfectly salted and paired with great dipping sauces to complement many beers, or the excellent mac and cheese (one of the better ones in the city) or the vegan chili, their food is pretty damn good.  Each food item, as appropriate for a place like this, has a beer pairing or two to go with it and some are dead nuts on.

I intend to come back here on a regular basis to try every beer they offer.  I expect it to take years and look forward to it.
author: Anand M.

description: I ordered sparkling wine. I'm gluten free and they mostly have beer. They have a decent wine selection but I prefer sparkling. After a few drinks I decided to try the sorghum beer (gluten free). I didn't like it and the waiter was very nice about bringing me another champagne instead. Their customer service was very warm, attentive and casual. I didn't get to try the food though I would like to sometime. For cozy and fun ambiance.
author: Addie S.

description: Came here based on a recommendation as a place to try the bread pudding.  It was great and loved that they have Pliny the Elder on tap.  Great place if you are a beer fan.  Staff has always been great and happy to help seek out a new ale to fit your mood and likes.  Returned for dinner with friends and was not disappointed.  Rich dishes good for accompanying your beer or ale of choice.  A bit pricey but fun to splurge a little and try some of the larger bottled brandywine and ales.
author: Andre D.

description:
I came here with the most bougie of beer drinkers, one who makes his own beer, and my cousin who is the most picky beer drinker around.

So coming here, I felt strange saying "oh I just want a Sierra Neveda."   haha.   

Our waitress had tons of beer knowledge, and pretty much tasted everything on the menu.   Even with the place packed at 7, she was very attentive and took lots of time to explain everything to us.

I ate;

- Fried Goat cheese with brushetta side 
- Veggie burger w/swiss and Grilled onions with Fries
- Pinapple bread pudding with ice cream on top

Everything was delicious, but the bread pudding was something you have to have a knack for.  I dugg it because it offsetted the dark beer. 

Also, I had a Ca IPA and a 12% beer, for the life of me cant remember the name, I will update this after I check the PDF!  

Prices are on the high side, but for the quality and selection that comes with it, its worth it.   Just come here early, unless you like to stand allllll night long!
author: ankur v.

description:
I'm leaving the city (gasp!) and before I go I wanted to bust out my organizational skills and figure out how many things from 7x7's list of 100 things to try in SF I could cross off in one day. Given the finite nature of the stomach, I opted to make this particular day's tour a bar-focused adventure (which, in retrospect was maybe not so wise). I knew it would take punctuality, skill, willpower and plenty of cab fare, but I had my trusty winglady with me and I believed we could do it! 

Stop #1: The Monk's Kettle for a giant pretzel with mustard.

What better way to start a day of drinking than with a giant pretzel? 

It really was a delicious pretzel but what I think was most noteworthy about this place was that it is a beer lover's FANTASY. The beer menu was several pages long and I picked it up and kinda prentended to read it but maaaaaaaaaaaaaan, it would have taken hours to figure out what I'd like so I saved myself the effort and asked the bartender for recommendations. 

He gave me two of the cutest little teeny small sample steins to taste and I think I was influenced by the hardcore beer atmosphere or something because I decided on one the bartender called "sour" but lemme tell you -- it tasted like I was drinking fish and chips with a dash of malt vinegar. 

Fish and chips that was served in a wine glass. 

Except I'm sure that a true beer drinker would roll their eyes and tell me that what I'm calling a "wine glass" is actually something very German and technical or whatever, but AT LEAST I DIDN'T WALK IN AND ORDER A CORONA, OKAY? 

Overall, I'd say this place is great for beer drinkers, pretzel lovers and appreciators of clean bathrooms.
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
Oh, yeah. My dreams come true. 

All the beers of the world, even those ones produced by a lonely Belgian monk in his lonely cave after 5 years in the dark are here! Yess. And the food is tasty too.  

Of course many people know this too and is frequently crowded.
author: Javi V.

description:
Monk's Kettle has probably one of the most diverse and comprehensive beer lists I've ever seen - I hadn't even heard of half the beers on the menu.   The food is more or less upscale pub grub, but the burger that I had hit the spot and - of course - matched my beer nicely.  They also do a pretty wicked giant-cookie-in-a-skillet with ice cream for dessert.   

My only complaint?  This place gets PACKED.  I went on a Saturday night with 5 others and ended up feeling like a human tetris block.   If you go for dinner during the rush, be prepared to have a couple of cocktails at Delirium next door while you wait.   I'll try to come back, but maybe during off hours during the week ...
author: Chung Y.

description: The Bavette steak was so good! And I rarely eat beef. The brussel sprout gratin was delicious as well as their dessert. Will definitely be going back.
author: Rebecca M.

description:
"DUDE, WE DON'T SERVE LIQUOR!"

So shouted the cute, pony-tailed, and dare I say docile bartender over my head, to the guy behind me as I sat at the bar with a couple friends.

Woah, right?

Well, at first I was thrown. So I asked the bartender, basically, "wtf?!" Turns out the guy standing behind me was aggressively trying to order over the people next to me, refused to look at a menu, and was being an overall jerk. And then he ordered a vodka gimlet. So I think the bartender's reaction was warranted. Once the guy left, the bartender went back to being his chill, smiling self. 

Overall, I liked this place. I will definitely return. My friends and I went in on a Friday night around 10 for drinks. The waiters/bartenders are essentially beer sommeliers, so I let our waiter (not the pony-tailed bartender) pick something for me. What was I in the mood for? "Oh, I dunno... something rich, smokey... " 

"I have the perfect beer."

He didn't even let me finish throwing out adjectives. In face, he seemed almost snobby. And yet he came back with an La Fin Du Monde, and it was exactly what I was looking for. 

Good job.
author: Tara B.

description: OHEMGEE mustard is so good here. As are their fries. The fries + mustard = heavenly.
author: Joyce S.

description:
Monk's Kettle is a great place to grab a casual, reasonably priced but high quality meal. When this place first opened, I had no interest in going because I thought it was just another mission beer bar...but then a friend clued me into the fact that they served food too, so I checked out the menu online and I was in!

I was worried about a long wait because my friend wasn't able to brave through the 1.5 hour wait on a Saturday night! Tonight was Tuesday, and we showed up around 7 pm...there was plenty of room at the bar,  but we decided to wait for a table, which only took about 20 minutes. We got some fries and a Magner's at the bar...the fries were a generous portion, served with two types of sauce. 

Then I had the ahi tuna sandwich and my BF had the bleu cheese flank steak sandwich. We subbed salads for fries, but it was just a bunch of mixed greens with hardly any dressing. The mains were really good for both of us, though...my sandwich had a nice, generous, very fresh tasting cut of perfectly seared fish in it...it was light and not too filling, although it looked big...the taste kind of reminded me of sushi, but in a sandwich form!

Service was good, especially for the mission which, in my opinion, is where you will most likely see some of the worst service in the whole city (people will eat there anyways so they don't have to up the ante). I would love to try the black bean cakes or the vegan chili at a later date...but like I said, my advice is to avoid going on the weekend, and they don't take reservations!
author: Shannon R.

description:
Finally a decent pub in the WHOLE BAY AREA!  Since moving here from Boston (a REAL beer connoisseurs paradise), I've yet to discover a nice pub to eat at with good pub food and a challenging tap list! 

 I spoke with the owners of this place when they first opened and I guess they lived in Boston for a while themselves and are familiar with the benchmark for quality pub food and a SERIOUS tap list, the Sunset Grill and Tap in Allston (110 taps, 400 bottles). 

I'm glad they have come out to the bay area to provide a bit of pub/beer education to this city and to show an area inundated with wine bars another path of flavors in the varieties and complexities of quality tap beer.  Good stuff guys.  Keep up the tap rotation and the great menu!
author: David M.

description:
Definitely not a place to drain a Coors Light and then smash the can on your forehead! 

Very tiny and popular place - one hour wait to get in on a Saturday night. A bit of a scene, but with enough Mission grit to keep it real. The doorman was very cool - when I didn't hear him call my cell as we were shooting pool in the bar across the street, he ran across the street to let us know to come over in about 10 minutes. He also lent me his jacket when I was outside - such a gentleman! 

Beer list - extensive and oh so educational. And every beer has its own special glass. Only domestics you can find here are microbreweries, and the beers are quite pricey. The waitstaff are friendly and quite knowledgeable and you can always taste a beer before committing. 

Food is good - charcuterie plate is so awesome, we had a second round. Excellent meats - salame, sausage, duck, prosciutto - and they are happy to bring you extra toasted bread if you need. I do love them tiny pickles! The pumpkin-sage gnocchi was a nice seasonal touch and flavorful but a bit too sweet for me. Mac and cheese was muy bueno with some bacon. But isn't everything better with bacon?? 

I'm glad we went and I will definitely go back!
author: Sarah S.

description:
It's tough for me to complain about any pub that serves Pliny the Elder, but it sucks to have to pay over $7 to enjoy a pint. Especially when Toronado is slangin Pliny for under $5 last time I checked. A saving grace is that the pint is 20 ounces, British style. 

The fries are delicious and come with curry aioli, herb aioli and chipotle ketchup, all of which are pretty good. At $5 dollars for a rather large basket, these fries are a steal.
author: Adam L.

description:
Gourmet pub-grub and comfort food with a beer list that comes on a clipboard.  Seriously, a freaking tome of beers, and all the menu items come with suggested "beer pairings."  The staff are all exceptionally knowledgeable about all the beers in-house, and can give you info, recommendations and even tastes of all the different beers so that you're sure to get a brew that's just right for you.

That being said, I went here for lunch, and my friend and I didn't WANT beer.  We were nervous that it might turn into a "No beer?  NO SOUP FOR YOU!!" type beer-nazi moment, but our server was happy to offer us a host of non-alcholic drinks and make pairing recommendations based on our orders.  (I had ginger beer, which wasn't dark like ginger beer should be, more like a ginger lager, and A had root beer).  My pulled-pork sandwich was excellent, and the chicken sandwich I had the last time I was there was also very good.  The folks next to us had burgers, and dang they smelled great.

If you are a beer connoisseur, you definitely need to check this place out.  Or if you are in the 'hood and want some high-quality comfort food (I hear the mac and cheese is the bomb), check this place out.

Really, just check this place out.  The beer pairing idea alone makes Monk's Kettle a unique dining experience.
author: Kevin H.

description: Went out late with a friend and surprisingly we had a hard time finding something good to eat. Another restaurant we stopped into but, was closing for the night recommended trying Monk's Kettle and said it was open late. We were not disappointed, had a great arugula salad and burger, both were fresh and tasty and the beer list is impressive. Definitely will go again when in San Fran.
author: Keith H.

description: Service= awesome. Atmosphere= pleasant. This place is small but the service, is great! They act as if you're their most important table. Server was great, suggested beer to my personal tastes and paired to be with my dinner choice. Dessert was amazing, we got the dark chocolate bread pudding and it tasted just like a warm, soft brownie, delicious! Definitely a return-to place!!!
author: Vanessa M.

description:
One of the better beer venues I've been to, with very intelligent and knowledgeable staff. I was looking for something "interesting," not smoke-beer interesting, but something you wouldn't expect out of a beer. Our waiter recommended a Flanders Belgian Brown Ale which uses a wild yeast and tastes something like a used sock mixed with sourdough. Surprisingly delicious, and well above my interesting mark. He recommended 4 beers, all unknown winners.

I will be going back for sure.
author: Cameron M.

description: This place is simply amazing!  I went here with my girlfriend and everything we ordered was delicious.  The Monk's Kettle has a very extensive beer list that comes with great descriptions and facts about each type of beer, which made the whole experience of choosing the right one even more enjoyable.  The restaurant itself is small, but has a very nice vibe and is very "Mission".  It was so much fun to go eat great food and people watch. I will definitely be coming back here!
author: Ben G.

description: Probably too many beers to choose from! We all liked the beers we selected, but I think the food might have tasted better! Wow, that was some delicious risotto; the burger was great with a nice char to it; fries crispy, but a little on the salty side; apparently kale salad was a winner too, as was the special of the day, a short rib plate. We even enjoyed dessert. Waitstaff accommodating and helpful. Speaking of wait, we didn't have a reservation, and the place is so tiny, that even with a small party, you might be quoted a wait of almost two hours on a Sunday night! Thank goodness for their open bar seating, which is half this tiny restaurant. Oh yeah, parking is a %$*&.
author: Cara K.

description:
Monk's Kettle combines one of the city's best beer selections with exceptionally tasty food. Favourites include the pulled pork (so good, a rabbi would eat it), the veggie burger and the baked cookie.

The staff's knowledge of the beers is comprehensive if not exhaustive, and they're happy to share it with you in a welcoming, genuine and never condescending manner.

They lose one star for (a) being too pricy and (b) being too small. Sometimes, you simply can't get in (or can't get a seat). But everything else  is so good, I keep coming back.
author: Paul S.

description:
Monk's is nestled at the corner of 16th and Albion, a little alley that share's it's name with the town where my dad had a place called Joe's Garage.  Well, at least I won't forget where it is.

One of the fortuitous elements of a corner location is that Monk's has plenty of windows and window seating.  An especially positive feature since I was there after knocking off work early on SF's sunniest day of the year so far.  A relatively narrow place, the long side borders Albion Street and is lined with booths.  The interior wall houses a long wooden bar with hooks underneath for purses and backpacks.  My drinking companion, however, scored what appeared to be the lone table for two right next to a window on 16th.

The bartender greeted us friendly and passed us some menus and the waitress followed up quickly.  The menu was *quite* extensive -- reminded me of the wine list and Rubicon both in terms of quantity and price.  To avoid information overload, we stuck to the beers on tap, which were in the neighborhood of a dozen.  The waitress was quite knowledgeable, asked about our taste preferences, and suggested beers my friend and I found quite pleasing.

Unfortunately, all too soon, the good waitress came by to report that she was leaving and another waitress would be taking here place.  And, yes, you guessed it -- a case of good waitress, bad waitress.  The new one was perfunctory at best and lacked any sort of good humor or warmth.  Fortunately, we were well happy with our beers and pretzel (a behemoth served with an excellent mustard and another dipping sauce I didn't taste) and decided to note the quality disparity in waitresses here on Yelp and not let it drag us down.  Thankfully, the bad waitress must of realized she was persona non grata at our table and the remainder of our stay was served by the friendly, bearded bartender who even put in a good word for me with my lady friend.  Thanks mate!

We had arrived earlyish, maybe 5 or so, but by 6p Monk's was filling up and it was standing room only.  After a couple of jostles, bumps, and excuse me's, we decided bid Monk's adieu and head out into waning sunlight.

All in all, Monk's is nice place that fits in the gap between a bar and a restaurant.  I'll definitely go back, earlyish in the day to avoid the noise and crowds.
author: Tom Y.

description:
Monk's Kettle is The Place to take a beer lover. Their selection of brews is vast and tasty. It's certainly the best burger and beer spot in the Mission. I realized this after engulfing myself face with a Niman Ranch burger. It was really a gastronomic dream come true.

The details in M.K. are very cute. You can sample beer in tiny glasses and there's even a small blackboard in the back area for those who love to doodle whilst waiting for grub/beer.

The wait staff is knowledgeable, but I've found their attitudes hit & miss. Nonetheless, I shall return. Great job!
author: Tim B.

description:
Great beer selection!!! That alone is worth the trip.

Decent wine options including by the glass or half bottles as I remember.

Didn't have to wait too long for table for two on a Thursday night, pleasant surprise.

Food was good, nothing overly memorable but had nice leisurely conversation with a friend and didn't feel rushed. 

I would come back & highly recommend (& have recommended) to beer connoisseurs.
author: Abby W.

description:
This beer selection is simply out of control. I first read about this place in the SF Guardian and had to check it out since it wasn't far from my place. It doesn't stand out from the exterior, just a very small wooden sign hangs outside the door on the corner of Albion and 16th, but the inside is quite different from the neighborhood dive bars. Very clean, stylish interior with an amazing carved wooden bar. 

I don't care what you say about gentrification, there are enough places with Journey on the jukebox that smell like piss an spilled Bud Light if that's your thing. I'd welcome a few more Monk's Kettle type places into any neighborhood. Here's why:

Despite having so many beers from around the world, the bar staff is surprisingly not at all pretentious. The are amazing friendly in helping you pick the right beer, offering samples of what's on tap, and giving pointers on how to enjoy each beer with its unique glass, etc. There is also very good food to snack on while enjoying a usually pretty high-alcohol content beer.

They even have a large chalkboard area at the bar stools in the back where you can sketch out whatever random thoughts are in your head as you slip into drunken splendor.

I think the prices max out with the one-ounce pour of Sam Adams Utopias for $25, which is just silly. At the other end of the spectrum, you can get a PBR or Tecate for $2.50, but the real good ones lie somewhere in the middle. I had a very unique rye beer on tap that was 11% ABV and certainly got the night rolling. I also enjoyed trying a few of the Belgium selections poured in their unique glasses and chatting with the bartender about which ones she preferred.

It does get pretty crowded, so not a great place for groups of more than 3 or 4, but service is still pretty fast.
author: Chris P.

description:
Great beer and service, pretty good food.

First, I love that they will call you on your cell phone when your table's ready.  We went over to Blondies for a drink while we waited.  That is a GREAT service given that the waits can get lengthy.  We were told it would be 1 - 1.5 hour wait for a table, but in reality it was only about 30 minutes.

The beer list was awesome, of course.  Loved the locally brewed Squid Ink "black IPA," of which the waiter kindly offered me a taste before I committed.  Nice!  My dining companions are beeries and they were highly impressed with the selection.

The service was friendly and fast.  We were not at all bothered by the "hipster attitude" that some other reviewers are complaining about.  In fact, I think it's some of the best front-of-house and table service I've experienced in SF.  If I had to nitpick, I'd say the waiter could have toned down the technicality of his beer explanations a bit (yes, yes ... we know you are an expert).  But I'm really stretching to find something NOT to rave about.

Now for the food.  The menu is great and we were all basically happy with our selections, but all four of us found our dishes somewhat over-salted.  The meat and chicken were all perfectly cooked and the accompaniments were well done, but it's the saltiness that's preventing me from going all in with five stars.  Over salting food is the sign of an unconfident or inexperienced cook -- it's kind of a shame that the food doesn't live up to the high standards of the beer experience.

One other minor quibble -- we were seated next to two women that were entirely too drunk -- to the point were they were having trouble eating -- and yet the waiter kept bringing them drinks.  Not cool.

That said, we all agreed that we would go back soon!  Unlike some other reviewers here, we thought that the prices were in line with the service and quality.  Moreover, if you liked the food (as most reviewers appear to have), then why complain about the prices when you can clearly check them out before choosing to eat here?   This restaurant is a big asset to the Valencia corridor.
author: Roger S.

description: This place is the Father's Office aka FO of nor cal.  The beer selection is massive.  -1 star for no brown ale on tap and a lamb burger that tasted like vietnamese meatballs.  Those artificial round balls you get with yer pho.  NaStaY.  The pretzel was pretty good here.  The cheese sauce put it over the top.  The ground mustard was really good.  The duck pate plate was also very good.  I'm not a liver fan but smearing it over a smoked cured sausage is amazing.  I would go back if this place was bigger in size.  This place won't fit fat people.  Thats why I had to order take out.
author: Fatty A.

description:
What an amazing beer selection! I love beer and this place had stuff I had never heard of-and was very excited to try. The bartender was really sweet and let me have a few samples before I committed to a beer. They are a little on the pricey side, but its worth it if you're going to savor flavors.

The staff is friendly and we received excellent service. When it came time to order I almost went for the pulled pork sandwich, which looked delicious. Upon speaking with the waitress, I went for the hamburger with bacon and grilled onions. And was as satisfied as one can get with a meal.
author: Analisa S.

description: Very long and unpredictable wait time. Mildly pretentious staff. But our server was kind and knowledgable. Don't bring friends who don't love beer because they will think you are nuts for buying a $15 beer. Definitely try the pretzels and be prepared to pay a lot for stuff. One person in the group got the veggie bean burger, everyone else felt pity for her. Other food was really yummy and went well with the beers.
author: Jo H.

description:
Really swell place.  Cozy and casual with neat design and decor.  Heck, there's a built-in chalk board around one of the seating areas for your doodling pleasure.

Great, grubby food with a fresh, gourmet twist.  My burger was splendid.  And I don't even eat burgers.
author: Rashi D.

description:
We had a GREAT experience here.  

It was extremely crowded and definitely hopping (got there at about 9 p.m. on a Sat), but we managed to squeeze into the back at the counter and received prompt service, LOVED reviewing the amazing beer list (it's about time there's a good place like this in SF...I don't think toronado has as many belgians.), savored some fabulous brews, and had two very yummy, properly sized, beautifully presented appetizers (black bean cakes & the bruschetta).  

This is a great place to really savor and enjoy some amazing beers (or two, or three) and have a few snacks with a friend who appreciates good beer.  It's definitely lively/loud/festive...so a good, decently energized place that's fun.  Also has a nice, modern interior with a few elements of character (marble booth backs that look like recycled stairs).  Not a place for groups - just too narrow/small and i think trying to wait for a table would test anyone's patience.
author: Nancy R.

description:
We got here around 7pm and got seats at the bar. The staff was fantastic, the food even better! I can't wait to go back... 
Just 4 stars for it being elbow to elbow at certain points during our dinner.
author: katrine n.

description:
It used to be that Toronado would be the ultimate beer destination in SF. Yet every time I go there lately the beer selection seems smaller, the douchebag quotient higher and the ability to sit and chill with a tasty beer diminished.

Thank god for the Monk's Kettle. It has to be said that we've been trying to go here for ages, but every time we stop by the wait for a table is edging an hour. Last night though, with our later arrival and the Mission relatively deserted, we were able to ban a table in less than a couple of minutes. 

I'm firmly of the belief that a Yelp review starts with five stars and loses from there, as opposed to working up from zero. In this case, there just didn't seem to be any reason to deduct anything. From the moment we arrived and the door guy did his best to get us a table (agreeing to seat us at the bar and move us when a table opened) to the warm greeting from the beer-mad server guy, the level of quality was consistently high.

Of course the beer selection is amazing, but any beer geek can rent a space and fill it with saison, rauschbier, dunkels and imperial IPAs. It's what you do with that space that counts, and in this case the approach is to hire friendly, knowledgeable staff and crank out terrific food.

The steak and fries were bloody terrific, amongst the best steak-frites-type dish I can remember having in SF (and a dish that I think can immediately separate a decent restaurant from the crowd). The beer was lovely, in my case a Franziskaner Dunkelweiss  for the main course and Youngs Double Chocolate Stout for dessert.

My main recommendation is to go when it's not busy, so that you can truly savour the awesomeness without being irritated by a wait.
author: Neil S.

description:
Its open! What a great selection of beer and food. A truly unique addition to the 16th street mission scene. I hope they find the right niche of patrons.

The owners poured a lot of hard work into this place. Support local owners by coming here for great times.

Tonight, Dec 19th, we're showing them our love by having a big opening party!
author: Shane W.

description:
Giant pretzel + cheese dippin' sauce = YES.

Delicious, great beer selection. A little crowded, but...oh well.
author: P R.

description:
I struggled a bit with this place.  I wanted to _really_ like it, but a bunch of little things marred it for me.

The beer selection, especially the bottle list, is extensive.  Prices are a real crapshoot, though.  $3.50 for a glass of Dogfish Head Punkin isn't bad, but $13 for 8 ounces of Kwak?  I know the glass is cool, but come on!  I didn't find their draught list particularly inspiring, either.

The food is similarly confounding.  The portions they give are perfectly fine, and the flavors are by and large pretty good, but again ... that dollar sign kind of lays it all flat.  My $14 bruschetta (at $7 per 5-inch piece) wasn't either plentiful or particularly inspired, and the $5 basket of frites was a bit greasy.  No real complaints about the service, though.

Overall, slightly disappointing, but certainly still perfectly okay.  It'd be a 4-star joint if they dropped their prices by about a third across the board.  And fergawdssakes, they've got to find someone who isn't on ass crack to price the beer list.
author: Susuk L.

description:
I went here after reading the review that they have a frickin awesome pretzel. And it is darn good. (Actually, I'd contend that it isn't really the best pretzel itself- it's a sinfully good cheese sauce that tops it over the edge. For the absolute best pretzel in this country, my vote goes to the Carmel Bakery in ... duh, Carmel CA). But I digress. And to stop with the apps would be a crime. 

I had a special- an aaaaabbbbbsooooluuuuuutely aaaaaahhhmazing scallop pot pie. Perfect crust. Delectable cream sauce. Scallops actually cooked perfectly. Oh so tasty. 

I'm not the hugest beer fan, but I do appreciate a good variety, and that they have. To counter that, I was happy to see that this wasn't just your usual pub fare (though that they have too- including nice crisp fresh thin cut fries)- I am anxiously awaiting returning to try one of their awesome sounding salads. 

A note: this place is NOT big, and gets crowded. Also, my man said his burger was good, but not 5-star good, so maybe not everything on the menu is as totally awesome as what I've had.
author: Kristen L.

description:
Tried the lamb burger and fries, as well as the mac & cheese.  The mac and cheese was excellent, the lamb burger merely good.
