The beers were awesome.  An American farmhouse style beer and a Tripel from Belgium.

Knowledgeable staff.  Nice vibe.  If only the wait for a table was shorter....
author: Aaron T.

description:
Pluses: 

- The beer list. Long. Expensive. Expansive. Niche.
- Pretzels. I hate pretzels, and they had a great pretzel, with that wonderful spicy brown mustard.
- Mac and Cheese. Done their way. Awesome.
- Wonderful chicken sandwich.

Minuses (Or a plus depending on how you look at it):

- Not easy to find. It's in the mission, which means most tourists won't find it. 
- Always crowded, even in the afternoon.
author: Patrick N.

description:
After attempting to eat here about four times and opting not to on account of  long wait time, I finally got to have dinner at the Monk's Kettle.

I ordered the salmon sandwich, and I gotta be honest- not so great. But really- who orders the salmon sandwich when are things like a giant pretzel with dipping sauce on the menu?

The ladies sitting next to me were eating what I SHOULD have ordered : the mac n' cheese. It looked amazing, and from the sounds of other yelpers it sho' is.

And yeah- the beer selection can't be beat. The atmosphere makes you feel all cool n' shit. This place is great, and I hope it lasts longer than that random japanese place did before it.
author: Amanda D.

description:
Great restaurant! 6 page beer menu, delicious burgers and fries, super friendly service and, the best thing, clean bathrooms!

Only negative is that it's always busy because it's very small.  Ate at 4pm and there was still a 30 min wait.
author: thao t.

description:
monk...i wish i knew how to quit you....

gorge:
ribs
andouille sausage pot pie
author: Jane L.

description:
I heart coffee porter!

and The Monk's Kettle!

it's about time.
author: Brandi H.

description:
I'm only rating Monk's Kettle in terms of the food (although for all of their beer selection they didn't have the one Lambic Belgium beer that I wanted).
Salad and Burger were average at best, but the Oatmeal cookie dessert in the cast iron pan was Really Good!
author: eric a.

description:
Good quality food, extensive beer selection, and lively atmosphere, not a bad place to be.

Beyond delicious pretzels, but I must mention that we were given 1 serving portion of both mustard sauce and cheese sauce for two pretzels, then when we ordered three pretzels later on, were only given one sauce of each total.  Since there wasn't enough sauce to go around, we asked for additional sauce and were told it was going to be an additional $0.50.  Fine, $0.50 but when you are charging me $15 for a bottle of Tripel Karmeleit that costs half that at the Trappist in Oakland, why can't one give an appropriate ration of sauce for the pretzels?  All of at the table were annoyed at the $0.50 charge when they had given more sauce initially, then did not give an equal amount later.  We joked that from then on we would just order one pretzel at a time, but I think that we should leave that restaurant talking about the great food, good beer, not how they inconsistently rationed sauce and then charged us $0.50 for what should have been included according to their earlier rations.

Besides the sauce rationing mentioned above, the pretzels themselves were very good and just baked.  The Three day ale bricked chicken, cranberry beans, and harissa dinner was quite good, flavorful and cooked just right.

The beer selection is great, and definitely our server was well versed in beer/dinner pairings, and his knowledge of the beers and details of certain breweries was impressive.  I did not realize that the Tripel Karmeleit was one that I have enjoyed a few times at the Trappist in Oakland, so when it came to the table, was surprised that I'm paying a bit more than twice as much as the other establishment, but I had ordered it, so I enjoyed it.

I just will now read the menu a lot more carefully,  but am still impressed with the selection and would return for the food and drink.  It can get a bit crowded, but I can deal for the food.
author: Miss C.

description:
I'll be the first to admit that MK has a significant and impressive selection of beer.  The beer menu is several pages long and lists beer from around the world.  The problem is not with the selection of beer.

The problem is, if it's to call itself a 'gastropub' the food menu ought to be more than a page long.  It was disappointingly short and the selections pedestrian (consisting mostly of burgers, chicken sandwiches, and salads).  What we did order was prepared in the same fashion that I'd find in hundreds of other pubs throughout the Bay area.

It's a nice little local bar and is cozy (to put it nicely) with a good atmosphere. If I lived in the Mission I could see myself occasionally stopping by.  But travel across the city to come here?  Not worth it in my opinion.
author: K. B.

description:
Huh. I'm amazed at the number of reviews that cite bad service. Granted, I came in sorta early on Saturday, like 7pm or so, but I found the service to be unusually warm and attentive. Maybe they read Yelp and are changing their tune.

I walked into the Monk's Kettle with my sister, and we were told we'd have a 20 minute wait. We hung out in the jammed front area for, like, half a minute before the bartender told us there was a spacious area in the back where we could hang out and read the menu while we were waiting to sit. Then he came over and helped us with our beer selection. Frankly, and I don't mean to judge, but you'd have to be the most retardedly ersatz-ironic hipster on the planet to order a PBR here. You can get delicious beer of many stripes, and I don't even like beer all that much.

The food's all high-quality pub fare, made with Niman Ranch meat, and I enjoyed my lovely burger immensely. It came with perfect steak-fries, and the waitress was totally cool with our many questions about dairy and mayonnaise (my sister and I are allergic to all SORTS of things). 

I generally have a pretty low opinion of Bay Area restaurants and, especially, service, so high marks from me are hard to come by. I had a great time at Monk's Kettle and have already made plans to return with pals, so I hope they keep up the good work. 

Oh, and the PRETZEL!! I think it might come as a surprise to people who aren't used to the big, soft pretzels you get on the streets of New York. We'd been missing those terribly, and the Monk's Kettle's version was totally perfect.
author: Amy K.

description:
Amazing beer selection and super-helpful server. She steered me away from a poor beer choice, which I really appreciated.

If we had just been there for beer, my review would have easily been five stars.

However....

If you plan to eat, you better prepare your budget ahead of time.

I appreciate a good meal and am willing to spend on a nice night out, but I was not ready for the prices at Monk's Kettle.  Maybe that's my bad.

My wife had an Iceberg wedge salad with bacon and blue cheese dressing for $11.  Then she added steak on the side for an additional $8.  I don't mean to sound cheap, but $19 for iceberg lettuce drowning in dressing with a few slices of steak on the side was a bit much.

I had the pulled pork sandwich, which was good, but not $12 good.

So, just a warning about the prices.  Otherwise, a wonderful experience.
author: Aaron C.

description:
I've eaten here three times.  They have an extensive & expensive beer selection and okay food. It's basically bar food with few unexciting twists.  I like the atmosphere at the Monk's kettle.  It's bustling, but it's not crazy loud.  

The service is friendly, but every time I've eaten here it's been slow. The server is trying to work too many tables at once.  I'm not sure if that's their choice or the owner's, but it definitely takes away from what could be a better experience.  

Over all I think the Monk's kettle is definitely worth trying.  However, after three average dining experiences, I'll more than likely never go back.
author: Antichris E.

description: Beer selection is still great, but the food has dropped off. Gone is the big pretzel, replaced with the microwaved knot of dough. Gone too the flank steak, now a tiny nugget of steak with a higher price point. What happened?
author: Gym W.

description: Good food selections.  The menu offers a nice variety of good food that pairs well with most of the beers on draft.  The beer selection is respectable and offers a nice variety of craft beers among their selections.  My only drawback was this place is a bit pricey.  However, given the quality of the food and beer I believe it is still worth a visit.
author: Ken S.

description:
I don't know much about beer, but my boyfriend introduced me to a lot of Belgium beers and I realy like them. 

Great selection on beer, over 134 kinds. 
I only tried the chicken sandwich and that was delicious, 2 slices of brie and 2 slices of bacon. 

It is a small place and it's only been open for 2 months, but so refreshing for the mission.
author: Judi K.

description:
I'm generally not a cervesa girl, but I decided to grin and beer it (sorry), because friends wanted to try this place.

Cool atmosphere; definitely a place you can bring people to. 
Amazing and extensive beer selection, including funky Belgian ones served in their own, eclectic beer bongs. Prices on the steep side, though.

And the pretzel was just too damn expensive, outshone by the stone ground mustard. We also tried the charcuterie and it was nice, but the beers are definitely the reason for the visit.

Minor vent--although the wines by the glass were delicious, particularly the S African Grootboom (sp?), those damn pours were on the skimpy side. I know it's only $7/a glass, but c'mon people. It's a bar.
author: Kathleen G.

description:
I'm perched on a barstool, drinking a tasty Belgian ale, talking to a friend, and patiently waiting for my table. A shockingly loud voice shouts near my ear but at the bartender:
- "Dude, gimme a Pauwel Kwak and a Hetch Hetchy"

The bartender, incredibly friendly and patient despite having to deal directly with the hordes waiting for tables that are crowded around the bar, smiles and replies:
- "Sure thing. No problem on the beer, but what was that other part?"

The loud voice next to my ear replies:
- "A Hetch Hetchy"

The bartender, cocks his head, smiles again and says:
- "I'm sorry, I don't know what that is."

The loud voice replies:
-  "Water dude, I want a glass of water. Y'know, Hetch Hetchy, that's where the water's from."
and turns to his friends, laughing like he is funnier than George Carlin.

The above story is a strong reason to not got to Monk's Kettle. The crowd is a mix of drunk after-work bar boys and couples on awkward dates with more than a little pretension and cluelessness.

There are however, many reasons TO go - 

Tasty food (though portions are small so it won't fill you up, and everything costs $1-2 more than it should)

Incredible beer, they even had a Belgian bottled beer that shares my uncommon last name that I've been looking for in San Francisco for 5 years 

The friendliest and most knowledgeable waitress and bartenders I've seen in a loooong time.

Many of their local drafts are available at plenty of other bars in the Mission and beyond for much less than the $6.75 Monk's Kettle is charging. Not sure why they're priced this uncommonly high, but it makes me suspect that I'm also being grossly overcharged for their more unique beers.

It felt a lot like a surcharge, almost a hidden cover charge for the privilege of eating and drinking there. That said, once we were at a table, we could apparently have stayed there, just drinking, for as long as we wanted to.

Clearly from the crowd, no one cares enough to NOT go because of the inflated prices, but I probably won't head back there too quickly. I work for a living and just can't justify paying more than reason (and the more affordable prices at bars in the same area) dictates.
author: Lauren G.

description:
I was included in a business dinner here and so $ was no object. There was an hour wait but they were super cool about taking a cell phone # and calling us when our table was ready, there are 4 bars to chose from while you wait on that block. 

I had the pot pie. It was amazing the waiter gave me the perfect beer pairing.

I tasted everything on the table and found it very much to my liking. 

A tiny place with "san franciscofied" pub fare and full on delicious.
author: kristen l.

description:
Wow, I was here on opening night and have been back at least once a week since.  I pretty much love Monk's Kettle.  I have been waiting to write a review until I could figure out how to put my love into words.  Well, I don't think there are the right words but I will try!

Amazing beer selection, Chef Kevin is a master, service is great (Stephanie and Brad rock).

Go there today.
author: Christie A.

description:
Oh wow....

Beer selection-check!

Classy joint-Check!

FREAKING PRETZELS THE SIZE OF THE MOON with awesome dips-CHECK!

Decent Prices-check!

My husband and I came here -after a friend advised that we do so... and so we did, and it was awesome, we came during the day it wasnt to full which was awesome... when we are in town, you bet your ass we will be back!
author: Erica B.

description:
The Gospel According to Beer. I don't know how an alehouse could get any better. With 6 pages of beer I found myself, for the first time asking, a waitress to give me more time on six separate occasions. After choosing my beer (Moonlight's Death & Taxes) my fiancee asked our waitress for some advice on picking between two IPAs. She received a great story and summation about her choice and we couldn't have been more pleased with the outcome. 

Having read the other reviews here I feel as though some people may have chosen an ale that wouldn't be served by the pint, as our choices were. The nice part about Monk's Kettle is that while the menu is rather short on choices for entrees the food is rather good. I would say great but when I order a pull pork sandwich I am expecting a gritty, slightly spicy sandwich. Now my sandwich was very delicious but not exactly what I was expecting (it was more on the sweet side, which is a way to go but I wasn't expecting it). 

The only reason I am giving this a 4 instead of a five is the setup. A little crowded and there is no way to counter act the cold climate from the constantly opening and closing door. Do not skip The Monk's Kettle. For an area so proud of its history of wine, this oasis of non traditional brews is where its at. I will return with all guests who are interested!
author: Patrick B.

description:
Attention all beer lovers... esp Belgian beer lovers....  YOU MUST STOP BY  THIS PLACE!!!

Need a nice beer after a long day's work?  How about after a crappy Sunday day date and you just need to drink to get through the rest of the date?  Go to the monk's kettle!  You don't have to be a beer aficionado to drink here.  Just ask any of the servers and bartenders here and they'll tell you what's good.  Many many selections of Belgian beers that can make any bad date a ok date.  

They also server food till 1am i believe.  

Over all a great beer place.  Food is really bar food but that's to be expected.  Come early because this place does get packed.
author: Allan T.

description: I dig this place.  It does have a bit of a pretentious vibe in my opinion, but that could be just in my head.  I've eaten here once and drank here twice.  Both food and drink can be pricey, note, can be.  They have an incredibly extensive beer list, larger than the Trappist in Oakland.  There are outrageously priced beers, moderately priced beers, and inexpensive beers from all over the world.  If you're looking for PBR, there is bar next door that will serve you that.  If you're looking for variety (it is the spice of life, after all) Monk's Kettle is a good choice.
author: Laura C.

description: Go for the beer, stay for the pork chop.  Just get there early, because they seem to pride themselves on making people wait.  That's obnoxious, but the beer and the food were anything but.  The beer list is extensive and I had several hearty, delicious brews.  The dinner menu was slightly all over the place and the wait staff was not helpful at giving suggestions.  She was a vegan hipster, so she couldn't eat anything on the menu.  Being able to eat the food on your restaurant's menu seems like a BFOQ, but I'm just an employment lawyer, so what do I know?  In any case, I had the lamb burger which was tasty, but I tried the pork chop a friend ordered and I was uber jealous.  It tasted like buttered bacon.  Even for a calorie conscious gay, it was worth every bite.
author: Oliver M.

description:
My girlfriend and I have kind of made this place our "regular".  The food is pretty good, though the prices are a tad high for what you get. For the price I believe the chef ought to put a little sweat into making an actual crust rather than just placing puff pastry onto their pot pies. They taste good though so I'll probably order it again. 

What we LOVE about this place is their beer selection and fabulous staff. The list is long, the knowledge is vast and the smiles inviting. 

Love it.
author: Shannon A.

description:
Monkey's Uncle? Nosiree, the monk's kettle, i love the name, and the love does not stop there...

This place used to be Kelly's Burgers, which i miss, then turned into this drab pan-thai place that went nowhere. My veg. date and I just went for drinks and appetizers, she had the black bean cakes, which i tasted, they wre served over corn, and has this chili kind of aftertaste, but was delish, i had the fries, which were thin and krispy. The wine and beer list are extensive, and the counter was rather loud, but when is it not? I will be visiting the monk again soon, with a main course in mind...
author: wayne s.

description:
People that tell you that you should go to this bar for their good selection of Belgian beers are lying. Or they're narrowminded. Or both. Monk's Kettle is way less discriminatory than that. They have all styles of beers that I have ever heard of, plus a few that I haven't heard of, all carefully listed in categories and subcategories, with descriptions. And when I say all styles, I mean _all_ styles. Under the compelling header "Grampa's suds" even PBR is listed. Of course, with all the goodness on this menu I can't help but to hope that they'd throw people out if they tried to order PBR, but you have to admire the effort of covering all possible kinds of beer.

So, yeah, you could go here for the Belgian beer (and they do have lots of it!). But then you'd miss out on German smoky beer, Norwegian winter ale, good old English ales, and yummy American beers with unappetizing names. It's damn expensive, but hey, what do you expect from items imported in small quantities. The staff is knowledgeable and will give you taste samples of the draught beers, yay!

If I wasn't so goddamn honest I'd write a bad review of this place to keep you guys out of there, because there's just no way to get in. It's too damn full! 

I had the steak sandwich and the namedropping in the  food description just couldn't leverage the chewy meat. I looked forward to eating french fries with aioli. Unfortunately the ambition of the chef extended to putting herbs or gorgonzola in it, but failed to recognize that garlic is one of the three main ingredients in aioli, and that there should be lots of it. Overall the food wasn't bad, but a bit bland and not up to my expectations for a posh-looking pretentious we-have-more-beers-than-God kind of bar.
author: Lina M.

description:
Don't be foolish enough to eat the beer food at wine prices here. If you want a $12 burger, you're better off at a place that have a menu full of burgers instead of beer. Come here after you've gorged on the cornucopia of cheap eateries around the Mission and spend the rest of your money on quality beers. 

Something about the psuedo-wine bar layout with its cupped candles and IKEA looking furnishings greatly annoys me. If not for the inherited cramped quarters of a hole-in-the-wall lineage, the Kettle rings more true for the Marina than the Mission. But after a good belgian beer your scrutinizing, unflinching vigilance for neighborhood purity will dull and take on a bypartisan stance. Have you ever had a beer that reminds you of tea? How about a beer that tastes like vinegar and you actually enjoy this acquired taste? All the nonsense with the cutesy decor aside, the kettle brims with unique beers you'd be hard pressed to find under one roof anywhere else. 

Pretentious? Yes, this place is pretentious as far as its appearance goes. The beers are of their own rite and remain unmolested by the misguided notions of the head monk. Judge the beers by the contents of their bottles and not by the house in which they are served.  After all, we are beer drinkers, we don't mess around with cuteness, we are about taste, and for a good taste, we're willing to put up with bad taste.   


P.S. if anybody out there knows the owner/abbot, can you please tell him or her to give us what we all expect, a monastery. Cold wet stones and mildewy wood beams. Abbot if you make it happen, I'll come worship more often. Promise.
author: Ji D.

description:
Definitely a great place for beer and good grub with friends. Need to get there early and make sure you're entire party is there otherwise they won't sit you. I suggest if you only have 2 then you could try to squeeze in somewhere at the bar as they are free for all. The host and waitress were very nice though. They really wanna make it work for you but still follow the rules of the house. I understand! I work at a restaurant too!

At our table we had the fried oysters, pickled stuff, burger and fries, flatbread, shrimp wrapped bacon, and daily roast short ribs. The oysters were ok...but I'm not a fan of cornmeal. They did fry it to perfection though so you can still taste the oyster and not just a bunch of fried cornmeal. I didn't eat the pickles stuff but there were some interesting items in there if you like pickled things. The burger was on the cheesy side and I could only managed half without getting a heart attack but yummmmyyy!! And the fries were one of the best I've ever had. I think they called them hop fries! Mmmmm!!! The flatbread was decent. The daily roast melted in your mouth goodness. If you still have room go get they're carrot cake!! OMG! My hey don't put nuts or coconut which is a plus for me but they're cream cheese frosting is light and has just enough flavor to complement the carrot cake like it should. Next time is the bread pudding for sure though.

Oh and the beer!! Chocolate beer is the bomb!!
author: Nikkie P.

description:
I took a friend here for his birthday mainly for the extensive beer list.  The place was small; therefore, the wait list for a table was about an hour, but luckily we grabbed the last two seats at the bar.  

The bartender was friendly and very knowledgeable about the beers.  My friend tried 3 different beers, but the only one I remember is the dessert beer I tasted: Meantime Coffee Porter.  If you love coffee and porters, this is a dream come true; my friend was in heaven with this beer.  I was excited to see they had Beamish since I heard Coors wasn't importing it anymore, but I decided to go with a Hoegaarden to pair with my beer brined pork chop.  

I had a bite of my friend's skirt steak which had a great sauce, but my pork chop was definitely the star player out of our menu items that night.  It was a big pork chop that was tender and cooked to perfection.  My mouth is watering now just thinking about it.  We both cleaned our plates although I did slow down towards the end.  For dessert we tried the chef's choice: poached pears with honey mascarpone and a lavender drizzle.  It wasn't our favorite, but that didn't stop him from finishing the plate.

Overall, it was a great experience.  I can't wait to go back when I'm not driving and try some other beers.
author: Jennifer R.

description: A good place for dinner/drinks. I've only been here a couple of times, but likely will return to check out their other items on the menu. Both the food and service were great!!
author: Annette L.

description:
OK, they have a nice beer menu and know what they are serving, but being a snobby Belgian myself, they will never see me in this place again.
Waaaaay OVERPRICED!!! I know other bars in the city (Tornadoes, City Beer Store) that serve the same and even better beers for a third of the price which sounds more fair to me.

The bartender trying to defend the prices as "that is how expensive they are in Belgium" and "good beer is like a good bottle of wine, expensive"....maybe try something else but you are not comparing apples to monkeys here... 

I hope their food better be amazing and hopefully for FREE :)
author: Tom V.

description:
$8 for a soft pretzel? It must be AWESOME....BUT it's not even made fresh.
Yes, the same frozen type they serve at the street corner vendor carts downtown but worse.It was like cardboard brushed with butter. 
Yes, it came with "stone ground mustard" and "cheese ale sauce" .
Mmm...just like Chanel No. 5 on a $8 hooker.
author: sean s.

description: These guys know their stuff! Great beer selection....something available for everyone. And the bartenders are super friendly and willing to make recommendations to fit your taste. Good food too...yummy veggie burger and oh try their chilli and honey roasted hazelnuts. delish! Only drawback is that it's way too popular, so wait time could be a bit painful if you show up at prime time.
author: Anitha I.

description:
I hate the fact that this is going to be my first yelp review and I am giving one star, but this had to happen.

I was waiting for my husband to finish his work and met up with him at 16th & Mission BART at around 11pm.  Most of the restaurants where we would go were closed so we headed to The Monk's Kettle to grab something to eat before going home.
We have been waiting to come here since my Husband is a big beer / spirits and wine lover and we heard good things about their food and beer selection.

We got there and it was packed.  The greeter told us that they have some tables that are opening up so go to the bar and they will come to seat us at a table as soon as it becomes available.  I checked to see if there were anybody waiting for a table ahead of us since we were starving, and all of the names on the list were crossed out.  I though "Yes, we are next!".

We went to the bar and there weren't even a stool open.  We stood uncomfortably in between the bar and a table right on the aisle.
A server came by and said to us abrasively "Excuse me!!".  Okay. . .

Then a table opened up and we sat down because 1), We were the first one on the list; 2), There weren't any room to wait at the bar; 3), We were hungry.

Then a waiter comes up and said "Were you seated by somebody?"
We said no, and he goes "This table is not even set up yet.  We will let you know when it's ready."  Okay. . . . .

Then unbelievably,, a party of four comes in and sits down in front of us as soon as the table was set.
We looked at each other and said "Really?"

We headed right to the entrance without saying anything to each other and the greeter said "Are you guys leaving? A table will be ready soon."  I thought, yeah right, we probably know more about what's going on in the floor than you do because you just sit there at the entrance, and everyone at the table were deep into conversation that none of them seemed to be leaving anytime soon.

I asked the greeter as I was leaving, "Were those people ahead of us?" He goes "They came at the same time as you."  I stared at him in the eyes as I left.  
. . . . .  LIAR!  I saw the list empty, and those people were nowhere as we came in.  Or did he really think that I was stupid enough to not know what just happened?

After leading us to a crowded area without seating, being pushed around by servers and somebody else who came after us being given priority. Wait, and then finally being lied at?  This is just a bad news. . .

They could have handled the situations way better.
1), Ask us to wait outside if there is no room!
2), Explain to us that they could be seating somebody else because of capacity control.
3), Apologize for mishaps - it happens!
4), NEVER FREAKIN' LIE TO ANYBODY, LET ALONE CUSTOMERS!

The Monk's Kettle?  Bad bad bad news!!
author: Christine T.

description:
Great beer selection.
Snooty, entitled (at times unhelpful) staff/service.
Good food. (burgers, especially)
ALWAYS PACKED!

I wish the place could accommodate more people so that I could partake in their beer selection any time but because they're always crowded and their staff are really hit or miss, I'll give them 3 stars.
author: Audrey L.

description:
Even if the food had been downright terrible and the waiter a downright a** I would have left here a happy lady because of the amazing beer selection. Did I mention it was amazing?

Since the food was also great, I don't have to question my own return-- it's signed, sealed and delivered. (Minus the outrageous crowd and line, unless you come in the middle of the day to enjoy your beers like me).
author: Alicia J.

description:
Summary:
Great beer and our server Kevin was super knowledgeable about the beer selection. It was refreshing to have someone who took such an interest in the food and drinks they served. I will be back.


Beer:
Great selection of unique beers (that was the main reason I wanted to go)

Food:
Pickle: they do some in house deal with a pickle and well it was great. I don't think I have specifically ordered a pickle before at a nice place.

Chicken: Prepared to perfection and came with some great veggies

Service:
Even though the place was full on a Monday night we were able to sit within 5 minutes. The service was spot on. Always had water and beer.
author: Scott H.

description: This place is rad. Great selection, knowledgeable staff, awesome. A little on the spendy side.
author: Matt M.

description:
A flagon of your finest mead, please!

Quite possibly the only spot in SF you could reasonably make this demand, Monk's Kettle serves the truest honey wine in the Bay or otherwise (though they don't really have flagons).  No glass of spoiled corn syrup this be.

The service was a little laggy last night, a Saturday, but once we had the attention of the winsome bartendress, we were briskly spirited the rest of the evening.  

"More mead?"  
"Yeah!"  
"That's the spirit!"

*hearty laughter all around*

I don't drink beer, but I can be assured my beer-snob boyfriend will happily accompany me here when I'm in the mood for MORE MEAD.

ps. Anybody know if there's an affiliation with Monk's Cafe in Philadelphia?  These two places are remarkably similar in concept, atmosphere, and (obviously) name.
author: Naomi M.

description: Loved this place. Great beer selection. The bartenders were awesome. They introduced me to Cellarmaker. I hadn't heard of it. Fantastic! We did have a flat bread while we waited for friends. It was really good.
author: Kurt D.

description: How is it that I have never reviewed Monk's Kettle before? Seriously. This has got to be one of my all time faves in SF. Food is delicious. Beer is out of this world. Service is amazing. Atmosphere totally fun. Decor is out of sight! Don't know why I'm channeling Diff'rent Strokes but here it goes: Dyn-O-Mite!
author: Kelly S.

description:
Monk's Kettle is a great little beer bar the likes of which I miss from Philadelphia (Monk's Cafe) namely.   The beer selection is quite good though I would yearn for a few more beers on draught.  They have St Bernardus Abt 12 on tap!!!!  We ordered two appetizers which were OK which forced me to dock a star (the pretzel was way better than the fries, ours was cooked fine maybe the other reviewer had a bad night).  My burger was excellent even sans cheese.  I would totally go back but would focus more on the beer than the food. 

One thing to note is this place is TINY (occupancy limit 49) so if you really want to get a seat and have some brews, go during non peak hours.

Edited: thanks to all for the lovely comments involving my mispelling of beer as bear.  Actually, if Monk's Kettle becomes a bear bar, maybe they will get that magical 5th star... especially if it's polar bears!
author: Jeff R.

description:
I like this place, I really do. Their selection is great and service is very attentive and friendly, something sorely missing from the Mission bar scene. I only tasted the beer because I'm not down with classed up pub fare (no offense, just not my thing).

There is one little reason for one star missing and that is the cost. Damn, that beer is pricey! I know that connoisseurs will enjoy this place, but with so many beers by the bottle, it would be hard for beer novices to experiment.

Maybe some happy hour specials could sort this problem out? hint hint.
author: G Z.

description: This place blows... the most inhospitable staff ever. Came in for an office event and the staff acted as if we were a major inconvenience when it was really slow late in the afternoon, there were about 15 of us paying with a single company card too... shitty.
author: Donna V.

description: HOLY COW. Have you seen that BEER LIST?! HAVE YOU TRIED THAT BURGER?! And seriously, the mac & cheese appetizer...the gigantic pretzel... I have no words.
author: Jessica W.

description:
I need to write a new review now that I live 3 blocks from Monk's Kettle and go there often.

It is a wonderful nook of delight.  The beer is still everything I already knew about before, and the food is great too.

It's a rare week that I don't stop in.
author: Patrick B.

description: It has definitely gone south in quality, price and service. Beer, burger and the waitress are equally cold, portions are smaller, very average in taste. Oh yes, I had to pay 75 cents for the mustard, if you can believe that! On the brighter side, the ketchup was free.
author: Shabi F.

description:
My gosh this place has blown the hell up since it opened.  I remember a few years back it was a thai restaurant that was usually always empty but had good food for good prices and red walls.  Today, it's a trendy place much like a hipster tavern.  Been here a few times and the last time was in celebration of life and good news.  Yes, that's it... Life. :) Why not?! (or maybe it is the alcohol but life always seems worth celebrating)

We started with some Belgium Pale Ale (I love it) and I got the Lobster pot pie while my friend ordered the Turkey Burger.  Both delicious except that my lobster tasted like chicken... oh right, it was chicken!  A minor screw up but disappointing since they still charged me for lobster since there wasn't any chicken pot pie on the menu.  Strange... i know. Unjust... slightly.

I still think they have a good veggie burger on a La Brea bakery bun and I love that they open as late as 1am.  It's a good place but it can get packed and loud.  Sardine city.  So come early or wait it out.  Good luck!  While you're waiting, there's plenty of beer to try, a black board in the back for some hangman or tic-tac-toe and plenty of hooks underneath the bar... so go, enjoy and cheers to Life (i know you just want to yack all over the extremely zealous optimism, but it was a good day)!
author: Christina C.

description: AMAZING selection of beer. If you love beer this is the place to be. They give you tasters in tiny little mugs (very good effect). They help you choose a beer without being pushy and take there time. The food is also good. I have tried the burger as well as the scallops and they are both tasty. Small little gem in the mission, almost walked right by it without even knowing it's there.
author: Alex Y.

description: Great beer selection. I miss the lamb burger though.
author: Alfredo A.

description:
awesome place!
I consider myself a pretty solid beer geek, and the bartender knew loads more than me.
 incredible selection of great beers, a wonderful by the bottle list and plenty of goodies on tap. Had a Port Brewing Hop 15 - an amazing imperial IPA, at 3.50 for a 13 oz (i think) glass...what an amazing deal! food looked delicious but didn't have any. I'll be back!
author: Ben B.

description:
Great little spot. Good beer and food. Usually 20+ beers on tap. Their shoestring fries are delicious and come with some great dips. I've heard good things about their soft pretzel too. 

I would definitely come back!
author: crystal e.

description:
Checked out Monk's Kettle on Sat night for dinner.  We waited a while for a table but it's not hard to wait when they have a huge selection of beer.  Ironically, we ended up getting a bottle of wine to start.  

The staff is great... friendly, fun, very knowledgeable of their beers  and have funny mustaches! 

My belly was so full of beer that I didn't end up getting an entree but we had a bunch of apps and I had a bite of my friend's pork chop which was not bad.  The mac n'cheese was to die for and the pretzel and fries were delicious! The mini beer mugs for beer tasting are so cute...I was so tempted to steal one!
author: Susan P.

description: Just moved to the city and we decided a Sunday night dinner at monks was in order. It took me about 20 minutes to finally decide on my first beer. With help from our waitress, I began to gulp the first of many death and taxes. The beer paired well with my steak. The mac and cheese seems to be a staple and the special lobster pot pie was great. We finished off with some sours and a kettle cookie which I practically ate to myself. Great food great beer great service, although it's Monday morning and I am feeling the repercussions of the strong ales. Party!
author: Stan W.

description: A total of seven trips to the Monk's Kettle and still no let downs!  Tried dinner on three evenings (early, mid and late evenening) and all three times very busy, but as the reviews indicate, well worth it.
author: Jimbowicz J.

description:
i love beer. i also love wine, but if wine is like a rich, sophisticated gentleman, beer is like a hot young guy with really nice pecs. so yeah, i love me some beer. 

until you've had a rich creamy, slightly sweet dunkelweissen, your tastebuds just haven't lived. seriously, get yourself over to the monk's kettle. this is the most impressive beer list i have ever seen, with brews from belgium, germany, austria, france, the states...i mean everywhere. 

the servers are very cool and know their stuff. ours could describe every beer we asked about, and we asked about a lot. they will be able to point you in the direction of your beer dreams. the space is awesome, warm and pub-ish, with a cool, chill vibe.

i really want to go back and have a burger here, because they looked outstanding. but i can vouch that the mac and cheese is the real deal. add bacon. cause salt is beer's perfect partner in crime.
author: rachel p.

description: This place is amazing...minus the guy at the door. When its busy he tries to push patrons away. Food is amazing, beer selection is insane, bartenders are ridiculously knowledgeable!
author: Di G.

description: as a fan of belgian's (beer) at the time, i visited monk's kettle the week it opened (december 2007) and was surprised by the great food and an extraodinary (if pricey) beer list. however, the recently declining service coupled with increasing prices has prompted me to give monk's kettle a miserly two stars. yeah, i don't wear skinny jeans and a flannel, and your staff probably shouldn't either - rapidly becoming zeitgeist II.
author: Friedrich G.

description: great pretzel. great beers. great staffs. great place to hang out. great pretzel. (it's that good i have to mention it twice)
author: Maya J.

description:
yeah sure, the beer selection is awesome (yet ridiculously priced) but the clear standout has got to be the delicious pretzel and cheddar sauce.

I recommend getting here early, as there always seems to be a crowd.  The beer menu can be overwhelming but the staff can point you in the right direction.  One word of warning is that a few of the beers have an alcohol content around 10 or 11% which can ruin your morning if you aren't careful.

Who knew the monks had it so good...
author: Joshua J.

description:
Great beer!  Great mac & cheese.  Creamy with a lovely crunchy topping.
The cherry pie was yummy too.  The place gets crowded but it's worth going just for the beer selection and the mac.  Not cheap however.

The dude at the door is very rude and does not seem to understand customer service.  We were expecting to be three but turned into four...three of us were present and I said we're here, so we were seated.  Within 5 mins, our fourth showed up.  The guy came over and gave us shit "um, you were only supposed to be three...was this unplanned??"  Dude, do you want us to spend an extra $40 or not?  It's (essentially) a bar.  People show up.  

Anyway, our waitresses were great.  The food was yummy.  Check it out.
author: A S.

description: I love this restaurant/ bar. It is usually pretty busy but that just adds to the atmosphere. The beer selection is fantastic, and the food is always wonderful. The bartenders and servers always know what to pair things with or can pick a drink for you based on just a description of what you like.
author: Jamie P.

description:
You should come here for the beer selection, if you want the fancy drinking environment. I prefer pubs with a bit more character. 
Don't come for the food. The lamb burger & pork chop are substandard for SF/bay area. The buns on the burgers really should be toasted. Arugula salad & charcuterie place - nothing special. No one in our group would come back, esp given the usual wait required.
author: Helen K.

description: Best beer you can find in the city. Beer from all over the world and country. A favorite next to 21st Amendment and Toronado.
author: Michael M.

description: Beer and food are good here. How can you not like that? Place is good for lunch or dinner with some good friends on a Sunday or weekday. Only drawback though it's not good for large groups.
author: Manny C.

description:
I was so excited to try this place when my cousin recommended we try out the new mission restaurant (yes, I'm a little late in writing this review, I know it opened about a year ago...) and now I see that it's part of Patricia P and I's 7x7 Big Eat escapade. 

#50 - giant pretzel with mustard.  I have not tried this yet, but it sounds amazing. What I did purchase at Monk's kettle were the sliders with french fries.  The burgers were super juicy and cooked a perfect medium rare to my liking!
 
Monk's kettle is also cool b/c they have a beer selection the size of California...Amazing it took me a good 20 minutes to decide which beer would go perfectly with me burger....I definitely want to go back and try the pretzel with a new kind of beer!
author: Jenny W.

description:
So my Yelp problem is that I only review things when I really like them, mostly. I'd like to change that about myself. Maybe next year.

The crowds that are dying to eat and drink here are right -- the beer selection is awesome, the food is first-rate pub food (that's what they're going for, after all), and there are even some nice fancy things like the charcuterie platter (a must), the burger (best in the neighborhood) and the pot pies (reliably tasty and where else are you gonna get that? Don't answer that.).
author: michael k.

description: Good food. I get there is a huge selection of beers, but if your customer is not a beer-o-phile and just wants a drink dont put them through the 100 question survey!
author: Vivek N.

description:
I wanted to like this place.

The beers are very good, the location is perfect, it's intimate and clean..

but the menu is sparse, not enough selection to appeal to a variety of tastes, and it's definitely overpriced.   Reminiscent of a financial district haunt, in terms of snobs and prices.

A bit of snobbery & high prices......near 16th & Valencia ..........bad idea.
author: Scott T.

description:
First off, one of the best beer selections in the city.  The list is enormous and can be a tad on the gourmet side (with prices to reflect it) but if you're on a budget, just gaze on over at the fan of a zillion taps and you'll find your match.
 
Secondly, I never come here during the feeding hours of the common street hipster.  I've seen the place packed to the point of bodies spewing out of the door and with the loud chorus of drunken banter, could be any one of dozens of Mission digs.  Hence, my gf and I wander in about 5 or 6ish and thoroughly enjoy ourselves.
Lesson: avoid gratuitous crowds = personal space to enjoy food/drink.

Thirdly, the wait staff is totally on their game with knowledge and recommendations.  Ryan, our fave, is always helpful and friendly and gives you the beer lowdown in layman's terms.
We've never been disappointed and are always discovering a great unknown brew.
Blue Apron and Telegraph Ale rock. 

Lastly, the food has never been a letdown.  I've seen previous reviews that hammered on the food and all I can say is, again, I've never been disappointed.  Granted, you are in a beer establishment in the Mission but I find the food to be above par with the rest of the bar fodder in the hood.   Lobster pot pie??  Are you fuggin kidding me?  A++!  Of course, the mac n cheese is never a let dow (and perfect beer compliment at midnight) and the salads are fresh.  The gf digs the oh-so-fresh desserts.  
I'm not a huge fan of the pretzel but it does rank well above Annie's shyte (as some poor tongueless reviewer suggested).

In all, one of my favorite spots in the Mish and with food being served unitl about 1 am, who can whine about that fer crissake?
author: Stephan J.

description: Good.but pricey, 10 plus dollars for beer. then again, I am not a big beer drinker. they have lots of beer and all the glasses that goes with it so if you're a beer love, this place is cool. i had the burger but it was okay. nothing special.
author: Tiff W.

description:
Staggering selection of beers.  Two pages of food options and twenty pages of beer options!  I have a prefererance for belgian beers and was quite happy with my different selections.  Excellent mac-n-cheese with loads of bacon and perfectly done burgers.  The gastro-pub movement is in full swing here. 

Two words of warning.  1. - the wait can be long (it's a tiny place) so don't show up and expect to sit down anytime soon.  2. - Check the price of the beer you'd like before ordering.  We were tasting away and almost (almost!) ordered a lovely italian beer at $75.
author: Lena J.

description:
Monday night: C. and I find this fantastic parking spot right in front of the Monk's Kettle. I gleefully parallel-park us in when this random man runs over and throws himself against the side of my vehicle, and proceeds to wipe my windshield with an uber-grimy t-shirt all the while hollering that he wanted to make a buck...

... so running into the dark, appropriately-lit chic bar of Monk's Kettle seemed like a good escape. Fresh, cold beer (though I am not a beer drinker, and made C. finish 3/4 of the remainder of the cold brew I ordered) and fries with herb aioli made everything better-- oh, and as did getting back into my car and turning on the automatic wipers and wash fluid! 

Food kept pouring out of the tiny little kitchen. Looked good, but we were too stuffed from Delfina to munch on anything more than fries.
author: Cheryl F.

description:
So, I came here 4 days after they opened, so obviously, they had some stuff to brush up on: I ordered a London Ale...and got a Guinness. 

BUT, their appetizers, salads & entrees were GREAT.

Great veggie options and 125 beers to choose from.

-1 star because they did not have the pretzel that I had been dying to have.

Boo on that one.

Small dimly lit restau-bar that's perfect for a low- key night out with friends (but not too many friends...the booths only fit 4 comfortably). 

I will definitely be back...but I will be checking ahead of time to make sure they have those pretzels!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Smaller than I had thought it would be.  And way crowded.  On a Saturday night at 9pm we were told to either find a seat at the bar, or along the back wall, or expect a 30 minute wait for a table, and that would only work if we were going to be ordering food.  :)  

So we managed to snag a spot at the bar.  This was written up in 7x7 as a beer type of bar, and it was definitely that, with a 5 page menu of beer options!  I don't think that any beer fan would be unhappy with this menu, the options were endless.  They even had beer with fruit in it for people like me who normally don't 'drink beer!  

We did manage to order some dessert, I think it was the bread pudding, and I must say it was the most amazing bread pudding I'd had in awhile.  It did end up being too much for me though so I didn't finish.  

I would love to come back sometime for dinner, but my Midwestern boyfriend was not loving some of the beer prices.  Me, I think you're at a beer tavern that has a niche filled, so of course they might be a little more expensive than other places, look at all your freakin' options!  But either way, yes would love to come back sometime to check out the menu some more.  So far though we liked what we saw!
author: Denise B.

description:
**This is a burger review (mostly)**

Overall:7.0/10 
Burger: Medium rare, definitely. Some nice beef.
Bun: Sesame seeds. How can you go wrong with sesame seeds?
Toppings: The best grilled onions that I have had on a burger so far. Cheddar was cheddar.
Other Notables: Good fries. I gotta say that we had some lack luster service tonight, but I have been here before and it was always better the previous times. This time though, about the burger, this is not a top of the pack burger. The fries and the burger are just south of Magnolia and at 14$ and change, no different in terms of price. The grilled onions are better here, but the fries at Magnolia are better (not to say that the fries at Monk's Kettle are anything close to bad).
author: Matt C.

description: The whipped bone marrow on toast with preserved lemons and popcorn was insanely good!
author: Tina M.

description: Props for a new menu. Despite missing my pulled pork and other american style favorites the new menu still makes my mouth water. Sad but true I always get the side of fries with spicy mustard and their aioli. And not to mention, oh yeah...the TEN page beer selection. Great job monks kettle!
author: Greta M.

description:
The beer selection is vast - maybe a contender for one of the best in San Francisco.   I only wish they would add Mac & Jack's from Washington State because that *ish is SO GOOD and impossible to find.

I stopped by for lunch on Saturday with a friend and was seated almost right away. I liked that there was no rush or pressure to move on since that's what lunch on the weekend should be like. I'm becoming a veggie burger addict so I tried their "homemade" version with fries - it was tasty but not cooked quite all the way, super mushy in the middle. It was thick too, maybe cutting down on that would help? Whatever, I ate the whole thing. I would go again, have more beer and try another dish.
author: Allison B.

description: This place is super cool.  Clean, cozy, unpretentious with a nice selection of beer and good food.  My favorite thing about this place though, is that they have the BEST giant hot pretzel I've had since I moved here from the east coast.  Or maybe even the best giant hot pretzel I've had EVER.  If you are a hot pretzel fan, then you definitely need to go here and enjoy a beer and a hot pretzel.  Best afternoon ever.
author: Sapna M.

description:
Easy to review:
pleasant place
good service
tasty sandwiches
good beer

RIDICULOUSLY OVERPRICED (typical San Francisco)
author: Mark F.

description:
it sounded to me that this place billed itself as a beer hall type spot with lots of counter space and fun, excitable crowds. NOPE. more of a low key spot to enjoy your beverage. Personally i find both the latter and the former enjoyable. it just wasn't what i expected. 

I wouldn't go here on a big, silly night out. but i might start here or perhaps swing by for dinner and a beer on a random weeknight. 

cute space, but TINY. not so conducive to serving food and being a bar at the same time. hopefully they will "find the right niche of patrons" as Shane W. said, because i agree it is a "unique addition".
author: Kimberly N.

description:
ORIGINAL REVIEW AUGUST 2008
Went there with a group of four people this past weekend for a late lunch.

Was very impressed with their beer selections (go to their website to check them out). Our group tried the Petrus Old Bruin, Ellie's Brown Ale by Avery and Stone 12th Anniversary Ale. All were on tap. Their bottled selections were also superb.

This is definitely more of a lunch/small dinner atmosphere than a bar setting, but they did have a small bar as well. They had beer pairings with each menu item as well which was quite handy. The server seemed to be busy, but was very attentive and responsive. Service the entire time was very fast.

Food was actually really tasty. I had the skirt steak which was very flavorful and tender. My buddy had the chicken pot pie which was one of the best I've tried. Price was reasonable.

Strong 5 star review.  Highly recommended if you are in the Mission District of San Francisco!

REVIEW UPDATE AS OF SEPTEMBER 2010
Went here with my family and had a 6-top.  Waited about 20 minutes for our table; it was a Friday night, so this was of no surprise.  The beer selections as I expected were superb.  EEmbrasse -  a belgian strong dark ale.  Strong, smooth and very good.  Pliny the Elder - always a treat.  Echte Kriekenbier - my girlfriend was raving about this sour.  St. Louis Gueze - strong horseblanket funk; delicious.  Moonlight Reality Czeck - always a treat; subtle but flavorful and easy drinking.  Moonlight Wheat (brand new and only at a couple bay area establishments apparently) - a sour wheat; very unique and glad I tried it.   

The food this time around was average to well below average.  The fried mushrooms appetizer was good which we started with, but it seemed to all go downhill from here.  The soup was not bad, but unmemorable.  The bruschetta was a terrible excuse for one.  Really, really bad.  Steak Sandwich was very unmemorable and lacked good flavor.  Burgers were lacking in flavor and well below average.  BBQ Baby Back Ribs were not bad, but I thought they were slightly overcooked and the bbq sauce was only mediocre.  The pot pie was average with too strong of a rosemary taste.  

The total for 6 was $245.28 after tax before tip.  Beers were expensive and food was moderate to expensive.  Service was excellent and beer was delicious, but the bad food is making me bring my strong 5-star rating down to a 4-star.  I'm not throwing the towel in on the place for their food; it could have been a new chef or an off night for the cooks.  If it is like this next time, though, I may just go there for the beers.
author: Benjamin P.

description: Every time I go to SF I'm excited to eat out and try new places, and was stoked to find this place though a friend.  So good!  Great beer, service, and be sure to order 'family style' if you're in a group.  Really good gastro-style cuisine.  Will be back for sure.  PS they have a few vegetarian options, but mostly geared towards the meat lovers.
author: Geoff G.

description: They have a ton of different beers, something like 4 pages worth.  I really like the Affligem Blonde, taste like apple juice.  The bartender was friendly and let us have some samples.  Some of the beers are a bit pricey.  I'll come back for the stuff they have in casks.
author: Matthew P.

description:
I paid $38 for a salad and one fairly mainstream draft beer.

Both were delicious, but c'mon people, is that ever justified anywhere on the planet?
author: D B.

description:
I arrived at MK's and my initial reaction was "fan-say!" 
"Where's the hearth at?"
Couldn't recall what had been here before, but it felt very uptown Manhattan. 
The gorgeous woodwork at the bar is well suited to the broad spectrum of exotic beers. AND, they had mmMaredsous which took me be back to olden times. 
They had a nice selection of veggie friendly pub vittles too. The vegan chili was reminiscent of a comforting moroccan chili I made long ago. I paired it with a recommended porter.
 Made me want to start drinking beer again (except for the steep $12 beer). 

Good thing it's not in my hood.
author: Sandrita R.

description:
Visited the Kettle on a Friday and after enjoying some great company, drinks, and eats, I figured I'd share a few thoughts with the class.

TIGHT QUARTERS - This place is cramped, seriously. When it's packed, it's hard to breathe. Even when you have a table. The entry area is jammed and valuable bar space is taken up by a giant lamp that looks out of place on the corner.

GREAT BEER - The beer menu here is outstanding. The draught list is great, but the real story at the Kettle is the bottled beer selection. One can find all sorts of rare treats from around the world. If you're just in the mood for some swill, you can refer to the 'Grampa's Suds' section of the menu and grab yourself an ice cold can of PBR or Olympia for $2.50.  The list also details ABV for almost all of their beers, so you can better calculate that all important cost-to-drunkeness ratio.

FOOD - Go for the fries..these things are seriously addicting. Beyond that, we tried the cheese plate and a Iceberg Wedge salad. Portions were large and the food was reasonably priced. (but don't expect a cheap night here, more on that in a sec!)

WATCH YOUR WALLET - The slogan for this place should be 'Home of the $11 Beer'. Beers start at $2.50 (Tecate, PBR, Olympia) and go up from there...way up. The rarer the beer, the higher the price, with more than a few specialty brews sitting at around $10-12 for a regular bottle. Large bottles (500ml, 750ml) can run you way north of $40 if you're not careful. And of course, the bulk of this beer is STRONG, so you can easily walk out of here with a savage buzz and a hangover in your wallet.
author: Jared K.

description: I had a very positive experience here. We were seated promtly and ended up having a great time. I wouldn't reccommend going in a group. The place is tiny. Good for two people. The pretzel was amazing and the cheese plate was also very good. So many beers to choose from, it was a difficult choice. The beer is a little overpriced.
author: Maria K.

description:
THE GOOD: After a long day, missed meals, and a late movie at the Roxie, I needed more than the usual Mission taqueria. How excited was I to find this place, all warm and sparkly, a few doors down! (Actually, living in the East Bay, how excited was I to find a late-night kitchen, period!) The doorguy and waiter were very welcoming to a woman dining alone at 11:30 PM, and folks at the bar were having much fun with the bartender, who clearly knew his stuff. 

THE BAD: Unfortunately, my nice waiter did not. When I said I wanted to try something new, either a Saison along the lines of a St. Feuillien or De Ranke, or a Belgian Strong Ale like Duvel or Chimay, he suggested Chimay. (Uh, no...) Then he leafed through the menu and read the descriptions to me (Again very sweet, but I actually know how to read). I asked him to ask the bartender for recs; instead he said he'd bring me an "awesome" beer he "knew" I would love though couldn't explain why. (Needless to say, there was no love.) After delivering the bottle (why would you open a bottle of something you can't even describe when there are 12-plus options on tap?), he never checked to see if I liked it, even when he brought my food. I had to grab him to say I hated his thin, formaldehyde-tasting recommendation, much to his apparent dismay. Finally he checked in with the big boy and brought me 3 tastes in teeny leprechaun steins (on my tall stool, I felt like a giant!). 

THE UGLY: When I ordered the lamb burger, my waiter immediately starting pushing the extra toppings (at $2 each). It already comes with a horrid (dill? mint?) yoghurt sauce, which ain't gonna get any better by adding a completely different flavor profile like cheese, sautéed onion, avocado, and mushrooms. I ended up spending $40 for a burger and a beer (with tip). The guys at The Trappist in Old Oakland are twice as savvy for half the price.
author: Faith A.

description:
The beer selection is ridiculous, hands down one of the best in town.  Food and service are really nice.
A neighborhood gem!!
author: Cyril B.

description: Came here for a beer after going to several restaurants and such before. Definitely want to come back earlier in the night and get some food and try some more of their beers. The food looked super good and their beer selection is awesome. Definitely worth a second trip.
author: Colleen M.

description: Friendly service. Helpful with choosing the right beer. The burger was  very good but oddly not filling. The fries were basic.  The beer menu is almost as extensive as Toronados. Worth checking out again.
author: Lou Z.

description: Monks Kettle is an establishment that is completely disrespectful to its neighbors by having deliveries everyday which block neighbors driveways.  If anyone out there in SF land has had this problem you know how aggravating it is.  I have asked and asked the owner not to block my driveway to an answer  of total disregard.  PLEASE RESPECT OUR NEIGHBORHOODS WHILE MAKING YO' MONEY!!!!!!!!  Please fellow restaurant/bar goers keep this in mind when deciding where to spend your hard earned money.
author: Dawn J.

description: Didn't eat here, but had some amazing beer on a rainy SF day while passing through town. One of the best beer lists I've run across. Sat next to the window and watched the rain, enjoying the hustle-and-bustle of the small and packed bar. Definitely worth stopping in.
author: Sean And McKinze F.

description: If you love beer and burgers, this place is for you.  Grand selection of beer, not my forte, but any beer lover would love this.  I would not come here with a big group and you should expect to wait a long time!   The fries were awesome and my weakness.
author: Sonia M.

description:
I ordered a chicken sandwich and my boyfriend ordered a burger. All things considered, the meal was pretty pricy considering 2 sandwiches and a pretzel ended up costing $40.

However, the food was excellent (!), the service prompt and efficient, and the atmosphere wonderful. We were impressed.
author: Hayley L.

description: Best beer menu in town.  I like their new and improved pretzel.
author: Amar P.

description: San Francisco skews my ratings because a "3" here is like a "5" in DC. The Niman ranch burger and BBQ sauce and Dunkel Veisen were all delicious. Our waitress was a nice and attractive hipster type. Open late nights - it had a cool vibe for th late 20's set who aren't ready to move to Noe.
author: Andrew K.

description: Nailed it!!  I needed to find the perfect SF pub for my in-laws to celebrate the 40th anniversary of the day they met in a pub in London. I read a zillion reviews and was drawn to The Monk's Kettle, but knew they didn't take reservations. I called anyway and wound up speaking with Greg and told him of my very specific needs (date, time, Barry White on the iPod).  He was fantastic!  Said he couldn't take a reservation, but would do his best to hold the window table for us.  I called the day before and spoke with Ky who assured me everything would be perfect.  We arrived to find our table waiting and the staff had been told about the celebration.  The service was excellent ( thanks Kristine!) and the food and beer was delicious.  Best moment - Barry White singing and my mother-in-law with tears in her eyes. Thanks to everyone at The Monk's Kettle for a perfect evening!
author: Bonita H.

description: Pliny the Elder. I have to love a place if they have Pliny. We tried a couple other beers as well because you kinda have to when the selection is so fabulous!  We sat at the bar, the wait for a table was an hour, to be expected for good beer and food. Interesting ingredients in most of the dishes. Between the 3 of us, we had some sort of meatloaf sandwich, house salad (yum!!), a burger, the daily pickle and a 3-day chicken-something-rather. Everything was really good. The only thing that wasn't a decent sized portion was the meatloaf sandwich, it was a little small. Everything else we had leftovers to take home. At the end of it all, we decided to get the Stout Bread Pudding with vanilla ice cream. Divine! Tasted a little like a bittersweet brownie. REALLY good! Our bartender was really friendly and knowledgable as well.
author: Kim T.

description:
Great beer and great fries. When we were there, we had an rudely aloof bartender who actually prioritized drying glasses over serving beer. Even the other wait staff acknowledged how unresponsive he was. Food was overpriced for what they offer. Beer on tap was pricey but not unreasonable for the quality. I can't comment on the value of the bottled beer.

Good place but not as cool as it thinks it is. A common condition of newer places in the Mission.
author: G H.

description:
Get in where you can fit in. Monk's Kettle is a busy, snug space framed by a gorgeous dark wood, mirrored bar that shimmers like a beacon of hope. I sat in one of the booths, smitten by the candlelight flickering off the glasses and the bartender's face. The space feels kind of designy, kind of "dude", kind of cozy, but with enough realness for me to feel like coming back again and again.

Now can we talk about the food? Comfort food basics made fresh, delicious and "right." Crispy is crispy, seared is seared, seasoned is seasoned. I had to tell our cute server to give props to the kitchen 'cos they are doing it well. Everything we ordered was great:
- Chicken breast w/mushrooms, greens & fingerling potatoes
- Bbq pork on toasted roll w/exceptional garlic fries
- Arugula salad w/apples, candied walnuts and shaved cheese
- Black bean cakes w/spicy mayo
- Hot apple cobbler w/vanilla bean ice cream
- I drank an Eel River organic porter that tasted like chocolate

Service was quick, cordial and efficient. The guy at the door had a great attitude, and kept us sane while we waited over 30mins for our table. Understandably this is a difficult place to leave. I'll be back for more!
author: Antoi C.

description:
OK. If you want a table at this bar/restaurant, it is expected that you will eat dinner. This is not such an exceptional policy, and really should not be what determines whether or not Monk's Kettle is a quality establishment. I did not have any problems at the door of this spot and my friend even wanted to pinch the cute cheeks of the host.

This place has a fantastic list of beers and the menu is interesting and well-executed. It's a popular joint and will be crowded at prime time, but if you go at an off peak time, you can enjoy a great burger and beer.
author: Lee T.

description: 5* Fresh Ground Burger with aged White Cheddar, house cured pepper    bacon
author: Aaron L.

description:
From a yuppie point of view (not really me, but can be), this place rocked:  massive selection of beer,  tasty cheese plate, friendly bartender that helped me picked both out.  The bar itself looks great!  There is a huge wooden fireplace facade at the bar.  The intricate design of the bar and the atmosphere scream POSH!  The vanilla-scented bathroom also looked great.

What I didn't like: it was cold!  Keep the freaking door closed, man!  And where is that constant draft coming from.  Oh, yeah, it does get pricey.
author: Wella A.

description:
I think I spend more time here than in my own home.   That's either a good or bad thing depending on the day, I guess.   MK has the largest beer menu I've ever seen.   We actually keep notes on each beer we try in hopes that we can try them all.    It's a noble effort at least.

Sit at the bar here.   Then order something Belgian to sip on.   Then order the giant pretzel to munch on.   Next, order something stout-y.   Then order the pot pie of the day.   Finally, order something else sudsy for desert.   Come back again and mix and repeat.  You won't be disappointed.  

My only fear about Monk's is that it will be come a favorite haunt for everyone else as well.   Luckily I live a block away so I can haunt it as much as my wallet will let me.

Long live, MK!
author: C H.

description: You got to Monk's expecting to get a very good variety of beer and wine which they have. What you don't expect is how awesome their food really is to make this place one of the better gastropubs. The pork chop and sandwiches here are very good. Seating is a little cramped given how busy the place is and I would not suggest for big groups given seating is usually for 2 or at the bar. One thing that would make this place better is if they  upgraded their TVs; I could barely watch the game since it was so small and far away.
author: Ed L.

description:
This place is a beer lovers dream, 7 pages of libations all with descriptions & most every beer we had (many) had it's own damn glass!  You don't get that kind of passion very often.  The service here is top notch, Sayre & 'Dennis' made sure all of our cravings were met with both beer & snacks.  Don't understand the expensive comments except they must be used to Sysco type eateries, this is not one of those places.  This hipster thing I don't get either but I've noticed the best places are usually tagged with 'hipster hangout' or hipster servers simply because it's popular & the staff has to hussle ...hussle doesn't equate to poor service or hipster!   

This will be the first stop on our next trip 'home', kind of bummed we moved out of the mission before their arrival.  

thanks for a great SF trip
author: Kim N.

description: Maybe the extensive beer list that I've ever seen.  Certainly the best mac & cheese I've ever had.  The only thing is this place will get extremely crowded, and by that, I mean if you can't get seated right away, don't even bother.  The only time I was able to actually sit, eat, and drink comfortably was when we happened to stop by in the early afternoon on a weekday for a late lunch.  I would definitely recommend making it a point to get out here if you ever get a chance.
author: Jason T.

description:
You can cloister yourself here, contemplate the merits of beer and sacrifice some modern conveniences like light and warmth.

Peering hrough the window, it looked like a cozy, comfort  spot.  For the most part, it was.  We were able to walk in on a Sunday evening and had no problem getting a table for four.  The pot pie of the day intrigued us and when we heard it was lobster pot pie, we were sold. We were a little worried about having lobster tidbit pot pie, but on my first bite, I had a huge chunk of lobster! It was creamy, filling and satisfying, but the crust could have been baked a bit longer. My husband was happy with his crisp, skinny fries, pork sandwich and beer.

The menu had a long and varied list of beers but the downside was it was too dark to read the details! Also, the cold wind blows right in when the door opens - and with the City weather being a bit chilly save for late August through October, it's quite cold inside. I had to put my jacket back on shortly after taking it off.

If I still lived in the neighborhood, this would be a place that I'd sidle up to the bar, book in hand and enjoy comfort food and a beer. But I might need to bring a reading light and a jacket!
author: Theda E.

description:
Great selection of beers on tap. Excellent Belgians (mostly bottled, but a few on tap). Very friendly wait staff. I'm not normally an outgoing guy, but I was alone and the bartender and I chatted for a while about SF beer week, and various local Belgian-esque beers. Food was great (I had the lamb burger; juicy, delicious, excellent tzatziki sauce).

As for the crowd, lunch was no problem, I'm sure it gets busy nights and weekends, but can you blame em?
author: Paul W.

description: Loved the food! and loved the beer! But The staff was knew their menu inside and out and made great recommendations for both the food and the beverage pairing. Beer pairings?! Now that's a great idea. The recommended follow up beer was exceptional! I thought it all was a bit pricey, but such is the new Mission. Did I say how much I loved the beer?!
author: Daniel P.

description: Comfortable atmosphere, fantastic service, delicious food, and superbly curated beer selection -- it doesn't get any better than this.  Ate a late mid-week lunch. Ordered the chick-pea burger with fries -- an 11 out of 10. Received a knowledgable and thoughtful beer pairing recommendation from our server -- spot on. Will definitely be back!
author: Carolyn S.

description: FINALLY got myself to Monk's Kettle this past weekend, and not a moment too soon.  I think any beer lover would love this place.  Is it cheap?  No.  Is it a dive?  No.  It's a nice place, with nice woodsy decor, and knowledgeable, friendly, and willingly helpful bartenders (I'm looking at you Toronado).  We were only here for drinks, but I definitely plan to come back again for what looks (and smelled like) to be some really good food.  Seriously, really dig this place, and yeah, you can go buy a bottle of some of this stuff at Whole Foods for a lot less, but this is a different experience and you are getting what you pay for.  Plus, they have absolute shit tons of beer on stock.
author: Sean H.

description: Good beer selection.  Food was so-so. Had the pulled pork sandwich.  Nothing special about it.  The wait was ridiculous. But that didnt weigh in too much on my rating.  Nothing in particular made this place stick out.
author: Sal L.

description: Jumped in for a quick cocktail before a dinner date and ended up staying for a pretzel!
author: Aileen B.

description:
Despite what other recent reviews have said, I enjoyed my food here.  The buttermilk fried rabbit, mussels, and the chocolate bread pudding were superb.  The beer list was impressive.  The only downfall was that I thought the pretzel was quite overrated... $4.50 for pretty much just a salted piece of bread.

It's an actual bar (they card at the front door), but it still felt very much like a cafe/restaurant.  They don't take reservations, but you can still enjoy your food at the bar or they'll call you if you put your name down for a table and leave to grab a drink elsewhere nearby.
author: S L.

description: I'm going to give this place a 3 star....for now, I just felt slightly underwhelmed by the food I ordered and beer I drank for the price I paid. Ok, so I just ordered soup ($8) which barely filled my cavities, an 8 oz Belgium beer ($9.50), dessert ($8), and a warm pretzel with 2 dipping sauces prior to this small meal. This sounds like a lot but being that I didn't expect to spend this much money for this little amount of food, I was a little shell shocked. Plenty of my friends, all guys, rave about this place, well, sure, I guess like I rave about shoes...They don't understand the concept nor do I understand the concept of this place unless you were a connoisseur of beers like I am to shoes...I'll just have to ponder that thought and next time I feel rich, I'll come back.
author: Natasha C.

description:
Even on a monday night, this place was nearly full. Just so happens 3 people moved from their bar seats and empty beer glasses to a table as soon as we walked in and wondered if there was any room for us. FYI, it turns out bar seating is first-come first-served, and tables are get-on-the-list type of thing. 

Bar seating was just fine - you can hang your coats and stuff on the under-bar hooks (always a nice touch), we were promptly presented with a 5 page beer list (great variety, btw) and menu, our drink order was taken and we were told the food specials (pot pie sounded and looked amazing, but I was already sold on the pork chop)... 

I was really impressed with our food, I must say. I think I was expecting more "bar food" food, but this was pretty damn good! My dish was a mouthwatering pork chop with a side of brussel sprouts and a perfectly done (read "crispy") potato pancake. It was soooo good, even if not good FOR me. 

I'd totally come back here again. Helps break up the start to a very tough work week! ;)
author: beth l.

description:
I had been wanting to try the Monk's Kettle for months and finally made my way over last night.  I had high expectations because I love beer and I had heard only great things about it.  Well........ it definitely lived up to my every hope and dream, and then some...

1 Star - The beer list is amazing - it's long and quite descriptive, you know  exactly how drunk you'll be after each beer, which is nice.  Unless of course you go with the "?" alcohol content - then you're really screwed.

2 Stars - The host and servers were all very nice and happy to help us find a place at the bar and make us comfortable for a maximum consumption experience.  Our server was very knowledgeable about each draft beer on the list, and both my man and I were satisfied with our choices - Hop Rod Rye (a very smooth amber) and Epiphany Ale (a very strong bittery Ale).

3 Stars - The crowd is mellow and friendly - I mean, it's all beer drinkers, so no one is wasted and downing shots and ordering vodka sodas.  Even on a busy night there's never a problem getting a table or chairs at the bar.  I was really happy about that!

4 Stars - Although I didn't eat there, the food looked delicious - mostly steaks and pork and such - with beer pairing on the menu.  We did however have the "giant pretzel" which was about the size of a basketball - smothered with salt and butter and ohhhh mannnnnnnn so good.  Perfect to saturate some of the beer so you aren't completely shitfaced if you aren't dining there.  

I was really impressed and will be sure to go back soon.
author: Alice H.

description:
I don't like beer. If you take me into a brewery, I'm going to be the designated driver and the only person in the tour group who remembers everything the tour guide says. I wish I liked it more, it just doesn't suit me.

So how is it that on a random Sunday night, my boyfriend - who is a bar owner and therefor somewhat of an expert on all things related to killing your liver - talks me into going here, a beer drinker's wetbar dream?

Two answers. 

1. The food is spectacular. I had something involving goat cheese. I wish I could remember exactly what was in it so I could try to reproduce it in my own kitchen. 

2. BLUEBERRY BEER.

You heard me. The girl with no love for beer has found a beer she loves at Monk's Kettle. It tastes as good as it smells and it goes down smoothly. 

Yesss. Blueberry beer.

By the way, Sunday night was still pretty busy but we didn't have to wait for a table. It might be a better night to venture in if you're opposed to waiting in line.

--

UPDATE:

The chef of Monk's Kettle sent me an email response today thanking me for the review and even let me know how to make the dish I loved so much the night I was in. How's that for great customer service? I will TOTALLY go back soon.
author: Kat E.

description:
Although known as the one not likely to turn down beer in most occasions, the unusually cold weather on Friday night made me a bit hesitant to say yes to Monk's Kettle.
