In scarf and mittens and boots, I trekked to the Mission and found myself in too much clothes once I stepped into MK.  Which made me crave exactly a cold glass of beer right away.

Instead of Houblon la Chouffe, I went for Mc Chouffe (the only knome on tap that night),  a nice brown ale with good flavors and no bitter after taste.  Then I followed up with a nice glass of Hop Stoopid.  They weren't joking about that hop!  It smelled like freshly cut grass--- in other words, quite lovely.  We also shared a giant pretzel that provided a gentle cushion for the 8-9% beer buzz.

The bartenders are friendly and knowledgeable, as the crowd laid back and mild.  The tables can take forever but the bar seats are usually a easy grab every 10 minutes or so.  

Drink your beer any time of the year!  I now know I will, especially if cozying up along the wooden bar at Monk's Kettle.
author: Jiajia C.

description: great beer selection  it , the beer menu is actually a whole book, but great vibe and service , had one of the starters and it was good ( local greens ) , great atmosphere overall and an awesome place to discover beer .
author: NAEL K.

description:
5/8/2008
Went back with some out-of-town friends and they were happily surprised by the extensive beer list.  

The wait list for getting a table was still not nearly as user friendly as, say, a chalkboard where you can write your name or being allowed to leave your cell phone number.  And since the magical clipboard is tucked in a high-traffic area, you constantly are either in the way of a waitstaff or patron.  

The food is still solid, but I have to say that while the meaty goodness of the Niman Ranch burger was good, the brioche was a crumbly mess.  And the baguette served with our cheeses was stale.  Not sure if they were having an off night for fresh breads or what.

1/22/2008
Yummy!  If only the place were bigger.  Somehow on a busy Friday night, I was able to snag one of the much coveted window/booth seats.  Though be forewarned.  Wear a warm jacket or shirt cuz if you're sitting next to the window, 'tis a might chilly.

Artisan cheese plate - how can you go wrong?

Charcuterie plate - SOOOO GOOD!!

(Split the) BBQ Niman Ranch pulled pork - didn't have enough kick, but the meat was luscious and the jicama slaw provided a clean contrast.

(Split the seasonal) cranberry and apple(?) cobbler - tasty but too tart to me.

Bubbles - NV Cava Brut Reserva Blanc de Blanc from Spain.  I truly appreciated that our server didn't try to steer us to the $150 bottle of Laurent Perrier to pad the bill.  And the bubbles were bright and sparkly with a touch of fruit.
author: Anonymouse C.

description:
We went late night Wednesday and this place was pretty full. We were able to get a table quickly though. We had a steak sandwich and a seared ahi sandwich. The meat on both sandwiches was a little tough and the ahi was a tiny bit fishy. Otherwise everything was great. The rolls the sandwiches were on were good and the ahi sandwich had these vinegar cucumbers on it (not pickles) that I really liked. The french fries were hot and delicious. They were the shoe string type though, so if you don't like that cut you may not be as happy as we were.

This place is mainly for beer. The food menu is one page front and back. There were appetizers, sandwiches and dessert. However, the beer menu is something like five pages long and includes pretty much everything from PBR on up, with several beers available on tap. The beer is not necessarily cheap, but this place is next to Delirium so if it's $2 PBR you are looking for you won't have to go too far. 

They also have wine. Even though the tables are a little tight, it's ultimately more cozy than cramped. Our service was pretty good but our waitress was just MIA enough for us to notice and have to ask the bus boy for stuff. She was nice though as were all of the staff. I will go back.
author: J F.

description:
Extensive beer selection - check. Adequately greasy (but good) food to go with said beer - check. Somewhat upscale digs - check. Reasonable prices given that they keep like a thousand beers available. But in the Mission? I have a problem with this.

What is happening to the Mission anyway? When I lived there I was a yuppie surrounded by non-yuppies. I liked it that way. Now the yuppies are surrounded by hipsters, and I'm now none of the above. Boo!
author: Amy K.

description:
Obviously the beer menu is rather extensive, very descriptive (educational even), and best of all, it's available online.

If you haven't realized: This place is upscale. Pricey. Even for Belgians. Maybe it's pricey because a lot of what comes in the bottle is 750ml. But seriously, $12.75 for a small bottle of Duchesse de Bourgogne? For my fancy pants beer I prefer the Toranado or Amnesia.

Drinks only will have a hard time sitting at a table, and the bar is only so long.

Oh well.
author: John F.

description: There were 4 of us that came in for lunch and there was no wait. It was super busy Saturday afternoon. I love that they have a beer bible but I was sad there were no red ales available. Their menu does change so definitely ask them what's on draft or the waiter can give you recommendations based on what flavors you like! We got an order (okay two) of the pickles. There was an assortment and there were also pickled grapes which were weird but tasty! If you like pickles, order this! so good. I ordered the arugula salad and the dressing was so tart that I couldn't finish it. It just tasted like pure lemon juice. I also got the lobster bisque and that was delicious. Another good one was the burger. I would eat that burger for breakfast, lunch, dinner, and while I was sleeping so my dream self could know how delicious their burger was. There was also a pulled chicken/pork sandwich that was pretty good. I can't remember what it was so maybe that says something? I can vouch for their fries though! Thin, crispy, and so delicious.
author: Jessica W.

description: Obviously epic beer selection. Giant pretzels available. Great sandwiches. Hard to get a table. Nice bartenders.
author: Nate M.

description:
I swear, this place is my favorite place for quality eating and drinking in California.

The first time I was here I got german beer. I was really impressed with the huge glass and the way it was served by the waiter. Not only did she do everything the traditional way, but the beer was smooth and perfect. The fries are really good. You get 3 different dippings. The Chipotle/Ketchup is my favorite and everyone should try it. Else you're depriving yourself! I've had the salmon sandwich here---and---I forget that else (the beer, man). But every-time I have plans to come here I get really exited. The guys who work here are damn friendly. It's crowded yes, for a reason. 

I need a raise to come here more often! Dammit!

Just so you don't think I'm biased: it's a bit cold and there is usually a long line for the restroom (only 1), so pee before you leave home.
author: Alexia R.

description: Like everyone says - small place with a large selection of beers. Went here to kill time before dinner and lucked out by getting a small table by the door immediately after walking in. I chose my beer by alcohol content and price (hah.) and ended up with an Old Viscosity. I was also sitting right by the hanging menu on the front window, which is why we also ended up with the cheese plate. Got the chevre and gloucester - delicious. It was unanimous that we had to go back and have a full meal there another time.
author: Micaela G.

description: The people are friendly and they clearly care and know their beers, and I'll definitely be back for drinks.  The food however...  The Humboldt Grassfed Beef Burger was okay (not bad, but not great either).  The Estancia Beef Flat Iron Steak had a piece of silver skin that ran through the entire steak rendering it inedible (can barely be cut, much less chewed).  How any place and call itself a gastropub and pride itself on food could serve a piece of meat like that is beyond me.
author: S T.

description:
The pork chops were amazing. The beer list is exhaustive and the waiter knew enough about it to help any beer novice navigate it. 

We are from out of town and were impressed and satisfied. This place gives SF a good name!
author: Andy S.

description: THE WAIT FOR THIS PLACE IS LONG!!!!! I wish people would stress about this on their review!!! BUT, the food was AMAZING!!! I was told it's busy every night, 7 day's a week, no matter what time!!! Yes there is a wait, but the food is so good, it's worth the wait!!
author: T C.

description:
I was indeed impressed by the selection, with both draught Duchess & Grimbergen dubbel available at accessible prices.

For eating purposes, the place isn't that big, perhaps 25 non bar seats.   The food was acceptable, but not the star of the show here.  

The staff was very attentive and helpful as well, we exchanged pleasantries with at least 3 of the staff on a busy night.
author: Matt T.

description:
Checked out Monk's Kettle over the weekend and had a good time. In regards to my rating -

1. I think the beer list is incredible.
2. Great space design - the feel is of a nicer neighborhood pub in England. 
3. The food was good, but the portions seemed a little small. It would have been nice to have a little greens with the steak sandwich and fries (thus the 3 stars).

I will be back for beer for sure, will have to re evaluate food.
author: Raymond M.

description:
Over hyped and overcrowded - for a good reason.

I guess going to the Mission for after work cocktails isn't such a good idea. First of all it's a Friday around 7.30pm, so we knew that we'll have to fight the crowds and wait and wait and wait. 
And we waited for a while.

On the upside, whilst waiting, I was able to try some exotic imported brews - yumm. A bit expensive but if your a beer snob like me and enjoy Belgian blonds (beer that is) then you won't mind.

Yes, the fries were good. 
Yes, the beef short ribs melted off the bones and into my starving mouth. 
Yes, even the polenta was worth mentioning. 
Yes, the staff was friendly and cute. We even got a freebie for having to wait so long.
Yes, the crowd was pretty good looking.

Overall, I'll be back to for seconds.

If you don't mind waiting or crowds (the place is small) check it out.
author: Sam H.

description:
It's a long story but a group of friends and I went on self directed great beer tour through Belgium last fall. Our only guide was Tim Webb's fantastic Good Beer Guide to Belgium and it treated us well. Many of the places we visited were only full of locals and other people holding the same book. My husband left that country quite the beer snob. You can find a good deal of the best beers we found during that week here at the Monk's Kettle. 

We got there shortly after 7 and got the last two seats at the bar, the space behind us filled with standing beer drinkers over the next half an hour. I knew what I wanted, a Rochefort 8, a favorite of mine. My husband wanted to try something on the menu he had never had. They were out but the bartender suggested Monk's Cask instead. They had just gotten it on tap and they would be the first to enjoy it (the bartender said he'd have to join him if he ordered one). It was a great pick and the hubs was pleased. The fries weren't quite Belgian, but they were tasty enough. The beers are a bit expensive but maybe they were similar to what we paid before considering the Euro conversion rate. We had a great time and would totally go back.

My husband declared The Monk's Kettle is the kind of place he would want to open if he ever decided to own a bar. If you knew what a beer snob he is you would know what a high rating this is!
author: Melissa W.

description:
Oh, my my.  Monk's Kettle, how I want to give you 5 stars, that hideous praise.  Alas, I cannot, but I can say with certainty that you served me beers the likes of which I had never imagined, and that deserves some serious stars of its own.

Yes, there were crowds.  Yes, this space is entirely too small for the masses contending with each other for a spot at a table.  Yes, this establishment is FAR better than the Thai restaurant that was its predecessor.  Yes.  the short-ribs were tasty.   Yes, the Monk's Cafe Sour is the most interesting beer I've had in a long time.  Yes, Fuller's tastes better on a nitro-tap.  Yes, a fresh pretzel is as good as you think it will be.

No, the staff was NOT pretentious -- they were friendly and attentive and apparently very happy to be serving such kickass beer.  No, the short-ribs were not the best I've had.  No, we did not get a table -- the bar was quite good enough.

I'm scared of a place like this being so accessible.  Be really careful going in here... you could walk out with a $100 beer tab.
author: Jay M.

description:
Mixed bag - 

I REALLY wanted to love monks kettle.  Its a traditional German Pub with an amzing selction of beers and som very good stuff.  But 4 beers and pub food for 2 shouldnt cost $70.

The good - 

1. Amazing selection of local and imported beers - i mean a REALLY good selection.

2. Awesome giant pretzle - authentc German sryle and cooked fresh to order -!!!   ($6.50)  as big as your head 

The in the middle - 

1. everything we had was delicious, albeit small portions

The bad

1. $4 more for the draft version of a beer they also had bottled ($12    vs.$8 - that's just wrong
2. $16 for a flank steak pot pie special  - served in a soufle dish - VERY small, and kinda dissapointing.   It asnt horribly overpriced, just too high for what it was.  

This place has the makings to be great and the beer selection will get me back for a second chance - the burgers looked good and are probably a better value.  

My wife only had an appetizer and I had an entree.  Id give it 3.5 if I could.  But I cant.  It really gets a 5 for beer selection but the food just didnt hold up
author: Rick R.

description:
I was seeking out the perfect pint of hard to find beer.  My thoughts were floating about  imagining myself sitting at the bar, bullshitting with the bartender about the intricacies of a nice IPA.

Descending upon The Monks Kettle last Friday night, my thoughts were dashed when we entered a packed shi-shi restaurant/bar which was The Monks Kettle.  I guess I was picturing in my head visions of  Toronado, but in the Mission.   

We found three spots at the bar that somewhat overlooked the kitchen and enjoyed the brew and some snacks.  Even though it was packed, the service was adequate and the bartender was great, taking time to make some great recommendations using terms like "iridescent" and "hue" when describing certain beers.  The food was spot on, think a beer version of the whiskey joint Alembic in on Haight.

If you're looking to drink hard to find beer, I would opt for Toronado, but If you're looking for quality pub-like food and a taste of some fine beers (and you can stomach paying $5.75+ per pint), The Monks Kettle is a nice place to go.
author: Mike T.

description:
Had foods and beers last night at the bar.  Couldn't figure out whether our bar tender thought we were annoying, everyone was annoying, or if she was hitting on one of us.  Just the same, she was playful (or sarcastic) and pleasant (passive aggressive?).  

We had the pretzel, the aioli needs more sumpthin - flavor, maybe.  More garlic, or sweetness or thickness?  Something.

The goat cheese was yummy, best if shared, too much goat for one person.  It was like a bruschetta with the tomato goodness served on top.  We found the flavors on the bean cake to be a miss.  The spice made it hard to taste the bean...

Our server/tender of bar recommended a brie like cheese with a peppered rind - so flipping perfect, and a good contrast to the manchego selected by my friend.  The cheese plate is busy in presentation, but all the parts were welcome in my mouth.  That's for sure.

We ordered the pot pie of the day, expected to be a steak variety of meat because that's how our server knew it...but the kitchen switched it up to bay shrimps without giving her the heads up.  It was edible, for sure, but fishy in the one bite we all tried before having it wrapped up for Roomie who is notorious for eating anything called "left over"...she's got a tummy of steel, friends.  Bet we would have LOVED the steak pot pie, because the consistency of the ingredients and the bready top were really right on.

No dessert.  Our bellies were gladly full of beer, the hef was a serious Hit, as were the 3-4 others we had the pleasure of trying.  

Server/tender of bar even (reasonably reluctantly) traded pens with me.  I had a great time, hope to go back.  Hope to chance upon a steak pot pie again. Yum.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
Stumbled into this place on a thursday night and it was packed tending to a late dinner rush. in the background you could hear a music playlist of 80s music and mostly cure tracks.

my group luckily found a couple of seats open at the bar. Their beer menu is extensive (pages long). Dont worry their bartenders were very knowledgeable about their selection and were able to describe, recommend and entertain us.

I really want to go back and try some of their food. We ordered a side of fries and it came fresh in a basket with bbq flavored ketchup and garlic mayo sauce. it was a great companion to our beers. a group of girls sitting next to us seemed to steal a couple of bites themselves.
author: Gabe H.

description:
If it was just the beer, I'd definitely give them more stars. However, as an eatery, it's overpriced for, at best, standard fare. They attempt to impress with presentation, but you've had better elsewhere, believe me. For example, I was stoked about the lobster mac'n'cheese - how yummy does that sound! Sadly, it sucked. The lobster was stiff and  the mac'n'cheese just wasn't that good. 

Also, everyone keeps trying to sell me on their burgers. Meh I say. Go down to the Front Porch and get a real burger and some crab grits to boot. 

The staff was nice, but the place is quite cramped and there is a definite douchebag factor in your fellow diners. I can accept that, it's that part of the Mission right? But just make the food worthwhile.
author: Jay N.

description:
I was walking around the area looking for an afternoon spot to eat and noticed the odd name.  Figured I'd try since it wasn't packed at 3 p.m. in the afternoon on a weekday.  The menu is a bit pricey but after ordering the chicken brie sandwich, it made up for it!  The sandwich serving was HUGE!  Very good.  I would have to say that two people could have shared it and still be full. The fries were pretty darn good too.

Metered parking all around the area.  Good luck on finding a meter-less space!   

The place is small and cozy.  Great ambience.  Definitely not for big group of friends, unless you want to stand around squished amongst diners all night.
author: Ny H.

description:
I like this place! Very SF-ish located in the Mission district. Monk's Kettle has a great selection of beer and food. The concept is sorta like a brewery, but is much more unique and intimate ... Most of the beers come with its own glass which is kinda cool!

The place doesn't take reservations so it might be hard to get a seat on busy nights. Your best bet to go is a Sunday evening ... spending a chill evening with yummy food and good beer, and then sleeping it off until another week of work begins. Can't find a better way to end the weekend!
author: buggy b.

description: Five stars for the extensive selection of beer, four for the food, ambiance, and service. Went on a Sunday and only had a 30 min wait. Pretzel was delicious, but mainly because of the cheesy mustard sauce. Juicy, flavorful flank steak sandwich with horseradish and shallots.  I wouldn't wait 2 hrs for a table, but if it's not crowded, a great place for some unique beers and food.
author: Alison S.

description: My boyfriend is beer obsessed...and I'm usually just along for the ride.  However, the bartenders found beers for me to try that I actually loved! Amazing service and selection.  A little pricey (the good, rare beers are between 11 and 15...and up!) but totally worth it.  The food was also delicious-fresh baked pretzels with nacho cheese fondue, burgers, and bread pudding! Heaven....
author: S. V.

description: I've lived around the corner from this place for like a year now & finally decided to go last night. Had bone marrow for the first time & was like UGH gross.. I like it. Also, I had my 100% perfect beer here it was freakin' delicious, it's called doggy style. Mm I guess.
author: Hana G.

description:
I spent a Sunday afternoon here, sampling delicious beer with recommendations from the knowledgeable bartender. The Hell or High Watermelon Wheat was interesting - light, a little sweet, and I definitely tasted watermelon. My favorite was the Russian River Porter, and I sampled almost everything they had on draught. The beer comes in 20 oz unless noted on the menu, and they serve tastes in these little shot glasses shaped like beer mugs.

I'd heard about the giant pretzel and noticed a few other people eating one, so we ordered one. The pretzel was yummy, and the beer-cheese dip that came with it was so amazing I could have drunk the stuff. I will definitely be back, I want to try the lobster pot pie the next time. It wasn't that expensive, either, for an afternoon drinking microbrews and eating gourmet bar munchies.
author: Alex V.

description: This place is really good. Their fries are delicious. I can't decide if it's the fries that I like or the dipping sauces. It's just right, I couldn't stop eating them. Their extremely long list of beer is delicious also. It  hits just the right spots. The pork chop is something I've never tasted, it's soo good. The sad part was that I couldn't finish it, but even the next day, it was sooo damn good. The veggies didn't seem fresh though, but that's fine with me, since I don't like veggies. Their peanut butter cookie is so good, the cookie was soft and sweet. And eating it with the ice cream was perfect.
author: Stacy C.

description:
I have been wanting to try this place for a long time, and finally, (after a 1.5 hour wait on a Wed. night)- I did! Great bonus that you can give the host your cell so you are free to roam at nearby bars while waiting. 

This tinnyyyy place has the most extensive beer list I have seen in the city, so def the spot if you are into that. The food was satisfying and all went well with beer- get the giant pretzel - you will want to eat the whole thing by yourself and well worth the $8.50 bc the mustards and cheese sauce are to die for. I had the lamb burger and was high in flavor and served on good bread. My fellow diners had the vegan chili (which had quite a kick) and the beet salad with chicken- and all plates were polished off! 

Although the food came out quickly, the service was not very attentive. And also try to get there SUPER early because a lot of the beers we asked for where sold out by the time we got seated. But overall, unique nook for solid beers and food.
author: Rena Z.

description:
I give this place two stars... and it's mostly for the pretzel.  I went on vacation with my husband for a week in San Francisco.  Using Yelp as tool to guide us towards the "good beer" in town, I decided to take my fellow "Yelpers" advice and hope on the BART down to Mission in order to experience the wonderful beer selection...

First of all, when we got there, we were informed that it was standing room only, though there were open tables.  When I asked to sit at a table, they told me I was going to have to eat... Well, I was planning on eating a pretzel with a few beers, but they meant eat dinner.  My husband and I waited awkwardly in the small space between the bar and tables, becoming an annoyance I'm sure for every member of the wait staff... finally someone was leaving the SMALLEST table you have ever seen by the window up front and offered it to us after over-hearing me say, "I'm sure we're everyone's biggest pain in the ass..."  15 minutes later, 20 hands, and about 30 "excuse me's...", we're finally sitting. 

I am going to complain about the price.  Sorry, people.  If money's just not an issue for you, well, great... I'm from San Diego, I like my San Diego type Ale's and I especially like not paying 500% mark up on them.  I was aghast at the prices.  When I told the waiter it was like tearing my heart out to pay these prices for my local brews, he shrugged his shoulders and said, "It's a restaurant?"  Well, thanks, I can see that, but please explain why you're asking 65 bucks for a (I believe) Lost Abbey beer I can get for 6 at the store?  While the beer list is extensive, this place is not for the true beer-lover.  It was cleary for the bougie-types, and funny thing is, most of the people we saw come in and out throughout our stay had only ONE beer... who goes to pub to have one beer?  When they are as expensive as the Monks prices, many people.  We ended up having 4 beers between the two of us and pretzel.  Got a decent buzz and got out of there... 

The decor is decent?  Eh, looked like synthetic flooring on the ground.  They have about 5 booths, pub style, and a bland bar.  Nothing special to wow you in aesthetic department.  In our search for good beer throughout the city, we found other places I'd like to recommend... my husband and I loved Magnolia Pub in the Haight, Toronado in lower Haight, The Irish Bank in Union, and The Thirsty Bear in SoMa.  They had decent prices and good beer.  

Hope this is helpful!
author: Natasha L.

description: I've never had more knowledgeable, helpful servers - I went to this place based on another recommendation from Yelp who said that the servers had PhD's in beer - it was no exaggeration. I rarely drink beer, largely because I've never cared for the taste of it. This server brought me tastings in adorable little beer mugs, inquired about my taste preferences, and helped me settle on the best beer I've ever tasted. Plus,with six pages of selection, I'm not surprised I found something I liked! Reviews from others in my group were similar - great selection, nice atmosphere, and fun place overall! I would go again!
author: Lindsay B.

description:
Monk's Kettle is exactly what's wrong with San Francisco in general and the snotty Mission in particular.  Trust-fund hipsters appear happy to congregate at this overpriced joke - I guess I didn't get the memo about not caring about quality or service.  Go if you want to be seen, but don't go if you'd be offended by a $18 steak sandwich that comes with tasteless steak on two-day old bread.  Especially don't go if you want to be refused a sample of one of their ample selection of draft beers unless you commit to the $8 full-pint purchase beforehand.  What is the point of a tasting, remind me?  

Merely OK food for stupid prices served by very rude staff.  Skip this archtypical SF nonsense.  If you must eat on this block, go next door for a crappy sausage from the skaters at Gestalt Haus - at least there the value-for-money equation is ethical.

You've been warned.
author: Garbo H.

description: Went with Matt last Saturday and we were lucky enough to get seats at the bar right when we walked in. The beer selection is amazing at this place. We had the charcuterie plate and the giant pretzel, both were great snacks during our beer drinking experience. The service was great, bartenders were really helpful with drink suggestions for Matt.
author: Lacy K.

description:
If you're looking for a place in SF with a lot of really good, hard to find beer, this is the place to go. Monk's Kettle has a fantastic selection of beers that you won't find anywhere else in the city. The food here is top notch (at least it was the last time I ate there, although they have apparently changed chefs recently). Despite what I've read in other reviews about issues with the staff, I've never had any problem with the guy at the door nor the servers.

Monk's Kettle also does a monthly beer night where they have a special beer pairing menu which I've been looking into for awhile, but haven't been able to try yet...you have to reserve your spot well in advance and the website/staff are a bit vague as far as what the guest brewery/menu/specific dates are. 

The only real con to this place is the size. Make no mistake...if you show up around dinner or later, especially on a weekend, expect to wait awhile for a table and/or get real friendly with the person standing next to you at the bar. There really isn't any spare room to stand/sit around and drink/socialize if you're not at a table or at the bar. But if you do get a spot, you're in for a treat.
author: Devin G.

description: I Finally went back after having some yucky experiences. This time I went in with my head held high ready for the pretentious attack. Guess what? It worked! I too pulled the pretentious card, drew on the chalkboard and enjoyed my german beers, got drunk! Yayyyya
author: Annie A.

description:
We went to the Monk's Kettle with high expectations based on the yelper's reviews.  First, we were told the wait was 1.5 hours for a 5 person group.  After coming back an hour and a half later, we waited for another 30 minutes before being seated, and were not greeted with great service, nor was the host very friendly.

The food was mediocre.  We ordered every burger on the menu and a salad.  While the beer selection was quite impressive, I wouldn't even recommend going for a drink because there is literally no standing room - we weren't even able to wait inside for our table despite it being freezing outside.  

While this place may be nice to grab a drink and an appetizer on a weeknight, the food is definitely not worth the 4 stars it has earned on yelp, and with the lack of available bar space for a passerby, it does not seem that the bar has really earned 4 stars either.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
125 BEERS...yes!!! Need not say more about this.

So the crowd here is ultra-yupster. That can be good or bad depending on your mood and tolerance. The environment generally manages to be cool and fun anyway. I randomly made several new friends and had a good time catching up with my buddy who came with me. There is something about the lighting and decor which is ultra relaxed and comfortable. 

I didn't try the food, but it looked good, and super tasty. Kind of pub-ish menu with all the usual suspects.

Didn't try the food
author: Nikhil B.

description:
I stopped by here on the last stop of a night of continuous bar-hopping and heavy drinking because it looked so fancy and different from the regular bars in the mission.

We went inside and found a table right away, which was really our luck cause the place was crowded.  It is definitely a place for the beer connoisseur, which I was not, so my friend and I stuck with the Grandpa's Suds (PBR and Olympia).  It was awesome cause it came in cans too!

The menu looked tasty, but a little too fancy w/ Grandpa's Suds, so instead we got "dirty" hotdogs from the vendor right on the corner.
author: Jolene W.

description:
This place will be much more bearable once the hype dies down and you don't have to spend a hour squashed next to bellowing frat boys for a table. Burger was excellent, as were the fries - but not quite worth the wait.
And you do have to pay dearly for the beer fetishism - $4.80 for a 12 oz Radeberger, $9 for Duvel  and $12.25 for Kwak on tap. So make your selections with care and do note that the paper menu they give you may not be up to date and you might have to get up and squint at the barely legible chalkboard.
author: Kei H.

description:
Beer: Awesome. Such an eclectic list. I ordered the "Monk's Cafe" and the bartender asked if i wanted to taste it first...as it's a bit unusual. A cool move when someone just ordered a $6 beer. I tasted, I liked, I ordered another. 
Vibe: Perfect blend of staying classy without entering D-bag land.
Size: Bigger than you think, plenty of room as long as you have a seat.
Staff: Everyone was cool. I wanted to hang with them.
Food: Hit and miss. Pretzel to start is a must. Burgers were solid, fries were like having 2 dates at my high school prom: Ultimately disappointing. You roll a Belgium beer list like the one they have at Monk's and you NEED killer fries. 

I'll be back.
author: Jordan K.

description:
Finally they did something good with this spot! I've watched this place turn over countless times, transforming itself from a burger place to Thai and on and on. The one thing the space always lacked was warmth. The Monk's Kettle more than made up for that. It's a cozy, candle-lit, American pub.

If you don't like beer, don't bother. But if you fancy a good stout, some American-style pub food, than this is a great spot.

Only problem is that it's TINY. So it's good for a random weekday night, but don't bother trying it on the weekend.
author: Kim M.

description:
I tried this place just once and thought I'd jot down my experience. I'm a huge Belgian beer fan so this place has been on my 2do list for awhile. For you beer lovers, the place has a HUGE beer list with many Belgians and others. Our server was very knowledgeable about the beers and very patient in helping us to make our choices (and we made many). In the end, we were there for some time and were helped by 3 different people and all were very friendly and helpful. No complaints about taking a table for so long either. (It was a Tues afternoon after all)

Why three stars in a sea of 4/5 star reviews? Well, I ordered the Lamb Burger, but they were out of lamb. (sorry, don't like to hear that) So, I settled for just the burger. The burger was good, but the bun wasn't as fresh as it should have been. Fer shame chef. Even after getting plowed on so many Belgians , I could still tell the bun was stale. Oh well. It wasn't bad enough to send back, but, it just isn't something that should happen. After all, the menu isn't cheap, and, well, even McDonald's seems to be able to keep that #$! straight. (I'd give 3.5 if it was possible, but I just can't give 4 stars). I'll go back some time and see if this was an anomaly.
author: Rich M.

description:
Came here with a friend this past Saturday night looking for some drinks. I remember another friend mentioning this place so we decided to check it out. 

We walk in around 10:45pm and the place is pretty packed. Nice decor and staff is very friendly. There's a guy that sits next to the door that's supposed to check peoples id's to make sure they are 21 but he gets a little preoccupied with his book. LOL!  Anyway...that was the BEST hefen weisen I have EVER HAD!!! The cups are very generous as well...not your regular sized cups...worth the money you pay for.  It's about two beers in one cup. We also got a sized of fries which we thought were good especially the creamy sauce that it came with...but not worth the $5 we paid for it. We almost got the giant pretzel but it was $7.50..OH NO! We saw some people get it and it didn't look like it was worth that much. 

I would come here more for the beer though. They have a three page menu of just BEER! and if you are hungry late at night the bacon wrapped hot dogs are sold a few shops down. We made a stop by there :) YUMMY!!
author: Jazmine S.

description:
One word captures this place: impressive.  

The beer menu is extensive.  When I say extensive I mean HUNDREDS of beers.  Prices range from your typical $4-$6 beer to a $60 bottle of beer for the elite beer pallet (and wallet).  Tons of imported beer populate the list, and the waiters are very helpful if you tell them what type you're looking for.  

The food is gastro-pub style.  Lots of traditional American style dishes.  My favorite menu item is the BBQ pulled pork sandwich.  If you're just nibbling get one of the cheese platters; they go surprisingly well with the beer.

Through and through this is a great addition to the neighborhood.  Sit for a drink, eat your yummy food, or spend long hours doing both, and I'm sure you will find this place welcoming and succulent!
author: Morgen N.

description:
I'm on a burger review kick which could be due to being a tad hungover and really wanting a burger.  I decided I was overdue to write a review of the place that served me quite possibly the best burger I've ever had.  Neiman Ranch organic beef and Point Reyes blue cheese is a marriage made in heaven.  I love their fries too.

In addition to the amazing burger, they have a great beer list and bartenders who know their stuff.  This is a great addition to the Mission.
author: Julie P.

description:
first of all shout out to the dude jake who works there who hassled me about using ketchup with my mac and cheese.you were clowning dude and cracked me and my friend Kelly up.

Nice restaurant,very interesting menu.My mac and cheese+bacon was great.My friend liked her garden burger .Extensive beer menu although admittedly,thats why I took off one star.I dont like beer and I hate restaurants that stick to just beer and wine ,or in this case just beer because it limits choices for us non beer lovers.BOO.

i'll be baaaack
author: Lauren V.

description:
GREAT beer selection, Monk's Kettel has my absolute favorite Belgian beer Popperings Hommel Bier but it's expensive.  9.75$ per bottle expensive but this intense Belgian beer packs such a wallop that I only ever have one.  

Gina and I went the other night after seeing David Byrne at the Symphony Hall to cap off an excellent night.   Monk's Kettle serves a comfort food-esque menu that is slightly pricey especially in the salad/appetizer area but they serve dinner til midnight.  In their defense, the portions are sizeable; I had the pork chop, brussel sprouts and corn cheddar scallion cake and it rules I brought home half to finish for lunch the next day.  

Head's up, my friends:  Monk's Kettle is on the small side, it is really good, and is thusly crowded during peak hours.  I recommend coming here on off hours, they serve through out the day- lunch seems to be less crowded or for an early or late dinner or snack to my experience.
author: annie s.

description:
We tried the 'Coleman Natural Hampshire' Cider Brined Pork Chop.

Tender, juicy, hot and extremely flavorful. Best pork chop ever! 

The salad was fairly forgettable, as the dressing was a bit overkill, but still not terrible.

The beer was outstanding and so was the service. I was impressed. I a great beer, made with poppy seeds! 

Expect a wait, but well worth it!
author: thrasher b.

description:
duuuuude! AMAZING BEER....and WARM SOFT PRETZELS! the staff is amazing and everything i have had as far as food and drink were totally killer...

thank you monk's kettle
author: janiece G.

description: So good!  Seriously wonderful food with an amazing beer selection. The service was great too.  The giant pretzel with the homemade mustard was to die for.  Mac and cheese with bacon?  Yes please!  There is nothing better than good beer and even better bar food.
author: Roberta J.

description:
If you like beer and trying new things this is the place for you!  

Amazing beer selection and great food!  I was lucky to try a bunch of different things on my visit.  If I could recommend one item it would be the Pulled Pork.  The first bite of the sandwich was sweet but count to 3 and pow, spicy!  It was awesome.  I'm from out of town so this may be the only time I try Monk's so thanks for beer and a great meal, the duck prosciutto was uhhhhh soo good!
author: Sean C.

description:
i'm so glad i didn't listen to another yelper about her experience here - if i had, i would have never tried it, ever, not in a million years.

it was valentine's day, a saturday, and we decided to skip the pillow fight and stay close to home in case the skies decided to open up once again and pour, we had no reservations anywhere, and ventured out around 7:30. my friend wanted to try the Monk's Kettle so we headed over there to see how long the wait was.

the host was great, he said for a 2-top it could be a few minutes to an  hour, depending on if the people before us took a long time or decided to show up at all...so he took my cell number and we went over to Gestalt for a pint...

time flew, we had a few, and decided to walk over to check on the wait...by this time it'd been about an hour, and we were getting hungry, but not impatient.  we talked to the gracious, funny host, who we were enjoying bantering with, asked if we should go get another drink or wait - he said "how about enjoy another drink next door at delerium, and if i call you, you'll just have to pound it!"  to which we laughed and amicably left for another cocktail...

we had just finished our drink when we got a call that our table was ready.  we had a great seat, interesting neighbors who all seemed to be highly intoxicated and in crazy good moods, and the food and beer were lip smackin'.  all in all, this place was the full package, despite the wait (but wait, we didn't have a reservation, on valentimes day, so it's amazing we even go in, right??), and i'd definitely go back there again to try more of their interesting beer offerings and nibbles.  great place to people watch too.
author: Suzanne A.

description:
Yum - great beer, even a really really great veggie burger.

Minus points for the 2 hour wait - the gentleman taking our name + number at the door was awesome to get us in there earlier than what we then became to anticipate.

Definitely a must-try (go early, my only advice).
author: Kimberly F.

description:
I found this tiny place by chance with a friend and I'm glad I did. They were very busy in the mid-afternoon when I went and we had to wait a while to get seated in the far corner on stools. However, the place we sat had a chalkboard in front of us which was entertaining while we waited on our food.

I had an excellent burger with a Jones pure cane sugar cola. Well worth the wait and I'd definitely go back sometime.
author: Reid B.

description:
I went to Monk's with my girlfriend while visiting her sister in the city.  First,  I'm not going to be like everyone else and say the beer selection was amazing.  Beer selection was plentiful, but like a lot of places in SF, it seemed like the selection was created to be as obscure as possible, regardless of  actual quality.  I feel like I know a quality beer since I went to school in Ft. Collins, CO--self proclaimed Beer Town USA and birthplace of the now famous Fat Tire.  When I asked our server for his suggestion, he looked at me like I was a total square, which turned me off a  bit.  In the end, though, he turned out to be a pretty cool guy and even brought me a few samples to try, including an extremely powerful stout.

As for the food, I had the steak sandwich which was damn good.  Really good fries too.  My girlfriend had the turkey burger which she seemed to enjoy.  After some food and a few more beers, my spirits were up and I ended up having a pretty good time.  I will definitely give this place another try next time I'm in the city.
author: art s.

description: Great selection of beer which was obviously hand picked. The prices are really steep but I think it is worth visiting for the variety of rare beers. This place is also a nice space to meet up with friends.
author: Eric G.

description: We came here on a Saturday evening and squished 6 people into a 4 person table.  A bit too squishy for my taste, but their long list of beers made it all worth while.  We also ordered the pretzel & popcorn.  I'll have to try this place on a weekday after work.  Hopefully it won't be as crowded.
author: Stacey L.

description: Dark chocolate bread pudding and one of the best beer menus in the city.
author: Jessica G.

description: Only stopped in for a beer, but boy did this place remind me of Philly with it's amazing beer selection and gastropub feel. They even had my good ol' speckled hen!? Beerfest for sure.
author: Chihee K.

description:
Ice Cube once said:

"It was once said by a man who couldn't quit;
Dopeman, please, can I have another hit?" 

Enough said...

See you there.
author: Chris G.

description:
Superb beer selection, classy glasses to serve the classy beer in, and, why lookee here, a dyed-in-the-wool wine snob enjoys his Saturday afternoon drinking beer!  Who would have thunk it???

Plus, the pretzel with beer-cheese sauce is calling me back there soon!

Oh, Monk's Kettle, how you have shown me the way back to appreciating beer!
author: Jim K.

description:
So I've been to some other places with as many beers (~150) as The Monk's Kettle, but I've never been to a place with such a global variety of brews. If you're looking for beers that you can also pick up at Safeway, this really isn't the place to go. It has an outrageous selection of (pretty much) all regional beers. Belgian, German, British, American microbreweries, etc. It's pretty dizzying to read through the 5 pages of listings. They even have "The Kwak" on tap, served in the funky glass.

Great atmosphere and the food is pretty good. They have a potpie of the day (I had the Wild Mushroom Potpie yesterday) and sort of the general bar fare. Beer pairings for the entrees is a nice touch. Kitchen's open until 1am.

Drawback is how long it took us (party of 5) to get a table: it took almost two hours on a Saturday night. But considering the main attraction of the place (the beer list), you can put that time to good use. And the GREAT and helpful staff will help you pick out beers that match you.
author: Jack C.

description:
Great beer selection.  Went here last night and got an Old Rasputin Stout on Nitro and a Fuller's London Porter on Nitro.  Delicious.  The bar tenders were friendly.  The prices for the quality of beer is pretty reasonable.   Food - the pretzel is great and comes with some yummy beer cheese sauce.  My dining mates had the burger and I had the steak sandwich, which were all good.  I like that they aren't ketchup monitors and actually provide little bottles and not just a small cup.  

My biggest complaint is their handing of table seating.  We walked in at 5:50 and asked for a table for three.  The bartender said you are first on the list.  Another group of seven came in after us.  I don't know if it was because some members of that group were especially pushy, or the staff wanted to get them seated and out of the open area, but somehow, they were seated before us (at a four and a two top).  We got our seats after waiting an hour and 20 minutes (how's that for being first on the list).  Evidently, there is  much confusion about seating in the booths, as essentially every time a table opened a group would sit down.  Then the bar staff would have to make them all get up when the people on the list would need to be seated.  Perhaps some signage would end some of this confusion.

Funny incident.  Some dude walked in there with two toddlers.  Then he walked out.  Why would parents think bringing children (of any non-legal drinking age) to a bar is a good idea?
author: Jory R.

description:
Shared a fresh pretzel w/ cheddar sauce and mustard sides, and spinach salad for starters; then a burger (med/rare) and an ahi sandwich for the main.  The pretzel was warm and fresh.  Pumpkin seeds on the salad added a nice touch.  The burger was pretty good.  It was juicy and sizeable and more importantly:: it was medium rare and topped with an organic tomato slice that was a bit small and mealy.  The fish sandwich was just dull.  

No beer for me but a bottomless glass of really good iced tea accompanied my meal.  Definitely looks to have an extensive selection of Belgians (beers that is) and will sample some next time.

The space is pretty small and the lighting is inviting from the outside and interesting to look at from the inside.   Could be cozy, but the temperature (at least at the booth nearest the front) was pretty chilly.  Interesting material and lighting choices add to the overall appeal.
author: Moching ..

description:
The Monk's Kettle is my newest discovery in San Francisco, and it's within a few blocks of where I live, life is good. They have a really interesting selection of beers and tasty food. If you're looking to branch out and experiment with new beers, give this place a shot.

This place even suggests beer pairings on their food menu, how cool is that.
author: Matt N.

description:
A new trendy burger spot in my hood? Had to go check it out to see if it lived up to the hype, as it was always packed when I walked by. 

I've been there twice now, and when you can get in it's really worth it. The beer menu is fantastic - and they let you try tasters so you can tell if you like their hard-to-find offerings are as fantastic as they say. The times I've gone I've asked what is good and let them give me a bunch of tastings until one strikes my fancy. The downside of this excellent service is its tough to go back to drinking your normal beer after this.

The food I thought was great - well the burger was, at least - when they brought it out after I sent the first well done one back. And the best part - they picked up our first round of beers because the first overcooked burger came out.

A great burger, extraordinary beer? Hard not to like.
author: simon m.

description:
I love this place so much. It breaks my heart that I can't get in most of the time. My secret has been to starting drinking early - like 3 pm early so I can get a seat before the crowds start. They get 5 stars if they ever expand and I can actually get a seat after 7 pm.

The food is great. A side salad and the best fries in SF are usually what I order. You can taste the potato - a novel idea given that most fries are frozen and processed into bland mush sticks. Also, the selection of beers is wonderful. 

They have a beer for everything. Even if you are suffering from the worst cold of your life. I went in with the hubby for a beer earlier this year. I had been sick for two weeks at that point and I couldn't handle staying in doors any longer. The waitress, noticing my suffering, offered up a warm cup of honey mead. Better than Robutussin. Not long after that I made a miraculous recovery.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Great staff--
Amazing mac and cheese--
Tasty beers--and many to choose from.

my only complaint is that its a tad on the small side. gets crowded very early. prepare to wait.
author: Shari E.

description: BEST BEER LIST!!! & love the atmosphere. Next time I'll come hungry so I can try some of the food... the menu looked amazing! Servers were knowledgeable and friendly too. Can't wait to see you again!
author: Chris H.

description: I went here specifically to try the giant pretzel. It was on some "good eats" list. It was your standard giant pretzel with rock salt. It came with two sauces: cheese and what I presume was homemade mustard. The mustard was extremely delicious. Had an ESB on the side too, great beer, went with the pretzel nicely. Overall, I had a good experience and would go back.
author: Sita M.

description: Do they have good food?  Good beer?  I'll never know.  Because they refused to seat me - at 4:30 in the afternoon, on a Monday.  I was there with my friend, my other two friends were parking around the corner.  There were maybe six people in the entire place, and some of them may have been staff.  Why?  "We don't seat incomplete parties so close to dinner."  Really?  So much for the concept of hospitality.  We turned on our heels and went across the street to Ti Couz.  At Ti Couz we received excellent service, enjoyed wonderful food and delicious French cider.  By all means, go to The Monk's Kettle if you enjoy being treated like an idiot.  It's their business and they can run it how they like.  But none of us will ever go back.  Zero stars, really, for this "Gastro-Flub".
author: Eileen H.

description: loved it.  great food.  great beer.  tough to get a table, but a perfect place for a late night dinner with a buddy
author: nick g.

description: I got the ribs special and two different beers which were both part of the specials. Everything was rib sticking good. Service was solid and the host was really friendly and helpful. It's what a Thursday night out should be.
author: Sean Q.

description:
Great beer list, great lamb burger, nice vibe. But the markup on their beers is so high, I really can't recommend to anyone that they go to the Kettle. I had a smoked beer that wound up being $14.75 for a bottle. A few weeks later I saw the same bottle at BevMo for $5.50. That's just annoying. 

And the lamb burger is good, but it's fourteen bucks. 

Hit up City Beer Store or Beer Revolution in Oaktown instead. Or check what's on tap at one of the umpteen good beer bars in the city. Good beer need not cost quite this much.
author: Noah K.

description:
I met a friend here while I was passing through SF and my goodness, the ale is great! Much better than the stuff we get in the UK in fact! The waitress was very knowledgeable and made a stellar recommendation for an ale to accompany our fine meal.

5/5 and a place I would have absolutely no qualms in recommending!
author: Henry M.

description: I came here after a Giants game with some friends.  We had some beers and they were all tasty.  I honestly don't remember too much about that day because I got too drunk, but I remember cute boys, chalk boards, and beer.  I'm giving them minus one star because they wouldn't let us sit at a booth and it was kind of difficult to talk to the entire group while sitting at the bar.  It's also a drunk girl hazard to limit us to stools without proper back support.  The bathrooms are clean though.
author: k h.

description: This place was packed and there wasn't a free table to be found, but it was a welcome refuge from the chilly May San Francisco weather (too chilly for this Floridian).
author: Jonathon S.

description: Great service, knowledgeable staff, excellent food, and imaginative and always changing menu. You can taste anything on tap with plenty of recomendations based on your preference. Go early to get a spot at the bar.
author: Chris W.

description: Awesome selection of beer... Great food..... Can't go wrong with this place. The servers are all very knowledgeable about the different varieties of beer and they have tiny beer mug that you can taste beer in... Talking about super cute and functional!!! Try bink blosem... Awesome beer!! Also don't miss the giant pretzel!! Goes well with beer!!
author: Emily Y.

description:
I was highly anticipating this restaurant. Similar to Chicago's Hop Leaf, the menu has a nice variety of tasty eats, and the beer selection is vast and delicious.  I'm sure both menus will only continue to improve as the pub matures. All the staff was super-friendly, which was a refreshing change from other beer bars in the city. I love seeing someone smile when they serve me.  Good music too. Nice ambiance. 

I found the bottle list to be pretty pricey - much of the bottles they offer I've bought for a pretty penny less, and I was deterred from ordering a few selections I was excited about, because I was unwilling to pay the mark up. 

I ordered my burger medium-rare, but there was no pink in the middle. Other than this small detail, the food was fabulous. In fact, there was a really funny guy next to us that exclaimed a loud "OooOOhhh" with each course he ordered.  The french fries, which are a special treat I rarely eat, were really really fantastic. Crunchy, then melt-in-your-mouth. My boyfriend also adored the "pot pie of the day," which was lobster! A very unique and exquisitely cooked meal, indeed. 
We finished off our meal with the seasonal cobbler - persimmon. Wow. It was wonderfully spiced, with a dollop of ice cream that melted into the pastry. I was in heaven, 4 sure. 

The funniest part of the meal was the coincidental bum-fight just outside the window. I guess there is a crack house next door, and two guys got rowdy over some rocks. It was an entertaining ass-beating that made my beer taste that much better. 

I look forward to bringing my friends here, and I can't wait to see what other beers they are going to have on tap. I hope they keep a good rotation, and keep smiling while they serve.
author: Cheryl J.

description:
Absolutely loved this joint and can't wait to give it a regular spot on the rotation!  The lighting and a few other accents remind me of a French bistro.  It's the kinda place that I'd want to pull up to the bar and stay dry during a long, cold rainstorm.  That block of the Mission could use some more class and these guys have found the right formula.

Popped in on a whim during the week and waited maybe 15-20 minutes (with a tasty Franziskaner Heffe) for a few stools to open up at the dining bar towards the back.  The beer menu was the most exhaustive (and descriptive) one I've seen and has something for everyone.  It's nice to see that they aren't trying to perpetuate the "let's try to out do each other's wine list" thing and are mixing things up.  And if it's a wine list you're looking for, there are about 9000 wine bars to choose from in town now (in case you hadn't noticed).  And for those complaining about the beer prices, well, there's affordable PBR *right* next door at Delirium.

Anyhoo.  So, granted, I was starving by the time we sat down, but the BBQ pork sammy that I had was pretty perfect.  The bread (from Acme, I think) was just the right softness/freshness and the pulled pork wasn't overwhelmed by the BBQ sauce.  Good sized portion along with a boatload of excellent french fries.

I liked that it was cafe style in that you order your grub at the bar and they bring it out to you when it's done (assuming it's different at an actual table).  Also dug the chalkboard that lines the wall in front of the dining bar (the wall could have been built taller to diffuse the bright/un-sexy kitchen lighting).  We got to hone our Hangman skillz!

Probably not a good large-group place, rather it's better suited for a more intimate dinner with just a handful of friends, I'd imagine.  Perhaps a date place, but not on the first.

Wish that I had a go-to place like this closer to my 'hood, but the distance won't stop me from going back.
author: Nick M.

description:
Monk's is almost doing it right. The beer selection is the obvious reason to be here, with a huge number of international brews to make any beerhound happy.

The food is slightly fancy pub grub, and it's adequate. The fries are really good. But really, who cares, once I've tied on a monk-induced buzz I'll eat most anything. You go to monk's for the beer, and have the handy option of soaking some of that high-alcohol sauce with a little food. With their beer list, I'm a captive audience.

That said, if you do get food at the bar, be prepared to do a lot of waiting. The bartenders seem to double as the servers for that area, including the hidden 6 or 7 seats out of their sight. When we asked the not busy bus girl about our check, she shrugged us off and said to ask the bartender. Dick.  So on the customer service front, even though the rest of the staff was quite cordial, they lose a few stars. They could stand to hire additional waitstaff.
author: MeatMaster X.

description:
I agree with Jessica J. There should be two slots here. The bar and BEEEEER side of things at Monk's Kettle is AWESOME, and the people seem to really know what they're talking about. Yum. I give bar a 5.

Restaurant side? Yeah. NOT so good. We arrived at 7:35, put our name on the list, were told it would be about 40 minutes, so checked back in a bit after 8, and they said ANOTHER 30-40 minutes, and then came back at 8:40 to be told "should be about 30 minutes". Um. What? 

In fairness, I did explain to the cute bald guy owner that we'd already heard that twice before, and he looked surprised and then comped us a round of drinks. So that part was good.

They then sat our party of 3 at a two-person table. Squished. Ok, I'm okay with that. 

Then the oven was broken. Wait. This place is new! The oven shouldn't be broken.

Ok, so no pretzles. Oh well. 

The food was really hit or miss. The salads were really good and original, if a bit small for the price. The black bean cakes? Super tastey. Same for the goat cheese fried up.

Not so impressive were the incredibly meager portions of meat or fish that we ordered. The tuna "steak" sandwich was the thinnest piece of tuna I've ever seen - it was literally 1/2 an inch. And I get that tuna is expensive, but for a $14 sandwich, that's a bit weak.

The chicken plate was also a sad, little piece of chicken. Definitely not worth the price.

I know this place is new, and I'd probably go back there, but they have a lot of glitches to work out.
author: Jen B.

description:
One word: impressive.

Five pages of delicious beer to choose from, one page of wine, and a double-sided menu of organic, "San Francisco" pub food.

I visited Monk's Kettle with the housemates yesterday for a night out.  We arrived around 7:30 on a Wednesday and the place was full.  There was over an hour's wait for the booths but bar service is first come, first served and as chance would have it, they had a spot available for us.   I'd hate to see how packed this place would be on the weekend so early weeknights are probably the way to go.

Even though we were at the back bar (near the chalkboard where a game of Tic Tac Toe was played), service was friendly, quick, and pleasant.  We ordered a first round and some appetizers and never felt pressured to order more.  But since the appetizers were so good (get the goat's cheese and spinach; the cheese literally melts in your mouth) we stayed for entrees and more drinks.  I ordered a chicken salad and while simple, it was executed perfectly.  The chicken was moist and tender, the salad well dressed, and the dressing on the side -just how I like it.

Definitely five stars.
author: A K.

description:
I think I've had the best service from a bartender in a long time (from Brad).  Great guy, loves beer ;)  Excellent ambience - small place overall (think 1 unisex restroom).  But they will not admit ppl into the bar if it starts to get full. A great PLUS!  I ate the pretzel with homemade cheddar ale sauce and stone ground mustard.  It came out piping out (like burn my fingers hot!!)  YUM!  Great IPAs.

Minus 1 star for no liquor!
author: Kristin C.

description: This review is not about the food or drink which are great.  Great place.  Awesome food and beer.  On Friday night 01-24-2014 myself, wife and a friend went here about 9:45pm.  The girl at the door said about 1 & 1/2 hours.  We waited about 45 minutes when she seated us.  We were at our table about 5 - 10 minutes when she comes over and says "  You have to get up from the table because she forgot to write down some other persons name on the wait list and they have been waiting 45 minutes and they are going to sit there."  I said BS lets leave and went across the street to  Picaro Tapas Restaurant which is a lot cheaper with a total bill for 3 coming to $47.00 plus tip.  Not only was The Monk's Kettle rude but embarrassing.  Funny thing our friend who is very clairvoyant said when we walked in the door that the vibe did not feel right.  Afterword we all felt that we were just not hip enough for The Monk's Kettle which is mostly Gen Xers with Tats.  Have been there only once before and love the food but i will never return and will spread the news.
author: David B.

description:
Probably my favorite restaurant in San Francisco that I've tried so far. Great food, even better beer. The waitresses/waiters are really helpful in recommending good beer and they're really friendly, unlike some other beer places I know of (cough, Toronado). 

Be prepared to wait for a table. They don't take reservations and it's a popular and pretty small place. 

Beer Recommendation: Dogfish Head 90 Minute IPA
Food Recommendation: Burger with mushrooms and Jack cheese.
author: Kenny L.

description:
As a vegan, I was pretty skeptical of the menu I found online for Monk's Kettle. Nevertheless, my friends and I had been wanting to go there for a while (got scared away one time by the 1-2 hour wait - yeah, be ready for that), and when we were fortunate enough to get seats (at the bar, mind you) on a Saturday night, I figured I had to give it the old college try.

The bartender who served us our beer and food was amazingly friendly and helpful! He gave great suggestions on what items were safe for my vegan-self, and he even checked my veggie burger when it came out from the kitchen to make sure none of that dairy or egg business had snuck into the dish. He advised me and my friends on what beers to order, and when my friend didn't like hers he asked her what she would change and grabbed her a new one, just like that. Actually, all of the bartenders here seemed unreasonably upbeat - I dunno if they are slipping ecstasy into the tap water or what, but whatever it is, they should keep doing what they're doing!

And while the service was excellent, please, let me assure you, it did not overshadow the tasty food and drinks. I've read some complaints on here about the veggie burger, so I don't know if they changed the recipe or if I just have an unrefined palate, but I thought it was delicious! I really liked it with the grilled onions and spring lettuce - none of that iceberg nonsense here. The fries were good - I am more into the thickly cut steak fries, and these were skinny lil dudes, but they were flavorful and not too greasy. My friends had the flatbread and seemed to like that a lot, too. The beer was also great! It was a few notches up the price scale than what I'm used to paying for beer, but that is partly because I ordered a bunch of imports. From what I scanned of the textbook they call a beer menu, it looked like they have a pretty reasonable price range. So yeah - prime location, fantastic service, yummy food, and amazing beer - Monk's Kettle is a standout!!
author: Kat W.

description:
I like pubs and I like gastronomy (for the most part). Dropped by here tonight, took a seat at the pub and started chatting up the bartender. Got a glass of Lebanese wine from the Beqaa (those who have followed my reviews know that I'm a fan of wine from off-the-beaten-path). The crowd seemed almost Marina-esque, but it is the Mission District. The women to my left had the Ahi burger, I had the hamburger, and the chaps to my right had Adam B.'s Giant Pretzel (only mentioned because the review is to my right and I know the chap) and one shedload of beer. I'm definitely one to share my food. So I told those next to me to feel free to help me out with my huge dish. Yep, these were American-size servings; I was promised I could have it for take-away, though -- this wasn't necessary. I also think I taled my way to my next job here tonight. If I do get hired by the chap, I'll be sure to increase my rating to 5 stars. Definitely worth a second trip. 

Now, why not 5 off the bat? Service is S-L-O-W. Makes MUNI seem like the TGV by comparison. When I tried to wave the person over to ask for my cheque, it took her 15 minutes to notice me. I wasn't at a back table, either. I was at the bar, pretty much squarely in front of her. 

Next time, I'm going to just toss a pencil at her or something to get service. Aye, that seems like it would work. =)
author: Hasan D.

description: I'm not a big fan of beer but here I've managed to find something that I really like! The Currant Cider is yummy! There food is awesome...you must try the fries, pretzel and mac n cheese! Monks Kettle staff are very knowledgeable of all the beers there almost as if you were at a wine bar looking for a specific wine!
author: Valerie F.

description: Monk's gets a full fiver for it's huge selection of specialty beers and being such patrons and proponents of the art.  There were plenty of interesting, complex beers under $10, but the more specialty, obscure ones, well, we'll just say art can be pricey--for good reason though.  The staff was on top of it, friendly, not overbearing and even took time to explain some of the beers to us.  You will leave knowing what a Lambic beer entails if you didn't already know.  You could tell they knew their stuff and seemed happy to work in beer heaven.  We didn't order any food but everything we saw coming out of the kitchen looked fantastic.
author: Ana B.

description:
I really want to give this place 4 or 5 stars because I love the variety of beer and it's potential but there are a couple of things that killed it for me.

1.  We asked the bartender to recommend beer after describing what flavors we like.  They were very helpful however one of them recommended a $23 bottle of beer (yes, $23 for a 12 oz bottle) to me without mentioning the price!  If I had known it was $23 I would have asked for another recommendation.  It is in really poor taste to recommend something that is way above the average or expected price and not mention it to the customer.

2.  It was 11:15 pm and when we attempted to move to a table that was empty we were told that we could only sit there if we were having dinner.  Who eats dinner at 11:15 pm at night?  The table was still empty when we left 45 minutes later.  Also our friends were turned away at the door during this time because they said "the bar was full and there was no room for people to stand."  What kind of business move is it to turn people away when you have empty tables?

Sadly, I can't bring myself to go back in, despite the fact that I love the concept and the huge beer menu...
author: Crystal S.

description: It's small, and can get crowded, but the food is delicious, the beer list is extensive, the atmosphere is good, and the staff is friendly and knowledgeable.
author: Chris A.

description: I love Monk's Kettle and I am not a beer drinker. They have a Ahi sandwich that I love. The flavors sesame seeds, wasabi-soy aioli, pickled ginger & daikon sprouts combo is perfection. The staff is friendly, causal and know beer. The parking in the neighborhood is non-existant and the waits are long if you go at peak times but it is worth the hassle for the food. My husband usually gets a burger and says they are great, though the last couple of times we both have that amazing Ahi tuna burger.
author: Tez A.

description: Our waiter was the beer whisperer. We told him what we usually like and don't like and he brought us our new favorite brews. Mine was Laguanitas Dogtown Pale Ale. The chickpea burger was awesome too. I went for lunch, I spent more than I usually would like for lunch, but I definitely paid for quality and keep in mind I'm a broke recent grad, so maybe what hurt my wallet won't hurt yours.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I had walked and driven past this place for months and last night I finally got the chance to go.  We walked in around 1030pm and it was pretty full of people (as expected on a Saturday night).  Pretty small place so it's not the best for groups.  Lucky us, a space opened up at the bar just as we walked in so we grabbed 2 seats.  I was impressed with the awesome and overwhelming beer selection from all over the world.  Prices range from $2 to over $60. 
Our bartender, Sayre, was great and well educated on all of the beers.  He helped us make our selections based on the types of beers we normally like.  We didn't eat meals so I can't really comment on the food... although we got an oversized pretzel that came with an awesome Cheddar Ale dipping sauce... I wasn't a huge fan of the mustard sauce it came with as it was a bit on the sour side and I like a zesty mustard.
Steve had his first Trappist Ale so it was a special experience for him.  We'll definitely be back here.
author: Alisa M.

description: Great ambiance, awesome selection of craft beers, and absolutely great food. This is NOT one of those pretentious places with tiny portions. The food is really well prepared, with substantial portions. Hits all the right spots. It gets pretty crowded on weekends, but that's how you know the place is great! AND, it is open until 2 in the morning every day!
author: B L.

description:
Pretzel with cheese and mustard is unreal.  So simple yet so good.
Beer selection is amazing.   Highly recomend the Speckled Hen.
Split the pork sandwich and ahi tuna sandwich.  Pork was amazing and the tuna was average.
Service was the best I have had in a long time.  Didn't try and rush you out to turn the table.
author: Tim G.

description:
Let me start off by saying that I am not a huge beer fan, so a place that has an enormous selection of beers is not going to get an automatic 5 stars from me.

I came here with a group of 7 or 8 people one night around 9:30.  That was the first mistake.  This place is small and there is no adequate space for a group to wait.  We stood around blocking the aisles and being jostled by the waitstaff for approximately 45 minutes before our table was ready.

We mostly tried appetizers, and I will say that the french fries were excellent.  The pretzel was good, too, although I did not like the cheese sauce.  What really bothered me, however, is what happend with our lettuce wedge.  

The lettuce wedge comes with a bleu cheese dressing, in addition to several toppings.  I liked the toppings but am not a fan of bleu cheese, so I asked for the dressing on the side in case someone else wanted it.   I also asked if it would be possible to get an Italian dressing on the side for myself and the waiter said yes.

Not only did the wedge come out with the bleu cheese dressing on it, it was absolutely DRENCHED.  There was not one piece of lettuce that didn't have bleu cheese on it.  The waiter said that the kitchen staff had messed up, but that unfortunately it was the last wedge of the evening, so basically we could either take it or leave it.  Since I was sharing it with someone else we took it, but I felt that we should have gotten it comped or something since it was their mistake.

I wouldn't come back here unless I was with someone else who really wanted to.  There are a lot of other places you could go that have large beer selections and comparable food choices.  I would NEVER come back here with a large group.
author: Gami G.

description:
Let's break it down.

Beer selection = freakin' awesome (5 stars)

Atmosphere = nice place (4 stars)
-but-
Crowds = out-of-control and the space is none too big (1 star)

Food = more style than substance... descriptions sound awesome with fancy mustards and whatnot, but the reality is blander than the description (3 stars)

Intangibles = if I can get some space, I usually have a good time here (4 stars)

Overall = 3.4 stars
author: David K.

description:
Beer: I am in love.

Food: Pretzel was dry. Fries were disappointing. Salad was forgettable.
 
I think future success of our relationship will depend on consuming a lot of alcohol before I consume anything on their food menu. And I am ok with that.
author: Rosie M.

description: Still loving this place, but I wish they would update their menu, especially the veg options. The black bean cakes & veggie burger are too similar - don't order both! But I love this place and everything it stands for!
author: Shal J.

description: I really liked the menu selection and the beer selection was fantastic.  It is a small, intimate space - but perfect for a casual night out in the mission.
author: Cherlyn M.

description: Cozy ambiance. Great service. One of the best burgers in SF, grilled to perfection (med. rare) with a nice char broiled flavor. Yum sesame seed bun...washed down with Reality Czech pilsner. Nice shoestring fries. 24 beers on tap. Soft pretzel was yum  and don't you think it should be for $8.25...It does come with 2 dips. They offer a beer pairing dinner with the offerings of one brewery each time..interesting.
author: Bleep S.

description:
I would probably give 3.5 stars if I could.

The good: Great beer selection and some of it is even sort of affordable. Tried two delicious beers for $10 for both. Both American made, one was a blond Belgian, the other was labeled an IPA but at 10% ABV came across more like a hoppy barleywine.

The not so good: Some of the beers are redonculously expensive ($45 for a half pint of Vintage Rasputin are you out of your fricken gourd?) and the cheese plate was overpriced for what it was. 

It just all felt a little too precious...but I guess I would put up with it to get those beers again.
author: Darien W.

description: A fun place with a nice warm ambiance. Went here on a scamper to find some good Belgian beers in the area and ended up coming back to revisit the experience. Nice draft selection. Good bar food menu with some helpful pairing advice. Bartenders seemed knowledgeable beer meisters. Prices were a little on the steep side but not completely out of line. Discovered on this trip that I'm in love with saisons. Cheers!
author: Michael C.

description: I would give it 5 stars if there was more seating area for dinner.  Belgian beer....and the food there is deserving of 5 stars.  Lobster pot pie?!  I've never even heard of that before coming here!  Luckily this place is far from me or else I would be a fat alcoholic.  Seriously.
author: Cindy B.

description: Awesome experience - the Homegrown IPA was so good: full of hops and delicious. I also had the mushroom flatbread which was perfect - creamy, full of greens and a filling vegetarian dish....
author: Emily S.

description:
just came from there tonite. 

bottom line, it was better when it first opened. i don't know what's up with this city, but why is service and friendliness such shite here?? no matter how good the grub (which it's totally overpriced here btw) or drink, if the service sucks, it destroys the whole experience. 

food - overpriced. DO NOT get the asparagus. you get about 6 spears, prosciutto, and some shaved ricotta salada. $12!!! insane! just get drinks!

beer - i am no beer connoisseur but when they have pages of it, you figure they know their stuff. BUT, when i asked the bartender for a recommendation, of course, in true douche-bag fashion, he brings me the most expensive draught, $12.75. i work in the industry, and ppl, please lookout for shy-sty folks like that. as we all have experienced, more isn't necessarily better ;)

overall, i ain't going back. why you ask? b/c i'd rather blow my money at a joint that serves half the beers but double the service/personality. viva la spuyten duyvil, broolklyn!
author: Mike Skinz Z.

description: Hummmmmm.............this place is good for having that one beer that you can't have any other place. However, a lot of the stuff they carry is overpriced. The place is overrun with yuppies who wear banana republic sweaters and discuss the awesome stock moves or new houses they bought. But if you can stand it and I mean that literally because it's always filled above the 49 people the fire department allows in there you can get that one beer you want, I was lucky enough to find a keg of sculpin on tap there once. the food is not all that either. The one good thing about this place is the fact that they have a updated list of whats on tap on the website so you can venture down when you see something you like. I recommend walking down Valencia to zeitgeist.
author: bart b.

description:
Second time:

I had already decided during my first visit, that on my second visit I would be having the pork chop.
