After a 45 minute wait, last weekend, this forecast came true.  The plate was really fucking good, the chop being a thick, well seasoned, delicious slab of meat, accompanied by buttery brussel sprouts.. and a melt in your mouth potato/cheese cake like thing.
author: Adam C.

description: Came here last night with a few friends. Obviously, perfect place for beer enthusiasts.  As far as food goes, the chocolate stout bread pudding is delicious. I got the pulled chicken sandwich and it was just okay. The place is small with only 5 tables to sit down for dinner. It gets loud the later the night goes on. Great service! I told the waiter what type of beer I liked and he chose for me.
author: Ayesha B.

description:
Monk's Kettle has a solid core but is rough around the edges.  

The core:  Beer
They do beer well.  They have an exhaustive list of brews from California, Belgium, Germany, and beyond.  The bartenders are very knowledgeable about said brews and they have great food to pair with those suds.

The edges:
1.  Music - I think the speaker was broken...could only hear bass lines and it was generally muffled.
2.  Space - there isn't much of it.  It is actually a really well decorated spot but there just isn't a whole lot of room.  For this concept, they could use some more bar space another bathroom and perhaps a lobby so the people waiting for tables aren't brushing up against your back.
3.  Service - Where the bartenders score in knowledge, they lack in the attentiveness category...we saw our salad sitting on the counter for about 15 minutes before it was brought over and then they brought the wrong main course...oops!

Overall, I have high hopes for this place...I'd love for them to read this post and realize that they should find another spot in the Mission with more space so they can really do it right.
author: Chris G.

description:
Kick-ass beers & food.
Beautiful decor.
Knowledgeable and super friendly staff.

A Mission must!
author: susan n.

description: Been here a few times now, a couple times for take away. Never a pleasant service experience - they can be downright rude if you aren't beer savvy. It is always sooo packed and loud that we just never have a chance to enjoy our delicious burgers in a way that we'd like. Takes forever to get service and order (again it's just over crowded, even on Mondays). Stop coming here people! I want to enjoy it too!
author: Tyler M.

description: Monk's Kettle = beer heaven. The staff here knows their stuff. I wholeheartedly recommend this place to everyone, but -- for those claustrophobes out there, be warned -- the tables are really, really close together.
author: Melissa S.

description:
I came here to check off the giant pretzel and cheese off my 7x7 list. I've been before but I ordered dinner. Luckily the afternoon of my visit screamed eat a yummy pretzel and drink some beer. As my Monk's Kettle luck would have it, I walked in and claimed the last seat at the bar. I ordered a rye beer to accompany my pretzel and the bartender questioned me to make sure I liked bitter beers. High Five for that. I do happen to like rye's but I was happy to know she was on her game. The pretzel was awesome and definitely deserving of its place on the top 100 SF eats list. The mustard was actually my favorite topping but the cheese was tasty too. In less than an hour I had carbo loaded to the max so I escaped with only one beer. 
  When I ate dinner here the portion was HUGE. I got two entire meals out of my pork chop dinner including both side dishes. It's almost ridiculous how much food they give you. All in all this is a great spot. It gets a bit crowded and I've lucked out for seating during both my visits. But even if there is a wait, it's worth it
author: chelsea b.

description:
yum yum yum food, serious beer selection, san francisco prices, pretty OK crowd.

late-night food option that won't give you a tummy ache.
author: Miranda E.

description:
Giotto di Bodone is said to have once painted, with a single stroke, a perfect circle that was used to prove his artistic brilliance to the Pope, who had sent a courtier to find the best painter in Italy.  An Italian proverb inspired by the story reads: "Perfetto come la 'O' di Giotto" or "As perfect as Giotto's circle."  Perfection of even the simplest of acts is undeniable, an achievement of skill and execution that is both noteworthy and singular.  

At The Monk's Kettle, their perfect circle is their fries.  Fries are deceptively simple to make but any chef worth their salt knows that frying is not  a simple cooking technique; there are so many variables in perfect frying (the condition of the fat, moisture content of food, amount of surface area, etc) that is as much an art as science.  The Monk's Kettle has perfected their art and subsequently turns out the most heart-breakingly perfect fries that even the Pope would weep.  In the two orders of fries we had with our meal, not one was limp and soggy.  Every single damn fry was perfectly cooked to crisp golden-brown deliciousness, an archetype of what french fries should be.

While the fries are transcendent, the focus at The Monk's Kettle is beer.  A board over the bar has a quote by Kaiser Wilhelm, "Give me a woman who loves beer, and I will conquer the world."  Not content with a couple of taps, their beer menu alone is over 5 pages.  Our server was helpful with recommendations and I settled on a De Koninck Belgian Pale Ale and my friend had the Frambozen Raspberry Brown Ale.

The food is grown-up pub grub, familiar and with thoughtful touches that keep it sophisticated but not pretentious.  Between us we had the vegan chili, pretzel, Angus burger, and the salmon sandwich.  I had the salmon sandwich, which was cooked just south of perfect at medium, but a forgivable offense with the delicious olive tapenade aioli and crispy shallots.  I didn't try my friends' food but plates cleaned of each speck of food speak volumes.

The Monk's Kettle is a neighborhood joint that keeps it fresh and sexy, classing up the traditional burgers and brew without a hefty price tag.  Its my kind of place and the next time I'm in San Francisco, I'll be back.
author: C C.

description: What happened?! I used to love this place. Every time I had friends coming to town I'd make sure I took them to Monk's Kettle for their great food and beer. I don't know what happened over the last few months, but this last trip was enough to be my last. Not only were my favorite items now absent from the menu, but they've replace them with some of the worst food I've had in San Francisco. And the prices have gotten out of control! $8 for a beer I get at my local hang out for $4, $25 for a tiny piece of meat and some overcooked greens? I don't know what they did, but I'm so bummed that this happened to my what used to be one of my favorite go-to spots.
author: Liza M.

description:
everything you want in a restaurant: great food, great selection & great prices! i had a brown sugga beer, and a friend and i split the giant pretzel and the grilled chicken sandwich. we paid around $12 each, before tax & tip, which is a phenomenal price for how delicious our meal was.

be warned: it's a small space, and gets crowded quickly. my friend and i waited around 20 minutes for a table, but it was well worth it! get there early and put your name it, and have a beer while you wait.
author: Jane H.

description:
It's sad, but true. It's been brewing for a while but I think I'm starting to see clearer now and have concluded: I've begun to fall out of love with Monk's Kettle.
I know!!! It's such a cozy, fantastic environment with a delectable menu of beers and... man I still love those fries.
But, what's with the service? The well groomed and versed staff have begun to numb my delight with Monk's, causing conflicting feelings of appreciation for their praise worthy recommendations and thorough explanations of beers with questionable names and vague descriptions, and feelings of dejection from their frustrated, snobby attitudes to those less educated in the field of beer.
Oh, and by the way, the pretzel wasn't as amazing as I thought it would be. 7x7 may have placed it on their list of things to eat before you die but seriously, it was just another large salty ass pretzel with a tasty but not mind blowing cheese sauce. To be honest, I went with the ground mustard most of the time so ha! I would take the fries over those supposedly famous pretzel any day of the week.
Monk's Kettle, I think we can make it happen but right now... I need some time to myself.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Last night I stopped in with friends, eager to try the latest addition to the hip Belgian brew scene. Belgian brews seem to be everywhere now and thank the gods, the Toronado is supreme for selection but not for comfort. So this lateset hot spot, well, in my view, the scene domintates the beer. I didn't try the food, it looked good. Fries are my favorite food with a Belgian brew and their's looked descent. The place was packed. Its got a fun decor. Its another hip addition to the funky Mission scene.

But as for the beer, its far over priced, I was shocked actually. These prices might fly at a more swank restaurant along Union Square or Union Street. The selection was good, losts of types of brew from light and hoppy to rich and velvety to titilatingly sour. The selection was not unuque, actually, StarEll grocery has the same and more. The selection included more than Belgian as well so variety is offered. There are several bars and restaurants, even in the Mission, offering good Belgian brews at a fraction of the price. If you're out for the beer, try another. If you're out for the scene, its a good spot, fun was had. 

cheers!
author: David U.

description:
Pretty darn good but a little cold and a little little.  Not that many tables.  The starters were great (had the Spinach salad and the pretzel) and the entrees were decent (had burger and fish sandwich).  The service was nice, and two people for $50 was fine.  If the entrees would have been a little better, it would have been four stars.  Did not have any beer but had some good iced tea...

Make sure not to try and go on a weekend.  Hour plus wait most of the time.
author: Noa H.

description:
I love this place. I was cat-sitting across the street at the end of 2007. I'd just relocated to San Francisco from New England and this place  totally helped me with my jonesin' for the heavier-hoppier local brews back east.

My favorite beer is Dogfish Head from Deleware, it does not get shipped this far. But now I've discovered the Double Daddy  by Speakeasy (not Big Daddy by Prohibition, which is also fine but...)

Back in Dec. 07  I sat at the newly renovated and beautiful bar and was promptly served. I was also lucky enough to be introduced to the owners and  their righteous staff.

The Neiman Ranch burger is the only way to go! Sorry for ya if you're not a meat-eater. And I'm not usually so insensitive.

Update Summer '08: So Dogfish Head is now in San Francisco, 

Oh!  Yeah!  And guess who has it....
That's right...The Monk's Kettle. 
You guys are a dream come true. I am home!
author: Darla M.

description:
So this is my review on just the pretzel and the burger.

Im not exactly sure why people claim this place has the best pretzel ever. It was a good pretzel but it definitely was not worth the 10 i paid with tax and tip. The pretzel is definitely not giant, its just a large pretzel. I read someone elses review that said his pretzel was basketball sized. Maybe they made my pretzel too small on accident?  I noticed on the earlier reviews the pretzel was around 6.50 which is a MUCH more reasonable price than $8. In fact my sister was appalled that I paid that much for a pretzel when I could have gotten the same size pretzel albeit with many more different flavor combinations at Wetzel's Pretzels or auntie annies. The ground mustard I thought was disgusting. It just tasted like horseradish bits mixed with vinegar. The cheese sauce WAS definitely good but definitely NOT worth the $8. If you are rich and don't care about throwing down ridiculous amounts of money on a pretzel then go for it. However if you want to get 3 pretzels with more flavor combinations + a dollar back go to the mall food court!

The burger was good too but just good not great. Not worth the $11 not including tax and tip. Also the fries that came with it were ok tasting? Im not exactly understanding why people think theyre the best fries either. And this is coming from someone who loves mcdonalds and arby's fries!

As for service it took quite awhile before any servers noticed us sitting there looking very hungry or occasionally waving to get their attention. There was this one tall guy that wasn't even doing anything it seemed. Just walking around the restaurant and behind the counter looking lost.

So overall the food here is good but its WAAYYY too expensive. I'm sure there are many cheaper options in the city.
author: Em F.

description: This place has a nice vibe.  Our server was very friendly and attentive. And their burgers are really good.  It's always crowded and a bit cramped.
author: Eric C.

description:
the food has really improved in recent months, and they're nailing the beer business as usual.  and the bartenders still know their business like none in the city.  it's still pricey, but it's worth it.

and it's still too crowded for my taste often, but i figure it's illogical to criticize them for giving the people what they want.
author: Brad S.

description: My favorite gastropub in town. Such a friendly atmosphere and welcomes all folks of different strides, colors, inner beauty, and orientation - and that is really what has kept on drawing me back to Monk's Kettle. I've seen two very distinct bartenders so far, both have earned, in my book, the right of being knowledgeable of their stuff. You definitely have to try Meantime beer and those others that are tinged with caffeine or chocolate. Very intriguing stuff! Ask the bartender and s/h/ze'll know. They also have a decent selection of savories you can order at the bar if you happen to prefer bar stools rather than the tables they provide. Fries with aioli, onion rings and gigantic pretzels are just a few of the delectable bonne bouche.
author: Claude C.

description: Huge beer selection. I tried a thyme beer that tasted like my herb garden. Come here for the beers and fries with three sauces. The dinner of burgers was just what you would expect - nothing extraordinary. Great for first dates when you don't want to offend your date with weird smells.
author: Susan D.

description: Beer selection alone would give 5 stars. They have some fantastic Belgian beers available, both on draught and by the bottle. What ruined this place for me was the "hipster" tax that they imposed on their customer base. In recent months I've seen a rise in the popularity of both Belgian Ales and Belgian Style beers amongst beer enthusiasts like myself. Just because it's trendy doesn't mean they should charge through the roof for their beverages. 8oz of St. Bernardus ABT 12 was priced at $10.50. I know places in the East Bay that sell 11oz pours for $7 and I know how much the kegs cost. Their markup is absurd. My hamburger was fine, nothing to rave about, but certainly not worth the $15 price tag. Glad to see pickles on the menu, pretty neat that they have different styles offered daily. I've heard that they get extremely crowded during the evening hours. Pretty sure I would avoid this place at anytime other than off hours. I don't enjoy being crammed in like a sardine with a bunch of suckers who'll gladly pay that much for beer and food.
author: Christopher W.

description: Very creative and delicious food. what else to say... good vegetarian options. it's nice to both eat and drink in the same place - they do both equally well.
author: ari s.

description: I still hate this place.  I decided to give it one more try a few weeks ago just to be fair, and once again the bartenders and bouncers were simply the rudest people i've ever experienced.  for being part of the servile class they certainly put on airs.  You're batting 2-for-2, monks kettle!
author: Anthony L.

description:
i count myself a very lucky guy to have this place right around the corner from my place, and to have a friend in town on an expense account business trip to pay for my first visit here.

i will look to monk's kettle more for the great beer selection than the food. i'm NOT saying the food is bad or just okay, it is fine. 

holy moly the beer selection rocks and is too vast to write in this review so just stop in or check the website. i can tell you what i had and they all were to my liking, which might not be saying much since i'm a beer 'ho from the bottom of the list on up. for this visit i was living on the up list having the st. bernardus abt 12 coming in at 8oz for approx $10 or so. this is kinda pricey for my cheap ways of living, but this is where my friend on the expense account came in very much appreciated. 

in addition to my first glass of belgian suds, i went northern california with the old rasputin stout-nitro, and the point reyes porter, throw in some cured meats and a burger with fries and we had a nicely buzzed guy with a happily full belly and wallet with only a half block walk home.  


i call monk's kettle a kinda upscale beer joint with a very nice selection of lagers, ales belgian and not, porters, stouts, and even some wine for my wife after she tired of beer. just what i think will work in my neighborhood of otherwise divey like bars, which I like just fine too!
author: roger b.

description: Ok, I agree with all the other reviewers in that yes the Monks Kettle has a great beer selection -5 pages long, staff are friendly and food is pretty good but lets be reasonable $12 dollars for a 12oz bottle of beer!!! and that was on the cheaper side.  Now I love beer and willing to shill out a little extra for something different, exotic and well made. But I think Monks Kettle is pulling the wool over our eyes by acting in an unpretentious manner while selling over priced beer that is just equal to our own local micro brews. Nice decor, love the bar and all its glasses but the place is small so come early or expect standing room only. Worth a vist but takes itself too serious.
author: Brendan H.

description: Gotta say, I loved this place. I don't often meet a bartender I don't like and MK's was no exception. Bartender had an excellent pour [though I admit I'm partial to my own] and they were super nice. Gouden Carolus Tripel was not my best choice -- too bitter of a pale for me -- should have gone with one of their Doppelbocks! The pairings on the menu are spot on, and the Tripel was nicely paired with my delicious chicken sandwich -- just not my favorite beer. Weihenstephaner Hefeweissbeir was good, and their pretzel was AMAZING! Get it. Super 'cute' and cozy, close quarters with the people next to you -- so naturally I struck up several conversations. :D
author: Angela H.

description: I'd kind of put this between 2 and 3 stars. My co-diners would have put at 2, I was probably more a 3. The burger was tasty, the two different beers I had (both that our server recommended) were very good, and the fries, while not the best I've ever had, were certainly good. The others probably ordered less well, including the Bavette Steak, Grain and Chick Pea burger, and mushroom risotto. Of the three, the risotto (which I did not try) was viewed as being good, the steak was okay (but the much anticipated bacon fritters failed to impress) and the Chick pea burger, for a person who likes her veggie burgers, was pretty much uneatable (confirmed by the writer). The service was very good, both our server and the guy who helped with the beer were nice, attentive and fun. While I would go back for the beer, and would even eat there again, this is not a "dining experience," it is good food (assuming you order correctly), very good beer and a cool atmosphere. One pet peeve is web site pictures. If you look at the one for the burger, it looks like a million bucks. The burger (and other items) that showed up on our table were pretty much uninspired. While I could, at some level, really care less about presentation in a beer joint, there is a certain degree of misrepresentation. Just a small deal, go, have some beers and grab a burger, this is a pretty good place.
author: C G.

description:
This place sucks.
Exorbitant prices, terrible food and spotty service.
I don't know how it even survives it's location in Mission hipster center with so many better choices around.
At yet another failed attempt at taking the boyfriend somewhere cool while he was visiting I thought we'd pop in here. It LOOKED promising what with an extensive beer selection and close proximity to where our hotel was. Unfortunately it was anything BUT a good choice.
My boyfriend's steak pot pie was an abomination NOT deserving the name of "pot pie" it was, as he so aptly put it, "a donut on top of a bad curry." Seriously. There was no crust surrounding the interior of the ramekin housing this noxious curry "stew" but a beignet with some salad greens resting on top. The taste sucked and there was hardly any steak to be found in it. My macaroni and cheese was supposed to include bacon but the server forgot it and instead brought me a side of crumbled bacon bits. WTF?! It's not the same taste sensation AT ALL! And he wouldn't be deterred from doing so. The mac and cheese wasn't cheesy enough and had a creamy and bland sauce. Great. The beer was the best part but also the priciest and not worth it in my opinion. I can have Saisson Dupont for far less pretty much everywhere else in the city.
An absolute waste of $55.
author: Jill D.

description: Also got Duvel Green beer here. Very good combo with the giant pretzel and great selection of Belgian beers. Giant pretzel came with two sauces, both the mustard and a cheese one. Mustard is very standard, but the cheese was... really great. Not overly salty like those you find in malls and it really was giant. Will have to come back more often.
author: Oliver L.

description: The beer list alone would keep me coming back.  But, the best thing about the Monk's Kettle are the incredibly knowledgeable staff: educated and enthusiastic but not so far into food-snob-land that they have lost touch with reality.  Reality: a drink is just a drink, not the meaning of life.  I like this place because it has a finely curated menu while not taking itself too seriously.
author: Caricia C.

description:
The beer selection is, of course, fantastic and the food is great.
But really I wanted to write a review for the very sweet doorman who was very nice to us while we waited and even took our drunk note in stride. Thanks, tiny hipster.
author: Gail P.

description: This place has a great beer list. They even have a beer from Vermont (my home state) I was impressed. The food was great pub food. We had the Baked Laura Chenel goat cheese, as a starter and split the lamb burger for a main course. The burger was like a Chawarma, very different and very good. I had a few of Mamas Little yella Pils to drink and they were yummy. The only down side to this place was it is small and there is a long wait. but it was worth it.
author: Alisha W.

description: I really like this place.  Great food and an excellent beer selection.  The waiters really know the food pairings and can recommend a good beer to go with any food or mood!
author: Chris B.

description: Incredibly strong beer selection coupled with better than average food. I  love their veggie burgers, totally different than any I've had before. Decent charcuterie plate, good mac and cheese.
author: jen w.

description:
One star? Yep, that's all this place deserves.  My friends and I were spent about 3 hours here and also a few hundred dollars.  The first server we had was nice.  She never screwed up our drink order and was generally ok.  We started with their giant pretzel appetizer.  It looked so awesome, but it tasted like vegetable oil and was way too salty.  I think it was like $8 bucks, too.  Our sever moved us to another table for dinner.  Our new waiter was this tall hippy guy.  He seemed cool at first, but then it became apparent that he was ridiculously sarcastic/serious.  See, this is a contentious point between me and my friends.  The dude seemed like the most sarcastic man in the whole world, but at the same time he wasn't sarcastic at all.  I found out that he wasn't sarcastic while waiting for the bathroom for 10 minutes, I asked him if he had any bread he could bring to the table.  It seems normal to offer patrons bread when they are drinking tons of beer and eating, right?  Anyways, he said no they had no bread.  The steak sandwich I ordered was on french bread so I figured that they'd have bread around.  I explained that I wanted some bread because I had some expensive cheese that was melting in my purse (ew).  I didn't want to throw out the cheese and I figured we were spending a bunch of money so what did they care if we ate our own cheese.  Well, our giant hippy waiter informed me that I should not eat my own cheese because it would really upset the chef.  He's apparently very *picky*.  If the chef saw my table eating non Monk's Kettle cheese, he would flip out and stab us with some large butcher's knife.  OK, not the words of the giant hippy, but that was the gist.  This all sounds sarcastic, right? Well, it's not.  He was serious.  I confirmed his seriousness when I asked, "hey, but you wouldn't rat us out to the chef, would you?"   The giant hippy replied that he would.  :(  He then suggested that we order the giant pretzel, again, and some Monk's kettle expensive cheese.  And then two women walked out of the single stall bathroom......So weird.

When my steak sandwich came, I tried to take a bite and I found it to be incredibly chewy.  I investigated my "medium rare" skirt steak sandwich and found that the steak was cold in the center and basically still alive (seriously).  It even tasted a little fishy.  I sent it back and when it came back to me, the giant hippy said, "Aren't you a lucky girl, young lady?".  I'm pretty young, but it really wasn't cool for the giant non-sarcastic hippy server to belittle me like that.  He never came back to check on the done-ness of the sandwich, and it turned out that it was just as rare as before.  I ate two tiny bites and called it a day.      

So, overall, I guess this is a decent place to spend the afternoon, but just go for drinks and don't order any food and beware of the giant non-sarcastic hippy jerk.

**UPDATE**

Apparently, the chef at Monk's Kettle just messaged me.  Here's a copy of his very mature response to my review: 

Senor B.
Block User    
37 minutes ago 

I'm the chef at Monk's Kettle. That by far was the funniest review of our establishment since we opened. I thank you for writing the best piece of fiction I've read in years. If it were true it would of been even more amazing but the only thing that rang true in that whole statement was 1.) We don't allow outside food for any reason in our tavern because we have a full size menu and frankly, it's just plain tacky to even ask and 2.) your 95% eaten steak sandwich medium rare was brought up to medium. Other then that, if you really think that a chef was going to murder you and the rest of your party for asking for bread, then you have bigger issues then a bad experience at Monk's but I do thank you for patronizing our very successful establishment and welcome you back anytime. Thanks for the laugh!!!! :D
author: K B.

description:
very cool place with an awesome beer selection but all is not perfect in the world of Monk's Kettle. Space is a problem so if you can't get seated straight away you're left to either hang out of the street (not advised - we were told to go fuck ourselves when he didnt give money away to homeless dude) or to huddle together in any microcrevice not occupied by a table. THe bar staff were cool but the waitress staff seem hassled and pissed off

tasty food and tasty drinks - just be careful - many of the beers are 9% and above !
author: Stuart g.

description: Love it! They have some great beer available, but I go for the atmosphere. It's warm, inviting, and laid back, but not too laid back....  I enjoyed the Kettle!
author: Heidi L.

description: Yes, they have a phenomenal beer selection, but how in the world am I supposed to enjoy it smashed in the corner with no room to sit or move?  The layout of this place needs some serious work, but other than that, I'm a fan of what they offer.
author: Christine M.

description: Came here for dinner and drinks on two separate occasions.Great selection of beers.  Love the mac and cheese.  The pretzel was too salty.  The beef wellington special was great.  Definitely will come again.
author: Ben C.

description:
Before I get started I'm going to admit this right now: I'm from Philadelphia where I am blessed to have dined many times at Monk's Cafe which is rated one of the best Belgian restaurants in the country and one of the best bars for beer selection in the world. When I see a restaurant with Monk's in the name I immediately assume that I will experience something similar to my beloved hometown joint, but unfortunately that isn't always true.

I consider myself a beer enthusiast and when I learned of Monk's Kettle I knew I had to check it out. At first glance of the food menu I was surprised that one of the most important items on a Belgian menu was missing - mussels. Disappointment aside, I picked up the beer list to get a footing on their selection. I was thoroughly impressed by the draft selection.. around 20 beers including a lot of locals and several Belgians. I ordered a double-IPA and went back to figuring out what to eat. For it's location I found MK's menu to be extremely overpriced. A burger will set you back $11 without toppings with an outrageous $2 for mushrooms, $1 for caramelized onions and more for cheese, etc. My date's burger came out to about $14 with toppings. I opted for the pulled-pork sandwich.

The food arrived rather quickly which was impressive considering the place was full. The burger was presented on an incredibly nice looking sesame seed bun, but we were unimpressed with how small the patty was; extremely thin, a quarter-pound, maybe. The burger itself with mushrooms, onions and blue cheese was incredibly delicious though, great seasoning and cooked to the correct temperature. My pulled-pork came on an extremely soft (almost too hard to pickup) foccacia roll but the sauce was delicious. We were a little upset about the fries, they weren't so much frites and didn't taste like they were handcut.

With a decent food experience you might ask why I gave the 3-star score. The real reason is price. $14 for a burger of that size is unheard of, especially in that area of the Mission. On top of that I was very disturbed by the pricing on the beer list. Our waiter who was very helpful in the beer department suggested I try Russian River's Pliny the Elder double-IPA so we ordered a 500ml bottle with two glasses for $11.50. The beer was delicious but here's the problem. Last night I was in both Whole Foods and Healthy Spirits and found a 500ml bottle of Pliny the Elder for $3.79. Never in my life have I seen a restaurant mark up a single bottle of beer that much. Other beers on the menu reflected the same extremely marked up pricing scheme. I know I'm going to catch flak from fellow Yelpers who will tell me that these beer stores buy much larger quantities of the beer, etc., etc. but with Pliny the Elder which is brewed in very small batches that simply is not true.

I called the restaurant to express my concern about their pricing and the manager assured me that "that's just the restaurant business man, all alcohol gets a 300% markup". He went on to tell me how Pliny the Elder is a very limited beer and the owners of Monk's Kettle price it high to try to keep it in the bar as long as possible. I found this to be funny considering Russian River explicitly has copy all over the bottle urging you to drink the beer as close to the bottling date as possible because double-IPAs don't age well.

My anal kvetching aside, if you don't mind spending some money and have an interest in trying beers from around the world, check out Monk's Kettle. Me? I'm going to stick to buying my beers from the amazing selection at Healthy Spirits on Castro for 300% less. Ha!
author: Ben K.

description:
so my hubby and i went to san fran for a vacation between christmas and new years and monk's kettle was on a list of recommended places from friends who lived (and still own a condo) in the city.  we knew that reservations were out of order, like many of our favorite places in chicago, so we went, put our name in and went down to gestault for a couple of beers.  the host said he would text when our table was ready in 90 min to 2 hours.  after 90 min, i hadn't gotten a text, so we just went back and the host said he had given up our table because i didn't respond to the text.  i repeated my cell number that i had given, but he had written it down wrong.  thankfully, he promised us the next available two top and we waited for less than 5 full minutes at the bar while we got a beer.  the liquor shelf, i will say, is lovely and impressive and includes carved animal heads (can't remember what) at eat end like the bow of an impressive ship.

my hubby was not feeling super well after all the beer and waiting so we didn't stay as long as i would have liked.  i very much enjoyed a salad and the most buttery burger i have ever had in a funky, stone-enhanced, booth.  the beer book was extensive but definitely missing some major regional craft beers from across the nation that i would have liked to have seen on the menu.  nonetheless, i would love to come back to try a full entree and more beer.  

i will say that for its size, this place this place seems to allow more people than a legal capacity should allow, but i'm not sure how san fran ordinances work compared to chicago.  there is also only one bathroom (literally one toilet) for the whole place, which is very frustrating for a place where so much alcohol is consumed.  this place is clearly cool, tasty and vibrant for young urban hipsters and those who like (like myself) young urban hipster places, but there seems to be a need for a spatial rethinking of this place.  the dollars seem to be flowing in, so i think they could make it a priority.
author: Jen J.

description: Man this place was packed at around 1pm on a Tuesday afternoon. Mike and I found a spot at the end of the bar and enjoyed a couple of beers. I tried a stout that tasted like coffee- I wish I remembered what it was called. Our server was awesome. He helped me decide what beer to get by giving me samples of mini mugs of different beer- they were so cute! Mike got Pliny the Elder, but didn't' like it. I liked the huge menu, but it was a little pricey.
author: Mel C.

description: I love gastropubs, and I love Monk's Kettle. This is such a great little gem tucked away in kind of a hipster-ghetto corner of 16th street between Valencia and Guerrero, and the beer selection is incredible, and the food is bomb-diggity. I love the moderate portion sizes, wonderful marriage of flavors, and great quality of ingredients. Beef cheeks with polenta was some of the tastiest beef cheeks I've ever had - rich, buttery, and melt-in-your mouth! The burger is to die for with plenty of juicy fatty beefy goodness, onion jam, and artisan ACME bun, and I love the use of seasonal ingredients like the potato-corn chowder I had there the other day. I ordered some beer to taste as well, got the plight - and it did not arrive in time, so the server brought us four different other kinds to taste as well. The price is pretty moderate for an establishment of the calibre I think, and everything is perfect for sharing. Service, while a little airheaded, is still extremely on the knowledgeable and on the professional side. Highly, highly recommended above other establishments of this style if you're in this area.
author: Y K.

description: Best beer and food around. Daily specials on food and beer changes quite frequently. Simply amazing place. Come early and get you name in. Not much seating but worth the wait!!
author: Michael D.

description: I ordered the mac n cheese which turned out to be very bland. The toasted bread crumbs added a nice touch...now if only I could have tasted the cheese.
author: Lubs Y.

description: I love this place. The beer list is endless. They have a great, wonderful staff that lets you sample the beer before buying them by the glass if they are draft. They have the best french fries with 3 different dipping sauces.
author: tamster d.

description: This place is rad! The soda pop was delish, and apparently the Mead and Hair of the Dog "Adam" is great as well. The wait staff was awesome, and even for a packed Thursday night, they promptly found us an area to sit gave us plenty of attention. They made sure our glasses were full and that we were happy. What more can expect from packed house on a Thursday night?! Their beer and wine list was massive, and I can't wait to come back and eat their food..
author: alvir n.

description: Great place for beer lovers. The burger was just ok, maybe a little bland. The mac & cheese was delicious, and the pretzel appetizer is SO good. Again a long wait for a table, especially for a bigger group, but fun place to go if you're prepared for that going into it. They take your number and call you if you want to go walk around while you wait. Also be prepared that it can get a little loud inside.
author: Nicole L.

description: I love the Blanche de Bruxelles here! Thanks N for recommending! It is a delicious wheat beer that goes exceedingly well with the pretzel appetizer (and cheese dipping sauce).  This bar has a welcoming atmosphere, a fun chalk board to draw on, impressive beer selection and great food. A perfect place to hang with old friends.
author: Julie D.

description:
the monk's kettle is the size of a teacup and that makes for an uncomfortable dining/drinking experience. and drafty as hell.

my foodie friend said this was the most he's ever paid for the least amount of beer, and our food was only so/so. 

as far as service goes, the gal who was our server was pretty good and the guy behind the bar greeted us as we entered, which was nice. i just wish i didn't feel cramped- there were more people waiting than seated at full capacity...
author: Michelle M.

description: I don't like beer, but the food is awesome. The people that work there are really nice, and they even didn't charge me for my beer when they notcied that I wasn't even drinking it
author: Meghan B.

description: I happened to walk by this joint when cruising through the Mish and I was instantly intrigued by the menu.  Namely, my heart beat a little faster when I saw Giant Bavarian Pretzel on the Apps menu.  My date and I were prepared for a wait (seriously only 6 tables?) but unfortunately we had to wait about 25 more minutes than originally quoted.  Kinda not cool, but before I could get really grumpy, we were seated and I had a giant pretzel with a trio of sauces placed in front of me.  And fries.  Yummy, skinny, salty fries.  My salad was exquisite and my date voted his veggie burger the best in the city.  I don't even drink beer and I loved this place!
author: Lacy T.

description: Food, Service, Decor, Beer, Wine = one hot plate of awesome. So glad The Monk's Kettle came to the neighborhood as we needed it! The only thing that would help is if less people would show up when I want the burger...
author: sarahjane s.

description: Love this place. Cozy booth-dominated pub atmosphere minus the kitche.  Wonderful international selection of beers peddled by cool & knowledgeable staff & surprisingly yummy, yummy eats. Great low-key drink place.
author: Jamie R.

description: I feel bad. I was there yesterday and paid my bill as the female bartender was leaving but the dude with the ponytail said he'd comp me a beer for the trouble. Cool. Problem was I had no cash and was relying on my debit card. I left a nice tip for the female bartender who had left but couldn't leave anything for the bartender with the ponytail. The Oktoberfest was awesome. I'm there a couple of times a month and will over-compensate the next time. You guys rock!
author: Scott L.

description: Okay 5 stars for the beer, but 2 stars for the food. I thought the beer selection was great, and the fact that you can eat late at night is nice too, only problem is its a little bit over priced in my opinion. But again I cannot stress how great the beer selection is!
author: Steven C.

description: Four of us biked here to get our day drinking buzz on. Monk's has a second-to-none beer list and a non-pretentious atmosphere. Try the sour ale for something different.
author: Ryan E.

description:
What a great place!

Sure, it's a bit small (so what), and parking is interesting, to say the least. And the prices might even be a bit high. 

Note to most people out there: Money is not the most important resource!

Now, I'll get off of my soapbox, and review the place, just like a good little Yelper should. 

My honeybunny and I were tired of the Latin/Asian food paradigm that we seemed to be stuck in. After aimlessly driving around the Dolores Park area, (not to mention seeing the 5 hovering helicopters and demonstrations), we decided to park in the pay garage on Hoff. 

A little walk is always good for the appetite, as by this time, we were pretty much starving. 

My darling noticed that there was this cool-looking place with awesome decor. Dark-toned wood, great lighting and packed to the gills. 

Never being one to dawdle about food, we sauntered on it. Okay, maybe not saunter; more like edged our way in. 

Be that as it may, we were greeted by the friendly host, who cheerfully informed us that it would be about 30-45min or so. However, this fellow had an excellent suggestion. "Why not hang out at the bar while waiting for your table? If a seat comes up at the bar, grab it, and if you like, we'll still hold your name on the waitlist". 

Now, my friends, I realize that you don't know me from 
Adam (and St(Eve)). But you must understand that I love beer. Just like Tom T. Hall. 

I drooled with anticipation as I saw the 24 beers on tap; I didn't even know that they have stuff in bottles and cans. Even Olympia. Seattle sucks. But I do recommend the Reality Czech Pils. Also "Let's Go Shopping". 

Long story short (too late, I'm sure), our beers were fantastic, service was great; props to the tall fellow with the ponytail who made great suggestions for beer AND food. 

My wedge salad w/bacon was delicious; my Angus burger was piping hot and drenched in flavor. Honey got the scallop pot pie, and I saw paroxysms of pleasure cross her face as she savored her meal. 

Side note: atmosphere was fun, and everybody (staff and patrons) were nice and friendly. We had a great experience and will be back. You can count on it. Crowded? A bit. A bit pricey. Perhaps. Who cares?

Life is too short for that "subtractive synthesis" mindset. 

Lighten up, folks...enjoy the Monk's Kettle. 

Scott Kathan
author: Scott K.

description:
Give me a place with over 100 beers to choose from and I am a pretty happy bitch. Serve that beer in a tiny, freezing cold 'restaurant' with overpriced food that fails to gratify and I'm less on the happy side and more on the bitchy.
I believe they're trying to be ironic or they think because they're in the Mission they have to serve Oly in a can and PBR. However, I believe it would be in their best interest to focus on what they're doing. Plenty of ignoramuses have been and will be packing the place in, then they'll end up going to a neighboring bar if they truly want to 'slum it' before heading back across the bridge, tunnel or waterfront condo landing they came from.
The charcuterie plate was ok, nice prosciutto & pate, standard fare salami, but the pulled pork on the side was like an afterthought and quite bland. The cornichons and tomatoes were sweet and delicious, all this was accompanied by a peasants share of strange toasts. The fried goat cheese atop garlicky spinach left us unimpressed and the $6.50 pretzel was seriously undercooked and inedible.
I'll take a pass on the Monk's Kettle.
author: Colleen B.

description: Based on one visit this place is great.  More beers than you'll make it through in two nights, good burger and fries, and the waitress was outstanding.  Helps that we got there early enough to get a table, as it gets really crowded, but that is the norm for Friday in the Mission.  Great place to take off early and get a head start exploring  some beers you've never heard of.
author: Kean S.

description: Oh Monk's how I love you. If it weren't for the long waits for tables then It would be a 5 star rating.  When I moved back to SF my friend took me here, I was so impressed by it that I ended up making it a second home for a good two months. It's got a fun, friendly, and knowledgeable staff, exceptional beer selections and very tasty food. Love it here, I'll continue to come back again and again. The size of the place ads to the charm, and having to wait for a table just means you'll be drinking great beer for longer - in my book that's not always a bad thing.
author: Courtney H.

description: I REALLY want to like this place. If it were only up to the beer selection, I would love it. I've been twice now and both times the beer was excellent but the food was hit and miss. The pretzel was seriously fantastic. The salads had nice ingredients but the dressing was minimal and bland. The burgers had potential but everyone at our table said they were undercooked for their order. (You can't overestimate how much a person who likes their meat *medium* does NOT want to see bright red in their patty.) The fries are good if you like 'em salty. Service is friendly but on the sloooow side.  I'd like to go there for just beer and pretzels, and maybe when the crowds die down, I will. Meantime,  fingers crossed that the food improves!
author: stephanie s.

description: Not bad.  The Monks Kettle has a wide variety of beers from every country imaginable.  It is like a world tour of beer.  As if that were not reason to love this bar, I like the atmosphere as well.  The bar is a wide hallway with some booths on the side.  It has the feel of a casual European pub.  I like it!  They have a decent wine selection for those of us not partial to beer.  However, if you are a beer freak, do come here and try some brew.
author: apple r.

description: We've been trying to get in here for a while, but they've always been packed (really PACKED), and the place is a tad small so it's not quite fun to wait around for a table while bumping into chairs/ other customers and servers.  It was a late sunday night after roaming the town and we wanted the get a nightcap....low and behold to my surprise, monk's kettle had plenty of seats to spare, so we strolled on in... The bartender was pretty nice and laid back. Their beer selection is crazy long....but i had my heart set on my hitachino nest ginger brew, tasty but a tad steep $13.25.... will try something else nexttime!  Their fries with chipotle ketchup, herb and curry aioli was reallllly good.....will order actual food next time we can snag a table!
author: Tara B.

description: I was there for 20 minutes.  Servers could have been a bit friendly, servers, bartend staff was great.  Green duvel was my purpose there.  Glass was literally half full.  Bartend should take their time pouring the beer, it's ok for me to wait an extra minute For a 13 dollar 8oz pour.  As far as the beer taste itself...As a duvel drinker I'll take that up to Duvel.
author: Ray B.

description: This place is a treasure trove in the mission with a limited but well thought out menu that I would describe as upscale pub food with some impressive entrees that you would expect in serious new American-style restaurants- that are making the shift to locally grown, organic, free range and sustainable ingredients.  Perhaps testament to the chef/ owners capabilities to procure fresh seasonal ingredients and transform burgers, ahi tuna, or pulled pork sandwiches to new levels.  The wine menu is often ignored, however, the beer selection is what makes this place addictive- need your fix of crisp lagers, wheaty, hoppy hefe's, ale, ciders, lambics, stouts- the monk has it all.  I will continue to return to this venue for the mid-week thirst-quencher and moreover for their fine culinary options.
author: Akash D.

description: Was turned onto Monk's Kettle by the May2010 GQ article. Just moved to SF and was looking for a good GastroPub. Wow, this place hit the spot! Excellent draught selection (awesome IPA's) and killer Charcuterie and Cheese plate. Pretzel is phenomenal (makes me miss Munich and Oktoberfest) and the Mac & Cheese is so rich, even I had to box-it to go. No small feat for any food group!
author: Nick P.

description:
beer! i found a beer i love!!! im usually not a beer girl. im not a beer girl! and the bartender who rules! the guy with the dark hair and ponytail dude you rock.

the soft pretzle plate sized with sauces ! omg took me back to nyc street food, and oh man
DUCK prosuccitto! fuckin a that ruled.

the music...all beatles all the time. blech.
author: dawn a.

description: What an awesome experience. This laid back place is a wonderful way to enjoy an evening of beers with your friends. All the times I've been there the wait is about 30-45 mins but its worth it. This is a kind of place to keep an open mind and an open wallet. Not that it's extremely expensive to come here but when you ask the waiter to recommend drinks for you, you have to just go with it. The last time I came here with some friends we asked our waiter to bring us something. He took one look at us, asked us a question or two and BAM the drinks were on the table. My favorite part is the presentation. They pour from the bottle and spin the bottle around to get all the sediment out. It's just nice to find people that care.
author: F F.

description: I'm a wine drinker but it's pretty overpriced here so I tried a beer; the big shocker is that I actually liked it!  Something dark and sweetish and super tasty.  Sadly, I went back to get it the following week and it had disappeared from the menu.  Went for cider instead which was also nice but a little too sweet.  Food is a little pricy but tasty for the most part.  Fries were average but I would order them again just so I could smother them in the delicious sauces served alongside.  Expensive, but a nice treat
author: Alicia B.

description:
UPDATE 1/21/08: And, yes! The food is quite good. A friend and I had dinner there on Friday night and enjoyed the white bean bruschetta, the flank steak sando with gorgonzola aioli (YUM), and the burger, which my friend said was good, though the bun was toasted a bit too much and part of it was rock hard. I worried she might chip a tooth... 

The service was friendly if a bit distracted. It was Friday after all. It was very busy, so I'll not bitch too loudly. Regardless, it is defintely worth a visit. However, I must reiterate that you should avoid the place on popular nights or peak hours. The crowd in there was huge and obnoxious. Again, it was Friday night, and you know, the mission on a Friday... so, I shouldn't expect otherwise...

Original review:
The caveat is our experience was limited to beer. I cannot yet speak for the food or the service of any staff member besides the bartender. But, I fully anticipate a return visit on, say, a Monday or Tuesday night, or quite late on a Sunday. The worst thing I can say about our experience there was the crowdedness. The place all neck, no bottle, leaving little space for the milling, eager would-be patrons. We hawk-eyed the single teensy bar table and ungraciously swooped it from under several others who were not so vigilant. 

All seating arrangements did seem a bit cramped, or you could call it friendly, depending on who you're dining with. I definitely wouldn't come here with a group that exceeded four very close friends. The room, however, despite it's, shall we say, cozy dimensions, is lovely, with dramatic touches of granite juxtaposed to the dark wood and lamp light. 

The beer list is not only extensive, but also educational, and, according to the brewmaster with whom I was enjoying the evening, unusually accurate. These people know their beer. Our bartender was a bit harried in dealing with the crowd, but we never waited too long for her attention or our beverages. We were also checked upon a couple of times by the equally harried waiter who was on the floor. 

After devouring an extra-large pizza for brunch while watching football in the afternoon, neither of us was much up for snacks, but the food looked amazing and smelled delicious and I saw people scrape their plates. The charcuterie plate in particular looked fantastic and their food menu in general complied with the principles of buying local and organic wherever possible. 

All in all I have happy feelings about the Monk's Kettle and plan to return there soon for a more robust experience. Though, at those prices ($70--including a rather crazy tip--for six beers. Granted they were quite expensive beers...) I'll probably wait for a pay day.
author: Sage R.

description:
This place is an oasis in the 16th and Valencia area. It's taken me 3 fanfriggin'tastic times to finally write a review... BUT, I'm am totally confident in my 5 stars. Every time I have been here, I experience amazing service, kick ass food, and beer that is to die for. The bald beer-tender, Sayir (sp?), along with his beer-loving brethren are super knowledgeable and recommended some amazing beers to a friend and I. The Ale Smith IPA is not to be missed, as recommended by said beer-tender.  
The food? DELICIOUS.
The fries are absolutely killer... a friend of mine who worked at Gary Danko claims they're the best fries in SF. 'Nuff said. (And I wholeheartedly agree). Came with chipotle ketchup, amazing aioli, and a super-delish curry sauce. Amazing.
Service was fantastic and working in the service/wine industry, I have been continually impressed by the staff's knowledgeability when it comes to beer. 
Please stop by to visit. Just don't tell too many people about this gem. ;)
author: Kelly N.

description: Oh San Francisco, how I miss you! Every time I come back, you tempt me with great spots like this. A full meal at 12:30 am in a cool, down-to-earth spot to hang out at? Unheard of in Irvine. This spot is great. It's not a place that you'd go to in order to go out drinking with friends at a true bar. It's a place you go to with some good friends in order to eat and get some great beer. The french fries are awesome as is the mac and cheese. They have a huge selection of beer from everywhere and the staff is knowledgeable about what beers suit everyone's taste and what pairs well with the food you order. I'm starving right now and just writing this review makes me want to go back and eat there. This place is definitely a new favorite on my list!!
author: Lauren C.

description: Have now eaten the mac & cheese, the pumpkin & sage ravioli, and the hot pretzel while downing tasty belgians.  The food is awesome and the bartenders continue to be some of the nicest folks serving up drinks anywhere in town.
author: Melissa Y.

description:
I noticed the more and more you get out of the mecca tourist trap of Stockton and Market, the better restaurant atmosphere it gets...

Hence, this place which is about a $10 cab ride from there.

I must say, I loved our bartender!  She was totally cool and a genius in the beer world.  They welcome the opportunity to try their beers for free, with tiny beer stein samples.  Our bartender questions you like if you were on match.com, but then she finds your soul mate.  Mine was the heiffenweizen that was a special that week.

They have an enormous list that changes weekly, even daily.  The bar is very tiny, with about 6 booths and the bar.  What was also cool was checking out the distinctive taps and they had all the glasses that go with the beer!!  Even better!

I grabbed a nice bacon cheeseburger which was sooo juicy and huge!  My client had the scallop pot pie, sounds weird and tasted weird.  He was jealous of my burger!

Atmosphere was fun, locals who were funky and trendy, not snooty and posh.  Try and catch a cab if you love beer and go to this place!
author: Melissa D.

description:
the huge variety of beers will tempt you to be forever trying something new, and the cozy, rustic, somewhat polished ambiance is really warm and welcoming. Another plus is, they have killer fries, perfectly crispy and salty, served with a peppery chipotle ketchup.

Be warned: there are two types of bartenders/waiters at the kettle. The really knowledgeable, helpful, friendly ones (more common, and really lovely), and the really knowledgeable pretentious arrogant ones. Usually, you ask for some recommendations and they are more than happy to oblige. But I had an experience once where I asked the waiter to give me some advice with the extensive beer selection, and rather than helping, he was snooty and offensive, looking down his nose at me for my lack of knowledge with belgian beers. So to spite him I ordered the "Oaked Arrogant Bastard," a beer they have on tap. I think he got the message, though, because later that night he brought me a "sample" full pint of beer on the house that he thought I might like based on my taste. It was quite good. So I think we made amends.
author: Alisa R.

description: The main reason I rate this 3 stars is the price $14.25 for a beer is a bit silly for this place in my opinion. The beer selection is supreme and pricey if you go with the waiter recommendations- who really know their beers when you tell them what you like and drink (but didn't recommend draught as an option until I mentioned the first one I tried was a wee bit pricey). The food was good, however, smaller portioned. My friend and I went there thinking we'd leave full and satisfied. We had to keep ordering. We had the roast pork grill of the day ($23)  and the burger ($16 w/ bacon added) to split each along with each ordering an appetizer. Drinks add up fast. Great date place and definitely a scene to see- the place is packed and you need to get there before 6pm to even dream of not having a wait. The food is very good, we just thought the portions were small for the price. The beer selection is good, just overpriced. I would go back and probably order different things, the people next to us knew what they were doing and seemed to enjoy their food immensely! Also I would rate this place not 2$$ but 3$$$.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
Meh, I came here and all they have is 130 different types beer...what a disappointment!  Then I went over to the Roxie and all they had were movies......sooo lame!  And then I headed over to Pizzeria Delfina, and all they were serving was pizza...hello, I want choices?!  Oh yeah, and Monk's Kettle was extremely crowded which meant I had to WAIT and when people opened the door I could feel the cold weather outside.  I just can't believe they aren't more focused on becoming less popular and making sure I experience a constant room temperature of 72 degrees Fahrenheit.  It's so weird because from the outside I thought the place was going to be a 5000 square foot beer hall, but then it actually ended up being pretty small.  All the adversity I have to put up with!  I feel like a Darfur refugee!!    

Oh yeah, and the beer is sooo expensive.  I have to pay five whole dollars for a 20 oz. pour of beer that can't be found anywhere else in the city.  At almost every other bar it is way cheaper -- like $4.50 for a 16 oz. pour of Anchor Steam.  Also, they have PBR and Oly, which means they are just trying to cater to the filthy people who indulge in the cheap taste of alcoholic piss.  It is so fucking frustrating that they would have those two beers which ruin the other 128 choices on the menu!  There are also a few beers on tap that I have already heard of, which makes all the others taste bad.  

Last but not least, I brought my hot date out for a five star meal at this "restaurant"  and all they had was organic, sustainable pub fare. I mean, come on -- only 13 or 14 different choices of food to eat?  Didn't you guys bill yourselves as Gary Danko's sister restaurant?  You seem to have more beer than food!  What is this, some kind of "BEER AND WINE TAVERN"? If so, why should I even come here and get a BBQ Niman Ranch Pulled Pork Sandwich, Braised with Housemade BBQ sauce when I could just go over to Zeitgeist and get a grilled cheese for $3? Oh, the gall.

I guarantee this place doesn't make it in the mission. It is way too crowded and nobody around here even likes beer.
author: Bert M.

description: Alright... I'm giving the Monk's Kettle 4 stars for the beer and hot pretzels alone. Their beer selection on tap is incredible (i recommend the Hop Stupid or Dead Man Ale) and the atmosphere is perfect if you can get a seat at the bar. I've been in here twice now just for beer and have tried to sit down and eat twice to no avail. The last time we swung in it was an hour and a half wait. And the Monk's Kettle has no down time from what I can see, so the food must be good. I'm sitting here drooling just thinking about trying their Niman burger or pork sandwich. But the bartenders are super cool, ask them about the beer selection, go ahead, they know what they're talking about. Oh yeah, the remodeling of the place from when it was that two-bit burger joint is amazing. I love when people put extra TLC into a remodeling. Gives me hope that style and class still exist in this world.
author: Michael E.

description: Beer heaven. Tons on tap and a gazillion on their menu. I was jonesin' for a Pliny and sad to see they didn't have it amongst the vast selection of beer, but they did have some others by Russian River Brewery so I ordered the Damnation and damnit...it was pretty damn good. The atmosphere is nice and the food is actually pretty good, better than most bar food I've had. I had the seared ahi tuna and my partner in crime had a juicy burger. We were both pretty pleased and satisfied. I'm so glad we came before the rush and landed a seat right away cause this place gets packed and people wait out the door. Will definitely be coming back fo mo beer.
author: Cindy G.

description: Yes, I'm a fan of what is known as the 'gastro pub." Typically I look for a place at the bar and pick a Belgian quadruple on tap.  The staff is really friendly, helpful and relaxed considering how busy this place can get. I wish it were bigger and they would bring back the salmon sandwich... and more Belgian quadruples.
author: Heather D.

description:
Great beer, good food and a pleasant environment make this place great. What makes it not so great is how we were moved 3 times in our short visit. First, while there were only 2-3 couples there, we were told we could not sit at a table unless we were ordering food. We said that we might be once we looked at a menu but, instead of being seated in an open table or booth, we were directed towards our seats at the bar, right next to the thru-way into the kitchen. Then we decided to order food so we were moved to a table. When our server came back around, she then told us we needed to move to yet another table (from a 4 top to a 2 top) so they could seat other "dinner patrons". So, begrudgingly, we moved again to a table so small that the 3 plates we did order didn't fit simultaneous with one another or the two beers we were drinking. So despite excellent beer selections and the fact that everything that I ate was really tasty, I am not eager to repeat the musical chairs game while policy dictates action over common sense (aka, give the paying customers there now priority over "dinner patrons" who may or may not ever arrive.) Had I been made comfortable from the get go, we might not have escaped immediately after our check was paid.

The rub? The two very small women who were eventually seated in the large booth we were eschewed away from didn't end up ordering any food. Just a single beer each and then an hour to drink them. 

To Monk's Kettle's credit, they did comp us a single beer after bitching about being moved around three times. *shrug*
author: Rocky H.

description: A great chill, dimly-lit spot for a late night drink and fancy snack...crowded but intimate, with tons and tons of beers to choose from...the Raspberry Brown Ale was delicious! Also tried the raspberry chocolate fudge which wasn't too hot, but I'm sure the food is delicious...and who else serves a cheese plate as late as 1 a.m.!
author: Sherry R.

description:
Monk's Kettle does not deserve the beer they serve. If I was a brewer I would pull my beer from this establishment. Craft beer pubs should hold themselves to a higher standard. Here is my story: 

My friend's and I went to Thirsty Bear (which was wonderful) and picked up a flyer with a map of other beer bars in the area. We decided to head over to Monk's Kettle. 

When we got there, the DOOR NAZI told us that we had to have half our party eat. His tone was condescending and his body language aggressive. My friend told him, "I already ate, but my other friends will probably eat." His response, "I don't need to hear your life story." We were stunned. We should have left after that, but we stayed. 

We finally got in and the beer was wonderful (the food was below par) but no matter how happy I was with the beer, I could not cleanse my palette from our encounter with the hostess/doorman. 

I overheard another group near us complain about the doorman's interrogation process. This clearly was a problem for not just us. Monk's Kettle needs to change their policy. 

Don't waste your time at this joint, there are plenty of other places to get a good beer in the city.
author: Lena S.

description:
i've had two experiences here

both were excellent as far as the food and drink. tasty and diverse selections of beer, exciting giant pretzels and good array of meat, for those so-inclined

they've also been highly mediocre as far as the service. the staff is doing their damndest, but the set-up does not lend itself to a comfortable dining experience. 

you have two choices on a busy night (most), eat dinner and wait for an hour to sit, or stand awkwardly in the wait staff's path, and get pushed aside every moment.

if, you may decide, to put your name in, eat elsewhere, and come back for snacks, beers, and dessert, beware. we had said idea, and were indeed seated within 15 minutes or so. only then to be un-seated because we weren't eating enough. which is fine, if the staff had the courtesy to find us a place at the bar.

instead we were told that us being rudely advised to surrender our seats was, "just common courtesy"
author: Seiji C.

description:
I kind of have to agree with Wayne L. I was at the Monks Kettle last night with a small group of friends. The bar was moderately busy but definitely not full - plenty of room for more people. But the guy at the door with the clipboard didn't agree. He wouldn't let in a couple of my friends as the bar was 'full'. So our entire group left the bar and went across the street to Elixir. I told him on my way out that it was a crazy policy and he'd basically just lost the custom of 6 people. He just looked at me and said "I don't make the rules". 

So yes, this bar has lots of nice beer and some good bites to eat, but it just seems like they don't really want people to enjoy it.

Idiots.
author: tom c.

description:
great beer selection, yummy fries, neat atmosphere. 

I'd go again :-) 

I ought to take my hubs next time - he's a total beer lover!
author: Jodie B.

description: This place serves over 1,000 different kinds of beer. Well, maybe not that many but the beer menu here is as thick as a phone book.  I entered the bar/restaurant after I had been drinking all night - I was stone drunk, accidentally dropped my beer all over the table and one of the employees  refilled the my glass for no charge! What a nice lady...I then ordered a mound of delicious French fries for $5.  Not bad!  The perfect bar for beer lovers, especially smug beer lovers (wasn't really digging the crowd here).
author: Scott G.

description:
After hearing good things and building the place up in our minds, we found ourselves in the area last Sunday and figured what the hell.  The skinny:

1. Excellent beer selection.  The Hefeweizen was amazing, and if the rest of the offerings are even half as good, they're still worth checking out.
2. Good fries, but nothing special.
3. The burger was mediocre at best.  Cost $15 once all the toppings were considered, was worth maybe $5.
4. Crowded as hell.
5. Service was good, but again nothing special.

So basically it's a good place to stop by for quality beer if you don't mind crowds, but that's about it.
author: Dave S.

description: One of the best fries I've eaten. Crispy but yet not too hard - just the way I like them. The burgers are one of the best you'll have and there are some unique combinations. Service was good. Prices are a little above the average bar price. (2-4 dollars more than expected). Worth it though.
author: Genie H.

description:
Already checked out The Monk's Kettle twice and I have not yet been disappointed!
Their beer selection is absolutely amazing and it changes daily and the staff is very helpful in helping you find out the one beer that suits you most. 
The food was incredible, too, from the pretzels to the amazing braised beef cheeks, not to mention the roasted salmon accompanied by the best herb roasted potatoes I've ever had....
This place rocks- very busy for dinner but perfectly toned down for lunch!
 I definitely recommend it, especially if you go in with an open mind and are not afraid to try something original other than your every day burger or food that you are used to...
The decor makes you think of a German pub but pay attention to the details of the wooden frame of the bar...definitely a piece of art like you will not easily find anywhere else...
Looking forward to going back and checking out the rest of the imaginative items on the menu!
author: Le Big Mac A.

description:
the reason to come here is for the impressive variety of beer, american, belgian, etc. including microbrews.  the food though is overrated.  order the unusual beers like splurging on a $30/bottle or experiencing 12% EtOH...
food:
*Elbow macaroni, house-made cheddar ale sauce and toasted bread crumbs presented in a mini cast iron skillet with house-cured maple smoked bacon -- now that's an example of making the dish sound better than it tasted.  it was merely regular mac and cheese with some bacon bits.  at least truffle it.  $14 way overpriced
*Estancia Beef Flank Steak, grilled to order, and served on a Metropolis Italian baguette with horseradish créme fraiche, fried shallots and organic baby arugula -- so we add caramelized onions and not caramelization going on.  the meat was cooked nicely though and i would have liked more shallots
*Coleman Natural Hampshire beer-braised Pulled Pork with house made Porter BBQ sauce, served on a Metropolis poppyseed kaiser bun with jicama slaw -- pretty sweet, not a standout
open late
author: Rob C.

description: The beers here are amazing! Rigor Mortis Abt" Quadrupel is a MUST. I think I just found my new long lost love! I didn't really get to eat a lot here, but the pretzel was one of the best pretzels I've ever ate and the Fries are just addicting.  The bartender spilled some beer on me but took care of the Tab...and it was another Quadrupel!! Great spot to enjoy Great beer!
author: Brian C.

description:
seriously, why am i writing a yelp review when this place already has almost 600 reviews?!?

well because...this place is AWESOME!! it's always SO packed so don't go in a big group (2-4 is a good number). tons of beers on tap, and even more by the bottle. (even really cute beers from Japan!). the pretzel is a specialty, and really, all the food is good here. 

a bit on the pricey side considering it's in the mission, but well worth the trip to drop in for a beer. i recommend the maudite, a belgium strong dark. stay away from the amber ale - strange aftertaste.
author: Jen C.

description:
OK,OK, what is with all of the great reviews of this place?  Am I missing something?  A friend and I went there for lunch and we were excited about trying the gastro pub food.  I mean, at those prices, it certainly seemed like we were in for a good meal.  Not so much.
The charcuterie plate had a GREAT pate.  This was the highlight of the entire meal. Not sure if they make it in house, but it is tasty.   Too bad the sliced bread tasted like it was from last week.  If you are going to serve stale bread, then toast the hell out of it, goddammit!
Then we had two sandwiches and the bread was the same situation.  SUPER STALE.  What a bummer.  The fillings were good but isn't it the bread that  makes a really good sandwich? 
We each had beers and the total on the bill was over 50 bucks and I felt a little cheated.  We thought about telling the server, but we figured it wouldn't make a difference and then we would be "some asshole customers".
I would come here again, maybe for dinner.  It has been my experience that lunch has always been the bitch in a restaurant that serves dinner too.  That doesn't make it right though.  Their cooks need to have a little more pride in what they serve.  Where is the love...?
Oh yeah...the server might want to offer a dessert menu, to boost her check average.
author: Suzanne L.

description: I love the mac 'n cheese and the lamb burger at Monk's Kettle!  The place can be a little crowded, especially since the venue is very small.  But, the food and beers make it worth it.  To avoid the weekend crowd, try going during the week around 9 or 10pm.
author: Deven H.

description: This place is a new favorite for me. Not only do I love their huge selection of craft beers, but it's great how they pair them with food. The macaroni and cheese is awesome and they have a great selection of salads and sandwiches that have just the right amount of "gourmet" to match the beer in flavor and style.
author: Sara W.

description: Not so much. Its overpriced for what you get. The salad was a bowl of dressing with a slice of lettuce and 4 small tomatoes. The cheese plate was minimal. They have a huge selection of beers and should just stick with that.
author: Susan M.

description:
Quite possibly the worst service in the Mission. The food is acceptable, but the atmosphere is hell.

My husband and I went for dinner and drinks last night. We added our names to the waiting list & waited patiently in the ear-splitting atmosphere. About 15 minutes later we managed to get a drinks menu and ordered some drinks to keep ourselves busy. The drinks were fine and arrived quickly. About a half hour later we checked in with a waitress to see how much longer it would be for a table. She gave us a slackjawed "don't know." After pressing she informed us that we'd have to ask the "keeper of the list." Apparently, it didn't occur to her that she could communicate with her coworkers. Anyhow, when we asked the rather apathetic looking "keeper of the list"  for an estimate of the wait , he responded "dunno" and then went back to reading his newspaper outside.

Seated at the bar near us was an incredibly shrill woman with an unfortunate fondness for whooping.  It was so loud we both quickly developed a headache.

By this time we were starving and would have left if  that wouldn't have meant starting to wait all over again at another restaurant. When we were finally seated our waiter was fairly quick and the food was acceptable--in a batchelor sort of way. I had a pot pie that was no pie at all and looked as if it was topped with frozen puff pastry. My husband had a pulled pork sandwich that tasted of storebought sauce or some 
kind of lack of imagination.

All but the most confirmed batchelor' can make better food at home... and should try before visiting this place.

There were tons of staff, but not much in the way of service.
author: Shannon S.

description: New Years Eve party was unbelievable! The food and drinks never stopped flowing!!! Best nye ever, thank you!
author: ann l.

description: I've been here three times (mostly during the day) since that first fiasco (when an employee also sent me whiny emails about my review) and I've liked it a lot.  The service has been consistently decent and the burgers are worth the dollars.  When you're getting a quick meal to go on a rainy afternoon, they'll give you a tall glass of water and a smile at the bar while you wait.
author: Coleen B.

description:
i really wanted to "not" like this place due to all the hipster hip hip hype. instead, i was charmed by my bartender, who was kind enough to give me a few beers to sample before i made my final selection. 

THEN...i had the amazing pumpkin soup with roasted  pumpkin seeds. yum, yum yum.  it's seasonal and on the specials menu.  highly, highly recommended.  i suggest going during the week to avoid usual B&T crowd.  

will be back to sample $58 champagne beer from france.
author: Angela N.

description: My bf and I stopped in for some post thanksgiving food last weekend and were pleasantly surprised by a great beer selection (and informative menu with pairing suggestions) and delicious food.  We shared the special salad a beautiful assortment of chicories with a perfectly sweet tart honey dijon dressing and some toast smeared with rich and smelly cheese and followed it with the housemade (lentil based) veggie burger and steak sandwich.  Everything was delicious right down to the 3 dipping sauces (curry aoili, herbed aoili, and chipotle ketchup) served with our perfectly slim and crisp fries.  So good, and giant portions, especially for a post thanksgiving meal - I barely ate half my plate and left absolutely full.
author: Maeve C.

description: A favorite in the Mission.  Outstanding beer list including great taps along with great food to match though the food is arguably getting a bit too serious lately.  It's small and can be crowded but the service is not only attentive but generally knowledgeable when it comes to the beer and able to recommend great pairings.  If you want a little beer adventure - Trust them and enjoy!
author: Steve D.

description:
They have beer for the craft connoisseur, a small but decent wine selection, and beer selections for even people that don't like beer (try a lambic!).

The food is wonderful, especially when properly paired.  Their pork chop was a near-religious experience.  (Instead of "Om", we chant "Haaaaaaammmmm".)

It's pretty tight, they don't take reservations, so be prepared for a wait.  There are a few other watering holes down the street to tide you over, if need be.

As an aside, I cannot understand why anyone would complain about parking ...  given the amount of great beer here, I doubt you'll be walking away sober.   And it's easy walking distance from BART.
author: Stuart C.

description:
I'd heard good things about this place from some fellow beer geeks and stopped by earlier this month. Didn't have anything to eat, as I'd already had lunch. Here's the rundown:
