Pros - great draft and bottle selection, friendly staff, beautiful pours.
Cons - price. and price.

For my money, Toronado may have a little smaller menu board and slightly gruffer staff, but the prices are friendlier ($12.50/10z v $9.50/13oz for the same beer!)
author: Jason K.

description: Beer heaven. Tons on tap and a gazillion on their menu..Monk's has a fairly robust selection of beers. There are quite a few more belgium beers on draught in San Francisco.....
author: Joel Santos G.

description:
Arrived at 7:30 on a Monday, came here for a friend's birthday.  Started by sitting at the bar due to the hour wait for a table for 4.   The bartender let me try three beers in mini mugs, went with the Supplication... super great beer with a tangy flavor!  

Ordered the chicken sandwich, which was amazing!  Bacon, brie, aioli, chicken on a poppyseed bun with thin fries.  Really can't go wrong with that combo for a sandwich!  Our table shared the giant pretzel, also amazing!

Loved this place, and will definitely be back!
author: Claudia M.

description: I thought my mouth was big until I met the Monk's Kettle burger.  It's huge, and it's damn tasty.  Up there for me in terms of burgers in the city.  The beer selection is phenomenal.  I was with a group of 6 (which is tough in such a tight spot btw), but we all shared our beers and each one was delicious.
author: Em S.

description: We met here tonight for my birthday.  First we were 7, then we were 9, in the end we were 15 - way too many for the capacity of the Monk's Kettle.  We liked the experience of the beer, the food, and the company.  I would gladly go back again.
author: Tracy A.

description:
A surprisingly classy corner spot nestled in the mini-ghetto that is the stretch of 16th st between Guerrero and Mission, The Monk;s Kettle provides an upscale, warm and comfortable dining experience.  From the table guy who calls your cell when your table is ready to the knowledgeable-yet-unobtrusive server who guides your way through the overwhelmingly huge beer menu, this place does it right.  
The beers are many and tasty.  I placed my fate in the hands of the sever and he brought me a goblet of sweet tasty Belgian Ale, a hearty 11% ABV which paired well with the food we ordered.  A large basket of salty crispy fries with three tasty dipping sauces- curry aioli, garlic aioli, and chipotle ketchup.  The lobster pot pie was a creamy masterpiece topped with puff pastry.  The beef carpaccio was bland but its fried capers provided a crispy touch.
All in all, this place is above-average for beer and food, and the service is top-notch.  Can get a little noisy but it's not to the point of conversational inaudibility.  I'd recommend it wholeheartedly!
author: Eric S.

description: My new favorite hangout.  The beer's a bit expensive, but that's partly cuz they serve nice beer (but I'm fairly sure you can get some of the same ones for slightly cheaper at Toronado...but it's quite a different atmosphere there).  It's a warm, cozy place to hang out with friends--if you want to get dinner, there are tables and a delicious looking menu, but so far I've only had the fries, which are quite crispy and come with chipotle ketchup and some kind of aioli.  They've got a bunch of belgian ales, which makes me happy, and the bartenders have been nothing but nice to my friends and me.  I haven't experienced any problems with the crowds and have gone on both a weekend and a weekday.  Yay, Monk's Kettle, thanks for moving down the street from me!
author: Gina K.

description:
Great food. Great, but expensive beer. Main courses in the $12-$17 range. All the dishes we tried were excellent. We had the lobster pot pie special, the BBQ pork sandwich, and I had the lamb burger. The lamb burger was very flavorful and the fries were thin, but done well. The pork sandwich is very spicy but tasty, and the jicama cole slaw helps cool down the spice. Beer selection is huge and they will recommend a beer to pair with your meal. The Belgian beers we tried were awesome, but watch the price because the can get expensive. The second beer was a bottle for $10. 
Overall great experience will definitely go back.
author: Jacob K.

description:
beer?  not my thing.  i only drink beer when its mixed with coke or 7-up (see walzwerks).  so i was prepared not to like this place very much.

BUT much to my suprise, i found monk's kettle to have tasty food and a decent selection of wines.  kirk b and i got two appetizers.  the bruschetta with cannellini bean puree, sauteed wild mushrooms and white cheddar was awesome.  $8 for two pieces was a bit steep but it was tasty and mushroomy, the way i like it.  the black bean cakes with roasted corn salsa and chipotle creme fraiche were also superb.  the corn was crisp and fresh and the cakes were crispy on the outside and soft in the inside.
we then split the house made veggie burger.  i have to admit it was a bit mushy but it was still good.  the bun and fries were great.  we were a bit disappointed because it almost tasted like they took the less-tasty version of the black bean cakes and put it in a bun.  i think if we didn't get the black bean cakes, we might have enjoyed the burger a little more. 
finally, to end the evening off, we tried the seasonal cobbler.  we tried to decipher what fruits were in it but it was mainly various berries.  i thought it wa one of the best cobblers i've had.  the traditional crumble was gone and replacing it was a dense, delicious crust that almost tasted like a sugar cookie!  mmmm mmmmmmmmmmmmm.
oh and the drinks.  kirk b had an altbier. i don't know what the hell that is but he said it was delicious and it came in an awesome bottle that kirk kept.  i had a glass of riesling that also was good.
the service was great.  we went a bit early, 4:30, and was immediately seated.  with dinner and drinks, we were out by 6:30.  it started getting a bit crowded by the time we left but the service never suffered.  overall, i'd say this place is worth 4 stars but the cute waitstaff bumps it to a glorious 5 starts!
author: Thom Y.

description: I was surprised to just show up and snag a prime table at this crowded, little spot.  Tons of beers on tap, and helpful staff to guide the beer-clueless like me.  The food was A-ok and totally filling.  A bit noisy --not somewhere for a quiet dinner-- but the atmosphere has a fun buzz, with a mix of different kinds of locals mingling.
author: Ryan L.

description: I give it 5 because I LOVE beer. The selection is very accommodating to all beer drinkers who may be particular about what they like. The Monks Kettle is comparable to the Trappist in Oakland except Monks has food! The food is very good and would be recommended for food fanatics and beer fanatics. Or beer food fanatics for that matter. Start out with a giant pretzel, have a beer, work up your appetite to an entree. You will pay for the great selection of beer, and it is well worth it! Be advised it is first come first serve, so you may have to wait a bit for a table. Since it's location is good, the wait will be no problem.
author: Alex S.

description: You're new.  I get that.  But let me give you a hint.  It's one level of poor service when it's busy and you have a hard time getting the bartender's attention, but when you do, you actually get your drink.  It's an entire other level when the bartender, who isn't even that busy, takes your order and then proceeds to ignore you completely and forget about your beer for the next 20 minutes until your friend gets his attention again and reorders it.  And what's with the reserved table thing?  Some spots do a good job navigating the bar-restaurant boundary, but Monk's Kettle doesn't seem to have figured it out.  My roommate loves this place, so I might give it another try, but only on a night when I'm willing to wait a half hour for my beer.
author: Rachel B.

description: Sunday Nite---3 bar stools immediately avail....order beer for the boys, wine for me...fries with 3 yummy dipping sauces....goat cheese....best burger in SF--white chedder/bacon/onions....chicken pot pie was great but burger was amazing....can't wait to go back ;)
author: Trish t.

description: Ok, new favorite restaurant in the city. I travel to London occasionally for business and for the past few years they have had the "gastropub" trend going on. You take an old school British pub, upgrade the kitchen, hire a really good chef, keep the food prices reasonable and the people start pouring in. Hmm, imagine that... Well, Monk's does pretty much the same thing, but with insanely good beer selection to boot. I've eaten here twice now and have been completely blown away by the food. Had the lamb shank with veal reduction. Oh the bartenders there have been super nice and accommodating as well. There been a little bit of a wait for a table both times I've been but had a beer in my hand within minutes from walking through the door, with a packed bar in front of me. If it's packed, sneak to the back where there some extra bar space.
author: Keith C.

description: I can already tell this is going to be one of my new favorites. I too am a beer snob, so right away the place appealed to me. However, the food really sealed the deal. I was absolutely blow away by the duck confit my friend and I had when we went there on Sunday. The flavors and textures were all spot on. We also tried the vegan chili and the black bean cakes, both of which are also very good. I feel  like so many restaurants try to do similar things but just don't get it quite right. The vibe is totally friendly, both patrons and service staff, and it's pretty affordable. Also, there's a back bar that is first come first serve (the difference being that you order from the bar rather than a server), so my friend and I were able to walk in and sit down immediately. I can't wait to go back!
author: Meredith M.

description: PS Whatever you do, order a dessert.  They change regularly, and feature fresh fruit and oftentimes have beer in them.  YUM
author: laura g.

description: The beer selection here is great, but everyone knows that. The show stealer is the burger (cooked medium rare). Now if only they would make cheese fries with the cheddar-ale sauce....Also tried the cobbler with apple and cranberry, which was FANTASTIC. Not what I would usually order but it was incredible.
author: john q.

description: Went here a year ago, but just became a yelping reviewer recently.  This place is great!  The food is incredible and the beer selection as well.  Staff is welcoming and knowledgable.  We had an hour to wait for a table and it can get pretty cramped in there, but was well worth it!  Can't wait to go back!
author: Dan Z.

description: Small place, very cozy.  Overwhelming beer selection and pretty decent food.  I'd say stick with the burgers and fries though, as a friend who dished out the dough for the pork chop was a bit disappointed, while the rest of us burger-munchers, fingers covered with grease, were all happy.
author: Andrew P.

description: They've got a fun, eclectic beer menu but the food is fairly mediocre. I'd heard so much about the place I was quite disappointed. Usually I don't review after one visit but I see no need to go back.
author: laura a.

description: I stopped in at the Monk's Kettle before a late dinner the other night. The beer menu is extensive, and my date enjoyed his dark beer (arrogant something or other). I had the black currant cider, which was sweet, tart, and tasty. The vegan chili was very mushroomy and didn't have a strong tomato base; different, but not quite what we were expecting. The  bar and kitchen staff were friendly, too.  The only downside was the brutal brawl outside by a few locals...
author: Bee H.

description: The search is over, I've found the best chicken pot pie in the city, at long last! Thank you, Thank you, THANK YOU Monk's Kettle.
author: Leesa P.

description: We came here again yesterday, and Monk's Kettle is still great as always. Great beer and food and we come here often.  I bumped off a couple of stars because it's overpriced compared to other beer spots in the city, plus, my friends ordered fries, and they didn't receive it.  We had to ask for it again and our waiter brought it at the end of dinner when we were finished.  He STILL charged us for the fries!
author: H. A.

description: Great beer selection, attentive wait staff and bartender, great menu ... What ore could you want? Prices are reasonable too. Only downer for us as out of towners is the location seems to be in a slightly sketchy part of town.
author: Greg L.

description: Great chicken sandwich, lots of beer options. A little too small and crowded but hey, it's the Mission. That describes pretty much every single good eating experience there.
author: Will M.

description: I'm a big beer drinker so I was naturally attracted to this place. The selection is seemingly endless, which gives me all the more reason to return and try them all. Food was tasty and came in large portions. The giant $8 pretzel, which may seem highly priced, was completely worth and I'd get it again. Its served with ground mustard and some cheesy delicious aoili sauce.  My partner had  the lobster pot pie, which was to die for. I had a chicken brie sandwhich, which while not very adventurous, was very satisfying--even more so when served with an enormous side of tasty fries. Only complaint is  that I left so stuffed that I was good for nothing the rest of the day. Not the worst thing in the world.  Will definitely return.
author: kevin b.

description:
So many beers!
Read about this place in the paper and being fans of all things beer related, my boyfriend and I headed over to the Monk's Kettle for some food and (much-needed) beers after work yesterday. The food was excellent and fairly reasonable, in true SF fashion we shared some small plates and all were great. Even though they ran out of something we had ordered, the owner came over and made it right. The beer selection is over the top, they even do food & beer pairings on the menu.
author: Sara C.

description: I love the Monk's Kettle! The owners, Nat and Christian are super friendly, knowleadgable, and make excellent recommendations. The beer list is deep and diverse, and the fries were crunchy and spectacular. It was a bit chilly inside, so wear a warm sweater if you end up near the door. Also, it's a happening place, so be sure to arrive early so that you can get a seat. I also love that they have a good wine list so that I'm not stuck with just beer on a particularly cold night. It was fun to try new beers that I had never even heard of. It was like an adventure in a pint glass.
author: Lauren D.

description: Good little spot.  And I do mean little.  They don't have room for groups larger than 6, heck a 4 top would be tight here.  Food was good, not spectacular but decent, burgers were tasty, pork chop was delicious, put the hockey puck of potatoes needed seasoning.  Beet salad was a great.  The atmosphere is brighter than I expected and is cozy, yet LOUD!  Nice assortment of beers, really good beers.  Although I would have liked to have seen more Belgium beers on tap,  but the bottled selection is extensive.  And I do believe this place is open late night for food as well.
author: Mickey D.

description:
I have frequented "craft beer" style bars from the east coast to west coast and I find Monk's Kettle to be way overpriced and over-hyped. Whether it be the $12.50 for an 11 ounce Koenigshaven Quad ($7.50 other places) to a 10 oz draft of Russian River Damnation for $5.75 (which can be purchased from Zeitgeist, 3 blocks away @ 20 oz for $3.50) it does not deliver a positive price/value. This place should never be mentioned in the same sentence with the Toronado which is a classic " craft beer" bar. The physical space of Monk's is ok (check out web site comments on their small size) but certainly nothing special. A good concept, but light years behind comparable bars in other locales. Hopefully, SF will attract more competition in this niche.
P.S. I noticed that even though my review was the most recent a very positive review from days ago was still listed first...is this a benefit from being a Yelp "sponsor"? I hope Yelp has more integrity than that.
author: Rick D.

description: This place is an amazing gastropub.  Awesome beer, good atmosphere and really tasty food.  Only reason it isn't getting 5 stars is because for the price the food could be a tiny bit better.  Have had the daily roast there multiple times and I always walk away happy and slightly drunk.  That being said, for how light my wallet feels after dinner there I'd rather not have my socks on!
author: Albert B.

description: Their food is delicious, and their beer selection is amazing. Navigating the beer menu can be a bit intimidating, but don't worry; the bartender is very knowledgeable and will help you find the perfect beer.  Plenty of vegetarian food options.  It's a small intimate setting, so the wait can be long and the place can get crowded, but I don't care.  I come back again and again.  Truly one of my favorite SF spots.
author: Ashley M.

description:
one clipboard, 7-8 pages of beer menu, tons of possibilities.

the place is cute, but that can also be referred to as tiny.  the food looks and smells good, but i've only eaten the fries.

the servers/bartenders know their beers, and the ambiance is great. just don't show up a primetime or you'll be hanging out across the street not drinking awesome imported beer.
author: Ameer N.

description: Very clean, modern gastropub in the heart of the Mission with an eclectic selection of brews.  Their pretzels are really good.
author: Tim G.

description: What a brilliant concept.  Really really good food + really really good beer in a fun and well designed bar/restaurant space.  Big windows to stare at all the hipsters walking by.  Long bar to belly up to and drink and eat the night away.  The place is so tiny so I'm not sure if I could handle a busy Friday night or something like that.  I shared a salad and pulled pork sandwich and it was delicious.  The menu is creative and pulls together fresh ingredients in a bar food presentable way.  Healthy but not really.  I actually enjoy that they trick me into thinking the whole experience is healthy.  I had the best beer I've tried in a long time...the piny the elder from RR brew co.  Awesome!  Our waiter was very helpful in suggesting beers but no so helpful in actually remembering to bring us our food but hey, details.  I can't wait to go back and try more of their beer selection.
author: Piper B.

description: Obviously small but great place. The beers are delicious and the bartender was able to provide lots of information on a few I'd never heard of before. The only problem I have is that it's hard to make this place a destination spot, since they don't take reservations and really only have a handful of tables...
author: Nicolas H.

description: Really impressive selection of beers. The tasting glasses are so cute! Food is pretty good here too. Expect it to be crowded. Friendly service.
author: Edward C.

description: I just stumbled upon this place this evening. I thought it was great! I didn't have anything to drink, which is what I think they are going for, however my food was excellent. We started with the brucetta which may have been my favorite! Then I had the steak sandwich and my friend had the pulled pork. Both were excellent... the pulled pork was definitely the best have ever had. I would definitely go back, and recommend it to friends, however I probably won't dream about it tonight.
author: Lisa K.

description: I only got beer here because the wait to eat was too long. The menu still made me really hungry though because all of the food sounded so good. The beer selection made me so happy, they had everything I could ask for.
author: Josh K.

description:
So came in here with 3 buddies for dinner. we've past this place enough times on 16th st drinking nights, had to check it out. 
We started at the bar, where our bartender was great in helping us choose beers. add a homemade pretzel to that and whoopie!
And then we sat down...
Started with mac and cheese with bacon and the charcuterie plate. The mac n cheese was kinda bland. needed better cheese, more flavor. the charcuterie was ok. the duck proscuitto was really oily. 
and on to the entrees. i had the lamb burger. the fries was quite good, i like those thin fries. the burger, bland bland bland. i tasted not a drop of lamb, and i'm pretty sure they had not seasoned the meat either. just not good. i didnt even finish it. one other guy had it and he didnt finish it either. warning sign, dont get the lamb burger.
another guy had the chicken pot pie. again, looked good, but they must be afraid of flavor here, because it had none. If everything tastes like chicken and chicken tastes like nothing, where does that leave us?
and finally the pork chop. Honestly, I was jealous of my buddy who ordered that, because it was the best food of the night. maybe a bit too much sauce, but it was well cooked and had flavor. well done. 
so with good beer selection, good pretzel and good pork chop, and a lot of other misses, i would recommend coming in for beers and pretzels...
author: Rich B.

description:
i'm really not that into 16th street, but i would traverse the street yuck to come back again and again to this place. 
their prices are kinda spendy, but everything i had was worth it.

do you like pot pies? ydo you like assorted meats? do you like giant pretzels glistening with butter???? you'll find all that shit here along with a jillion beers

flicks of the food are here: 
http://i8that.wordpress.com/
author: eve l.

description:
I've been to this place three times.  The last time was just a couple weeks ago - a friend was taking me out for a belated b-day dinner.

First off - great beer selection - but that goes without saying.  Friendly staff - good job there - always willing to chat about the beers and I've always gotten good service.

I can't remember what I got the very first time I went Monks Kettle - must have partook of the beer a bit too much.  But the second and last time I was there I got a pulled pork sandwich.

The previous time, the sandwich was very tasty with jicama slaw on the side.  I didn't want to take any chances so I ordered the same thing a couple weeks ago - wow - I think someone must have been smoking bowls in the kitchen because it was a completely different sandwich - runny, drippy, BBQ pork - almost like sloppy-joe.  When I took a bit of the sandwich the filling oozed out the sides - messy-ass meal indeed. 

Also disappointing was the bread pudding.  It was very dry.  Probably been sitting in the fridge for a few days.   I had to gulp about 4 cups of coffee to get half of it down.  I left the rest of it for the dishwasher.

Lastly, the place is a bit cramped and I had the chair side of a duece which was adjacent to the aisle.  I got bumped in the head repeatedly by people going by.

If you go there, be sure to score the window seat, don't order the bread pudding, and hopefully the cooks in the kitchen wait until after their shift to smoke the fatties....
author: David M.

description: Thank you Monk!!! After a not so savory experience across the street at Andalu, we decided to try this place. We were sad they did not have brunch but decided to go for it anyway. We were seated promptly and greeted within in a moment. The server, Jason, was friendly and gave his two cents when asked about menu items. We both really enjoyed what we had. This is a great little place for lunch but a bit overpriced. Also, it cost $2.50 to substitute a side salad for french fries. The salad consisted of a small handful of field greens on the plate with my sandwich. I am hoping these were magic greens. And of course, if you like beer this is probably one of the best in the area.
author: Josh S.

description: What a great gastropub that's stumbling distance from my door. I went there for the first time last night and the beer menu is fantastic. The bar tenders are knowledgeable and gave me a great recommendation on a hefeweizen, the shcneider edelweiss. I only got to try their cheese plate, and have to say it was delicious. I look forward to going back and having a full meal next time.
author: Grant L.

description: We went here for a New Year's Day drink and nosh fest and it was fantastic.  Started off with a shared basket of fries which were thoroughly addicting.  It came with three dips - ketchup, curry aioli, and garlic aioli.  Delicious.  I had a British pale ale which was good - and the waitress poured it in my cup with little head so that's a plus, too.  I had the BBQ pulled pork sandwich with a side salad.  It was yummy.  Th ambiance is great for a pub - smallish but I like to think cozy spaces make for good conversations and good drinking.  They have this crazy long list of their beer selections and they specialize heavily in Belgian beers, which I probably should have chosen from but I'll do that next time.  This is a great place to go with a few friends (but not too many, it's small, like I said) for good food and mucho selection.
author: Tres N.

description: Gotta downgrade Monk's for a 90 minute wait for a table on a Tuesday, especially when initial estimate was 30 minutes.  Still, best beers around and the most delicious pretzel you'll ever have.
author: Matt S.

description: I liked the vibe. Quiet and laid back on a Monday night. The bartender was really helpful in navigating us through the beer list. We just sat at the bar but the food looked delicious. Kind of pricey for a college student though. Perfect for a sweet date.
author: Beth T.

description: Good beer selection and a clean joint, however a bit small.  Nonetheless, a nice change from the grungy run of the mill in the Mission.
author: John D.

description: I will start off by saying I am a big fan of service.  It's not always a deal-breaker if the food is exceptional but it definitely pushes things over the edge.  I love to go to bars and restaurants where people like what they do, know about food, beer, spirits, wine and want to share that knowledge with enthusiasm, not arrogance.  I want people to act like professionals.  So...The service here is impeccable.  The staff is friendly, knowledgeable and not high-falutin.  As far as food--I wanted to order everything on the menu.  In the end, I got the lamb burger paired with a Belgian ale (recommended by our server) that was familiar yet different and very fresh tasting to boot.  The beer selection is amazing and the pairings are just a fantastic idea.  sometimes I just don't feel like wine with food.   I can't wait to go back.
author: katie b.

description:
lamb burger = tasty 
temperature of lamb = well done ( i asked for med rare ) wtf
taste = good 
fries = thumbs up 
ketchup = mucho good
beer selection = mucho mucho good (i had the alaskan summer ale )
bartender = very knowledgeable and you may ask about what and i say  beer bitch!
service = efficient and non-intrusive
stars = 3.785482
don't understand why temperatures get asked when it comes out well done any way? by the way its 3am right now and i can't sleep because i had some of that strong ass but tasty good coffee they serve.
author: goldberg d.

description:
Fantastic place.  Utterly fantastic.

Great food, better selection of beers, even better knowledge of said beers from the bartenders.  Bartenders there are like sommeliers of beer.  If you want a great experience, sit at the bar for lunch and shoot the breeze with the bartender while enjoying the burger with grilled onions and swiss cheese.

Just wonderful...

Take the BART to the 16th Street stop then walk "up the hill" for about two blocks.  It's on the left.
author: Greg B.

description: Minus the fact that we had to wait to get in (@ a bar?-r u kidding me?) the spot was worth the 2mins (lol)  of lag time-staff was good, friendly, and make good recommendations, especially if you don't know what to pick out of there thousands of options!!! Mortification-is def my pick! Good beer, good vibes, sports on tv -what else could you ask for!
author: Mack M.

description: The best burger and fries I have had here in S.F. Great atmosphere! Cozy yet shiek. Definately a must eat for any foodie.
author: B H.

description: The Monk's Kettle is my beer bar of choice.  I like the beer list and it's absolutely thoughtfulness.  For a wine drinking town it is hard to find a good bar to have beer and to appreciate the artistry of beer--The Monk's Kettle does a lot in a very small space.  The service is quite good and very knowledgeable--love their ability to not just 'know' beer but be able to guide their customer to a beer they are going to enjoy.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: OMG, they had a BIG SELECTION of beer from around the world!!!  I asked for a recommendation and got a YUMMY Belgian beer on tap.  We will definitely come back again to try other beer.  I must say that the beer is a bit pricey.  Alot of them are around the $10 range for 1 glass (not pint size).  The standing room isn't that big and the dining area isn't that big either.  So it's probably not the best place for a big big group.  Maybe 4 people at most.  The 4 star goes to a great selection and great beer.  The pricey factor took off the 1 star.
author: Irene C.

description: Went for lunch and ordered the beef and turkey burger. Both were delicious even though the beef was medium well and not medium rare. Great selection of beers. Our server was quite knowledgeable, attentive and friendly. Five stars for service!
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description:
I really like this place! It's a quintessential Mission Restaurant/Bar. Monk's Kettle takes the Mission to new culinary heights, and not just because it's the only non Asian or Latin cuisine around for 4 blocks - it's just really delicious and simple food that plays to their strengths well, and that is you guessed it - BEER.  What I appreciate the most about this place is the degree of commitment they pay to the beer here. They don't play around with the quality by any means whatsoever. Just like what you would find at a really upscale restaurant when you look at a menu and see entrees besides a suggested a wine selection. You'll find a beer pairing coupled with an upscale version of a "comfort food" such as a Chicken Pot Pie, or better yet - a nice Neiman Ranch burger. I went here a few months ago with the awesome Carrie C. and must say - I have been dying to go back. It's so great to know that their kitchen is open until midnight. Monk's Kettle deserves 5 stars and more. Please note, the menu is a bit pricey, so prepare to spend around $20 a person for dinner and a drink. If you don't go out to dinner a lot this is a good place to go to treat yourself. 

The beer is pretty strong too, so you just have to love that about it. The
author: Laura G.

description: Cozy in size with friendly and knowledgeable staff makes this one of my favorite gastropubs. Expect a short wait for a table, but if you're lucky you can find a spot at the bar while you wait. Each of their meals lists recommended beer pairings on their menu, from their vast selection of really great beers (local and abroad). I recommend their lamb burger, and be sure to get the 3 dipping sauces for your fries ($0.75 for your table) -- totally worth it.
author: Adrian F.

description: awesome! simply awesome!  black bean cake appetizer super tasty. seafood gumbo incredible. correct glass for each belgian beer- authentic and impressive. beer selection second to none! much recommended.
author: Ed S.

description: You can probably skip this place if you think a good beer is Bud or Coors.  If you enjoy craft beers, this bar has one of the best selections from a variety of places around the world.  Yes, you're paying more for a smaller amount of beer but considering how far your beer has traveled and the alcohol content, it's not that bad of a deal.  I normally start with the Charcuterie Plate as an appetizer and sample a few Doppelbock or Trappist beers.  Their bottle selection is huge but check on the prices before you take your bartender's recommendation.  The food here is alright but it's the beer that bring me back.
author: Shannon W.

description: Great spot, great beer selection, very knowledgeable and friendly ber tenders.  didnt try the food, so i can comment, but the whole  beer experience  was great.  the only prob is that it is small and a bit crowded.  over all tho i will go back to this spot and use it as the measuring stick.
author: the one m.

description:
Both times I went to this tiny place, it is busy and we have to wait awkwardly in the entryway. Last night the host said he "had a couple options" after waiting quite awhile, then disappeared to talk to a table. I think this was the first any staff had acknowledged us.

After finally sitting, the service started out slow. we had to wave someone down to order food; the pot pie special even changed between getting menus and ordering. After that, it was great; the waiter showed up when we needed more beer and was knowledgeable about their extensive beer menu.

I had the veggie burger. I asked for no cheese. I got a veggie burger with cheese. Since I am technically vegetarian, I went ahead and ate it. It was quite bland with little structural integrity. It was firmly on the beanier side of the fake-meaty/beany veggie burger spectrum.

However, this place does have a thorough beer menu. A bit overwhelming, but that is a good thing.
author: Neil D.

description:
It took me a while to find this place.  It's across the little side-road from Delirium.

Although we were there on a Thursday evening, it was pretty full.  We had to ask the guy at the door to add us to the waiting list for a table, and we sat at the bar for about 20 minutes before a table was available.

All the beers there are obscure ones.  I asked the bartender for "something like Stella", and she brought me a couple of candidates in tiny beer glasses to try.  Nice.

The beer was good.  The food was pretty good.  The service was good.  I'd go again.
author: Alex M.

description:
UNORGANIZED - so much so that we left and went elsewhere to eat after we couldn't seem to get any service (either to find the elusive list for table seating, or to be directed to seating at the bar, or to get a menu, or for anyone to take our order - REALLY none of this happened). 

And then, as I looked around to see who, if anyone, was working there,  I saw food served (hope! potential! excitement!). But as quickly as my  hopes were raised, they were dashed. The man who served the food promtly sat down at the table where he had just delivered it and tucked into his dinner. I don't know if he is a friend of the owner or simply another customer that needed help and took action into his own hands. I decided not to wait around to find out.

They really need to figure out their logistics but I'm giving them 2 stars because I appreciate that they choose to serve meat that's organic.
author: Teddy B.

description: 4 stars for the beer - and the helpful bartenders who encourage you to taste their weird beers and find ones you really like. They listen to examples of what you like and make real recommendations, not just "such-and-such is very trendy." Open for lunch, which is a good option if you are prepared to drink beer in the afternoon. Crowded to madness with day-trippers on weekend nights. The food is clearly lower priority than the beer, but its a solid californian effort, not greasy, and not too heavy (save more room for the beer). Snacks are good, the lamb burger is nice and fresh, and the salads, well, are fine. Good place to take your folks for lunch on a friday, or get an early drink.
author: Carrie G.

description: really cute place in the mission. food is excellent. gets really crowded friday nights
author: Daisy J.

description: I am not usually a fan of beer...or anything alcoholic for that matter.  In fact, some would even say that I am quite the lightweight, but the draft Duchesse de Borg here was probably the best beer that I've had.    It's served pretty in a wine glass and tastes really fruity.  Perfect for us lightweights!  (But surely on the pricey side at $9.75 for an 8 oz portion.)
author: Judy K.

description: We went here specifically because the birthday girl we were celebrating wanted mac-n-cheese.  /We even planned ahead knowing there would be a wait, popped int a neighboring bar for a drink until we got our table ready text.  We were near devastated to find that the menu has changed - evidently to smaller portions and less pub food.  No macaroni and cheese or cookies in the pan.  We were very fortunate that our server was on a break and an absolutely adorable fill in candidate and was not only accommodating but so incredibly helpful in guiding us to food and beverage we loved.  He listened, made us laugh, brought sample beer til I found one I loved and when I happily gobbled all but the bean smush (wanna be jalapenos popper shaped), he brought a pretzel to fill in any remaining spaces in my belly.  He left us very happy, very full, and appreciative.  Unfortunately, our server did return before our dining experience ended and we were back to what we have experienced here before - hipster aloofness that neither wants or needs my dishes, dessert order, or money.  The sweet and competent server we spent most of our night with made our experience delightful.  The small portions for the prices and glimpse of pretentiousness cost a few stars.
author: K M.

description: Awesome selection of beer, even if somewhat pricy (some over $20). The giant $8 pretzel was buttery, piping-hot, and fucking awesome. The sloppy-joe-esque pulled pork sandwich was visually unappealing but decent and kinda spicy. The guy at the end of the bar who wouldn't move his stool down 6 inches so my friend and I could squeeze in another stool was a true penis-sniffer who I probably should have farted on instead of kindly smiling and walking away. Next time I will order the chili so I can fart away all the haters.
author: Adam C.

description: I liked this place a lot the first time I went, but less so the second time.  The charcuterie plate with a tall glass of beer is delicious.  The steak was yummy and perfectly cooked.    The turkey burger is pretty good as well.
author: T D.

description: "Great pub feel. Didn't get to eat anything else except the pretzel which was good, but a tad overpriced. Packed to the brim on a late Friday evening. Great selection of beers tho"
author: Jocelyn L.

description: 4 stars as a pub. 2 as a gastro pub. Good food on the menu but probably not warranting a gastro pub' label . Only had the cheese plate - came with burnt toast.  Really. no one checked it? Great beer selection. Cool bright modern interior.
author: sanjee w.

description: I heart the Monk's Kettle.  I heart the food, I heart the wine, I heart the service, I heart Katy.  Open up a location on Fillmore, please!
author: Amanda S.

description:
Indeed you will find a mind-numbingly long beer list here.  Ask your server for help, don't be shy.  Or ask your neighbor.  On our first trip here, we sat down at the bar and the fellows next to us-- who seemed like they'd been there a while-- immediately insisted that we try Consecration (Russian River Brewing Co.).  How could we say no to such enthusiasm?  I'm not a beer drinker, so excuse me if this is inane, but I'd describe it as the shockingly attractive lovechild of Chimay and kombucha.  Smooth, fine bubbles, acidic bite.  As our new bar buddies exclaimed, "It's vinegary.  But in a good way!"

Allow me to recommend a non-alcoholic option as well: the Bundaberg ginger beer (also found at Ike's).  It is mild and sweet, with a unique herbiness.

We only had snacks, but the food was excellent.  Everything was hearty and satisfyingly recognizable: pretzels, cheese, burgers-- we're at a pub after all!-- but with a slow food/gourmet twist.  

To address fellow patrons' complaints: Yes, it's crowded at night and waiting sucks.  But, you know, it's a great bar in the Mission.  And one *does* find hipsters here, but to complain about hipsters in this neighborhood is like bitching about old Italian ladies in North Beach.  Anyway, I have found hipsters to be a very accepting and food-loving people.  There's no need to fear.  Just slip on in, slide up to the bar, and ask that skinny, flannel-wearing dude next to you what he's drinking.
author: Emily D.

description: Honestly the staff here may need some manors and some lessons in how to provide service.  Remember a waiter/bartender/manager etc.....  are all service positions.  It doesn't matter what you do for a living outside  the doors of the establishment.  It matters how you treat people and how they feel when they walk in.  The sour staff makes the beer taste bitter and flat.  The place lacks heart and soul.  The beer is good, the seats uncomfortable, the music thumbs down, and the food is ok.  Not a first choice as far as a meet up spot, date spot, or a casual beer.  May only return if a friend says they want to go to hopefully be charmed.  Three stars for the remodel and the mood lighting.  A visual improvement to a funky corner spot.
author: Velvet V.

description: Good atmosphere and beer selection.  The food was okay - wouldn't say it's anything to ride home about.  Would definitely recommend for happy hour if you don't mind paying top dollar.  Way over-priced on their beers.
author: Ally M.

description:
Okay, ever the contrarian, I will go against all the 4 and 5 stars and ask, "what the hell is so great about this place?" - and "is there something I'm missing that 576 people did not?" Yes, they have a sublime and impressive selection of beers, but so does the Toronado (to quote my friend Jessica Brown). 

We get on the waiting list, and it's one hour, ONE HOUR for a burger joint. I figured, it had better be good and worth the wait, in this economy: I'm talking Kobe beef, Belgian ale and some seriously good sides.

So we idle over to the Kilowatt, not our regular dive but saw a few friends over there, and it was happy hour, so perfect.

One hour later, we get the call that our table is ready. We are seated next to a loud group of dot-commers from Bangalore or some tech concern - loud, drunk geeks who can't seem to hit "special shut down" on the weekends. Ambiance? Non existent.

Our 'beer sommellier' comes over and attempts to pair our beers with our burgers (now I've seen everything). I was actually rather excited for this burger to be better than sex the way she described it. With a creamy Belgian ale on the way, I was willing to forgive even the "Killer App" developers to the right of me. 

So, I'm one Kilowatt margarita to the wind, the dot commers are getting more animated regarding their peerless industry prowess, and 3 sips into my beer, the plates are plunked down in front of us. Nothing like drawing out the evening, people. They make you wait one hour, but your dinner had better not take longer than 30 minutes, door to door. Decent food, for sure, but this $13 burger was just no big deal. Not bad, not great, but just nothing to write home about. I mean, I can understand waiting in line for Pauline's Pizza (artisanal and organic ingredients), Suppenkuche or Waldwerk (yummy German home cooking with imported beer on tap too). But the difference is that Suppenkuche and Waldwerk don't get all prissy about their beer and the pairing of it with entrees, they are German, (East and West) and they serve beer the way they drink it, wordlessly and without hyperbole. 

But I digress. So the dot com guys are slathering over themselves, and my husband and I are wondering what the big deal is here - the forgettable burgers? The worlds largest pretzel? The beer sommellier? The fact that culture vultures all over town are willing to wait one hour for something that just ain't that impressive.

So we get our bill, 2 burgers, 2 beers, 40 bux. We could have gone to the Big 4 for the best cheeseburger in town for the same price. Or Whiz Burger for half the price. But it was "date night" so we decided to give it a whirl (based on all the 4 and 5 star Yelp reviews).

But in every cloud, there is a silver lining:

If you believe that "it's not the destination, it's the journey" philosophy like I do, you know that the Lord giveth, and the Lord taketh away.... And working off the "House that Jack Built" methodology: if we hadn't had to wait an hour to get into Monks Kettle, we wouldn't have gone to the Kilowatt, and wouldn't have seen our friend Jessica who stated that our dear friends THE HOOKS and Socals legendary THE ZEROS were playing at the Elbo room, and we wouldn't have called Ronan Mulligan and he wouldn't have put us on the guest list and then we wouldn't have seen bands we would have happily paid to see individually. But together? Gratis? Even better! Considering that THE ZEROS were playing out when I was in braces (and on the opposite side of the country), I would never have seen them at all if we hadn't eaten at Monk's Kettle. And of course, THE HOOKS played a blistering set, as always.....

So you see? It's good that we decided to go to Monk's Kettle after all, but not because of the food....
author: Karolina G.

description: The food here is good, I have onl been here once and I think I ordered salmon sandwich which was good. The fries were yummy but not the best I have tasted. We also ordered the Chili which was Ok. i would not order it again just becasue the veggies were pretty chunky. I forget what my friend has but he liked his food allot. Lots ans Lots of beers. i would go here again.
author: Ge I.

description:
i think the mission really needed a good beer place.  i only went for the beer and sat at the bar, the place was very crowded and my friends who were waiting for a table ended up leaving out of frustration (it was always another 20 minutes).  but what delicious beer it was!  it's like a fancy toronado's with fancy food and less attitude.  

to some people that is awesome, to others it is awful.  choose wisely.
author: Neha N.

description:
3.5 stars, my friends! 

What a huge and intimidating beer list...  Luckily the servers are friendly and helpful when you ask questions, and although I didn't have one, it looked like some samples were poured when people weren't sure which one of the hundreds of beers was right for them...  My husband had the pulled pork sandwich and I had the burger w/ white cheddar.  I was happy with my burger because it wasn't huge and fat (it was big, but not one of those horrifying Burgermeister type patties that make me want to go back to being a vegetarian.)  I liked my husband's pulled pork better than my sandwich, but I always like his better unless it's some disgusting charcuterie platter that tastes like mothballs.  Overall, there were some very tasty items on the Monk's menu, and it was hard to decide what to get, so I went for the most basic item (burger), and was quite pleased.  I was also pleased that even though the place is teeny, the tables weren't right on top of one another.  Now if they'd just open one in the Outer Sunset I'd be happy...
author: robyn s.

description: The Monk's Kettle is a great place for unique delicious beers. While I know nothing about beer and have ordered "something similar to Amstel Light" I get no snootery from these people. They're very willing to get me a light pilsner and educate me on the robust qualities of whatever I'm drinking.
author: C P.

description:
after i left elixir we walked down the street to monk's kettle... and it was a great place for beer drinkers... they handed me what i thought was a menu for food and drinks, hmmm it wasn't. it was the menu for all the beers they have, it was great! had a beer called rejection which was really good with macaroni and cheese with bacon.... made the sunday rainy night! 

good vibe, company and beers!
author: jonathan g.

description: This beer is strong - makes you do things you normally wouldn't do (e.g., drunk dial your ex-gf 15 times). The food is pretty tasty, but they need a new bun for the pulled pork sandy.
author: Boyd W.

description: Good beer pub, a welcome and elegant addition to this obnoxious strip of 16th St.  I liked everything about the place--antique bar glimmering with different shaped beer glasses, fun menu including the popular and heart-warming pretzel--except the terrible music.  I don't understand how late 90's frat boy Hip hop goes with the rest of the concept; and, in the danger of sounding like my mother, it is really quite loud enough already.  I am definitely looking forward to trying this place again on a weekday afternoon when it is hopefully a little calmer.
author: NoodleBelly S.

description:
I've been sick of places that only serves Bud or Heineken, so boring!

I only tried their beer, but god! Just their selection of beers is amazing enough. So much variety from all over the world (50+), probably need a year to try out all of them. 

But the place is really too small, even 6pm Sunday evening was already full.
author: Kevin L.

description: This place is a nice addition to 16th street. I went with a friend for an afternoon snack, and we really enjoyed it. The atmosphere is relaxed and has nice character. I would definitely go back.
author: Adrienne G.

description: This is a nice little place, and the chicken sandwich with bacon and a side of fries was really delicious. The beer selection looked really great, but at $13 for the sandwich I didnt have much left over. No complaints though, the food is really fresh and delicious. They should put some cushioning on the wooden benches. I will be back for sure.
author: Julian M.

description:
I'm having a moral dilemma here. I love this place, so I want to give them a great review, but they are small and I don't want to have to share. So let me tell you how awesome they are, and you will promise not to make it too crowded for me to get in. yeah? okay!

So I'd been wanting to come here for a long time, and finally had the opportunity to do so this weekend. I originally came by around 10:30ish , we were a group of 5 and were promptly told at the door that there was no room for us. We were disappointed, so we went across the street to tokyo-a-go-go for a bit, and then to a local bookstore before coming back around 12. We got in and after spending a good 15 minutes trying to get the bartenders attention with no luck, opted for a table, and ordered some snacks and drinks. It's a small place, so it was nice to be able to sit down and talk to each other without being spread out all over the place. This is definitely not the kind of place where you want to go with more than one or two people. that being said, the five of us had a marvelous time. Our server was super friendly, and helped recommend a few beers. We somehow missed the last call for food, but they still agreed to fry us up a second basket of fries. These fries were the most addictive thing in the world. Not only were the dipping sauces good, but they must had fried them in magic oil because I hadn't had fries that good since I was in Germany. 

Come closing time, one of the bar keeps is trying to get everyone to finish up their drinks quickly, and we're joking a little because we have half a glass of Hitachino left and are squabbling over who gets to finish it when Mr. Obnoxious buts in. From our playful jokes with the bar keep Mr. O takes it to the next level of fight. Sure, the clock on the wall was ten minutes fast, but can you blame them for wanting us all out before 2am so they don't get fined? seems perfectly reasonable to me. besides... it's 10 minutes, it's not like you were going to drink all that much in the last ten minutes. I didn't get to see how it ended, the manager was on the phone with the cops when we walked out, not in the mood for drama.

All in all, they have great food, an AMAZING selection of beer and a super friendly and helpful staff. I felt sorry for them having to deal with Mr. O at 2am, but I guess drunks will be drunks. 

Now that I have discovered this place I'm going to be dragging just about everyone I know here, weather they like beer or not.
author: Allyson S.

description:
Visiting from out of town, I had only one night in town to enjoy dinner/drinks.  By god am I glad I stumbled across this place (thanks largely to you SF yelpers).

Chicago has a few gastropubs of solid caliber, but nothing quite like this one.  A delectable mix of superb beer selection, refined yet accommodating menu, quaint size, and amiable staff.

Monk's, I treasure our one-night stand...
author: Fred M.

description:
ooohh yummy!

yep, this isn't somewhere i'd go terribly often.  Unfortunately for me, my pockets are stretched thin.  But, man oh man, I had the fortune of needing  to waste a little time before heading out of the city and the forethought to think of this place.  There was someone else that loves beer but was driving, so I had him order for me so that at least he could sample several.  What a wonderful place to save the designated driver!  I have no idea what i had to drink that afternoon.  But oh my, it was delicious!  The bartender is very sweet and just the right amount of friendly.  

She suggested the bruschetta and we also ordered the fries.  Both were very excellent.  Fries were thin cut and plentiful, and for the swank place that it is, a pretty good deal.  The bruschetta was with a cannellini puree and was perfect to wash back with a beer.

I've got to come back and tried an intimate dinner here sometime when i got the cash.  I sure wish they were in Oakland.  This is what I wish the trappist would be!  Amazing beer and good food.  But there's always luka's for that too, I guess....anyways, I'll definitely be back!  But don't drive!  That's no way to enjoy these crazy delicious beers!
author: Rebecca R.

description:
was in town visiting a good friend and walked to monk's from his place. was not disappointed. the beer list is eye-popping, and we sampled i think 6 different beers. great service, even tho the dude was a bit blatantly flirtatious with one of our party =P
the food was OK, appetizers were the BIG pretzel (wow that was good - salty and buttery deliciousness) and a cheese tray which complemented the brews nicely. i worked on a burger for dinner, wifey had the scallop pot pie special. we barely stuffed down the cinnamon chocolate bread pudding and peach cobbler (amongst 4 people). 
liked it a lot, would go back!
enjoy
B
author: Brian G.

description: Awesome beer selection, good food and nowhere to sit.  The Monk's Kettle is a proper gastro-pub with one of the most extensive beer menus in the city.  Negatives are that the place is a bit pricey (especially for the Mission) and on weekend nights the bar gets really packed (+1 hour waits for a table).  Nonetheless, the perfect alternative to a PBR at one of the many other nearby bars.
author: Mario N.

description: I LOVE monks kettle!!!!!!!!!!!  I seriously want to be a regular here!  Let me just say that I hate beer....but the two bartenders that helped me on Monday night found a beer that I LOVED!!!!!!!!!!!!  And, the food was fantastic!  My boyfriend and myself shared the pomme frites and the cheese platter and it was FANTASTIC!!!  You will see me there at least once a week as I truly want it to be a place where everyone knows my name!
author: alex f.

description: Nice beer selection. Very small and crowded, but I can deal with that. Very Mission Hipster - felt a little out of place, but it goes with the territory. Food was decent, but nothing amazing, and WAY overpriced. I might go back for the beer, but won't bother with the food again. If I'm spending that much I need quality taste.
author: Monika M.

description: I like beer the way most Californians like wine and the Monk's Kettle has the best beer selection in town.  The staff is extremely friendly and knowledgeable and the food (mostly organic and free-range) is excellent.  I particularly like coming in late at night on a week night when it isn't too crowded.  And yes, it's a bit pricey, but it's completely worth it.
author: Rich R.

description: I love eating. I love eating even more when I can drink and eat at the same time. And that means choices. Lots of them. Monk's Kettle has a great selection of beers. Everything was great, not just menu fillers. And their food  is a perfect accompaniment. Macaroni and Cheese. Hot pretzel with cheese dipping sauce. You know, things that go well with beer. A fun drinking environment. Solid food. Hard to get tables. Well worth coming for the peanut butter cookie in a cast iron skillet. Has the makings of infamy.
author: Timothy P.

description: My first visit here, exceeded my expectations, and We didn't even have a beer. Great food, we ordered the Pretzel with homemade spicy mustard, the flank steak, and grilled chicken, all looked, smelled and tasted wonderful. In case you forgot you were in the Mission, your waiter will drop some knowledge about local artists and music in the area. It feels good to live in the city
author: Missy I.

description: I'm writing this as a bar review, so only gave it three stars.  While the drink selection is good, I've had a bad experience with nearly everyone who worked here during my 3 or 4 visits (the bouncer, the waiter, the bartender, hell, you name it).  It's more of quiet reprieve in the normally loud Mission bars on a Saturday night.  As a restaurant, the food is great (the chicken sandwich with brie, the mac and cheese are all recommended).
author: Mark P.

description: This place has an excellent beer selection, just like everyone says. It is also rather small and can get crowded/cramped very easily. The fries we had were very yummy and the aioli served with them was yummy. The service was ok, except for a waiter insulting my choice in beer. I don't know much about beer and was kind of overwhelmed by the menu. You'd think they would want to help people cultivate a taste in beer to get repeat business, but I guess not. If you are confident in your taste in beer, you will have a good time.
author: Whitney R.

description:
ok yes you may have to wait a while but it's worth it.
the beer selection is pretty much fantastic. they are very willing to answer any questions you have about them even though they are extremely busy.
i'm from los angeles and a big fan of la brea breads witch is what they serve there grilled chicken on. it was very tasty and i had lunch for the next day.
the pot pie of the day which i stumbled upon on a very lucky evening was scallop and i almost licked the ramekin clean.
friendly staff, great food and awesome beers, what more can one wish for?
author: tinkerbell e.

description: It's a good option for the next time I have people who are into beer visiting town.  I thought the food was good, and you get a good view of the grill from the bar.  Early on this summer evening, it had the right level of spaciousness and activity to feel comfortable despite the slightly uncomfortable bar stools.  I didn't think the place was pretentious like some have said, although clearly the bartenders know and care about their brews.  It felt effortlessly neighborhoody not hipster.
author: Leo C.

description:
nice decor, good concept, quenches any beer drinker's thirst, brilliant pretzel.

very happy with this new addition to the mission. their menu changes quite a bit so you won't get bored. fresh seasonal ingredients as evidenced by my baby arugula and peach salad with ricotta salata and pine nuts.

as my date remarked, "world class beers and a gourmet pretzel with cheddar ale sauce? perfect afternoon snack." sometimes boys are so great.

cheers.
author: Laura H.

description:
Hands down some of the best food in the city. Yes it is small and can take awhile to get a table, but wow the food is GOOD. Pretzel with chedder/ale sauce is best pretzel i've ever had - pork chop is so good i can't even explain...had a fish special awhile back too that was amazing - they just can't cook a bad dish in that place. 

If i were walking by there is no way i'd say "let's do dinner there" - cause it's a classic pub type place and i'd figure greasy food, etc., but Monk's is way different. For those familiar with Marina, it's like a Braisen Hen - small joint, great drinking atmosphere, and amazing food - seriously the best I've had in 1 year in SF...and I eat out a lot. 

Note: Don't go for dinner with a big group - 6 at most unless you call first or something...(small place and such a size could take a long time).

Will be back soon!
author: JOHN O.

description: We were told the beer at this place was amazing so, four of us went here on a Tuesday night round 8,30pm. We were told there was a 45min wait and that we couldn't wait inside (it's pretty small) because it was full. The host took my name and number and went for a walk. Since we were pretty hungry we ended up eating elsewhere...I got a call back about an hour and a half later!! ridiculous!! No beer can be THAT amazing.
author: An A.

description: This is a great place if you're a fan of beer.  It's really small and cozy.  We sat at the elevated table right next to the entrance, which was perfect for people watching.  It was awesome to see so many beers from our hometown of San Diego on the menu, but we chose to try some of the Northern California beers.  Crystal tried the Lagunitas American Strong Ale called Brown Shugga and I chose the Moonlight Czech-style Pilsner called Realty-Czech.  I'm half Slovakian, so anything with Czech or Slovak in it's name gets automatic selection, even if it's a Pilsner.  Both of the beers were really good.  The wait stafff was attentive.  The music that was playing was good.  I guess my only complaint, which isn't really a complaint but a preference, is that it's a little stuffy.  Everything is super clean and the clientele seemed super well off.  Some grit and character to the place would push my rating to a 5.
author: Chris-tal P.

description: Great beer selection.  Mac and cheese is really good, good place, food is reasonably priced, but the beer is a bit expensive.
author: Eric W.

description:
Pro's
- Selection of beer.
- Good chicken burger. Plenty of food,  I was full
- Good salads.



Con's
- Terrible, terrible service. I order a very expensive beer, and it takes over 15 minutes to pour it?? And I was sitting all of 15 feet at a table from the beer. WTF? I don't care if it takes an hour to get my good, but I want my beer fast.
- A little Overpriced.

If it was slightly cheaper and I got my beer faster I'd come here. Considering how many people are complaining about the service its very shocking to me -- it's a tiny place and a lot of patrons feel the same.
author: Brian E.

description: giant soft pretzels??  yes please!  and they are served with mustard and a cheesy sauce - sooooo good.  i admit i was lame and had wine instead of beer, despite their impressive listing of beers.  next time, beer for sure.
author: Carolyn B.

description: I think this place is now my favorite bar in town.  The beer menu is so extensive that even a non-beer drinker was able to find something that I like.  they have a lot of draft beer too.  the staff is very nice and helpful.  and the ambiance is casual and lively!  Will go next time for wine!
author: Vivian H.

description: These guys had the best fries I've had in the City!  Their beer selection was awesome as well.  But I got a $13.50 beer that was a little bit more like champagne and served in a girly glass.  Reminds me of 99 bottles in Santa Cruz.  Not great for big parties and their food menu selection was impressive (not your regular pub fare).  I wish they had fish and chips though.  I had the short ribs that were moist, a generous portion, & falling off the bone but could've used more flavor.  It just opened recently so there were tons of people on a Wednesday night and they don't even have a happy hour.  And they're packed every night.  I dunno, maybe go earlier ~before 6pm to grab a seat.
author: kiwi l.

description: You think you know your beer? Well, I don't claim to be an expert but I thought I knew a few brews. Here, I did NOT recognize maybe 90% of the beers on their menu. If you're not sure what to get, don't be afraid to ask the bartender for a recommendation. Nice ambience, though a tad claustrophobic/cramped. Jury's still out on the food, as all we did was drink. Will try the food sometime... With their supposed variety of 100 beers, this is hands down beer heaven in the Mish.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Been there only once, but definitely plan on returning. They have a great selection of beer and the fries were awesome! What more does one (a vegetarian) need on a lazy afternoon?
author: Paawan K.

description: 85 beers on tap.  $15 specialty pot pie.  And a prime location in case you want to bar hop.  Parking sucks but if you plan to drink a lot of beers, might as well cab it.
author: Kimmie N.

description: Wooow....beer and food? So simple and so clever those little monks cooking and gathering all those beers under one roof! My new favorite watering hole in the mission. I love this place! The waitress knew her beers like no one business, quite impressive for this little pub!  The food was pretty spot on. We had the black bean cakes which were very yummy and the tuna sand. The only thing I would say is that they forgot the house-made sausage on the Charcuterie Plate?? All well. I forget things here and there when the tough gets going. Keep up the great work and I'll be by soon again to taste more of those tasty beers and yummy food.
author: Bronson M.

description: Clean beer bar.  Good selection.  Can be hard to get a table.  Food is good not great.  Beer is the reason to go.  Need a snack to soak up the booze and it is a good choice.  Wish I lived closer!
author: Doreen D.

description:
Very good beer selection, not cheap.  Some damn fine beers though.
I have only had late night dinner menu.  The veggie burger with grilled onions and cheese is really good.  The mac and cheese was disappointing- it was gritty and had verry little flavor.

Slightly overpriced.
author: Tbone J.

description: Loads of beer on draft and a delicious Lamb Burger. Sometimes that's all you want.
author: Niki N.

description: I def like this place. I wish it were in my hood instead of the mission but oh well. The food for the most part is good, try the mac n' cheese! I wasn't too impressed with the vegan chili. Next time I'm there, I'm trying the giant pretzel.
author: Lola D.

description: Been going here since they had the lamps on the bar, and still my go to place for a great lunch and beer. Excellent and knowledgeable staff - don't be afraid to not know what beer you want, they always help point you in the right direction.
author: Philip G.

description: its ok. nice if u have a table to sit down n chat
author: Cindy L.

description:
The main selling point is the huge selection of beers, but there's a lot to like here even for those (like me) who aren't beer people.  I had a giant pretzel, which came with stoneground mustard (yum) and cheddar ale sauce (good, but more cheese than ale).  If I were less lazy I might try to recreate the chipotle ketchup that came with our fries. 

The only downside is the limited space (and it's not unequivocally a downside because it makes the place cozy): you might have trouble getting a booth quickly on a busy night.
author: S P.

description:
While MK has everything one looks for in a gastropub there are a couple points worth noting that if taken into consideration will make your experience there much better.
The place is small. Ten years ago, this wouldn't be surprising, but the gastropub concept is very popular now so its surprising that MK is in such a small space. They don't take reservations so think twice if you have a party of more than two and get there early.
The beer list is advanced. I wouldn't recommend this as a place to learn beer. There are a handful of approachable and affordable items, but for the most part the beer list is geared toward some who wants a unique beer and is willing/able to pay top dollar.
Also, I found the staff to be warm and friendly. They weren't exactly leaping to assist me, but Im sure they're a bit worn out from dealing with the sort of doucbaggery that is attracted to anyplace that is a bit pricey.
Is MK worth the money? Absolutely. Is it worth the effort? Meh. But to get anything similar you'd probably have to leave the city.
author: Jay S.

description: had dinner here the other night and man did it hit the spot. we got the vegan chili to start which was awesome and had i think cumin or cloves in it, very different tasting... then i got the lamb burger and i substituted the fries with a salad, the lamb had this awesome cucumber dressing on top...yum yum yum...they have an amazing beer selection as well. it was crowded and we had to wait 20 minutes but it was super worth it. great food. i'll definitely be back!
author: Dana C.

description:
Yum yum yum yum yum yum yum!

I've been here several times over the past few months, at different times of day and different events, and each time I LOVED this place.  The lamb burger - juicy and amazing!  Fries - perfection!  Drinks - wonderful!  The cookie dessert - I'll probably have this EVERY time i go in to this restaurant.
author: Josh C.

description: Beer isn't my favorite alcohol, but this place lets you really enjoy it. I loved that it had beer pairing with the meals. I had mussels (a random choice, but turned out fine) and a bottle of Sweetgrass. My friend had a glass of this beer that I can't remember the name of, but it almost tasted half wine (apparently there's too much bacon in the burger, but I think that's a good thing, no?). It was all good stuff. The place is super crowded, and the servers rush you with the paycheck as soon as you're done with your plate, but I can understand.
author: Kelly G.

description: the beer menu just never ends! pages and pages!  Dishes have beer pairing suggestion, the bartender and I discussed to see what i'd get, he knew what he was talking about. Kinda like Alembic on Haight, but less expensive and more spacious.
author: Damien J.

description: Wish I could give 5 stars. . . we had a great meal and the drink recommendations were all great. The problem was my husband is gluten free, and while we probably wouldn't have gone there on our own, we were in a group of 6 and it wasn't our pick. So when we saw gluten free beer on the menu it was very exciting. My husband ordered the gf beer. Then when we ordered dinner he ordered a burger with no bun, at which point he mentioned to the waiter that he was gluten free. Then he and the waiter talked about it again when we ordered a cider. For dessert however we ordered the cheese platter to share. My husband had a sample of each cheese before the rest of us dove in with bread. Even though the cheeses were explained to us, it wasn't until after the meal when we were talking to the waiter that he mentioned the stinky cheese is washed in beer! My husband started feeling the symptoms shortly after we had to leave the group early and go home because he was sick. After it coming up 3 times before I really think the waiter should have been able to make a point of telling us if a shared dessert was gf or not, ruined our night and our experience at an otherwise good new neighborhood option.
author: Kate J.

description: This is actually my husband's new favorite spot - but I love that it's two blocks from where I work so it's a convenient happy hour meeting place. The staff is friendly and they really know their beer - they have introduced me to some great new brews. And unexpectedly, the food is fabulous (upscale pub fare). done and done.
author: Ellen O.

description: Pretzel appetizer.  Yes, please.   Super packed on weeknights for dinner.  No, thanks.  Just about perfect for a Friday lunch though.  If you can get here mid-day for lunch, you'll be glad you did.
author: Julie B.

description: The people who opened this place were formerly back-of-the-house employees at Zuni Cafe, so it's not a surprise that their simple pub fare is absolutely delicious, and a bit expensive.  But the real reason to come here is the amazing beer selection (also a little expensive).  Anything you want or could imagine wanting- they most likely have it.  I've gone in for an afternoon snack and a beer and ended up with a $60-$80 tab more than once now.  The staff is very down to earth.  It's not a large place and is currently a new hot-spot in a the Mission, so getting a seat can be a little tricky during peak times- be prepared to stand.
author: Dina A.

description: I'm finding myself here a lot lately. Uncomfortably small but unexpectedly classy in the heart of dirty hipster Mission. The impressive four-page beer menu intimidates me into ordering the same few beers every time. Food and drinks are pricey but you usually get what you pay for. I approve.
author: Jordan B.

description:
I went here on the recommendation of a friend, and while I was very incorrectly anticipating a beer garden-type spot, I loved it. The atmosphere is nice - it's small, but not cramped - and the beer selection is fabulous (mostly CA and Belgian). I tried a few that were on tap (in some amazing mini-beer mugs/shot glasses) and ended up with a couple that were great. 

We sat at the bar, enjoyed the bartenders (fairly witty), ate a pretty awesome pretzel, and planned our next visit.
author: Allie H.

description: I love this place.  They have the best beer selection in the city and their food is excellent too.  The only reason it's 4 and not 5 stars is because they're overpriced.  Still, I always have a good time when I go to Monk's Kettle, and their kitchen is open late.  Score!
author: Chris C.

description: there are so many selections of beer here you cant go wrong. the bartenders are really friendly and great at helping you pin point the exact beer you are in the mood for. it is a little small for a bar and restaurant so if you are planning to eat here don't come in a group unless you are ok with a long wait. my preferable time to come is during the day for a beer in between activities, we have had fun sitting by the chalk boards at the bar to entertaining ourselves with a game of hangman etc.
author: Barbara C.

description: Best beer selection in the city! Must try the burger and the pretzels. Really awesome staff that will talk the time to help you find the perfect beer for you. Definitely hard to get a table but worth the wait
author: Mike W.

description:
Went to Monk's Kettle for the first time last Friday.  Was hankering for some drinks and yummy grub and this did the trick!

We had to wait over an hour but that was not too big of a deal since they take your number and text you when your table is ready.  We went across the street and had some beers and ran right over when they called.  

The place is very small, but cozy.  I don't think I would be very thrilled about eating at the bar (too many bodies in such a tight space), but if you were flying solo, probably wouldn't be that bad.  We got a small booth in the back for our party of 4 and it was perfect.

The service was awesome.  The host was upfront about the wait, but very cool about contacting us via text once our table was ready.  Our server was great and very knowledgeable about the menu and available choices for beer and wine.  Their list is huge so any help deciphering is great.  They also offer beer/food pairings on the menu so you aren't lost in too many choices.  Our server did a great job of pouring the beer and made it seem like it was special treatment.  Which was probably good b/c the beer cost $14!  (However, if you want something on the cheap side, they have $2 cans of Tecate beer).  I drank wine and was impressed by their selection considering their specialty is beer.

The food was awesome.  We got two appetizers to share, the mac + cheese (w/ bacon on top of course!) and the wild mushroom bruschetta.  Both were fantastic, but I would recommend the mac + cheese if you're going to go with just one.  I had the steak sandwich which was perfect.  I would have liked maybe a little less garlic aioli, but overall a very solid sandwich.  The steak was still tender and easy to bite.  My dinner companions had the lamb burger, the chicken sandwich and the steak.  Everyone was happy with our selections.  The fries that came with all the sandwiches were great--well salted and slightly crispy.

So if you're into beer and good pub food, head to the Monk's Kettle.  If you're bothered by a long wait or a crowded and noisy atmosphere, probably you should go elsewhere.
author: Jennie B.

description: Who does this place think they are toasting up a sidewalk vendor super pretzel and charging $6 for it?  Atmosphere was small and cozy.  Food was expensive and mediocre.  Beer selection was good, but pricey.  Bartender was  knowledgeable and friendly.  I don't think i'd come back again though.
author: LT B.

description: This review is based on a fuzzy memory, after all, this place is a pub. What I remember most, has to be the friendly staff and their wide variety of different tasting and flavorful alcohol. Try the chocolate tasting one.
author: Danny Y.

description:
This place is succeeding in being exactly what it is trying to be, and doing so very well: serve tasty, interesting beers with a carefully-chosen menu of quality food in a cozy, neighborhood setting. It's only been open for 10 days, and is already on its way to popularity and longevity.

It's cold out, so get a smooth, creamy porter or stout while you sit at the bar with a couple of friends. Or sit in a booth and order the pulled pork sandwich (delicious) or a pot pie after work with a pint of whatever ale has been suggested for your dish.

Attention to detail, good atmosphere, very friendly staff...this is exactly what the neighborhood needs.
author: Russell B.

description: I was really impressed by the beer selection, lots and lots. However not by the price of the beer - totally understand it costs A LOT and I mean A LOT to open a restaurant. Believe you me I design them and see the cost of construction - HOWEVER does Hitachino Red Rice beer really need to be $11.00 for a small bottle when I can get it at Coffee Bar and City Beer for $6.99? Needless to say I did not get Hitachino because I wanted to try something new anyways. I was also a disappointed with the veggie burger and fish sandwich. French fries were super good, servers were friendly, decor was nice, seating comfy, restroom nice. I have heard that the burger is really good. We also had the chartcuterie plate and that was good the cured duck prosciutto was super. I think the next time I go back I'll order something else - and try some more beer.
author: melissa h.

description: I went here for lunch on the weekend, which might be a good way to avoid a wait as there aren't a lot of tables so I can imagine it would be crowded for dinner.  An impressive selection of beers on tap and an even more amazing selection of ones in bottles.  Food was really good, if a bit pricey.  The pretzel was excellent as were the dips for it.  The Ahi tuna sandwich was also very good, although the Pulled Pork was just decent.  Still, I will probably go here again if I am in the Mission at noon on a Saturday.
author: Alured P.
