description: A freind peeked my curiosity about this place because she told me about a Watermelon bear they had that was super tasty.  I was disappointed that they stopped carrying the beer and was unable to try it, but was pleasantly surprised by the level of service.  The bartender/ waiter was super knowledgeable about beer (since I know squat) and he allowed me and my friend to sample different brews.  They have a great variety of Delicious beer to choose from.  The fries I ordered were served with three sauces (mayonnaise, ketchup, and mustard)  all sounding very unoriginal, but were actually uniquely tasty despite their looks.  Anyways, the staff was friendly and the place is CLEAN!
author: Connie C.

description: A classy relative to the all the bars in the area establishment more suited for eating than drinking with your fellow man or woman.  The food is good and flavorful.  They have a great selection of beer.  The restrooms are very clean.  I shared the cheese plate and salad and was quiet happy with the flavors.  Pick your poison (alcohol & food) and you'll die and go to heaven.
author: Po L.

description: Incredible gastropub. If you like beer, you are doing yourself a disservice if you don't visit. Fantastic beer, great food. Knowledgeable staff
author: Jon N.

description: I've already hit up this place twice. As far as beer there is too much to choose from, and I still can't find one I like. I didn't like the cheapest beer on the menu, which is what I got. I usually go for belgian ale anyways. As far as the food, I would recommend getting a pretzel for the beer, and the baby back ribs for the grub. The only bad thing about this bar, is the wait to get a table. Otherwise the staff is friendly and the ambience is fitting.
author: Dave Y.

description: Tried to take my boyfriend here last night for dinner since he LOVES beer, but never got a table. Much like other reviews I had a problem with the door guy. After telling us it was an hour and a half wait I tried looking around at the bar top for some seats and there were clearly some people getting ready to leave. After telling him we would try and sit at the bar he informed me there was some imaginary wait list for the bar?! That is one of the lamest things i've heard. How can there be a wait list for the bar? This guy was so annoying and never took our name, which left the groups of people who came in after us ahead of us on the list. So we left annoyed and hungry. I really do want to actually eat and drink here some day but probably will never go back cause their system is so lame.
author: Shayna G.

description: Good beer. Weak food (at least mine). Had Downtown on tap. Very tastey. Pulled pork sandwich w/ fries. Not sure if there was any pork in the sandwich. Tasted the bbq sauce and the bun but not much else. The burger - which I didn't get - looked good. Next time. Very nice staff. 5 beers, my meal, and a salad came to $112 w/ tax + tip. Too pricey for what was delivered.
author: Will S.

description:
Being a beer lover, this place is right up my alley. They have a diverse, ever-changing selection from around the world, and around the corner. Beers are served in genre specific glass wear, so the amount of the pour will vary, as will the shape of the glass. Check the list for how many ounces you get for the price, and beware, those smaller cheaper choices add up quick. The bartenders are always cool about giving a sample from the taps, if your not sure about committing to a glass. They seem to be more about presenting you with a beer experience, than just pouring you a pint. I've had some great food there as well. I highly recommend their cheese plate, which is well portioned, and includes some other yummy nibbles to pair with your choices. They also make a great burger, and have other tasty seasonal food offerings. If you are a dark beer lover, you must try the nitrogen charged, Fuller London Porter, pure heaven.
If it's just a great beer selection and prices you want, go to Toronado. Monk's Kettle steps it up with great food, nice, clean atmosphere, and friendly, helpful staff.
author: Nicole K.

description: The beer selection is obviously the draw but I gotta say the food really stood on it's own.  The pork chop was fat, nicely grilled, and tasty.  It came with some brilliant brussels sprouts and an awesome little potato-cheddar pancake.  Plus a little dash of sauce to tie it all together.  Only problem was that things were over-salted - my friends fries suffered similarly - and the service was a bit behind (probably due to the ridiculous crowd).  Still, the waitress took the time to warm up the bottom of our bottle-fermented Fransiskaner Dunkel, a move that really blew the two of us away.
author: Mike G.

description: I agree with Boyd...the beer is strong and the pulled pork sandwich does need a better roll, but otherwise the food was really good and I LOVED trying beers I've never heard of. The service was excellent from both the bartender and the waitress. The ambiance is nice...perfect for a date or a night out with friends.
author: Tina S.

description: What an awesome beer list!  Drinks are 5-star, Food and service are 4-star and crazy-loud-acoustics is 3-star.
author: J P.

description: Expansive selection of beers - I LOVE Belgian ales!
author: D L.

description:
Great food. The duck pate bruschetta was fantastic.

The bartender showed no annoyance as I explored the beer selection by continuing to ask for new recommendation with each visit to the bar.  She even offered samples to help choose.

It's small and crowded, but you can't blame them for that. The chalkboards by the rear bar seats provide some good side entertainment.
author: David A.

description: this is now my second favorite sunday afternoon lunch spot.  i won't tell you my #1 favorite spot.  it's a secret.
author: Mary C.

description: The place was small. My friend and I went on a monday night around 7pm and the place was packed. The server who greeted us added our names to the waitlist and asked if we wanted to start with beer while we waited. He then handed over the LONG beer list.  Mostly Belgium beers but also beer from around the world and beers brewed locally.  Beers ranged in price from the cheap (~$5) to the expensive (~$40s).  We were overwhelmed by the list and had asked the server for recommendations.  He was very knowledgable and recommended two economically priced beer; a Pilsner for me and a Hefeweizen for my friend. We didn't have to wait long before we were led to our seats.  I ordered the Lamburger (medium rare as recommended by our server) and it was delicious (juicy and very flavorful). The lamburger and the perfectly fried thin-cut fries paired with the recommended glass of brew was wonderful.
author: Justin Y.

description: What a diamond in the rough!!! Located in the mission district surrounded by a bunch of dive bars and taquerias and it is so awesome! Yes, there is construction going on outside but don't shy away! This place has one of the best selections of beers in the city. 8 pages of all kinds of beers to satisfy everyone's desires! It was jam packed on a wednesday night around 10pm.  There is dim lighting and not very much seating. If you come at the wrong time, you may have to wait in the street for a table or bar seating to open up. If you do come here, sit at the bar. There is a fun chalkboard set up as a wall in front of the bar area where you can doodle using multi-colored chalk while you sip on the best beers and taste amazing food!  Some people are amazing artists...I had to doodle around some of the artwork...there were faces, comic sayings, and even phone numbers LOL  If you find yourself needing a munchy but do not want a meal, I highly recommend their homemade giant pretzels with stone ground mustard and house made cheddar ale sauce. Delicious and satisfying and actually paired well with the Belgian Crisp Apple Cider beer. This beer was sweet, lush, crisp, and tasted like champagne. Overall it was $46 for the pretzel and 5 beers among our group. It could be seen as pricey but I think it was well worth it to try such a selection of amazing brews! I will return again and again!
author: Lauren S.

description: Wow I can't believe I haven't reviewed this place yet.  I've been here MANY times since it opened.  They have an amazing beer selection and their food is really great as well.  I have 2 slight complaints about the place through.  The first is that it's really small so if you don't get a seat at the bar or a table, you're standing in the aisle and it's really uncomfortable.  That is usually why I frequent it on the week days.  I also have been there recently and there was a totally snooty lady that was working at the bar.  I was there with 2 girls from out of town and some dude was hitting on one of them.  She kept motioning to us that he was drunk and to ignore him.  How did she know that my friend didn't like the dude?  It's just real disappointing because the other guy, who I think is the manager, is really nice and I've seen her there a few times as well and her attitude belongs in the marina, if you know what I mean.
author: Mitch A.

description: Stopped by one afternoon while in SF to sample some of their expansive beer offerings. Enjoyed every minute of the experience -- nice ambiance (for a beer bar in the afternoon), great selection, and friendly waitstaff. I desperately wanted to go back later in our trip to try the food (the menu looked incredible -- especially  the lamb burger), but alas, as all vacations tend to do, we ran out of time.
author: Mari-Beth G.

description:
Here's the thing: I love pot pies. Love 'em. So anywhere that has 'em on the menu, I'm partial to. But then here comes this place which has different pot pies daily. It's a wet dream. Very very wet. So I've tried a few different pot pies there and the first one was super good. But I noticed with the next few that the only thing that changes is the type of animal they put in--beef, shrimp, scallop, lobster. It's good, but gets boring fast. 

It's a little pricey too, but if you love pot pies it's worth it. The big problem is that the service sucks. I mean really sucks. The waiter's just walking around looking at stuff, forgetting what you ordered, telling you the wrong pot pie of the day, taking forever to get you an orange juice when there's only two other tables in the place. You see what I mean.
author: jackie t.

description: Nice atmosphere, concise menu, delicious beers and extraordinarily comforting mead!
author: Heirloom Z.

description:
Normally, good food, good service, nice crowd, awesome beer-- but, worth the wait?  Not really.  If you're in the Mission, it's a solid option, but I wouldn't come specifically for it. 

Also, here's a question:  If a peach & arugula salad has no peach, is it still a peach & arugula salad?
author: F N.

description: Good choice of wines - love the Sauvignon Blanc.! Also, good spinach salad.  I was craving one that day and it really hit the spot!
author: V B.

description: Amazing beers on tap, and the food is very good (although not super original--mostly high end pub food). I was able to get a spot at the bar, and had three excellent beers (Damnation on tap, fin du monde, nice little trippel that escapes me). It is busy, packed, and a popular.
author: dave s.

description:
Yum! Visited Monk's Kettle last night for the first time (and not my last) and enjoyed a thoroughly tasty meal and several beer pairings. 

Let's start with the food: had the flank steak and chips which was perfectly prepared and cooked. This typically bland cut of meat was delicious and succulent - fully of meaty good flavors. The chips were awesome and seasoned oh so nicely. I wolfed it down much to the detriment of the conversation at the table (sorry dear and understanding husband for my silence). For desert, the cherry cobbler. To be honest, this wasn't a real cobbler but it was still very nice. Tart wild cherries under a layer of puff pastry and vanilla ice cream. The portion was so huge, I felt like I ate for an hour and hardly made a dent. I would definitely recommend splitting deserts whenever possible.

And now the beer: other posters have commented on the extensive nature and of the list which covers so many palettes and tastes. I had the Maudite with my steak and the Rodenbach Grand Cru with the dessert. Both came recommended by our knowledgeable and enthusiastic wait staff including a little disclaimer that the Rodenbach isn't for everyone. 

I would have to really dig deeply to find critical comments for the Monk's Kettle and be knit-picky simply for the sake of knit-picking. Overall, I was very impressed and can't wait for another tasty beer and meal there.
author: Kristin N.

description: i love beer & more beer....had the stout stuff & the strongest beer they had on the menu (which was recommend by the cute bartender).....i dig places like this cuz theres so many damn options to choose from which will make me come back for more...kudos for the flat screen playin the giants game....i was about to take one star off due to the bouncer @ the door....yeah a bouncer who said last nite it was too packed & might be a fire hazard if they let more peeps in....
author: elmer d.

description: I EFFIN HEART BEER THEREFORE I EFFIN LOVE MONKS KETTLE!!! Went there few days ago for the boyfriends birthday and had a Doublebach Double vision......O....ma......gud. I usually don't like stouts and porters but this was soooooo good. Pursuit of Hoppiness is reallllly good too. I know they rotate their taps so get hurry hurry! Minus one star for the triple attempts at gratuity. This place charged us gratuity AFTER tax rather than before it AND they attempted to add another gratuity charge when i paid my half with a card. Not too many hipsters here since they all dwell next door at delerium. Plus 1 more star :)
author: Too F.

description: Loved it. Great food, nice service. Insane beer selection. A little on the tiny side. We came in at 4:45pm and they were already full. That's a good sign right off. I'll definitely be back!
author: Stacey O.

description:
I'd been curious about this place ever since I stopped in one night to mellow out from a friend who was misbehavin' with a married dude across the street at Double Dutch. Why we were at a place like Double Dutch and why the friend was making out with a married guy are all stories for another time and place . . . At any rate, as I, along with another friend, walked down the street looking for a cup of coffee, TMK's warm wooden interior seemed inviting.  And, that's exactly what the place turned out to be.  Despite the fact that they were about to close and despite the fact that we wanted nothing more than coffee, the wait staff kindly obliged us.  So I vowed to go back.

And last night I did.  While the place was packed, everything else was perfect.  The service was excellent and friendly.  I found the beer list to be fascinating and the food was yummy.  My friend and I split the ahi tuna sandwich and a salad.  For $14, the sandwich seemed like a steal -- a generous portion of sushi grade tuna, lightly seared and coated with flavorful sesame seeds and an aoli sauce.  The fries accompanying the dish were perfect, arriving hot, fresh, and clean (meaning they used a good, clean oil to cook the fries).  And while I didn't drink (I was the designated driver), my friend thoroughly enjoyed the beer.  With an alcohol content of about 8.5%, it certainly got him buzzed and content in no time . . . 

Last night I stopped by b/c I just happened to be in the city.  The next time I go to the city, it'll be to eat at the Monk's Kettle again.
author: East W.

description: We were visiting San Francisco and wanted to hit up a bar with a decent beer selection.  The selection here did not disappoint.  However, $8.75 for an 8 oz pour of St. Bernardus???  Over $9 for a 10 oz pour of Piraat???  Great beers with a high alcohol content (hence the small pour I guess), but a bit extreme in my opinion.  The pricing here is just crazy.  I know SF is an expense city, but common.  You guys are getting screwed on this stuff.
author: Adrian R.

description:
I came here only for the beer.  They have a few different types on tap that seems to me were selected based on their distinguishable characteristics.   If they don't fancy your palette you can also try a few from their vast selection in bottles.

i am always up for trying out new beer so it was very nice to have a knowledgeable bartender with an inclination to give out samples.   I don't remember the dude's name and I bet I won't recognize him either so I can't give him props.  But I will sure go there again.
author: Dan I.

description:
Great service even on a busy Friday night
Excellent beer selection
Very good burger and fries
More places should have furniture in the bathroom
author: Kevin I.

description: did i not yelp this place yet?  i swear i did.  anyhoo, fantastic beer selection.  i just had an apricot ale from dogfish head?  freaking delicious.  their food is very straightforward, but really tasty.  had a super juicy lamb burger tonight...had the pulled pork sandwich another time.  its like a place for the evolved guy's guy.  burgers and beer...but not bud light and big macs.  good luck getting a table any night.
author: Robert S.

description: It is either a beer lovers paradise or an agoraphobes worst nightmare, actually it could be both. I went on a rainy and dreary Monday night, and it was still packed with a wait list (about 25 minutes) and the place was packed from when we got there till when we left. Their beer selection is impressive, it's 5 pages  and a little over priced, but the options are there. The thing that really got me was the service, or the lack there of. So after our waiter brought our dinner he said he would be right back with some ketchup/mustard, after all it is a sandwich/burger dominated menu, he wasn't. Not 1 minute later, not 3 minutes later, not 8 minutes later, however 12 minutes later I finally tracked him down and asked for our condiments and he brought them, but with no I'm sorry, no explanation to absolve him of offering the glorious grey poupon and then never bringing it. The food is okay nothing special and price is so so. The name Monks Kettle is cute and yes slightly yuppie which should have been my first clue. It was way to yuppie chic for my taste, I much prefer the better priced selection of beers at Toronado. All this from a rural fag who would probably go for a Yuengling if he could find it on the west coast.
author: Brian S.

description: We split the cheese plate and had scallop pot pie for the entree. It was very good. Nice staff, cool atmosphere and very good food. It has to to compete on this block.
author: Sturdy M.

description:
went on a weekday.  we did have to wait like 20.  but everyone was so nice.  we didnt really care.  

the vibe was great.  good music, nice booth, felt very comfortable.  we took a long time on the menu since we had to pick a beer and figure out how to get as much food as we wanted.  

i had a shrimp pot pie, cheese plate and a salad and shared.  the pot pie was amazing as was the cheese plate.  food was great.  not cheap but i was fine with it.

but...

the server was fantastic.  knew her shit.  let us take our time.  she was a sweetheart.  we were a table of 3 servers and we were all impressed and wish i could be as genuinely friendly and patient as she was.  

i'm not craving it, but i'm looking forward to going back.
author: suzanne e.

description:
I've been here once, their kitchen is open till 1am I think, which is great.  The food was a little pricey, but...any kitchen that is open late seems to have slightly higher prices.  Plus, its SF and not cheap indian or mexican, which is what's mostly available late in the mission.

The decor and menu are great.  I love how there are explanations for each kind of beer on the menu.

I went late on a sunday night with a couple of friends, and I was supremely exhausted.  The bartender noticed this and took me for a drunk and told the rest of the staff not to serve me alchohol.  That's a little harsh for not ever seeing me before and not interacting with me at all, but since I wasn't too thirsty it didn't really matter, and I'm sure that the late sunday night shift is going to be filled with more oddballs than a thurs-sat.  Then I looked at the prices of the beer and I really didn't want one.  I'm not a complete beer expert, but there is a wonderful Belgian beer bar near my place in oakland that I frequent and I recognized a lot of the beers on the monk's menu, and the price disparity was frightening.  Its not that there are beers over $10, its that there are plenty of them, and some over $20-30.  It just seems like price gouging to me.
author: Roland G.

description: Great place.  Food 'til 1:00am...that rules!  Great selection, but the mark-up on bottles almost kills me.  But not at 1:00am!
author: scott t.

description:
I stopped in last evening before dinner with a friend.  

While the beer was tasty, the bartender was a complete jerk.  We asked for his recommendations after mentioning a few beers I know and like, and he looked at me like I was asking for the blood of a sow.  I finally asked him to suggest a lager and he said "they're all lagers, which one do you want?"  (and of course they aren't all lagers).

Maybe he was having a bad night.  I'd go back, but we are blessed with so many great bars in this town that have friendly, informed staff that I'd rather spend my hard-earned $$$ elsewhere.

Beer: A
Service: D-
author: capt c.

description:
My girlfriend and I walked here on a whim around 6p or so on a weeknight. We didn't have to wait at all and actually got the 2 seater right by the window in front. We felt like we were in Europe, especially while eating the super yummy pretzel and fries (the feeling went more with the pretzel if ya know what I mean). The one bummer was the crackwhore giving a major stripshow right in front of the window...bummer because I saw a crackwhore almost completely naked, double bummer because she was completely oblivious of the sad show she was putting on.
Anyways, this place is really great for getting a beer and a bite to eat right after work.
author: CH H.

description: often crowded with a crazy long line, but the beer selection is ridiculously large, and the burgers are to die for. try the burger. just do it.
author: Joy X.

description: I love beer. Most of the time I want one I'd prefer not to have a host stop me at the door and act like I'm probably going to be a problem because I want a beer. Especially at a place that has its main focus on beer. While the selection is really nice, the beers at The Monk's Kettle are EXTREMELY overpriced. San Francisco has a few great places to drink really good beer, and this is the most ridiculously expensive one I've been to. They even charge out the ass for local beers. For those of us who buy bottles of artisan beers regularly it's a little insulting. This place is also usually uncomfortably packed. It's tiny. So if you have to stand and you block the path of the waiters, they are understandably annoyed. On the plus side the food here has been exceptional every time I've had it, and the service is as good as it could be given the parameters. If you want something delicious and don't mind waiting a while to get into a loud, crowded spot with overpriced beer, this could be your place. Nine times out of ten I'll keep walking and go to Frjtz (good food, a few belgian beers), Bender's (awesome food, decent beer selection), or Shotwell's (no food, outstanding beer selection). I've never been for lunch, maybe that's a better time to try.
author: Tyler H.

description:
There's a fine line between clever and stupid and there's a fine line between a good dining experience and a lame one.
If the hight pitched voiced hipster bartender had been on top of his shit instead of flirting ceaselessly with the girls with laughter that sounds like a chair being dragged across a slate floor it would have been all fine.
I had to wait for everything from the moment I sat down, recognition, a menu, to order and worst of all my food. Even the cook got impatient and had to ring the pick up bell several times to get homeboy to pay attention to his job and not the skinny blond. He did have beer knowledge so I'll give him props for that and not toss my feces at him, juts a banana!
The food was fine and now that I have fallen off the vegetarian wagon I can't get enough meats. I ordered a steak sandwich that was served with some fries; it was tasty but the fries were cold and thre was too much mayo on the roll.
author: Daisy S.

description: the beer menu, coupled with the mac'n cheese (w/bacon) or the burger is a must!  downside, its small and there is usually a wait.
author: Mauri L.

description: just ate here yesterday and it was pretty amazing. not only do they offer a five page long list of beers, but they actually serve food until 1. we had the mac and cheese which came in a cool small pan baked with bread crumbs on top. it was simple and to the point. yum. then i enjoyed the pork osso bucco which is on the special menu. the meat was tender and delicious and served with i'm not sure what, polenta risotto? i definitely like how they suggest a beer pairing with almost every meal. if they put the pork osso bucco on the mac and cheese, that would make a damn good meal!
author: Dennis L.

description: Great beer list and if you don't know what to get, the bartender makes great suggestions.  Just don't go on Friday or the weekends.  It's way too crowded.  It's best to enjoy this place when it's slightly on the empty side.  Also, gotta order the giant pretzel to go with your beer.
author: J.A. T.

description: Incredible gastropub with a great Belgian selection.  The wait on the weekends can be long, but it is well worth it.
author: David A.

description: While visiting from Atlanta, we had lunch here.  We had wanted to visit on a Friday night, but we were told that it was WAY too small for four people to get in (without waiting for a long time) during busy times.  After walking right by it a few times (the signage is not terribly obvious), we entered and were greeted by a warm atmosphere and a friendly bartender.  It IS really tiny, with a maximum occupancy of no more than 50 or so, but it was lunchtime on a weekday and we practically had the place to ourselves.  We started off by sharing a soft pretzel, served with house-made beer cheese sauce (drooooool) and stone ground mustard; it was a chewy, salty, perfect start to the afternoon.  Fiance opted for the grilled chicken sandwich with house-cured pepper bacon, herb aioli, and brie.  It was HUGE, but it was so tasty, it disappeared in no time flat.  I chose the lamb burger, which came with lettuce, tomatoes, red onions, and a cucumber tzatziki sauce.  YUM.  The meat must have had some cinammon in the seasoning mix, as it had a sweet-salty-spicy taste that really wowed me.  The fries that came with both sandwiches were excellent--crunchy, hot, tender, and well-salted.  We really enjoyed our experience, and we had a great time talking to the bartender about the various beer offerings.  No wonder this place gets so crowded on the weekends!
author: Betty R.

description: this place is tiny!  but well worth the cramped quarters!  Bartender was friendly and the beer selection was great.  Food was excellent and the decor is perfect.  Worn wood abounds!
author: Kerri G.

description: did not expect this place to have such an extensive food menu, very well executed from what i can tell. chicory beer was really outstanding. happy to find a down to earth, unpretentious spot in this area, will be back for sure
author: Miranda R.

description: the menu looks great, but they were out of giant home made pretzels, we'll be back to eat but our first venture was a beer only one, they have an impressive list of beers, in bottle and on tap, the selection is from all over, and the owner is knowledgeably and nice, the wait staff is friendly and quick, and also seems to know quite a bit about all the brews.
author: Jared Z.

description: Was completely surprised by this place. Had heard about the huge beer selection and headed there with a friend after work.  No problem getting a seat at the bar at 7pm. The beers lived up to the reputation -- huge selection of draught and bottled beers, with great choices for local brews and some seasonal selections. However, what took us by surprise was the food. I have devoured bread pudding in restaurants and homes for more than 20 years and this was truly the best bread pudding I have ever had. Everything else was also really well done -- pork tenderloin with bacon cream sauce (!), mac & cheese, salad. A tiny bit pricey, but they make no pretensions of serving cheap bar food, so it was worth the price (we got out of there stuffed to the gills and over the legal limit at $40 each including tip). The menu also has beer pairings, which I thought was a little OTT at first, but the Canadian beer we had with our pork tenderloin was indeed a great match. We left around 9p on a Tuesday and it was getting crowded, so I suspect that its insane during peak hours. But if you're looking for unique brews and surprisingly good food, go during off hours and enjoy without hesitation. We will be back Monks Kettle!
author: Arkay K.

description: price was def high.. but i didnt pay (thanks adolf). beers were good (the hef was deliciousness). but what was even better was the cidar brined pork chop w/ potato cake. i wish i paid attention and saw that it came with brussel sprouts... bc i would have subbed those s.o.bs. and the mac n cheese (with mothereffin bacon) was inspirational. pork is a problem solver! but not as much as red meat..
author: geoffrey l.

description: Wow, none of the reviews I read mentioned how tiny this place was!  I had pictured this place much larger in my head.  I don't know why...I've dined in hundreds of SF restaurants before.  Annnnyways, I loved it.  I'm not too knowledgable when it comes to beer so I asked the bartender what he'd recommend in the way of light beers.  He kindly brought out two samples for me to try in mini mugs, fun!  We then ordered the cheese plate, the goat cheese appetizer and the mac and cheese.  Yes, we were in the mood for cheese, okay?  Is that a problem???  Moving on, the cheese plate was fantastic and our waiter happily brought more toasts as we quickly ran out.  The goat cheese appetizer was really good but oh so filling!  When we finally got to the mac and cheese, I was so full, I could hardly breathe!  But I charged on, because well, it's mac and cheese.  And it was dang good!  The only thing I'd have to say is that it was quite peppery but that certainly didn't stop me.  I must say, prices were decent as well.  Some day we'll come back and maybe then, we'll get past the appetizers.  Until then, it shall remain on my fav list.
author: Kelly H.

description: Kick ass beer selection and good food. The beers are a bit pricey and you have to pay attention to what size the beer is, otherwise you might end up buying a 10 ounce beer for the price of a quality 6-pack. The mac and cheese is damn good.
author: clay b.

description: We wanted to love the Monk and we will give it another chance. We went for lunch and did not have to wait for a table. The bartender was our waitress and she was nice. I loved my beer and I loved the glass they served it in. The food was just ok. The pretzel was just that- a pretzel. The sauces sucked, the mustard came from a jar and was too cold, the cheese sauce had NO flavor. My pulled pork sandwich was very average and i saw the line cook heat it up in a small pot to order...hmm, why not keep it simmering or something? It had super hot and then cold spots inside and for $13 I expected more. The fries were average and they need kosher salt on the table. My partner had the veggie burger and he said it was OK. I will go back if its not busy and sit at the bar and drink that lovely Belgium beer I had but think I'll skip the food. Oh, its not cheap, lunch was $60!  3 beers, 1 pretzel and 2 sandwiches. At these prices the food should be solid.
author: James S.

description: If you ever need food that sticks to the ribs but not too too heavy with a cool and easy ambiance then this is the place.  Shimmy over to Double Dutch after for a nightcap.
author: S M.

description: this place is AWESOME! fyi, you can't get in unless your 21 because its not really a place to dine but i love their food anyways. my friend brought me here to try the mac n cheese because thats my guilty pleasure but sadly the chefs had changed and they took it of the menu.  service was great. i love that its casual and chill.
author: Josephine S.

description: I finally got to The Monk's Kettle the other night. I have to say it doesn't feel like the Mission at all. It has that pub vibe from the midwest - like I remember in Chicago. It is all warm lighting and comfort food, good beer and friendly people. The guy who took our order was friendly and patient. So the giant pretzel is super cool - 2 sauces, a creamy mustard type sauce and a stone ground mustard. Yum. We ordered a reasonable bottle of Pinot Noir eventually - local CA, tasted great. I got the Lobster Pot Pie - thumbs up - super rich with a velvety sauce. The blue cheese wedge salad was another success, great big chunks of blue cheese, perfect bacon pieces, cherry tomatoes. My friend ordered the chicken - with roasted potatoes, and garlicky green beans. Home run. Too full for dessert we stumbled out of the Monk's Kettle vowing to return for more great food and good times. If you know what's good for you.......
author: Tom R.

description: This is actually the only reason I will go to the mission. I dont care how that sounds I just dont see the attraction. Anyways, this place is great but Im not the only one that has this feeling so its super duper crowded starting right at 5. Well one day took a vaca day on a tuesday so this was the only time I could actually relax so I went here and just like sat from like 2-5 and had a great time since I wasnt getting squooshed. This is the place that got me into Belgian beers I just love thier selections. The food is really really tasty but its overpriced i mean come on....You can go to other places , get the same quality, and at lower prices... I have eaten like 4x here and I havnt tried anything other than that damn pork chop. It's braised in beer or something and super duper thick...They use the cuts that would allow one to stuff it. Because of this entre, I have started researching how to braise pork with beer bc I cant afford to spend $28 on a pork chop but its a damn good pork chop!!! Oh gosh, I always leave the potatoe/starch when i go out to eat in order to cut the carbs but here-well- that would be a sin not to medntion a waste. Its like au gratin or sumthin but they must use multiple artisan cheeses in thier recipe. You cant waste local artisan cheese..thats just un american..its quality scalloped pototaes for sure you cant help but eat it and  then the brussel sproats with truffle oil.  Im all about American food slow cooking and it seems thats what they do. It  does take a while to get the chop bu they warn you and im usually too busy getting sloshed anyways...Its just good but not that affordable. After a couple 9% beers you dont really think about what stuff is costing until you get a bill for like $85 for just your stuff including %18 tip..this is the cost for 3 imported beers $15 dollar a pop imported beers (why go ther if you arnt going Belgium)..and the $28 pork chop..I had to stop going here bc I was spending too much $. They have cheaper beers, but I want something special or else whats the point of going out. Also, I went to Whole Foods and saw that the same pork chop cut was sellin for about $12 a chop so I got to thinkin....yes they need to make a profit but i cook alot and its not hard to make so i had to slow down with this place...but yeah i would bring out of town guests here for sure. Gotta get there at like 4:30 if you want a table..firts come first serve and the bar is crowded. I sat there once and just drank and stared at the chic next to me's food. They usually have sports goin on the TV so its good for sitten and veggin out...Her food looked great...some delious looking fat steak. It was that think cut again...I will say they care about thier meats and i very much apprciate that. Im getting to be a meat and poultry snob these days.... They cooked it nice amd medium rare too. The problem is that its getting more crowded. Its startng to get to the point where you cant be like ...oh why dont i just take a stroll to Monk for a beer...bc its hard to get two seats together unless you get there at like 3pm. annoying. Also, the service is so so....The owner is cool and personable but his people....its like the bartender dude...I had a hard time getting served and getting a menu...he totally saw us... Mayby bc Im not a gay male but he acted like  we went gonna order anything..mayby cuz we are not a group he thinks he cant make $$ off of us.. I had to beg for a menu. He seemed surprised i was ordering food. I went here like a year ago and the staff was totally cool and they gave you tasting and education...Now they dont. Im actually npot as fond as i used to be but i get bored easily and now that i shop farmers market these days...I feel like I can replicate myself for 1/3 of the price.
author: First L.

description: go here on lunch (obviously because you can take long lunches and spend more than $30 on lunch everyday of the month and come back to work drunk) i like this place. it has lots of beers to drink. it has daily special pot pies. the staff is nice people to me.  basically if youre a cheap-ass, you need to reconsider your modus operandi and just go ahead and when you are about to spend $5 on something, instead spend $50, and do this 10 times in a row instead of once. that is a good way to sample all the delicious beers in a short period of time and eat pot pies all day long FTW.
author: christopher a.

description: Finally! 16th and Albion has a restaurant it can hang on to. The beer menu here is certainly impressive. Unfortunately I thought I was ordering a $4.50 glass of lambic, but it turned out that 4.5 was the alcohol percentage and not the price. Thus I got a rude awakening when my lambic cost more than my meal, a whopping 17 dollars. Not to mention my hamburger was extremely dry, so all in all, I wasn't  that stoked when we got the bill for 71 bucks (two beers, two hamburgers, and lambic, which apparently is worth it's weight in gold) Although the ambiance is quite pleasant and the friendly wait staff will bring you samples of beer they think you'll like, you better be prepared to spend a fair amount for what you get. Maybe just don't try to have a nice cheap date there on a Tuesday. You might end up chanting 'credit and forget it!' as you walk out the door as we were last night. 4 stars because I have a feeling I'll try it again and love it. It's all about ordering smart. (read: no lambic, hamburger medium rare)
author: Carly S.

description: great beer! huge selection and great service! it gets crowded, but the staff is super nice and the turn-around is decent. cozy and lively.
author: Totally A.

description: i can't believe the selection of beer at this place!!  the beer menu is about 10 pages long and nicely organized by categories:  draft, bottled, belgian, lambic, IPAs, etc, etc.  the staff is knowledgable and can suggest beers for you if you know what type you like.  they will also give you a taste, which comes in a mini-stein.  i told the bartender that i liked hooegarden, which they have bottled, but i wanted to try something similar on tap.  she gave me a taste of a white beer from maine, which was really good, so i got a glass of that.  for food, i got the salmon sandwich, which came w/ a side of fries.  for dessert, the four of us shared the choc hazelnut bread pudding, which was not overly sweet and came piping hot.  food was typical, but you really come for the beer, and my friends and i were not disappointed.
author: Helen T.

description: every time i come to the monk's kettle, it just gets better and better for me. this time i ventured away from the cheese platter (which is delicious here) and tried the mac & cheese. ummmm, HEAVEN. and we also tried the black bean cakes. phenomenal. seriously, they were perfect. you can't lose with a trip to monk's kettle. :)
author: Kim C.

description: this place is cool. the server was charming and funny. the beer selection was impressive. the chicken sammy and the bleu cheese salad wedge thing were delish. and that is all. thumbs up.
author: Rikki D.

description: there are days when a girl needs to shake off the old hat of wine whine bar with their plates of stale crackers and lo-fat hummus & throw her best heels up in the shoe rack, pull down the old jeans, slip on some tom tom shoes and head over to monk's kettle. nestled in a barstool at the good wood bar, she'll know she wants a glass of the moa, pushing away the extensive beer list to peer at the little paper menu beneath the warm glow of the bar lamps and decide to order the "Coleman Natural Hampshire" Beer Brined Pork Chop with cheddar scallion potato cake, caramelized brussell sprouts, maple cured bacon and stone ground mustard cream sauce." them's there good days.
author: diana m.

description: A great place to meet someone for a drink.  I loved the place . I'm not a beer person and this place has the best beers.  About 25 on draft and over a 100 bottle.  They let you sample them.
author: around town e.

description: Hands down worst bar tender in SF = Ashley.  Great food, great managers, Nat is especially caring about his craft.  However  all the positive attributes of Monk's ownership and menu pale when dealing with San Francisco's "worst bar tender".   Nate and the ownership of Monk's Kettle would be well served by firing  Ashley (or disciplining if it is truly that  hard to find a replacement). Her lack of civility ruins the best beer cuisine SF has to offer.  A true disappointment to an otherwise perfect Mission location.
author: Josh H.

description: i liked this place quite a bit.  this was my first "gastropub" experience, which i guess is like an upscale version of the ubiquitous microbrewery or something.  anyhoo, we got there at about 7ish on a sunday and were seated immediately even thought it looked very busy.  they have five pages of beer!  they also recommend beer pairings for most of their dishes.  we had the cheese plate which was fantastic.  there was honey, candied walnuts, balsamic reduction, pears, some jelly stuff, bread, and bleu cheese as well as some spanish cheese with sheep, goat and cow milk.  everything went well together no matter what combination you threw together.  for my entree i had the pork chop.  it was well cooked and had some green, cream based sauce that i think was made with cilantro.  it came with carmalized brussels sprouts with bacon bits on it as well as a cheesy potato cake thing (the best thing on the plate)!  there was a lot going on on the plate but everything paired well.  for my beer, i had the watermelon hefewiezen which went well with both the appatizer and the main course.  the prices are a little steep (this includes the beer) so i dont think i can come here very often, but i still recommend to anyone wanting good food and beer at the same time.
author: Christian C.

description: The beer  (pints of Pauwel Kwak) was delicious and the chalkboard in front of the back barstools is a stroke of genius but the female bartender last night was horribly rude.  She yelled at us across the entire restaurant as we left asking if we were dining and dashing.  This was after she had closed out our tab and returned our card to us.  It was a busy night and I could understand if she was confused but she handled it in a manner that was rude and uncalled for.  All of the male staff were polite and charming so she is clearly the exception.
author: jessica p.

description: i've always loved this place and last night finally went to one of the beer dinners.  all i can say is - wow!  everything was top notch:  the food, the pairings, the portions, the service... EVERYTHING.
author: Jen H.

description: Really great food (high-end, high quality pub fare). Friendly and knowledgeable service. Great ambiance. The place is tiny and always seems to have a wait, but it's worth it if you have time. The noise volume can get quite loud in the evening. Parking is the typical nightmare in this neighborhood in the evenings. The beer selection is global and unrivaled and can be pricey depending on what you choose. Overall value is good for what it is.
author: Joe C.

description: Yelp folks- if you are reading this: can we please have the option of adding a half star?  I find that many establishments are deserving of 2 and a half or 3 and a half stars.  So, Monk's Kettle is pretty fine.  Well, the pretzels are huge and amazing, the fries are a decently sized portion, and if you like beer than you are in luck- there is a long list of unusual beer (and wine) options...stouts, lagers, porters, fruit infused stuff, etc.  I guess the reason for the two stars missing is because it's not the most comfortable atmosphere- it's a bit formal and stuffy for the area...and I ALWAYS get a horrible food hangover that begins about an hour into the meal and lasts for the rest of the night.  Don't get me wrong- the pretzels are delicious and worth trying, but the combination of heavy bavarian-ish food with gourmet beer is a little unsettling...would be cool to have hard alcohol, but I understand that Monk's is really a beer gourmet's bar.
author: Liza W.

description: I went here last night, and really wasn't impressed. The beer is expensive and the staff was extremely inattentive. I could deal with the expense if the staff didn't suck.
author: Photo D.

description: I posted a review of this place earlier ( which I could not find hmmm.) I even emailed the owner of my extreme displeasure. He quickly responded to my complaint and even mailed me a gift certificate. I went back and ordered the same thing I always order ( a lamb burger and an Aventinus)  Only this time waiter/bartender was wonderful. The place has WONDERFUL food and the beer selection is second to none. I am glad that my previous experience was just a one time bad deal ( maybe the bartender was just having a bad day) So if you have friends in town get there early and enjoy!
author: Alan C.

description: I have been to Monk's Kettle several times since the opening and thoroughly enjoyed it.  The food is always solid, service is friendly.  I feel that it's definately unique considering all the mediocre restaurants and pubs in SF.  However, my last experience was disheartening.  Our server, Jake, was terrible.   But, the busser was wonderful, friendly, and should have been our server.  The host was great as well. He treated us with the worst attitude, as if minutes before, we had insulted him on the street, and then expected nice service.  He was pissed that we didn't decide on our drinks and then when we asked for water, he acted as if we were asking for something free.  When we did decide what to drink, he delayed returning to our table, and he also did when we ordered food.  Finally, when the food came, he threw a spoon on the table for soup that my girlfriend ordered after already giving her one.   This was the point where I felt insulted, especially since our previous experiences had been wonderful.  So, the food was great, as always, and the service was epicly awful.  We'll probably go back because we love the food, but don't ask for Jake.
author: Zach H.

description: Fantastic beer selection.  The food is ok but a bit over priced for the quality/quantity. Someone else said "split review" I agree. I would definitely go back for the bar but thats about it. This place does have potential though.
author: Aaron A.

description:
hmmm...two stars for having a great beer list.

one bonus star for bringing this beer to the land of pbr.

minus one star for friendly but inattentive service even when the place was slow.

minus one star for drastically inflating the beer prices.

if i end up thirsty in the neighborhood again i will settle for a pbr and head down the street.

if i am in the mood for a great beer or three, i will go where the selection is better, the faces are friendlier and the employees know what they are there for...if you don't know about Dave's place, you probably don't deserve to
author: RahBurt B.

description: I ordered a 14 oz pilsner draft and paid $6.75 for it.  Bad deal.  I ordered a veggie burger and substituted a salad for the fries and was charged a $2.50 "up charge" for the salad (ludricous). I'm not positive on the next statement, but I believe the patty of the veggie burger was deep fried.  If not, it some how was crispy and greasy, which is not good (greasy) if one is ordering a veggie burger. Oh, and I added cheddar cheese which brought the total for the veggie burger w/cheese and "up charged" salad to $15.  Yikes!  I also ordered a glass of french chardonnay (the only chardonnay by the glass) for $8, maybe $8.50, which was such a small pour, that there were most likely six more "small/short pours" left in the bottle.  Overall, it was a bad deal or maybe you gathered my opinion already? Oh,  I forgot to add that the chardonnay was not very tasty :-)
author: louis l.

description: A bit crowded and 'hot new place' for me but good beer selection.   And a good burger (although my dinner mates lamb burger had too many surpising, risky spices to be enjoyable - it was more of an experiment).   Should be better when the hype dies down and ther's a next new place.
author: oyefunke a.

description: This bar is everything you want in a Mission bar. Good, inexpensive food. Delicious beers, a pleasant, modern atmosphere, and a friendly staff. The unisex bathroom is such a refreshing change from the other dirty, stinky, paperless restrooms that The Monk's Kettle shares 16th Street with. It feels like you are in your rich uncle's bathroom with the wood accents, curtains, furniture, and lavender candle buring on the walnut armoire in the corner. The kitchen is separated by large chalkboards with chalk so that you can sit, sip a beer, and draw. Or you can sign your name while waiting to go pee. Enough about the asthetics. Good bar food. This place looks like you would spend $12 on a mustard pretzel but it's about $6! All of the menu items are very reasonable and from the few I've sampled, delicious. There is something for everybody, from a juicy cheeseburger to vegan chili. This is a definite must if you are in the Mission and in the mood for yummy food and good beer....oh, and a nice bathroom.
author: Greggory O.

description:
i like monk's kettle. the fries are so good, i created a secret shrine to them in the back of my closet. sometimes i would wait until monk's closed up for the night so i could follow the fries home, and feel a little closer to them. but then the fries had get get all snobby and file a restraining order. so now i just hang out and drink the delicious beers, but im secretly just eyeing the fries. but dont tell the beers, i dont want to mess up a good thing. 
and i dont mind that i have to stand sometimes when im at monks....anything to be close to the fries. did i mention how good they are? thats why its so busy!
 with delicious food and amazing beer ( although i will note that the beer selection is lacking when i feel like a refreshing Chelada or Miller Chill) of course the place is going to be packed! And i truly admire the waitstaff, because im sure night after night of screaming "excuse me! pardon me! right behind you sir!" must put quite a strain on ones vocal chords. yet they are still friendly and willing to chat with me casually about what beer will pair well with my giant pretzel and fries.
author: stephanie z.

description: Really good place to relax with a glass of wine or a pint of beer.  They have a good selection of wines and beers (more beers than wine). Good amount of food selections (not your typical bar menu).  There are some traditional bar food such as burgers and fries. However, the quality of food exceeds any ordinary bar food.  Food is very fresh and well prepared. Really good for late night eating.
author: Vivian T.

description: Yes I am bias. I love this restaurant. Christian, Nat, keep up the good work. Best burger in town, and the Pabst blue ribbon comes with a paper bag. God I love this place.
author: Derek d.

description: A friend introduced me to Monk's Kettle in December and I've been a fan since. All of the waiters are really knowledgable about beer (which, sad to say, I know little about) and make excellent recommendations if you, like myself, don't know what you're doing. The Boyfriend, an avid beer-fan, loves this place as well. It's very small and easy to miss and there's always a line but you can put your name down, leave your number and they'll call you when they're ready to seat you. The place is always crowded but I think that adds to the fun atmosphere. I know some people have complained that it's too "smooshy" in there, but real estate in SF is hard to come by. Suck it up and get ready to get cozy with your neighbors. I really like the burgers but they're very large - don't eat too much before going to Monk's. For appetizers, I would recommend the mac-n-cheese with bacon which was apparently delicious (I didn't have any - it's a long story as to why not) or the pretzel (served warm and soft). Their specials change and I don't know if they repeat but the lobster pot pie was fabulous - puffy pastry with deliciousness inside.
author: Christine P.

description: good beer selection.  looked they have good menu options although i didn't try. con - they didn't teach me how to dougie
author: Jo W.

description: it's actually really great here. they have an incredible selection of beer: on tap, imported bottles, domestic cans, you name it: they've got it. their beer menu is organized well too; each beer has a colorful description that makes it sound T as in tasty. what food i've had, is yum. their menu entices.
author: julia r.

description: I went here last week and it was pretty good. The ambiance is pretty cool with dark wood and little candles everywhere. I like the glow that it gave the place. We weren't really in the mood for beer (which we didn't know it was mainly a beer place, or we would have waited till we were in the mood since they have HUNDREDS of selections.) I ordered the pulled pork sandwich with fries, curry aioli and a slaw, my BF ordered the chicken pot pie. My sandwich was really good and I ate it all!!! The pot pie was very creamy and also delicious, but the helping was rather small, he ended up eating anything left on my plate. =P It was a good time, other then the 45 minute wait in the cold (the place is small, so there was no waiting area, but we gave the hostess our number and he called us when our table was ready.) I'm sure the beer is great and they may get more stars once I've actually tried any of them. Other then that, I probably wouldn't go OUT of my way to go there, maybe if I'm in the area though. *shrug* Not too shabby though.
author: danae k.

description: a great new addition to the mission. beer snobs finally have a place to congregate (well, if they weren't satisfied with gestalt right down the street). great natural meats and casual dinners paired with gourmet beers from around the world. it gets busy here though, watch out for that.
author: Marla W.

description: Fantastic belgian beers, and more beer types overall than I'd ever heard of (saisons and Flanders Reds).  Staff was knowledgeable and attentive and offered great recommendations based on beers we already knew and loved.  They were packed on a Saturday night, but every drink and food order was served quickly.  We ignored the threesome that grumbled over waiting for a table after the waitress kindly offered them a 2-top with extra bench space when they first arrived (these beggars clearly wanted to be choosers).  I loved it, and look forward to returning.  Oh, and the food was delicious, but felt like an afterthought.
author: Jen H.

description: Excellent beers, very knowledgeable bartenders. Food - all right - not great but not bad. Good place to hang out with good friends for the entire evening.
author: Priya K.

description: came here for the second time a couple of weeks ago with a buddy. ordered some wine (it was good - but i forget the name). we also ordered the special - mac & cheese w/ lobster bits in it. really it was just a chuck of lobster meet in the center. sure it was good, but it was $22. i need to come back again. it's a cool little place.
author: James J.

description: The fries and giant pretzel were delicious!  They also have one of the best selections of beers I have seen anywhere.  The atmosphere is cozy and chill - very appropriate for a place like this.
author: Saikat C.

description: this place has a great beer selection, and decent food. the servers are very knowledgable and friendly. the drawbacks are that food is very overpriced, even by gastropub standards. the last two times i tried to go the hostess was very rude, and i decided not to wait.
author: steven w.

description: Fantastic beer selection.  Service could be a lot better.  I was significantly over-charged and their method regarding last call is to yell repeatedly "the bar is closing in __ minutes. We will take your drinks away from you if you don't finish them."  The last call method is a pretty tacky blemish on what could be a classy establishment.
author: pauline e.

description: two thumbs up for monk's kettle, and i don't even drink beer.  we came in for a couple drinks on saturday before going to a late dinner and really liked the place.  although their extensive beer list is very impressive, they also have a nice - yet more limited - selection of wine (including a few from kermit lynch - can't go wrong there).  the crowd was a fun mix of people of all ages, and the bartenders were friendly and knowledgable.  the bar itself is quite impressive as well.  we did not get any food, but what we saw of it looked tasty.  we'll definitely be back!
author: Erin C.

description: I love this place.  My friend and I ate there last Sunday night and had terrific pulled pork and steak sandwiches.  Their beer selection is excellent and perfectly served.  It was not overly crowded for us but I imagine it can get pretty crowded during peak periods.
author: J. O.

description: wonderful places for beer and food lovers of all stripes.
author: Malik C.

description: if this place wasn't so packed with bros i'd give it 5 stars. i really like the giant pretzel and the cheese sauce it comes with.
author: Renee L.

description: more like 3.5 stars.  i give 5 stars for the eclectic beer list.  the food itself was too salty and the steak was poor quality.  i ordered it to be cooked medium rare, but it came out bleeding and way too chewy.  it's a pretty noisy place.  the staff was nice.  stick with the beer.
author: Big e.

description:
great beer and food.  anyone who likes theses two things belongs here.  
beer pairings with the food, a great veggie and meat eater selections.  well worth the price, and a great well needed concept for the mission.
cant wait to go back to this future mission staple.
author: john m.

description: Mediocre, overpriced food. But the tap and bottle list is very, very good. Much better ambiance than Toronado. Great place to get a couple of quality beers with a friend who appreciates good ales (or lagers, for that matter).
author: Ben L.

description: We have been to the Monks Kettle several times for lunch and dinner.  Never a disappointing meal or beer.  I only wish they could do a beer flight as I would enjoy tasting a variety of the many tap beers they serve.  If you like good beer and good food this is definitely a must!!
author: t m.

description: Saw a blip about this place on-line and decided to give it a try last night. Definitely small and intimate. And a damn good thing we arrived around 7:15, because at 7:45 at least 10 people showed up simultaneously and stayed for the remainder of the night. Keep in mind this place only has about 5-6 booths and a bar that seats 10-15 max, so a good deal of patrons were standing. After 20 minutes of waiting a booth opened up for us. The bottled beer is a little expensive, especially if you're aiming for one of the lesser knowns from far away countries (or Santa Rosa apparently..), but most of the drafts ran $4-5. The food was pretty tasty though. I had the burger with white cheddar and sauteed onions, one friend had the BBQ Pork Sandwich, the other friend the steak sandwich. All three of us had no complaints. I guess after the add-ons on my burger, $13.50 is getting to the top of what I'd ever pay for a hamburger. It was juicy and definitely one of the better burgers I'd had. If you come here, I'd recommend coming early and expect to make it a semi leisurely event. Just pretend you're in a nice bar that serves good food.
author: Rory L.

description: Wow what a great spot! Really nice atmosphere, great food and wonderful beers...wonderful.  Our waiter was not only the nicest guy, but was also very knowledgeable about all the beers on their extensive menu. All the beers he recommended to us were spot on and paired with our meals perfectly. On top of all that, the music they were playing was great!
author: peter a.

description: place is tiny, but they let us eat at the bar which is nice. great beer selection too. fun atmosphere---good food. expect it to be crowded.
author: Matt K.

description: I was not impressed. The beer selection is good - no mistake about that. It is too crowded and we waited too long for mediocre, over priced food (this was Saturday night, though). There was no place to stand, and it was too loud to carry on a conversation. Not a bad experience, but there are much better places to eat, drink, and be merry.
author: Monica T.

description: Went here last night after desiring to go for quite a while. Glad to see that SF is sprouting more places that serve food past 10pm. I've been to NOPA and I've been to Beretta, so I had to try out this place. Showed up at 11pm after watching The Dark Knight at the Metreon. It took quite a while before we were noticed standing at the door. We were seated and the menus were dropped. I was very disappointed that they didn't offer the full menu - only apps and "in between breads." When I looked online I saw a menu with salad and entree options and those were what I was after. We almost left immediately after realizing we couldn't eat anything that wasn't a bread cheese bomb (and probably should have in retrospect), but we were hungry and so went through with it. The service was okay. Even though they were slow they could have used another hand on the floor (there was only one guy running the whole place). Once our orders were taken all arrived promptly enough. My girlfriend had the pulled pork on "focaccia" and I the chicken with bacon and brie. The onion slice on my sandwich was gigantic (like 1/3 an onion) so we took it off and used it as a saucer on which to place her nasty jicama slaw salad in a ramikin. The pulled pork was totally off. The chicken was alright, a little dry. No tastebuds bursting with joy and I felt a bit ill afterwards. I do see how people could be into this place - don't not try it just because I didn't like it.
author: pax r.

description: Last time I stopped by, they had only two Belgians on tap.  That's a big drop, and very disappointing.  Given that their markup is at least a dollar too much on every Belgain beer on the list (including bottles) TMK has clearly slipped behind The Trappist and La Trappe, in my view.  I guess they were having a hard time moving the Belgian stock at their prices, but a bunch of "Belgian influenced" American beers (and Unibroues) isn't the same as offering a real Belgian selection.
author: Dan G.

description: Do not even think about it on the weekend! Our party of 4 waited an hour and a half for a table on a friday night until we finally were so starved and sick of waiting that we aborted the mission and ordered at the bar.  Dinner involved yelling over the crowd and around a lamp at the bar. Food is nothin' special-mediocre and overpriced. On the up side, the bartender was sweet and helful in doing 'beer education' and to Monk's Kettle credit, they did take some drinks off our check for the fruitless wait for a table. In summary, check it out on the weekday or off hours and stick to the brewskies instead of food.
author: marie g.

description: ok, booze durnk yuppie bar and restraunt
author: Leigh McInnis Lee G.

description: Had our second visit today. Last visit- we split the charcuterie (sp?) and pulled pork sandwich after reading the reviews here, and i had an excellent london's porter on nitro. Pulled pork sandwich was meh- I don't understand the rave reviews here. The charcuterie plate rocked. Today, I had the nieman's ranch burger (med) with blue cheese- the burger was cooked med-rare and was wonderful, as were the fries. Husband had the steak sandwich, ordered med-rare which came out rare. Not quite as good. Chocolate lava cake for dessert- wonderful. I had the point reyes porter, husband had the arrogant b-. In all honesty, this place is about the beer, NOT the food (well, except for the fries and the chocolate lava cake, both of which are quite good). will we be back? maybe- the beers in our fridge (bought from bevmo) are a lot more varied and one helluva lot cheaper, and the food at home is WAY better. But the atmosphere is nice even though it requires one to wear thermal underwear because its so cold inside, and I can see us meeting friends for beer and fries.  And then going elsewhere for dinner.
author: R K.

description:
ok ok, where to start here... um, yes, beer! this place has one hell of a beer selection. quite a few esoteric beers from the vast lands of europa, epitomizing and characterizing this place. on with the good and other than:

#################################################
the good:
!! great beer selection from light ales, amber, porter, organic, weizen, barley wine, malts, you name it.
!! good food? YES, definitely a chip off the olde' palate, maybe two. i have not had everything on the menu, but everything i have had makes me yearn for seconds and thirds. i recommend the bruchetta and chicken pot pie! one thing to note is the servings will be medium to small sized, but the quality is definitely there.
!! open late? YES!!!!! this place is open til at least midnight, and its just what the doctor ordered when you are stumbling about the city trying not to go back to that late night quack ass eatery you only go to cuz its open late. this attribute by itself earns it 3 of the 4 stars awarded.
!! ambiance? Yes, but only one capital letter here because it is quite small inside. But, a semi romantic and happy vibe non-the-less.
!! decent staff. definitely not the best, but i'm a tad forgiving of a place this damn popular.

#######################################################
the other than:
!!!! AMAZINGLY CROWDED, almost all the time. if you would like some space and not to wait 1-2 hours for a mere 2 person seat, i recommend coming late night on a tuesday.
!!!! a "lemme see your id" doorman! what the wolfgang puck? i am led to believe this semantic is instilled due to the immense number of goons in the dicey area which is 16th and valencia. he also does serve to getting you on the xmas list to get in.
!!!! only fits around 25 people, so be prepared to rub shoulders with your new neighbors
!!!! is the beer expensive? HOLY MOLY YES, without a doubt. make sure you bring your trust fund check cuz you'll be breaking the piggy's back to indulge in the fermented party.
!!!! good idea to not have to park. best of luck trying to park in the hub of the mission.
!!!! you might notice the beer snob flashes from time to time, quite possibly from your waiting staff. it feels a bit weird, basically because it seems damn near everyone who comes in here would rather be drinking PBR, or they enjoy the novelty of a beer they know nothing about.
!!!! this is kinda a good and bad thing i guess, one of those double edged swords... they will let you tries shots of each beer, but it seems the staff hones in on people who they think have a lot of money, or are beer snobs. i say this because the crowds to both sides of my company gave these impressions and they got the royal treatment, while my skater-appearance'd group wasn't even given the inkling. :( oh, well, a skateboard can only take you so far in life... if in doubt, nicely ask for a bunch of different shots of free beer!


bottom line, the monk's kettle is worth checking out.
author: Dayman D.

description: beer selection is great and i would come back for the beers and chalkboard fun.... and probably the mac n cheese with bacon
author: Mike L.
